column2: WEST POINT, N.Y., April 17 -- An 11-gun salute and Major Gen. James B. Lampert, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, today welcomed Brig. Gen. Richard P. Scott as the new Commandant of Cadets.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Were the Republican party given to iambic pentameter, it would want these days only some lean and hungry Cassius to whisper to some unsettled Brutus:
Training will start this week for a score of lawyers who will take a "busman's holiday" this summer by volunteering to represent civil rights workers who run afoul of the law in Mississippi.
ORSON WELLES: a name to conjure with, Ceilings, Staircases, Angles, Shadows, Interrupted sentences, Resonant tones, Echoes, Egotism, Enormity. A talent 20 years ahead of its time.

Your April 11 editorial "Medical Research Controversy" in The Times refers to the Wooldridge report, which "indicates a preference for cutting down the amount of what it calls 'university-like research' conducted in the N.I.H. [National Institutes of Health] laboratories."

GUATEMALA CITY, April 17 -- A fund of $42 million for Central American development was set up this week by the board of governors of the Central American Bank of Economic Integration, meeting in Antigua, Guatemala.
Butch Zullo's two-run triple in the seventh inning sparked Fordham to a 4-1 triumph over New York University yesterday in a Metropolitan Conference game at Jack Coffey Field.
HONG KONG, April 17 -- Communist China has begun an offensive against "Western bourgeois music" -- a phrase that is applied to almost anything from Beethoven to the Beatles.

A SMALL city garden can be designed to be interesting 12 months of the year. The garden plan shown here is for a small city yard, 32 feet by 24 feet. It is adjacent to the living room and provides a wide flagstone terrace for sitting outdoors in good weather. There is also a work space for potting plants either for the garden or for taking indoors.

CARRIACOU, Grenadines, B.W.I. April 17 -- A yacht regatta, the first ever to be held in the Grenadine Islands in the eastern Caribbean, has been announced for the end of July. It is being sponsored by J. Linton Rigg.
THE job of replacing a defective or obsolete wall switch with a new, modern unit is a comparatively simple project which any reasonably careful home handyman can safely tackle.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., April 7 -- The Laboratory of Quantitative Biology here, described in a recent bulletin of the United States Information Agency as a "great American research center," is threatened with extinction.
Stuart Feick of the New York Polo Club scored seven goals last night to lead his team to an 11-7 victory over Westchester at the Squadron A armory.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 17 (AP) -- J. Graham Brown's Gallant Romeo led from wire to wire today in winning the $23,000 Ben Ali Handicap at Keeneland.
It seems difficult to understand why the quota for gift purchasing and personal shopping for tourists should be reduced from $100 to $50 to save the outflow of gold.
HARTFORD, April 17 -- Trouble is building up between the liberal-minded Republican state leadership and the conservative-oriented Connecticut Republican Citizens Committee.
Three more independent African nations will have new direct air links with the United States on May 16.
Pre-Columbian, African and Oceanic art and French 18th-century furniture and decorations will be auctioned in two sales this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street.
The summer training camp roster of the Chicago Bears, released recently, had on it the name of Louis Brian Piccolo, a rookie running back from Wake Forest, followed by the notation "free agent."

The Lehman collection of art will be opened to the public on two evenings, May 4 and 5, as a benefit for the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York. The collection is owned by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lehman and contained in their home at 7 West 54th Street.

LAST week's disclosure that Yale University had quietly picked up 70,000 shares of stock of the American Broadcasting Company and in a year's time realized a cool capital gain of $2 million gave a rather refreshing twist to the subject of education in television.
The over-the-counter market staged one of its best performances of the year last week active trading.
A few days ago, a New York savings-and-loan broker received a letter from a wealthy woman who winters in an expensive Palm Beach, Fla., hotel.

THE European shtetl is gone. We are not sure at what precise point the decline set in, or even if it was Hitler who sounded its knell. The shtetl was the Jewish community in Eastern Europe and it had a flavor all its own. In Itzik Manger's fine novel, "The Book of Paradise," the shtetl is Heaven, and Heaven is the shtetl.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. -- After the tornado or flood has passed come the saddest and most difficult of problems to solve.

" ENTER LAUGHING," the play by Joseph Stein based on Carl Reiner's funny, autobiographical novel of that title dealing with a young New Yorker's stumbling entry into the world of the theater, now is cause for additional rejoicing by the Messrs. Reiner and Stein and Morton Gottlieb, its producer.

SAMUEL FRENCH MORSE is full of mild surprises and subdued utterances. Blandness, easy observation, repetitive idea, a chiming of rhymes -- these are dangers which he gets through pretty well, though one must plow through a good deal of very conventional material in the first fifty pages of his book.

Outside New York City's Board of Education headquarters at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, two diametrically opposed camps picketed each other and the board last Wednesday. Members of the predominantly white Parents and Taxpayers Associations charged that the board's integration blueprint went too far.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17 -- Britain and the Soviet Union are sending their leading disarmament negotiators here for the session of the 114-nation Disarmament Commission that opens Wednesday.

FITTING tribute to a remarkable connoisseur, the late John S. Newberry, is paid at the Museum of Modern Art in a memorial exhibition of drawings he presented to it. This attractive and varied small anthology represents no more than a fraction of the Newberry collection, now largely elsewhere.

NAGOYA, Japan, April 1 -- Except for traffic on the left-hand side of the road, direction signs in ideographs and frequent glimpses of thatched cottages or ancient temples, an American driving over Japan's new Meishin Expressway might imagine himself on a parkway in southern New Jersey or upstate New York.
A note of thanks to the Johnson Administration will be played this Easter morning on the new organ at Concordia College, Milwaukee.

Like any unfolding drama, the annu al meeting season builds slowly to a climax. This week will be about Act II in the movement toward the climactic day -- April 27 -- the busiest day of the season when almost 100 big companies hold their annual meetings.

VIENNA, April 16 -- The dialogue that the Roman Catholic Church envisages with atheists will be mainly with Communists, if they can be persuaded to talk, it was indicated here by Franziskus Cardinal Konig, Archbishop of Vienna.

MONTREAL, April 17 -- The Montreal Canadiens, slick and smart, showed off to a Forum crowd of 14,737 tonight and scored a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks as the Stanley Cup championship playoffs opened.
Two men were found shot to death yesterday in a car in the Cypress Hills section of Brooklyn.
Pole vaulters competing in the annual Queens-Iona Relays at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday found themselves landing on air.

BONN, April 17 (Reuters) --Advice by West Germany's top etiquette committee not to shout "Heil!" during next month's visit by Queen Elizabeth II of Britain has mystified many Germans, who have not heard this Nazi greeting for years.

IN a mixed perennial border, succession of bloom is the goal, and this takes time to achieve. It is possible, however, to select plants that will bloom from April to October. Although most gardeners usually supplement perennials with a few spring or summer-blooming bulbs and one or two annuals to fill the inevitable bare spaces, a satisfactory border or garden can be made of nothing but perennials.

Some match-ups, like Sonny Liston vs. Floyd Patterson or Rome vs. Carthage, seem to produce remarkably consistent results, and one such match-up is Juan Marichal of the San Francisco Giants vs. the New York Mets.

The Appalachia program, despite the promises of its enthusiasts, is capable of having a detrimental effect on a part of the country which has always been outside the mainstream of urban American life. Recent articles, like that by Marjorie Hunter in The Times of March 29, overlook the damaging effects federally supported assistance programs can have in such a region.

FLOWERING quince is one of the first shrubs to bloom in spring. Bright flowers and clean, shiny foliage make this shrub outstanding at a time when there is considerable competition from other spring flowers.
LOS ALAMOS, N.M. -- Spring is being welcomed with special eagerness in this part of New Mexico because of a new kind of treasure hunt that can be pursued with improving weather.
The waterfront industry in the Port of New York may be moving into an era of labor stability and productivity without parallel in its history.
THE sunflower (Helianthus), cheerful and thoroughly American, could well be the national flower of the United States. It grows wild in every state from the Atlantic to the Pacific.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- Brown scored seven firsts in winning a triangular track meet today with 79 points on Franklin Field. Columbia finished second, with 66, and Pennsylvania third, with 47.
PITTSBURGH, April 17 (AP) -- Roberto Clemente singled home the winning run in the 10th inning, giving the Pittsburgh Pirates a 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros today.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 17 (UPI) -- Bill Hartack saved the speed of Cool Prince until the last today and the W.G. Helis Jr. colt turned the tables on Babington to win the $65,200 Pan American Turf Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

Hanson Baldwin in reviewing General Power's "Design for Survival" called attention to the fact that the General "takes as his text Luke XI:21-22: When a strong man armed keepeth his palace, his goods are in peace.'"

THE Voting Rights Bill of 1965, now before the Congress, has the intention of adding new voters to the registration books in many parts of the country and the odds are that it will have just this effect. Not a few observers are beginning to wonder what the consequences will be as one after another of the traditional requirements for voting are dropped.

The chairman of the Republican party needs a reference guide to keep track of the number of Republican organizations that have sprung up since the 1964 election. Listed below are some of these groups along with others that antedated the election:
The European Common Market's executive commission recommended last week that increased subsidies be paid to European shipbuilders to help them fight Japanese competition.

BOSTON -- The first major hotel to be built in this city in 38 years will be formally dedicated tomorrow and Tuesday. The hotel, the 29-story Sheraton-Boston, is the 100th unit in the international chain of hostelries operated by the Sheraton Corporation of America, and, fittingly, Boston is the home base of that organization.

SCRATCHES on dark colored furniture can often be easily concealed with simple household materials. On dark colored mahogany finishes, ordinary iodine will usually work well. For lighter mahogany, and for most maple furniture, dilute the iodine half and half with rubbing alcohol.
Three men were wounded last night in a gun battle on Fulton Street in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- The continuing growth of Florida's tourist volume, and of its tourist industry, is attested by figures compiled by the Florida Development Commission and the Hotel and Restaurant Commission.

THE address which President Johnson delivered on April 7 at Johns Hopkins University is important for two reasons. On the one hand, the President has shown for the first time a way out of the impasse in which we find ourselves in Vietnam.

TOKYO, April 17 -- Tokyo citizens, long Irritated at bureaucratic handling of the myriad problems of the world's largest city, were shocked today by the arrest of the Speaker of the Metropolitan Assembly on a charge of bribery.

LONDON, April 17 (Reuters) -- Manchester United turned in its finest performance of the season today in beating the league leaders, Leeds United, 1-0, before a capacity crowd of 52,000 in the big match of the day.

Easter got its name from the Teutonic goddess of spring, called Eastre in the old Anglo-Saxon; but the word itself reaches back to the Sanskrit, where it meant dawn and the east. So it has venerable origins, all of which were related to the renewal of life, to the rising sun, to a new day and a new year, to hope made manifest in everything around us.
HIGH WYCOMBE, England, April 17 (Reuters) -- About 2,000 British campaigners for nuclear disarmament left here today to the sound of guitars on a 45-mile protest march to London.

When the Hudson Manhattan Corporation holds its annual meeting April 21, one phase will have ended in the trial to determine compensation to be received from the forced sale of property to the Port of New York Authority.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 17 (UPI) -- Mike Belkin, who almost dropped out of the Masters invitation tennis tournament to play with the University of Miami team, upset Cliff Richey of Dallas in the semi-finals today, 6-1, 6-1, 6-3.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Last year, one of the drafters of the nation's antipoverty legislation observed:

" PEOPLE write about her as though she's a saint. She isn't." The mart who has known Marian Anderson for many years spoke affectionately and a little regretfully. An image-happy press has indeed done its share to perpetuate the symbol of remote perfection, a regal figure admired to the point of idolatry.

Phyllis Levin's article of Feb. 21 ("Breaking the News of Death") begins by referring to a recent paper of mine in which I had described the small child's ability to understand death. This was possible, I wrote, if death was realistically and feelingly explained to him by his parents in terms of the loss of life in people or animals to whom the child did not have a close emotional tie.
RYE, N.Y., April 17 -- This city's golfers teed off today on the 429-yard first hole of their own course, a "community country club" bought for them by the City Council.

Five full days a week, into the late evening, 24-year-old Lewis Littman is studying to be a rabbi. On weekends, the tall, thin student is "good listener, buddy, amateur psychologist and counselor," as well as a student rabbi.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 -- The varsity crew of Massachusetts Institute of Technology routed Columbia today over a mile and three-quarters on the Charles River. There were 22 seconds separating the heavyweight eights at the end of the race, which means a margin of five lengths.

BOSTON, April 17 -- A paperback profile of Vice President Humphrey, depicting him as "following in the footsteps of Adolph Hitler and Benito Mussolini," is scheduled to appear Monday across the nation.
The next time you drink liquor or beer, the chances are you are indirectly aiding a farmer or rancher.

YONKERS, April 17 -- Fly Fly Byrd, a 5-year-old driven by William Gilmour, virtually clinched a place in next Thursday's $50,000 Good Time Pace with an impressive triumph in tonight's $15,000 feature at Yonkers Raceway.

MOST Russian folk songs are recorded in customary large-choral fashion popular in Eastern Europe. But if that is not your samovar of tea in folk music, attention is directed to Yulya Sings Russian Folk Songs (Monitor 422, mono and stereo).
THE African Violet Society of Greater New York, Inc., will transform the Queens Botanical Garden at 43-50 Main Street, Flushing, into "A Garden of Violets" Saturday and Sunday.
RIVER VALE, N.J., April 17 -- Red Shoes -- with her owner Betsy Gerson, in the saddle -- won the open-jumper championship at the Holiday Farm horse show today in her first outing of the year.

AQUAINT Old World village with a famous clock atop a high tower, an inquisitive little girl and a scheming count's plan to capture the village are the well-blended ingredients in Jay Williams's new tale. Every hour for a hundred years the great clock has chimed on the hour and, even more marvelous, in times of danger a bell in the tower magically sounds the alarm.

IT is rather surprising that shrubs as choice as the cotoneasters are planted so infrequently in home landscapes. The genus Cotoneaster (pronounced kotone-e-aster) is a large one, comprising perhaps 50 species, many of great beauty.
TONAWANDA, N.Y. April 17 (AP) -- A 37-year-old mental patient home on a trial basis, apparently killed his wife and three children early today and then took his own life, the police said tonight.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., April 17 -- Following is the text of President Johnson's statement on Vietnam as read here today:
Miss Cronin's first goof was in referring to us as St. Croixers. As a Crucian, I simply don't know how to answer this one.
BUTLER, Md., April 17 (AP) -- Janon Fisher's Mountain Dew turned back two challenges today and won the 63d Grand National point-to-point steeplechase by 15 lengths over Scandanus.

IF Dorothy Collins' white hat on "The Bell Telephone Hour" is a little too white, which means that it could cause electronic refraction on her face, then Miss Collins's hat, in TV's expanding color vocabulary, is Noisy. And the white hat must be sprayed gray, because the color system that viewers will be learning more about next fall when the color campaign begins is keyed to flesh tones, not the feathers of NBC's proud peacock.
Eleven Americans who rose from humble beginnings to success will receive 1965 Horatio Alger Awards May 17 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., April 17 -- Red balloons dotted the skies here today in a colorful protest by homeowners who charged that they were being buzzed by low-flying planes.

THE most prestigious awards in the field of crime books are those of Mystery Writers of America, which will be made late this month, and those of the Crime Writers Association (London), which have already been announced.

ALL of the great Adamses were born more than a little bilious. They transmuted their choler, though, into courageous public policies that even today shine as triumphs for good sense. By modern standards the Adamses were totally lacking in political appeal, but in their own day they were at the center of events. Their candid pessimism about mankind seemed as convincing and as necessary as the come-out optimism that would overwhelm it.

An 80-year-old woman was killed and another woman injured yesterday afternoon when they were struck by an auto that mounted a curb at Seventh Avenue and 23d Street. The driver, a new Jersey student. was charged with vehicular homicide and drunken driving.

David Boroff's dandy piece on C.C.N.Y. ("A Kind of Proletarian Harvard," March 28) recalled the table-tennis games in the stuffy, congested cafeteria alcoves. He tells us that the action would start after the brown paper lunch bags had been cleared from the tables and someone would pull "a net out of his pocket."

BOSTON, April 17 (AP) -- Frank Malzone drove in four runs, including a deciding bases-loaded single off Steve Barber in the eighth inning, as the Boston Red Sox outlasted the Baltimore Orioles, 12-9, today in the Red Sox home opener.

Franklin Folsom of Roosevelt, N.J., a writer, got a friendly response from the Soviet Writers' Union last summer when he proposed a royalty system that would give American authors payments, divided between rubles and dollars, for their books published in the Soviet Union.

Flag Raiser flew into the lead as the field got away in the $92,650 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday, and stayed there all through the 1 1/8 miles of the race. By doing so, he brought off one of the bigger upsets of the current racing season.
MILWAUKEE, April 17 (UPI) -- George Altman sparked a 16-hit Chicago attack today as the Cubs defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 9-4.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 17 -- Army displayed power in running and Yale countered with strength in the field events today, but the cadets posted a 93-61 track victory in a dual meet.

TWO "old masters" among contemporary American composers are heard from on two Louisville Orchestra First Edition disks. Charles Ives, who died in 1954, is represented by his Variations on "America," and Wallingford Riegger, who died in 1961, by his Fourth Symphony.

THE New York Giants had gone sour during the 1949 season and they had just dropped the first game of a double-header with the Reds, a misdeed that didn't improve the disposition of Leo Durocher, the dandy little manager. Leo the Lion stormed into the clubhouse, eyes flashing in anger and his agile mind casting off sparks as it whirled wildly in search of a solution.
TOKYO -- More than 1,000 rehabilitation workers from 29 nations gathered here last week at the Third Pan Pacific Congress of the International Society for Rehabilitation of the Disabled.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution convene their 74th annual Continental Congress next week to elect new officers and to adopt resolutions.
RICHMONT, Va., April 17 -- In Virginia, traditionally devoted to history and shrines, Epping Forest, birthplace of the mother of the nation's first President, has been offered for sale.

Since midday radio and television announcers had reported a danger of tornadoes in various Midwest areas. Along Route 32. east of Shannondale. Ind., heavy rain had been falling on the fields of corn stubble, but the family of Wayne Rose felt snug in his spacious farmhouse.

EDMONTON, Alberta, April 14 -- The Edmonton City Council has authorized Mayor Vincent Dantzer to begin a project that many citizens consider undesirable and even ridiculous in a prairie city incorporated just 60 years ago.
CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Burglars looted the three-story home of Gerald Grant, a nationally known art authority, of $40,000 worth of antiques.

DAVE GARROWAY, the low-pressure master of ceremonies who deals in small humor, returns to television at 11:15 P.M. tomorrow as host of the American Broadcasting Company's "Nightlife" program. "Nightlife" is a major change for the man who spent 10 years as host of the National Broadcasting Company's "Today," which begins at 7 o'clock in the morning.

If weather reviews continue to be favorable, spring may be a hit in the Northeast after all. Local parks and gardens report increasing bloom; signs of the season can be seen along roads and parkways. Cornus mas and early rhododendrons and magnolias have center stage; daffodils, species tulips and early spring bulbs play supporting roles. Next week, the spotlight should shine on a much larger and more colorful cast of flowering plants.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- American shipyards are offering vessels at "bargain prices" -- some 15 to 20 per cent cheaper than they were eight years ago -- Edwin M. Hood, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, said this week.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 17 -- A bright, bouncy, semi-artificial racing strip has successfully undergone a winter of testing at Roosevelt Raceway and the all-weather surface will be put down on the main course for the fail meeting.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 17 -- Hofstra University will inaugurate Dr. Clifford L. Lord a week from Wednesday as the third president in tile university's 30-year history.

Bitter memories of the harsh rule of Japanese occupation authorities from 1910 to the end of World War II have led many South Koreans to oppose any effort to improve relations with Tokyo. Even though South Korea is Japan's closest neighbor, the two countries have no formal diplomatic ties.
Swim wear with the fishnet styling is a strong summer item, orders to resident buying offices indicate. Such models pace generally strong orders for swim and beach wear.
SELMA, Ala., April 17 (AP) -- A Selma group that did not sign an appeal for Alabama business leaders to offer equal job opportunities to Negroes and whites reversed its stand today.

An instrument designed to detect the measure the quantity of gold in objects passing through customs has been developed under an Atomic Energy Commission contract, according to Tracerlab, a division of the laboratory for Electronics, Inc.

THERE has got to be a better way of getting one's baggage back after a flight across the Atlantic, or any other ocean, than the archaic system the long-suffering tourist endures these days at Kennedy International Airport.
A bitter tug of war again is going on over whether to relax or strengthen restrictions on oil imports.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- It will take years before the wounds caused by the vicious Christmas week floods in Oregon are healed. However, operators of tourist facilities are working overtime to be ready for the spring crop of visitors, and reports indicate that there should be little or no inconvenience by the time early May rolls around.

NICE, France -- The 1,000-mile-long Amber Route, a series of trails blazed through western Germany and southeastern France some 5,000 years ago and later used by ancient Greek traders to transport amber to Rome, still provides a colorful and romantic passageway between northern and southern Europe.

V.S. PRITCHETT of London stopped over in New York in the summer of 1963 to renew a long acquaintance with the city and to look at some parts he had not seen before. The German photographer, Evelyn Hofer, was here at the same time working on the same project, a splendid book now published as "New York Proclaimed."

Maryland State, Villanova and St. John's swept the seven championship relays yesterday in the Queens-Iona Relays at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. This meet is the traditional opener of the Eastern outdoor track season. The chilly weather was traditional, too, and it may have been partly responsible for the generally slow performances. The winning times were considerably slower than last year's in each of the seven major relays mostly because the track was soft.
MADISON, Wis., April 17 -- Wisconsin discovered this week that it had millions of dollars ready to give away -- but no takers.

MOSCOW, April 17 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union contended today that one of its aircraft had set a new speed record of 1,441.583 miles an hour over a 1,000-kilometer (621.372-mile) closed circuit, carrying a payload of two tons.
ALBANY, April 17 -- Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki said today that he hoped to win passage of two separate legislative reapportionment proposals and let the Federal Court choose between them.
LONDON -- "Let's dine at an old country inn," I said to a visiting French gourmet. "West End London meals are the same is you get in Paris."

KANSAS CITY, April 17 -- The Kansas City Athletics entertained the New York Yankees tonight with "the only zoo in the major leagues," a German short-haired pointer that frolicked with the outfielders, a gigantic alarm clock to time the pitchers and a traveling mule.
American women are by no means alone in their quest for beauty. It is a global proposition and United States cosmetics manufacturers have found ripening markets abroad for their products.

I concur with your editorial of April 10 "Negotiating Monetary Reform" and join with you in urging Secretary of the Treasury Fowler to move ahead with negotiations for the reform of the international monetary system.
THE idea behind this fantasy is immediately engaging: suppose the Moon were inhabited and considered Earth to be a dead planet. What might happen when both civilizations meet?

MOSCOW, April 17 (AP) -- A revised opera by Dmitri Shostakovich, Russia's best-known composer, has opened in Leningrad and "made a great hit," Tass said tonight. The original was denounced under Stalin.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 17 -- A group of students scheduled to leave Ithaca for Washington were delayed for almost an hour last night as demonstrators sat in the street to prevent the departure of their buses.

The Yorkville Youth Council will benefit from the 41st annual production of the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta "The Yeomen of the Guard," to be given at the Hunter College Playhouse on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17 -- There is evidence that the "summit spirit" among Arab leaders is just about dead and that they are shifting from a preoccupation with the Jordan River and Israel to old quarrels among themselves.

LANDSCAPE architecture, as a profession, has just passed an important milestone. To honor its first 100 years, the American Society of Landscape Architects has designated the year 1964-65 as the Centennial Year of Landscape Architecture.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 17 (AP) -- The official entry list for the 49th Indianapolis 500-mile race May 3 appeared complete today at 68 cars.
FALLS CHURCH, Va., April 17 -- A new street in this Virginia suburb of Washington will be named for the late James Thurber, the writer, humorist and chronicler of urban and suburban foibles.
The Port Authority Trans-Hudson Line will offer improved evening, post-midnight and weekend service on the Hudson Tubes beginning next Sunday, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday.

BOGALUSA, La., April 17 -- Negro civil rights leaders released today their terms for holding negotiations aimed at ending demonstrations that have plagued the downtown area of this southeastern Louisiana town for the last week.

The crack racehorse "Memnon" (above), winner of the 1825 St. Leger, painted by J.F. Herring Sr., is one of the 300 English paintings, 1700-1850, from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon now on view at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven.

ON March 28, Paula Cronin, in an article datelined Christiansted, St. Croix, portrays such nostalgia for the past of 150 years ago that she is prompted to write that "Christiansted's history since then has been one of decline."
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 17 (AP) -- Six vacationers were killed and four were injured today in a collision before dawn on the Florida Turnpike.

The Times's military editor, Hanson W. Baldwin, seems to have let his enthusiasm for more military spending affect his sense of proportion. Mr. Baldwin writes, "Moreover, beginning this next fiscal year the arms budget will come into increasing conflict with the needs of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. . . ."
A COAST-TO-COAST search for riding talent will be held by the United States Equestrian Team in June, the U.S.E.T. president, Whitney Stone, announced yesterday.

My article on St. Croix was intended mainly as an impressionistic piece and, perhaps, the vulnerability of the article is that the impressions were general. That, in turn, may cause overgeneralization.

MONTREAL -- A 130-acre portion of this city's waterfront is the scene of much activity these days. There, not far from the projected site of the 1967 World's Fair, "Old Montreal" is being re-created at a brisk pace by an administration dedicated to preserving this city's unusual historical identity.
On the floor of the New York Stock Exchange one day last week, as General Motors kept accelerating across the tape to new highs, a visitor asked a stock broker: "What's making Motors move?"
SAVAGE, Md., April 17 -- On the surface, which is where the synthetic track is poured, it looks like the biggest, strip of almond-crunch candy in the world.

RABAT, Morocco, April 17 -- A joint Moroccan-American company with capital of $100 million is being set up for the exploitation of a Moroccan chemical complex based on phosphate rock, according to Armand Hammer, president of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation of Los Angeles.

Despite improvement in the weather last week, Easter business fell short of merchants' expectations. This is not to say that dollar volume in the final two weeks before the holiday was below that in the pre-Palm Sunday and pre-Easter week a year ago.

THE worrisome state of the Paris art market is Topic A for most French dealers, who've been keening loudly about the "crisis" caused by declining sales. But recently the noted marchand de tableaux Aime Maeght, in New York for the gala Chagall opening at the Peris Galleries, dismissed their concern as outre.
MEXICALI, Mexico, April 10 -- A small card printed in green ink has suddenly become the outstanding success symbol of this thriving city on the California border.
BATAVIA, N.Y., April 17 (AP) -- Six people were killed and four were injured in. two'l separate automobile accldentsi near this Genessee County city[ today.

THE Chevrolet-powered Chaparral owned and driven by Jim Hall and Hap Sharp of Midland, Tex., is the world's fastest sports car. It won the recent Sebring, Fla., 12-hour race by four laps (20.8 miles) and at an average speed of 84.723 miles despite a tropical rain storm that kept the course awash for almost three hours.

C.L. Sulzberger, in today's Times, observed that "Not enough Americans have studied the writings of Mao Tse-tung. . . ." A justification for this can be found in the Book of Job, "Behold that my desire is . . . that mine adversary had written a book."

Navigation deficiencies on both sides appear to have been a factor in the Thanksgiving morning crash involving the Israeli luxury liner Shalom and the Norwegian tanker Stolt Dagali. Nineteen Norwegian crew members lost their lives.
FORT WORTH, April 17 -- This city had reason to be proud earlier this month when it added the slogan "All America City" to "Where the West Begins."

FOR myself, London, Paris, Rome and New York are the only livable cities. They have their beauty, they have also the ugliness of great cities; but instantly you find your corner; you know you are tolerated; you are excited by your freedom and, though you may be lonely, you are consoled by the variety of human life.

" Festival of the Sun," the annual ball of the Brooklyn Museum, will be held on May 1 in its specially decorated auditorium court on the third floor. A champagne reception in the first floor gallery will precede the dance, a buffet dinner and entertainment.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Fifty-one Senators and 270 members of the House have joined in a declaration opposing any United States concessions to Communist China.
ATLANTA, April 19 -- The next Georgia Legislature may include eight Negroes and al Grand Dragon of the Ku Klux Klan.

TOKYO, April 18 -- A colorful show of little girls' fashions presented here by the American designer Helen Lee was received enthusiastically today by an elite international audience. Fashion leaders predicted that the showing would have considerable effect on Japanese designs.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Only the hardy got to the White House today for the Easter Monday egg roll.

FOR his second recital in Carnegie Hall, Sviatoslav Richter last night drew an audience that filled the auditorium and overflowed onto the stage. It is a measure of his hold on his admirers that he offered an unusual program, about three quarters of it is quite subdued in character, and played it with great introspection, yet apparently did not lose the attention of his listeners.
IT is as clear as the Lucite legs under his tables that Milo Baughman is a man of his time.

PHILADELPHIA April 19 -- Eight bearded and grimy aviators of the United States Navy and Marine Corps emerged in good spirits and good health today from two small chambers in which they had made a simulated 34-day journey into space.

The First National City Bank announced late yesterday it was making no "general increase" in its 4 1/2 per cent interest rate on loans to securities houses -- with the emphasis on the word "general." The two-sentence announcement included this statement: any broker or dealer customer of National City "whose borrowings exceed a historical pattern" will be charged 4 3/4 per cent, starting today, "on the excess."
The Radio Corporation of America has decided to go it alone in merging electronics with printing.

THE slowest bridge players in the world are almost certainly the French experts Pierre Ghestem and Rene Bacherich, who have been known to think for 15 minutes about a single play. The fastest players may be some of the commuters who converge daily on Grand Central.

The annual meeting of Yale Express System, Inc., originally scheduled for May 14, has been postponed, a New York Stock Exchange spokesman said yesterday. Sources close to the company said the meeting probably would be held sometime in June.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19 -- Nine United States Army helicopter crewmen were killed in Binhdinh Province today as they airlifted Government troops into an area thick with Vietcong troops.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Joseph Walker Barr, designated by President Johnson yesterday as Under Secretary of the Treasury, is one of those rare personalities in the Federal bureaucracy whose susceptibility to Potomac fever has never prevented him from excelling in his job.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A House subcommittee said today that the late Rachel Carson "created an atmosphere of panic" over the dangers of pesticides.

It may come as a surprise to the millions who have shopped at Robert Hall Clothes for the last 25 years, but there never has been a Robert Hall. The name is only a fictional one, but with the kind of ring that comes across clearly on radio, and now on television.

BALTIMORE, April 19 (AP) -- Steve Leo Jr., owned by Joe Nechamkin, scored today his third victory in eight starts this season by winning the Baltimore Spring Handicap, the feature race on the opening program of Pimlico's 24-day spring meeting.

BUENOS AIRES, April 19 -- Argentina's moderate government made public today a decision to press ahead with plans for rapid economic expansion rather than accept the advice of the International Monetary Fund to move at a slower and more stable pace.

Like many of the pavilions at the World's Fair, the Japanese seemed yesterday hopelessly behind time for the fair opening tomorrow, but appearances are deceptive. The new attraction of the Japanese Pavilion -- a long series of miniature copies of ancient and treasured shrines and pagodas in the home country -- is in place.

HONOLULU, April 19 (AP) -- A top-level conference on Vietnam started today with Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, meeting with commanders of United States forces in the Pacific area.
ALBANY, April 19 -- Collecting the new 2 per cent sales tax will cost the state about $8 million this year.
BUDAPEST, April 14 -- They call them "the unreachables," a group of about 600,000 Hungarian workers who commute to factory jobs, many of them over distances greater than 150 miles.

WHITE PLAINS, April 19 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors, by a vote of 31 to 9 today, chose as the site of the projected State University campus and Medical School the 455-acre tract immediately north of the Hawthorne traffic circle of the Taconic State and Saw Mill River Parkways.

A dramatization of Edith Wharton's famous novel "Ethan Frome," viewed on television by 24 million persons, infringed upon the copyright held by the late dramatist Owen Davis, Federal Judge Wilfred Feinberg ruled yesterday.

Twenty years after the destruction of Nazi Germany by the Allied armies, the time has come for the German people to reassert their "national identity" with pride, Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin declared here yesterday.

YONKERS, April 19 -- Meadow Skipper and Safe Return were among the eight standardbreds named today to start in Thursday night's $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway. However, those who did the naming did not say "positively" when they dropped the slips into the entry box.
Gov. George Romney of Michigan charged yesterday that the Johnson Administration's Great Society programs were not solving the nation's growing economic problems.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 (AP) -- The Rockwell-Standard Corporation reported today the largest first-quarter salse and earnings in the company's history. Its earnings rose 14 per cent to $6,608,000 from $5,798,000 in the corresponding period last year.

The leader of the nation's newspaper publishers contended yesterday that fear of automation was greater than the fact. Strikes or even strike threats are the truer danger to newspaper jobs, he asserted.
Television viewing is on the increase, according to research figures of the A.C. Nielsen Company.
The Pennsylvania Railroad, the nation's largest, reported yesterday that on a consolidated system basis it had experienced a 23 per cent gain in earnings in the first quarter this year.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 19 -- The Supreme Court today ordered the release of Miguel Arrais, former Governor of Pernambuco, who has been jailed by military authorities for more than a year.
BRIGHTON, England, April 19 (AP) -- Reinforced police details scattered rowdy bands of youths in four seaside resorts today. Arrests for the four-day Easter holiday mounted to about 175.
The works, words and possessions of 14 great men -- 13 United States Presidents and a British Prime Minister -- were previewed at two sites at the World's Fair yesterday.

The Concert Opera Association and the Little Orchestra Society will suspend operations in New York during the 1965-66 season. Thomas Scherman, founder and music director of both organizations, will take his first sabbatical after 18 seasons in a row.

ATLANTA, April 19 -- Following are klan terms taken from a book of klan organizations and ritual, copyrighted in 1953 by tile late Eldon Edwards, Imperial Wizard of the now-defunct U.S. Klans, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, Inc., and still in use by most klan groups:
" It's a deal -- but not a hold-up."
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Yields on the new issues of Treasury bills edged upward this week.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Mrs. Margy Williams is a 34-year-old native of Brookhaven, Miss., who was deserted in Chicago four years ago by her husband. She supports four children, aged 10 to 17, on $250 a month in the aid-to-dependent-children relief programs.

Figures just compiled by the Welfare Department indicate that the cycle of inherited want in this city is becoming a disastrous upward spiral. The number of children growing up on the public relief rolls has risen from 128,556 to 276,179 in the last ten years. The total cost of providing them with aid has nearly tripled; it now exceeds $18.5 million a month.
A 30-year-old Puerto Rican, awaiting trial for murder, was found hanged in his cell at the Tombs on Sunday.

A group of the youngest children ever to be given a lecture tour at the American Museum of Natural History clustered eagerly around Janet Saleh yesterday at the first meeting of a new program, the "Look and Listen Hour."

A little over a year ago, on April 16, 1964, the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company confirmed the the fact that it had made "a major discovery of zinc, copper and silver in the Timmins area of Ontario, Canada."

SELMA, Ala., April 19 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. told a cheering crowd here tonight that last week's advertisement by Alabama businessmen urging compliance with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 was a positive step forward."
MONTREAL, April 19 -- "Look at this suit," Gump Worsley said today as he sat down to a sizable meal of roast beef, potato salad and cold slaw. "It cost me $37 custom made.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- New changes were announced today in the Latin-American bureau of the State Department as part of the department's continuing reshuffling.
The Federal Intermediate Credit Banks are offering today a new issue of approximately $288.5 million of 4.30 per cent debentures dated May 3, 1965, to mature Feb. 1, 1966. They are priced at 100.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox equaled an American League record by using five pinch-hitters in the seventh inning tonight and two of them drove in runs that helped the White Sox to a 7-2 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles.

Testimony in support of a motion to set aside the conviction of Mark Fein, a Park Avenue executive, for the murder of his bookmaker was completed in State Supreme Court yesterday. The prosecution will call rebuttal witnesses today.
American industry's cost-cutting drive for efficiency has been catching up with the modern-day high priests of efficiency -- the industrial engineers.
BOSTON, April 19 -- Japanese runners, absent from the Boston Marathon for five year returned today with a vengeance. Five Japanese ran, and they finished first, second third, fourth and sixth.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 19 -- First-quarter results of the Freeport Sulphur Company will bear out earlier predictions of good business, Robert C Hills, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here today.
LAWRENCEBURG, Tenn., April 19 (AP) -- State troopers enforced a court curb on picketing today, and the big Murray Ohio company bicycle plant was reopened to some 1,800 workers.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Interior Department announced today that Josephine, one of 50 whooping cranes known to be in existence, had laid an egg yesterday.
Macy's and Gimbels were barred yesterday from selling at cut-rate prices any of the liquors distilled or distributed by Seagram's.
DETROIT, April 19 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk tonight reasserted the Administration's intention of continuing air attacks against North Vietnam.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- The Chicago and North Western Railway Company reported today that net income for the first quarter of 1965 totaled $42,947, compared with a loss of $347,825 for the first quarter of 1964.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies jumped on an old nemesis, Dick Farrell, for four runs in the third inning tonight and went on to wallop the Houston Astros, 8-0, behind Jim Bunning's five-hit pitching.
Is social responsibility a function of business? And is the creation of a corporate image of social responsibility a function of public relations?
Henry Luce 3d was named yesterday as a director and a member of the executive committee of the East Texas Pulp and Paper Company, a subsidiary of Time, Inc.

A series of annual scholarships to be offered to top students at 50 Journalism schools was announced here yesterday by Joyce A. Swan, the publisher of The Minneapolis Star and The Minneapolis Tribune.
MOSCOW, April 19 -- The Soviet Government warned the United States today that aerial bombardments and the use of gas in Vietnam might lead to "retaliation in kind."
The duties of chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America were shifted yesterday to John D. Harper, the president, from Lawrence Litchfield Jr., the chairman.

THE baseball season was only three games old when those masterly magicians on the New York Mets engineered a triple play. This is considered par for the course because statisticians offer the information that each league averages approximately one triple play a year. Although there have been five seasons when the production of three-ply erasures has reached as high as seven, there also have been 15 when there was nary a one.
MONTREAL, April 19 (AP) -- The first ship from the Soviet Union ever to use the St. Lawrence Seaway is expected to enter the system tomorrow bound for Toronto and Hamilton.

Wall Street analysts took up sledgehammers yesterday and pounded away at pieces of plastic with an interesting future. It was all in line of duty at the luncheon of the New York Society of Security Analysts, who played host to the White Motor Company, maker of trucks, farm and other industrial equipment.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- In its haste to enact the Great Society, Congress is rushing headlong into collision with what might be called the problem Problem.
HOUSTON, April 19 (AP) -- At least three tornadoes spun their deadly funnels to the ground in south Texas today as a score or more of towns were slapped by heavy hail. Damage was not estimated.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 19 -- The Longshore Country Club here will be the setting for the Southport-Westport Antiques Show, April 28 through April 30. There will be displays by more than 35 exhibitors. Proceeds, exclusive of exhibition sales, will go to help the Near and Far Aid Association.
Copper futures contracts rose the daily limit yesterday in active trading on the New York Commodity Exchange.
Customers who buy stocks on margin are due to see their interest costs go up a notch -- and thereby hang several interesting threads as far as the stock market is concerned.
The New Haven Railroad sent yesterday to the Governors of New York and Connecticut a counterproposal for emergency aid to keep the bankrupt line's passenger service alive for a year or more.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- "If conscientious, able and independent men are put on the bench," wrote Charles Evans Hughes in his Columbia University lectures (1927), "you cannot predict their course as judges by reference either to partisan motives or personal or party loyalties."
FOR some time I had been worrying about the piranha, ever since, in fact, I passed a shop specializing in selling tropical fish.
The West Side is fighting to recover some of its sidewalks and to challenge a basic city policy.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 19 -- Greek nationals are to be expelled from the country and the Ecumenical Patriarchate is to be "controlled."

NEW DELHI, April 19 -- Indian resentment was growing today over President Johnson's abrupt postponement last Friday of the visit to Washington by Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri scheduled for June.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 19 -- Directors of the Christiana Securities Company are studying the best means of disposing of Hercules Powder Company stock held by Christiana.
Three persons were slightly injured yesterday when a dozen manhole covers were blown into the air at Avenue of the Americas and 17th Street after fire caused an explosion in an underground conduit.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 19 (Reuters) -- The first Chinese-Japanese diplomatic meeting in 20 years -- since the end of World War II -- took place here today when Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China conferred with a special envoy of Eisaku Sato, the Japanese Premier.
The handbag industry's 75-year-old union offered yesterday to invest $2 million to help construct a light-manufacturing industrial park at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
HARTFORD, April 19 (AP) -- Toy ducklings suspected of being contaminated with harmful bacteria have been confiscated by the State Department of Consumer Protection.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19 -- U Thant, the United Nations Secretary General, authorized a spokesman today to say that he had "high esteem" for Senator J.W. Fulbright and for "the vision and wisdom in his approach to international affairs."

Arthur C. Clarke, a spectacled, keen-looking science writer, talking with friends last week in the office of William Jovanovich, president of Harcourt, Brace World, smiled when someone mentioned Telestar as a new wonder.

Jackie Robinson, who played a leading role in the integration of professional baseball and who has been active in the integration of business, politics and banking, has turned his efforts to the life insurance business.
Manuel Ycaza replaced John Seliers yesterday as the rider on Mrs. Ben Cohen's Hail to All for the May 1 running of the Kentucky Derby. The change left Bold Lad without a jockey.
NEW YORK'S art galleries have housed everything from stuffed goats to horses with gold-filled teeth. Now one of them has a real live tiger in its tank.
Can mankind survive in the kind of world that man is, himself, creating?

The Dinizulu Dancers and Drummers, who appeared at the African Pavilion of the World's Fair last year, gave two performances at the Renata Theater last night as the first of a series that is to be continued -- on April 24, 25 and 26.
LA JOLLA, Calif., April 19 -- An enterprising young man man named J. Thomas Jefferson startled this affluent suburban community last week with an artistic coup.

LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- A new eight-foot-tall portrait of Queen Elizabeth II aroused controversy today. Painted by Peter Greenham, it will go on view at the Royal Academy's summer exhibition in early May.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today against the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company and 13 of its officers, directors and employes who allegedly bought stock in the company, or advised others to do so, while they withheld news of a rich ore discovery in Canada.

Two hundred children from Mobilization of Youth's adventure corps, carrying signs urging residents to "Keep Your City Clean" and "Don't Be a Litterburg," marched through two miles of the lower East Side yesterday in a clean-up campaign.

Archbishop Molloy, scoring in seven of the 12 open events, captured the team title yesterday in the ninth annual All Hallows Relay Carnival at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. The meet drew entries from 47 Catholic high schools in the metropolitan area.
Price cuts were announced yesterday on an antibiotic and on frozen orange juice.
I am visiting the United States with my family for a period of eighteen months. During this time I am employed as an official visitor at the Oak Ridge National Laboratories.
COLUMBIA, S.C., April 19 -- President Johnson flew here today to pay tribute to an old Democratic colleague, Senator Olin D. Johnston, who died yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 19 (UPI) -- Homer Jack Dean was freed from Ohio Penitentiary today, 15 years after his conviction for a murder in 1947. But sheriff's deputies were waiting at the gates to rearrest him on an order of the county. prosecutor.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York has purchased a 22-story apartment house in Pittsburgh from the New York Life Insurance Company. The building, known as Highland House, has 164 apartments.

Total Matches Record Set for Week of March 27 Steel output in the United States climbed back to 2,785,000 tons last week, thus matching the record set in the week ended March 27, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The Edith Stephen Dance Company appeared at the 41st Street Theater last night in the second of three performances it is giving here. The final performance will be on Monday.

The New York University-Office of Economic Opportunity experiment to make teachers of sixty "unreconstructed New York City slum boys" who would not normally go on to college, but who have the required "functioning intelligence" (as reported in The Times on April 3), is a moving and imaginative new approach to education and opportunity for this segment of our society.
Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its net income and earnings per share in the first quarter of 1965 were more than double those of the first quarter of last year.

LOS ANGELES, April 19 (UPI) -- Marcelino Lopez, a 21-year-old Cuban left-hander, scored his first, major league triumph tonight when he turned back the Detroit Tigers on a seven-hitter and gave the Los Angeles Angels a 4-2 victory.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 19 -- Two bearded Sikh brothers from Nairobi -- Joginder and Jaswant Singh -- battled perilous escarpments, mud and swollen rivers of three countries today to score an unexpected victory in the East African Safari.
SINCE Henry James and Edith Wharton each had a private hell, it is boorish to poke fun at them.

BOGALUSA, La., April 19 (AP) -- Singing and chanting "We Shall Overcome," 400 Negroes marched through rain and hail to City Hall today, demanding that three white policemen be discharged "for improper conduct."

Francis Keppel, United States Commissioner of Education, cautioned educators and community leaders yesterday that they had to work together for the Administration's education and antipoverty programs to succeed.
The city's Health Commissioner, Dr. James, whose first name is George, reported yesterday that Michael was now the most popular name for boys born here. For girls, Lisa is the most popular, he said.
The election of Thomas D. Barrow as a director of the Humble Oil and Refining Company was announced yesterday by Carl E. Reistle Jr., chairman.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19 -- A United Nations committee was urged today to intervene on behalf of six South Africans who are seeking asylum in the United States.
NEW HAVEN, April 19 -- Henry R. Luce, publisher and chairman of Time-Life, Inc. began a five-day visit as a Chubb Fellow on the Yale University campus today.
PITTSBURGH, April 19 -- The United Steelworkers of America, with a possible strike only 12 days away, moved today to bring bargaining with the steel industry to a head.
LONDON, April 19 -- Ban-the-bomb marchers, most of them teen-agers, massed in Trafalgar Square today for a peace rally, but violence erupted on the way.
Mayor Wagner yesterday hailed the "proven ability" of the New Dramatists Committee to provide the American theater with playwrights of "high caliber."

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company's annual rate of revenues climbed "beyond the half-billion mark" during the first three months, Donald C. Luce, president, told yesterday's annual meeting at Newark, N.J.

STATION WINS yesterday became the first New York radio outlet to offer a continuous round-the-clock news service. Straight news summaries as well as feature interviews were carried as the outlet of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company began the task of seeking a distinctive identity in the fiercely competitive metropolitan market.
Irving J. Bronstein, executive vice president of the Bronley Corporation, has been elected a director of the Crown Aluminum Industries Corporation. Bronley is a Crown subsidiary.
BOSTON, April 19 -- Coach Red Auerbach of the Boston Celtics always lights a big cigar when he is sure his team is going to win a game.
HONG KONG, April 19 -- Top-level delegations representing Communist China and North Vietnam met in Peking today for talks that observers said centered on the military situation in Vietnam.

Stanley G. Reiben, chief counsel for George Whitmore Jr., who is on trial for murder, asked to withdraw from the case yesterday and then, when permission was refused, asserted, "The defense remains mute! for the duration of this trial."

BONN, April 19 -- Barry Goldwater, vacationing in Europe, spent the Easter weekend touring and sightseeing around the Stuttgart area with his host, Lieut. Gen. William W. Quinn, commander of the United States Seventh Army, an aide to General Quinn said today.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- The surging floodwaters of the Mississippi River tore a 75-foot hole today in a dike near La Crosse, Wis., and a gasoline storage tank complex was quickly flooded. Water began inundating the nearby La Crosse municipal airport.

E. I du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., the giant chemical producer, reported yesterday a decline in its net earnings to $102 million, equal to $2.16 a common share, for the first quarter of this year. In the corresponding quarter last year, du Pont's net income totaled $113 million, or $2.40 a share.
THE following menu is suggested as guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Governors of nine Appalachian states and representatives of two others met today to set in motion the $1.1 billion program of economic aid that grew out of a campaign promise by John F. Kennedy in 1960.

The New York Building Congress will hold its 44th annual meeting today with a luncheon at the Astor Hotel, at which new officers for 1965-66 will be elected. The speaker will be Joseph D. Keenan, international secretary of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
ST. LOUIS, April 19 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs knocked Ray Sadecki from the mound with a four-run, four-hit barrage in the first inning and went on to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals 7-3, tonight.

An attractive introduction to the dance styles and legends of India is being presented at Philharmonic Hall this week in six matinees planned especially for children. Two of the performances of "The Travels of Krishha," as the program is entitled, were given yesterday, and two each are scheduled for Thursday and Saturday.
HOUSTON, April 19 (UPI) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration absolved Maj. Virgil I. Grissom of any blame in the off-target landing of his Gemini 3 capsule last March 23.

OF the new plays introduced by Theater 1965 at the Cherry Lane this season, "Do Not Pass Go" is far and away the best. It is, in fact, one of the better new plays presented this season -- not a vintage one, it is true -- on or off Broadway.
Nathan Jackson was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison the week of June 7. He was convicted the second time on April 2 for the murder of a policeman in 1960.

RICHMOND, April 19 -- George Lincoln Rockwell, commander of the American Nazi party, filed today his declaration of candidacy for Governor of Virginia. He said he would run in November as an independent concentrating on a white supremacy platform.
Government and corporate bond prices declined yesterday in quiet trading.
Canadian stocks moved slightly higher on moderate volume yesterday. British and continental stock markets were closed for the Easter Monday holiday.
ONE of the wildest spots to shop is the Country Place on Bonwit Teller's fourth floor. There, way-out fashions often make their debuts under respectable auspices.

The pedestal that has stood empty for more than five years at the southern end of Central Park was crowned yesterday with its statue -- Anna Hyatt Huntington's bronze sculpture of Jose Marti, the patriot who died in the final Cuban uprising against Spain.
JAMES THURBER thought Fred Allen's finest line might be the one about the crows so terrified by a new scarecrow that they brought back corn they had stolen two years before.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 19 -- A judge in Nassau County Court questioned the constitutionality of the state's 1894 antihazing law as he dismissed charges today against two members of a high school fraternity.

LONDON, April 19 -- A young sweater- clad Negro, haranguing a crowd in the northeast corner of Hyde Park, lashes out at American use of nonlethal gas in Vietnam and then shouts with special emphasis, "The people of the Afro-Asian nations are on the march."

MONTREAL, April 19 -- Canadian authorities were investigating security at the jail here today, following the suicide last night of a prisoner held on a charge of conspiracy to blow up three Federal monuments in the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Government field trials of a new concept in vaccine immunization against respiratory disease caused by viruses have proved 100 per cent effective, it was reported here today.
GOODWOOD, England, April 19 (UPI) -- Jim Clark of Scotland raced to victory today in a Formula One International 100-mile auto race in a car that broke down on the final lap.

PORK loins are an economical buy in most markets at this time. Baked slowly, after marinating in a sweet-sour barbecue sauce, the pork develops a golden brown crust and a delicious flavor. Served with glazed bananas, it is a pleasing substitute for barbecued roast suckling pig.
An evening program at Yonkers Raceway has been planned for May 5 as a benefit for the Hamilton-Madison House, a Lower East Side settlement house and neighborhood center.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has rejected a Federal Maritime Commission claim that the agency can order steamship companies to produce their complete corporate records for rate-making review.
Oil and drug stocks dominated trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, as the market advanced in the heaviest volume in almost three years.

The prolonged travail in Albany over the Rockefeller budget upset the statutory timetable for New York City's annual fiscal debate. The Mayor's executive budget will, if completed, be presented by April 29. It will then go to public hearings correspondingly delayed by two weeks. Since any new taxing powers required by the city must be endorsed by the Legislature, a new battle at Albany as well as at City Hall seems sure.
BOSTON, April 19 -- This old city combined the archives of its history with the resources of its present to dramatize today the opening of a midtown center dedicated to its future.
MOSCOW, April 19 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin has announced that the next Five-Year Plan will pursue a twin policy of providing more consumer goods and higher wages to pay for them.
Yeshiva University's Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Catholic Charities' Kennedy Child Study Center joined forces yesterday to expand research and education in mental retardation.

ATHENS, April 20 -- Turkey's threat to deport the Orthodox Ecumenical Patriarchate from Istanbul may prompt the Soviet Union to resume imperial Russia's role as protector of the Orthodoxy, areliable Greek source said today.
LOS ANGELES, April 20 -Two Los Angeles savings and loan associations at their stockholder meetings today reported slightly increased earnings over the similar 1964 quarter.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Something is happening to the process of political debate in America. It is lagging far behind the events it is intended to influence, and a good deal of the time it takes the form not of serious intellectual inquiry but of one-sided headline hunting and even of physical defiance of the law.

The annual meeting of the Crescent Corporation, a diversified maker of switches, electronic devices and library furniture, began in routine fashion yesterday, but ended with a surprise in the form of the election of a new director from the floor by cumulative voting.

YONKERS, April 20 -- Earle Avery paced Meadow Skipper six miles at Yonkers Raceway this morning. At the conclusion of the workout, the 71-year-old trainer-driver of the favorite in Thursday night's $50,000 Good Time Pace insisted all was well with the 5-year-old.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy has emphatically rejected a compromise plan for civilian review of complaints of police brutality.

The American Civil Liberties Union urged Georgetown University yesterday to reconsider its dismissal of Dr. Francis E. Kearns, who has been notified that his contract is not being renewed for 1965-66 because his "services were not considered necessary."

Senator Olin Johnston of South Carolina, who died the other day, could have reasonably been described as an old-fashioned figure or as a forerunner of the coming trend in Southern politics, for he was both.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 20 -- A program to speed Suffolk County's payment for $20 million worth of property that has been condemned for parks and wetlands will be proposed to the Board of Supervisors next Monday.
Continuation of New Haven Railroad commuter runs into New York for at least 18 months was virtually assured yesterday.
A concert devoted to works by Vincent Luzzi, a New Yorker who studied composition at the New York College of Music, was given last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Five members of the Lombardozzi family were sent to prison yesterday by Federal Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in Brooklyn. They had been convicted of severely beating an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation two years ago.
FEW women have the time, patience, money or inclination to have all their clothes made to their measurements, but many would find an occasional custom dress a great spirit booster.
The Tony awards, presented to the theater by the American Theater Wing, have been reactivated, it was announced yesterday.
A broad program of consumer education in the nation's schools was called for yesterday by Mrs. Esther Peterson, Special Assistant to the President for Consumer Affairs.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- A thousand college admissions officers and registrars met today in anatmosphere of gloom. They were told that never before has the admissions picture been as "bleak as it is today."
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Kermit Gordon will resign as director of the Bureau of the Budget on June 1 and be succeeded by Charles L. Schultze, the White House announced today.
