Monroe E. Spaght will become chairman of the Shell Oil Company when John H. Loudon retires from the post July 1.

Despite the objections of stockholder John Gilbert and owners of 175,000 shares, shareholders of Botany Industries, Inc., voted overwhelmingly yesterday to approve a one-for-two exchange of the company's common stock.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 20 -- The Kenya Government complained today of what it called "total interference" by the United States in offering scholarships to 29 Kenyan students who returned two weeks ago, bitter and disillusioned, from the Soviet Union.

Plans for a major build-up of United States ground forces in South Vietnam and an intensification of the bombing of North Vietnam are reported to have been discussed at a military conference in Hawaii.

LA CROSSE, Wis., April 20 (UPI) -- The raging Mississippi River, climbing toward its highest flood crest here, rampaged along the borders of five states today, driving thousands more persons from their homes from Minnesota to Southern Illinois.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 (AP) -- Roberto Clemente drove in two runs with a pair of singles today as the Pittsburgh Pirates spoiled the home opener of the San Francisco Giants by posting a 3-1 victory.
DETROIT, April 20 (UPI) -Parke, Davis Co., reported today first-quarter sales of $52.4 million and net earnings of $7,631,595.

In a critical report on international education and student exchange Dr. Homer D. Babbidge Jr., president of the University of Connecticut, cautioned both the Government and the academic world yesterday against the use of education for political or utilitarian purposes.
The New York Central Labor Council started yesterday to round up support to get the legislators to override Governor Rockefeller's veto of a $1.50 minimum-wage bill.
Braniff International Airways has changed its name for the fourth time in the 37-year-old history of the airline. It will now be known as Braniff International.
Paperboard production rose to 413,324 tons in the week ended April 10, from 390,157 tons in the corresponding 1964 week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

Peace Corps volunteers training at Columbia University shopped yesterday morning in a "Nigerian market." Using the Igbo language they have been studying for the last 10 weeks, they bargained hard over akwukwo nri (greens), anyu (squash), and oja (leg rattles), but didn't offer a shin (shilling) for an okuko (chicken).

NASHVILLE, April 20 (UPI) -- A Federal judge ordered Gov. Frank G. Clement today to show cause why state troopers should not be enjoined from interfering with Teamsters union pickets at a bicycle plant in Lawrenceburg, Tenn.

IF the Yankees are not coming home as conquering heroes today, at least they are coming home. It's about time. Although normal procedure always has called for all ball clubs to have their home openings within the first few days of the start of each season, the erstwhile Bronx Bombers have been wandering all over the landscape since they left Florida, stopping over in Houston, Minnesota, Los Angeles and Kansas City.

BALTIMORE, April 20 -- The News-American, a Hearst afternoon and Sunday newspaper, suspended publication and placed its employes on furlough today in support of The Sunpapers, struck since Saturday by members of the Newspaper Guild.

PARIS -- The Vietnam war is America's most crucial short-term problem in Asia, but India is America's most crucial long-term problem. China's drang nach Sueden aims at establishing suzerainty as far south as Indonesia.
NEW DELHI, April 20 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri has canceled his visit to the United States, Foreign Minister Swaran Singh told Parliament today.

ATLANTA, April 20 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and members of his staff considered today their next step in the move to boycott Alabama products. They met with Harry Belafonte, the singer, and civil rights youth leaders.
AKRON, Ohio, Wednesday, April 21 (AP) -- A midnight walkout against the three major rubber companies -- Firestone, Goodrich and Goodyear -- was postponed last night as contracts expired.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A fast, easy and inexpensive blood test to detect German measles infection has been developed by scientists at the National Institutes of Health.
Copper futures continued their advance yesterday in active trading on the New York Commodity Exchange.

CENTER LINE, Mich., April 20 -- Management of the Chrysler Corporation, speaking optimistically about the outlook for the company and the economy, reported today record first-quarter sales and earnings.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 20 (AP) -- The favored three-some of the medalists, Nancy Roth; the defending champion, Phyliss Preuss, and the national titleholder, Barbara McIntire, scored victories today in the opening round of the North and South amateur gold championship.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The continuing change in the Republican National Committee brought today a new assistant chairman, State Senator Mary Brooks of Idaho.
Foreign exhibitors in the International Area of the World's Fair say they expect to draw bigger crowds this season than they did last year.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -Former Senator Kenneth B. Keating announced today that he would head a new national campaign for deeper Governmental involvement in promoting birth control.

BOSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Felix Mantilla hit his first grand-slam homer and drove in all the Boston runs today as the surprising Red Sox took sole possession of the American League lead with a 5-2 victory over Washington.

An underwriting syndicate headed by the Security-First National Bank and the United California Bank won $25 million in bonds sold yesterday in competitive bidding by the Los Angeles Unified School District.

MIAMI, April 20 -- The chief of the Federal Narcotics Bureau for southern Florida and two city detectives were arrested by Federal and local policemen tonight on charges of accepting bribes from a narcotics peddler.
Finland's new Ambassador to the United States, Olav Munkki, said today that Europe's two big trade blocs will not combine in the near future.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution was urged today to pass 13 resolutions that included opposition to the Administration's proposed immigration law changes, a call for more Government anti-Communist activity, and support for a drive against crime.

MIAMI, April 20 (AP) -- George Beebe, managing editor of The Miami Herald and president of The Associated Press Managing Editors Association, said today that editors felt that the American public was not getting "the full story nor the true story" of the war in Vietnam.

The World's Fair, its 168 pavilions representing a half-billion-dollar investment, will open its second and final season today with fireworks, charity balls, a parade, a few speeches and determined hopes. It will be the financially decisive season for the fair and there was an undercurrent of optimism among its officials that the disappointing first season would be followed by a successful second run.
The first quarter of this year was the best such period in the history of Texaco, Inc. This was announced yesterday by J. Howard Rambin Jr., chairman, at the annual meeting yesterday in New Orleans.

TO belong to the elect, the elite, the fortunate and the exclusive is as much a human craving as to be successful or loved. The object of desire may be a royal court, a gang of juvenile delinquents, a country club or the "in group" whose members are ever so important and knowing about quarter horses, bank mergers or contemporary art.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, April 20 (Reuters) -- Only two balls were needed to give West Indies victory over Australia on the fifth day of the hard cricket test today.
PATERSON, N.J., April 20 -A treatment center for narcotics addicts may be established here by the Roman Catholic Mount Carmel Center for Alcoholism.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- President Johnson's successful curbs on the outflow of dollars for loans and investment overseas have been a little too successful here.
The Government completed its case yesterday in the alleged multimillion dollar diet-pill fraud involving the Kastor Hilton Chesley Clifford Atherton advertising agency and two other defendants.
MIAMI BEACH, April 20 (UPI) -- Bandits rifled safety deposit boxes at another Miami Beach hotel today, this time hitting a small hotel that caters mostly to elderly vacationers.

CHICAGO, April 20 (UPI) -The United States deficit in international payments was "much smaller" in the first quarter of 1965, largely because of President Johnson's program to reduce the dollar outflow, a high Administration official said today.
The Puerto Rican Bar Association plans to petition Mayor Wagner by the end of the week for action in the cases of four Puerto Ricans found hanged in their jail cells in February and March.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The State Department of Insurance said today that it would delay its decision on the Blue Cross request for a rate increase until the Legislature acts on pending bills that would affect the hospital insurance concern.
The Moll Flanders Supper Dance and Ball will be held on May 7 at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to benefit the Metropolitan chapter of the National Hemophilia Foundation.

RUMORS have been drifting back to New York of an exciting Spanish soprano by the name of Monserrat Caballe. Last night she made her debut here with the American Opera Society in its last presentation of the season, Donizetti's "Lucrezia Borgia."

BUENOS AIRES, April 20 -- Brazil's foreign minister, Vasco Leitao da Cunha, conferred here today with President Arturo U. Illia and other Argentine officials on means of strengthening the Organization of American States.
Dramatic advances in the Space Age as well as priceless historical manuscripts and objects will be among the scores of new displays at the World's Fair in its final season.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company became yesterday the fifth New York bank to raise its broker loan rate from 4 1/2 per cent to 4 3/4 per cent.

Prince and Princess Stanislas Radziwill gave what the Princess called "a teeny, tiny dance for less than 100" last night in their Fifth Avenue duplex. And although the gathering was "not for anyone or anything -- just a little thing we're giving before we go back to London," it was well supplied with New Frontiersmen, some of whom have graduated into the Great Society, and other notables.
Industrial stocks rose slightly in quiet trading on the London stock market yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Sam Zagoria of Somerville, N.J., took office today as a member of the National Labor Relations Board.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 20 -- A village custom here of accepting cash for park purposes from real estate developers, instead of contributions of park land, was ruled unconstitutional today by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Two high school seniors in Oceanside, L.I., were saved from fines or imprisonment by a question about the validity of an old state law. There was, however, no question about the fact that they had inflicted severe injuries on a fellow student.

BOSTON, April 20 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, the United States representative at the United Nations, told the Massachusetts Legislature today that the meeting of the Disarmament Commission at the United Nations tomorrow would result in "more polemics than progress" unless the major participants were sincere.
With the migrant birds returning, an old, old question presents itself again. Why do they come back?

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 20 -- Charles de Silva, leader of the House of Representatives, presented a motion in Parliament today proposing the appointment of a joint committee of the House and Senate to consider a revision of the Const itution of Ceylon "and other written law."

PARIS, April 20 -- President de Gaulle has told West Germany that until the countries of the European Common Market agree on foreign and defense policies it is futile to talk about creating new political institutions in Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, April 20 -- The major motion picture studios here have quietly embarked on their most important period of expansion and modernization in more than three decades. The expansion promises to change both the face of Hollywood and the future course of the movie industry.

" Adventures in Golden Bay" and "The Red Balloon," two featurettes from Czechoslovakia and France, will open today's program of the week long International Children's Film Festival now being presented at Town Hall. The two movies will go on at 11 A.M.
As quoted in your April 17 edition Jacques Rueff believes that gold is sacrosanct and indispensable to our existence.
PITTSBURGH, April 20 -Government wage guideposts designed to discourage inflationary labor contracts may be partly responsible for a steel strike if one occurs May 1.
HONOLULU, April 20 -- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara announced tonight a step-up of the anti-Communist war in South Vietnam, with special emphasis on measures against Vietcong ocean traffic.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 -- The United States intends to urge the Disarmament Commission, convening tomorrow, to act quickly on an agreement to halt the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

REMARRIAGE, for better or worse, is an established fact of 20th century life. For many couples remarriage means not only building a new adult relationship but also establishing a family that involves children from previous unions.

Eugene Ormandy brought his Philadelphia Orchestra, the Westminster Choir and four soloists to Philharmonic Hall last night for what become an annual event -- a performance of Verdi's "Manzoni" Requiem. The work was done here last spring as part of a special World's Fair salute.

The reopening of the World's Fair today will be treated by the Police Department as just "another large gathering." Only a normal detail of 281 traffic patrolmen -- including 5 on motorcycles -- has been assigned to smooth the motorists' path to the 20,000 parking spaces ringing Flushing Meadows.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 20 -- Communist journalists in Sofia have been given details on the plot against the pro-Soviet leadership of Bulgaria.

HONG KONG, April 20 -- Organizations in Communist China were called upon today to "make full preparations to send their own people to fight together with the Vietnamese people and drive out United States aggressors."

ROME, April 20 (AP) -- Dino de Laurentiis, Italian film producer, confirmed today that he had received an American offer for the purchase of his huge motion picture production center 13 miles south of Rome.

An attractive introduction to the dance styles and legends of India is being presented at Philharmonic Hall this week in six matinees planned especially for children. Two of the performances of "The Travels of Krishna," as the program is entitled were given yesterday, and two each are scheduled for Thursday and Saturday.

Consolidated net income of The New York Times Company in the first quarter this year amounted to $1,308,000, equal to $2.89 a share on 409,515 shares outstanding, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

BOSTON, April 20 -- The Earl of Avon, formerly Sir Anthony Eden, strongly supported today President Johnson's offer to negotiate the Vietnam crisis without reducing joint efforts to defend South Vietnam.
Union Miniere du haut Katanga, the Belgian-owned mining company in the Congo, reported yesterday a rise in profits to $11,320,000 in 1964 from $7,446,580 the year before.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Senator Clifford P. Case announced today the appointment of Miss Frances Henderson as his administrative assistant. She succeeds Sam Zagoria, who resigned to become a member of the National Labor Relations Board.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 -- In one of the most gallant performances of his incomparable career, Warren Spahn scored his first victory as a New York Met tonight amid late-inning heroics worthy of a World Series setting.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that Communist China's threat to intervene in the fighting in Vietnam was an added element of danger in the situation "for both sides."
Holy Cross College authorities denied yesterday that Lew Alcindor had applied for admission to the Jesuit school in Worcester, Mass.
LAPIDUM, Md., April 20 -- A few miles before the Susquehanna River flows past Havre de Grace into Chesapeake Bay it is held up by the Conowingo Dam.
LONDON, April 20 -- There is much talk these days of London as the scene of a renaissance in the performing arts, a flowering of youth and talent.
BOSTON, April 20 (UPI) -- A group of 81 schoolchildren filed a suit today accusing the School Committee here of setting up segregation in classrooms.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- President Johnson conferred with Italy's Premier, Aldo Moro, for an hour today and then afforded him the rare privilege of sitting in on a Cabinet meeting. Mr. Moro, a strong supporter of United States policies in Europe and Southeast Asia, arrived here last night for three days of get-acquainted talks with Government leaders.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- Seventeen youths demanding immediate withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam sat down in a White House driveway today. They were hauled away by the police.
Prices will be lower and some attractions free in the amusement section of the World's Fair this year. The objective remains the same: In Robert Moses' phrase, "Clean fun for the whole family."

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 20 (UPI) -- Gail Goodrich, the all-American from University of California, Los Angeles, got off the bench last night to spark the United States All-Stars to 67-61 victory over the Soviet national basketball team at Las Vegas Convention Center.

ALTHOUGH New York is, in theory at least, the gastronomic capital of the United States, it is a place where more often than not both appetite and conscience may be better appeased by going to small, moderately priced restaurants than to those that by virtue of decor, expense and the waiters' tailoring are more celebrated and talked about.
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 20 (UPI) -- The Oklahoma Supreme Court declined today to rule on the constitutionality of the state's law banning interracial marriages.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 20 (UPI) -- Jan-Erik Lundquist of Sweden defeated Paul Hutchins of England, 7-5, 6-2, 6-2, today to gain the third round in the British hard-court tennis tournament. Lundquist is seeded first.

Those little three-wheeled "bugs" called Escorters will be missing from the fair this season. A trademark last year they once enlivened a cover of The New Yorker magazine -escorters may be cropping up in some unlikely places this summer -- estate gardens, resort boardwalks, college campuses and baseball diamonds, for instance.

Two of Mayor Wagner's sharpest critics, one a Democrat who is considering a race against the Mayor and the other a Republican, took divergent stands yesterday on the city administration's proposals for supervising the campaign against poverty.
ATLANTA, April 20 (UPI) -- Two youths, angered because they could not hear their favorite records at a party, rode up and down a street tonight "shooting at everything that moved," the police said.

LONDON, April 20 -- Britain's teachers today cheered a plan of the Labor Government to ease a shortage in their ranks but rejected a key provision in the program, their acceptance of substitute teachers.

Fresh demands for a better deal from the rich countries are now being aired by the poor at the meeting of the United Nations Trade and Development Board, an outgrowth of the major conference on international trade and aid held a year ago in Geneva.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 20 (UPI) -- A helicopter carrying Gov. John A. Volpe of Massachusetts and three other men crashed on takeoff late tonight. No one apparently was injured.
Stanley G. Reiben agreed yesterday to resume his role as chief counsel for George Whitmore Jr. after Whitmore told a Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice that he wanted the lawyer to represent him.
A final accounting of the receipts of the 1964-65 Neediest Cases Fund was submitted yesterday to The New York Times Company by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board.

A sampling of scientific,] cultural and entertainment ] events at 35 sites in North] America and Europe will be/' televised live on both continents[ during the inaugural broadcast to be relayed by the Early Bird communications satellite.
The new-issue market is starting to heat up again after resting on Wall Street's cold back burner for more than three years.

ALTHOUGH the tragic character that Rod Steiger powerfully plays in the solemn new film, "The Pawnbroker," is very much a person of today -- a survivor of Nazi persecution who has become detached and remote in the modern world -- he casts, at it were, the somber shadow of the legendary, ageless Wandering Jew.

Your March 8 editorial "World's Biggest Boondoggle" is heavily critical of the proposed Rampart Canyon Project in Alaska. The term "conservation," frequently misunderstood, includes the careful, balanced use of natural resources in a manner that will assure their continued future availability.

THE greatest failure of the celebrated Ely Culbertson was undoubtedly his effort to popularize asking bids. This method of slam bidding was certainly efficient and an improvement on methods current in the thirties, but it was far too complex even for most experts.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 20 -- Chile's state-controlled copper department emphatically denied today a report circulating in New York that a meeting of world producers of copper had been planned here with the idea of raising the price for Chile's copper.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 20 (AP) -- A group of students at Rutgers University wants teachers as well as students to be graded.
The United States Rubber Company turned in first-quarter net earnings of $7.7 million, equal to $1.10 a share, up 18.3 per cent from the $6,542,318, or 90 cents a share, earned in the 1964 period.
Mrs. David Susskind, wife of the television producer, was awarded $750 a week alimony yesterday by Justice Arthur Markewich of the Supreme Court. It was one of the highest awards on record here.

While the Legislatures in New York and other states struggle to work out the consequences of the Supreme Court's reapportionment decision, Senator Everett Dirksen has been quietly pushing a constitutional amendment that would effectively reverse that decision.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 20 -- Gen. Hamilton H. Howze, commander of United States and United Nations forces in South Korea, authorized the Government today to move additional Korean troops into Seoul to assist the police in controlling civil disorders.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Assistant Secretary of Commerce Herbert W. Klotz said today he had had no specific information concerning the huge ore discovery of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company when he bought options on 2,000 shares of its stock.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (UPI) -- Ruben Amaro drove in Cookie Rojas from second base with a two-out single in the 13th inning tonight to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 2-1 victory over the Houston Astros.
The World's Fair and environs are going to steep the visitor in a warm-weather cultural brew of arts -- performing, visual, fine and some not so fine.

World's Fair connoisseurs -those who spent many hours and days touring the Flushing Meadow spectacle last year -have learned a few tricks to save wear and tear on the family pocketbook; to conserve energy while seeing a maximum of exhibits; to reduce the waiting time on lines before the popular shows.

GREEK honey cake, or karithopeta, would be a treat for unexpected guests because it will stay fresh for almost a week when stored in the refrigerator. The cake is flavored with walnuts and orange rind and is left to soak in a lemon-and-honey-flavored syrup until it is served. A recipe follows.

OF the 68 cars eligible to compete for the 33 starting positions in the 500-mile race at Indianapolis on May 31, 46 are of rear-engine design. Among the 22 with engines in conventional position in front of the driver are two four-wheel drive specials with supercharged V8 Novi engines and a front-wheel drive car entered by Mickey Thompson of Long Beach, Calif.
For the second consecutive day, volume on the American Stock Exchange surpassed the 3 million mark as declines outnumbered advances by a narrow margin.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- A contest for control of the Chicago taxi cab drivers' union between James R. Hoffa, the teamsters union president, and Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, picked up momentum today, following a quick visit last night by Hoffa.

The word "insider" was being used in Wall Street yesterday as it had not been since the early days of the New Deal. This followed the Securities and Exchange Commission's charge Monday that inside information about the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company's Timmins, Ont., ore strike of 1963-64 was used by 12 officers, directors and employes of the company to trade in Texas Gulf stock before the public was told of the rich find.
Experts on water resources met here yesterday to lay the groundwork for a conference to discuss a broad regional conservation and utilization program for the Northeast.
The Yankee Stadium outfiid railings were draped with fnagl ngber padding' yesterday to protect Mickey Mange. Roger .Marts and visitin, fly-chasers from injm'y.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The State Department reserved comment today on the decision by Prime Minister Shastri to cancel his trip to the United States.

A former assistant purser and a bellboy for the United States Lines were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in connection with the theft of $42,900 from a safe aboard the liner United States in 1960 when the ship was at sea.
Income $64,716,260, outgo $82,256,360. Result: deficit.
The United States Department of Commerce reported yesterday that new factory orders for durable goods totaled a seasonally-adjusted $21.2 billion in March, unchanged from the February level.

A leading economist from the Philippines said yesterday that tougher foreign competition had reduced the United States share in his country's foreign trade from 60 per cent to 40 per cent in the last eight years.

Arnold Johnson, public relations director of the Communist Party, U.S.A., has assailed formation of a new Progressive Labor party as an "effort of some sectarians to appropriate the name 'Communist.'"

HONG KONG, April 20 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a resolution passed by the standing committee of the National People's Congress of Communist China, as transmitted in English by the Hsinhua press agencys
The first stock financing of the Bell System this year was announced yesterday.
Mayor Wagner will outline tomorrow night a plan for more effective deployment of New York's 25,000-man police force.
The Pentagon has approved, in principle, the maintenance by the Army of a new type of division, equipped and trained to move around the battlefield and to supply itself with its own aircraft.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Army Engineers recommended to Congress today the authorization of Federal projects for harbor improvements at New York and at Newport News-Norfolk, Va.
The New York Yankees will make their first appearance at home today, nine days and six games after opening the baseball season in the West.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 -- The chairman of the Special Committee on Apartheid called on the Western powers today to halt all further investment in South Africa as a means of pressure against the white-supremacy policies of the Government.
Kids love fairs, and world's fairs are no exception.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20 -- The three oarsmen who stoked the engine room in the 1964 Yale varsity were in the Oxford crew that recently beat Cambridge handsomely on the Thames in England.

WASHINGTON -- April 20 (UPI) -- A House Republican leader charged today that Congress no longer thought for itself and attributed it to President Johnson and the heavy Democratic majorities in the House and Senate.
The elections of Robert L. Leeds Jr. and Laurence C. Leeds Jr. as executive vice presidents of the Manhattan Shirt Company were announced yesterday at the annual meeting here.
Brooklyn Navy Yard workers are being offered first chance at 2,500 new jobs at the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard.

The Turkish threat to expel all Greek nationals from Turkey and to "control" or even deport the Greek Orthodox Ecumenical Patriarchate is clearly a political move. It is part of the game of trying to force Greece to accede to talks between Greeks and Turks on Cyprus. The potential victims of this blackmail are the 6,000 Greeks living in Turkey, who are innocent of any involvement in the Cyprus conflict.

Wall Street lawyers predicted yesterday that a flurry of litigation would grow out of the Securities and Exchange Commission charges that Texas Gulf Sulphur Company insiders turned advance information on a major ore strike to their advantage in the stock market.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 -- Canada pledged support today to further efforts by 17 nonaligned nations to bring about a conference to end the fighting in Vietnam.

The Irving Trust Company, whose $3 billion of assets make it big but not very big by New York City standards, and the Merchants National Bank and Trust Company of Syracuse announced yesterday plans to link up by forming a holding company.

MONTREAL, April 20 -- The crowd of 14,438 at the Forum was brought to its feet twice tonight. The fans didn't have to bother the second time. Jean Beliveau's second-period goal was all the Montreal Canadiens needed as they turned back a dull Chicago Black Hawk sextet, 2-0.

The Bank of America, San Francisco, reported yesterday that its net operating earnings fell to $21,755,000, or 76 cents a share, in the first quarter from $22,989,000, or 81 cents, in the first quarter of 1964.
THOUGH the repertory be ever so familiar, there is nothing quite like the opening of a New York City Ballet season to set a New Yorker's pulse tingling and fill him with pride.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 20 -- Prince Abdul Rahman, Malaysia's Prime Minister, said tonight he had accepted a Japanese proposal for another meeting with President Sukarno in an attempt to end Indonesia's dispute with his country.
The prosecutor who obtained a second degree murder verdict against Mark Fein assumed a new role yesterday when he took the stand as his own witness in defense of his handling of the case.
New Yorkers will have an improved Flushing Meadow Park at the close of the World's Fair this year, but any idea of how much better it will be depends on the fair's success at the box office.
LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- Harry Scott of Britain won a controversial decision over Rubin Carter of Paterson, N.J., a leading challenger for the world middleweight crown, in a 10-round bout tonight.
The Consolidated Edison Company won the right yesterday to construct a power substation in the Morningside Heights area despite the strong opposition of two city agencies.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- President Johnson said today that he was encouraged by a growing community responsibility in the South toward giving the Negro full civil rights.
LONDON, April 20 -- Britain seems to have overcome her most pressing economic problems, but mounting pressure for increased wages and rising retail prices are posing new problems for the future.
State and city agencies and local business organizations are stepping up their activities touncover the fraudulent business practices of midtown "gift" shops that prey on out-of-townvisitors.
BOGALUSA, La., April 20 -- The Justice Department filed a lawsuit today in New Orleans to force six Bogalusa restaurants to serve Negroes in compliance with the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -The planet Mercury does not always keep one face to the sun as previously believed, radar astronomers reported today.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 -When William Edward Simkin, the steel-dispute mediator, went to Washington from Philadelphia in 1961 to talk about taking the job as director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, he casually asked Arthur J. Goldberg, then Secretary of Labor, how much the job paid.

A tentative agreement has been reached to sell the assets of the John Deere Chemical Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Deere Co., Chicago, to Nipak, Inc., Dallas, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Lone Star Producing Company, it was announced yesterday. Lone Star Producing is a subsidiary of the Lone Star Gas Company.

DAVID BRINKEY cast a wondering and skeptical eye over the City of Washington last night and more particular the hopes of The Great Society to beautify the nat onal capital. At its best his fihn, produced by Ted Yates, was a drolly humorous outing, but it also was often a formless hour with puzzling digressions and occasional lapses in taste.

Gathering and distributing news cost the United Press International $44,898,000 last year, an increase of $2,028,000 over 1963. Mims Thomason, president and general manager, told the service's annual business meeting yesterday.
A policeman on duty on an IRT subway train arrested a man for wielding a knife Monday night, but he had trouble finding anyone willing to make a complaint.
HAVANA, April 20 -- Cubans are wondering why Premier Fidel Castro is now speaking about "gorillas" instead of "worms."

A small Brooklyn garment manufacturing company will be able to triple its production facilities and the number of its employes as a result of a $21,500 loan it has just received from the City Industrial Development Corporation.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 20 -- Premier Suat Hayri Urguplu said in the Chamber of Deputies today that the Government was preparing "positive action" in the Cyprus dispute and would soon seek Parliamentary approval of a "serious decision."

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Representative Eugene J. Keogh announced today that he would retire from Congress at the end of his present term at the end of 1966, after having represented his Brooklyn district for 29 years.

SAIGON, South Vietnam April 20 (AP) -- Information given to reporters about the United States military role in Vietnam is under the supervision of the United States Information Service, the field units of the Information Agency.

The J.C. Penney Company will construct this fall its first, full-line department store in the New York area in the South Shore Mall Shopping Center, in Bay Shore, L.I. The 85-acre shopping center is owned by R.H. Macy Co., Inc.

BUFFALO, April 20 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York expressed "dismay" today over the new 2 per cent statewide sales tax but he made it clear later that he does not hold Governor Rockefeller responsible for it.
Business spokesmen don't expect the second season of the World's Fair to contribute to the city's output of goods and services as much as the first season did: more than $500 million.

The Central and South West Corporation's first quarter showed "continuing gains" and the outlook for the remainder of 1965 is "favorable," John S. Osborne, president, told 50 stockholders yesterday morning in the Plaza Hotel.

Milliman and Robertson, Inc., a Seattle consulting actuarial concern, has announced the appointment of William J. November as vice president in charge of its New York office. The appointment becomes effective July 1.
SALINAS, Calif., April 20 -- Representatives of organized labor said today that Northern California asparagus growers neither needed nor were legally entitled to emergency alien harvest labor.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 20 -- American airpower struck repeatedly today at fortified Vietcong villages in South Vietnam and at highways and a bridge in the North.
The bond markets appeared not quite sure yesterday which way they wanted to move.
Seventy-two per cent of comic strip readers are adults, the nation's newspaper publishers were told yesteday, and a question was raised as to whether the comics "have gone too adult."

" The Pirates of Penzance" made its first appearance of the season on the bill of the City Center Gilbert and Sullivan Company yesterday afternoon. Dean Ryan conducted a comfortable performance, not too fancy in musical style or in staging.
The stock market eased in late trading yesterday, possibly because traders grew uneasy when they learned that Chrysler's record first-quarter earnings came on a dip in the profit margin.
In a follow-through on its new "flight plan," Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday that it was consolidating its various advertising activities with one agency.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that 800 to 1,200 volunteers would participate in a voter-registration drive this summer in Alabama, Mississippi and South Carolina.
North American Aviation, Inc., one of the few aerospace companies reporting increased earnings, yesterday announced sharp increases in profits and sales for the quarter ended March 31.
A red-haired grandmother who lives in Flushing across the street from the World's Fair says of it: "I didn't go once last year." Would you believe it?"
Last week, for the first time in more than 10 years, fewer than 25,000 watched Kurt Hamrin work. The occasion was Hamrin's first appearance in the calm world of American soccer.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 20 (AP) -- Iraqi troops and air force jets have launched an assault to quell rebellious Kurdish tribes in northern Iraq, according to reports reaching here today.

ATLANTA, April 20 (UPI) -The segregationist Lester Maddox made an unsworn, 65-minute plea before an all-white jury today and won acquittal on charges of having pointed a pistol at a Negro who tried to integrate his restaurant last summer.
BONN April 20 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard called upon the United States again today to demonstrate fidelity to its pledge to work for the reunification of Germany.

The city killed a proposal yesterday for a middle-income housing project that civic groups had charged was part of a deal by an Assemblyman to "sell out" his opposition to the Lower Manhattan Expressway.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A device has been developed that enables a research ship to follow continuously the main axis of the Gulf Stream.

Those improvers of the breed who put stock into the "horses for courses" adage might take note that Affectionately, the 5-to-2 favorite to capture the Toboggan Handicap today at Aqueduct, has posted 17 of her 23 career-victories at the Big A.
An "alarming" vacancy rate of 9 per cent in competitive office buildings in Manhattan was reported yesterday by a group of the city's major real-estate executives.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., April 20 -- Gary T. Rowe, one of the four men originally accused by Federal officers in the slaying of Mrs. Viola Liuzzo, emerged today as an undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
MOSCOW, April 20 -- The Soviet leadership announced today that it was canceling a debt equivalent to more than $2 billion that the country's collective farms owed to the State Bank.
Paul Miller, president of The Rochester Times-Union and Democrat Chronicle, was re-elected president of The Associated Press yesterday at the board of directors meeting at 50 Rockefeller Plaza.

The Ford Foundation made grants yesterday to the Nieman Foundation of Harvard University and the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism aimed at improving the education of American newsmen.

The 1964 P.E.N. Translation Award will be presented to Joseph Barnes for his translation from Russian of "The Story of a Life," by Konstantin Paustovsky. The book was published last year by Pantheon. Mr. Barnes is senior editor of Simon Schuster. He will receive the award at a dinner of P.E.N., a world association of writers, at the Overseas Press Club on May 3.
There was a surprise birthday party for Mayor Wagner yesterday at Gracie Mansion. Ostensibly the party was a reception at the Mayor's residence for Willy Brandt, Mayor of West Berlin.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 21 -- A tall, scholarly man with a penchant for collecting first editions of the classics, Gov. Donald Stuart Russell reflects many of his personal traits in his administration. It has been quiet and

ALBANY, April 21 -- A substantial part of the voting power of upstate counties in the Assembly would be transferred to the New York City suburbs under the Democratic redistricting proposal that is now nearing completion.
Wearing a pink hat topped by a pink rose, Mrs. Alice Hirshfield scattered handfuls of wheat onto Sherman Square yesterday, and the first trial of a birth-control program for pigeons was under way.
Prices of most issues on the American Stock Exchange eased yesterday. The trading pace slumped following two days of hectic activity.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 21 (AP) -- Rational actions and realization of a state's responsibilities were called for today by a leading Alabama industrialist.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today he would seek legislation in the Senate to prevent local administration of the poverty program from becoming embroiled in politics.

Kenneth Rosewall of Australia was seeded first yesterday in the draw at the 21 Club for the professional indoor tennis championships at the 71st Regiment Armory. The tournament, bringing the top players here for the first time in two years, will start Wednesday and end Sunday, May 2.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Johnson Administration, disappointed by the absence of positive reaction to the President's offer of "unconditional discussions" on Vietnam, will apparently shift its concentration to a greater effort to win the ground war in South Vietnam.

KEENELAND, Ky., April 21 -- A classic race that has produced the last two winners of the Kentucky Derby will be contested at the Keenelaed race course tomorrow. The $25,000-addd Blue Grass Stakes, at 1 1/8 miles, will have its 41st running and despite a shallow field of six starters is expected to have a strong bearing on the 3-year-old thoroughbred picture.

The tiniest kingdom, in which Everyman has a gilt and diamond palace, had lain still all winter. The paint-bright vision of a summer's wonders had become like a vaguely remembered dream. Then the Wizard stirred -- he is a whole epoch of a man, and his wrath and his language have a glory their own.

Something like 7.9 million New Yorkers didn't go to the reopening of the World's Fair yesterday, and a considerable number of them, mostly young, ended up in midtown Manhattan, along with countless out-of-towners.

THIS IS the most readable story of the American people that has ever been written. It will be a long time before anyone matches Samuel Eliot Morison's achievement. It should be read by the millions for whom it is meant.

Newspapers have expanded employment faster than the national averages, and grown in size, circulation and advertising since World War II. And the prospect for the next decade is the greatest circulation increase in history.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has named William P. Sirignano executive director in addition to his present office as general counsel.

A long-term leasehold mortgage of $13,795,000 has been arranged by the Alexander Summer Mortgage Company of Newark for the final section of Horizon Houses, a tower apartment development overlooking the Hudson River at Fort Lee, N.J.
The Gorham Corporation, primarily known as a manufacturer of silverware products since 1831, is planning to expand the operations of its paper business.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 21 (AP) -- A two-run homer by Willie McCovey and Juan Marichal's tight pitching gave the San Francisco Giants a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

A full bottle of vermouth, half a bottle of rum and dancing to Latin-American music livened the occasion for a pair of burglars Tuesday night as they spent more than four hours looting a Washington Heights apartment.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 21 -President Makarios announced tonight that Greek Cypriote armed posts and road checkpoints would be removed in western and southwestern Cyprus, except "defenses against an external attack."

The Atomic Energy Commission has selected a joint proposal of the Douglas Aircraft Company and the United Nuclear Corporation as the basis for negotiation of a contract to operate the reactor and fuel fabrication facilities at the A.E.C.'s Hanford plant near Richland, Wash.

Robert Moses wasn't there, nor was Vice President Humphrey, nor were Winston Churchill's paintings. But 38,212 persons were at Yankee Stadium yesterday instead of at the World's Fair, as the Yankees, champions of the American League, opened their home season before the largest opening-day crowd in 13 years.
CLEVELAND, April 21 (AP) -- Leon Wagner's second home run of the game gave the Cleveland Indians a 10-inning, 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles Angeles in their home opener today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, said today that automation and manning scales would be the key issues in negotiating maritime contracts, most of which expire June 15.
BRIELLE, N.J., April 21 -- Undaunted by age or obesity, the fat ferryboat Cranford finally made it today to a new berth and the threshold of a new career.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 21 (UPI) -- Jan-Erik Lundquist of Sweden outlasted John Barrett, a former British Davis Cup captain, in the third round of the British hard-court tennis championships today. The scores were 4-6, 7-5, 3-6, 7-5, 6-4.
DUBLIN, April 21 -- Sean Lemass was re-elected Premier today by 72 to 67 in the new Dail Eireann (Lower House of Parliament ).

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 21 -- Michael Stewart, the British Foreign Secretary, said today that the Yugoslav Government had agreed that it was "unrealistic" to demand that the United States pull its forces out of Vietnam as a condition for negotiations on the crisis there.

BONN, April 21 -- The Western allies -- the United States, Britain and France -- protested to Soviet representatives today over the dropping of aluminum foil last Monday in the air corridors leading to West Berlin.

Dr. Carl Norcross, former executive editor of House Home magazine, has been named president of the newly formed Goodkin-Norcross Research Corporation in Washington, D.C. The company is a subsidiary of the Sanford R. Goodkin Research Corporation of Los Angeles, a real estate research and marketing company.

The introduction of a new system of financing Roman Catholic schools was advocated yesterday by a leading prelate. He urged also an end to "gimmicks" such as raffles, bazaars and sales of Christmas cards, candy, jewelry and school uniforms.

ALGIERS, April 21 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia and President Ahmed Ben Bella of Algeria joined today in attacking "United States interference' in South Vietnam. They called for "immediate negotiations" for a "peaceful solution."

CHICACO, April 21 (AP) -- Extra-base power helped the Cincinnati Reds to a 9-2 triumph over the Chicago Cubs today as Larry Jackson, a 24-game winner last season, failed as a starter for the third straight time.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- The New York Central Railroad's earnings in the first quarter of 1965 are expected to top those in the corresponding period last year by at least 30 per cent, Alfred E. Perlman, president of the railroad, said here today.
Industrial shares edged up yesterday in quiet trading on the London stock market.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 21 -- Phillips Talbot, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, arrived here today for brief talks on the Middle Eastern situation with Israeli leaders.
Edward G. Budd Jr., son of the late founder of the Budd Company, was elected yesterday to the new post of chairman. He continues as chief executive officer.
More than 150,000 persons -- half of them less than four feet tall -- swarmed across Flushing Meadow yesterday for the opening of the second season of the World's Fair.

A star circus clown, who had brought laughter to millions with his blinking neon eyeglasses and misfitting orange and red coat, was found murdered in his hotel room yesterday morning, a block from Madison Square Garden, where the circus is playing.

DETROIT, April 21 -- Detroit's City Plan Commission unveiled today plans for a $250 million, 200-acre cultural center. The center, expected to take at least 20 years to develop, would reserve 100 acres for new apartment housing around a core of landscaped parkland ringed by new theaters and museums.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 21 -- A rabbi urged today the lifting of what he termed the "5 o'clock iron curtain" that separates Roman Catholics, Jews and Protestants after they have been working together all day.

While visiting last week in New York I had the pleasure, among others of a cultural nature, of viewing some of the fine educational programs being presented on Channel 13, WNDT. This TV station, I am convinced, is a tremendous asset to New York, providing as it does an excellent range of classroom and adult programs.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission stayed its order today approving the proposed purchase of the Railway Express Agency, Inc., by the Greyhound Corporation.
NEW DELHI, April 21 (AP) -- Communist China has begun a crash program to convert Hainan Island "into the most modern all-purpose strategic base," an Indian Government publication says.

Amid rumors that a Texas banking group has been trying to buy control of the Royal National Bank of New York, the bank's directors put into effect yesterday, 70 days ahead of schedule, the resignation of R. Harold Bach as chairman and a director.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- President Johnson declared Wisconsin a major disaster area today and thus made it eligible for Federal financial help in efforts to recover from flood and tornado damage.
Eager crowds greeted new features at the World's Fair yesterday as pavilion managers, wreathed in smiles, counted heads.

LAWRENCEBURG, Tenn., April 21 (AP) -- State Troopers arrested approximately 60 Teamsters pickets at the Murray Ohio Company plant late today as strikers, some covered with grease to hamper officers, walked picket lines or sat down in exit roadways.
COLUMBIA, S.C., April 21 -- Gov. Donald S. Russell announced today that he would resign tomorrow to be appointed to the Senate seat vacated by the death of Olin D. Johnston.
Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, predicted yesterday that in less than two years most countries throughout the world would be linked together on a regular satellite system.
The election of Louis H. Powell and Richard H. Robinson as directors of the Colonial Sand and Stone Company was announced yesterday.

Customers' net credit balances, which show the borrowings of individual investors on margin, continued to move upward last month, according to figures released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 21 -- U Thant called on the 114 members of the United Nations today for greater efforts to avoid an impending crisis in the nuclear arms race.
WHITE PLAINS, April 21 -- Westchester officials said tonight that while they had received no rejection of the Hawthorne site, reports had circulated that an engineer had called it too hilly.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 21 -- Thirty-one African countries called tonight for the Security Council to meet "urgently" on the plan for an election May 7 in Rhodesia. The election could guarantee continued white control of the self-governing British colony and therefore threatens peace, the Africans asserted.

The City Center Gilbert and Sullivan Company gave its first performance of "The Yeoman of the Guard" this season at yesterday's matinee. The cast was, for the most part, familiar from last season's production, with Mary Burgess particularly admirable for her assured singing as Phoebe.
On April 17, in a season holy both to Christians and Jews, three things occurred bearing significantly on our ugly war in South Vietnam.

Seventeen-year-old Gary Schuster, who waited two days to be the World's Fair's first paying customer, got what he described as "a bum deal" yesterday morning when the main gate opened shortly after 8:30.
PITTSBURGH, April 21 -- I.W. Abel will be declared the official winner next week over the incumbent, David J. McDonald, in the election for president of the United Steelworkers of America.

Fiorentina of Florence, Italy, had to beat Eintracht of Frankfurt, West Germany, last night to win the first international Easter round-robin soccer tournament at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, and the Italians did just that.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Premier Aldo Moro of Italy held a second round of talks with President Johnson today and expressed "full understanding for the position and responsibilities of the United States" in Southeast Asia.
Twenty-five inhabitants of Adana were reported to have been executed in 1918 for possessing copies of the new resistance newspaper Yeni Adana.
The head of the Teamsters Union in New York accused State Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretski yesterday of "torpedoing" the proposed new state minimum wage of $1.50 an hour.

BANGKOK Thailand, April 21 (AP) -- An unidentified plane dropped three bombs that exploded harmlessly in the jungle in a northeastern province of Thailand near the Laotian border, a police spokesman said today.
HONG KONG, April 21 -- Communist China rejected today President Johnson's renewed offer of "unconditional discussions" for a peace settlement in Vietnam.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 21 -- The authority of Yemen's President, Abdullah al-Salal, has been diluted in a six-man Presidency Council, which is to "plan, direct and supervise the execution of state policy," the Sana radio announced last night.

JUNIOR showmanship, a form of dog show competition in which the proficiency of young people in handling dogs is judged, has become so important that specific rules should be adopted, said Wentzle Ruml Jr. of East Orange, N.J., yesterday.
MONTREAT, N.C., April 21 -- Samuel Jasper Patterson, a 64-year-old layman from San Antonio, Tex., was elected the 105th moderator of the Southern Presbyterian Church tonight.

NEWARK, April 21 -- The police investigated the possibility today that a man driving a car that smashed into a truck, killing his wife and seven of their children, might have deliberately caused the crash.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 21 -- United States and South Vietnamese aircraft flew round-the clock bombing missions today in an attempt to tie up North Vietnamese supply routes.

" Nobody Waved Goodbye," a Canadian National Film Board picture that opened yesterday at the Capitol and the Murray Hill Theaters, was reviewed by Bosley Crowther on Sept. 17, 1964, after its showing here at the New York Film Festival.
PITTSBURGH, April 21 -- The United Steelworkers America and the steel industry moved closer today to a possible strike May 1.

The New York Mets were 2,700 miles away yesterday, but their spirit invaded the 43d opening of Yankee Stadium -- one of the most festive openers since Babe Ruth started it all by hitting a home run against the Boston Red Sox on April 18, 1923.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- A new code of ethics for the teaching profession has been adopted by state associations representing 1.5 million of the nation's 2 million classroom teachers, the National Education Association said today.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI) -- News service printers of United Press International and The Associated Press have been placed in President Johnson's office.
The $30 million issue of Florida Power Corporation bonds offered to investors yesterday at a yield of 4.48 per cent was reported about 40 per cent sold by late afternoon.
A $15 million Issue of Republic of Venezuela bonds was offered to investors yesterday at a price to yield 6.354 per cent.

The agreement that the New Haven Railroad will continue commuter operations into New York at their present level for at least eighteen months from June 1 is a reprieve for 25,000 daily riders from Connecticut and Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Marine Corps sketched a picture today of the Leatherneck of 1985. He looked remarkably like Secret Agent James Bond or the man from U.N.C.L.E.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., April 21 -- The Long Island Lighting Company announced today that it planned to build a $75 million nuclear-powered plant in Suffolk County.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- It was a beautiful spring day in Washington today and President Johnson loves to walk -- and talk -- when the weather is fine.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Johnny Orsino smashed a two-out home run tonight in the 11th inning, giving the Baltimore Orioles a 3-2 victory over the Washington Senators.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, April 21 -- Fourteen persons, including four policemen, were killed in election violence today in the new eastern Sudan city of Khashm el Girba.

RAROTONGA, Cook Islands, April 21 (Reuters) -- Elections for a new Legislative Assembly here, heralding home rule for the 20,000 Cook Islanders, ended in a sweeping victory today for Albert Henry's Cook Islands party.
Vladimir Horowitz will return to Carnegie Hall on May 9 at 3:30 P.M. to give his first public concert in 12 years.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Navy League gibed indirectly at Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today in an attack on what it called one-man control of the Defense Department.
Rape cases in the city increased 6.6 per cent in the first three months of this year, according to a crime report issued yesterday by the Police Department.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- The Curtis Publishing Company registered "a modest operating profit -- $36,000 in the first quarter of 1965, John M. Clifford, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here today.

Little, Brown is preparing to issue Francis Parkman's New France history, in a nine-volume set. Samuel Eliot Morison, the historian, will write a general introduction to the series and a separate essay for each volume. Francis Parkman wrote this history for publication by Little, Brown from 1865 to 1892.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. urged the nation's 260,000 lawyers last night to help do away with unjust laws that are "out of harmony with the moral law of the universe."

MOSCOW, April 21 -- Soviet industrial production in the first spring of the post-Khrushchev era appeared to be off to a good start as the Government reported that the decline of the growth rate in the last two years had been checked.

The eyes -- not only of Texas, but also of the entire investment world -- will focus today on the annual meeting of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company in Houston. The meeting, which is scheduled to begin at 11 A.M. in the company's office at 811 Rusk Avenue, is expected to develop into one of the more intriguing stockholder sessions of the year.

A 22-day strike held first-quarter earnings of the American Can Company slightly below those in the initial three months last year, while sales edged up, William C. Stolk, president and chief executive officer, disclosed yesterday.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced yesterday that its Australian subsidiary had signed an agreement opening the way for a large-scale minerals search program in northwestern New South Wales.
LAPIDUM, Md., April 21 -- After unsuccessfully trying several spots on the Susquehanna River near here for hickory shad, now beginning to run up the river, I began talking to the fish.

First-quarter net earnings of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company rose to $10,218,000 from $8,204,710 in the 1964 initial quarter, J.P. Levis, chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Toledo, Ohio.

ALBANY, April 21 -- The State University said today that it was considering a number of sites for its projected four-year college in Westchester County, but that the controversial Hawthorne site was not one of them.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Directors of the Monon Railroad voted today a two-for-one split of its Class B shares and discussed strategy in the Monon's struggle with the Chesapeake Ohio Railway for control of the Chicago, South Shore and South Bend line.

LOS ANGELES, April 21 (UPI) -- Jerry West and Gene Wiley led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 126-105 victory over the Boston Celtics in the third game of the National Basketball Association playoffs tonight.
Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey was an outstanding attraction at the reopening yesterday of the World's Fair. And he was free, if something of a hazard.

In a letter to the Controller General, Chairman Adam Clayton Powell of the House Education and Labor Committee has made formal his demand that Federal antipoverty funds for New York, Chicago and Cleveland be cut off unless these cities give slum-dwellers a larger voice in the initiation and control of community action programs.

The electrical manufacturing industry expects record sales of $30.09 billion in 1965. This would be 4.8 per cent above the record $28.71 billion set last year, according to figures of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
MOSCOW, Thursday, April 22 (Reuters) -- The director and the star of the Soviet film "Hamlet" were awarded a Lenin Prize today.

The 1965 Mike Berger awards of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism were presented yesterday afternoon to Homer Bigart of The New York Times and Bernard Gavzer of The Associated Press.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.3 per cent in the week ended April 17 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

Rudi Gernreich's latest line features a modified topless swimsuit for younger sisters. Since the suits are for toddlers and preteens, there seems little likelihood of Gernreich's creation being banned on many beaches.
The British pound recovered from early weakness yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

TRENTON, April 21 -- Jim Clark of Scotland and Roger McCluskey of Tucson, Ariz., spent six hours today at Trenton Speedway breaking in two new Lotus Fords that have been earmarked for the 500-mile race at Indianapolis on May 31.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 21 -- The Government said today that it was determined to complete the Congo's marathon election on schedule next week.
Back in the Gay Nineties -- a thoroughbred race introduced at the old Morris Park cavalry grounds in the Bronx was named the Toboggan Handicap because it was to be held on a downhill course.

THE veteran metropolitan master Walter Shipman won the recent Atlantic Open, topping a field of 134 by the score of 5 1/2-1/2 in a six round Swiss system. James Gore and Bernard Zuckerman, both of New York, tied for second and third with 5-1 each.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Final action by the Interstate Commerce Commission on the Pennsylvania-New York Central Railroad merger was set back by an order today extending from April 28 to July 12 the deadline for submitting exceptions to the plan.

Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., put part of its annual meeting on video tape yesterday with the idea that television viewers might like an inside view of "corporate democracy'' at work. Some stockholders seemed very much aware they were on camera.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest declined slightly in the month ended April 15 by 76,000 shares to 6,675,780.
The election of William A. Silverman as president was announced yesterday by the W.F. Schrafft Sons Corp., Boston producer of confectionery products.

The cautious April 9 statement of James Reston suggesting an exchange of emissaries with the Vatican is one that deserves a prompt reply. It should be made clear that there is a vast volume of public opinion in this country which is solidly set against any such exchange.

Last night's program by Wayne Raper, oboe, and the Philadelphia String Quartet in Carnegie Recital Hall might be reckoned a bonus of the previous evening's visit by the Philadelphia Orchestra, for all five participants are members of that ensemble.

AKRON, Ohio, April 21 (AP) -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company came to terms with the United Rubber Workers tonight after Firestone Tire and Rubber and B.F. Goodrich had reached similar agreements with the union during the day.

YONKERS, April 21 -- Important questions will be answered tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway, where the 16th annual Good Time Pace, a $50,000 event, tops the card. Eight pacers, including Smoke Cloud, Cardigan Bay and Safe Return from New Zealand and five American-bred and owned horses, are scheduled to participate in the 1 1/4-mile test.

THE Royal Ballet of England opened its eighth American tour last night in a manner that was nothing if not grand. The audience that packed the Metropolitan Opera House was headed by Vice President and Mrs. Humphrey and included distinguished representatives of the diplomatic, political and theatrical worlds.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- James K. Hitt, president of the American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers, said today that the problem of getting into a college or university was even tougher than the experts had realized.

The Empire State Building which serves as an office structure, a television antenna tower and a place to study the habits of migratory birds, has a new use. It will be a smoke-watching station for the Consolidated Edison Company.
