Crompton (Tommy) Smith and Jay Trump will soon be off to Paris. The first American jockey to ride an American-owned and bred horse to victory in the Grand National is ready to begin "homework" for an unusual steeplechase with his unusual winning 8-year-old gelding.

Robert Moses epitomized the World's Fail slogan of "Peace Through Understanding" when he reopened the fair yesterday with kind words, solicitous deeds, and a philosophy of patience and tolerance that was more Job than Jove.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The White House sought today to make amends for an increasingly embarrassing diplomatic snub by again putting out a welcome mat for Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India.

The Medical Letter, a privately published journal of drug evaluation for the medical profession, disclosed yesterday that the new edition of U.S. Pharmacopoeia has dropped the listing of Meprobamate, popularly marketed as Miltown.
BOSTON, April 21 (AP) -- Moose Skowron's home run, with two out and a man on base in the 11th inning, gave the Chicago White Sox a 3-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

Two short German operas proved to be excellent material for the Mannes College of Music opera workshop in performances at the school last night. They were Ernst Toch's 12-minute "Edgar and Emily" and Boris Blacher's 40-minute "The Tide."
LOS ANGELES, April 21 -- In 19 consecutive years with the Braves, in Boston and Milwaukee, Warren Spahn scored 356 victories. But in his second start as a New York Met, he scored a triumph.

William S. Paley, chairman of the board of Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., disclosed at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that C.B.S. would obtain all rights to the film version of "My Fair Lady" on Oct. 21, 1971, seven years after the movie was released.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Six learned men met in New York the other day to discuss man's chances of surviving in the kind of world that man is creating. The papers report that they were mildly optimistic.

NYLON, which has ruled the stocking world for a quarter of a century, now has a loud-mouthed rival named Vectra. But, in spite of a flamboyant advertising campaign, the new fiber has not made much headway against the older one, a survey of stores here shows.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Man is not likely to know whether it is safe to land on the moon until he tries it, a leading astro-physicist said today.
PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., April 21 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. came to upstate New York tonight to pursue a new and muted version of his campaign for the Governorship.
Prices of copper futures dropped the daily limit yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange in direct response to the settlement of the Chilean rail strike.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- William H. Orrick Jr., the head of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, defended his office's polices today against those who say those policies are hurting business growth.

Grief D. Patterson, senior partner in the Chicago law firm of Winston, Strawn, Smith Patterson, was elected a director of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation at its annual meeting yesterday in Boston.

CARSON CITY, Nev., April 21 (AP) -- The Nevada Gaming Commission issued an emergency order today suspending the licenses of Ruby Kolod as principal operator of the Stardust and Desert Inn casinos at Las Vegas.

THE Yankee Stadium glistened resplendently in the bright sunshine yesterday for another home opening. There is always a distinctiveness to any opening. The stands were festooned with bunting and the fans seemed just a bit gayer and in a more festive mood.
The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association held its annual meeting here yesterday and the emphasis was on the bureau's creative program.

The stock market wallowed in heavy seas most of yesterday, but made some headway in late trading. The over-all result was the least impressive market performance since the rally to historic high ground began three weeks ago.
R.H. Macy Co. agreed yesterday to charge prices set by Heublein, Inc., for Heublein liquor products under the Feld-Crawford Law, the so-called "fair trade" act.

DETROIT April 21 (AP) -- Don Demeter's two-out double in the fourth inning scored Norm Cash and enabled the Detroit Tigers to post a 1-0 victory over Kansas City today. It was the home opener for the Tigers and it drew 32,658 fans.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (UPI) -- The operator of a variety store was adjudged guilty today in the wood alcohol deaths of 17 "skid row" derelicts.
Allied Stores Corporation's flirtation with discounting has blossomed into a serious romance.

ROME, April 21 -- The Italian Communist party's Secretary, Luigi Longo, said today there was a need for a "unified Socialist party" -- a proposal described by a well-informed observer as "a new-sheepskin for the same blasphemed old wolf the popular front."
A top management change was unexpectedly announced yesterday by Prentice-Hall, Inc., the book publishing company.
FREEPORT, L.I., April 21 -- A pawnbroker here says he has been offered $3,500 for a 132-year-old violin he obtained for a $40 loan and he is willing to split his profit.

LA CROSSE, Wis., April 21 (AP) -- The Mississippi River laid siege to La Crosse with a record flood stage today, and sent a mighty torrent southward, where it claimed a half-mile strip of Dubuque, Iowa.

Everywhere Rudolf Nureyev walked yesterday -- across Madison Avenue, down Park, into the Russian Tea Room for lunch -- people turned to stare at him. They watched his every step, every gesture and every twitch, hoping perhaps to learn the secret.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- On the initiative of its majority leader, Mike Mansfield, the Senate today responsibly fulfilled the role assigned to it by the Constitution to "advise" the President on foreign affairs.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 21 -- The stringent operation of South Africa's General Law Amendment Act was illustrated today in the marriage of a man deprived of liberty by the act.
The "Seven Sisters," women's colleges, like the Ivy League colleges, are feeling the effects of the civil rights movement.
ST. LOUIS April 21 (AP) -- Bill White and Lou Brock ,snapped St. Louis out of a hitting slump tonight as the Cardinals beat the Milwaukee Braves, 6-3.

The United States Navy is employing Japanese seamen of "questionable" qualifications to man a fleet of small vessels engaged transporting supplies to South Vietnam, Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, charged yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 21 -- The Illinois Senate voted 31 to 23 today against the reappointment of Charles Gray to the state's Fair Employment Practices Commission.
BALTIMORE, April 21 -- Prospects dimmed today for an early settlement of the Newspaper Guild strike that has closed all daily newspapers here. The Guild includes news and commercial employes.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., April 21 -- A grand jury investigating the slaying of Mrs. Viola Liuzzo completed its deliberations here today. It was reported to have voted three murder indictments. The all-white panel considered the Liuzzo killing for 52 minutes this afternoon. It then adjourned to report to Judge T. Werth Thagard at 9 A.M. tomorrow.

Representative Eugene J. Keogh of Brooklyn, finding it "increasingly difficult" to serve in the House and also engage in his law practice and private business ventures, has decided to retire from Congress next year. Congress and the nation are likely to find the loss bearable.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A Japanese seismologist reported today that he may have stumbled on a way to predict earthquakes.

A POPULAR feature of English bridge clubs that is unknown in America is the partnership session. One or two afternoons and evenings each week are designated in advance for partnership rubber bridge, in which players retain their chosen partners throughout.

The Controller General of the United States is preparing a legal determination of whether antipoverty projects of the city administrations in New York, Cleveland and Chicago meet the intent of Congress as expressed in the Economic Opportunity Act.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Jake Jacobsen, an Austin, Tex., lawyer and friend of President Johnson, has joined the White House staff.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 21 -- Miguel Arrais, former Governor of Pernambuco, held by military authorities for more than a year as a "subversive," was released today on orders from President Humberto Castello Branco.

A capacity audience went to Town Hall last night for a music lesson. In the course of the evening, those present were thoroughly entertained and also contributed to a worthy cause, the scholarship fund of the Manhattan School of Music.

THE Munich Bach Chorus and Orchestra last night brought Bach's B minor Mass to a capacity audience at Carnegie Hall. The Mass is no novelty, but complete performances are rare these days, so it was not surprising to see the large crowd.
A committee of prominent New Yorkers has proposed that the city radically change its methods of dealing with criminal offenders in order to reduce the overcrowding in prisons and detention homes.

Criminal Court Judge Herbert I. Sorin was attacked by two youths, who threw him to the sidewalk and pummeled and robbed him Tuesday evening near the house in the East New York area of Brooklyn where he has lived since 1906.

Latin America is being urged to give immediate consideration to a bold concept -- a continental common market. An integration plan has been drawn up by four of Latin America's most distinguished economists. They ask each government to approve establishment of a Latin-American parliament and of an "institutional mechanism" for an economic union.
ATHENS, April 21 -- Olympic Airways, the Greek national airline owned by Aristotle Onassis, announced today it had ordered three Boeing 707 jetliners at cost of $30 million, including spare parts.

Robert Rosenblatt, a former broker, pleaded guilty today to having stolen $125,695 from people who gave him money to invest. He had been indicted on 32 counts of grand larceny, involving theft of more than $429,000 from investors who included his mother-in-law and a former college roommate. He pleaded guilty to six counts.
PARIS, April 21 -- President de Gaulle will deliver a television address to the nation on Tuesday, the Government announced today.
LOS ANGELES, April 21 -- The Mets' dreams of scaling new heights were rudely dispelled tonight by Don Drysdale and the Los Angeles Dodgers, who beat the New Yorkers, 5 -- 1.

Robert Rosenblatt, a former broker, pleaded guilty today to having stolen $125,695 from people who gave him money to invest. He had been indicted on 32 counts of grand larceny, involving theft of more than $429,000 from investors who included his mother-in-law and a former college roommate. He pleaded guilty to six counts.
PARIS, April 21 -- President de Gaulle will deliver a television address to the nation on Tuesday, the Government announced today.

The case of Victor Shange and the five other South African Negroes who are asking for political asylum demands closer scrutiny by the Government. These men, who have no rights of the citizen in their own country, and indeed who now face the retaliation of the South African system if they are forced to return, are in a lonely predicament.

The Royal Ballet disrupted the dinner hour last night by opening at 7 P.M., but the balletomanes, Anglophiles and other New Yorkers who showed up at the Metropolitan Opera House did not seem to mind. A lot of them, especially those in the upper tax brackets, had fortified themselves with such things as caviar sandwiches, smoked salmon, vodka or champagne.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 21 -- Serbian literary circles were surprised this month by the reappearance of writings by Radovan Zogovic, leading cultural arbiter of the Stalinist school from 1945 to 1948.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed by voice vote today President Johnson's nomination of Palmer Hoyt, editor and publisher of The Denver Post, as a member of the United States Advisory Commission on Information.
The Port of New York said good-by yesterday for the second time within a month to a grand old lady of the Atlantic. This time it was the 37-year-old Italian Line's Vulcania.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution renewed their criticism of the United Nations today as they adopted 12 resolutions, nearly unanimously.
Salvador Dali has signed a contract with Jack Winter, sportswear, to design the first Dali collection of women's apparel.
LONDON, April 21 -- Some of the contents of one of Britain's most richly endowed ancestral homes, Harewood House, will go under the auctioneer's hammer next June to pay for the estate's upkeep.
PHILADELPHIA April 21 (UPI) -- The Houston Astros scored four runs in the eighth inning and five in the ninth tonight and routed the Philadelphia Phillies, 11-4.

TORONTO, April 21 -- The world's biggest nickel producer, the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., earned a record profit on record nickel deliveries in the first quarter of 1965, the annual meeting was told today.
BOGALUSA, La., April 21 -- A group of Negroes expressed their glowing dissatisfaction with Bogalusa's city administration by picketing City Hall for more than an hour today.
The Florida Power Corporation sold $30 million of first-mortgage bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate managed by the First Boston Corporation.
The United Nations Secretary General, U Thant, reaffirmed a "willingness and desire" yesterday to help find "some basis for mutual accommodation, if not for a permanent solution," in Vietnam.
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -The American Telephone and Telegraph Company painted a bright picture for the 4,128 stockholders who trooped into Convention Hall here today for its 80th annual meeting.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 22 -- Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., took his case against Federal regulation of network television programing before the American Association of Advertising Agencies here today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 22 -- A growing wave of strikes and street demonstrations by thousands of university and high school students in the larger cities prompted the Government today to place the railroads under army personnel.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- In the wildest, best played and most amazing game of these Stanley Cup finals, the Chicago Black Hawks turned in a stunning performance tonight to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 3-1.

BALTIMORE, April 22 -- This port's poor longshore safety record appears to be directly related to the almost complete lack of a safety training program for lower echelon supervisory personnel in the stevedoring industry, a high-ranking Department of Labor official said here today.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 22 -- Continued United States economic aid at the present level will soon put South Korea over the "one step" needed for self-sufficiency, President Chung Hee Park declared today in an interview.

In a "press conference in reverse," two United States Senators asked questions and news executives went on the defense yesterday to contend that newspapers now provide more diversity than ever before.
The London stock market maintained its recent film tendency yesterday on light trading.
LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- In an exchange of grievous mistakes, the Los Angeles Dodgers emerged with a 2-1 victory over the New York Mets tonight as Sandy Koufax out-pitched Jack Fisher.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -Assistant Secretary of Commerce Herbert W. Klotz resigned today, just 72 hours after a disclosure that he had bought stock in the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company on the basis of an indirect tip from a company insider.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 22 -- The official Bulgarian Telegraph Agency ended its two-week silence today on reports of a plot against the pro-Soviet leadership. It denied that a coup had been attempted, but acknowledged that high officials had been arrested.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, April 22 (Reuters) -- Another election clash loomed tonight as the Interior Minister, Clement Mboro, threatened to use force if the People's Democratic party went ahead with a rally planned for tomorrow.
The Congress of Racial Equality said yesterday that it would demonstrate at the World's Fair at 11 A.M. on Sunday as "the first step in the CORE campaign against the re-election of Mayor Wagner."

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 22 (UPI) -- Gardner Dickinson, a wiry, 130-pounder, fought pain and par with equal success today to grab the first-round lead in the $50,000 Texas open golf touranment with a five-under-par 32, 33 -- 65.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- A $100 million borrowing program to provide additional financing for Crown Zellerbach Corporation's growth needs was announced to share holders at the annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -As the sun rose early yesterday over Australia it was almost without blemish. But by the time it appeared over Sicily an angry cluster of new sunspots had emerged, heralding the start of a new 11-year cycle.
MONTREAT, N.C., April 22 -- The Southern Presbyterian Church is debating whether to cancel a speaking invitation issued by one of its agencies to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

PARIS -- The partition of both Germany and Europe began, in a sense, twenty years ago when, on April 25, 1945, American and Russian infantry units met upon the Elbe River. The Reich was cut in two and, around it, the Continent.
Hunch bettors in the crowd of 29,825 that turned out at Aqueduct yesterday in shirtsleeve weather should have had no difficulty in picking the winner of the $10,000 Primrose.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -In the last few days, President Johnson has asked the leaders of India and Pakistan to postpone their state visits to Washington, and advised the press that he has changed his mind about traveling soon to Latin America and Europe.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 22 (AP) -- The rampaging Mississippi River posed new threats today to communities along a 400-mile stretch in a four-state area.

Alice Esty's annual recitals have come to be anticipated with interest for the new works she introduces. At Carnegie Recital Hall last night, the soprano sang compositions written on commission from her by Daniel Pinkham, who was in the audience, and by Darius Milhaud.

YONKERS, April 22 -- Bengazi Hanover captured the $50,000 Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight, outfinishing a field that had been watered down and weakened by late scratches. While the victory of the 4-year-old son of Tar Heel was conclusive as he defeated Irish Napoleon by three-quarters of a length in the 1 1/4-mile classic, the withdrawal of Cardigan Bay and Safe Return took more than a bit away from the event.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., April 22 -- Alabama's Attorney General, Richmond M. Flowers, asked Gov. George C. Wallace today to join him in an investigation of the Ku Klux Klan in Alabama.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- Charlie Dressen, looking thinner but well, made a visit to the New York Mets' dugout before last night's 5-1 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers. A mild heart attack had taken the Detroit Tiger manager away from his club during spring training, and he was now an impatient but cheerful convalescent.

RICHMOND, April 22 -- The creation of a Congressional committee or a Presidential commission to investigate restrictions on business mergers has been suggested here by Stuart T. Saunders, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -Senate leaders opened debate on the voting rights bill today with a moving appeal to members to make finally effective for Southern Negroes the rights proclaimed in the Declaration of Independence and embodied in the Constitution.

Miriam McCaffery, a pioneer in the teaching and practical application of casework and public welfare in voluntary social work, was honored last night upon her retirement after 30 years as a professor at the Columbia University School of Social Work.

Barry Golomb, counsel for the Bronx County Medical Society, in his letter published April 8 labels me a "hospital administrator" -- evidently in an effort to deny my competence to speak concerning threats to Medicare as I did in my letter printed March 24.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -Negro leaders gave notice to the Government today that on Monday in Cleveland they would begin a series of demonstrations against discriminatory hiring practices on Federal building projects.

HOUSTON, April 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission "summarily rejected" an offer by Texas Gulf Sulphur Company office's and directors to surrender to the mining concern profits they hade made in its stock. Claude O. Stephens saw yesterday.
The pressure of supply is getting heavier for municipal bond underwriters and lighter for corporate bond investment bankers.

The vote of the steel union's Wage Policy Committee to authorize a strike on May 1 confronts the economy with another test of strength in an industry that had seemed in recent years to be moving toward lasting peace between labor and management.
LONDON, April 22 (AP) -A guards officer making his predawn round of the Tower of London discovered that the main gate was unguarded.

The Rev. Billy Graham predicted yesterday that the United States would create "a truly multiracial society" within a generation. The Baptist evangelist spoke at Mayor Wagner's second annual Prayer Breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria.
BALTIMORE, April 22, (AP) -- A horse named Mr. Ping, ridden by a jockey named Leonard Pong, won the third race at Pimlico Race Course today and returned $9.40, $6 and $5.20 for $2 across the board.
The Drama League of New York will hold its annual spring luncheon next Thursday in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 22 -- An atmosphere of reasonableness marked the statements of the Soviet Union and the United States today at the second meeting of the committee of 33 to study peacekeeping operations and report to the General Assembly by Jun. 15.

The Overseas Press Club announced yesterday that the George Polk Memorial Award was being given posthumously to George Clay of the National Broadcasting Company, who was killed by rebel gunfire in the Congo last Nov. 24.
BONN, April 22 -- The directors of Volkswagenwerk, monarch of the West German automobile industry, voted today to recommend to shareholders dividends of 20 per tent of base capital for 1964.
Premier Aldo Moro of Italy arrived in New York last night after an automobile trip from Washington. En route he paid a visit to Philadelphia.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 22 -Sing Sing Prison was picketed by 300 state employes in relays today in protest against pay scales, a lack of collective bargaining and continuance of the Condon-Wadlin Law barring strikes by public employes.
The closing of three major Army transport terminals, in line with Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's recent cutback order, will save the Government more than $14 million a year.
THE rain in Italy is apparently as inspirational to fashion designers as it is elsewhere in the world.

Within the past ten days The Times has reported delivery to the Presidents of all Latin-American nations of a thirty-page report prepared by four outstanding hemispheric leaders proposing the establishment of a Latin-American common market, Vice President Humphrey's endorsement of the idea for the Administration and my call for an action committee for the economic union of the Americas.

The Board of Education said yesterday that it would abolish its 138 junior high schools by 1973 and take other steps to provide "excellence of education" for the city's one million public school pupils.

JACKSON, Miss., April 22 -Civil rights workers told a statewide biracial organization today that the racial climate was easing in Mississippi and that there was less likelihood of another explosive summer.

Spectacular business of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., in the final quarter raised sales and earnings of the big department store chain in the year ended Jan. 31 to the highest levels in its 122-year history.
The Shell Oil Company announced record quarterly earnings at its annual meeting yesterday.
Militancy and controversy rather than submission and conformity were urged on Roman Catholic students yesterday by Sister Margaret, president of Trinity College in Washington.
SAIGON, April 22 -- North Vietnam was reported today to have halted all daylight activity in its central region and to have instructed the population to take cover.
Attractive first-quarter earnings continued to crowd the financial wires yesterday and helped traders overcome misgivings on the steel negotiations.

ALBANY, April 21 -- The Court of Appeals rejected today a protest by a group of Manhattan parents that the rezoning of the area served by Public School 6 had discriminated against their children by excluding them from the student body.
Like Old Man River, the Minnesota Twins just kept rolling along yesterday, hitting three more home runs and overpowering the New York Yankees for the third straight time this season.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- The State Department denied today that the United States had offered scholarships to 29 Kenya students who left a Soviet university after having charged discrimination and "indoctrination."
CHICAGO, April 22 -- A cross section of college officials from Massachusetts to California defended the computer today as the best friend a burdened campus administration ever had.
Byong Chun Kim, a tenor from Korea who has studied at the Juilliard School of Music and sung locally for the Asia Society, gave his first Town Hall recital last night.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- The Soviet leadership called today for "united action" of Communist parties against the "aggressive forces of imperialism." Its statement was inter preted as a bid to Peking to tone down the ideological differences between the two parties in the interests of increased Communist effectiveness in Vietnam.
BOSTON, April 22 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. brought the 20th-century civil-rights crusade north today to the cradle of the 19th-century abolitionist movement.

The Democratic plan for reapportioning and redistricting the State Legislature is being drafted behind the locked doors of Room 415-A of the Capitol. The maps and charts being drawn by the Joint Legislative Committee on Reapportionment are secrets, guarded as carefully as those in a war room. Assemblyman Louis F. DeSalvio, who heads the committee, says that the plan for redistricting the Assembly will not be ready until the end of next week.

ATLANTA, April 22 (UPI) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen struck the Southern Railway in a surprise walkout that snarled traffic throughout the South today. But the union ended the strike after a Federal Court ordered crewmen back to their trains.
The Penn Relays which provide more action than Times Square on New Year's Eve, will start today at noon. Five hours later, St. John's hopes to win one of the day's two major races.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- Luis Aparicio led a 20-hit attack tonight as the Baltimore Orioles set a D.C. Stadium scoring record by beating the Washington Senators, 18-4. Aparicio drove in four of the runs with a homer, a double land two singles in five official times at bat.
LONDON, April 22 -- Harold Wilson's Labor Government will move next week to take into complete public ownership companies producing 85 per cent or more of British steel.

The St. Regis Roof was filled to its Capacity of 275 persons last night for the fourth annual Botticelli Ball for the benefit of Orphans of Italy, Inc., which maintains orphanages in Verona, Naples, Chioggio, Salerno and Palermo. The decor was in green, yellow and white, the colors of the Italian flag.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 22 -- Andrew Wilson, a director and retired chairman of the County Trust Company of White Plains, died here yesterday at his home, 401 Fort Hill Road. He was 73 years old.

Rebounding from Wednesday's decreases, prices of copper futures closed sharply up yesterday in active trading on the New York Commodity Exchange. Wednesday's drop was in response to news of the settlement of the Chilean rail strike.
The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company's application to take over the First National Bank in Yonkers was rejected yesterday by Frank Wille, New York State Superintendent of Banks.
Most stocks on the American Stock Exchange moved higher yesterday as volume edged up to 2.42 million shares from 2.20 million shares on Wednesday.
A NEW YORK couple who have been trying out a "mother's helper" with a difference report that they are delighted with the results. The difference is that their nursemaid is a young man.

The Sierra Club of San Francisco, a conservation organization with 27,000 members around the nation, received the Carey-Thomas Award yesterday for "a distinguished project of creative publishing," for its books about the Grand Canyon and California's disappearing redwood trees.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -Gov. Donald S. Russell of South Carolina has decided to brave the hazards of being an "instant Senator" and thus has made himself eligible for the mythical J.J. Hickey Award. The award is named for a former Governor of Wyoming who is perhaps the classic example of the bleak fate that can overtake a Governor who has had himself appointed to the United States Senate to fill an unexpired term.

Frank S. Adams's "Modernizing Our Penal Code," in your edition of April 19, calls welcome attention to the revision of the New York Penal Law which is now before the Legislature. He is inaccurate, however, in attributing to me the guidance of the drafting commission and direction of its staff.
MOSCOW, April 22 -- The Soviet Union's orthodox Marxist economists have suffered a severe setback as a result of the awarding of the Lenin Prize to a group of reformers they opposed.

ATHENS, April 22 -- Greece has decided to break off discreet diplomatic exchanges with Turkey as a result of Ankara's open hostility toward the Greek minority and the Greek Orthodox Church in Istanbul.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 22 -A "peace" conference proposed by Ahmed Mohammed Noman, New Premier of the republican Government of Yemen, will deal with conflicts among Republicans and not with strife between republicans and royalists, according to diplomatic information reaching Beirut.
A New York County grand jury will begin an investigation next month into conditions in the Women's House of Detention. District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday.

The 4 per cent retail sales tax yielded the city $328,605,477 for three-quarters of the fiscal year that will end June 30. The sum was $21,119,713 above the collections for the corresponding period of the year before.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Retail sales in the United States during the week before Easter rose 8 per cent above the level of the previous week and 15 per cent higher than in the pre-Easter week of 1964.
A suspected narcotics seller was shot and killed by a plainclothes patrolman at 12:20 A.M. today in the rear courtyard of a tenement at 27 East 110th Street, according to the police.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Mrs. William Henry Sullivan Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., was officially declared the winner by 184 votes tonight in a close vote for the post of president-general of the Daughters of the American Revolution.
A German shepherd led detectives yesterday to an apartment where, the police said, her master and two other men were running a $5,000-a-day bookmaking operation.

The Board of Education's "Statement of Policy" for the achievement of "excellence for the schools of New York City" gives bright promise of a new start. It is no more and no less than an order to the professional school administration and an appeal to the political authorities and the public to forget the fumbling, obsolete, disunited past and to create a better future.

BERKELEY, April 22 -Leaders of the Free Speech Movement at the University of California tried unsuccessfully today to provoke the school's administrators into actions that would arouse lagging student support.

AFTER the hazards of conducting "Die Walkure," "Aida," and "Vanessa" at the Metropolitan Opera, William Steinberg appeared to be easing into his second six-week engagement with the New York Philharmonic this season by presenting an all-Mendelssohn program in Philharmonic Hall last night.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 -- Lucky Debonair, Mrs. Ada L. Rice's brilliant campaigner, did the expected today in winning the $30,400 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland. The son of Vertex and Fresh as Fresh scored by a half-length over Earl Allen's Swift Ruler.
Al Hirt, the large and bearded trumpeter, appeared last night at Carnegie Hall with a 19-piece orchestra drawn from the cream of New York's freelance jazz musicians.

The credibility of the United States Government has been one of the numerous casualties of the war in Vietnam. Time after time high-ranking representatives of government -- in Washington and in Saigon -have obscured, confused or distorted news from Vietnam, or have made fatuously erroneous evaluations about the course of the war, for public consumption.
ALBANY, April 22 -- Governor Rockefeller's ambition to transform downtown Albany is a step nearer realization.
ON the top of a grove of black pines near Jones Beach the wriggling pillars of white were egrets.

The Family Finance Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed public offering of $35 million of senior debentures due May 15, 1990.
Trading volume on the American Stock Exchange in the first quarter soared to 112.2 million shares, the third highest in the exchange's history. Edwin D. Etherington, president, announced yesterday.
Stanley Steingut's supporters, overriding his objections, have decided to meet with Mayor Wagner to discuss the leadership impasse that has split the Kings County Democratic organization.

CUERNAVACA, Mexico, April 22 -- Some of the Western Hemisphere's philosophers, writers, political scientists and government officials are discussing here this week the hemisphere and its relations to the world.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 22 -- The appointment of Dr. Bert James Loewenberg as director of the Center for Continuing Education was announced yesterday by Dr. Paul L. Ward, president of Sarah Lawrence College.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 22 -- Forensic fury, facts and figures filled the Military Academy here today as the "world series of debate" began its 19th annual three-day stand.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -The consensus among the directors of United States aid missions in the Latin American countries is that 1965 "will be the year of noticeable advances" under the four-year-old Alliance for Progress.

Stockholders of the Interlake Steel Corporation were told yesterday that the company, enlarged by a merger last year, registered record sales and earnings in the first quarter of this year and that the full year should be a good one.
Pennsylvania has created one of the most favorable "business climates" in the nation, Gov. William W. Scranton said yesterday.
BOSTON, April 22 -- A prominent Massachusetts state legislator and seven other persons, including several present and former state officials, were indicted today by a special grand jury.

Many persons gave cocktail parties last night before the dinner dance held in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club. The boys and girls of the Kips Bay chorus entertained the guests.

DURING the last ten years scores of novels have been published reporting in fictional terms the political changes that have swept over Africa. Some were melodramas written by men who bitterly expected the worst and who laid their stories in the future, so their predictions can not yet be proved wrong.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 22 -- Mayor Wagner and city officials called on the Secretary General, U Thant, today to discuss the merits of Welfare Island as an alternative site for the United Nations International School.

While volume booms these days at the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange, a churchyard tranquility prevails at the city's third securities marketplace -the National Stock Exchange.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 22 -The "peace offensive" of President Makarios is being regarded with suspicion by Turkish Cypriotes.

IF asked to name the bridge event that attracts the highest percentage of New York's experts, most players would probably select the Reisinger Trophy contest, the knockout championship of the Eastern Regionals which begin at the end of May.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 22 -- A team of Turkish officials today began a detailed examination of the finances of the Eastern Orthodox Patriarchate today but agreed to suspend the inspection until Monday, after the Orthodox observance of Easter.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 22 -- Prince Souphanouvong, leader of the Pathet Lao, the pro-Communist Laotian faction, left here this morning in the company of Communist China's Foreign Minister, Chen Yi.
Two power stations of the Consolidated Edison Company -one new and one old -- were inspected yesterday by members of a City Council committee investigating sources of air contamination.
A 10-week-old strike by social workers and other employes of the Henry Street Settlement ended yesterday.
LONDON, April 22 -- Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip were lampooned from a West End stage last night, and they roared with the rest of the audience.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 22 -- The Republic of the Congo, five years after independence, still depends on United Nations and foreign experts for the backbone of its essential government services.

Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli, Italian pianist, who last played in this country in 1950, will appear with the New York Philharmonic next season. Mr. Michelangeli was heard with the Philharmonic in 1948 but not since.
BALTIMORE, April 22 -Negotiators for The Baltimore Sunpapers and the newspaper guild agreed today to meet tomorrow for their first talks since the strike began here last Saturday.

A study of renting campaigns for six new Manhattan apartment buildings offering a total of more than 1,000 suites appears to support recent indications of a resugence in the luxury-apartment market in Manhattan.

Mayor Wagner agreed yesterday to ask the Defense Department in Washington today to reconsider its decision to close the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn next year. The Mayor said he expected to be in Washington most of today.
Adlai E. Stevenson declared last night that the United States must learn to engage in new international partnership instead of its past "long isolation and brief supremacy."
DEMOPOLIS, Ala., April 22 (UPI) -- The police used tear gas and smoke bombs today to break up the first of two demonstrations by Negro youths in this western Alabama town.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said, after a call on President Johnson today, that he had been asked to stay in his present post indefinitely.

The music blared and the cheers rang out at the daring of the spangled young men and women of the flying trapeze, the precision of the bareback riders and the high jinks of the clowns in Madison Square Garden yesterday.
A Columbia University survey of 430 cases showed that almost half received "less than optimal" care in 98 hospitals here.

KANSAS CITY, Me., April 22 -- Trans World Airlines has arranged the borrowing of another $100 million to pay for 12 new long-range Boeing 707 jet planes it ordere last January, stockholders were told here today at their annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended April 17 rose in volume from the level of the corresponding week of 1964. Rail carloadings during the same period, affected by plants closed down on Good Friday in various industries, registered a decline.

DETROIT, April 22 -- Three automobile companies have now rejected conditions laid down by the United Automobile Workers as the price for the union's support of a joint effort to eliminate the auto excise tax.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 22 -- A band of Communist guerrillas challenged a United States Marine patrol in a valley outside Danang today and set off the marines' first extended ground action of the Vietnam war.
TRENTON, April 22 -- The New Jersey Republican gubernatorial primary race suddenly became a three-man contest today.
BOGUALUSA, La., April 22 -- Gov. John K. McKeithen ordered 300 more state policemen in this racially tense mill town today to join 80 already here.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. Four stars pertain to restaurants regarded as among the finest in the area.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday first-quarter net income reached a new high of $74.8 million, compared with $74.7 million a year earlier. Earnings in both periods were equal to $1.47 a share.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Senator Edward V. Long said today that "foot-dragging" by Federal officials would not stop an investigation into charges of invasions of privacy by United States agencies.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 22 (AP) -- Gail Sykes continued riddling the favored ranks today when she gained a 19hole victory over Mrs. Alice Dye of Indianapolis in the quarter-finals of the women's North and South amateur golf tournament.

" Next Generation: Travels in Israel," by David Pryce-Jones, will be published by Holt, Rinehart and Winston on May 3. The author teaches at the Iowa University Writer's Workshop. Having spent a year in Israel, he has written an account of the ordinary people "who will make up Israel's generation after the founders and heroes are gone," the publishers say.
Dr. Robert Lekachman, an economist, has resigned from the faculty of Barnard College in a disagreement over trends in teaching and research in economics at Columbia University.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 22 -- There were strong indications here today that a merger between Tatham-Laird, Inc., Chicago, and the Kudner Agency, New York, was imminent, and that an announcement would be made in the next few days.
DIAL Portside 5-4070, and a feminine voice with the softness of a lonely-hearts club receptionist answers cheerfully. "Horizons."

The Johnson Administration's policy in Vietnam was attacked as "hopeless" and defended as "essential" last night in a debate between Senator Ernest Gruening, Democrat of Alaska, and William P. Bundy, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs.
TUNIS, April 22 -- President Habib Bourguiba has proposed a settlement of the Israeli-Arab dispute on the basis of the United Nations plan put forward 17 years ago.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -Reluctant witnesses in certain types of criminal cases could not legally withhold testimony on the ground of self-incrimination under new legislation proposed to Congress today.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 -- Fifteen Federal Officials have been appointed Princeton Fellows in Public Affairs, Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, announced today. They will enroll in September in the university's education program for Federal executives at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs.

Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, stars of Britain's Royal Ballet, which is appearing at the Metropolitan Opera, House, will perform on Ed Sullivan's television show May 16 over the Columbia Broadcasting network.

Elizabeth Hubbard and Jaime Sanchez were designated yesterday as winners of the 20th annual Clarence Derwent Awards, given for the best theater performance by an actress or actor in a nonfeatured role.
Three New York banks announced yesterday the election of a new trustee, a vice president and a director.

PARIS, April 22 -- President de Gaulle was reported today to be considering France's withdrawal from the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization as a step toward greater diplomatic freedom in East-West negotiations.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 22 -- The Special Committee on Colonialism urged Britain today to act immediately to cancel elections scheduled for May 7 in Southern Rhodesia that are expected to confirm the grip of the white minority on the Government.
Expenditures in the United States during 1964 by foreign travelers exceeded $1 billion for the first time, the American Express Company reported yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, April 22 -- The United Steelworkers of America today decided to call a strike against the 11 major steel companies on May 1 if no agreement is reached by then.
Record first-quarter earnings and sales were reported yesterday at the annual meeting of Union Carbide Corporation, which drew close to 1,000 quiet stockholders to the Hunter College auditorium.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The National Association of Securities Dealers announced plans today for an independent study of the economic impact of the new price qutations system for over-the-counter securities and of other reforms the Securities and Exchange Commission is urging on the association.
PITTSBURGH, April 22 -- The United Steelworkers of America today decided to call a strike against the 11 major steel companies on May 1 if no agreement is reached by then.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 22 (UPI) -- Billy Knight, a British Davis Cup player, scored another impressive victory today in the British hard court tennis championships to move into the semi-finals.

Amid the flurry of company meetings yesterday, four leading corporations found time to announce major executive changes. At its annual meeting the Shell Oil Company named Richard C. McCurdy to be its new president, effective July 1.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the three-month and 12-month periods ended March 31.
KAMLOOPS, B.C., April 22 -- A 6-footer in a 10-gallon hat, wearing high boots and jeans, strode out of the saddle store on Victoria Street this morning -- and rode off in a 1965 sports convertible.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) -- A California Democrat, declaring he was "tired of being maligned for what somebody else was doing," moved today to cut from $18,907 a year to $1,500 the Congressional pay of Mrs. Adam Clayton Powell, wife of the Manhattan Democrat.
NORFOLK, Va., April 22 -Vice President Humphrey warned here today that unless Americans had the patience to "work and bleed and die" in Vietnam the Communists might conquer the world "bit by bit."

Nine oarsmen have been lost to the Columbia heavyweight rowing squad in a disciplinary action that Athletic Director Ralph Furey termed yesterday the most serious in his 41 years of association with the university.

Kenneth MacMillan's "Romeo and Juliet" is a work that cannot be fully comprehended or appreciated in one viewing. Seeing the Royal Ballet's second performance of it at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was a revelation, or the beginning of one, for this reviewer.
An alibi was offered for George Whitmore Jr. yesterday for the night he allegedly stabbed to death Mrs. Minnie Edmonds, a cleaning woman, in Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Billy Williams smacked an eighth-inning single today that drove in Glenn Beckert and gave the Chicago Cubs a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -The East Garden of the White House, seen by almost two million tourists a year, today became the Jacqueline Kennedy Garden. Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson dedicated the dainty, eighteenth-century-style gar den of flowers, hedges and kitchen herbs while Senator and Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy; Mrs. Eunice Kennedy Shriver; Jacqueline Kennedy's mother, Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss, and friends stood by.
Commercial and industrial loans at 14 leading New York City banks increased $14 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that Merkel, Inc., had sold sausage products unfit for human consumption to the New York City school system, state hospitals and prisons, the Army, the Air Force, supermarket chains, restaurants and hotels.
A renewal plan for 116 blocks on Manhattan's upper West Side with major revisions limiting the expansion of Columbia University for a decade was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

Murray Helwitz, manager of the Shubert theaters' central ticket office, who pleaded guilty to exacting more than $70,000 from nine ticket brokers in 1963, was sentenced yesterday to eight months in jail and fined $4,600.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 22 -- If a fishing expedition on the Susquehanna flats at the head of the Chesapeake Bay fails to produce fish, a visitor with an interest in birds and wildlife can just prowl around and enjoy himself.
Record sales and earnings in the first quarter were registered by American Tobacco Company and its consolidated subsidiaries.
MEXICO CITY, April 22 -The Mexican Government suspended today, at least temporarily, a permit granted the Pan American Sulphur Company to export 18,000 tons of sulphur.
A diver who descended 240 feet to a sunken ship to collect navigation instruments that are needed to fight $5 million in court suits discovered that another diver had already removed the evidence.

ALBANY, April 22 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that criminal defendants in all state courts must be told in plain language that a lawyer will be assigned to them if they cannot afford to hire one.
Mayor Wagner's campaign against crime moves today from the subways to the streets.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 22 -- A pair of birdies -- the only two in the tournament -were the difference today in the opening event of the Garden State Women's Golf Association season.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 22 -Seventeen Russian technicians arrived in Nairobi today, presumably to instruct the Kenya army in weapons it has been promised by the Soviet Union.
A key Washington official cautioned yesterday that it was premature to count on Federal approval of the plan to continue New Haven Railroad commuter runs into New York.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal court overturned today the eavesdropping conviction of a private detective who had been compelled later to tell a grand jury about the incident.

THE new spiritual leader of the nation's 10.3 million Methodists is a jovial churchman who has twice broken the ecclesiastical color barrier. The second time was last night in Houston, when Bishop Prince Albert Taylor Jr. formally took over as president of his church's Council of Bishops.

Jackson W. Smart, a partner in the accounting firm of Touche, Ross, Bailey and Smart, and Kenneth Ingalls Moe, president of KGW Enterprises, Inc., have been elected directors of Thomas Industries, Inc.
" Resolved that it be the privilege of all Americans to drink Kickapoo Joy Juice every day of their lives, and for several days thereafter. . . ."

SAIGON, Friday, April 23 (UPI) -- Vietcong guerrillas infiltrated to within three miles of heavily guarded Danang last night and opened fire with small arms on a Government radio station near the big United States air and missile base.
HAYNEVILLE, Ala., April 22 -- Three Ku Klux Klansmen were free on $10,000 bonds tonight after being indicted for first-degree murder in the slaying of Mrs. Viola Liuzzo.
The appointment of William H. Hagendorn as general counsel of the American Express Company has been announced by Howard L. Clark, president of the travel-service company.
Questions as to when Worthington Corporation would increase its dividend and when profit margins would exceed 4 per cent were asked by stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

The brilliant young race rider from Brooklyn, Michael Venezia, wound up his term as an apprentice in glorious style yesterday, winning the featured one-mile Kerry Patch Purse at Aqueduct with the Greentree Stable's 3-year-old colt, O'Hara.
PARIS, April 23 -- President de Gaulle emphasized today his hostility to United States policy in Vietnam by withdrawing French units from the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization's naval maneuvers.
MARY CUSHING, whom everybody calls Minnie, and who snorkles, surfs, skis and sky-dives, took up another exciting sport this week.
FINDING a blacksmith who will forge iron decorations is about as unlikely today as coming across one shoeing a horse in the middle of Times Square.
Seventeen women candy makers in a small Long Island factory have asked the National Labor Relations Board to free them from a union with underworld connections.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- The American Medical Association's administrative staff charged today that President Johnson's Commission on Heart Disease, Cancer and Stroke raised more questions than it answered.

THE Village Light Opera Group, Ltd., an amateur company founded in 1935 and dedicated to the operas of Gilbert and Sullivan, gave the United States premiere last night of a possible addition to the canon, "Engaged! or Cheviot's Choice."
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) Danny Cater's two-run homer capped a three-run sixth inning tonight that carried the Chicago White Sox to a 5-3 victory over the Washington Senators.

" FAULKNER'S MISSISSIPPI," a painstaking documentary complemented by the writer's own words from his stories and speeches as the camera swept across the land he loved and sometimes hated, was a moving, often lyrical portrait of an artist through his work.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 23 -- A Beirut newspaper published a cartoon today showing President Bourguiba of Tunisia as Judas walking away with 30 pieces of silver while Palestine dies on the cross.
TRENTON, April 23 -- The State Supreme Court unanimously upheld today the constitutionality of the legislative reapportionment act approved 11 days ago.
NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Saturday, April 24 -- Two teenage boys were struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train last night just west of the New Hyde Park station.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (UPI) -- Police raided a dozen San Francisco nightclubs last night and today in a long-expected crackdown on dancers doing the swim in topless bathing suits.
ROME, April 23 (AP) -- Salvatore Burruni, a 32-year-old Sardinian, outpointed Pone Kingpetch of Thailand tonight and won the world flyweight title.
New York City's practice of limiting sales of certain city-owned land to religious and educational users is under constitutional attack.
At Carnegie Recital Hall last night, the young soprano Geraldine Overstreet exhibited a lovely voice, but rather less than complete control in her ambitious program.

Recommendations that would end the absolute control by the clergy of Roman Catholic elementary school boards have been made to superintendents throughout the country by a special committee of the National Catholic Educational Association.
CINCINNATI, April 23 (AP) -- Curt Flood slammed a homer and a two-run single tonight in leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.
A distinguished Swedish physicist has revived a theory about the moon that holds it was once an independent planet.
LOS ANGELES, April 23 (AP) -- Johnny Podres pitching for the first time in almost a year, hurled a four-hitter tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-0.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission moved today to protect local television operators from the mushrooming competition of community antenna television systems.
PARIS, April 23 -- For the first time since the Revolution, the Soviet Union will send abroad an exhibition of the renowned treasures of its two greatest museums.
Broadway, ever mindful of the needs of others, yesterday helped a cause of its own -- a program to support young, aspiring playwrights who seek to learn the finer points of the playwright's craft.

The courage of President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia in suggesting Arab-Israeli negotiations and mutual concessions can be measured by the denunciations to which he was subjected by his fellow-Arabs yesterday. Arab newspapers accused him of "high treason," and declared him to have "become raving mad.'"

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., April 23 -- A 16-year-old girl and an 18-year-old boy were found dead today in an isolated area on Raritan Bay that had been swept by a brush fire the victims are believed to have set in a suicide pact.
HAVANA, April 23 -- Cuba's Government-controlled press hinted today that enemies of the state were trying to sabotage the sugar harvest by setting fire to canefields.
CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians scored a 6-2 victory tonight over the Kansas City Athletics. Dick Donovan was the winner, though he needed help in the sixth from Luis Tiant.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Johnson is expected to send to Congress next week a package of labor bills that will leave unions and employers plenty of room to bargain.

An engineer who has built ferries, waterfront terminals and airport runways has retired after 50 years in the service of the City of New York. He is Capt. Lewis H. Rabbage, chief engineer of the Department of Marine and Aviation.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- Gary Kroll, who beat the San Francisco Giants in New York last Sunday, started for the New York Mets tonight against Gaylord Perry, the pitcher he defeated then. About 14,000 attended the opener of a four-game series in cold, windy weather at Candlestick Park.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey said today that President Johnson wants a dollar's worth of service from Government agencies and employes for every tax dollar spent.
The commuters who have complained for years about the service and facilities of the New Haven Railroad were joined yes-yesterday by a noncommuter with a new complaint.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The index of wholesale primary-market prices was unchanged at 101.6 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended April 20, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., which is building a new store on East 59th Street, said yesterday that it would fight any effort by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to construct a department store nearby.

In its two appearances earlier this week in Carnegie Hall, the Munich Bach Chorus and Orchestra presented two large-scale works, the St. Matthew Passion and the B minor Mass. Last night, the ensemble turned to Bach's "Christmas Oratorio," not nearly so imposing an assignment as it sounds.
Largely the same Harvard heavyweight varsity crew that established itself as the best college eight of the country last year opens its season today, along with Pennsylvania and Syracuse.

LONDON, April 23 -- It was lucky that Chancellor of the Exchequer James Callaghan did not walk into the opulent River Room of the Savoy Hotel today. He would have found himself roasted on the spit of his recent budget.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy is campaigning for inclusion of two New York State rivers in the national "wild rivers" system.
LOS ANGELES, April 23 (AP) -- Local, state and Federal authorities seized two truckloads of arms and ammunition parked on a street in Los Angeles's Eagle Rock district today.
Shortly before 7 o'clock last night, Patrolman Donald B. Fenn, his blue uniform tight across his shoulders, walked purposefully into the East 51st Street police station.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- It was distance-running weather, but the sprinters and jumpers set the records today in the schoolboy division of the Penn Relays.

A television newsman with a habit of carrying around a black bag to hold his notes was mistaken by two armed men at 1 P.M. yesterday for a man who was supposed to get a payroll at the First National City Bank branch at 28-11 Bridge Plaza North, Long Island City, Queens.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 -- More than 200 American and South Vietnamese aircraft destroyed seven bridges and two ferryboats in North Vietnam today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, urged today the elimination of the poll-tax ban written into President Johnson's right-to-vote bill.
BALTIMORE, April 23 -- Bargaining teams of the Baltimore Sunpapers and the Newspaper Guild held their first face-to-face meeting today since the guild started a strike last Saturday.

THE lead of the fourth-best of a long suit against a no-trump contract has been so deeply embedded in the consciousness of card players since the days of whist that it has the impact of a law rather than a convention.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation is offering a submersible vehicle called the Turtle for mining and farming on the Continental shelves. The inventor, Dr. Willy A. Fiedler, regards the ocean as more promising to man in the next few years than space.
Daylight saving time goes into effect at 2 A.M. tomorrow and more than half the nation will have to turn clocks ahead one hour.

LOS ANGELES, April 23 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics, with Sam Jones scoring 37 points and Bill Russell controlling the backboards, beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 112 -- 99, tonight and moved a step closer to the National Basketball Association championship.
A proposal for the construction of a 500-car parking garage at Park Avenue South and 25th Street, just north of Madison Square Park, is being considered by the city.
Proponents of New York filmmaking expressed concern yesterday over the adverse effect of complaints made against local union technicians by Delbert Mann, the director of "Mr. Buddwing."
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Two policemen were attacked and beaten early today when a crowd attempted to free two men who had been arrested.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 23 (AP) -- The Little Rock School Board is shifting gears in its move toward complete desegregation. But a Negro leader greeted the move today with skepticism.
F.A.O. Schwarz, the toy specialty-store chain, will soon have retail outlets on both coasts, if current acquisition talks are successful.

CAIRO, April 23 -- The Egyptian press, signaling the end of Cairo's 16-month-old policy of pursuing Arab harmony and cooperation, lashed out today at the proposal by Tunisia's President, Habib Bourguiba, for Arab coexistence and negotiations with Israel.
CHICAGO, April 23 -- Prof. Ronald Freedman, president of the Population Association of America, suggested today that the world was in a new era of declining birth rates.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 23 -- Bringing a little color and movement into the lives of about 30 infants born and reared for four months in the bland surroundings of a state hospital has had a "remarkable" effect on their alertness, according to an experiment reported here today to the Eastern Psychological Association.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 23 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit refused today to delay a sanity hearing for Jack L. Ruby in Texas courts.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 23 -- Life has become easier for South Korea's tourists and for foreign residents who do not have access to the United States Army's huge PX and commissary system. O Kas is the governments agency for the promotion of tourism has acquired a president who once wanted to operate a Macy's or Gimbels of Korea.
J. Lyman Bingham, the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee, accepted the first official donation yesterday for the 1968 games.

LONDON, April 23 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson has summoned 25 Western European Socialist party and Government leaders to a conference in Britain, a Government spokesmen said. The Southeast Asian crisis was expected to be a key topic of discussion.

WASIHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Mrs. William Henry Sullivan Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., feeling "very humble," took over direction of the Daughters of the American Revolution today in its diamond jubilee year.
The British pound slipped today in light trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 23 -- Sheik Othman Shariff, Tanzania's Ambassador to the United States, was reported today to have been arrested during a visit to Zanzibar and sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment.

Hundreds of exhibitors registered this week for the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit, scheduled for opening on May 21, but the annual mayoral proclamation, which is the license for the spring and fall street shows, has been held up.

OXFORD, Miss., April 23 (UPI) -- The University of Mississippi offered an apology today to a biracial group whose visit here to attend a literary festival touched off the first racial violence on the campus in two and a half years.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 23 -- Brazil dropped its export price for coffee by a cent a pound today in a competitive reply to African and Central American producers.
MOSCOW, April 23 -- The Soviet Union proclaimed continued interest tonight in an international conference on Cambodia.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 23 -- Chile's capital gradually returned to normal today after 18 hours of rioting.

PRINCETON, N.J. -- A carved figurehead of Daniel Webster taken from the stern board of an old whaler stares down from one end of the room at a six-foot iron cauldron that was once used to boil whale blubber.
The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday a price of $48 a share on the 5,611,360 hares of additional common stock it is offering to its stockholders.
The limited numbers of aircraft available and the technical shortcomings or unsuitability of the United States planes used in Vietnam are causing increasing worry among military officers.

ROME, April 23 (AP) -- Maria Callas won a legal battle today with the Rome Opera House over her walkout in midperformance of Bellini's "Norma" on an opening night seven years ago. The incident almost led to a riot in an audience that included Italy's President, Giovanni Gronchi.
Is Whitey Ford through? Will arthritis-plagued Sandy Koufax regain his old form? Can Warren Spahn, "too old" at 43, be a winning pitcher for the Mets at 44?
George Whitmore Jr. testified yesterday that the police had beaten a confession out of him one year ago today.

The Armenian nation, everywhere in the world, is today commemorating the most tragic event in its long history. This was the massacre by the Turks that began on April 24, 1915. The former United States Ambassador to Turkey, the late Henry Morgenthau, called it "an episode which, so far as I know, is the most terrible day in history." This was, of course, pre-Hitler.

A real estate syndication promoter, who allegedly swindled small investors out of $350,000, pleaded guilty to first degree grand larceny yesterday and was sentenced to two and a half to five years in prison.
Hans Werner Henze's Piano Sonata and piano works of three other composers received their New York premieres yesterday afternoon in Robert Floyd's impressive Town Hall recital.
Your April 14 "Funds for the City's Schools" editorial is a timely reminder and reflects an understanding of the educational challenge confronting us.
Prizes were given last night to outstanding films and film-strips at the closing dinner of the seventh annual American Film Festival at the Biltmore Hotel.
THE HAGUE, April 23 -- There is renewed discussion of combining six European airlines into a single "air union."
Brokerage houses that believe Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., is tough competition might take a look at the current issue of that firm's employe publication entitled, "We The People."
Controversy developed yesterday over a court suit challenging a $10,000 award last year by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation to Dr. Nathan S. Kline, a leader in medicine.
DANANG, Vietnam, April 23 (AP) -- Security regulations for newsmen at the air base here were relaxed somewhat today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 23 -- Roger Seydoux, the French representative, indicated today that France was leaning more toward the Soviet Union's view on the role of the General Assembly than toward that of the United States.

An Episcopal Liturgical Conference, called to examine in depth the practices and procedures of the church's public worship and their relevance to modern man, will be held here for three days beginning Monday.
SEOUL, South Korea, April 23 -- Anti-Government agitation, which has produced ominous civil disturbances here, has begun to assume an anti-American tone.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 23 -- Roosevelt Raceway has filed a suit against Nassau County in State Supreme Court challenging the validity of the county's 30 per cent admission tax.

CHERRY HILL, N.J. April 23 (AP) -- Joey Giardello, the middleweight boxing champion, plodded to an easy decision over Gil Diaz tonight in a 10-round nontitle fight but came out of it with an elbow injury that required taping and cold packs.

Negotiations over the wildcat strike in the school bus system appeared to be proceeding with inexcusable lack of urgency. Day after tomorrow the children return to school; but the bus stoppage has still not been settled.
The Traffic Department's 192 meter maids have been working like beavers in their first week of enlarged jurisdiction over parking violators.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Saturday, April 24 -- Owen Vincent (Owney) Madden, whose blazing underworld career terrorized two states in the Prohibition era, died in a hospital here early today. He was 73 years old.
Pan American Sulphur Company's stock dipped more than 6 points yesterday, but at the close stood at 45 3/8, off 4 1/8.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS. W. Va., April 23 -- It's been a year since the much-talked-about study of public attitudes toward advertising was first disclosed here.

We who were there think your coverage of the April 17 march on Washington missed the point entirely. The tone of the news article was frivolous and the implication was that the facts are unimportant. It would seem that the marchers were simply off on a springtime romp and certainly not to be taken seriously.

BERLIN, April 23 (UPI) -- A United States Army veteran who wants to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the linkup of American and Soviet troops in Germany was blocked today by East German Communist officials.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- On an afternoon more fit for Eskimos than for runners and jumpers, Villanova and Missouri won the major honors today as the 71st annual Penn Relays began.

HONG KONG, April 23 -- Chinese Communist leaders can be counted among the most careful students of public opinion in the United States. Their propaganda reveals a special awareness of American comment on Vietnam.

MOSCOW, April 23 -- The United States and West Germany rejected as "wholly inaccurate" today Soviet charges that West German military authorities planned to string nuclear mines across Germany and along the border of Czechoslovakia.

First-quarter earnings of the Borg-Warner Corporation increased 10 per cent to $9,959,000 from $9,061,000 in the first three months of 1965. Sales were up 11 per cent to $198,432,000 from $178,541,000.

TOKYO, Saturday, April 24 (UPI) -- Communist China said today that the Honolulu conference this week attended by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara; Maxwell D. Taylor, the United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, and key American military leaders was held to plan "bigger war ventures" in Vietnam.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- Contract negotiations between the United Steelworkers of America and the steel industry are back in a familiar pattern. It is a cross between a tribal dance and a poker game. The ritual prevails in much of American collective bargaining.
A two-day conference on the labor movement's role in advancing civil rights and fair practices in horsing and employment was opened here yesterday at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 23 -- A 41-year-old mother and two of her children were found beaten to death today in the frame tenement where they lived at 66 Townsend Street.

MONTREAT, N.C., April 23 -- A committee of the Southern Presbyterian Church debated late into the night a church statement calling for "sympathetic understanding" of the Negro revolution and its principal instruments -- demonstrations, boycotts and sit-ins.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Johnson coolly accepted today the resignation of Assistant Secretary of Commerce Herbert W. Klotz, who profited from an indirect stock tip.

A vision of Montparnasse replacing Skid Row glimmered Thursday night around 222 Bowery when Wynn Chamberlain, the painter of conventional people unadorned by clothes, had 130 friends up (six flights) to hear William Burroughs and Mack Thomas read their own fiction.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Claude Provost, the most unpopular performer in last night's third game in the Stanley Cup playoff finals between the Montreal Canadiens and the Chicago Black Hawks at Chicago Stadium, doesn't care if he never wins a popularity contest here.
The stock market survived a late sinking spell yesterday to close the week at a record level.

IMPORTANT and delightful light is shed on American art in the exhibition of 19th-century drawings and watercolors from the collection of the late Maxim Karolik, on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 23 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, has appealed to South Africa to permit young South Africans to study abroad as "United Nations Scholars." He was understood to have made his request at a private meeting today with Matthys I. Botha, South Africa's chief delegate.

The Madden Memorial Awards of the New York University School of Commerce Alumni Association will be awarded this year to John W. Larsen, executive vice president and treasurer of the Bowery Savings Bank; Joseph Sandler, senior partner of David Berdon Co., certified public accountants, and Phillip Lovell West, vice president, New York Stock Exchange.
BALTIMORE, April 23 (AP) -- Robin Roberts drove in three runs tonight with a bases-loaded double in the second inning and pitched the Baltimore Orioles to a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

The Board of Education, anticipating a continuation of the school bus strike, announced yesterday that children entitled to free transportation would receive special passes for use on public transport.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- The nation's 11 major steel companies and the United Steel-workers Union resumed negotiating today in efforts to reach a temporary agreement that would prevent a nation-wide strike on May 1.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 -- Latin-American countries will devote more than $12 billion for self-development programs this year, according to Carlos Sanz de Santamaria, the chairman of the Inter-American Committee of the Alliance for Progress.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company were sued for $25 million in punitive damages here yesterday for allegedly buying stock in the mining company while suppressing news of a rich ore discovery it had made in Canada.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to raise $325 million through the sale of debentures and common stock, the company announced in registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

Most political satire is topical and short-lived, and most is effective only in brief dozes. Bleak truisms, but they can often subvert the proper guffawing mood of even the best-intentioned reader. Yet one must take one's laughs as they come.

A high-ranking member of the Roman Catholic educational hierarchy, who had just given an address at the National Catholic Education Association's convention here, said to some associates: "Now I better call out my bodyguard."
The Federal Government charged in Brooklyn yesterday that a handsome young man used bank holdup receipts to avoid the harsh Long Island winter by vacationing in Florida.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 23 -- More than 1,000 students of Rutgers University expressed sentiment for and against the Administration's policy in Vietnam as they turned out this morning for an eight-hour "teach-in."

The American Symphony Orchestra will give 20 concerts during its 1965-66 season, four more than in this season. There will be 12 Monday evening performances and 8 on Sunday afternoons, with a total of 12 different programs.
DETROIT, April 23 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins scored two runs in the 10th inning tonight and defeated the Detroit Tigers. 8-6.
MOSCOW, April 23 (AP) -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia printed two articles on crime in the United States today under the headline: "Behind the Iron Curtain."

LISBON, April 23 -- Government censors today authorized publication of a manifesto by the Social Democratic Opposition challenging Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar to a "valiant fight" in this year's legislative elections.
Copper futures prices turned easier yesterday in active trading on the New York Commodity Exchange.

LOS ANGELES, April 23 -- A special committee of the regents of the University of California set forth today a proposed new code of student conduct intended to resolve eight months of turmoil at the institution's Berkeley campus.

Armenian communities throughout the United States are commemorating today the fiftieth anniversary of the massacres that began in Turkey in 1915 in which, according to estimates, 600,000 to 1,500,000 Armenians were killed.

GREENEVILLE, Tenn., April 23 -- About 125 male students at Tuscuum College, a Presbyterian college with about 500 students, went on a rampage here last night. They broke some windows and did other damage at three dormitories before officers restored order early today.
Stanley H. Lowell submitted his resignation last night as chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights.
Throughout the dozen years that the Modern Jazz Quartet has been playing, it has skirted the fringes of effete, tearoom jazz but it has never fallen completely under its spell.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 23 -- Churchill Downs, the site of the Kentucky Derby in an unbroken sequence since the race first was run in 1875, will open its annual spring meeting tomorrow. DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 23 (AP) -- Flood waters of the Mississippi River apparently reached a crest today at Prairie du Chien, Wis., and rolled on toward sections of Illinois, Iowa and Missouri.
