Manhattan's Democratic and Republican party leaders declared their opposition yesterday to a special election to fill the vacancy for the State Senate in the 21st District.

Having recently visited Madison County, N.C., and Leslie County, Ky., in Appalachia, the 144th and 6th poorest counties in the nation, I was struck by Theodore Will's letter [April 18] in defense of the pastoral life in Appalachia against Federal programs.

ROBBINSVILLE, N.C. -- Here, in the southwestern corner of North Carolina, are scenic and recreational riches that span the centuries. They range from forests primeval to projects related to the space age, and from waterfalls higher than Niagara to Indian wigwams.
DESTO Records, which recently issued "Songs by American Composers," an album originally subsidized by the Ditson Fund of Columbia University, has another project that stems from the fund.

TOWARD the close of Maurice Shadbolt's AMONG THE CINDERS (Atheneum, $4.95), 16-year-old Nick Flinders, son of a rural New Zealand school-teacher, feels that he is at last in the vortex of the grown-up world -- "right in the midst of their curious adult intrigues and mysteries."

Salt Lake City will briefly become the railroad capital of the mountain West on May 12, when the presidents of four major railroads meet Utah's Gov. Calvin L. Rampton in a round of talks he hopes will "convince railroad officials of Utah's growth to potential, and create a favorable climate for lower rail freight rates."
Senator Robert F. Kennedy said yesterday that the state and city of New York have been "derelict" in failing to ask for Federal funds that have been available for research in narcotics addiction.

ROME, April 24 -- The long-controversial draft declaration on the attitude of the Roman Catholic Church toward Jews and other non-Christians again is under convergent attack by two powerful forces -- reaching up to the highest levels of the church.
GREENPORT, L.I., April 24 -- A 40-foot "sleeper" ocean racing sloop is taking form in a small boatyard at this former whaling port on eastern Long Island.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 With Ron Turcotte giving him an expertly paced ride, Powhatan's Tom Rolfe came through with an impressive victory in the Stepping Stone at Churchill Downs today.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- Bobby Hull spent part of his first Christmas away from home in the penalty box at Madison Square Garden.
LIFE is going to be more relaxing this year for Jacks or Better, the defending high-point champion in the open jumper division.

A country two-fifths the size of the United States with two and one-half times more people makes the already serious population problem in the United States (192 million) seem a minor one. Having spent one summer in India (where I had the pleasure of meeting Mr. Chandrasekhar and hearing him speak) I left no longer appalled by the desperate idea of sterilization.

BOULDER CITY, Nev. -- The biggest gamble in this state's history is beginning to pay off. Nearby Lake Mead, which was half-emptied by engineers last year so as to permit three mammoth man-made lakes to form on the Colorado, Green and San Juan Rivers, is slowly refilling.

TOKYO, April 24 -- Premier Eisaku Sato has told Henry Cabot Lodge, President Johnson's special representative, that Japan "strongly desires" further efforts by the United States Government toward a peaceful settlement of the Vietnam conflict, Government sources said today.

AMMAN, Jordan -- Although Jordan prides itself on being an ancient land, it is working to brush off the sands of time. Within the last two years, four new hotels have been constructed in Jerusalem and one here in Amman, the capital.

THE refreshing thing about Mexican painting today is that the international goose-step has never really caught on here. This might seem to mean only that the country is provincial artistically (as Mexican artists and collectors are fond of saying), but such an explanation is too easy.
RICHARD M. NIXON told an off-the-record dinner in Washington recently that his trouble was that he had been over-nominated and under-elected.
SINGAPORE, Malaysia, April 24 (UPI) -- Most attempts by Indonesians to infiltrate Malaysia have failed, Christopher Mayhew, Britain's Minister of Defense for the Navy, said today.

The Port of New York in March registered the highest customs collections in its history. Revenues from ship and air imports amounted to $77.6 million, according to Joseph P. Kelly, Collector of Customs.

STANDARD dwarf bearded iris hybrids are comparative newcomers to the iris world. They bloom with the Darwin tulips and can be combined attractively with them. New varieties of these vigorous and delightful middle-sized hybrids can easily be created by crossing Iris pumila with the tall bearded irises.

Scientists at the National Institutes of Health last week announced the development of a vaccine against a severe acute respiratory viral disease. The vaccine, developed according to a new concept in immunization against respiratory infections, was said to have proved 100 per cent effective in field trials.
ALBANY, April 24 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that work would begin this year on two 1,000-bed hospitals for the mentally ill. One will be on Staten Island and the other near Albany.
MOSCOW, Sunday, April 25 (UPI) -- Several hundred Moscow youths jeered and made insulting gestures today at Russian Orthodox priests observing Easter at the city's Central Cathedral.

TWO United Nations stamps, to be issued May 17, will celebrate the 100th birthday of the International Telecommunications Union. They express the advance in communications from the days of the semaphore, and the origins of the Morse telegraph system, to today's use of space satellites.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Johnson does not now intend either to halt the United States air attacks on North Vietnam or to move American combat troops into the forefront of a stepped-up antiguerrilla war in South Vietnam.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 23 -- Holden Roberto, president of the Angolan revolutionary government in exile, explained today why he does not get discouraged when his movement falters, as it has in the last year.

BONN, April 24 -- Walter Hallstein, president of the Executive Commission of the European Economic Community, or Common Market, called today for closer European-United States cooperation to solve the "great problems" of world trade and finance.
Joe O'Donnell's home run over the center-field fence in the top of the 12th inning gave Harvard an 8-7 victory yesterday over Columbia at Baker Field.
THE pursuit of gardening pleasures can lead down many fascinating paths. One such delightful byway is the planting of night-fragrant flowers.

Lucky Debonair, Mrs. Ada L. Rice's winner of the Blue Grass Stakes on Thursday, arrived at Churchill Downs from Lexington Saturday. Isidor Bieber's Flag Raiser, the winner of the Wood Memorial, will get here on Monday, from Aqueduct.
Business activity in Dallas over the last five years has been good, but figures compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas indicate that it was excellent in March.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 21 -- About a century ago a golden age came to this Connecticut River Valley community, which was settled by families of Pilgrims in 1650.

BOSTON, April 29 -- Harvard's heavyweight crew, which had seven of the eight oarsmen who comprised the nation's best college crew last season, used new equipment and style today to prove that it is again the college crew to beat.
A spring gourmet dinner for the benefit of Comeback, an agency specializing in the therapeutic use of recreation, will take place on May 3 at Le Perigord restaurant, 405 East 52d Street.

THE marigolds and zinnias, once considered lowly flowers in the gardens of yesterday, are fast growing in popularity. Remarkable progress has been made in the development of their flowers by the plant breeders, and today they are taking their places as worthwhile additions to flower borders.

Ghosts of bankers past would be on familiar ground discussing most of the myriad problems facing the Manufacturers Manover Trust Company if the Justice Department should force a reversal of the merger that formed the bank.

There is a discouraging gap between our Government's stated objectives in Vietnam and its actual behavior. President Johnson's assurance that we uphold the right of self-determination should lead logically to a policy based upon free elections and representative government.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 -- Piling the incredible upon the implausible, the New York Mets repeated in broad daylight today the ninth-inning trauma they inflicted on the San Francisco Giants in the middle of the night 18 hours before.
EASTON, Md., April 24 -- As the dogwood blooms and farmers break the earth for spring planting, Maryland's fishing season begins to pick up with some species coming to lures better than others.

One recent night in a quiet section of Brooklyn a thief entered a public telephone booth, attached window shades to the glass walls by means of suction cups, and, so concealed, tore the entire telephone -- wires, bell and coin box -- from the wall.
DUKE GARDENS, a 10-acre showplace under glass in Somerville, N.J., opens today for the 1965 season. The gardens may be seen from 1 to 5 P.M. Wednesdays through Sundays by appointment.
SANTA COMBA DAO, Portugal, April 24 -- A statue will be unveiled here Wednesday to the village son who has achieved the distinction of being the dean of European autocrats.

" OUR Private World," the Columbia Broadcasting System's answer to "Peyton Place," will make its television debut May 5. A nighttime twice-a-week serial, "Our Private World" is a spin-off from the C.B.S. daytime soap opera, "As the World Turns," which has been turning for nine years.
WEST BABYLON, L.I., April 24 -- Don Broggini of the Port Washington fleet led at the end of three races in the Region 1 Penguin Class championships on Great South Bay today.
Classified advertising managers of 29 United States and Canadian newspapers will participate in a two-week seminar beginning tomorrow at the American Press Institute of Columbia University.

WHAT with all the assorted film festivals and revival showings we've been getting these past few years -- and may God bless the enterprising people who run our marginal theaters for that -- it is time and it is especially appropriate that we should have this year a really comprehensive retrospective showing of David Wark Griffith's films.

I SUPPOSE it is news when a Nobel laureate writes a suspense novel. It is certainly news, of a sort, when a long established professional publishes a novel so bad as to embarrass any self-respecting amateur.

THE author's avowed purpose in this volume is to exploit "the hybrid heritage" of the English language "as a passport to language learning. . . . Having completed this book, the reader should be able to mitigate the hard grind of learning about fifteen European languages."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 24 -- The head of the world's largest advertising agency warned today that a lack of sufficient growth in advertising volume could place limits on the expansion of the nation's economy.

In my article on Senator Russell Long, published in The Times Magazine April 4, I inadvertently stated that Senator Joseph S. Clark of Pennsylvania had voted for Senator Long as Assistant Democratic leader.

Scholars, with their preference for understatement, try to avoid superlatives in discussing the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N.J. Thus, Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, who announced yesterday that he plans to retire in 1966 as director, once termed it "an intellectual hotel."

PORT REPUBLIC, Md. -- If one were to search for a good reason why Maryland is still sometimes referred to as a "Southern State," he need only come to this spot, for here the northernmost cypress swamp on the entire East Coast occupies nearly 100 acres of murky, muddy ground.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee moved today to keep commercial helicopter service operating in New York City, Chicago and Los Angeles until at least June 30.

Your recent editorial "Reaping the Whirlwind" excited considerable interest among those of us who are involved in the perplexing problems of Great Plains agriculture. The Times's interest in such matters is, in my opinion, entirely appropriate and extremely welcome.
The Women's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor has formed a National Committee on Household Employment to upgrade the status of the nation's more than 1.5 million domestic workers.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 24 (UPI) -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's chief of state, said today that there was no need to invite the United Slates, Thailand or South Vietnam to the proposed conference to guarantee Cambodia's neutrality.

Robert Ross of River Edge, N.J., 1961 Maccabiah Games bronze medalist in free pistol match, wil head a list of 11 men named as eligible candidates for the 1965 United States Maccabiah Games pistol and rifle shooting teams.

A tiny band of women candymakers in Long Island is fighting courageously to break the chains that now hold them captive in a union with a long and odious record of underworld connections. The difficulties they must overcome demonstrate once again the extent to which the Federal labor laws, as interpreted by the National Labor Relations Board, serve as a shield for rackets masquerading as labor organizations.
NAIROBI, Kenya April 24 -- Kenya's dispute with the United States over the attempts of some Kenyans to obtain American scholarships appeared today to have disappeared.
HAVANA, April 24 -- Premier Fidel Castro is a fan of the new Mozambique rhythm, his brother, Raul, condemns Western dances as decadent and many young Cubans go in for something else -- "filin."
BONN, April 24 -- A leader of the junior party in West Germany's coalition called upon the Government today to quit playing "satellite" to the United States and recognize Communist China.

TIMES readers have long appreciated C.L. Sulzberger's straight-to-the-jugular summary analyses of international affairs. Those familiar with his "My Brother Death" also understand his underlying philosophical apparatus. His talent is to look through spates of confusing events, swiftly spotting fundamentals.
DETROIT, April 24 -- G. Mennen Williams, who served six terms as Michigan's Governor, is being given increasing attention here as a possible candidate for state office in 1966.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- It was more than 20 degrees cooler yesterday in Franklin Field than the average temperature on the island of Jamaica, but the Kingston College High School from that Caribbean area was red hot at the Penn Relays.

ENTRIES for the Trenton Kennel Club show closed last Tuesday with 2,415 dogs, which not only was a record, but entrenched the event more firmly than ever as one of the country's foremost canine fixtures.
OSLO, Norway, April 24 -- Parliamentary elections are not due here until September, but a lively campaign is already under way.

THIS stupefying work -- two volumes, 1,337 pages, 32 chapters, 3,073 footnotes -- is purportedly a study of liberal attitudes toward foreign policy in the United States in the years from Mukden to Pearl Harbor.

The New York State Legislature has shown a cavalier disregard for the voters who elected them. The first one hundred days of this session can be characterized only as a total debacle, the Legislature having failed in each of the three major crises presented to it.
READING about the new editions of "Psychopathia Sexualis" in your Book Review recently I was reminded of some free verse which I wrote some years ago and which seems appropriate. Here it is:
The most delicate situation a decorator can be faced with is reconciling the old-fashioned tastes of one marriage partner with the way-out tastes of the other.

Princess Benedikte of Denmark will be guest of honor at a luncheon to be held in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza on May 6 for the benefit of the American Cancer Society's New York City Division (Children's Fund to Fight Lukemia).

COLUMBIA seems to be the only company these days at all interested in the serious side of the Broadway -- or off Broadway -- theater. Interested enough to put their offerings into more or less permanent form on disks, that is.

What is it with spring this year? In other years there were carpets of daffodils by now and the trees were canopies of pink cherry blooms. Tips of many tulips were showing red and yellow and the dogwoods braved the warmest spots with snowy white blooms. Instead, this spring brought snowstorms to New England on Easter Sunday, lackadaisical forsythia that seemed reluctant to come or go, poky daffodils and frost-browned magnolias.

Princess Vera of Russia, her niece, Princess Marina Romanoff, and Princess Vera's nephew, Prince Michael of Prussia, will receive guests in the evening of May 3 at the St. Regis for a showing of a documentary of Czar Nicholas II and his family, dating from 1894 to 1914.

AS with so much of the music of Charles Ives, trying to sort out the tangled history of the Fourth Symphony, which Leopold Stokowski will conduct tomorrow night in Carnegie Hall, is a bit like working out a three-dimensional double crostic.
The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University will mark its 10th anniversary and honor, Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of the university, at the Americana next Sunday.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 24 (UPI) -- Jacky Cupit, posting the lowest 54-hole total of the 1965 golf tour, grabbed a two-stroke lead in the third round of the Texas open today with a 31, 33-64 and a 200 total.
A blast at racial discrimination in the Southern Federal Courts by the Southern Regional Council this week has raised questions about the operation of the American jury system as a whole.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Mississippi Freedom Democratic party drew up plans today for a nationwide lobbying effort to gather support for its campaign to unseat the five Mississippi Representatives.

WASHINGTON -- Two centuries ago, George Washington visualized the Potomac River as an inexpensive trade route to the West. Today, the river has again drawn the attention of a President -- this time for its scenic and recreational possibilities.

James Reston's article "The Capital and the Easter Story" in the April 18 Times is the best statement I have seen of the fact that whether we admit it or not American policies and political institutions are a reflection of religious principles.

SCARDALE, N.Y., April 24 -- McLain Street, a striking old gray gelding belonging to the Duffy Stables of Rye, N.Y., began the defense of the Boulder Brook Club's spring horse show open-jumper championship today with a .500 performance.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. -- This 40,000-square- mile Canadian province sits in the Atlantic like a huge cork, stoppering the Gulf of St. Lawrence. In late spring and summer, it offers a most unusual holiday experience, and by 1966, with the completion of the eastern end of the Trans-Canada Highway, it will be entirely accessible to motorists.

DETROIT April 24 (AP) -- Gates Brown hit a pinch homer with two on base in the ninth inning today and gave the Detroit Tigers a 7-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins. The defeat ended a five-game winning streak for the Twins.

IT is unfortunate that the reviewer of Julio Cortazar's "The Winners" (March 21) did not choose to explore some possible extensions of the theme of the novel after such an exhaustive discussion of its plot. The action unfolds on a ship, but the use of this ambience links Sr. Cortazar's work with the venerable Narrenschiff tradition, the microcosm.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 24 (AP) -- Northeastern won the varsity and junior-varsiey races today at the third annual Marist College President's Regatta.

FOR THIS WEEK: Pine shoot moth feeds on red, Scotch, Austrian and mugo pines; clip off and burn infested shoots or spray groups of trees with Sevin and malathion. . . . Last call to apply pre-emergent chemicals to control crabgrass. . . . Start mowing the lawn if the grass is over two inches tall. . . . Finish rose pruning.

The Inter-American Development Bank reported today that 1964 was a year of marked recovery in the rate of economic development in Latin America.

Providence Journal: The Vietcong are backed by hundreds of thousands of North Vietnamese regular forces which are in turn backed by millions of Chinese. What forces have we to back our men? Thus it will begin, the long-dreaded U.S. entanglement on the Asian land mass. But where will it end?

Some 2,000 members of Cancer Care are expected to spend a weekend at the Concord Hotel in Kiamesha, N.Y., from May 14 through 16, to benefit the agency, which assists cancer patients and their families.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24 -- In recognition of the increasingly strategic role of desalinization of water in the economies of less developed countries, the United Nations has published a handbook on simplified procedures for computing investment and maintenance costs for such plants.
ALBANY, April 24 -- The leaders of the Democratic-controlled Legislature were reported today to be seeking to remove one, and perhaps two, of the four members of the State Investigation Commission.

DERBY, Conn., April 24 -- Possibly the finest eight-oared varsity crew Jack Frailey has developed at Massachusetts Institute of Technology defeated Yale by the rather astonishing margin of three lengths today on the Housatonic River.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- A Soviet wartime commander, Marshal Ivan S. Konev, has hailed the meeting of Soviet and United States forces on the Elbe River 20 years ago as a "symbol of victory, of military comradeship in years of war."

MRS. AMES is different -- an old-fashioned, pleasantly eccentric widow ill at ease in a modern-day community which has grown up around her. Over the years, she has gradually withdrawn into a seclusion shared by an ever-increasing number of stray cats.

MADRID -- The "winds of change" have been blowing with rising intensity along Spain's tourist routes. In some places, they race at gale velocity, and elsewhere they limp across the bewitching plains like a sirocco on its last legs.

It is nonetheless fascinating and fresh, because of its often superbly precise attention to a rich world that includes many animals and plants as well as human beings.
TORONTO, April 24 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson completed two years as head of the minority Liberal Government this week and said he was ready for two more.

The Yankees did better yesterday against Wilmer Dean Chance, the big farmer from Wooster, Ohio, who pitches for the Los Angeles Angels. Yankee batters collected six hits and three runs off Chance, but they still could not beat him.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 24 (AP) -- Barbara McIntire of Colorado Springs beat Nancy Roth of Hollywood, Fla., 1 up, today to win her fourth North and South amateur golf championship since 1957.

DOES orthodox medicine have a stranglehold on the public? Are important health benefits denied the sick through the studied neglect by physicians of "fringe" methods such as acupuncture and naturopathy? Brian Inglis suggests that the answer is "yes."

MARTIN QUIGLEY'S novel concerns a single June day in the life of Barney Mann, field manager of a National League team here called the Blue Jays. It is full of ordeals. Between reluctantly lecturing U.N. dignitaries on the fine points of baseball and reluctantly accepting an invitation to a party being thrown by the club's playboy owner, Mr. Quigley's hero must win a ball game.
RIO DIE JANEIRO, April 24 -- Theatrical productions that voice a political protest against Brazil's semimilitary regime are producing good entertainment and a new look in drama here.

The Commonwealth Edison Company's Dresden nuclear generating station, 50 miles southwest of Chicago, will become the country's largest commercial atomic power plant with the addition of a second unit costing $76 million.

BONN, April 20 -- A Swiss lawyer will protest to the European Commission on Human Rights in the next few days on behalf of an Austrian citizen who has been kept in a West German jail for five months without formal charges against him.
A woman in Canada wrote: "Please find my husband. He's no good and I want to serve divorce papers on him."
The redeployment of 500 additional patrolmen to nightly street duty as part of Mayor Wagner's campaign against crime apparently achieved early success, the Police Department indicated yesterday.

MOAB, Utah -- Barring floods, fires or Indian uprisings on May 8, the boys at Dugout Ranch will whack a rusty steel tire that serves as a dinner bell and invite all outlanders who happen by to join in a large, no-napkin chuckwagon feed down at Squaw Spring.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 24 -- "Alice in Progressive Wonderland," a cabaret show by a young newspaperman, is getting the loudest laughs in Belgrade with its merciless exposure of shortcomings in Yugoslav Communism.
SEATTLE, April 24 -- Angry American fishermen are considering drastic action in their continuing dispute with Japan over salmon fishing in the North Pacific Ocean.

ASK any bridge player to name the most successful tournament player in the last 15 years and you will probably get the wrong answer. The most popular choices would no doubt be Charles Goren and Oswald Jacoby, whose names are known wherever bridge is played.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The Penn Relays, America's oldest and biggest track and field carnival, ended today with the greatest record binge within memory.

NEW ORLEANS, April 24 -- Efforts to restore stability to ocean shipping rates from Gulf ports to continental Europe are beginning to show fruit, a steamship official said here this week.

By the last week of April, whether spring's beginnings were early or late, the season commences to catch up with itself. May will complete the transition. Already the green and fragrant world of busy chlorophyll and bright-petaled blossoms is taking shape. The old saw about April showers and May flowers is more than a rhyme, yet somewhat less than complete truth.

While sudden or violent exercise is no longer a necessity of our daily life, no one can predict when it may become essential. Emergencies do occur and by their very nature they occur without warning or time for training.
A REVIEW in these pages on Feb. 14 made reference to the Odeon import of the Shostakovich Twelfth Symphony, played by the Philharmonic Orchestra under Georges Pretre, as evidently withdrawn.
Department store sales continue to increase last week. Volume exceeded levels attained in the corresponding 1964 week and in the preceding 1965 week.

When Lewis Dusenbery Gilbert literally took a couple of body blows for his highly vocal efforts from a fellow shareholder at the Thatcher Glass Manufacturing Company annual meeting early this month, it proved what the man who likes to think of himself as the "nation's number one stockholder" has long known and even revels in -- the way of the reformer is hard.

In your April 11 issue you published a letter from Burnham Finney in which he said that The Times was incorrect in having stated (in a news story on March 28) that John Diebold "is known as the man who coined the word automation."

CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 24 -- Johnny Sellers rode his fifth triumph of the day in bringing Ogden Mills Phipps' filly, Time Tested, home first in the $30,150 Delaware Valley Handicap on Garden State Park's opening card today.
Clocks were set ahead one hour this morning as daylight saving time began for the 47th year. The lost hour will be regained on Oct. 31 with the return of standard time.

OFF BROADWAY is further than most theatergoers are willing to go. It isn't surprising, then, that a farther out branch of the theater, known variously among its initiates as Off Off Broadway, the underground or, with more pride than proof, the avant garde, should have sprung up completely unnoticed by the people who fill the seats nightly at "Hello, Dolly!" and "The Odd Couple."

Publication in Moscow last week of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin's blueprint for the next Soviet Five-Year Plan directed attention again to the economic problems the present Kremlin rulers inherited from Nikita S. Khrushchev and their attempts to cope with those problems.
A busy week of auctions is scheduled at Parke-Bernet Galleries, with sales of modern prints, paintings from the 14th to 19th centuries and of English furniture, decorations and old masters.
TRANS WORLD AIRLINES asked the Civil Aeronautics Board last week for permission to try an experimental "Family Style Fare Plan" for one year, beginning June 3, on all T.W.A. domestic routes.
SARNIA, Ont., April 24 (AP) -- Four persons were found dead today aboard a 50-foot luxury cruiser after it docked here, across the St. Clair River from Port Huron, Mich.
PARIS, April 24 -- The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, will invite President de Gaulle to visit Moscow when he confers with the French leader Tuesday, Communist sources reported today.
MONTREAT, N.C., April 24 -- After an hour of debate today, the Southern Presbyterian Church voted to keep in effect a speaking invitation this summer to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
THE marketing age is fast creeping up on a last holdout, Art. Latest evidence: Edition MAT, which will soon make its U.S. debut at New York's Museum of Modern Art. What is Edition MAT?

DANANG, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 25 -- Vietcong guerrillas overwhelmed two United States Marine outposts near the vital air base at Danang today, killing two Americans and wounding four others. It was the first conventional military attack against United States combat troops in South Vietnam.
BATON ROUGE, April 24 -- Vice President Humphrey stepped in at the request of Gov. John J. McKeithen to help avert a potentially explosive racial situation at Bogalusa, La., this week.
AN old gag, familiar to chess buffs, is that Black enjoys a forced win. White, having the first move, has the first opportunity to blunder.
In an era of mergers when the big brokerage houses grow bigger, many a small firm finds it can compete successfully -- and make money at the same time.
A 23-year-old clerk who helped protect a young college girl from an attacker aboard a speeding subway train was praised for his action yesterday by a Criminal Court judge.

AN eight-tined electric hoe, introduced this spring, can be used for soil preparation and cultivation. Equipped with a dual speed control, the steel hoe, called Starflyte Model 3320, will dig a six-inch-wide swath through the earth to a depth of three inches.

YONKERS, April 24 -- Smoky Mountain, the 4-year-old roan gelding who recently returned from Rockingham Park in New Hampshire after starting and winning one race there, made it two in a row tonight by capturing the featured $10,000 invitation handicap pace.
An assistant dean of Columbia College charged yesterday that colleges fail to provide students with adequate information on the psychological and physiological aspects of sex.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A Senate subcommittee has set aside three days in the coming week to find out whether Food and Drug Administration agents used melodramatic snoop, swoop and seize tactics in petty law enforcement cases.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 (UPI) -- The police arrested today three men in connection with a million-dollar art theft that occurred March 20 at the Hillsborough, Calif., estate of the late W.W. Crocker, a banking and real-estate tycoon.

RED BANK, N.J., April 24 -- Paintings, sculpture, wood carvings, rare books, prints and maps, all relating to the sea, are being assembled for display at the Monmouth Museum for a four-week exhibition that starts on Sunday, May 2.

BALTIMORE, April 24 (AP) -- Lee Thomas slammed a three-run homer, his fourth hit of the game, into the right-field bleachers in the 12th inning today to give the Boston Red Sox a 7-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

BEDFORD, N.Y., April 24 -- Sleighs, buggies and old carriages will be dragged out of local barns in the next two weeks to create an antique atmosphere around a tall evergreen for the "History on the Village Green" fair on May 8.

COLUMBUS, Ceylon, April 24 -- Procedures for payment of compensation to one British and two American oil companies whose assets and installations in Ceylon were nationlized in April, 1962, by the then Premier, Sirimavo Bandaranaike, are to be speeded up, the Government said this week.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- Chicagoans reacted enthusiastically this week to an announcement of plans for a downtown subway system that would eliminate the ancient elevated structure in the Loop.
TAMPA, Fla., April 24 (UPI) -- Emmett Kelly led the circus world today in paying tribute to Paul Jung, the 65-year-old clown who was found slain in his New York hotel room Wednesday.
Buoyed by a stream of favorable first-quarter earnings reports, the over-the-counter market moved up last week in active trading.

Five thousand men in their 20's and early 30's turned up at George Washington High School in the Inwood section of upper Manhattan yesterday morning to take a test for transit patrolman.

The booming American economy is threatened with a setback this week. The Administration, businessmen and economists are watching the labor negotiations in Pittsburgh between the United Steelworkers of America and the 11 major steel companies.

DAWSONVILLE, Ga. THE asphalt cuts a mud-bleeding gash into a red clay bank just before U.S. 19 winds over the hills into Dawsonville, 51 miles north of Atlanta. The eye moves ahead, past ragged patches of dried cornstalk and broom sedge swaying in the wind, to a stark silhouette, rising on a ridge like an upthrust tower in El Greco's "Toledo."

A City College freshman was killed early yesterday in a fall from the roof of a Bronx building, apparently while searching for the burglar who had ransacked the apartment where he lived with his parents.

Otherwise, an announcement by one of their number, Charles Berrard, might have gone unrecorded. As it was, it went unheeded for six months.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24 -- The Nieman Foundation is considering using the facilities of the projected Kennedy Institute at Harvard University for an advanced seminar program.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., April 23 -- The appointment of Joseph C. Palamountain Jr., provost of academic affairs at Wesleyan University, as president of Skidmore College was announced here today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 24 -- President Sukarno today signed a decree ordering the seizure of all foreign-owned enterprises in Indonesia.

THERE has been a cherished notion abroad these many years that getting along with the group and conforming to the rules of society results in an assembly-line man. This notion, as it turns out, is as conformist a view as ever there was. Conformity, in most of its aspects, is not necessarily a sign of weak behavior or of low I.Q., but rather a sensible approach to getting along in the world.

TRENTON, April 25 -- Jim McElreath, a 37-year-old Arlington, Tex., driver, drove a new rear-mounted Offenhauser to victory in a thrilling championship race on Trenton's International Speedway today. His car, owned by John Zink of Tulsa, Okla., was designed by Jack Brabham, a former world road-racing champion.

GOOSE ISLAND, Norwalk, Conn., April 25 -- A group from the Westport Audubon Society came to this island today to try to save a colony of breeding terns, a handsome, gull-like creature, by poisoning rats suspected of eating the eggs in the ground nests.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 25 (UPI) -- President Georgi Tralkov will make an official visit to the Soviet Union early next month, the Government announced tonight.

No American industrialist showed greater sensitivity to the enormous human problems engendered by automation than John I Snyder Jr., chairman and president of U.S. Industries, Inc. His company pioneered in making equipment to be used in automating factories, and he never wavered in his conviction that this country had to avail itself fully and swiftly of new technology to raise living standards and maintain its competitive position in world markets.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 25 -- Jimmy Rice, the 14-year-old grandson of the owner of Rice Farms of Huntington, won the horsemanship championship, then led his team to the Class B title in the Junior Olympics today at the Thomas School of Horsemanship.
SAN JUAN, P.R., April 25 -- Juan Bosch said tonight that he had accepted the call of rebels in the Dominican Republic to return as soon as possible as the constitutional President.

DURHAM, N.C., April 25 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey said today that the United States was approaching the point in its history when "the senseless struggle of class against class, region against religion, and race against race will be ended."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 25 -- Australis, a 6-year-old bay mare owned and ridden by 16-year-old Danny Lopez of Glen Head, L.I., became the open jumper champion tonight in the Boulder Brook Club's annual spring horse show.

Drastic new curbs on the use of water are in the offing here unless there is a sharp increase in the amount of rainfall by June 1, Armand D'Angelo, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas land Electricity, warned yesterday.
PAU, France, April 25 (UPI) -- Jim Clark of Scotland, the former world driving champion, won the Paul Formula Two grand prix auto race today in a Lotus Cosworth.

The appointment of Walter H. Wheeler Jr. as chairman of the United Community Campaigns this year was announced yesterday. Mr. Wheeler, chairman of Pitney-Bowes, Inc., manufacturers of postage meters, will mobilize support for local United Funds and Community Chests.
PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP) -- Steel union and management negotiators waited today for the Government's next move to head off a strike.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A newscaster getting ready for his evening program on an Iowa station wants an up-to-date commentary on an issue before Congress.
AMONG the smaller chess clubs in the metropolitan area, one -- fiercely competitive in individual and match play -- is the Baltic Chess Club of New York.

A pastoral letter from Cardinal Spellman urging generous contributions to the annual Bishops Fund Appeal was read yesterday by the Rev. Edward McCorry in St. Patrick's Cathedral, and from all pulpits in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

Having just swept the last Soupy Sales addict off our doorsill after ten days of idolatrous teen-age mayhem at our supposedly dead neighbor, the Paramount Theater, we can think of many things the country needs more than a mass import of similarly talented pop entertainers from Great Britain -- or even Hoboken.
ROME, April 25 -- Premier Aldo Moro reaffirmed today the ties of friendship between the United States and Italy and his nation's loyalty to the Atlantic alliance.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced an amendment today to its Regulation T, which limits credit that may be extended on securities.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25 -- American military strategists here regard the destruction of 24 bridges -- a majority of the bridges in North Vietnam's southern sector -- as the first effective result of 12 weeks of bombing.

MOSCOW, April 25 (AP) -- One of the Soviet Union's most vigorous antireligious propagandists was castigated today for having insulted religious believers. The rebuke came from the official magazine Nauka I Religiya -- Science and Religion.

The National Broadcasting Company will televise a one-hour interview with the two Soviet astronauts who participated in last month' s historic Voskhod 2 orbital flight, during which one of them became the first man to walk in space.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 25 -- The spanking performance contributed by Tom Rolfe in the Stepping Stone Purse yesterday caused the stock of that excellent colt to zoom in the speculation on Saturday's Kentucky Derby.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- President Johnson awarded Presidential citations today to two American and three Vietnamese military units for heroic service in the war against the Vietcong.

Six school dropouts working as teacher-helpers in kindergartens on the Lower East Side since mid-March were so successful that the experimental program is being expanded, the Board of Education and Mobilization for Youth reported yesterday.

BOSTON, April 25 -- Six months and nine days after the start of the National Basketball Association season, the campaign ended today just as everyone expected it would -- with the Boston Celtics the league champions for the seventh straight year, a record.

In a letter entitled "Spain's Economic Improvements Noted" published April 13, Benjamin Welles disputed some statements which appeared recently in a New York Times editorial, among them the assertion that in Spain "most Spaniards live just above tile poverty line," which Mr. Welles qualified as "nonsense."

Leaders of major American Jewish organizations expressed disappointment and criticism yesterday at a report from Rome that opposition was rising among conservative Roman Catholic prelates to the draft declaration on the attitude of the church toward Jews.
NEW DELHI, April 25 -- Indian intelligence has reported that Pakistan has ordered mobilization of her armed forces, official spokesmen said tonight.
Ed Bowes led a one, two, three New York Athletic Club finish yesterday in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union eight-mile run at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx.

SANTA MARIA, Calif., April 25 (AP) -- A 16-year-old runaway from Long Beach, Calif., turned roadside sniper today and killed two motorists with a high-powered rifle, sheriff's officers reported. He wounded 11 other drivers and passengers.
TIMONIUM, Md., April 25 -- Ch. Aizbel the Dauphin de Usher, a black miniature poodle, won his first best-in-show award today at the 30th annual Baltimore Kennel Club show. There were 1,168 entries.

The City Planning Commission's proposal to improve commuter service by integrating the Long Island Rail Road into the municipal subway system represents the longest step yet taken by any agency toward a basic solution of the metropolitan area's chaotic transportation problems.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 26 -- American and South Vietnamese spokesmen confirmed for the first time today that a regular unit of the North Vietnamese Army was fighting in South Vietnam.
PARIS, April 25 -- A new candidate entered the French presidential race today while an old one reinforced his position.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday it was tightening its standards for new listings as well as for continued listings.
BERGEN-BELSEN, Germany, April 25 -- It rained in Bergen-Belsen today.
The Waterfront Commission is planning vigorous opposition to any weakening of its role in the port or any substantive change in its rules, sources close to the agency said yesterday.
Exhortations to combat pornography and obscene literature were delivered to two communion breakfasts here yesterday.

Your editorial of April 19 "Inescapable Veto" describes Governor Rockefeller's veto of the bill to raise the state minimum wage to $1.50 art hour as "a necessary act of economic realism." I must dissent from your definitions of "necessary" and "realism."
Representative Adam Clayton Powell's political power could not survive the destruction of Harlem's black ghetto, Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, psychologist, believes.

Heroic King Henry V of England popped up as "Hypocrite Hal" at the 75th annual meeting of the Shakespeare Club of New York last night at the Delmonico Hotel. One hundred and fifty members and guests pondered the fate of Falstaff, Bardolph and Pym in Shakespeare's three plays about the King and his father.

TOKYO, Monday, April 26 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists quoted Prince Sihanouk today as having said that an "international conference on Cambodia should not be used by certain big powers to bait their adversaries."
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $92,068,132,569. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

MONZA, Italy, April 25 (AP) -- A 30-year-old Swiss driver, Tommy Spychiger, was killed today when his privately entered Ferrari Prototype missed a curve, turned over and exploded in the Monza 621-mile automobile race.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A panel of scientists has urged Congress to make the National Science Foundation "a much larger agency than it now is" to insure adequate Federal support of basic research.
LORAIN, Ohio -- The headlines are black with warnings of a strike next Saturday for higher pay, but the workers in this steel center are more worried about jobs than money.

Stewardesses are pretty. Stewardesses are charming. Stewardesses get married -- usually within two and a half years after they begin flying. Because of this, many of the nation's airlines are facing an increasingly severe shortage of flight hostesses.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- By beating the San Francisco Giants, 4-3, with a seven-hitter in the second game of today's double-header, Warren Spahn gave the New York Mets a split for the day and victory, three games to one, in a wild weekend series.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- This is the day after the Penn Relays here and the Drake Relays at Des Moines, Iowa. Tradition dictates that the performances in these gigantic track and field carnivals be placed side by side for minute comparison leading to an authoritative judgment that one meet is superior to the other.

The new rector of the Episcopal Church of the Ascension spoke about "The Door Between Church and World" in his first sermon yesterday. The Episcopal church at Fifth Avenue and 10th Street has been known as "The Church of the Open Door" since 1929, when a policy of never locking the building was begun.
Observation of National Library Week began yesterday in the 50 states, the District of Columbia and in Armed Forces bases throughout the world.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Bobby Hull led a third-period barrage against the outplayed Montreal Canadiens and the Chicago Black Hawks coasted to a 5-1 victory tonight to square accounts in the Stanley Cup Playoff finals.

A new 186-bed pavilion was dedicated yesterday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn's Borough Park section, while protests were raised over plans to close St. Catherine's Hospital in the Greenpoint-Williamsburg area.
This week could well turn out to be a climactic week for the municipal bond market.

PITTSBURGH, April 25 -- Steel mills were preparing last week for a possible strike May 1 or shortly afterwards. While still not giving up hope that some type of extension could be negotiated with the United Steelworkers of America, mill officials were taking the following steps:

A call was issued last night for a research program by independent men's wear retailers to stave off inroads being made by dual distributors. Louis C. Stengel Jr., president of the Manhattan Shirt Company, told a group of New York merchants the potential of the independents was being "eroded by competition from manufacturer-owned stores."
They hissed and hollered and debated one another for about seven hours yesterday, and when it was over -- 70,000 words later -- they could not agree on much of anything.
Steamship operators and their ship crews are moving ahead in achieving a new atmosphere of labor-management cooperation in solving merchant marine problems.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday warned housewives who are embarking on spring cleaning to beware of unscrupulous door-to-door salesmen bent on a spring cleanup of their own.
Fifty years ago, on the night of April 24, 1915, the deportation and massacre of Christian Armenians began in Turkey.

WEST BABYLON, L.I., April 25 -- Bill Healy, a New London, Conn., doctor who does most of his dinghy sailing in either Marblehead, Mass., or the Thames River fleet in New London, won the Region One Penguin Class championship today on Great South Bay.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 25 -- The martini glasses have been put away, and mint juleps are back in style today at the elegant Greenbrier here. The men from Madison Avenue and their ladies have gone home.

LOS ANGELES, APRIL 26 (AP) -- Dick Stuart drove in four runs with a double and home run today as the Philadelphia Phils defeated Don Drysdale for the ninth straight time and snapped the Los Angeles Dodgers' four-game winning streak with a 6-4 decision.
LOS ANGELES, April 25 (AP) -- Two offensive drives in the second half carried the United States All-Stars to a lopsided 85-68 victory over the Soviet Union's national basketball team tonight.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 2 (UPI) -- Frank Beard, who last year won a bout with encephalitis, today won a stretch battle for the Texas open's $7,500 top prize with a final round 35, 33 -- 68 and a 72-hole total of 270.

CAIRO, April 25 -- The Egyptian Communist party, bowing to President Gamal Abdel Nasser's threat of arrests, has decided to disband formally and adopt the popular-front tactic of pushing its members into the President's Arab Socialist Union.

An experimental program in which prominent lawyers and insurance-company representatives serve as unpaid referees has helped to reduce sharply the backlog of automobile negligence cases in New York County Civil Court.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 25 -- In fervant nationwide observances today. Australians showed the deep significance this country attaches to its part in the 1915 Allied attack at Gallipoli in World War I.

A WOMAN who is getting ready to face the world in the morning sits at her dressing table. She has been told in countless magazine articles that the current look in make-up is "natural" or "quiet," or, as one company puts it, "the clean, country look."

CAIRO, April 25 -- The Cairo press voiced concern today that Morocco, Libya and Saudi Arabia were silently supporting the proposals of President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia for Arab acceptance of Israel and negotiation over the return of the Palestine refugees.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Agricultural Department announced yesterday it would issue new and corrected figures tomorrow on stocks of soybeans in the United States.

The Rev. Dr. Milton Galamis who organized three boycotts to protest racial imbalance in the city's public school system, went on public record yesterday as an enthusiastic supporter of the Board of Education's new policy statement.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Bell Telephone System employment should remain fairly stable in the next 10 years, according to a study of automation effects that was made for a major union in the telephone industry.
AFTER a year and seven months of exile, Juan Bosch may be about to return to the Dominican Republic to reassume the Presidency from which he was ousted in September, 1963.

LONDON, April 25 -- Why should a Prime Minister with a margin of just four seats in the House of Commons insist on pressing a piece of legislation that arouses the most noise from the Opposition and has no unanimity of support in his own party?

A Unitarian minister emphasized yesterday the role of the layman as that of a religious dilettante "who appreciates, discusses, discriminates, criticizes and encourages" in a way to make his life "something in which he may delight."

DOTHAN, Ala., April 25 -- The Rev. Billy Graham preached in the rain today to an interracial crowd of 2,500 huddled under umbrellas. It was the second day of his tour of racial conciliation in Alabama.
Representatives of the Board of Education and of 1,000 school bus drivers and mechanics reached an agreement last night. They predicted the 20-day-old walkout would end tomorrow.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 25 -- The Netherlands Government appears more interested in getting a bigger share of the profits from this country's underground gas treasure than in telling the world how big the treasure is.
THE bare bones, of H.G. Wells's "Kipps" have been invoked to fashion a Victorian soap opera to music.
In Daniel Nagrin's recital at Kaufmann Concert Hall Saturday night, the dancer's first solo program since 1959, no fewer than six new works were introduced.
Mayor Wagner, now coming down to the basic decisions on his 1965-66 budget, knew he was heading into trouble months ago.
The number of refugees in South Vietnam who have fled under Communist pressure from central rural areas to coastal cities has risen to "several hundred thousand," according to Premier Phan Huy Quat.
The Eastman Kodak Company turned in a sparkling report of its operations in the first quarter with earnings up 41 per cent on a sales increase of 16 per cent.
IT is 65 years now since the publication of "Sister Carrie" and 40 since "An American Tragedy" made its appearance.

ADEN, April 25 -- Sheik Abdullah Bin Hussein al-Ahmar, Yemen's Interior Minister in the Cabinet announced by Premier Ahmed Mohammed Noman last night, issued a statement broadcast by the Sana radio today inviting all Yemeni tribes to a "national peace conference" in Khamer, 20 miles north of Sana, on April 30.
MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 25 (AP) -- Fred Lorenzen won his fourth straight 250-mile stock car race at Martinsville Speedway today.

VICTORIA, B.C., April 25 -- British Columbia, which thrives on superlatives, whether they concern the weather or the province's boundless natural riches, has a new one -- the staying power of its Social Credit Premier, W.A.C. Bennett.

The fighting between Pakistanis and Indians in the desolate salt marshes known as the Rann of Cutch seems senseless. Yet two important nations do not indulge in a dangerous military clash without reason.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 25 -- Premier Levi Eshkol asserted today that the Arab refugees should remain in the Arab states for their own good.
ROCK ISLAND, Ill., April 25 (AP) -- Murky, swirling floodwater from the swollen Mississippi River surged through a broken dike in Rock Island today, inundating a 54-block industrial area.
THE distinctive dress worn by Roman Catholic nuns usually impresses laymen, especially non-Catholics, as being charged with drama.
WILD water cress in swiftly running streams is a harbinger of spring that catches the eye of botanist and cooking enthusiast alike.

Triad, a dance group composed of Kazuko Hirabayashi, Richard Gain and Richard Kuch, made its debut at Kaufmann Concert Hall yesterday afternoon in performances of works choreographed by the three dancers.

The Women's City Club called yesterday for the abolition of the offices of borough presidents, which "at a time of city fiscal crisis consumed close to $4 million of the current city budget, although the present city charter sharply reduced their duties."

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Whatever inducements may have been offered to Gary Thomas Rowe to be an undercover man in the Ku Klux Klan for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, it can be taken for granted that he will not be left to fend for himself on the hostile streets of Selma, Ala.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- A nationwide conservative organization appealed today for an American "forward strategy" to win the war in Vietnam. Its proposal included the commitment of "sufficient American ground forces" to do "the necessary job."

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 25 -- The vice president and treasurer of the United Medical Service of New York (Blue Shield) and his wife were killed early this morning when a fire destroyed their home here.

A report calling for the establishment of a $38-million tristate regional system of 32 publicly owned airports for general aviation was released yesterday by the Tri-State Transportation Committee.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 25 -- The United States-supported Government of Donald Reid Cabral fell today after a military coup.

PARIS, April 25 -- There were two heroes of the triple bill of Stravinsky ballets just staged at the Paris Opera. The first, not unexpectedly, was the absent Igor Stravinsky. The second was the very much present conductor, Pierre Boulez.
THE Royal Ballet's magnificent production "Giselle," which has been seen here previously, was reintroduced on Saturday with afternoon and evening performances at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Members of New York Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2 voted at a meeting yesterday to submit their proposed contract with the Publishers Association of New York City to a membership referendum for approval or disapproval.
A sizable majority of registered Democrats in New York City disapprove of Mayor Wagner's performance in office, according to a poll completed about two weeks ago.

The Foster Wheeler Corporation had a big day yesterday. It announced the election of a new chairman and chief executive officer, the resumption of a regular quarterly dividend and an increase in first-quarter earnings.
BONN, April 26 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard is planning a "private" trip to the United States in June to reconfirm his credentials as a German politician in good standing in America.

Your April 13 editorial highlights a point that cannot be too strongly emphasized: sooner or later the city must use purified and treated Hudson River water. It had better he sooner. It is only ten years since the city made its ill-advised commitment to construct Cannonsville and it has already become even clearer than it was then that the additional supply anticipated from the Delaware River watershed is undependable and limited.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Supreme Court today cleared the way for trial in the New York State Courts of the Rev. Milton A. Galamison and 59 others arrested during civil rights demonstrations in New York last spring and summer.
NEWARK, April 26 -- A Newark police lieutenant was indicted today by an Essex County grand jury on charges of nonfeasance in office.

It may be only a short distance from Herald Square to Nassau and Suffolk Counties, but adequate communications between managers of main and branch stores evidently requires more than mere telephone lines.
ROME, April 26 -- An American magazine publisher said today that he had withdrawn, at the request of Italian publishers, passages in a speech dealing with the perils of the population explosion.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today major provisions of Louisiana's subversive activities and Communist-control law.

AFTER about 50 years, the Fourth Symphony by Charles Ives finally received its world premiere. Leopold Stokowski, who through the years has been responsible for introducing so much major new music to the United States, led the American Symphony Orchestra through the extraordinary score last night in Carnegie Hall.

THE Cavendish Club celebrated its recent removal from Park Avenue to 23 Central Park South with a cocktail party last Friday evening. Well over 200 persons were present, including almost all the elite of New York bridge, and some 60 of them occupied themselves at the card tables.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner showed unconcern yesterday over the findings of a poll that showed their popularity at low ebb.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Officials of two large corporations agreed today that top management must keep up the pressure on subordinates if integrated employment is to be achieved.
ALBANY, April 26 -- The Democratic legislative leadership acknowledged today that it would be unable to meet a court-imposed deadline for passing a redistricting plan.

HIGH POINT, N.C., April 26 -- The Southern furniture market is now the one to watch. It has superseded Chicago as the place where furniture manufacturers from all over the country first take the wraps off their new designs. And here is where the buyers decide what furniture selection a consumer will have in department stores in the coming months.

The Metropolitan Opera Association has named two directors to its board and added two members to the organization. The new board members are Frank E. Taplin and Walker G. Buckner. Mr. Taplin is a co-founder, director and board chairman of Scurry-Rainbow Oil, Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta, and a director and principal stockholder of the North American Coal Corporation of Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Children write to complain that they are bored and life is no fun. "What can we do?" they ask. The following list of things for children to do is based on a survey of things their parents did when they were children.
NEW DELHI, April 26 -- The Indian Army has been put on an alert. New fighting erupted, meanwhile, between large Indian and Pakistani forces on the Cutch-Sind border.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 26 -- A mob of 20,000 Cambodian students attacked the United States Embassy today, hurling rocks, ink bottles and other missiles at the building and ripping down the American flag.
WASHINGTON, D.C., April 26 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the dismissal of Federal charges against the accused killers of three civil rights workers in Mississippi last year.
Copper futures prices, subject to wide price movements in recent days, dropped the daily limit of two cents a pound yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange.

" I DECIDED I would try to have the best of everything for this boutique." said Nancy Reals, owner of the six-week-old Boutique at Enrico Caruso, 110 East 55th Street, "the best clothes, the best decorative objects for the home -- and the best pastries."
CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) -- Twenty-four pickets protesting alleged hiring discrimination against Negroes were arrested today at a Federal building construction site where they blocked traffic.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- With the exception of a few pictures, the large and celebrated Chester Dale art collection will be seen for the first time in its entirety at the National Gallery of Art, beginning May 6.
MONTREAL, April 26 -- Strange things are happening in the Stanley Cup playoff final.
A probationary patrolman, helped by a passerby, captured a robbery suspect in a subway station yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 26 -- A Chicago toy designer has what he hopes will be a gold finger in the toy market.
Municipal bond dealers, heading into their busiest week so far in 1965, got news yesterday that the Public Housing Administration planned to sell $133.28 million of bonds May 26.

This first novel by a talented English writer exploits the familiar fantasy of the would-be voyeur: to be, an unnoticed witness to imagined obscene events, the fly on the wall. It also proves once again that as a literary device shock is only fleetingly effective; we become inured. When a whole novel is made to depend on slock, and on shock alone, our responses are apt to be equally limited -- most often to disgust.

HONG KONG, Aril 26 -- Communist China indicated today that it was opposed to an international conference on Cambodia that could also be used as a forum to discuss a settlement of the conflict in Vietnam.
