Sixty-five of the city's business leaders called yesterday for "a single public agency or cooperating state agencies" to operate and modernize commuter railroad services.

The mood was definitely on the "up" side yesterday at the trade show of the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers. With a record Easter season under the belts of most men's wear retailers and with consumers continuing to display their willing ness to buy higher-priced goods, merchants touring the show were generally optimistic about prospects for the fall season.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 26 -- The Rev. Dr. James V. Claypool, superintendent of the Providence district of the Methodist Church, and a distinguished Navy chaplain in World War II, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 65.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Johnson signed a liberalized and extended Manpower Development and Training Act today. He called it "a wise and necessary companion" to the Education Bill that he signed April 11.

The purchase of two properties at prices totaling about $2.5 million, one a large manufacturing plant in Brooklyn and the other a mid-Manhattan restaurant building, has been disclosed by Irving Goldman, vice president of Greenpoint Terminal Warehouse, Inc.

Qualified high school seniors whose applications for admission to Brooklyn and City Colleges were rejected because College Board scores were missing will have an opportunity to appeal, it was disclosed yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 (UPI) -- Sandy Koufax suffered his first defeat of the season tonight when the Philadelphia Phillies belted him for three runs on four hits in the first inning and went on to beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3.

After a long, hard fight that was going on while historic buildings were being knocked down like tenpins, New York finally has a landmarks preservation law. The law is an immense achievement, but it gives no guarantee that anything can be saved. It is only a protective tool to make historic and esthetic preservation possible.

HAVANA, April 26 -- The departure of Cubans for Moscow for training in Communist party work and many personnel exchanges on various levels suggest that Premier Fidel Castro's regime is again strengthening its ties with the Soviet Union.

LONDON, April 26 -- Britain has accepted a proposal by the Soviet Union that they try to organize an international conference on the neutrality of Cambodia, a neighbor of Vietnam. One object would be to provide an opportunity for the United States, North and South Vietnam and Communist China to discuss ending the Vietnamese war.
" Is this a Beatle thing?" asked a passer-by of a policeman in front of Carnegie Hall yesterday morning.
LISBON, April 26 -- The Harkness Ballet received a stormy pateada or stomping -- the Portuguese equivalent of booing at the end of its performance last night in the Sao Carlos Opera House.
ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP) -- The May Department Stores Company of St. Louis announced today it had acquired control of the Meier Frank Company, Inc., of Portland, Ore.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Washington's war of words over Vietnam was escalating today, with critics sharpening their language and the Johnson Administration expanding its efforts to win public and Congressional support.

In a rare political move, the leaders of the New York County Republican and Democratic committees announced yesterday their opposition to a special election to fill the State Senate seat vacated by Mrs. Constance Baker Motley when she became Borough President on Feb. 23.
DECORATING news may be made by far-out fashions, but most people find that they cannot live with such extremes in their homes.
Harry A. Leeb, a multimillionaire who married a young divorcee in the Champagne Room at El Marocco 10 months ago, asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to annul the marriage.
Allied Chemical Corporation reported record first-quarter sales and earnings at its annual meeting here yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Tuesday, April 27 -- The United States Navy will begin later today to evacuate American citizens who want to leave the Dominican Republic in view of the mounting threat of a breakdown in public order.
The big question in the cigarette industry yesterday was whether the price increase instituted by four manufacturers in recent weeks would be rescinded.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it had granted $918,500 to the National Municipal League for a study of the implications of legislative reapportionment, covering at least 10 states.
Secretary Rusk's acceptance of an international conference on Cambodia could open the door for informal talks on Vietnam and the entire Indochina problem if the Communists want the door opened.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Supreme Court reversed today the convictions of 29 Freedom Riders arrested in 1961 in Jackson, Miss., during a protest against racial segregation in interstate bus and train travel.
The Moiseyev Dance Company, which will give 13 performances at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning May 18, will also play 14 performances at Madison Square Garden from June 15 through 27.
HAYNEVILLE, Ala., April 26 -- The three Ku Klux Klansmen charged with the murder of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo pleaded not guilty today on arraignment in this sleepy county seat.

The annual bridge party of the Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution will be given next Tuesday at the Colony Club. Plans were completed recently at a tea given by Mrs. John Sheaff Zantzinger at the Pierre Hotel.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 26 (UPI) -- Mario Savio, who led a mass student sit-in demonstration at the University of California last December, announced today he was quitting the campus Free Speech Movement.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- An independent panel of experts urged today an immediate start on a program to explore, Mars for possible signs of life.
The Metropolitan Opera has commissioned Marc Chagall to paint two large murals that will hang at each side of the entrance of its new opera house at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
A second major New York City bank, the Bankers Trust Company, plans to join forces with upstate banks through the device of a holding company.
MEXICO CITY, April 26 -- Foreign producers of sulphur in Mexico will be limited in their annual exports to 10 per cent of the country's known reserves, the Government announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Vice President Humphrey will be present tomorrow when Senate leaders and Senate liberals meet to patch up their differences on the voting rights bill.
ALBANY, April 26 -- A State Supreme Court justice upheld the legality today of a controversial school integration plan in White Plains that involves the busing of children.
The British pound moved ahead yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here.

Twenty-five placard-carrying parents picketed Junior High School 115 yesterday morning to demand renovation of the 51-year-old building before its planned conversion to an elementary school this fall.

The report of the House Subcommittee on Agriculture Appropriations, criticizing the late Rachel Carson and her book "Silent Spring," comes as no surprise. Last August, about the same time that he launched his so-called investigation of the pesticides problem, Chairman Jamie L. Whitten of this group described as a "witch hunt" the official concern about chemical residues on foodstuffs.
Severio (Sam) Cardile, the Italian-born trainer who some day hopes to become a suitable subject for a Horatio Alger rags-to-riches story, was riding high at gloomy Aqueduct yesterday.

A lawyer from Cape Town, who was one of the founders of South Africa's multiracial Liberal Party, testified yesterday that five Zulu dancers here faced a "very real risk" of official persecution if they were deported to their homeland.
LONDON, April 26 -- Joshua Macmillan, the 20-year-old grandson of former Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, was found dead last night in his room at Oxford University.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Yields on the new issues of Treasury bills eased this week.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 -- The North Vietnamese battalion that is fighting in the South apparently started moving into South Vietnam before United States air strikes in the North began on Feb. 7, a well-qualified source at the United States Operations Mission said today.
A team of Air France physicians has found that more than three-quarters of the airline's crews suffer psychologically from rapid transitions through time zones on long-distance flights.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26 -- Adlai E. Stevenson flung back today a blistering Soviet attack on the United States' policy in Vietnam with the assertion that this country would "not yield or falter in resisting aggression."
World's Fair attendance sank in yesterday's rain and drizzle to the lowest point in the exhibition's two seasons -- 22,939 paid visitors.
Three members of a committee urging reforms in the Women's House of Detention presented recommendations to Deputy Mayor Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. during a two-hour meeting yesterday at City Hall.

The American Booksellers Association has named The Publisher of the Year Award for the late John W. Barnes, president of Barnes Noble, booksellers and publishers. This award, begun last year, was won by Harper Row, with Doubleday the runner-up.
The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday that its net income soared to $1,520,650, or 23 cents a share, for the first quarter of this year.
Sales clerks and other union employes at 13 E.J. Korvette stores in the metropolitan area went on strike yesterday. Picket lines were set up but the stores remained open.

DANANG, South Vietnam, April 26 (UPI) -- Correspondents covering the Vietnam war t were told tonight they would be declared unwanted if they violated new press restrictions established by the United States.

ORADELL, N.J., April 26 (AP) -- A bus driver was shot dead today when he walked into the office of a Public Service Coordinated Transport garage as three masked gunmen were staging a holdup. The gunmen escaped with $26,000.

The City Council's Committee on State Legislation is expected to decide in a week or two whether to ask the Legislature to pass a bill calling for a civilian board to review complaints about the city's police.
Billy Mills, a runner who thoroughly enjoys running, will get more than his fill this weekend.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A new Federal program designed to help members of minority groups become independent businessmen named its first recipient today.
The London stock market was steady yesterday as an absence of selling caused prices to respond to the smallest demand.
A major effort to revitalize the liturgy, or public worship, of the Episcopal Church got under way yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NORFOLK, Va., April 26 -- Louis E. Wolfson, the $297,000-a-year board chairman of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, said today he would resign as soon as he fulfilled his obligations to the company.
HOUSTON, April 26 -- And in the confusion, Casey Stengel recorded his 3,000th victory as a manager.
A long-time practitioner of public relations took a long look last night at the future of that activity and found that it had come a long way from its infancy some 30 years ago.

A high-level Government team from Australia is spending the better part of the week in New York and Washington to air that country's concern over the curb of United States capital investments and to plead its need for continued development aid.

CAIRO, April 26 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia flew here tonight for a noisy welcome and three days of talks with President Gamal Abdel Nasser. They were expected to concentrate on a new neutralist effort to promote Vietnam peace talks.
THE burning question about "And Things That Go Bump in the Night" is this: Is Clifton James earning his salary the easy or hard way?
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that as far as he knew Federal funds for New York City's antipoverty program would be "channeled through the city."
The Celanese Corporation of America, major producer of acetate fibers, announced yesterday the appointment of Peter H. Conze and Rudolph E. Ludt as executive vice presidents.

In his column of April 21, on the recent Vietnam discussion in Cambridge, James Reston lists me as one of the defenders of President Johnson's policies. This is accurate. I noted that the President's choices had been greatly narrowed by the earlier history.

PARIS, April 26 (UPI) -- Marcel Cerdan, son of the late former world middleweight champion, scored his eighth straight victory tonight, a third-round technical knockout over Robert Di Martino of France at the Palais des Sports.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision holding that the United States and Federal officers were not liable for damages because of tear gas fired during riots over the enrollment of James Meredith at the University of Mississippi.
DECORATORS who have a pervasive influence over the look of today's home are also changing the look of interiors of the past.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26 -- Efforts to demarcate the border between Cutch and Sind have never succeeded. In the past, nomadic tribes crossed it freely, but paid taxes to both.
LONDON, April 26 (Reuters) -- Manchester United beat Arsenal, 3-1, tonight and virtually clinched the English League's First Division soccer championship.
A few special-situation stocks held the trading spotlight yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as the market generally advanced on heavy volume.

Governor Rockefeller's former special investigator, Herman T. Stichman, disclosed yesterday that he had arranged to give Attorney General Louis J. Leibowitz the data he collected during his investigation of New York City's enforcement of housing laws.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for the easy-to-prepare main dish.

The International Nickel Company presented yesterday its candidate for a coin to substitute for silver and immediately drew fire from the vending machine industry, the country's largest users of coins.

The New York City Ballet, which opened its spring season at the New York State Theater last Tuesday, announced yesterday that the 10 performances of the first week were played before audiences totaling more than 20,000 persons.
A campaign to increase the number of trees along New York streets will be opened Friday, the beginning of City Parks Week.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara reported today that North Vietnamese aggressive operations against South Vietnam had "grown progressively more flagrant."

Supporters of government medical care always maintain that politics will not interfere with the practice of medicine. We maintain that free choice of physicians is possible without any outside influence.
Most sulphur producers, thanks to rising demand and the price increases they have been able to make stick, expect to come out of this year with sizable earnings gains.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 26 -- Officials of the Connecticut Highway Department are pleased that new type of highway divider they have constructed in an experiment has thus far gone untested.

NEARLY 50 years have passed since the memorial exhibition of work by the eminent American academic painter Wiliam Merritt Chase (1849-1916) was held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It is high time for a second look, now gratefully provided at the Gallery of Modern Art in Columbus Circle.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The New York State law limiting ticket brokers to a $1.50 surcharge for each ticket was upheld today by the Supreme Court.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that New York State had proved that government support of the arts need not mean government control.
TRENTON, April 26 -- The Assembly completed legislative approval today of an investigation into the administration of New Jersey's campaign against poverty.
More than one million "practical patriots" are being sought by 27 of America's top executives.
PANAMA, April 26 -- Efforts to foment guerrilla activity among the Guaymi Indians have been reported by an eyewitness who visited their reservation in northwestern Panama last week.

The George Foster Peabody committee, which issues awards for distinguished achievement by television and radio, said yesterday that "a dreary sameness and steady conformity" dominated programing and "1964 was not a vintage year for broadcasting."

PINEHURST, N.C., April 26 (AP) -- Bill Buppert, a husky, two-handicap player from Arlington, Va., opened the North and South men's amateur golf tournament today with a major upset, eliminating the defender, Dale Morey of High Point, N.C., 1 up.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Following are the conclusions and recommendations of the National Academy of Science Study Group, which issued a report today advocating exploration of Mars:

LOS ANGELES, April 26 -- The Anti-Defamation League's regional headquarters expressed concern today over what it described as the proliferating number of front organizations of the ultra-conservative John Birch Society.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 -- Get acquainted day will be observed by Bold Lad and Bill Hartack at Churchill Downs tomorrow. The famous colt, owned by the Wheatley Stable, and the famous jockey, owned solely by his independent spirit, will operate as a combination for the first time in the Derby Trial.
The opening of the Three Swans restaurant at the Forest Hills Inn in Queens Sunday will be a benefit for the Protestant Big Brothers and the Eastern Tennis Patrons Association.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (UPI) -- Willie Pep of Hartford, the former featherweight champion, gained a unanimous six-round decision over Jackie Lennon of Philadelphia in his second fight after a six-year layoff.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today erased all previous orders removing Northeast Airlines from its New York-to-Florida route.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Legal means are being sought to avoid a strict ban by the Department of Agriculture on a Japanese gift of 3,820 new Japanese cherry trees.
PARIS, April 26 -- The Vietnamese war was the first item of discussion today when Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union began a week of talks with French officials.

It wasn't a very good day for a drive in the country yesterday, but Charles Burton, 26 years old, of 193 Lenox Avenue, had made arrangements to borrow a friend's flashy white convertible, and despite the rain, he drove to Orange, Conn., on "business."
Barge traffic on the nation's inland waterways rose 5.3 per cent during the first three months of 1965 over the comparable period in 1964, the American Waterways Operators, Inc., reported yesterday.
AFTER writing American history for more than a half-century, Samuel Eliot Morison can afford to be a little breezy.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) -- A special committee of the American Bar Association met today with representatives of news media to discuss how defendants could be insured a fair trial without hampering freedom of the press in coverage of criminal proceedings.
Striking school bus drivers and mechanics voted yesterday to end their 20-day walkout and transportation for more than 80,000 pupils was expected to be close to normal today.

A page in manuscript of "The Pickwick Papers," one of 50 of the Dickens classic known to have survived from the original draft, is in a new show at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., April 26 -- Lee E. Koppelman, Suffolk County's director of planning for five years, today was appointed executive director of the new Nassau-Suffolk Regional Planning Board.
Stock prices rose in late trading yesterday in response to rising hopes that a steel strike would be averted on May 1.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The worldwide flap over weekend Washington reports that the Administration is not absolutely excluding the use of atomic armament in Southeast Asia, regardless of any and all circumstances, was an inevitable consequence of the timing of the reports, their specific reference to "nuclear weapons," and the unmistakable marks they bore of high official authority for publication.

The Weyerhaeuser Company, the timber and pulp producer, broke all of its previous records for sales and earnings in 1964 and experienced a record first quarter this year, Norton Clapp, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

LONDON, April 26 -- Britain is facing a new dollar problem. Copies of Confederate dollars made by a bubble-gum manufacturer are flooding the country, and some citizens have tried to get pounds for them at their banks.
Steel makers in the United States put in another record performance last week, pouring 2,806,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings.
C.W. Thompson has been named operations vice president of the Refractories division of the Howe Sound Company, Mr. Thompson formerly was in charge of sales and technical services for the unit.
DETROIT, April 26 (AP) -- The six-millionth car of the 1965 model year will roll off an automobile assembly line tomorrow, about three weeks ahead of the pace set last year.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, proposed today that Congress recognize Whitehall, N.Y., as the birthplace of the United States Navy.
Following are excerpts from the transcript of Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
Higher prices and strike-free operations enabled the Anaconda Company to raise its first quarter profit by 54 per cent over the level of the corresponding 1964 quarter, the company said yesterday.

Pearl Bailey, the nightclub singer who suffered a slight heart ailment last Thursday, collapsed last night after completing her 18-number show at the Royal Box in the Americana Hotel. She made a dramatic return, however, for the second show.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., April 26 (UPI) -- Mississippi River floodwaters punctured a new hole today in the dikes protecting the Illinois-Iowa Quad City industrial complex and routed National Guardsmen from a crumbing earthen lever near Burlington, Iowa.

THE lions and tigers are frightening the deer in New Hampshire, and this time there is a little more substance to the matter than when the state suffered a rash of black panther rumors a few years ago.
PITTSBURGH, April 26 -- An agreement was reached here today between industry and union negotiators to prevent a nationwide steel strike scheduled for Saturday morning.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Federal Maritime Commission was told by an examiner today that it was not illegal for steamship lines to impose higher rates on export steel shipments than on import.

TRENTON, April 26 (AP) -- Hutchins F. Inge, a 65-year-old Negro physician, was entered as a Democratic organization candidate for the State Senate from Essex County today. He is the first Negro Senate candidate ever given Democratic organization backing.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25 -- South Vietnam's basically agricultural economy appears able to withstand the the strains of continuing guerrilla warfare and even to make some gains generated by the war effort itself, officials here maintain.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 26 -- A Democratic plan for reapportionment that would double the membership of Suffolk County's 10-man Board of Supervisors set off a heated 30-minute debate today at a board meeting.

The Great Northern Railway reported yesterday a drop of nearly $5 million in its earnings for the first quarter this year. The carrier attributed the decline directly to the fact that the unusually large wheat export shipments of last year had not reoccurred in the first period this year.

NAPLES, Italy, April 26 (UPI) -- Julie Heldman of New York overcame a display of temperament today to beat Madonna Schacht of Australia, 6-3, 4-6, 6-0, and win the women's singles title in the Naples international tennis tourney.
Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., Britain's largest chemical and fiber producer, yesterday cut the price of nylon yarn and staple fiber from 5 to 7 per cent, effective immediately.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department corrected its soybean report today to show that stocks stored on April 1 totaled 346,882,000 bushels instead of the 337,487,000 bushels reported last Friday.
DETROIT, April 26 -- James R. Hoffa said today that he would resign as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters if he were sent to jail as a result of charges against him.

The first deeply rooted controversy over the future of global communications by satellite, reflecting the revolutionary implications of using the sky as a mammoth switchboard that every country can plug into, is scheduled to reach a climax this week or next.
Earnings and sales of the Ford Motor Company soared to records in the first quarter of 1965, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The National Academy of Sciences honored eight American and British scientists tonight "for outstanding achievement in scientific research."

Three major oil companies, the Continental Oil Company, the Union Oil Company of California and the Atlantic Refining Company announced yesterday significant increases in net income for the first quarter.
The Seven-Up Company, the privately owned producer of soft drinks, announced yesterday a major realignment on the top management level.

An issue of $65 million of Greatamerica Corporation 4 per cent convertible debentures priced at 100 was oversubscribed yesterday soon after it was offered by a syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers.

THE feat of Jack Nicklaus in scoring a 64 over the tough, defiant Augusta National course during the Masters tournament a fortnight ago has sent imaginations soaring. The powerhouse from Ohio is only 25 years old and therefore it's reasonable to assume that he has yet to attain maximum proficiency.
George Whitmore Jr. left the witness stand yesterday after testifying for a day and a half. He is charged with the murder of Mrs. Minnie Edmonds, a Brooklyn charwoman, a year ago.

Greenwich Village householders, many of whom are within earshot of the noises coming from windows of the House of Detention for Women at 10 Greenwich Avenue, will open their homes Thursday afternoon in behalf of the prison.

The New York Legislature returns to work today after a recess made necessary more by the duration of its disagreements than by the volume of its lawmaking. It has put safely behind it the troublesome but essential task of raising taxes. But it simultaneously acquired an equally controversial problem: court-ordered reapportionment of legislative seats.
Canada's controversial Finance Minister, Walter Lockhart Gordon, who presented his 1965-66 budget last night, achieved a reputation as an economic wizard before he assumed his present post.

YONKERS, April 26 -- Speedy Count, the actual favorite, rallied to beat Su Mac Lad, the sentimental choice, in the Volomite Trot before 23,105 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The $25,000 free-for-all attracted eight starters, but at no stage of the 1 1/4-mile test was it anything except a two-horse race.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon, hinted today that he might seek to bar national banks from investing in state and local government revenue bonds unless Congress permitted them to underwrite these bonds as well.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Supreme Court held today that Idaho could not constitutionally impose an excise tax on gasoline delivered in Utah and later brought into the state by the buyer.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 26 -- There is no possibility that Pakistan will accept a cease-fire in the disputed Rann of Cutch area as long as Indian forces remain north of the 24th Parallel, a spokesman for the Foreign Office declared tonight.

Ten months ago James Mitchell, a gangly, 19-year-old Negro, was so quiet and withdrawn he still sucked his thumb. Yesterday he impressed a white member of Congress with a free-swinging attack on "the white power structure."

Bernard Halpert has been elected vice president of Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, Inc., and will continue to specialize in mortgage financing as he has done for the company for the last two and a half years.
OTTAWA, April 26 -- Canadian's will receive a 10 per cent personal income tax cut on July 1 under legislation introduced tonight by Finance Minister Walter L. Gordon.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A Government report today sharply criticized Federal, state and city programs for the relocation of families and businesses displaced by urban renewal and downtown highway construction. It called the programs unfair and inadequate.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 26 -- A solution to one of the major unsolved problems in genetics was proposed at a scientific meeting here today.

SANTA MARIA, Calif., April 26 (UPI) -- A 5-year-old boy, tonight became the third person to die from the barrage of bullets fired on motorists yesterday by a young sniper standing on a quiet hillside.
The containership Ponce, the latest addition to the fleet of coastal, intercoastal and offshore container transports of Sea-Land Service, Inc., is scheduled to make her debut here today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A Government report today sharply criticized Federal, state and city programs for the relocation of families and businesses displaced by urban renewal and downtown highway construction. It called the programs unfair and inadequate.
Richard Best, bass-baritone with the Metropolitan Opera Studio, made his New York solo debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
City tax collections rose substantially in the nine months ended March 31.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would close at least one entrance at 175 of the city's 481 subway stations from 8 P.M. to 4 A.M. in its campaign against crime.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 27 -High Bulgarian officials said today that 8 to 10 persons had been arrested "so far" for conspiracy against the Government and the Communist party.

ANYONE who has not been peeping during this last week and who was not among the 500 guests at the invitational preview last evening will find much to examine in Barbara D'Arcy's new room settings opening today at Bloomingdale's.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 -- It was a gray, sullen afternoon and even the tulips in the Churchill Downs infield seemed to cringe in the clammy cold. But it was the day of the Derby Trial, last of the preliminaries before the 91st Kentucky Derby at this ancient cavalry post on Saturday. The only thing that gave it any distinction was that it offered the final test to Bold Lad, one of the favorites.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Dr. James M. Nabrit Jr., president of Howard University, said today that Communists had joined a student protest group on the campus of the predominantly Negro college here in an effort to "disrupt our fight for justice."
DEMOPOLIS, Ala., April 27 -- About 250 Negro youths held a brief protest march today in this western Alabama town that is desperately trying not to become another Selma.

CLEVELAND, April 27 (UPI) -- Bobbie Brooks, Inc., announced the election of five top executives today and said some offices now in New York City would be transferred to the company's headquarters here.

The New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday voted Frank D. Gilroy's "The Subject Was Roses" as the best play of the 1964-65 season. "Fiddler on the Roof," based on stories by Sholem Aleichem, was chosen overwhelmingly as the top musical.
MOSCOW, April 27 -- The Soviet Government was reported today to be reluctant to act quickly on its own proposal for a conference on Cambodia.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27 (UPI) -- Premier Phan Huy Quat said today that the struggle in South Vietnam was the "final test" between the Communist and non-Communist worlds.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Every recent President has added something to the Presidential news conference and Lyndon Johnson is the most prolific innovator of all. At various times he has given the news conference a hay bale for a rostrum, a dog on a leash, a two-mile walk, reporters' children playing in the aisles, a television prompting device, the 20-minute opening monologue, and live Government appointees being introduced like head-table guests at the Rotary Club.
Edward R. Murrow, whose independence and incisive reporting brought heightened journalistic stature to radio and television, died yesterday at his home in Pawling, N.Y., at the age of 57.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 27 (AP) -- Bill Campbell, the National Amateur champion, led the way through an upset-riddled second round of the North and South amateur golf tournament, played today over the No. 2 par-72 course of the Pinehurst Country Club, measuring 7,000 yards.

SAN JOSE, Calif., April 27 -- A $150 million expansion program designed to keep the International Business Machines Corporation in the forefront of the computer business was announced today at the first I.B.M. shareholders meeting held in the Far West.

State Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Chimera reserved decision yesterday on a suit aimed at forcing Governor Rockefeller to call a special election to fill a Senate seat vacated by Mrs. Constance Baker Motley when she became Manhattan borough President on Feb. 23.

PARIS, April 27 -- President de Gaulle declared tonight that he strongly disapproved of "the war in Asia, which is spreading more and more each day." The French leader made plain his opposition to United States bombings of North Vietnam in a radio and television speech that stressed French independence of the United States but affirmed friendship with it.

BECAUSE of the dangers a new Philadelphia gun ordinance presents to out-of-state hunters and target shooters visiting Pennsylvania, a release just put out by the Pennsylvania Game Commission is reprinted here in full:

Stockholders of the Ritter Company, Inc., of Rochester, N.Y., and the M.F. Patterson Dental Supply Company, Minneapolis, approved plans at meetings yesterday for a merger. They voted approval despite a request by the Justice Department last Friday to postpone the consolidation until the agency had further time to study the merger on anti-trust grounds.
PARIS, April 27 -- A project for screening "Years of Lightning, Days of Drums" during the Cannes Film Festival has been threatened by a difference of opinion over possible diplomatic repercussions.
PARIS, April 27 -- Barry Goldwater, the Republican candidate for the Presidency last year, said today that "my President has done the right thing in the right way" in Vietnam.

LISBON, April 27 -- A Spanish magistrate and police officials have gone to Villanueva de Fresno, two miles from the Portuguese frontier, to identify three bodies, one of which was reported last night to be that of Lieut. Gen. Humberto Delgado, Portuguese opposition candidate for the Presidency in 1958.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The Senate Commerce Committee voted favorably today on legislation to require the printing of a health warning on cigarette packages but it balked at extending the warning to cigarette advertising.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell predicted yesterday that in the coming mayoral election "Mayor Wagner is a sure winner and the city is a sure loser."

The New York Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital will benefit from the Polyclinic International Fiesta, a dinner dance to be held next Wednesday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, and from a champagne reception on Thursday that will open an exhibition of the Jacques Kaplan art collection at the Greenross Gallery, 51 East 57th Steret.
PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- The Gulf Oil Corporation reported today that earnings for the first three months of 1965 reached $107 million, the highest for any quarter in history.
CHICAGO, April 27 -- William M. Cooley, newly elected president of the Guild of Religious Architects, said today the era of the "tunnel" Gothic church was over.

The president of the United Federation of Teachers charged yesterday that the Board of Education was using the proposed transfer of experienced teachers to slum schools as a "smokescreen" to obscure its failure to provide proper teaching conditions.

The Corn Products Company, a widely diversified company, best known for its food processing, will spend $60 million on capital expenditures this year, according to Alexander N. McFarlane, chairman. Although this year's expenditures are expected to be $16 million below those for 1964, they will be $12 million more than in 1963, Mr. McFarlane said.
The East Side penthouse apartment of a French Countess was looted of $100,000 in jewels, furs and cash early Monday, the police said yesterday.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 27 -President Jomo Kenyatta presented to Parliament today his long-awaited definition of what "African Socialism" is intended to mean in Kenya.

United States support for a strong, independent India as the only ultimate alternative to Chinese hegemony in all of Asia was urged last night by Harrison E. Salisbury, assistant managing editor of The New York Times.

DETROIT, April 27, (AP) -Jim Fregosi's two-out single in the eighth inning, his third hit of the game, scored Jimmy Piersall with the decisive run as the Los Angeles Angels defeated the Detroit Tigers tonight, 4-3.
Copper futures prices declined again yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Commodity Exchange.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- A careful study of an Administration proposal to broaden the authority of the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Small Business Administration has been urged by Senator William Proxmire.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Robert Paul Gerholz is a booster, a joiner, an optimist, a hail-fellow, a self-made man, an immigrant's son, a believer in the "free opportunity system" and the self-reliant community that does not lean on the Federal Government.
Forty battle-scarred detective squad commanders sat in a classroom the other day and learned about Mapp v. Ohio, Escobedo v. Illinois and People v. Malinsky.

Shareholders of Thompson Ramo Wooldridge, Inc., voted a change in the company's name to TRW, Inc., effective at the close of business on Friday, April 30, at their annual meeting yesterday in Cleveland.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 27 -Cornell University celebrated its 100th anniversary today in Charter Week observances looking, characteristically for the pioneering school, more toward the future than at the past.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- The Hilton Hotels Corporation's revenues and net earnings increased in the first quarter of 1965 and are expected to show an increase for the full year, Robert P. Williford, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -A leading physicist said here today that there were only three basic particles of matter and that physicists as a whole had come to believe this, even though they did not say as much.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, April 27 (Reuters) -- Senator Jan de Klerk, the Interior Minister, disclosed tonight that Hitler's former bodyguard had been allowed to enter the country, but that an American official of the Roman Catholic Church had been refused permission.
BONN, April 27 -- The Communist world is developing an elaborate propaganda campaign to turn the 20th anniversary of victory in Europe into "Hate West Germany Day."
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches, with more than 700 competiters, got under way over 23 courses yesterday.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has upheld the Delta Steamship Lines's unfair labor practices complaint against the National Maritime Union, involving picketing in June, 1963. The line seeks $507,000 in damages.
YONKERS, N.Y., April 27 -An average income of 16 per cent in water rates for Yonkers consumers was recommended in a report received tonight by the Yonkers Common Council.
CHICAGO, April 27 (UPI) -John Buzhardt maintained his mastery over the Boston Red Sox tonight by pitching the Chicago White Sox to a 10-1 victory.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Senate passed today an omnibus $2,257,869,415 appropriations bill carrying $352,300,000 to finance the start of the $1.092 billion Appalachian Regional Development Program.

WHEN Dame Edith Sitwell died in London last December she was 77 years old. A writer of genuine and fiercely individual talent, she had produced more than 40 volumes of poetry, criticism, essays and biography. She was a literary lady who sedulously cultivated her own eccentricities for most of her life.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday a sharp rise in sales and earnings for the first quarter of this year over the period a year earlier. It also declared a dividend of 50 cents a share, thus continuing the level it introduced in the third quarter of 1962.

HARRISON, N.Y., April 27 -- The Westchester Professional Golfers' Association opened its season today with a pro-pro tournament on the 6,490-yard par-72 West Course at Westchester Country Club. The make-up of each foursome was decided by blind draw.
YONKERS, April 27 -- Bret Hanover, the only standard-bred to have achieved "harness horse of the year" recognition as a 2-year-old, is en route to Yonkers Raceway.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27 -- Dr. Tingfu F. Tsiang, Nationalist China's Ambassador to the United States since 1962, has resigned his diplomatic post to return to Taipei, a delegation source said here today.

Indian reporters (and I am one of them) whose task it is to interpret the changing moods' and problems of this country have found it difficult to explain to our readers at home how so practiced a President could be so brusque in his treatment of an elected Prime Minister of the world's largest democracy.

Trade, politics and cultures have always been influenced by the routes of communication. The effect of the satellite era on relaying information is that no one can foretell now what new routes may come into use or how they will be employed.
Despite a 23-day strike that shut down 80 per cent of its metals plants, the Continental Can Company chalked up record earnings in the first quarter of 1965.

The County Calicos Collection at Altman's is as American as a square dance in a big red barn. The clothes offer a lively alternative to the imported Mod and Ye Ye looks that are swinging around young fashion circles.

THE average bridge player spends a good deal of time bemoaning bad breaks in post-mortem, but there are occasions when he should be bemoaning a good break. Some situations occur in play in which a player must pray for a bad division of a key suit in order to have a chance of making his contract.

New York's two major public music libraries have postponed their move to Lincoln Center, scheduled for next month, because of a lack of funds. Both the 42d Street Reference Library and the 58th Street Circulating Library will remain closed until further notice.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- An Alabama Representative today read to the House details of alleged sex orgies and drunkenness during civil rights demonstrations in his state last month.
Shipping circles were intrigued here yesterday by authoritative repores that two divers, not one, descended recently to the site of the wreck of the Norwegian tanker Stolt Dagali.

In all the many years in which New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have fumbled their way toward a remedy for the railroad commuter problem, never has a governmental solution been so specifically endorsed by a group of business leaders as it was this week by the newly organized Businessmen's Committee for Action on the Commuter Railroad Problem.
Twelve paintings, described as belonging to the "school of magic realism," disappeared over the weekend from the Banfer Gallery at 23 East 67th Street.
In your April 13 editorial "The Two Irelands" you say that Prime Minister Lemas "is a man of the new age looking toward a future which often-unhappy Ireland can now contemplate with hope."

A Broadway play, "And Things That Go Bump in the Night," which opened Monday at the Royale Theater, will sell all its seats for $1 each, starting tonight, for the remaining performances. It will close on Saturday after eight showings.

HOUSTON, April 27 -- After putting Yogi Berra on the active list during the afternoon the New York Mets made their indoor debut at the Astrodome tonight and suffered their most stunning defeat of the year just when they had come within on pitch of new glory.
World shipbuilding is at a recod level, with 1,664 merchant ships aggregating 10.9 million gross tons under construction, Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Edward R. Murrow lived long enough before he died this week to achieve the two great objectives of a reporter: He endured, survived and reported the great story of his generation, and in the process he won the respect, admiration and affection of his profession.
The National Library Week organization reported yesterday that the week this year is being observed more widely than ever before in its eight-year history. The week ends Saturday.
The last of this season's four "Evenings for New Music" was given at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. It was a fairly easygoing event for this avant-garde series.
The case of George Whitmore Jr., charged with the knife-slaying of Mrs. Minnie Edmond a 46-year-old charwoman, will go to the all-male jury tomorrow in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

For most of yesterday afternoon, leaden skies poured rain on Aqueduct's track, already soggy since the weekend, and there was little to warm the hearts of the 24,490 fans on hand in the program of eight claiming races and one allowance test.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Some communities have gained in jobs and public revenues after the Defense Department closed bases that had bolstered their economies, Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara told Congress today.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Supreme Court took these actions today:

The City Council moved last night to aid Mayor Wagner both in budget-making and in his fight against crime. In a session that ended at 7:15 P.M., the Council, by a vote of 32 to 3, asked the Legislature to give Mayor Wagner until May 13 to submit his 1965-66 budget to the Board of Estimate and the Council.
Burlington Industries, Inc., the largest domestic producer of textile products, reported yesterday sharp gains in sales and earnings for the three-and six months periods ended April 3.

The problems of designing a supersonic aircraft safe enough for commercial transport are proving less difficult than expected, the chief medical officer of the British Ministry of Aviation said here yesterday.

Many of the longshoremen who had gathered along the Brooklyn waterfront yesterday were stocky Kazan types puffing cigars -- and, just before the 8 A.M. "shape," the labor leaders were anticipating trouble.
The Norfolk Western Railway reported yesterday a profit of $19,715,000, or $2.10 a share, for the first quarter of this year, up from $18.27 million, or $1.94 a share, in the 1964 period.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 (AP) -- Dennis Ralston, the No. 1 United States tennis player, will not be considered for Davis Cup play against Canada in June because of a temperamental outburst at a Houston tournament last week, George MacCall, the team captain, said today.
WASHINGTON, April 27--President Johnson said today that the Federal budget deficit this fiscal year would be at least $1 billion below the January estimate.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -The 15-year-old National Science Foundation is about to undergo its first full-scale Congressional investigation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27 -- India today voiced the resentment of the poorer nations that a privileged "few" powers alone might get the option of not paying for United Nations peace-keeping costs of which they disapproved.

LONDON, April 27 -- The Government gave details today on what is probably the major British tax measure of the century. A bulky, anxiously awaited Finance Bill, giving effect to proposals in the April 6 budget, shows no signs that the Government despite its miniscule majority in the House of Commons is retreating on any tax front.
The Southern Pacific Company sold $8.1 million of 4 1/4 per cent equipment trust certificates yesterday to a syndicate managed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
Charles A. Buckley's Bronx Democratic Committee and the Bronx Liberal party organization are holding their annual dinners on the same night, May 6.
PARIS -- The most babyish feet in the world can now be seen toddling around on the bumpy pavements of Paris.

The Commerce and Industry Association declared yesterday that state, local and Federal governments must help pay to continue rail commuter service here, but it favored "an operating railroad as agent" to run the lines.
ALBANY, April 27 -- East Harlem will lose one of its three Assembly seats in the reapportionment proposals of the Democratic leadership are put into effect.
BOSTON, April 27 (UPI) -- K.C. Jones and Tom Heinsohn, members of the world champion Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association, announced tonight that they would retire after next season.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday gains in total operating revenues, net income and volume sales of electricity, gas and steam for the three and 12 months ended March 31.

About $17,000 worth of pure nickel was stolen from electroplating plants in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx over the weekend, raising to $40,000 the total worth of the metal stolen in the metropolitan area in recent months.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -President Johnson defended the nation's antipoverty program today against what he called unfair and unjust criticism.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Supreme Court struck down today a Texas procedure that allows a woman and her new husband to adopt her child by a previous marriage without giving notice to the child's father.
HONG KONG, April 27 -Communist China accused the Soviet Union today of collaborating with the United States to defeat the insurgents in South Vietnam.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 -- Giving every evidence of the speed and power that made him the champion of his class last year, the Wheatley Stable's Bold Lad sped to a most decisive victory in the Derby Trial today.
The United States District Court here yesterday denied the Federal Maritime Commission an injunction that would restrain nine steamship conferences from applying surcharges on freight rates.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The new president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States appealed today for more local community action, rather than Federal Government programs, to solve problems of poverty, unemployment education and urban blight.
The seasonal flood of annual stockholder meetings reached a crest yesterday when scores of major corporations held sessions.

WHITE PLAINS, April 27 -- Westchester County's 152 water districts pledged cooperation with New York City's water conservation program today even if it means leaving golf course fairways parched and backyard swimming pools empty.

TUNIS, April 27 -- Thousand of Tunisians marched through the streets today to demonstrate against the eastern Arab countries that have come out against President Habib Bourguiba's plan for the settlement of the Israeli-Arab dispute.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Administration sent three top officials to Capitol Hill today to support legislation to lower the tariff between Canadian and United States auto industries.

Julio Cesar del Castillo, who has resigned as Cuba's Consul General in London and defected to the United States, arrived here yesterday and expressed astonishment at the public interest in his decision not to return to Havana.
The Rockefeller Foundation distributed more than $40 million last year in worldwide programs against hunger, over-population, racial inequality and for education, arts and humanities.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27 (AP) -- The top United States military and Embassy spokesmen in South Vietnam denied today that a new press policy that could lead to the expulsion of correspondents from Vietnam had been instituted.

Lipstick, a huge wardrobe and a sound swing are necessities on the women's pro golf tour. Margaret Masters, the first Australian to join the group, named these yesterday as the requirements for success.

LINDEN, N.J., April 27 -Mayor Alexander G. Wrigley today called for an "all-out municipal fight" against a Tri-state Transportation Committee recommendation that Linden Airport be expanded to handle traffic diverted from Newark Airport.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Frederic G. Donner said today that he did not regard the Soviet Union's new communications satellite as competition for this nation's ambitious effort.
Relative to Brian J. Kilbey's letter in The Times of April 20 headed "Visitors' Tax Protested":
WASHINGTON, April 27 -President Johnson renewed today his offer to talk with any government, without any conditions, about ways of ending the war in Vietnam.

When Riverdale decided to have its own "Man of the Year," there were a number of national and international celebrities who might have been chosen from among the residents of the quiet community where the Hudson River flows past the Bronx.
Declines outnumbered advances by a narrow margin on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as volume continued heavy.
LONDON, April 27 -- Edward R. Murrow's death was mourned tonight in the country whose story he told in her darkest hour.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 27 (Reuters) -- The Cambodian press agency published today the text of a joint proclamation by Parliament and the Government about the disgraceful article published by the American magazine Newsweek on April 5, 1965."
ALBANY, April 27 -- The Assembly gave final approval today to three bills that would increase by a maximum of $10 a week the state benefits payable to workers who are unemployed, sick or injured.
Floyd D. Hall, president of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., had some good news to share with his stockholders yesterday. He addressed 500 of them at the company's annual meeting at the Americana Hotel.
PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- Negotiators agreed today to resume bargaining on May 18 for a long-range agreement covering the basic steel industry.

Richard L. Schneider has been elected predident of Weber Heilbroner and Broadstreet's, New York, men's wear chains operated by the retail division of Botany Industries Inc., Michael Daroff, chairman and president of Botany, announced yesterday.
The New York Convention and Visitors Bureau said yesterday that the city had done more convention business last year than ever before.
Most of the ranking tennis professionals of the world will be seen in the indoor championships starting tonight at the 71st Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 34th Street.
NEW DELHI, April 27 -- Indian forces knocked out six Pakistani tanks in battle yesterday in the disputed Rann of Cutch, official Indian spokesmen said tonight.

Prof. Robert L. Calhoun, a theology historian who helped the Protestant churches rediscover their unity of ancestry with the Orthodox and Roman Catholic communions, will be honored tonight at the 55th annual convocation of the Yale Divinity School at New Haven.

President Johnson could not have been more emphatic yesterday in reaffirming his proposal of "unconditional discussions" to seek a peaceful settlement in Vietnam. He defined his proposal, which he said will remain open, as an offer to discuss "any subject and any point of view with any Government concerned . . . anywhere, any time, without any conditions."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 27 -- A blast of dynamite today opened a 9.9-mile tunnel that will make possible an increase of Lebanon's electric power by one-third and eventually make available for the first time a regulated flow of water on the Western slopes of the Lebanon mountains.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 27 -- The military-civilian revolt aimed at restoring former President Juan Bosch to power in the Dominican Republic collapsed tonight at the end of a day of savage fighting in which hundreds may have been killed.
The common stock of W.R. Grace Co., which has traded on the New York Stock Exchange for the last dozen years, is branching abroad to the Netherlands.
Leonard Bernstein, in a wistful and philosophic mood, emerged briefly from his sabbatical yesterday to announce the music he will conduct on next season's New York Philharmonic programs.
Net new orders for machine tools -- the machines that make machinery for the nation's production lines -- are continuing to climb.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., won a reprieve yesterday, until Jan. 17, for the trading of its stock on the New York Stock Exchange. This was revealed with the release of the text of a letter from the exchange to Victor Muscat, president and chairman of the beleaguered transit company.

The decision of the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America to extend their contracts for four months ends a ludicrous situation that might have done great damage to the national economy. There never was any justification for a strike threat at this time, and none would have arisen if both sides had not shown such ineptitude in handling truce talks.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27 -- The Government announced today that the United States Navy would begin patrolling South Vietnam's coastal waters within the three-mile limit.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -Eight major appointments, including a change in the heads of the Government's aviation agencies, were announced by President Johnson today.
CINCINNATI, April 27 (AP) -- Frank Robinson and Tommy Harper rapped four hits each tonight in leading the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-3 triumph over the Chicago Cubs.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -The National Academy of Sciences elected 35 new members and six foreign associates today in recognition of "distinguished and continuing achievements in original research."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -A unanimous Supreme Court held today that a Virginia law requiring voters in Federal elections to file a residence certificate is a substitute for a poll tax and therefore unconstitutional.

MILWAUKEE, April 27 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves unloaded a 13-hit attack, including homers by Eddie Mathews and Denny Menke, to trounce the St. Louis Cardinals, 9-5, tonight. A crowd of 1,677, the smallest in County Stadium history, saw the game in 40-degree weather.

HAVANA, April 27 -- The young woman came home from the university later than usual and explained, "We had a long talk with The Horse." Her father, somewhat distrustful, said, "Again? What was it all about this time?"
The McCall Corporation held its annual stockholders meeting yesterday, and it was short, sweet and optimistic.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -United States officials received with relief tonight the news that the violence and bloodshed in the Dominican Republic appeared near an end with the collapse of the military revolt.

CLEVELAND, April 27 (UPI) -- Camilo Pascual hit the second grand slam homer of his major league career and pitched a two-hitter tonight to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 11-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

ROCHESTER, April 27 -- Former Republican State Chairman L. Judson Morhouse invoked the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution about 30 times today to avoid answering questions at a Federal hearing into alleged bribery at the Finger Lakes Race Track.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today that the Federal Government adopt the British system of legalizing narcotics for addicts, on a limited experimental basis.

The general contract for the construction of a $95 million office and apartment building in Chicago, to be known as the John Hancock Center, has been awarded to the Tishman Realty and Construction Company.

Several stockholders at the Crane Company's annual meeting yesterday urged management to consider raising its cash dividend above the $2 now paid, or to declare a stock dividend. Last year the company earned $4.54 a share, compared with $4.30 a share in 1963.

ROCQUENCOURT, France -- Behind all major troubles in the NATO alliance lies the atomic argument between the United States and France. Although this became relatively quiescent last winter when President Johnson decided to refrigerate our project for a mixed-manned nuclear force (M.L.F.), there has been no progress toward solution.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The Supreme Court held today that a businessman may sell his company to a tax-exempt organization, continue to operate it and pay capital-gains tax rates on the profits up to the amount of the sales price.
Deputy Mayor Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday that an investigation of charges of "snake-pit" conditions at the Women's House of Detention "were without substance."
NEW HAVEN, April 27 -- Spring arrives in college and university communities in many ways.
MOSCOW, April 27 -- Musical auditions now being held here behind closed doors may decide the fate of jazz in the Soviet Union.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 27 -- The Nassau County Chapter of the Red Cross will give a spring benefit luncheon and fashion show on Monday in the Georgian Room of the Garden City Hotel.
THE New England Region of the Sports Car Club of America will open its racing season Saturday afternoon on the Lime Rock (Conn.) course.

Seven prominent playwrights were unable to touch common ground yesterday on the question of what role the dramatist should play in the American theater. Their views on his rightful function ranged from the belief that he should reflect the times to the contention that he should stimulate patron interest.

Findlay Cockrell, the 29-year-old New York pianist who as a contestant in the recent Chopin international competition in Warsaw charged the jury in a letter with favoring Russian and Polish entrants, played his debut recital last night at Town Hall in a Chopin program.
MONTREAL, April 27 -- With 14,762 fans at the Forum playing it Chicago-style, elegant Jean Beliveau scored twice and led the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-0 rout of the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.
NEW HAVEN, April 27 -- A lawyer and former Government aide was elected president and chief executive officer today of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.
An Anglican bishop and 12 Episcopal priests celebrated holy communion together yesterday at temporary altar set up in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Postmaster General John A. Gronouski opposed today pending legislation to give third-class mailers a postage discount and reduce the cost for bulk third-class mailers who voluntarily use the ZIP Code.

Eleven major American insurance companies, in an unusual financial transaction, signed an agreement yesterday for a loan of $50 million to the Jewish Agency for Israel, Inc. -the principal beneficiary of the United Jewish. Appeal campaigns.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 27 -- Rebellious philosophers who have been criticizing Yugoslav Communist practices for six months are facing retribution at the fifth Croatian Party Congress in Zagreb. The meeting opened yesterday.
The generally favorable reception given to yesterdays heavy slate of new offerings in the tax-exempt bond market gave municipal dealers their first encouraging sign in several weeks.

ANAHEIM, Calif., April 27 -Having achieved formidable success in its 10 years as a daytime amusement park, Disneyland has decided to spend $1 million this year to build up it reputation as a nighttime entertainment center.

SELMA, Ala., April 27 (UPI) -- An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified in Federal Court today that he saw deputies of Sheriff James G. Clark Jr. use cattle prods while putting several hundred young Negroes through a forced march.
Most Government bond prices did not change yesterday as Wall Street awaited the terms of the Treasury's plans to refund $8.4 billion of securities maturing in May.
The State Department is being asked for an opinion on whether five Zulu dancers from South Africa should be granted political asylum in the United States, an immigration official disclosed yesterday.
MASERU, Basutoland -- A cold and cutting wind blows in Basutoland, sweeping down from the towering mountains that cover three-quarters of the country.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) -- The Washington police said today that a local confidence man appeared to have flimflammed another Southern Mayor.
DRIED FIGS were known to the pyramid builders of Ancient Egypt. They were one of the first fruits known to have been dried and stored for food.
LOS ANGELES, April 27 (AP) -- Dick Tracewski drove in three runs for the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight as they handed the Pittsburgh Pirates their sixth straight defeat, 5-4.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 27 (UPI) -- The "hot line" that connects the White House with the Kremlin was out for 16 minutes yesterday when the line was accidentally cut by a Danish bulldozer, it was reported here today.
ALBANY, April 27 -- An attempt by legislators to reach a compromise agreement on Blue Cross legislation failed today, but the issue was kept open for further talks.

Howard L. Clark, president of the American Express Company, said yesterday that the concern hoped to write off against taxes as much as $27 million of the $60 million it may make available to creditors of American Express Warehousing Company, Ltd.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, April 27 -- The idea of converting Latin America into one great protected market was the keynote today of the sixth annual meeting of the governors of the Inter-American Development Bank.

CAIRO, April 27 -- The United Arab Republic announced tonight that it had withdrawn its Ambassador from Tunisia in the wake of a reported attack on its embassy by Tunisian crowds. The Government also denounced any attempt by President Hahib Bourguiba of Tunisia to be an intermediary between the Arabs and Israel.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 27 (AP) -A promising vertical take-off plane ran into unknown trouble on its first public flight today, nose-dived into the desert and exploded in a ball of flame.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 27 (UPI) -- A drive to raise as much as $1 million to be used by scholars as an 81st birthday present to former President Harry S. Truman was announced today.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Negotiations between the State Conservation Department and the Schine hotel chain over renewal of the contract for operation of the Gideon Putnam Hotel at Saratoga Springs have ended and the state has decided to choose a new operator.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -President Johnson today defended his postponement of official visits by the leaders of India and Pakistan as a wise decision and "one that I would make again."

MEXICO CITY, April 27 -The Pan American Sulphur Company, whose export operations have been held up here since last Wednesday, will resume operations immediately and be allowed to export up to 1.5 million tons of sulphur this year.
THE HAGUE, April 27 -- The new Dutch Cabinet will continue the foreign policy of its predecessors aimed at strengthening the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and European unity.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -The House Banking Committee, by a vote of 19 to 8, tabled legislation today that would have permitted banks to underwrite state and local government revenue bonds.
MOSCOW, April 27 -- Two Soviet war veterans said today they would be in favor of a reunion with United States veterans in East Germany to mark their meeting on the Elbe River 20 years ago.

BALTIMORE, April 27 (UPI) -- Frank Howard drove in the first four Washington runs with a homer and single tonight and the Senators went on to score a 5-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles behind the relief pitching of Steve Ridzik.

In an evident breakthrough toward establishing itself as retailing's new wave, the discount department-store industry released yesterday its first annual study of merchandising operations, plugging a statistical gap that has long detracted from discounters' respectability.
State mediators stepped into the labor dispute at E.J. Korvette stores yesterday but the strike of 3,000 clerks and other employes at 13 stores in the city area continued for the second day.
The British pound eased a little in moderate trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
Increased Federal grants to help New York and other cities solve their problems were urged yesterday by Earl B. Schwulst, the chairman of the Temporary Commission on City Finances.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., April 27 (UPI) -- Work battalions doggedly built a new dike today to hold the flooding Mississippi River out of downtown Rock Island. They pumped water out of the river into the streets of its sister city, Moline, to relieve pressure on the levees.
WARSAW, April 27 -- A North Vietnamese cigarette factory, a Polish reporter wrote today, will soon employ only women because all the men are being called back into service.
A late selling wave swept away most of the stock market's early gains yesterday, but leading indicators still managed to finish at records.

Stockholders of the Pub United Corporation, a holding company, voted at their annual meeting yesterday in the Sheraton East Hotel to change the name of the company to the Rheingold Corporation, it was announced by Bernard Relin, chairman of the board, and Sheldon S. Wilson, president.

SPONGE (the Society for the Prevention of Negroes' Getting Everything) has no office or headquarters, no constitution or charter, no officers or recognized leaders, no regular meetings, no staff and no agreement on what constitutes membership.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27 -- United Nations representatives on space matters would like to have another meeting, but they cannot decide where.

TRENTON, April 27 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today that he would accept the word of State Senator Nelson F. Stamler, Republican of Union County, that the Legislature's investigation of the state's antipoverty program "would be fair and would not impede" it.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President Johnson indicated today that he would have liked a flat ban on poll taxes in the voting rights bill but had deferred to the Justice Department's view that this might raise a constitutional problem.

Three motion picture film classics, including the 1924 production, "Greed," directed by Erich von Stroheim, will be televised here by educational station WNDT (Channel 13). The other pictures are "Mother," made in the Soviet Union in 1926, and "La Maternelle," a French film released in 1932.

The international Communist bank appears to be facing a major crisis in the wake of a Polish public statement yesterday charging that the bank had failed to create genuine multilateral trade among its member and calling for the creation of a convertible ruble based on gold.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27 -- The United Nations Trade and Development Board moved unanimously today toward resumption of the abortive 1963 United Nations conference on cocoa, in recognition of the "tragic situation" caused by depressed world market prices of the commodity.

James Reston [April 21] correctly describes some recent teach-ins as "anti-Administration demonstrations disguised as 'teaching.'" Reston also points out that other teach-ins have been effective educational experiences in which a diversity of positions has been represented.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A former Georgia Governor pictured Food and Drug Administration agents today as "master spies" who used "un-American, police-state, Gestapo-like tactics."

William Chadbourne Mitchell, the 28-year-old singer who founded the Chad Mitchell Trio six years ago and helped to make it one of the country's most successful folk-singing groups, is leaving the trio to make his acting debut on Broadway.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 -- Bold Lad went into the lead in the Kentucky Derby calculations today for the first time in several weeks. The Wheatley Stable's colt had been bracketed with Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Lucky Debonair as the favorites in Saturday's 1 1/4-mile race, but now, on the basis of his smashing 1:35 1-5 mile in yesterday's Derby Trial, Bold Lad stands alone.
NEWARK, April 28 -- The city today embarked on an information program to urge voluntary water conservation in view of an impending water shortage.

The National Institute and the American Academy of Arts and Letters announced yesterday awards totaling $57,000. They went to23 writers, graphic artists, painters, sculptors and composers, and one architect.
Details of new tax proposals had an unsettling effect on the London stock market yesterday, but the list closed with a small gain on late buying.

IT is almost 15 years since "Guys and Dolls" breezed into town, and except for a slight change of locale induced by the international scene it remains what it was at the outset: a happy, exuberant example of the American musical theater at the top of its form.

DEMOPOLIS, Ala., April 28 -- This morning at 8 o'clock, like every other morning in the last two weeks, Negro teenagers with bright bath towels around their necks began to appear on the dusty roads leading to the Morning Star Baptist Church.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- Former President Eisenhower and Oeng I eral of the Army Omar Bradley! were reported today to have declined Soviet invitations toi attend celebrations here of the] 20th anniversary of the end ofi World War II.
CHICAGO, April 28 (UPI) -- The Inland Steel Company reported today first-quarter earnings of $19,293,607, or $1.06 a share, on revenues of $2,253,402,527.
HOUSTON, April 28 -- The Houston Astros, wiping out three-run deficits in the fourth and sixth innings, scored their seventh straight victory tonight by beating the New York Mets, 12-9.

LA COTE BASQUE, a restaurant that was briefly one of the most celebrated in Manhattan and one of the most elegantly styled dining establishments in the world, will reopen May 18, according to Henri Soule, the owner who is also proprietor of Le Pavillon.

DR. ARIEL MENGARINI, a New York master, captured the first prize in the recent North Jersey Open in Plainfield, sweeping the boards 5-0 in a five-round Swiss system in which 86 players participated. Walter Browne and Michael Valvo, both of New York, tied for second and third with 4 1/2-1/2 each.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 28 -- Jack Nicklaus, to the surprise of no one, is the favorite in the Tournament of Champions beginning here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Supreme Court held today that state judges and prosecutors violate the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution if they comment on a defendant's failure to testify in his own defense.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The United States has agreed to supply a small amount of additional arms to help modernize Jordan's army, diplomatic sources reported today.

President Sukarno of Indonesia is on a rampage -- which is a normal state of affairs for him. He has now completed the seizure of all foreign properties in Indonesia. His militant nationalism is still being exercised against Malaysia, the number one target, and also against the United States, Great Britain and every Western country linked to the former era of colonialism and "imperialism."
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- A Jewish leader said tonight that Zionist programs could help lead to a "segmented, fragmented America."
A city report on the Women's House of Detention was denounced yesterday as a "whitewash" by Heman T. Stichman, former State Commissioner for Special Investigation.
Copper futures prices turned mixed yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Commodity Exchange.
A Brooklyn scrap-metal dealer was arrested yesterday as the receiver of at least two tons of the nickel that has been stolen from electroplating plants here in recent months.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 28 -- Rebel elements supporting former President Juan Bosch held control of the northern and central parts of Santo Domingo today, according to telephone reports from the capital of the Dominican Republic.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 28 (AP) -- Bill Campbell, the National Amateur champion, and four former Walker Cup players, Bill Hyndman, Ward Wettlaufer, Bob Gardner and Dr. Ed Updegraff, were the victims today in two upset-filled rounds of the North and South golf tournament.
LISBON, April 28 -- A Portuguese opposition group today hailed Lieut. Gen. Humberto Delgado for his "patriotism, idealism and self-sacrifice."

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Some of the most memorable verses ever written are attributed in the anthologies to "Anon." And no one knows what and how many disciples put in written form the oral discourses of the Prophet Isaiah, to whose book President Johnson turns most frequently for appeals to the higher nature of mankind.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay was recommended for a 60 per cent disability rating when he retired as Air Force Chief of Staff Feb. 1, it became known today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 28 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has ordered a new rein put on persistently speeding cars of arrest-immune foreign diplomats -- a police escort to the nearest exit.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- President Johnson received what he called an "interesting and encouraging" report today on voluntary efforts by American business to help reduce the balance-of-payments deficit.
LONDON, April 28 -- The Labor Government threw down today its first serious challenge to a powerful labor union since taking office last fall.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Supreme Court said today that it was all right for the National Mediation Board to provide no place on its ballots for employes to vote against union representation.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 28 -- Dr. Clifford L. Lord, who was inaugurated today as Hofstra University's third president, declared that student revolts for the right reason should be welcomed.

JERSEY CITY, April 28 -- About 750 students at St. Peter's College and a sprinkling of faculty members demonstrated peacefully today, with a rally and a parade, in support of United States policy in Vietnam.
Four unions representing 65,000 merchant seamen and officers asked shipping companies yesterday to begin negotiations on bonus payments for service in the Vietnam area.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Malcolm Muggeridge, the English writer, reports that "America is drenched, if not submerged, in sex." Writing in The New Statesman, he describes a country that makes Sodom and Gomorrah sound by comparison like Philadelphia on a Sunday afternoon.
Sales of a group of leading chain stores and mail order houses increased by 2.6 per cent in March from the level of the 1964 month. The late Easter this year tended to hold down the gain.

Never in American history has a Secretary of State made such a sharp attack on a large segment of the academic community as did Dean Rusk in his comments of April 23. It is no wonder that United States policy toward South Vietnam has been so devoid of alternatives and clear thinking, given the proclivity of vitriol displayed therein.
LONDON, April 28 -- Baristers learned happily today that their wigs need no longer cover their ears when they argue cases in the House of Lords.
The keel of the last of the nation's 41 ballistic missile submarines was laid recently in Groton, Conn. The name Will Rogers has been chosen for it.
