Because of protests from passengers, the Transit Authority has postponed for at least a week its plan to close two of the four entrances at an IND subway station in Brooklyn late at night.
ROCK ISLAND, Ill., April 28 (AP) -- The crest of the most disastrous Mississippi River flood in history pounded today at weakened levees protecting the Quad Cities of Illinois and Iowa.

While the Ronson Corporation is proud of the fact that its name is virtually synonomous with a cigarette lighter, it would also like to emphasize the fact that the company has diversified a little in its 70-year history.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) Charles A. Lindbergh is striving mightily to save elephants, white-winged doves, grizzly bears, prarie chickens and other wildlife from extinction.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 -- The consumption of wine by Americans has finally reached a gallon a year per person, a goal long sought by vintners.
Ten years ago on May 4 the Brooklyn Philharmonia was born, with a concert in the Brooklyn Academy of Music under the direction of its founder, Siegfried Landau.
ALBANY, April 28 -- The Senate unanimously adopted today a resolution that would increase the term of office of Assemblymen and Senators from two years to four.
NEW YORK got back on a burlesque wheel last night, with all the familiar orbital motions, when "The Wonderful World of Burlesque" opened at the Mayfair Theater.
Three major United States newspaper groups -- Knight, Scripps-Howard and Copley -- have won the 1965 Inter-American Press Association award for promoting Inter-American friendship and understanding.
Following is the text of President Johnson's remarks last night on the Dominican situation, as recorded by The New York Times:

A model of the new $125 million Madison Square Garden Center was put on display yesterday and one of the first viewers. Mayor Wagner, declared that the center had possibilities for attracting Presidential nominating conventions to the city.

William B. Rand, president of the New York Shipping Association, said yesterday that its new four-year contract with the International Longshoremen's Association was a "revolutionary document in waterfront labor agreements."

OTTAWA, April 28 (UPI) -- Canadian Football League players will meet in Toronto within the next two weeks to complete the organization of a players union, Bernie Faloney, the all star quarterback who is waging a contract fight with the Montreal Alouettes, said last night.

Sales of knitted apparel and fabrics are approaching $2 billion a year, Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director of the National Knitted Outerwear Association reported yesterday. The industry has more than contributed its share to the growth of the economy, Mr. Korzenik told the association board at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The school improvement and integration program, made public yesterday by Acting Superintendent Bernard E. Donovan, calls for determined, massive action rather than a host of new pilot projects. In implementing last week's policy statement by the Board of Education, the plan outlines the year-by-year steps which must be taken between now and 1972 to bring about the proposed drastic reforms, while maintaining stability of operation.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The B-70 flew at more than 1,600 miles an hour today, continuing to pioneer the way for supersonic airliners.
SAIGON, Thursday, April 29 (AP) -- Bitter fighting in the Mekong Delta yesterday left two United States Army advisers dead and a third wounded, a United States military spokesman reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- Robin Roberts pitched the Baltimore Orioles to a 6-3 victory over the Washington Senators tonight for the 273d triumph of his career. That tied him with Red Ruffing of the Yankees for 16th place on the list of major league pitchers.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- The House unanimously passed today a $380 million antipollution bill. The measure would include increased Federal authority to reduce dirty water and a "carrot and stick" inducement for states to set water quality standards. The vote was 396 to 0.
Pan American Sulphur dominated Wall Street's attention yesterday as the market drifted down a bit on a slide in trading activity.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, April 28 -- David E. Bell, United States aid administrator, assured Latin Americans today that balance-of-payments problems will not stem the flow of private investment to this area
SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 28 -- The Bulgarian people today received their first official word that a plot against the Government and the ruling Communist party was thwarted this month.
Municipal bond dealers found several new significant reasons yesterday to be more optimistic about their market than they had been in the last several weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- A Federal judge ruled today that Maj. Arch E. Roberts should be reinstated to active duty in the Army so he could retire voluntarily with the full benefits of a 20-year man.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Supreme Court took these actions today:
A group of 50 American evacuees from the Dominican Republic arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night with tales of shooting and terror.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States looked hopefully today toward a friendly relationship with "the people" of mainland China.

A jury was told by a prosecutor in Brooklyn yesterday that George Whitmore Jr. could be brought to trial by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan in Manhattan for the 1963 murders of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert on the basis of his confession in that case.

YONKERS, April 28 -- Half the field of 3-year-olds in tonight's $5,000 mile pace at Yonkers Raceway boasted spotless records for this, their sophomore season. Obviously, and barring a four-way dead-heat, only one could remain unbeaten this campaign.

DETROIT, April, 28 (UPI) -- Jerry Lumpe atoned for an error that cost three runs by hitting a two-run triple to tie the score and then scored the winning run tonight as the Detroit Tigers topped the Los Angeles Angels, 5-4.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to prevent District Attorney Frank S. Hogan from examining his financial account in the House of Representatives. The case will be argued May 10.
ROME, April 28 -- Italy's leaders expressed interest today in the British plan for an Atlantic nuclear force and said that they would participate in discussions of it in Paris next month.

WARSAW, April 29 (AP) -- The Government-owned newspaper Zycie Warszawy accused David Halberstam, the Warsaw correspondent of The New York Times, today of a "tendentious and malicious presentation" of Poland to readers.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Treasury announced today the refunding terms of $8,436,000,000 of notes maturing on May 15. It indicated that while it isn't likely that it will have to make another borrowing for the balance of the current fiscal year to June 30, its cash needs in the second half of calendar 1965 may rise to $8 billion.

Leaders in international communication foresee the development of spacecasting -- the transmission of television programs from an orbiting satellite into millions of homes without networks or broadcasting stations on the ground.

The American Electric Power Company expects its 1965 net income to increase "on a percentage basis just about the same as it did in 1964," Donald C. Cook, president, told about 235 stockholders at the holding company's 58th annual meeting yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.

TEN years ago the editor-in-chief of Harper's Magazine asked a fledgling reporter covering the Minnesota State Legislature to join the journal as an editor. The young reporter declined. Yesterday the reporter, John Cowles Jr., was named president of a new magazine corporation formed to publish Harper's.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The so-called invisible government became glaringly visible for a moment today as dozens of intelligence experts crowded into the White House Cabinet Room for the swearing-in of the new Director of Central Intelligence.
When the Marines landed in the Dominican Republic yesterday, they were continuing a tradition of activity in the Caribbean that began in 1776.
The British pound was steady in active trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

WHEELING, W. Va., April 28 -- Norton Simon, chairman, offered stockholders of the ailing Wheeling Steel Corporation the prospect of still more sweat and tears today, but tinctured his prognosis with optimism.

Contract talks between the American Merchant Marine Institute and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, in progress since earlier this month, may become complicated by a union request disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, April 28 -- The Royal Academy of Arts has decided to send its rarely viewed masterpiece, a marble relief by Michelangelo, on a trip around the world.

THE war, in Vietnam is now almost twenty years old. It has cost countless lives, mostly Vietnamese, and billions of dollars, mostly American. For the West -- specifically, France and the United States -- it has been a war marked by endless frustration and defeat, and by official optimism and denials of defeat.
SYRACUSE, April 28 -- Loren Schoel is starting a rebuilding program in Syracuse rowing with a squad composed almost entirely of juniors and sophomores.
The New York Young Republican Club asked Governor Rockefeller yesterday for an immediate investigation into "the entire housing situation" in this city.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 28 -- The third attempt in a month to hold an election in the Congolese capital went off so smoothly today that it could have been used as a model for an advanced civics course.
The nation's electric power production rose 4.9 per cent in the week ended April 24 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
I. John Billera was elected president and chief executive officer of U.S. Industries, Inc., yesterday succeeding the late John I Snyder Jr., who died on April 24.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- Ministers, priests and nuns who took part in the Alabama Freedom March accused Representative William Dickinson today of spreading slanderous falsehoods about the civil rights demonstration.

James Drought, the writer who printed and peddled his first novel when he could not find a publisher, is getting ready to issue in September his eighth book, "Drugoth." He obviously has become an industry. L.B. Carlson, general manager of his publishing agency, Skylight Press, of Wolfpit Road, Norwalk, Conn., reports that there will be a million copies of Mr. Drought's books in print this summer.

AMERICA'S most beloved baby doctor came to town yesterday. The occasion for yet another in a recent flurry of visits to New York by Dr. Benjamin McLane Spock was the publication of "Caring for Your Disabled Child" (Macmillan, $4.95), a book he has written in collaboration with Marion O. Lerrigo.

George D. Wideners Steeple Jill won the ninth running of the one-mile Bed o'Roses Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday. Under a hustling ride by John Ruane, Steeple Jill managed to beat Sought After, a 94-to-1 shot from the Gedney Farm, by a neck, with the Isidor Bieber-Patrice Jacobs entry of Petticoat and Treachery third and fourth.

Investment companies grew so cautious during the first quarter of 1965 that they actually sold more stock that they bought. This is one of the highlights shown in a survey of portfolio changes as complied by E.F. Hutton Co., Inc.

Stuart T. Saunders, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad, and Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central, have been nominated for the top positions in the Pennsylvania New York Central Transportation Company, which is slated to be formed when the Interstate Commerce Commission authorizes the merger of the Pennsylvania and Central.
MEXICO CITY, April 28 -- A cargo ship, the Surrey Trader, is scheduled to leave the port of Coatzalcoacos early tomorrow with a full cargo of dry sulphur bound for Australia.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- President Johnson accepted today on behalf of the Government a bronze bust of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and described her as "one of the great human beings of this century."
The F.W. Woolworth Company will open a permanent art sales gallery on Fifth Avenue hard on the heels of a two-week out-of-town tryout in New Jersey.
The appointment of Dr. E. Hugh Luckey to the new post of president of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, effective July 1, 1966, was announced yesterday.

BONN, April 28 -- Walter Ulbricht, leader of East Germany, demanded in a speech published today that West Germany pay his communist state the equivalent of $30 billion in "compensation," apparently for East Germans who have fled to the West.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 -- The sun finally drilled a hole in the low overcast at an unseemly hour this morning and wrapped a golden glow around the handsome head of Bold Lad as the favorite in Saturday's Kentucky Derby contentedly munched grass in front of his barn at Churchill Downs.

Evangeline Marko Benedetti, a 24-year-old cellist who made her debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last night, announced herself in her first selection as the possessor of the big, vibrant tone one likes to hear from her instrument.
The much awaited Treasury announcement of its plans to refund $8.4 billion of notes maturing in May evoked an initial favorable response from dealers yesterday afternoon.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
HARTFORD, April 28 -- Plans for the construction of New England's largest nuclear-powered electric generating plant were announced here today.

MILWAUKEE, April 28 (AP) -- Bob Gibson posted his third victory and second shutout with a three-hitter tonight as the St. Louis Cards defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 5-0. There were only 1,324 fans on hand, the smallest crowd in Country Stadium history.

WASHINGTON April 28 (UPI) -- Allegheny Airlines announced today that it had ordered four "king-size" DC-9 jets, had taken an option on four more, and was negotiating to purchase 10 F-27 prop-jets. The four planes, including spare parts, will cost $32 million.

The Royal Ballet gave the third performance of "Giselle at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Svetlana Beriosova appeared in the title role, and Donald MacLeary was Albrecht. The remained of the cast was familiar from the previous performances.

Stoke-on-Trent, England, April 28 (Reuters) -- Sir Stanley Matthews, a 50-year-old star, bowed out of English professional soccer tonight in a match studded with many of Europe's great players of the last decade.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- United States Marines landed in the revolt-torn Dominican Republic today to protect and evacuate American citizens, President Johnson announced tonight.

In the "Quotation of the Day" (April 20) The Times repeated West Berlin Mayor Willy Brandt's emphatic and dramatic declaration that, "No one has the right to insist that German sons must bear the responsibility for the Germany of their fathers." (From Mr. Brandt's speech at the New School in New York.)
LONDON, April 28 -- The Duke of Edinburgh, piloting the royal helicopter, made an unscheduled landing on an Oxfordshire Parade Ground Monday to avoid a hailstorm.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 28 -- A large banner reading "Let's break diplomatic relations with the United States" was hung across the street in front of the United States Embassy yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Gasoline supplies in the United States narrowed in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

Eighty-six persons in the area have been indicted for alleged violations of Federal gambling laws. The indictments followed the Government's use of electronic computers for the first time in uncovering bookmaking activities.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Senate Investigations subcommittee ended today its secret inquiry into allegations that "fast-buck manipulators" had profited by buying control of eight banks, which then lent more than $400,000 to the new owners and their businesses.

Uncertainty about the Pan American Sulphur Company's future in Mexico propelled the company's stock to the top of the New York Stock Exchange's active list yesterday. Its shares presently outstanding closed at 37, off 6 points from the closing price on Tuesday, on a turnover of 236,800 shares.
A 6.4 per cent reduction in first-quarter profits of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) was reported yesterday by M.L. Haider, chairman.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 28 -- The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steelmaker, reported today that first-quarter earnings rose to $44,132,000, or 97 cents a share, a sharp gain from the period a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Government's Consumer Price Index went up slightly last month.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 28 (Reuters) -- Rebel forces trying to bring former President Juan Bosch back to power have gained strength and now control the center of Santo Domingo, a United States Embassy spokesman said tonight.

The recent Texas Gulf Sulphur suit in which the Securities and Exchange Commission charged company insiders with having made wrongful use of information not generally available to the public, has already had a tangible effect on the corporate community.

Excerpts from television and radio broadcasts by Edward R. Murrow, who died Tuesday, will be presented on a special hour- long program to be televised at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The election of Mike Antkies and Stuart M. Lilien as vice presidents of Sutton Towne, Inc., has been announced by Ralph Joseph, the real estate company's president. The two brokers, working as a team, have negotiated in the last seven months commercial leases with rentals totaling $14 million.
EVANSTON, Ill., April 28 -- The National Merit Scholarship Corporation announced today the names of more than 1,900 winners of four-year college scholarships valued at $7.5 million.
The election of M. Nielsen as chairman of the Babcock Wilcox Company was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors.

Maryan Filar belongs to that vast group of fine pianists just below the top rank. His playing last night in Carnegie Hall was admirable for the care he lavished on lyrical passages, for his delicate tone in Mozart's Sonata in C (K. 330) and for the way he separated melodic from accompanying material.
LOS ANGELES, April 28 (UPI) -- Donn Clendendon doubled in two runs in the eighth inning tonight to snap the Pittsburgh Pirates' six-game losing streak with a 2-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

NEW ORLEANS, April 28 -- The St. Tammany Parish (County) School Board was ordered today by Federal District Judge Frank B. Ellis in New Orleans to present a plan by May 14 for the desegregation of the parish public schools.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Australia's reported decision to send a combat battalion to help the fight of the South Vietnamese was not a surprise here. However, offical sources withheld comment.
MOSCOW, April 28 -- President Johnson's latest offer of unconditional negotiations in Vietnam was likened to "impudent demagoguery" tonight by Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper.

Governor Rockefeller told the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday that the New Haven Railroad's commuter runs into New York were "at or close to the break-even" point. He added that cash revenues exceeded cash expenses.

Scriabin specialists 18 years of age are a rare breed on the concert stage, and so Paul Schoenfield's New York debut last night at Town Hall was something of ah event. The young pianist from Detroit offered two Scriabin sonatas almost never heard here, the No. 7 ("The White Mass") and the No. 9 (The Black Mass").

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- A General Motors executive told Congress today his company believes that the United States-Canadian automotive products agreement "while not free of difficulties, is over a period of time a workable plan."
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Administration wholeheartedly supports the truth-in-packaging bill, Mrs. Esther Peterson, Special Assistant to President Johnson for Consumer Affairs, said today.

There is widespread agreement in New York that Robert Wagner's re-election to a fourth term as Mayor would be a grave disservice to our city. Yet many New Yorkers throw up their hands in despair and fall victim to the twin platitudes "Wagner can't be beaten" and "this city can't be governed."

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., April 28 (UPI) -- Dennis Ralston said today that if he were not allowed to play here in the opening United States Davis Cup competition in June, he would make no attempt later to gain a berth on the team.

Biting his lip in concentration, 7-year-old Desmond Morgan tapped a tambourine in time to a record player the other day, as his second-grade classmates in the Bronx sang along with the music and followed the words on large posters.
As an "Escorter" driver at the World's Fair last summer, I must take exception to your news article of April 21 on the abolition of Escorters at the fair.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 28 -- Henry Cabot Lodge, former Ambassador to South Vietnam, arrived in Saigon today and said the war effort against the Vietcong had improved in the 10 months since he resigned his post here.

Mount Sinai Hospital announced yesterday that nearly $15 million had already been pledged in the drive it opened last night to raise $55 million for a 23-story school of medicine within the present hospital complex on the upper East Side.
ALBANY, April 28 -- The controversial State Investigation Commission won another reprieve today as the Legislature voted overwhelmingly to extend its life until April 30, 1967.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 (UPI) -- Matty Alou, whose ninth-inning homer won last night's 14-13 game, batted in four runs today in leading the San Francisco Giants to a 9-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phils.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Two North Korean MIG-17 jet fighters "attacked and damaged" a United States RB-47 reconnaissance plane over the Sea of Japan last night, the Pentagon announced today.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 28 (UPI) -- The owner of a segregated bar stood ready to negotiate today with University of Texas students who want Negroes served there.
WOODBRIDGE, Conn. -- A relatively new teaching technique called "color reading" or "visual dictation" has tremendously brightened the reading skills of kindergarten children in this New Haven suburb.

WASHINGTON, APril 28 -- The Atomic Energy Commission asked the National Academy of Sciences today to help it settle the highly controversial question of where the next giant atom smasher should be built.
CAIRO, April 28 -- A rook of rioting Arab students stoned, ransacked and set fire to the Tunisian Ambassador's residence today.

PARIS, April 28 -- Capt. Edward Molyneux, the gentle and very correct couturier who once taught his rich and well-known clients to dress as discreetly as a governess should, deserves to be a fashion idol this year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 28 -- Lord Chalfont, Britain's Minister for Disarmament, warned the United Nations today that a failure to halt the spread of nuclear weapons would raise the danger of their use by irresponsible revolutionary forces.

PARIS, April 28 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union has stated his agreement to holding an international conference on Cambodia, Minister of Information Alain Peyrefitte said today.

THE Portuguese Water Dog Club of America has 10 members. If half that many more join it will contain all the owners of the breed in the United States. There are 19 dogs, so the breed is among the rarest.
The Irving Trust Company has leased 55,000 square feet of space in the 47-story office tower now under construction at 245 Park Avenue, on the site of the old Grand Central Palace.

The world's only floating professional tennis troupe opened a five-night stand yesterday for $15,000 in prize money and a chance to show the public that the globe-hopping pros still had zing in their shots.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 28 -- Authorities in this town and in Springfield in nearby Union County are trying to apply official brakes to skateboards, the latest juvenile fad on wheels.

BARBRA STREISAND found herself in an extremely enviable position last night. The 23-year-old performer, who has only two Broadway shows to her credit, was given an hour of her very own on the Columbia Broadcasting System -- to sing, smile, dance and do just about anything she wanted.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 -- What may be an explanation for the cancer-causing ability of a potent toxin from a mold that grows on peanuts, rice, corn and other foodstuff was presented at a scientific meeting here today.

Molly Picon, who last appeared on Broadway in "Milk and Honey" (1961), has agreed to return to the local stage next fall in a new comedy, "Madame Mousse," by Jean Pierre Aumont. The producers are Emmett Rogers, Stanley Gordon and Max Brown.

Seldom in all the years of Democratic maladministration of New York City has the opportunity for a reform ticket beckoned so brightly as in the 1965 election; but as usual the Republican high command shows every sign of being ready to throw in the towel before the fight begins.

The New York Yankees reached the .500 mark with a 6-6 record in the young American League baseball season yesterday by beating the Kansas City Athletics, 5-1, at Yankee Stadium. But the victory may prove a Pyrrhic one.

A $40 million program to improve education and bring about better racial integration will go into effect next September, Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Acting Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

From a small printing shop that the brothers James and John Harper started with horse-powered presses in downtown Manhattan in 1817 has emerged a powerful publishing organization that has exerted considerable influence on American literature, education, Journalism and perhaps on some important modern legislation.
PARIS, April 28 -- Advertising men from 47 countries pondered today the question of how to keep on succeeding without bringing on government intervention.
The nation's first statewide emergency communications network for hospitals was put into operation yesterday in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Mike Mansfield and Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate, will move soon, probably tomorrow, to remove the outright ban on poll taxes from the voting-rights bill.

A PLAYER with an unbalanced freak hand, with one long suit and only one or two cards in his two shortest suits, can be sure that the auction will be competitive. It is more important to become the declarer than to attempt any precise valuation of your side's trick-taking potential, so tactical considerations are paramount in the bidding.

PITTSBURGH, April 28 -- The Wage Policy Committee of the United Steelworkers of America ratified this afternoon an interim agreement with major steel producers that will prevent a nationwide strike. The walkout had been scheduled for Friday at midnight.
SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, April 29 -- Australia will send an 800-man army battalion of jungle-warfare troops to South Vietnam, a Sydney newspaper reported today.
Sharp gains in first-quarter sales and earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation were reported yesterday by Thomas F. Patton, chairman and president.

W. Averell Harriman, United States Ambassador at Large, said yesterday that President Johnson, in his handling of the Vietnam crisis, was acting on the principles that guided the late Sir Winston Churchill.
A plan for the imaginative development of 1,080 acres on Staten Island into a model community was advanced by the city yesterday, after two years of indecision and infighting.
THE Danish male, unlike his American counterpart, toileth not and spinneth not in the kitchen, Dagmar Freuchen commented recently.

LONDON, April 28 (UPI) -- Eleazar Davidman fought off three match points in the third set and went on to unset Mike Sangster, 3-6, 2-6, 7-5, 7-5, 6-4, today to give Israel a 1-1 split against Britain in the opening round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis series.

A Minneapolis newspaper company has bought a half-interest in 115-year-old Harper's Magazine, one of the country's most influential monthlies. The other half-interest is being retained by Harper Row, book publishers.
CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP) -- Two Cleveland homers and three Minnesota errors that accounted for six unearned runs gave the Indians a 9-3 victory over the Twins tonight.
NEW DELHI, April 28 -- The Indian Government charged tonight that Pakistan was using American-supplied tanks to fight Indian troops in the Rann of Cutch.
HONG KONG, April 28 -- This morning's Peking newspaper documented what analysts here describe as the drift of Communist China toward international isolation on the Vietnam issue.
ALBANY, April 28 -- Two major planks in the Democratic legislative program -- offtrack betting on horse races and a bipartisan commission to reapportion the Legislature -- all but collapsed today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 28 -- South Vietnamese Government forces have concluded one of their most succesful weeks in the history of the war against the Vietcong, American analysts said today.

ALBANY, April 28 -- The Democrats, in the hope of out-maneuvering Governor Rockefeller, have tentatively decided not to adjourn the Legislature when the work of the current session has been completed.
BUFFALO, April 28 (AP) -- The Buffalo Board of Education approved 4 to 2 today a plan to end racial imbalance in city schools.
Asamera Oil set the trading pace yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as the market generally declined on heavy volume.
The General Motors Corporation did it again in the first quarter of this year, rolling up the largest corporate profits in the history of American business.

BIAR BET, Rann of Cutch, April 28 -- "They are dropping their equipment and running like hell," the Pakistani commanding officer shouted in my ear as medium artillery a mile in front of us blasted every few minutes.

Indian Head Mills, Inc., filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed sale of $20 million of with warrants for the purchase of 400,000 shares of common 25-year 5 1/2 per cent debentures of 400,000 shares of common stock.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upheld the Federal Trade Commission today in a ease involving alleged reciprocal buying -- "I will buy from you if you will buy from me."

Two events next month will benefit the Child Study Association of America. An all-day art and garden tour has been arranged for May 12. Visitors will view a collection of works by French impressionists and contemporary artists at The Reader's Digest building in Chappaqua, N.Y.
The election of Richard H. Turrell and John S. Nichols as vice presidents of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York was announced yesterday.

NEWMARKET, England, April 28 (UPI) -- Niksar, a 3-year-old with a liking for a slow track, splashed to a one-length victory today in the 2,000 Guineas, the first major race of the British racing season. The event had its first running in 1809.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Republican fund raisers struck a bonanza tonight.

LET all anglers and conservationists salute the State of Montana, its Legislature, its Fish and Game Commission and others who worked to bring about a new law. The legislation signed by Gov. Tim Babcock, according to details published in the current issue of Conservation News, is a model statute providing protection for fishing streams.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Food and Drug Administration underwent a second day of intense criticism today before a Senate committee. Witnesses accused the agency of "criminality" and said that three members of its staff seated in the hearing room had committed perjury.
The Spring Festival of Fragrance, a dinner dance at the Astor on May 18, will benefit the Kidney Foundation of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman today set May 4 for a referendum among growers of flu-cured tobacco to determine if they wished to adopt a new acreage-poundage production-control program.

The Sperry Rand Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement under which it would pay additional Federal taxes and interest of $25 million on former operations in Puerto Rico.
CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- The trial of four men accused of mail fraud in the promotion of Krebiozen began today in United States District Court after several months of delays.
HIGH POINT, N.C., April 28 -- The most popular sport at the Southern furniture market is trend-watching.
A house and garden tour in Brooklyn Heights has been arranged for Wednesday from 2 until 5 P.M. to benefit the Willoughby House Settlement at 285 Myrtle Avenue in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The American Bankers Association took strong exception here today to proposed legislation that would merge into one Government agency all bank regulatory functions now handled by the Controller of the Currency, the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
CINCINNATI, April 28 (AP) -- Ernie Broglio balked home the winning run in the 14th inning, giving the Cincinnati Reds a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.
The word "new" as applied to advertised products is as old as advertising itself. And in many cases, it would appear that only the word "new" is really new.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission granted today a group of news services an extra month to file exceptions to a proposed increase in their private telegraph line charges.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 28 -- The General Electric Company has decided to make its long-awaited serious plunge into color television by producing its own color picture tube.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Negroes who succeeded in business after a tremendous amount of trying were asked by Vice President Humphrey today to spread the word that "a new day" had dawned for their race.
Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, called yesterday for the removal of Orville L. Freeman as Secretary of Agriculture.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- Following, as made public by the State Department today, is a list of Americans from the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area evacuated from the Dominican Republic:

Dr. James W. Silver received a $500 award from the Sidney Hillman Foundation yesterday for his book, "Mississippi: The Closed Society." The professor of history on temporary leave from the University of Mississippi to the University of Notre Dame also spoke at the awards luncheon given by the foundation at the Commodore Hotel.

LONDON, April 29 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of "direct armed intervention" in the Dominican Republic to prevent the return of Juan Bosch, the former left-wing President. Other Communist parties in Europe also assailed the United States' Marine landing there.

THE World Championship tournament to be held in South America is now only two weeks away, and the North American team will open today its full-scale training program. The main task is to learn thoroughly the three difficult foreign systems that will be met in Buenos Aires: the Roman, the Neapolitan and the Little Major.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) -- Six minority stockholders have begun a fight to get themselves elected directors of the Reading Company, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.
PARIS, April 29 -- Communist delegates complained today about a speech by a Polish sociologist at the International Advertising Association's congress here.
The naming of Dr. John T. Flynn as director of medicine at the Beckman-Downtown Hospital, effective tomorrow, was announced yesterday. Dr. Flynn is a specialist in internal medicine.
The Sinclair Oil Corporation announced yesterday that first-quarter earnings totaled $18,234,266, or $1.21 a share, a gain of 16 per cent over the $15,710,426, or $1.05 a share, in the 1964 quarter.
SEATTLE, April 29 -- A severe, rolling earthquake shook the Pacific Northwest at 8:28 A.M. today, taking two lives and causing widespread though minor damage.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Senator Gale W. McGee urged university campus groups today to make their discussions of United States policy in Vietnam a real debate.

A series of Freedom Rides to the North -- the first one from Selma, Ala., to Syracuse, N.Y. -- to "dramatize Northern hypocrisy" was announced yesterday by the Congress of Racial Equality and the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.

WINCHESTER, Va., April 29 -- The band played "I'll Be With You in Apple Blossom Time," Jack Dempsey smiled a beatific smile, Senator George Murphy picked up the silver crown, and Neva Goodwin Rockefeller, daughter of the president of the Chase Manhattan Bank became "Shenandoah XXXVIII, Fair Queen of the Apple Blossoms."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 29 (AP) -- Nearly a month has passed since thee Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called for an economic boycott of Alabama. Indications so far are that the Negro leader missed his mark.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -The Attorney General and the Senate leadership reached agreement late today on a substitute for the voting-rights bill now before the Senate.

Dr. Ralph Bunche, the United Nations Under Secretary and Nobel Peace Prize winner, will accept the National Academy of Sports Award for the University of California, Los Angeles, at the New York Hilton Hotel Monday night.

The El Mole Rachmim (God, Full of Mercy and the Yizkor (In Remembrance), the solemn Hebrew prayers for the dead, echoed in Times Square at noon yesterday in memory of 60,000 Jews who died in the Warsaw ghetto uprising 22 years ago.

Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey gave the nation's mutual-fund industry a ringing note of affirmation yesterday. "One of the great investments in the Great Society is the mutual fund," he told a luncheon audience of the Investment Company Institute at the Biltmore Hotel.
BALTIMORE, April 29 (AP) -- Norm Sieburn's two-run homer with two out in the eighth inning gave the Baltimore Orioles a 5-4 victory tonight over the Washington Senators.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -In an atmosphere of calm that contrasted with the general excitement that existed through the entire region, the field for the 91st running of the Kentucky Derby Saturday was drawn today.
WASHINGTON, Friday, April 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of the State Department announcement early today on the dispatch of troop reinforcements to the Dominican Republic:

HOLLYWOOD, April 29 -- The race issue in Hollywood, dormant for the past three years, is stirring again. A vigorous new campaign to gain more jobs for Negroes in show business will be opened next month under the leadership of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

HAVANA, April 29 -- Premier Fidel Castro's Communist party newspaper called today for Cuban backing of the Dominican people, who it said were "fighting the most brutal repression." It violently attacked the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A fund-raising party for Representative Adam Clayton Powell is being investigated by the District of Columbia's Department of Licenses and Inspections. The department is checking its records to determine whether sponsors of a $50-a-glass cocktail party in the Harlem Democrat's honor at a night club on April 2 had obtained a license for charitable solicitation.

Deputy Mayor Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. has concluded his investigation of charges that "snake-pit" conditions prevail at Women's Prison with a smug all's well. In his personal tour of this black hole of New York Mr. Cavanagh discovered gracious personnel catering to "bright and alert" girls and women in facilities that were "excellent" and "clean."

WASHINGTON, April 29 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee served notice on all underdeveloped countries today that "they have no 'inherent' right to assistance from the United States," and that any mob action against American property would result in the prompt termination of aid.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 -- A long and well-fortified network of Vietcong trenches was discovered today eight miles south of the Danang air base.
CINCINNATI, (AP) -- Glenn Beckert's two-run single capped a four-run sixth inning that helped the Chicago Cubs gain a 6-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that evidence obtained illegally by police officers cannot be used in a proceeding for forfeiture of personal property.
LONDON, April 29 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson warned Rhodesia today that she was courting "disaster" by threatening to declare her independence without negotiations.

The moderately strong earthquake that shook the Pacific Northwest yesterday caused substantial property damage, but the loss of life was remarkably small. For comparison, it is worth recalling that about 115 persons were killed little more than a year ago when a quake battered some half-million square miles of thinly populated Alaska.

BABYLON, L.I., April 29 -- The sun was bright and Great South Bay was calm and placid. The flounders lay in regiments around the bottom, eager and happy to please the fishermen who were willing to take time off from work, tear themselves from their families and board a Captree State Park party boat.

The Royal Ballet of England, which has given six performances of "Romeo and Juliet" and three of "Giselle" since its opening at the Metropolitan Opera House last week, broke the pattern of full-length works last night to offer a program of three short ballets -- "Les Patineurs," "Les Biches" and "Marguerite and Armand."
BERKELEY, Calif., April 29 -- The Free Speech Movement at the University of California is dissolving, and a new organization is being formed to replace it.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A beam of light has been used to produce sound waves more than a million times higher in pitch than those audible to the human ear.

The Soviet Union has placed textiles high on the list of consumer products for which expanded production will be sought. In this program, it is planned to double the output of man-made fibers in the next five years.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -Directors of the New York City neighborhood houses said today that their groups had been shunned by that city's Anti-poverty Operations Board.
A program to raise $38 million in two years for major improvements and expansion at the University of Rochester was announced yesterday by W. Allen Wallis, president.

The License Commissioner's office, looking into ticket sales for the May 9 concert by Vladimir Horowitz, has found no illegalities but has made a suggestion: a second concert by the pianist for those who left empty-handed when the box office sold out in two hours last Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -Units of the United States Coast Guard have been ordered to South Vietnam to join in coastal patrols to block infiltration of Communist guerrillas and arms.
ELK GROVE TOWNSHIP, Ill., April 29 -- W.A. Patterson, chairman of United Air Lines, Inc., announced today the best first quarter since United began jet operations in 1959.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- Soviet electric-power interests and conservation-minded public officials have clashed over the proposed sites of two large hydroelectric projects. As a result, Moscow has ordered careful studies of their value.

Last night marked the 167th anniversary of the first performance of Haydn's oratorio "The Creation." It is not the usual number of years for a celebration, but it was a good enough excuse for Martin Josman and his New York Choral Society to perform it at Carnegie Hall.

Sometimes it takes a foreigner, in this case an Englishman, to present an objective view of a figure such as Warren Gamaliel Harding. Andrew Sinclair explores in this book the many myths about Harding -- the self-made man, the country boy, the Ohioan, the dark horse. Harding went to the White House because he was the man from Main Street that Americans dreamed they wanted.

A spokesman for General of Army Omar N. Bradley said here yesterday that the former commander of the 12th Army Group had not received an invitation from Moscow to attend a 20th-anniversary celebration of the end of World War II in Europe.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 29 -- The Westchester County Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars has withdrawn an invitation to Representative Richard L. Ottinger to speak next Sunday at Loyalty Day ceremonies in Hartley Park here.

When Sidney Weinberg, a senior partner in Goldman, Sachs Co., propounded his "hard line" doctrine on the freewheeling antics of "professional minority" shareowners at annual meetings, he may have done for corporate executives what Mahan and Clausewitz did for the military, opening up a whole new tactical and strategic world.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 29 (AP) -- The United States Government was asked today to tell the Turkish Government that limitations placed upon the Eastern Orthodox Ecumenical Patriarchate in Istanbul constitute "a most serious violation of religious liberty."
SYDNEY, Australia, April 29 -- The Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, announced in parliament tonight that Australia would send an 800-man battalion, to fight the Communists in South Vietnam.

THE West is still the place where pioneering is done with pride and where the Spanish Colonial tradition flourishes, judging by the large display of furnishings opening today at Macy's. Drawn in part from the California Design IX show, which opened last month at the Pasadena Museum of Art, the store's display on the ninth floor includes indoor and outdoor furniture, accessories and an art exhibition.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Senate Finance Committee began hearings on medical care for the aged today, with favorable action all but certain.
Mayor Wagner proposed yesterday the creation of a super-agency to coordinate all commuter-train service, and eventually all transportation, in the three-state metropolitan area.
LONDON, April 29 -- Who goes to the opera? The Sadler's Wells Opera found out that not more than one in a hundred of London's adults attend.

A trial has just begun in the lovely little Yugoslav seaport of Zadar -- once famous for its maraschino liqueur -- which will provide fascinating insight into the extent of change occurring in Communist East Europe since Stalin's death.

The Municipal Art Society will give its top awards this year to Mayor Wagner and one of the city's new skyscrapers. The Mayor will get the society's Illuminated Scroll of Honor for his support of the city's new landmarks preservation law, which he recently signed.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 28 -- Billy MacKnight is one of 35 teen-agers here who operate a downtown parking lot that is expected to gross $16,000 a year and that contributes to charities.
ALBANY, April 29 -- Sol Neil Corbin, Governor Rockefeller's chief legal adviser, has decided to resign this summer at the end of the regular legislative session.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 29 -- President Jomo Kenyatta rejected a shipment of weapons from the Soviet Union today after the bulk of it had been unloaded at Mombasa.
The hearing into the application of Mark Fein for a new murder trial was reopened yesterday at the request of the prosecution, which presented a surprise witness.
WAR may be the most terrible addiction of the human race, a hideous folly which all men of goodwill profess to deplore.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 29 (AP) -- A military spokesman said today that North Vietnamese troops overran a Government post north of the Plaine des Jarres yesterday,

Analyzing the current wave of unrest on college campuses, Dean Joseph F. Kauffman of the University of Wisconsin has placed some of the blame on the "crass opportunism" and selfishness of many university faculty members.
Barbra Streisand's special hour-long show that was televised Wednesday evening will be repeated on a date still undetermined, the Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 29 -- A full-size model of the Soviet Union's manned spacecraft Vostok was placed on public view here for the first time today.

ZADAR, Yugoslavia, April 29 -- Mihajlo Mihajlov pleaded not guilty today on charges that he had written insultingly about the Soviet Union and that he had distributed his banned article, "Moscow Summer 1964."
TOKYO, April 29 (Reuters) -- A baseball feud between the United States and Japan ended today when the Nankai Hawks agreed to send Masanori Murakami to the San Francisco Giants for the 1965 season.

Barred by Commissioner of Parks Newbold Morris from taking test borings for the proposed garage under Madison Square Park, Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes disclosed yesterday that he had found another way to accomplish his objective.

The purpose of President Johnson and his advisers in bombing North Vietnam has been to make it too costly for her to continue her support for the Vietcong in South Vietnam and force her rulers to negotiate on terms acceptable to us.
Kenneth B. Keating, former United States Senator, retraced the 50-year history of 20th Century-Fox at a luncheon yesterday honoring the film company, given by the New York Variety Club.
The B.B.C. Symphony Orchestra, Antal Dorati, conductor, with Heather Harper, soprano, performs 20th-century music at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:30.
Robert Moses said yesterday that the possibility of a change in the World's Fair price structure was being considered.
The Buckingham Corporation has appointed Edward J. Laux as secretary and treasurer.

Contracts for future construction awarded throughout the country in March were equal in volume to the dollar value of contracts placed in March, 1964, the F.W. Dodge Company, construction marketing and information specialists, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The astronauts who will make the next Gemini flight said today they were ready for direct exposure to space.

The city's $115,555,594-a-year, 14,444-employe Department of Sanitation will get an office of management planning as a result of a report issued yesterday sharply criticizing the agency's planning function.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 29 -- Nine students suspended from a Negro university here last week are seeking a Federal court order that will get them back in school.
The United Steelworkers of America and the Aluminum Company of America opened negotiations yesterday for a new contract to replace one expiring June 1.

The 30th annual spring dance of the Boys Club of New York last night at the Plaza was a tribute to Mrs. Jarvis Cromwell, the chairman of the first such benefit for the club, held in 1935. Mrs. Cromwell, honorary chairman of yesterday's fete, Was introduced to the assembled guests.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 29 -- Arnold Palmer smashed par by six strokes today to lead in the opening round of the Tournament of Champions with a 66. In the select field of 26, Palmer was able to gain a two-stroke advantage over three who tied for second.
Prof. Kenneth B. Clark of City College said yesterday that he would set up a private project for work with selected young people in Harlem.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -The Office of Education today set the fall of 1967 as the target date for complete racial desegregation of the public schools.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 29 -- The formation of a county traffic department "to advance the orderly and efficient flow of traffic" was recommended today by the Nassau Commission on Governmental Revision.
United States holdings of convertible foreign currencies rose by $263 million in March, a large gain for one month, to $490, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.

ROME, April 29 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson disclosed today a British initiative for a heads-of-government meeting of the European Free Trade Association to seek policies to heal the economic split with the European Economic Community, or Common Market.

CAIRO, April 29 -- Delegates from 12 Arab states indirectly censured Tunisia's President, Habib Bourguiba, today for having advocated conciliation toward Israel. The delegates declined, however, to approve proposals to oust Tunisia from the Arab League or to bar President Bourguiba from future Arab leaders' meetings.
Never have so many made so much in so short a time.
A prominent American pacifist said yesterday that the action taken by the Communist-dominated World Peace Council in Stockholm last weekend was "ominous" and "belligerent."

TWO things stand out about Brig. Gen. Elias Wessin y Wessin, leader of the counter-revolutionary forces in the current civil war in the Dominican Republic. He is well known for being incorruptible and for being a fierce anti-Communist.

WHAT does a woman wear when she is invited to someone's house to look at television? At Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Goodman's party Wednesday evening in their 22-room penthouse apartment atop Bergdorf's, the answers ran the gamut from pajamas to Paris ball gowns.
Top representatives of seven of the world's leading ship classification societies will attempt in a meeting here next week to develop an up-to-date international standard for ships' load lines.
Asamera Oil continued to dominate trading on the American Stock Exchange for the second consecutive day as the market edged off in active trading.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 29 -- The use of certain viruses to combat bacterial infections was re-examined at a scientific meeting here today with both promising and perplexing results.
The Union Pacific Railroad reported yesterday that its earnings in the month of March hit a new high and cited an increase in its first-quarter profits.
PRINK HILL -- If it were not for British poets, and for Shakespeare in particular, the citizens of northeastern America would not be so consistently pained by April.
The New Jersey Bell Teephone Company announced yesterday it planned to sell $40 million of 40-year debentures.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 29 -- The United States made a gesture today toward compromise in the deadlock over the voting rights of the Soviet Union and other countries that have refused to pay assessments for peace-keeping operations.

Barry Smith and Gil Robinov, vice presidents of Sutton Towne, performed some high-level acrobatics to sign a tenant who recently took space in the 24-story building at 1212 Avenue of the Americas at 48th Street.
Potato futures prices rose sharply yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- A spokesman for the British Embassy said today that the embassy had thus far been unable to get permission for a visit to a British tourist held by the Soviet authorities since Sunday on unspecified charges of "alleged involvement in subversive activities."

They brought 44-year-old Pancho Segura out of retirement to play in the $15,000 professional tennis tournament at the 71st Regiment Armory last night. The popular little Ecuadorian might as well have stayed home.
BRUSSELS, April 29 -- The severe shortage of labor in the European Economic Community or Common Market, will continue in 1965, the executive Commission of the six-nation bloc reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today international airline agreements continuing air fares across the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans generally at their present levels.

All the restaurant space, including the cafe-bar, in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street has been leased by the Brody Corporation, headed by Jerome Brody. The company operates the Rainbow Room atop the R.C.A. Building in Rockefeller Center, and Gallagher's Steak House at 228 West 52d Street.

A sufferer from hay fever would be well-advised to live in the city rather than the suburbs and, above all, should avoid driving on country roads in an open convertible before dawn, particularly if there is ground fog.

A force of "50,000 underground Dominican fighters" stands ready to destroy counter-revolutionary tanks and conduct a house-to-house battle in the civil war in the Dominican Republic, exiled supporters of Juan Bosch declared here yesterday.

MOST of last night's Philharmonic concert centered on the Mahler Symphony No. 6 in A minor, one of the less-played of the nine. It runs almost an hour and a half, virtually an entire program in itself.
Brown Bolte obviously is a man who knows what he wants and knows how to get it.
The stock market put in another dull day yesterday on a drop in activity. There was no marked trend, as leading averages held their ground and the gains and losses nearly balanced out.

CINCINNATI, April 29 -- To everyone else, Houston's glassed-in Astrodome is the world of the future, especially to Lindsay Nelson, the radio announcer who worked last night from a flying saucer 208 feet directly above second base.
The Metropolitan Opera opened the doors yesterday of its new building going up in Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. But only the press was allowed in.
PERCHED 200 feet above Madison Avenue, on the roof of Abercrombie Fitch, is a modern vacation house, dramatically silhouetted against the skyline of New York.
Bohemia Stable's Kelso, thoroughbred racing's leading money-winner with $1,893,362, returned to New York yesterday after a long vacation in Kentucky.
MEXICO CITY, April 29 -The Government took another step today that may curb the operations of the two United States companies accounting for most of the sulphur exported from Mexico.
ALBANY, April 29 -- The legislature voted today to grant the Wagner administration a second two-week extension of the date for submission of the city's expected $3.5 billion budget.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., April 29 -- The development of a Westchester Colonial village of 35 old houses, grist mills, shops and museums on 150 acres of the vacant county land at Hawthorne was proposed tonight by Allison Albee, the official county historian.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- In these perplexing days when the dreams and plans of the nation seem to be going badly in many parts of the world, it may be useful to remember that policies are not necessarily disproved because they are opposed or even rejected. As G.K. Chesterton once remarked, "The lost causes are exactly those which might have saved the world."

LOS ANGELES, April 29 (UPI) -- Don Drysdale pitched the Dodgers back into first place tonight with a 2-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants. Tommy Davis drove in both Dodger runs with a triple and single.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The chairman of a Senate subcommittee accused the Food and Drug Administration today of wholesale misconduct in the performance of its duties.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The United States Court of Appeals here ruled today that the International Brotherhood of Teamsters must produce financial records subpoenaed by the Labor Department.
A small railroad that operates largely on hope and a big deficit -- the New York, Susquehanna Western -- held its annual meeting yesterday at its Edgewater, N.J., terminal.
DETROIT, April 29 (AP) -Auwtomotive news reported today that the nation's automobile industry turned out 205,483 cars this week, including the six-millionth 1965 model.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 29 -- Premier Moise Tshombe said tonight that his provisional Government had completed its mission.
QUINCY, Ill., April 29 (AP) -- The flooding Mississippi River kept pressure on levees along a 250-mile sector of the Iowa-Illinois border tonight.
LISBON, April 29 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar's political machine today accused the Communist party of responsibility for the reported death of Lieut. Gen. Humberto Delgado.

STUDENT designers who had sketched and snipped and sewn during their dressmaking course at the Parsons School of Design were rewarded last night by seeing their fashions paraded by professional models in the ballroom of the Essex House.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -Carloadings of rail freight in the week ended April 24 rose to the highest level in five months. Intercity truck tonnage in the week was ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1964.

" My Fair Lady" has reportedly recorded the highest gross receipts for one week of an exclusive, reserved-seat theater engagement. From April 19 though 25 at the Criterion Theater, the film's gross was $108,966.14.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 29 (AP) -- Tom Draper, a 50-year-old chemical salesman from Birmingham, Mich., advanced today to the semi-finals of the North and South amateur golf tournament, along with Don Allen, David Boyd and Morris Beecroft.
Because of a coincidence in telephone numbers, a housewife in Ridgewood, Queens, never knows when she picks up her phone whether the caller will be seeking her or President Johnson.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A fresh and unfamiliar breath of efficiency blew through the fusty corridors of Congress today.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal estate taxes could be collected on flight-insurance benefits paid to the beneficiaries of a person killed in an airplane crash.

NEW DELHI, April 29 -- Pakistani troops continued their advance against Indian positions in the disputed Rann of Cutch today, official Indian spokesmen said tonight. Meanwhile, Britain and the United States pressed efforts to achieve an end to fighting in the wasteland, the Indians said.

It must have come as a surprise bordering on shock for American parents to read in "Pupils Put First in Teacher Code" (New York Times, April 22) that, according to a new code of ethics for the teaching profession adopted by the National Education Association, ". . . teachers will put the children they teach first."

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- (AP) -- Congress passed and sent to the White House today a compromise $2,227,563,977 appropriation bill that include $349 million to start the Appalachian regional development program.
The impact of the Treasury's May refunding plans was mild Yesterday in the bond market.

The Lincoln Center Repertory Company will end its residence at the ANTA Washington Square Theater at 40 West Fourth Street on May 29. The company is moving to the new Vivian Beaumont Theater in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts scheduled to open in October.
MOSCOW, April 29 -- The Soviet Union and Communist China today concluded a trade protocol for 1965.
The ninth annual Junior Republic Ball, a benefit for the George Junior Republic in Freeville, N.Y., will take place next Friday at the New York Hilton.
PARIS, April 29 -- France and the Soviet Union called tonight for an end to foreign intervention in Vietnam.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor swore in its new top executive officer yesterday, and he immediately said that the commission would wage a vigorous campaign against efforts to weaken its control of the docks.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges have reported the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J., April 29 -- Demolition experts from the Naval Aviation Depot at nearby Earle recovered 14 live hand grenades today that had been thrown into Lake Louise by a group of 10-year-old boys.

WASHINGTON, Friday, April 30 -- The Organization of American States voted this morning to call a special meeting of the foreign ministers of the Americas for tomorrow to consider "the serious situation" in the Dominican Republic.

HONG KONG, April 29 -Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China today made official Peking's opposition to the use of an international conference on Cambodia as a forum for discussing settlement of the Vietnam conflict.
Sweeping changes that include the imposition of a one-year residence requirement for state welfare aid were urged yesterday by a five-man panel appointed by Governor Rockefeller.

SANTO DOMINGO, Friday, April 30 -- United States airborne troops began landing here early today as a further step under President Johnson's policy of using American forces to protect American lives and restore order in the Dominican Republic.
ROME, April 29 -- Joseph M. Proskauer, 87-year-old New York lawyer and philanthropist, delivered an appeal here today for interfaith understanding an cooperation.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -President Johnson has asked Americans to "See the U.S.A." this year, and his wife will be among the first to do so.
BALTIMORE, April 29 -- Two new daily newspapers were born here tonight to fill the gap caused by a strike of the American Newspaper Guild.
Business spending for plant and equipment will swell this year to a record-breaking $51.7 billion, for a rise of $6.8 billion, or 15 per cent, over last year's outlays.

An automatic landing system that will take airliners to within 100 feet of the runway in bad weather has been approved by the Federal Aviation Agency for use by commercial airlines. The system is guided by a computer.

Prices fell sharply yesterday on the London Stock Exchange with the surprise announcement of tightened credit measure by the Bank of England. Some recovery was registered late in the session, but prices were still weak at the close.
The British pound rose sharply in spirited trading on foreign exchange markets here.

The Continental Independent Telephone Corporation of St. Louis has offered to acquire all of the common stock of the California Interstate Telephone Company through an exchange of stock. This was disclosed yesterday in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams said today a Treasury Department report for 1964 listed 839,225 taxpayers as delinquent in payming $1,173,911,000 in various Federal taxes.
Does not Cyril C. Means Jr. in his letter published on April 16 make a point exactly opposite to the one he intended?
ONE can imagine a bright, even original, comedy being written about the sex habits and other tribal rites of today's college generation, but "A Race of Hairy Men!" is neither bright nor original.

The city administration was criticized yesterday for what was called its failure to plan now for future parks. The criticism was voiced at a one-day conference sponsored by Pratt Institute at the Americana hotel.

Yet, it was just such criticism that helped impel President Johnson for the first time to make firm proposals for peace negotiations and the extension of economic aid to Southeast Asia.

Stockholders of Aluminium, Ltd., were told yesterday that the company's first-quarter profits dropped to an estimated $7 million, or 20 cents a share, from the $10.6 million, or 32 cents a share, earned in the period last year.
The New York State Housing Finance Agency plans to sell $79,785,000 of bonds during the week of May 17.
The wholesale commodity price index was unchanged at 105.8 on Wednesday.

A plan to establish a new bank in the northern part of Manhattan's garment district has been abandoned. Organizers of the proposed Pioneer National Bank have dropped the project because they were unable to find a location that looked sufficiently attractive to them.
YONKERS, April 29 -- Irish Napoleon, a low horse on the standardbred totem pole only three years ago, was the surprise winner tonight of the $50,000 National Championship Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

There was a valid reason for the United States to put a Marine landing force into Santo Domingo. This reason was to protect Americans and evacuate those who desire to leave.
