It will be for the Organization of American States to pick up from there.
The appointment of Walter D. Scott as a general partner in charge of the Chicago office of Lehman Brothers was announced yesterday by the investment banking concern.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -- In the window of the Christian Science reading room on Fourth Street tonight, a spotlight illuminated the golden text on Everlasting Punishment:
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- The Mariner 4 mark probe set a space communications record today.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., April 29 -- The nation's courts are falling behind in the race with the rapidly increasing number of automobile damage suits because they are still using "horse and buggy" procedures, the 27th American Assembly of Columbia University was told tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- Retail sales for the week ended April 24 declined 8 per cent from the level of the previous week, but were up 7 per cent from the level of the corresponding 1964 week, the Commerce Department reported today.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced today increased earnings for the first quarter of 1965 and promised an improvements program expected to cost some $700 million over the next seven years.
The Royal Marines Tattoo, 160-strong will tour the United States and Canada next autumn.
SAVANNAH, Ga. April 29 -- The largest Episcopal church in southern Georgia is seeking to withdraw from the denomination so as to avoid racial integration.

ATHENS, April 29 -- Premier George Papandreou reappointed his 46-year-old American-educated son, Prof. Andreas Papandreou, today to the key Cabinet post of Alternate Minister of Economic Coordination.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -- The woman's touch has finally caught up with the prosaic and utilitarian barn area at Churchill Downs. That is why one of the lesser contenders for Saturday's Kentucky Derby, Mr. Pak, is living in equine elegance.

TOKYO, Friday, April 30 (AP) -- The Chinese Communist press agency Hsinhua criticized the United States today for having dispatched marines to the Dominican Republic. In a broadcast heard here, it said: "The new intervention on the part of the United States, which came at a moment when United States imperialism was wildly extending its aggression in Vietnam, threw further light on its hideous feature as the international gendarme."

MEMBERS of the United States Coast Guard Auxiliary have been in the city this week, holding their annual national conference. The nature of their business has largely been one of communication, meaning the leadership operations on the highest level of this nationwide organization by various district commodores, and also one of education.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 29 -- The manager of the American-owned Singer Company was detained in his office for two and a half hours this morning by the Indonesian police when he refused to hand the building keys to a group of employes who announced they had seized the concern.

Seismic waves from the earthquake on the West Coast yesterday sped across the continent in minutes and were recorded here at a magnitude of 6.5 to 7 on the Richter scale. The figures marked the disturbance as a major earthquake.

In London there is a frightfully fashionable little discotheque called the Ad Lib that is patronized by, among others, Rudolf Nureyev, Sybil Burton, Ringo Starr, the hippies from Queen Magazine and a dozen tiny St. Trinian belles who all look like Wendy Cook.
QUANTICO, Va., April 29 -- Billy Mills, the Marine Corps lieutenant who captured the 10,000-meter run last October, won a battle today but may have lost a war.
Although Hans Werner Henze is a highly regarded opera composer in Europe, it was not until last night that one of his operas was produced in this country.

The case of George Whitmore Jr., charged with murder, was placed in the hands of a jury before noon yesterday after a 90-minute charge by Supreme Court Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi in Brooklyn. After deliberating for 11 and a half hours, the case was adjourned until 10 A.M. today.
Pope Paul VI will present a special message to the people of the United States in a live trans-Atlantic television program Monday on the National Broadcasting Company network.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- The Stanley Cup remains unpacked in the lobby of Chicago Stadium.

LONDON, April 29 -- The Government announced today further tightening of the credit valves in a move aimed at supplying additional evidence to foreign bankers that tough deflationary policies are being followed.
NEWARK, April 29 -- The public relations director of the Newark Police Department has since 1960 been on the payroll of a vending machine company run by the reputed boss of the New Jersey underworld.

MILWAUKEE, April 29 (APi -- A throwing error by Curl Flood and a wild pitch by Curt Simmons helped the l[ilwaukee Braves score two fifthinning runs tonight and they posted a 4-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Houghton Mifflin will publish on May 11 "Emergent Africa," by Scipio. This is a new work, not something left by Scipio Africanus Major, the conqueror of Hannibal. The publishing concern advises that Scipio is a pseudonym for a European expert in African affairs.

Mayor Wagner yesterday issued the proclamation that sanctions the use of Greenwich Village streets for the semiannual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit, but, in return, the show will have to produce a financial statement by May 31.

FOR the sedentary, one of the easiest ways to see the World's Fair is by television. There's no standing in line, no weather worries nor the problem of where to sit. Last night, the American Broadcasting Company presented its tour of the fair and, in doing so, performed a service -- the special was a guide on pavilions to avoid.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- A special committee of business, academic and government economists that has spent two years studying balance-of-payments statistics of the United States asserted today that the figures had greatly exaggerated the deficit in recent years.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Harlem, said last night that, "with the proper backing," he would seriously consider running against Mayor Wagner in the Democratic primary for the nomination for Mayor.

CAIRO, April 30 -- Presidem Tito of Yugoslavia and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic urged today an immediate end to American air raids against North Vietnam and renewed a call for negotiations "between the parties concerned" to end the conflict in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana, who opposed last year's program of medical care for the aged, now seems to be moving toward the Administration camp on the issue.

QUINCY, Ill., April 30 (AP) -- The Mississippi flood crest swirled toward Burlington, Iowa, and the already submerged town of Gulfport, Ill., across the river, today. The record flood has caused damage between Dubuque, Iowa, and Hannibal, Mo., estimated at $10 million by the Army Engineers.
The United States passed Britain last year in the number of books published, according to statistics gathered for "The Bowker Annual of Library and Book Trade Information" now being distributed.
ALBANY, April 30 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller today reappointed Ira M. Ball of New Hartford as a member and chairman of the state Bingo Control Commission.
The Renaissance Chorus, directed by Harold Brown, gave an interesting and technically accomplished recital of unaccompanied choral works at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

THE B.B.C. Symphony Orchestra is one of Europe's finest, and last night it made its New York debut at Carnegie Hall in the first of six concerts devoted to 20th-century music. But only a small audience turned out.

CHICKEN mit noodles, seven sweets and seven sours, Dutch salad, homemade potato bread and shoofly pie make up a highly unlikely luncheon menu for most of today's weight-conscious, calorie-counting suburban matrons.
Prices for copper futures soared yesterday in active trading on the New York Commodity Exchange.
Following in the text of President Johnson's televised remarks last night on the Dominican situation, as recorded by The New York Times:
CHICAGO, April 30 -- Rightwing leaders, many avowedly segregationist, backed away today from proclaiming a new third party. Instead a committee was formed to talk about it.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 -- The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, now engaged in an $80 million expansion program, may increase the total beyond previously announced plans, shareholders were told at the annual meeting today.
The case of George Whitmore Jr., charged with the knife-slaying of a Brooklyn woman, was declared a mistrial last night after the jury reported itself "hopelessly deadlocked."
The pervasive computer swung into action this week in New York and came up with 86 alleged bookmakers.
A group of direct mail companies and the union representing their employes reached agreement yesterday on a one-year contract.
The special study of the balance-of-payments problem conducted for the Bureau of the Budget has divided economists into two schools of thought. Neither of the schools favors the present system.

The third annual edition of the "Program Guide to Summer Activities for Teenagers," issued by the New York City Youth Board, is now available. The 38-page booklet provides suggestions for sightseeing excursions in the city, weekend camping and boating trips, job opportunities and various ways to make constructive use of leisure time.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Jim (Mudcat) Grant hurled a three-hitter tonight as the Minnesota Twins stopped the Chicago White Sox five-game winning streak with a 7-0 victory.
SEATTLE, April 30 (AP) -- Damage in the state of Washington from a 45-second earthquake yesterday morning was estimated at $12.5 million today.
The establishment of the State of Israel on May 5, 1948, will be commemorated today by Jewish communities throughout the nation.
From annual reports and meetings, stockholders can often get a free and valuable education in economics.

A three-man committee has been formed by Chief Consolidated Mining Company to study the feasibility of modifying the company's capital structure by setting up a single class of stock to replace the present common and preferred shares, Thomas V. Tozzi, president, announced yesterday.

SIR FREDERICK ASHTON'S "The Dream," a dance version of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," was given its first New York performance last night by the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House.

" TAP" was red-headed and very studious, a friend of college days recalled yesterday in describing William Tapley Bennett Jr., Ambassador to the revolt-town Dominican Republic. "But sort of retiring," the friend said.
The stock market focused on sulphur issues again as traders uncertainly pieced together reports on Mexico's new sulphur export restrictions.

The surprising thing about David Diamond's excellent Piano Trio, which was played last night by the Beaux Arts Trio in Hunter College Playhouse, is that it had never before been given in New York. It dates back to 1951, but the local premiere is in honor of the composer's 50th birthday, which falls on July 9.
ALBANY, April 30 -- A bill extending the life of the State Investigation Commission for two years was approved by Governor Rockefeller today.
Mayor Wagner's special taxicab labor panel has made generally sound proposals for resolving the controversy over union representation that led to the one-day strike of New York's taxis last month.

CLEVELAND, April 30 (UPI) -- A $500,000 gift to establish a professorship at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration has been made by the Weatherhead Foundation, it was announced yesterday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 30 -- President Jomo Kenyatta won the resounding approval of Parliament today to take over the Lumumba Institute, a center of Communist indoctrination that opened here barely five weeks ago.
A recurring bidding problem arises with a hand of the following type:
WASHINGTON, April 30 Representative William Fitts Ryan urged the head of the Federal Antipoverty program today to force Mayor Wagner to modify New York City's plan of administering the program there.

KANSAS CITY, April 30 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels scored three runs in the fourth inning tonight and defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 4-0, behind the seven-hit pitching of Marcelino Lopez and Bob Lee.
ATHENS, April 30 -- Greece warned today that a new flare-up was likely in Cyprus if construction of a strategic road Turkish Cypriotes was not halted near Kyrenia.

ZADAR, Yugoslavia, April 30 -- The Zadar District Court today pronounced Mihajlo Mihajlov guilty of having offended the Soviet Union in his article "Moscow Summer, 1964." He was sentenced to nine months in prison.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering to stockholders of rights to subscribe for $18,364,300 of 25-year convertible debentures.

About 350 mystery-story writers put down their knives, forks and pseudonyms at the Astor Hotel and listened last night as "The Spy Who Came in From the Cold" was announced as the best mystery novel of 1964.
The American Tobacco Company and the Consolidated Foods Corporation have called off merger talks because of "practical difficulties."
AUSTIN, Tex., April 30 (UPI) -- Randy Matson, Texas A. and M.'s giant sophomore, put the shot 69 feet 3/4 inch today to shatter his own world record .
The B.B.C. Symphony Orchestra, Pierre Boulez conducting, with Heather Harper, soprano, performs 20th-century music in Carnegie Hall tonight fat 8:30.

When President Tito two months ago permitted publication of his furious attack on the young scholar Mihajlo Mihajlov for his essay "Moscow Summer 1964" it was reasonable to assume that dire consequences would follow. The Yugoslav President had assailed the Public Prosecutor for not having moved quickly to indict Mr. Mihajlov, whom Tito called a "reactionary" and whom he linked with the imprisoned Milovan Djilas.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 29 (AP) -- Tom Draper, a 50-year-old chemical salesman from Birmingham, Mich., and 26-year-old Don Allen, a Rochester, N.Y. insurance man, scored impressive semi-final victories today in the North and South amateur golf tournament.
FAIRMONT, W. Va., April 30 (UPI) -- An explosion ripped through an air shaft being constructed at a coal mine near here tonight, killing four men and injuring a fifth.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, April 29 -- President Alfredo Stroessner, Paraguay's strongman, said today that the Dominican crisis revealed the "permanent danger" from revolutionary Communism in Latin America.
The City Gardens Club has arranged a tour of six home gardens and penthouse terraces for Tuesday afternoon and six more for the following Tuesday, May 11.

PALO ALTO, Calif., April 30 -- The Stanford University administration has made known its determination to stand firmly behind the Stanford chapter of Sigma Chi in a fight to rid the national fraternity of de facto discrimination.
NEWARK, April 30 -- The County Prosecutor has given Newark's police director the names of 14 policemen accused of neglect of duty in a gambling investigation.
Thirteen youths received summonses for disorderly conduct last night after a free-for-all disrupted art around-Manhattan discotheque cruise sponsored by a college club.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices was unchanged at 101.6 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended April 27, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products declined in price, while processed foods advanced.

PARIS, April 30 -- The ad men gathered in Paris for the 17th World Congress of International Advertising Association. They rounded off three days of telling each other what ought to be done today by announcing a list of awards to those who had done it -- in the best and brightest way -- during the last year.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 30 -- Santa Barbara County Superior Court Judge W. Preston Butcher ordered the Santa Barbara Board of Education today to desist from forcing students in its jurisdiction to recite the pledge of allegiance to the flag if they objected on grounds of violation of conscience.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Gen. Wallace M. Greene Jr., commandant of the Marine Corps, exuded optimism today over the military prospects in Vietnam, although he said "the situation looks pretty serious."
NEWARK, April 30 (AP) -- A tale of confusion, terror, panic and chaotic rebel gunfire was recounted today by five New Jerseyans evacuated from Santo Domingo.
Montclair, Piping Rock and Apawamis, all district champions, were winners yesterday in the second round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team, matches.

A fruitful transaction between an auto dealer and a housewife in Bristol, Conn., will be closed on Tuesday when the dealer hands the housewife the keys to a 1962 Pontiac Tempest four-door sedan in exchange for 500 pounds of bananas.
At its first Symposium on American Literature, held recently in Washington, the Library of Congress played host to almost a hundred literary magazine editors and educators.

YONKERS, April 30 -- Egyptian Pride, a harness horse who was bred for trotting, started as a pacer, shifted to the trot then went back to the pace, captured tonight's $15,000 invitation handicap one-mile pace at Yonkers Raceway.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 30 -- President Joseph Kasavubu extended the life of Premier Moise Tshombe's provisional Government today.

The Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation has been discussing a possible merger with a number of companies, including the ABC Consolidated Corporation. William Black, chairman of Chock Full, a chain of counter-service restaurants and producer of food products, confirmed that discussions have been held with several companies.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 30 -- The sidewalk in front of 1 Aleksandr Stambolisky Boulevard is packed with people from morning until late at night.

LONDON, April 30 -- The Government announced plans today to renationalize the bulk of the British steel industry and to pay stockholders nearly 30 per cent more than their shares were worth at yesterday's closing prices.
SAIGON, April 30 -- The Armed Forces Council, which has been the unifying force in Vietnamese politics during the many upheavals of the last six months, may disband itself next week.
LOUISVILLE, Ky. April 30 (AP) -- Amerivan won the 91st running of the $48,525 Kentucky Oaks today at Churchill Downs.
Sales of color-television sets are so strong that a "critical shortage" of picture tubes has developed.
VERSAILLES, France, April 30 -- The May Festival opened here last night with a gala performance of Gounod's rarely performed comic opera "Le Medecin Malgre Lui," from Moliere's play.
A fistfight broke out at the World's Fair yesterday between an Arab and a Jew.

EXHIBITIONS of importance continue in full spate as the spring season slopes towards summer. Notable among them are the Justin K. Thannhauser bequest to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum comprising no fewer than 75 outstanding paintings, drawings and pieces of sculpture by masters of the late 19th-century and early 20th-century School of Paris.

Jack Elliott, a folk singer whose stature and influence have been strong here and in England for nearly 15 years, gave his first Town Hall Recital last night. About 1,000 persons attended, nearly "filling" the hall with their enthusiastic applause.

The Four Winds Theater Studio, Inc., a local amateur group dedicated to presenting medieval and renaissance productions, last night gave its version of the Ben Jonson masque "The Triumph of Delight" at the Manhattan School of Music.

ROME, April 30 -- Pope Paul VI appealed today for the prayers of the faithful and for conciliatory action by world leaders at a moment when "grave new threats are endangering the supreme benefit of world peace."
Johnny Keane got his first look at the Baltimore Orioles from the front trenches of Yankee Stadium last night and discovered to his horror that everything he had heard about them was true.
What it's like to fly off the roof of a 59-story skyscraper was demonstrated yesterday by New York Airways. And those who took the ride agreed it was like nothing else.
A Columbia University economist suggested yesterday the investment community might develop "new indicators" to detect speculative excesses in market prices of blue-chip stocks.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- An inquiry that opened before Easter amid loud charges of "political patronage" in the antipoverty program dragged to a quiet ending today in a nearly deserted committee chamber.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. April 30 -- Steering the ball carefully through a 20-mile-an-hour desert wind, Arnold Palmer held the 36-hole lead in the Tournament of Champions today. With a 69 on a par-72 Desert Inn Country Club course, Palmer brought his total to 135.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has submitted to the Justice Department a proposed settlement of a Government antitrust suit brought against it.

VOGUE, the fashion magazine that chronicles the allegedly "beautiful people," has been searching for pulchritude at Radcliffe, the college whose students are rumored to be the brainiest girls in the country.

NEW DELHI, April 30 -- Sir Morrice James, British High Commissioner in Pakistan, flew here today for consultations with John Freeman, British High Commissioner in India, on the conflict between the two countries in Cutch.
ATLANTA, April 30 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and James Forman an nounced today that their organizations would begin working closer together on civil rights projects.

A novel about men of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics on guard along the Mexican border, "Fruit of the Poppy," by Robert Wilder, will be issued by Putnam's on Friday. The story also concerns their counterparts in Mexico. The antagonists of both these law forces are the gangs seeking to smuggle opium into the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon told Congress today his office knows of, and usually is able to cope with, what he termed underworld groups that try to get control of banks.
A 42-year-old midtown jeweler was accused yesterday of meticulously planning and rehearsing a $500,000 jewelry stickup with two accomplices.

The nine-day hearing into the application of Mark Fein for a new murder trial ended yesterday with summations in which prosecution and defense lawyers accused each other of making misleading statements.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 30 -- Indonesia signed a contract today to buy two four-engine DC-8 jetliners from the Douglas Aircraft Company of Long Beach, Calif.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 30 (AP) -- Apparently fearing the specter of American intervention, Latin Americans reacted angrily today to the landing of United States forces in the Dominican Republic.
Your April 24 editorial "Armenia Remembers" was greatly appreciated. At long last I was able to read current editorial comment on the tragic events which engulfed my parents and relatives.
Three oil stocks accounted for a good portion of the heavy trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the market ended mixed.
MADRID, April 30 (UPI) -- Former Senator Barry Goldwater said today that he approved of President Johnson's decision to send the Marines into Santo Domingo.
Six of Charlie Chaplin's best-known feature films are about to be made available for general theater booking in the United States and Canada for the first time in many years.

The official union tellers have now certified I.W. Abel as victor in the tense contest for the presidency of the United Steelworkers of America. The closeness of the result -- a margin of 10,000 votes in a 600,000 total -- has already brought notice from the defeated incumbent, David J. McDonald, that he intends to file a formal challenge with the union's executive board.

The latest volume on the thorny and somewhat esoteric problems in the United States balance of payments bears an imposing title: "The Balance of Payments Statistics of the United States: A Review and Appraisal."
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson helped plant a 20-foot red oak today, and the Arbor Day ceremony blocked off a key downtown street for two hours during the morning rush period.

There is so much else that is sound in the report of Governor Rockefeller's Committee on Welfare Costs that it is surprising that it voted -- even if only by a 3-to-2 margin -- for a one-year residence requirement for recipients of state welfare aid.
A panel appointed by Mayor Wagner recommended yesterday that taxicab workers be allowed to vote in a citywide election to determine whether they want to be represented by a new union.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 -- In Hollywood's version of the Kentucky Derby, the hero is a colt from the wrong side of the track who is ridden by a 14-year-old farm boy named Red. At the head of the stretch, Red whistles "Dixie" in his mount's ear, and the hero storms to victory over the impeccably bred aristocrat.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 30 (Reuters) -- Jacques Nevard, Pakistan correspondent of The New York Times, was acquitted today on a contempt-of-court charge brought by Capt. Gohar Ayub Khan, son of President Mohammad Ayub Khan.
ROME, April 30 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the encyclical letter issued by Pope Paul VI today, as translated from the Latin by the Vatican:

The Del E. Webb Corporation, real estate and construction concern, reported yesterday a sharp drop in earnings for the first quarter to $143,734, or 2 cents a share, from $1,055,054, or 16 cents a share, in the 1964 period.

The protection of the city's greenery was urged yesterday in a tree-planting ceremony that paid tribute to George Washington and observed the opening of City Parks Week by the Park Association of New York City.

LONDON, April 30 -- XYZ, Inc., pays a 48 per cent United States income tax on its profits. Its stockholders pay income taxes on the dividends they receive. XYZ, Ltd., under Britain's new tax reform measures, will pay no more than a 40 per cent profits tax. In addition, it will pay the income tax for its stockholders on the dividends it distributes.

The railroad industry hauled 667.2 million ton miles of freight last year. This was a 6 per cent gain over 1963 and the greatest volume since 1945, but the carriers still experienced a small dip in their share of the over-all traffic, according to preliminary figures compiled by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Johnson made the decision to send marines into the Dominican Republic Wednesday after a warning from the United States Ambassador, W. Tapley Bennett Jr., that without such troops American lives would probably be lost.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 -- The international tellers of the United Steelworkers of America declared today that I.W. Abel had been elected the union's next president by a narrow margin. David J. McDonald, the incumbent, announced that he would go before the union's executive board to contest the tellers' report.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 (UPI) -- McGeorge Bundy, a Presidential adviser, and a group of professors from Washington University have lectured each other in an exchange over United States policy in Vietnam and Mr. Bundy's rejection of an invitation to address the group.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- President Johnson announced tonight his hurried signing of a $2.2 billion supplemental appropriations bill to prevent delays in the payment of welfare checks to hundreds of thousands of persons.
LONDON, April 30 (Reuters) -- A young Malayan belly dancer became a peeress today with the death of Lord Moynihan, a former chairman of Britain's Liberal party.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 30 (AP) -- Nan Merriman, American mezzo-soprano, said Wednesday night that she had performed for the last time, ending a 25-year career.
Mayor Wagner has now carried the argument for transit unification in the metropolitan area one step beyond the concept usually advanced.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 -- Front-running bettors got off to an early start today in the wagering on tomorrow's 91st Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs. But the late surge at the windows tomorrow will determine the odds on the 11-horse field.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 30 -- Cuba called on Secretary General Thant today to take action through United Nations bodies against "the monstrous fact of the invasion of the Dominican Republic and the military occupation of that country that is being prepared."

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor endorsed legislation today for Government regulation of the packaging and labeling of food and other household products, but industry witnesses said that it would increase prices.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 30 -- A man who resigned from the British delegation to the United Nations in protest against the former Conservative Government's policy on Rhodesia rose today in the Security Council to defend the Labor Government's modification of the policy.
The constitutionality of the voting power of Westchester County's Board of Supervisors was challenged yesterday by two Westchester residents in a suit filed in Federal Court here.

AUBURN, Ala., April 30 -- With his crewcut hair and Madras sports shirt, Thomas Justin Millican Jr. looks pretty much like any other undergraduate on the quiet, shaded campus of Auburn University here.
Prices on the London stock market recovered briskly yesterday from the setback of Thursday's surprise announcement of new bank-credit restrictions.

The Carter Handicap, which was named for a tugboat captain and which produced the only triple dead heat for first place in American turf history (1944), will have its 65th running today at Aqueduct. With six starters, headed by Mrs. Ehtel D. Jacobs's mare Affectionately, the gross purse will be $55,300.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A leader of the American Council for Judaism termed as "preposterous" today a recent assertion of an Israeli official that Jewish refugees needed persuasion "to want to come to the United States."

HOUSTON, April 30 (AP) -- Two major stockholders of the Pure Oil Company indicated today there might be a proxy fight over the proposed merger agreement between Pure and the Union Oil Company of Califormia.

Not a single nation is truly supporting United States aggression in Vietnam. Most of the world knows the truth that Washington has tried to conceal from United States citizens: the Government of South Vietnam is a feeble and illegitimate puppet of our own creation.
THIS IS one of the boldest novels of the year. Why? Because it gets along without pornography in the parlor and perversion at the bar. It is in advance of the advance guardees.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 30 (UPI) -- Gov. George C. Wallace sent invitations today to editors of more than 1,700 daily newspapers across the country to visit Alabama in June to get "the true Alabama story."

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced today the award of contracts totaling $52 million to the General Electric Company and Allmanna Svenska Electriska Aktiebolaget, a Swedish concern, for work on the Pacific Northwest-Pacific Northwest-Pacific Southwest power intertie.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Johnson, who merely intended to congratulate the Treasury Department on its efficiency, turned that agency into the least productive one in Government for about 20 minutes today.
Bond prices closed the week with barely a ripple yesterday as the Treasury's May refunding offer continued to evoke much vigorous market reaction.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 30 -- One United States Marine was killed and at least 12 were wounded in engagements today with Dominican rebel ir regulars. This was reported by official American sources.
New York State expects to open negotiations with the Pennsylvania Railroad next week for acquisition of the Long Island Rail Road.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The House Armed Services Committee asserted its Congressional authority today in its dispute with the Pentagon, then restored most of the $654 million it cut last month from defense budget requests.

The General Dynamics Corporation reported yesterday that earnings for the first quarter of 1965 dipped slightly to about $7.1 million, or 59 cents a share, from $7.3 million, or 61 cents a share, a year ago.

HOUSTON, April 30 (AP) -- Joe Gaines's two-run pinch homer and Al Spangler's sacrifice fly following Joe Morgan's second triple of the game in the eighth inning gave the Houston Astros a 4-3 victory tonight over the Chicago Cubs.
Officers on the 22-ship tanker fleet of the Gulf Oil Corporation have rejected an organization bid by the Brotherhood of Marine Officers by a seven-to-one margin.

I have just read in The Times of April 13 Anthony Lewis's news article about electricity in London. The situation in Texas is equally confusing to an Englishman. I live in an apartment house with two separate supplies of electricity -- one at 120 volts, the other at 230 volts.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A $3 million Federal grant that will keep the New Haven Railroad's commuter service in temporary operation is scheduled for approval here within the next two weeks.

NORFOLK, Va., April 30 -- Adm. Thomas Hinman Moorer relieved Adm. Harold Page Smith today as Supreme Allied Commander, Atlantic, of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization; United States unified Commander in Chief, Atlantic, and Commander in Chief of the Atlantic Fleet.
Brooklyn Heights, settled in 1634 and a genteel, well-heeled semisuburb since 1820, was designated yesterday a registered National Historic Landmark by the United States Department of Interior.

James Reston in his pounding [April 21] of the "teach-ins" on Vietnam, asks us to believe that the teach-in audiences were: duped into attending; misinformed about conditions by equally misinformed spokesmen, and denied opportunities for rebuttal.
LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- Britain defeated Israel and Yugoslavia completed a sweep of Morocco in European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition today as first-round matches were played in a dozen cities.
The regional manager of a food company in the Chicago area was offered a new job recently in another part of the state with a $2,000 salary increase in a region with a lower cost of living.
The stage of the Paramount Theater, no stranger to rock 'n' roll, rose from the pit with another type of musician yesterday. A troupe of 26 country musicians began a week's run of four shows a day.
THE spirit of the industrious Shakers was at work all winter in the Shaker Museum in Old Chatham, N.Y.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell said yesterday that he would not pay a $52,000 defamation judgment until all related civil suits against him were dropped.

The civil contempt conviction of Salvatore Bonanno for refusing to answer two questions before a Federal grand jury investigating the disappearance of his father, Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, reputed Mafia leader, was unanimously upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Senate liberals of both parties reserved judgment today on a substitute voting rights bill that had been framed to attract their support.

P.R. Mallory and Company has announced the election of Samuel R. Sutphin and Frank E. Conant as directors. Mr. Sutphin is chairman of the Beveridge Paper Company. Mr. Conant is vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

BUENOS AIRES, April 30 -- The Foreign Minister declared today that, while Argentina maintained her traditional defense of the principle of nonintervention, she was not prepared to accept a situation where "those who intervene complain afterward against those who react against their intervention."
SYDNEY, Australia, April 30 -- Most Australians today swung behind the Government's decision to send a battalion of troops to fight the Vietcong although there were strong dissenting voices.

BURLINGTON, Vt., April 30 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Lester Pearson of Canada affirmed today his nation's basic support of United States foreign policy. But he warned that Canadians would worry about and sometimes disagree with the implementation of this policy.
A select group of show people met at the Friars yesterday on behalf of a cause, although the cause managed to get lost in the conversation.

The Swedish American Line has announced the appointment of Philip C. Peterson as passenger traffic manager, succeeding Earnest B. Bearnarth, who has retired. Mr. Bearnarth, who reached the mandatory retirement age of 65, had been a vice president.

TUNIS, April 30 (AP) -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia has asked President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic to meet with him in an attempt to settle their bitter dispute over Arab policy toward Israel.
LONDON, April 30 -- Lady Churchill, Sir Winston's widow, is to become a life peeress.

John W. Beal's letter in the April 24 Times defending the location of a Consolidated Edison power plant at Storm King Mountain misses the important issues raised by such controversies. The points he makes are frequently advanced in similar instances across the country, and their importance therefore transcends that of Storm King Mountain alone.

OTTAWA, April 30 (AP) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway showed increases in almost all categories during 1964 but it still accumulated an operating loss, the seaway authority's annual report showed today. The season was the longest since the seaway opened in 1959.
The Board of Education's $40 million school improvement and integration program has won the enthusiastic endorsement of Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education.
A company interested in accepting a corporate marriage offer ran into some criticism from its stockholder family yesterday about the cash in the dowry.

QUANTICO, Va., April 30 -- Georgetown and Villanova won two of the three feature races today as the ninth annual Marine Corps schools relays began. The third big race, expected to be a duel between those two track powers, turned into a runaway in record time for the host Quantico Marines.
Preliminary calculations by some weather specialists have convinced them that the introduction of commercial supersonic air travel may bring about substantial climate changes.
PARIS, April 30 -- Andrei A. Gromyko said today that his week's discussions with French officials marked a "turning point" in French-Soviet relations.
The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday granted the financially troubled Yale Express System, Inc., a six-day extesion on the filing date for its annual report.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- Following, as made public by the State Department today, is an additional list of Americans from the New York-New Jersey area evacuated from the Dominican Republic:

CINCINNATI, April 30 -- The New York Mets, who have proved countless times that they can beat themselves, got unnecessary and unwelcome help from the umpires tonight as they lost to the Cincinnati Reds, 6 -- 1, and took sole possession of last place for the first time this year.
The British pound declined yesterday following news that the Government was planning to nationalize the bulk of the country's steel industry.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Johnson announced tonight that a cease-fire plan put forward by the Papal Nuncio had been agreed upon in principle in the Dominican Republic, but that fighting was still going on.
TOKYO, Saturday, May 1 (UPI) -- Communist China welcomed 39 foreign delegations to May Day celebrations in Peking today with boasts of its new nuclear power.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Cavitron Ultrasonics, Inc., of New York, has developed a process capable of driving a toothpick into a solid block of plastic. More important for industrial purposes is its ability to insert screws without first drilling holes.
The advent of more seasonal weather and the peaking of the Easter season in mid-April provided New York City department stores with an 8 per cent sales increase in the month.

Leading medical educators questioned yesterday whether President Johnson's Commission on Heart Disease, Cancer and Stroke had provided a workable apparatus for transmitting better medical care to the community in its report on the problem issued last December.

PATERSON, N.J., April 30 -- Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, facing possible defeat because of a deep cut in the flesh above his left eye, knocked out Johnny Torres tonight with a smashing left hook to the chin in the Paterson Armory.

The big guns were rolled out last night at the $15,000 professional indoor tennis tournament and form prevailed as Ken Rosewall and Rod Laver, seeded No. 1 and No. 2, respectively, scored victories to gain the semi-final round.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 (UPI) -- Vernon Law had a one-hitter with two out in the seventh inning tonight until errors by Dick Schofield and Gene Alley and hits by Bill White and Phil Gagliano gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 30 -- A 29-year-old Olympic cyclist was working out two weeks ago on the Jericho Turnpike when a truck horn sounded behind him.
GENEVA, April 30 -- The Swiss Government disclosed today that an East German and a Swiss have been under arrest since November on an espionage charge.
WARSAW, May 1 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka bitterly accused the United States in a May Day speech today of having "become the policeman of colonialism" through its policies in Vietnam.
The over-the-counter market continued to make good gains last week in active trading.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The fear of "another Cuba" has been the main inspiration for the Johnson Administration's responses to the rebellion in the Dominican Republic.

LES OUADHIAS, Algeria, April 26 -- One hundred thirty Soviet technicians arriver here yesterday to put new life into Algeria's showcase for her sagging "socialist voluntary work" movement.

STANTON, Del., May 1 -- Ch. Nederlan Herman V. Mack, a keeshond owned by Mr. and Mrs. Emerson P. Hempstead of Greenwich, Conn., topped a field of 929 contenders today to win his fourth best-in-show title at the Wilmington Kennel Club's 24th annual event.

CHICAGO -- The fantastic Marina Towers -- those twin buildings shaped like coin changers -- rise 60 stories above the Chicago River. But even the topmost resident can get in his boat by taking the elevator.

ST LOUIS, May 1 (AP) -- Phil Gagliano singled across Bill White in the seventh inning, giving the St. Louis Cardinals a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

SIMPLE tricks will often enable the home handyman to repair minor defects on damaged furniture. The drawings at right illustrate techniques that can be used to help correct three of the more common Problems -- drawers that swell up and stick, blisters that form when veneer lifts, and dents which are left when a heavy object is accidentally dropped on the finished surface.

THE majority of Americans who visit Europe are exposed mainly to its cultural aspects: its architecture, its art treasures, its music, its festivals and pleasure spots. Whatever landscape they manage to see is cultural -- towns, roads, cultivated land, bridges -- all visible from the beaten path.

A distinguished group of scientists convened by the National Academy of Science suggests that this country begin immediately an ambitious program aimed at determining within the next few years whether there is life on Mars. Wells, Edgar Rice Burroughs and other writers who took the existence of Martian life for granted.

Next December France will elect a President by direct balloting for the first time since 1851. Your article "What's All the Shooting For," (April 18) focused on a concern of mine which includes not only the ultimate violence of war, but the lesser evidence s of youthful destructiveness, gang wars, riots, etc.
Congratulations on the article, "Airport Madness" Do keep on working and needling about this matter.

EDITH SITWELL begins her autobiography by quoting Kierkegaard, who in calling himself a two-headed Janus said he laughed with one face and wept with the other. This book has little weeping in it, but a good deal of laughter, some of it crackling with satire.
The Zim Israel Navigation Company of Haifa, Israel's major steamship line, has called a temporary halt to its fleet expansion program.

Great sighs of relief were aspirated in Pittsburgh, Washington, Wall Street and corporate suites last week when steel union and management negotiators found a formula for deferring a threatened strike in that key industry.

A tea dance will be held on Thursday in the Sheraton-East's ballroom to mark the 73d anniversary of the Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York was instrumental last year in establishing a new steamship line communications system that could link the New York offices of major companies with their offices in other East Coast port cities at reduced rates.

ANOTHER stay of execution has been granted to the showing of motion pictures on international flights. The deadline on the proposed ban on films on other than domestic runs has been extended by the International Air Transport Association from its original one of last Tuesday to June 9.

I am a subscriber to a weekly magazine published in Communist China. On several occasions in the past I have informed the Post Office Department that I wanted this publication delivered to me. Presumably my name was entered on a list and the list furnished to the F.B.I. and the House Un-American Activities Committee.
TUNIS, May 1 -- A two-month course on the theater, claimed to be the first of its kind, will begin today in Tunisia's International Cultural Center at Hammamet.

Mr. Gielgud, currently appearing in "Tiny Alice," recently delivered an address to the graduating class of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in which he offered advice and reflections on his own career.

On the other hand, he arrives with a flourish of trumpets. His novel is not merely a novel, but the first of a trilogy, which has "created great international excitement."

The Johnson Administration has been carrying on two dialogues in its efforts to deal with the Vietnam crisis. One dialogue is with the Communists and is aimed at opening the door to a negotiated settlement. The other is with critics at home over the wisdom of U.S. policy in Vietnam.

NEW DELHI, May 1 -- Not since the days of King Canute have so many people awaited the results of inexorably rising tides as this week in the desolate wasteland of burning desert and salt marsh known as the Rann of Cutch.

In New York City, Council President Paul R. Screvanel serves as chairman of the Antipoverty Operations Board. His salary as Council President is $35,000 a year, and he receives no extra compensation for the antipoverty post.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 1 -- A heavily favored Harvard varsity eight turned in a record-smashing performance this afternoon in sweeping to victory over the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the 29th Compton Cup regatta.

WASHINGTON -- May 1 -- President Johnson has ordered that American food and medical assistance be given to the people of the revolt-torn Dominican Republic, and today he received a report on what bad been done so far.

SIR FREDERICK ASHTON'S investment of the Royal Ballet's talents, production funds and prestige in Kenneth MacMillan's "Romeo and Juliet" rather than his own was an atypical act in the usually self-centered world of dance.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 -- The race is on for one of the nation's biggest political prizes -- the governorship of California -- but the entries in the 1966 contest are almost exclusively of the "Well, maybe" or "I'm available if --" variety.

DARIEN, Conn. -- Dr. Gregory C. Coffin, Superintendent of Schools here, said this week that a recent integrated teacher-exchange program with New York City had been so successful that he hoped to expand the project next year.
Two university presidents last week reacted to what has come to be known as the student revolt.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 -- In the Churchill Downs stable area today, an hour after the 91st running of the Kentucky Derby, a smiling 21-year-old groom led a 3-year-old bay colt toward Barn No. 24.

SALEM, N.H. -- A large Plexiglas drum containing 333,334 tickets will be rotated next Thursday at Rockingham Park, the state's only thoroughbred racing track, thus setting into motion the first drawing for New Hampshire's 1965 Sweepstakes.

Many of the serious earthquakes of this century have occurred in the perimeter of the Pacific, from Alaska to Chile and New Zealand to Japan. Within this wide area exists an ever-present potential for disaster. Only last month a devastating earthquake struck Chile; in 1960 an earthquake there killed 5,700 persons.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 -- A group of student editors in the Harvard University community plans to establish an independent newspaper to report civil rights activities in the South.

The first of five regional training sessions for New York police personnel charged with enforcing the state's navigation law will be held Wednesday and Thursday at the Village Hall in Perry, N.Y.

Vince Parlegreco, one of Florida's leading boat racing drivers, scored triumphs in four straight heats and took second place in another to capture top honors in the Miami Outboard Club's second Snowbird Regatta April 25.

FOR THIS WEEK: Fruit tree spraying has begun, consult state agricultural extension bulletins and follow the schedules exactly. . . . Young shoots called suckers sprout from the base of maple, magnolia and fruit trees; prune them out now. . . .
DARIEN, Conn., May 1 -- The first arrests were made here last night under a two-week-old ordinance prohibiting teen-agers from drinking or possessing alcoholic beverages on town property.

PARIS, April 16 -- With 50 legitimate stages for 5.5 million Parisians, everyone agrees that some of them will have to go, but no one sees eye to eye with anyone else about which. And this week, the news that no fewer than four of the city's theaters are threatened, has revived an old controversy.

TORONTO, May 1 -- The Government, in an attempt to preserve the national identity of Canadian publications, is planning to impose restrictions on foreign publishers.

EDINBURGH -- This city is famous for many things, but least of all for a tiny museum off the Royal Mile. It is the Museum of Childhood, which is dedicated to bringing back to adults the memories of years past.

DALLAS, May 1 (AP) -- Eighteen-year-old Cliff Richey whipped Ramanathan Krishnan of India, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3, today to gain the final of the Dallas Country Club tennis tournament.

Formal gowns for graduations, weddings and proms are being ordered, resident buying offices report. As in past seasons, pastel shades are most popular.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 1 -- United States troops pushed across the Ozama River bridge into a rebel-held downtown area here today as all sides were reported striving to put a cease-fire agreement into effect.

CONSIDERING all of Igor Stravinsky's activities in the recording studios on his own behalf during the last 35 years, it is surprising that he has never recorded the complete version of L'Histoire du Soldat.

CINCINNATI, May 1 -- Putting the New York Mets and their pitching staff in its present condition into little Crosley Field with the wind blowing out and Cincinnati players allowed to carry bats is like locking an unarmed Boy Scout in a telephone booth with an emotionally disturbed puma.

A TWO-DAY plant sale to benefit the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will take place Wednesday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. and Thursday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. in the Main Building Rotunda and the Greenhouse Courtyard. CINCINNATI, May 2 -- Jack Fisher of the New York Mets pitched the Cincinnati Reds into first place in the National League today.
A 52-year-old blind man was shot and critically wounded by a holdup man in his Harlem apartment last night, the police reported.

HOUSTON, May 2 (AP) -- Larry Jackson started a four-run, third-inning burst with a triple and, with help from Ted Abernathy, pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 6-3 victory today over the Houston Astro, snapping the Astros' winning streak at 10 games.

THE 1965 World Championship, which begins in Buenos Aires on May 15, will be remarkable in one respect. For the first time in such an event, the users of artificial systems will outnumber the users of standard natural systems.

A month-old picket line of the National Maritime Union against two towboat companies has been extended from Pittsburgh to facilities in Louisiana, Delaware, Tennessee. Illinois and Washington, the union announced yesterday.

TUNIS, May 2 -- President Habib Bourguiba accused President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic today of trying to become the dictator of the Arab world.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., May 2 -A thorough overhaul of state judicial systems across the nation was asked today by the 27th American Assembly of Columbia University.

The Community Church of The New York yesterday celebrated Wesak Sunday, commemorating the birthday of the Buddha. A bust of the Buddha stood in front of the pulpit and two vases of flowers stood on the sides.

The eyes of the collegiate lacrosse world will focus Saturday on Baltimore, where the East's two undefeated teams, Navy and Johns Hopkins, are scheduled to meet. A crowd of 10,000 is expected.

United States copper companies with mines in Chile were kept busy over the weekend informing their customers of that country's latest move on copper prices. On Saturday, the Chilean government raised the price of its copper exports 1 cent, to 36 cents a pound, effective immediately.

COPENHAGEN, May 2 -Denmark is still suffering from severe inflation. A new price index has been released showing an increase of 1.9 per cent above the January figures. WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Defense officials do not like the terminology, but they readily concede that Vietnam has given the United States armed forces a "laboratory for war."
LISBON, May 2 -- The West German Defense Minister left today after talks with Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar and a visit to a German jet training base under construction in southern Portugal.

The first link in a worldwide live television system was opened yesterday afternoon as the Early Bird satellite united millions of North American and European viewers in a cultural, educational and journalistic exchange on the home screen.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Mr. Bosch said today that the Dominican revolt had been won until the United States intervened, so that it was now Washington's responsibility to bring democracy to his country.
LIMA, Peru, May 2 -- W. Averell Harriman, President Johnson's Ambassador at Large, arrived here today on a mission to obtain Latin American support for United States policy in the Dominican Republic.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 2 -- Representative Richard L. Ottinger, whose invitation to address Loyalty Day exercises was withdrawn, then restored by the Veterans of Foreign Wars, delivered the speech today and declared:

The following is a supplementary list of over-the-counter stocks prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. It consists of securities less widely held or those that, or other reasons, do not appear on the daily Over-the-Counter list. Bids are inter-dealer prices and do not include retail markdown or commission. Asked prices have been adjusted upward to include approximate markup.
JEFFERSON, Tex., May 2 -Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson spent this weekend moving backward in time.

MILWAUKEE, May 2 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies ended a slump today by sweeping a double-header from the Milwaukee Braves, 6-0 and 10-7. Chris Short won a seven-hitter in the opener and Jack Baldschun contributed a brilliant relief job in the second game.

LONDON, May 2 -- "Television has indeed come of age and we have this evening been part of its celebration party," Brian Connell of the Independent Television Authority told British viewers of the Early Bird program tonight.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 2 -- This is a city at war with itself.
Mrs. Ann M. Roberts says her first six months on the job as staff direction have convinced her that the city's antipoverty program is on target in its efforts to help the poor.
The annual fund-raising fete for Just One Break, Inc., will be a May Festival Ball on May 20 in the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 (UPI) -- Tommy Davis, the Los Angeles Dodger outfielder, will probably make a "complete recovery" from a leg fracture, but will not be able to play ball for at least three months, Dr. Robert Kerlan said today.

Ratification by unionized printers and photoengravers of their new contracts with the city's major newspapers, coupled with tentative agreements already reached in several other crafts, provides a hope for two years of peace between the papers and the ten unions with which they deal. But, apart from the assurance of uninterrupted news flow to millions of New Yorkers, there is little to cheer about in the new agreements.

Louis Danto, a tenor who was born in Russia and made his local debut in 1961, sang a program at Town Hall last night that proved him a skilled belcanto vocalist. Mr. Danto is also a cantor at the Atlantic Beach (L.I.) Jewish Center.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., May 2 -- For a hundred years or more now, this Black Belt county seat has lain sleeping under the Alabama sun. Much of the rich, red earth that produced cotton for Northern mills has gone over to cattle pasture, but in the shady courthouse square, dogs still doze on the board sidewalks, and sunburned deputy sheriffs with worn leather holsters at the hips squint suspiciously at strangers.

SHOES are to Italy what blue jeans are to the United States, and heaven forfend that even the tiniest toddler miss her share of imported goodies. Bloomingdale's has a fresh crop of espadrilles in sizes 8 to 12 for toddlers, 12 to 4 for older youngsters. In pastel shades of pink and turquoise or pure tones of white, green, red or blue, the shoes come with crepe or soft suede soles with rope trim.

A LOVE of words and a talent for storytelling ought to be helpful in the writing of fiction. Often they are. But a good novel requires much more: the creation or characters interesting in themselves so that their company seems worth keeping for hours or days; and a vision of life dramatized in fictional terms that can inspire respectful attention.
Seventy dock supervisory personnel of the International Terminal Operating Company have completed a 20-hour safety training course conducted by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Standards.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 2 -- W. Averell Harriman said the purpose of his visit here was to contribute to the fullest cooperation between the United States and Colombia in dealing with the problem of the Dominican Republic.

TOKYO, Monday, May 3 (AP) -- A Peking broadcast charged tonight that the Soviet Union had joined the "United States aggressors" in trying to put over a "peace negotiations swindle'' on Vietnam.
ROME, May 2 -- Pope Paul VI, referring to the outbreak of violence in the Dominican Republic, said today that "better news came from Santo Domingo last night, but the equilibrium is not yet secure."

Although George Lawrence's piano recital in Town Hall Saturday night was his New York debut, Mr. Lawrence is no youngster. He is, in fact, a past master of Paramount Lodge, the Masonic organization for whose Nathan M. Hutner Foundation the recital was a benefit.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 2 (UPI) -- The United States Navy ended today the major part of its evacuation of refugees from the Dominican Republic. It brought 1,415 United States and foreign nationals here today, raising the total number evacuated to nearly 3,000.
LONDON -- The split of Europe into two trading blocs is causing increasing concern in the British business community.
Nearly 10,000 workers in the garment district will begin picketing 1,200 companies today in a demand for a wage increase and better jobs for "minority groups."

HAVANA, May 2 -- A violently anti-United States May Day speech by Premier Fidel Castro was rebroadcast all day today, indicating that Cuba is striving to exploit events in the nearby Dominican Republic in effort to attract Latin-American an opinion.

QUINHON, South Vietnam, May 2 -- A solemn-faced Vietnamese girl of about 8 walked slowly, stiffly out of the operating room. In her left hand she clutched a bullet that had just been removed from her body. Politely, holding back tears, she asked for a drink.

ALGIERS, May 2 -- President Ahmed Ben Bella declared today that Mohammed Khider, exiled former party chief, had made off with $12 million in party funds to finance "a desperate political fight," and not for "personal gain."

Sir John Gielgud and Irene Worth, who are playing in New York in "Tiny Alice," paid tribute to T.S. Eliot and Dame Edith Sitwell last night in a memorial program at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue at 92d Street, by giving life to their poetry.
Fire insurance, the most basic of property coverages, grew out of the great London fire of 1666, which wrought $13 million in damages.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, announced today he would introduce antitrust legislation requiring companies planning mergers to notify the Government in advance.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 2 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson charged today that District Attorney William Cahn had attempted to get the assistance of the county police in the commission of a crime.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 2 -- Arnold Palmer ended a long losing streak today by winning the $75,000 Tournament of Champions. Finishing in a desert windstorm with a 71 for a 72-hole total of 277, Palmer secured the victory by two strokes.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 2 -- Chairul Saleh, Third Deputy Premier and a leading opponent of the Indonesian Communist party, has come out openly in favor of Communist demands that "capitalist bureaucrats" be purged from state enterprises.

The Democratic leader of the State Senate charged yesterday that William H. McKeon, Democratic state chairman, was responsible for killing legislation to legalize and tax offtrack betting in New York City.

Customers at the New York Flea Market yesterday poked happily at a century-old, pedal-operated dentists drill ($150, without drills), a 200-year-old Irish harp ($400), a Canadian wall telephone ($45), and a basket made from an armadillo (price unstated).

STONY POINT, N.Y., May 2 Senator Robert F. Kennedy walked along the Hudson River today, near the place where Mad Anthony Wayne surprised the British in a night attack in 1779. After looking at garbage dumps, auto graveyards, dead rats, empty beer cans and a bottle of murky water from the river, he was asked how it all struck him.
PIERRE BOULEZ, composer, conductor and one of the big men of modern music, conducted the second concert of the B.B.C. Symphony contemporary music series on Saturday night in Carnegie Hall.
The New York Public Library is preparing to complete and publish a new "Guide to the Research Collections, through a grant of $40,200 from the Old Dominion Foundation.

Your analysis of "descalation" in Vietnam [editorial April 25] demonstrates unintentionally how difficult it has become to reason clearly about that situation. Fears that a bigger war will come "accidentally" are accordingly increased.
The Columbia Broadcasting System was the only network to carry live on television President Johnson's speech last night on the situation in the Dominican Republic.
ALBANY, May 2 -- A Democratic team of legislative mapmakers, working in shirtsleeves and with little sleep, was striving today to complete a redistricting plan.

A leading Methodist clergyman called yesterday for the United States to abandon "what comes close to being a Messianic complex" in its Vietnamese policy and to channel future aid through the United Nations.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 -- The most famous thoroughbred in the land celebrated his third birthday today, munching on hay and biting at a birthday cake of real sugar. Lucky Debonair, who won yesterday's Kentucky Derby, was the unconcerned center of attention at the Churchill Downs backstretch, where his diminutive trainer, Frank Catrone, accepted congratulations steadily all through the morning.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., May 2 (UPI) -- Marilynn Smith scored an eagle on the 17th hole today and won the Peach Blossom invitation with a three-under-par 213 for 54 holes.
ONE of the pleasantest surprises of the recently reopened World's Fair is the laudable nature of the Top of the Fair restaurant on the upper level of the Port Authority Heliport.

" And Things That Go Bump in the Night," the play that was to have closed Saturday night at the Royale Theater after a week's engagement, has been extended. Tickets for the Terrence McNally drama, staged by Michael Cacoyannis, will continue to be sold at $1 each.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) -- Leaders of the Federal Government's drive against poverty announced a new yardstick today for determining which United States families were poor.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Johnson announced tonight that he had committed a total of 14,000 United States troops to the Dominican Republic and said that their mission was to protect lives and to "prevent another Communist state in this hemisphere."

BRISTOL, Tenn., May 2 (UPI) -- Junior Johnson of Rhonda, N.C., staged a late rally today and beat Dick Hutcherson of Keokuk, Iowa, by one second in winning the fifth annual Southeastern 500-mile stock car race.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Senate liberals are expected to decide early this week whether to give up their fight for inclusion of a ban on poll taxes in the voting rights bill.

CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP) -- Jim King's pop foul in the first game and his tie-breaking single in the second game carried the Washington Senators to 3-2 and 4-2 victories over the Cleveland Indians today.

ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP) -- Bill White hit a home run in the ninth inning of the second game today to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-4 victory and a sweep of their double-header with the Pittsburgh Pirates.

The devotion of mothers in general and of the "Mother of God" in particular prompted Pope Paul VI to issue his encyclical "Mense Maio," last Friday, Msgr. Joseph P. O'Brien said at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 1 -- After a long, cold winter of Edmund Wilson's lectures on American literature, John Cage's recitals of avant-garde music and Francois Truffaut's new-wave films, the students at Wesleyan University have donned their oldest sneakers, grabbed their skateboards and fled to the outdoors.

Thomas H. Fitzgerald was re-elected president yesterday of Theatrical Protective Union No. 1, known as the stagehands union. The election was held at the group's headquarters, 254 West 54th Street. The union, which has jurisdiction in Manhattan the Bronx and Staten Island, lists 1,480 members.

QUINCY, Ill., May 2 (UPI) -- The Mississippi River rose again today, fed by the swollen Des Moines River and fanned into whitecaps by winds up to 30 miles an hour, creating new pressures on straining levees.

The annual Nat Osk Amateur Athletic Union 10-mile handicap walk held by the 92d Street Y.M.H.A. at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday attracted a field ranging in age from 16 years old to 71.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 2 -- United States Navy planes from the Seventh Fleet are now participating in strikes against the Vietcong, a United States military spokesman said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2 -The discovery of a substance that seems to occur only in cancers of the human digestive tract and in human embryonic tissues from that system was reported at a meeting here today of the American Federation for Clinical Research.

If you listeners out there in radioland in Westchester County hear a disk jockey greeting you from Station WLS in Chicago today, there is nothing wrong with your set. You'll be tuned in to WFAS or WFASTV, a local radio station that is inaugurating an experiment in trade advertising.
Compton Advertising, Inc., has announced the promotion of four executives of its Chicago office to senior vice presidents.

Aaron Copland will be the host and conductor of a new summer television series, "Music in the Twenties," which will begin here next month on Channel 13.

Earnings of the American Investment Company, a diversified finance concern, St. Louis, for the first quarter of 1965 were $2,165,131, or slightly more than last year's first-quarter earnings of $2,143,313 Donald L. Barnes Jr., president, reported over the weekend.

A Soviet United Nations employe who plunged three stories from his seventh-floor apartment Saturday night to the roof of an adjacent church was reported in fair condition at Lenox Hill Hospital last night.

A recognized danger of any piecemeal amendment of the already complex New York State Constitution is the effect that any given change may have on other provisions of the Constitution itself. Such a danger is presented by an amendment just forwarded to the voters for ratification in November. It would lengthen terms of legislators from two years to four.
QUANTICO, Va., May 2 -- Tom Bauer is a 21-year-old St. John's University senior from Island Park, L.I. He is a handsome, black-haired youngster with a brooding face. There was no brooding look today.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- James R. Hoffa told 1,500 cab drivers at a rally here today that he would "deliver the goods" if Chicago drivers selected Teamsters Local 777 as their bargaining agent at a National Labor Relations Board election to be held here Wednesday.

YONKERS, May 2 -- Walter Hewlett, a 20-year-old runner representing the Harvard University Athletic Association, won the Charles Bisbine Memorial 10,000-meter regional title today at War Memorial Field. The program was sanctioned by the Metropolitan Association, Amateur Athletic Union.

MONTREAL, May 2 -- When Jean Beliveau hoisted the Stanley Cup to his shoulders last night and glided around the Forum rink in a victory lap, he was carrying more than a piece of hockey hardware. He was, in a sense, carrying the Canadian Dream.

A 63-year leasehold on the 37-story Palmolive Building, a Chicago landmark, has been bought for $2.7 million by Playboy magazine. The magazine and its related enterprises will use seven floors and the rest will be rented to business tenants.

The sale of the assets of a subsidiary, Baker Laboratories, Inc., a manufacturer of milk formulas for infants, to Chas. Pfizer Co., was announced yesterday by the U.S. Vitamin and Pharmaceutical Corporation.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 2 -- Kathy Doyle, a 17-year-old from Boston who hopes to follow her instructor, George Morris, as an Olympic rider, won the working hunter championship at the Rice Farms Horse Show today.
A national study group reported yesterday that too many of the nation's high school English teachers know far too little about their subject.

Frank Wille, the New York State superintendent of banks, has concluded that he favors permitting New York City's commercial banks to expand into Suffolk County, sources close to the banking-department chief reported over the weekend.
Cardinal Spellman, who will be 76 years old tomorrow, dedicated a $2.3 million addition to the Lavelle School for the Blind yesterday.

SAIGON, May 2 (AP) -United States Marine medium tanks went on their first patrol today in a search operation. The 52-ton M48 tanks with marines clinging to their sides, encountered only scattered Vietcong sniper fire. No one was hit. The tanks ranged out on the salt flats around Danang Bay.
The 60-year-old St. Regis Hotel has been sold to new owners who plan to continue it as a pillar of elegant living on Fifth Avenue.
The former pavilion of Sierra Leone at the World's Fair will become the site for a United Nations exhibit, Robert Moses, president of the fair, announced yesterday.
First quarter operating revenues of Northern States Power Company and subsidiaries rose by 6.8 per cent, the company reported over the weekend.
Plans to build four new police stations at a cost of more than $5,000,000 were advanced yesterday by Mayor Wagner. Two are to be erected in Brooklyn, one in Manhattan and one in Queens.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 2 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy from Kings Point, L.I., scored 211 points to retain the honors in the annual service academy sailing championship that ended today.
DALLAS, May 2 (UPI) -- Cliff Richey and his sister Nancy scored upset victories today to capture the men's and women's singles championship in the 19th annual Dallas Country Club tennis tournament.

LONDON, May 2 -- Fifteen West Indians, six Pakistanis and six Indians have tried to join the London police force in the last three years.

LONDON, May 2 -- Representatives of 14 nations will meet here tomorrow in an attempt to persuade Norway, the Soviet Union and Japan, the only nations left in the deep-sea whaling business, to accept scientific advice on how the industry should be internationally controlled.

United States Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg proposed last night the creation of a neutral, fact-finding United Nations commission to investigate religious discrimination throughout the world.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 (AP) -- Willie McCovey hit Bob Miller's first pitch in the 10th inning for his second homer of the game today and gave the San Francisco Giants a 4-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

What is good for Portofino is good for Quogue, Bloomingdale's reasoned when it was planning its summer beachwear collection. A bipartisan group of 11 Councilmen, all actively interested in additional City Charter reform, will offer a bill tomorrow requiring the Mayor to get the approval of the City Council before initiating any public works project.

Last week municipal bond dealers had their busiest week so far in 1965. This week it will be the corporate bond underwriters' turn. A total of $228,780,900 of taxable bonds is scheduled for sale this week, more than double the $107,700,000 marketed last week.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 -- When the horses streaked under the wire at the finish of yesterday's Kentucky Derby, Willie Shoemaker rose gleefully in his stirrups and let Lucky Debonair coast down the track. Alongside him was Milo Valenzuela on Dapper Dan, the 30-to-1 shot whose projectile burst at the end had left him a neck behind.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 2 -- Philip Dollin of Sea Cliff (L.I.) Yacht Club sailed Mabel to a 50-second victory today in the opening race of the International Class championship season during the second spring regatta conducted by Larchmont Yacht Club.

GENEVA, May 2 -- Secretary General Thant said on his departure today for New York and tomorrow's Security Council session that he felt he had to be present for the debate on the "very serious" Dominican situation.

ALTHOUGH the garment industry is as committed to seasonal rhythms as the members of a primitive cult, its seasons do not necessarily coincide with those in nature. Before summer arrives it will be deep in autumn, and before snow falls it will be thinking spring.

The Yankees play the Mets tonight at Yankee Stadium in the third annual Mayor's Trophy Game. Once again, the event is expected to be a stunning tribute to social mobility and the American axiom, "baseball makes strange bed-fellows."

SANTO DOMINGO, May 2 (AP) -- United States military planes landed and took off at San Isidro air base, east of here, every two minutes. About 2,000 paratroopers of the 82d Airborne Division arrived overnight and more flew in during the day.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -Civil rights leaders have begun to express concern about President Johnson's delay in appointing a commission to administer the fair employment practices section of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
The New York Yankees, who played 20 double-headers last season before losing one, took it on the chin twice yesterday from the Baltimore Orioles in their second double-header of 1965.

KANSAS CITY, May 2 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics broke a seven-game losing streak today by defeating the Los Angeles Angels, 9-5, in the second game of a double-header. The Angels slammed their way to a 10-8 victory in the opener with a 15-hit attack.

SECOND time around, the Spanish Pavilion at the World's Fair is the best total work of art in the whole place. And to clinch matters, the pavilion's painting and sculpture exhibitions are even better than last year's.
The recent centennial of Lincoln's death was marked by the publication of four books of Lincolniana, two of which deal with the tragedy.
PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- The Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh will be asked at its 100th annual concention here on May 11 to declare the Right Rev. James A. Pike persona non grata in this diocese.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Early Bird is the 12th communications satellite to be launched by the United States. All but one of the others worked at least for a time.
PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- Steel men expect relatively heavy shipments over the next four months. Some also think prices may go up during this span.
DETROIT, May 2 -- Former United States Representative Neil Staebler has been elected to his old seat on the Democratic National Committee after a three-month battle.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will sponsor a summer program of educational, cultural and recreational activities for for 35 Manhattan and Bronx neighborhoods that have been designated pockets of poverty.
LONDON, May 2 (AP) -- The United States will press for further help from its allies in the Vietnam conflict, Under Secretary of State George Ball said tonight.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., May 2 -- Madam, a 5-year-old bay mare from Salem View Farms in North Salem, N.Y., won five blue ribbons, a reserve championship and a championship at the Sleepy Hollow Horse Show today.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) -- Texas, the home state of President Johnson, leads the nation in junkyards and "similar eyesores" along its main highways and streets, the White House said today.

The Mall in Central Park echoed yesterday with joyous song and music and the rhythmic beat of youthful dancers in a salute to Israel's 17th anniversary as a nation. About 20,000 persons roared their approval.

His memoirs record what he observed in Russia in World War II days and also tell of his encounters with such figures as Winston Churchill, Charles de Gaulle, Anthony Eden. Wendell Willkie and Averell Harriman.

FELTONVILLE, Pa., May 2 -- A 2-year-old Maltese, Ch. Aennchen's Sari Dancer, owned by Anna Maria Stimmler, Fairview Village, Pa., gaited to best in show honors in a field of 844 contenders today in the 22d annual Penn Treaty Kennel Club fixture.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) April 30 -- The people and Government of Israel have performed such prodigies under Arab pressure that any change in the form of the pressure, any reduction of its intensity raises important political and psychological questions for a country that in many respects lives in a state of Siege.
