At Carnegie Recital Hall last night, Corinne Isaac Barkin played an imaginative program of piano music, including 10 of the 24 preludes that constitute Scriabin's Op. 11 and Prokofiev's Sixth Sonata (A major. Op. 82.)

MIAMI, May 2 (AP) -- Gov. George C. Wallace's offer to show newspaper editors what he calls the "true Alabama" is a propaganda gesture that should be challenged, the president of the Associated Press Managing Editors Association said today.

Waterfront employers in the Port of New York have notified members of the Legislature that they are "unalterably opposed" to a pending measure that would close the waterfront to new workers and curtail the authority of the Waterfront Commission.

Robert Lorel's April 5 letter discussing the Hoover moratorium is both unjust to Herbert Hoover and inaccurate by virtue of pertinent omissions. The Hoover moratorium of 1931-32 was a one-year moratorium on all intergovernmental obligations to ease the balance of payments problem inherent in the worldwide depression.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 2 (AP) -- For the first time outside Congressional chambers, Representative William E. Dickinson has repeated his charges of immorality during the civil rights march from Selma to Montgomery.

Members of the printers and photoengravers unions ratified new contracts with seven of the city's daily newspapers yesterday.
ALBANY, May 3 (AP) -- Eastern New York construction employers said today they would halt $250 million dollars in building projects in the face of a dispute with unions.

BUFFALO, May 3 (AP) -- A two-year scientific study has shown that filters in cigarettes may be helpful in preventing cancer by cutting down the amount of smoke-tar intake, three scientists reported today.

Steeplechase racing made its 1965 debut at Aqueduct yesterday with part of the focus on the only two American sportswomen whose steeplechasers have won the famed Grand National at Aintree.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 3 -- President Sukarno today reviewed a parade of about 20,000 Indonesian workers, youths and students who marched through downtown Jakarta past the Presidential Palace.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, today linked any possible increase in dividends to labor costs, which he said were the largest element in all costs.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The United States payments position apparently showed a surplus in April and March, Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler said today. He told the House Ways and Means Committee that, even so, this was no time to slacken efforts to reduce overseas spending.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The United States proposed to the Organization of American States today the formation of an inter-American peace force to help restore order in the Dominican Republic.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the United States was not liable for damages resulting from a 1958 collision over Brunswick, Md., of a Capital Airlines passenger plane and a jet trainer of the Maryland Air National Guard.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- New orders placed with the steel industry fell by 12 per cent in March, after three months at abnormally high levels. The volume of new orders received by all manufacturers nevertheless continued to climb during the month.

The price of copper moved toward a uniform level throughout the world yesterday -- at 36 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Johnson paid tribute to the national physical fitness program today in White House ceremonies honoring 12 winners of community fitness leadership awards. The awards are sponsored by the Junior Chamber of Commerce and the Standard Packaging Corporation of New York.
A total of 105 elevators in eight midtown Manhattan buildings were stopped by a power failure for periods of from seven minutes to one hour yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, May 4 -- Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that he expected to run for a third term next year. "I like to stay flexible," he said at a news conference in the Red Room of the Capitol. "I think everyone in politics does. But I have every intention of running again."
WASHINGTON, May 4 -Outstanding consumer installment credit rose by $637 million in March, about the same amount as in February, the Federal Reserve reported today.

BURBANK, Calif., May 4 -- Shareholders attending the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation annual meeting today heard president Daniel J. Haughton report gains in business in spite of a slow first quarter, but that gains may be more difficult to attain during the rest of the year.

MASERU, Basutoland, May 4 (Reuters) -- The Basutoland National party, which favors a working relationship with neighboring South Africa, won a narrow victory today in this British protectorate's pre-independence elections.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 4 -Nassau County Deputy Chief Police Inspector James R. Ketcham, who resigned four days ago as Sheriff, said today that he was "astonished" at District Attorney Cahn's plan to put two undercover agents in the county jail.

Ernest M. Weaver has been appointed vice president of the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company. He was formerly assistant vice president and manager of the national title division of the Lawyers Title Insurance Corporation of Richmond, Va., with offices in New York.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., May 4 -- Two Air Force jet fighter planes collided in the air today while flying formation near here. One plane crashed into a wooded area, while the other landed safely. Princess Benedikte of Denmark ended her first full day in New York dancing sedately around the Pierre's ballroom floor. The partners assigned to her included two ambassadors, her cousin and four tall first classmen from the United States Military Academy.

GENEVA, May 4 (Reuters) -- Russia gave trade figures today for the first time to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and promised to develop trade with "countries of other social systems."
CINCINNATI, May 4 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers frittered away a four-run first-inning lead tonight and then rallied to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 8-6, with two runs in the ninth.

Governor Rockefeller's ready rejection of a plan for a possible tie between a state-owned Long Island Rail Road and the city's subway system [Times April 29] as proposed by the City Planning Commission discriminates unfairly against the city.

Suffolk County is having difficulty in working out a plan for redistricting its Board of Supervisors to comply with the one man-one vote doctrine of the United States Supreme Court. The present Board is very badly balanced. The Supervisor in the town of Shelter Island, population 1,400, casts one of the ten votes in the Board, and so does the Supervisor who represents the 162,000 residents of the town of Huntington.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 (UPI) -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said today that productivity was not the only yardstick to determine wage increases in the steel industry.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 4 -- The corridor that United States troops opened through rebel-held territory here is a mixture of war and peace, of carnival and Latin suburbia.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., submitted the winning bid yesterday for $2,482,000 of bonds sold by the Central School District No. 5 of Brookhaven and Smithtown, L.I.

WHIPPANY, N.J., May 4 -- Leaning against the fieldstone wall of the railroad station, dressed in his denim coveralls and the big canvasback work gloves, Paul Henriquez-Gil rushed back his high-crown engineer cap and told a group of fathers and their children all about it:

LAST summer it was the topless bathing suit. This year the intrepid designer from out of the West, Rudi Gernreich, has come to town with a collection of knitted fashions for Harmon that is strong optical art.
VANCOUVER, B.C., May 4 -- A Roman Catholic nun said here today that she was willing to face a threat of ex-communication rather than obey a church directive to close an animal shelter she runs.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 4 -- The twin cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul faced the confusing prospect today of operating on different times beginning Sunday.

TOKYO, May 4 (AP) -- A Peking broadcast declared today that the war in South Vietnam has entered a new phase, in which the tempo of the United States aggressors' approach to complete defeat is being accelerated." The remark was contained in an article in Red Flag, a Chinese Communist party organ, broadcast by Hsinhua, the Peking press agency.
A wildcat strike touched off by a jurisdictional maritime union dispute forced more than 22,000 irritated Staten Island ferry commuters to find alternate ways home in last evening's rush hour.
Subway traffic was snarled in large sections of Brooklyn most of yesterday after a crane-car of a work train crashed through a barrier on an elevated track and half fell into the street.
HOUSTON, May 4 -- Dissident stockholders of the Pure Oil Company agreed today to fight a proposed merger with the Union Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to appropriate $700 million in extra funds to finance the expanding war in Vietnam. Increased American fighting there "may well have already brought us much closer to peace," he said.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4 (AP) -- A state constitutional amendment to reapportion the Ohio House was rejected in today's primary election.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -President Johnson's effort to improve the balance-of-payments deficit with a "See America First" campaign has won a cool reception on two domestic fronts.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate plan to file a closure petition Monday to shut off further debate on the voting rights bill and bring it to a vote.
ST. LOUIS, May (UPI) -Two-run homers by Jesus Alou, Willie Mays and Jim Hart gave the San Francisco Giants' a 9-2 victory tonight over the St. Louis Cardinals.
WARSAW, May 4 (UPI) -A second gigantic meat swindle has been discovered in Poland even as the trial of participants in the first blackmarketing ring was being prepared, it was announced today.

BONN, May 4 -- The Western Allied powers are striving to come up with an agreed policy declaration on Germany to mark the 20th anniversary of the Third Reich, which surrendered unconditionally May 7, 1945.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Commissioner of Education Francis Keppel asked today for standby authority to provide Federal assistance to public school systems in disaster areas.

BOSTON, May 4 (AP) -United States concerns plan to cooperate in the Administration's voluntary balance-ofpayments program by expanding exports rather than curtailing overseas investment, Assistant Secretary of Commerce Andrew F. Brimmer said today.
YONKERS, May 4 -- This city is looking forward to a renaissance downtown, but it seems reluctant to pay the price -- relocation of its slum dwellers into quiet, residential neighborhoods.
Representative Gerald R. Ford Jr., Republican of Michigan, said yesterday that President Johnson's disavowal of a "rocking chair" approach to Communist aggression carried a plain innuendo.
BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 5 -- Twelve hundred American paratroops began landing before dawn today to set up strengthened defenses around the large United States air base here.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Consolidated Edison Company offered today to build a $1.5 million barrier in the Hudson River to protect fish there from any adverse effect of its power plant on Storm King Mountain.
American Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday for permission to end the weight limit on the free baggage transportation provided for its passengers.

LONDON, May 5 -- The flourishing trans-Atlantic exchange of pop singers and musicians has been halted indefinitely by an agreement between the British Musicians Union and the American Federation of Musicians.

ATLANTA, May 5 (UPI) -- Calvin Craig, Grand Dragon of the Georgia Ku Klux Klan, evidently lost today in hid bid for a seat in Georgia's reapportioned Legislature, but at least 11 Negroes were nominated.
An increase in the quarterly dividend was announced yesterday by Sears, Roebuck Co., along with word that it attained record sales in April for the 48th consecutive month.
ALBANY, May 5 -- Governor Rockefeller's $1.7 billion program to fight water pollution throughout the state sped through the Legislature today without a dissenting vote.
The General Aniline and Film Corporation reported record first-quarter results yesterday, and directors declared the company's first dividend in 10 years.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- President Johnson's request for $700 million to finance expanding United States military operations in Vietnam was approved by the House of Representatives today by a vote of 408 to 7.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Consolidated Edison Company proposed a new route today for the overhead power lines that will connect its Cornwall plant on the Hudson River with the existing system serving New York City.
The stock market marched uphill again yesterday, trampling its day-old record highs in the process.

The plaudits of The New York Times [editorial April 5] for the new route identification signs on the sides of buses are a bit premature, if the signs are to load more unessential advertising than identification, as is apparent.

If, as seems plausible, New York City's Republican leaders are preparing to designate John J. Gilhooley as their candidate for Mayor they have almost guaranteed the re-election of Robert F. Wagner to a fourth term.
First-quarter earnings of the Copper Range Company rose 40 per cent from the 1964 level to 82 cents a share, James Boyd, president, told the annual stockholders meeting in Boston yesterday.

Dr. Jules Backman, research professor of economics at New York University, warned yesterday that the current "marked expansion" of plant and equipment in the chemical industry "will lead to a new condition of excess capacity."

WHITE PLAINS, May 5 -- Proposed pay increases averaging $1,000 a year for teachers in Cortlandt Central School District 3 led to the narrow rejection today of its $3,081,083 budget by a vote of 239 to 227.

MILWAUKEE, May 5 (UPI) -Eddie Mathews doubled in the 14th inning tonight, scoring Mack Jones, to give the Milwaukee Braves and their young left-hander, Wade Blasingame, a 2-1 victory over the Houston Astros.
LONDON, May 5 -- The Council of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization condemned in the strongest terms today the Communist assault on the Republic of Vietnam.
BONN, May 5 -- West Germany marked the 10th anniversary of its sovereignty today with a hopeful expression of confidence that its Western allies would continue to try to reunify Germany.
TO 17 young women with pretty faces and excellent figures -- among them a Eurasian, two Chinese, a batch of Europeans and an American Indian -- the World's Fair opened yesterday.
Skimming along the rail in the final phase of the short race, Herbert Allen's Timely Move won the 52d running of the $24,500 Youthful Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, May 5 -- The Security Council postponed tonight a vote on a resolution calling upon Britain to take all "necessary measures" to prevent a one-sided declaration of independence by Rhodesia.
The car of the Spanish consul general and the car of the Argentine consul general collided yesterday at Park Avenue and 86th Street in bright sunlight and with considerable impact.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission temporarily suspended today all trading in the securities of Webb Knapp, Inc., and of Roosevelt Field, Inc., a subsidiary that is 75 per cent owned by Webb Knapp. The real-estate concerns are headed by William Zeckendorf Sr., chairman.

The HRH Construction Corporation yesterday elected Saul Horowitz Jr. to the office of president to succeed his father, who becomes chairman after 40 years as chief executive officer of the 71-year-old concern.
LONDON, May 5 -- A Government-appointed study group today recommended construction of a pedestrian mall above Piccadilly Circus, the Times Square of London.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The threat of leaders to shut off debate had the intended effect today, and the Senate began to make progress on the voting rights bill.
DETROIT, May 5 (AP) -John Buzhardt and Joel Horlen each pitched a four-hitter tonight to lead the Chicago White Sox to 4-0 and 4-1 victories over the Detroit Tigers in a twilight-night double-header.

THE ultimate tribute to the Chester Dale collection, now established once and for all in Washington's National Gallery of Art, is that as a public collection it retains the warmth and individuality that marked it as a private one.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 5 -- In a shift of emphasis Adlai E. Stevenson said today that the United States emergency action" in the Dominican Republic had two aims: "to protect lives and to give the inter-American system a chance to deal with a situation within its competence."
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 5 -- The discovery of what may be the main mechanism of the world's leading cause of death was reported at a scientific meeting that ended here today.

Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday the details of a "Summer in the City" program designed to combat poverty in neighborhoods of special need. On Sunday the Cardinal issued a statement saying such a program would be conducted.
Prince Sihanouk's decision to sever diplomatic ties with the United States stems from his conviction that he can avoid complete vassalage to Communist China by paying occasional political tribute.

ALBANY, May 5 -- The Democratic leaders of the Legislature indicated today that they would try to salvage at least a small part of the strong Ethics Code for legislators that was defeated yesterday by the Democratic-controlled Assembly.

Prices of Maine potato futures hit a record of $6.34 a hundred-weight on the May delivery here yesterday. The final price on the spot month was $6.31, up 33 cents on the day. The earlier record, $6.29, was reached last week.

The Association of Theater Benefit Agents will not handle tickets for the Alan Jay Lerner-Burton Lane musical, "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever." The show is due Oct. 16 at the Mark Hellinger Theater.
MONTREAL, May 5 -- The Canadian Pacific Railway suggested to stockholders today that, in the absence of large, export-grain shipments this year, earnings from railway operations would be below 1964.
NEW LONDON, Conn., May 5 -- The Navy described today an underwater vehicle it plans to build to rescue the crews of disabled submarines as deep as 6,000 feet beneath the ocean's surface.
Leaders of a Puerto Rican organization called for abolition of the city's Human Rights Commission last night after a stormy two-and-a-half-hour meeting with commission officials.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company is expected to raise about $75 million through sales today of debentures and convertibe preferred stock. The debentures -- a $45 million issue -- are expected to carry a 4.85 per cent interest coupon and to be priced at 100.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., May -- Robert T. Person, president of the Public Service Company of Colorado, was elected president of the Edison Electric Institute today at the close of the organizations' 33d annual convention.

CINCINNATI, May 5 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit set aside today a lower court order that had freed Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard and ordered him to serve a life prison term for the murder of his wife.
It was a rather pleasant day on Madison Avenue yesterday.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 5 (AP) -- The Kaiser Industries Corporation reported today a net loss of $1.95 million for the three months to March 31, compared with a loss of $59,000 for the first quarter of 1964.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell said today he supported President Johnson's actions in the Dominican Republic but believed the bombing of North Vietnam would "not have much effect one way or the other" on the war there.

Banco de Credito del Peru announced yesterday the election of Fernando Berckemeyer and Ettore Bottoni as directors.

" Boss Tweed's New York," by Seymour Mandelbaum, a picture of life in the city nearly a century ago, will be published by Wiley on June 9. This is the first book of Wiley's "Historical Cities" series. The author is assistant professor of history at the Carnegie Institute of Technology.
THE shad are finally getting up the Delaware River to points where the fishing is easier.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -Local telephone companies, using electronic monitoring equipment, regularly eavesdrop on conversations between their employes and their subscribers, a labor union official told Senators today.

THE success of "Peyton Place" was certain to be followed by more soap opera in the evening under the rule of cyclical imitation in television. Last night brought a nighttime two-parter called "Our Private World," a spin-off from the durable daytime serial called "As the World Turns."
LOS ANGELES, May 5 (UPI) -Jim Fregosi led the Los Angeles Angels into third place in the American League on a 6-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.
The B.F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it withdrew sponsorship of "The Science of Spying" because it feared the documentary program might harm the United States Government.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 5 (Comtelburo) -- About 50 delegates from the nine member countries of the Latin American Free Trade Association continued today discussions on maritime transportation.

A hospital-based group medical plan, whose internists, pediatricians and dentists will devote their services exclusively to the care of 5,000 teamster families in the metropolitan area, was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 6 -- A ministerial meeting of the Organization of American States voted early today to create an inter-American military force to help restore peace and constitutional government in the Dominican Republic.

YONKERS, May 5 -- Most harness racing experts are in agreement that Express Rodney, the only true free-for-all horse in the two-mile race, has "not much to beat" in the $50,000 Pete Manning at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

CHICAGO, May 5 (UPI) -- A local of the Seafarers International Union had little trouble today in defeating a comeback bid by James R. Hoffa's teamsters union in a hard-fought election for the right to bargain for 4,000 Chicago cab drivers.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A Federal Appeals Court dismissed today contempt proceedings it had instituted against former Gov. Ross R. Barnett of Mississippi and Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has prohibited "corned beef sandwich" incidents such as the one that occurred in the recent Gemini space flight of Maj. Virgil I. Grissom and Lieut. Comdr. John W. Young.

I feel that Sp/4 John Murray and Pfc. Edmund Dobush ("Soldiers' Viewpoint," letter published May 1) have somehow missed the point of most of the demonstrations against the war in Vietnam, and stand on shaky ground in their conclusions that citizens demonstrating are "out of line" and a "disgrace" to the men who are giving their lives in that war.
QUINCY, Ill., May 5 (AP) -- The worst of the Mississippi river floods appeared beyond the danger point today. But the long, costly task of repair and recovery is beginning.
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson talked to children today in a child development center to get a preview of a project planned for some 500,000 children this summer.
LONDON, May 5 -- Aubrey Jones, a shy Tory intellectual, is about to begin one of the toughest jobs in Britain as director of the Labor Government's new machinery to control inflation.
BOSTON, May 5 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge agreed today to hear arguments in District Attorney Garrett H. Byrne's attempt to block the May 25 Cassius Clay-Sonny Liston heavyweight title fight.

Evidence of a problem of "survivor guilt" among former inmates of Nazi death camps has been bolstered by recent research findings, two psychiatrists said in a report drafted for yesterday's session of the American Psychiatric Association's meeting here.
SAN JUAN, P.R., May 5 -- Details of an unsuccessful effort to obtain an understanding between the Johnson Administration and democratic rebel elements in Santo Domingo came to light today.

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- The regional director of the National Labor Relations Board said today that suspension of publication by The Baltimore News-American on April 20 "constituted an illegal lockout" of its employes.
WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Has President Johnson proclaimed a new "Johnson Doctrine" for the Western Hemisphere?
BONN, May 5 -- The Chinese Communist Government has just taken delivery of a Mercedes-Benz $13,500 limousine.
A footwear manufacturing concern charged yesterday that a union local with asserted underworld connections had used threats and strong-arm tactics in an effort to organize its 450 workers.
NEW CITY, N.Y., May 5 -- Voters in eight Rockland County central school districts voted today for school board members and to approve budgets.
The United Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday a 63.5 per cent increase in first-quarter profits over the 1964 level.
ALGIERS, May 5 -- Ronald B. Ramsey, a 26-year-old American psychologist, was expelled from Algeria today after four months' imprisonment on unspecified charges.

HARTFORD May 5 -- A rare lithograph, taken some time last night from the new art building of Trinity College here, was recovered by the police at 7:25 P.M. today in a confessional booth of St. Michael's Church, 5 Clark Street.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 5 (AP) -- A.J. Foyt of Houston, the 1964 winner of the 500-mile Memorial Day race, wrecked his Sheraton-Thompson rear-engine Lotus Ford at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today. He escaped injury.

THIS is agony time for a considerable number of marginal major league players -- midnight Wednesday is the deadline for cutting active rosters to 25 men. The uncertainty professional athletes feel as such a time approaches is a peculiar form of torture hard to describe to those engaged in more ordinary occupations.

As a former combat officer familiar with the South China Sea and with many of the land areas surrounding it I am dismayed to note that most persons discussing our position in South Vietnam are debating the question of whether we should be where we now are.
Small advances were the order of the day on the London stock market yesterday.
Better street lighting was added to part of the West Side last night as a result of pressure upon the city by a group of safety-minded residents.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the week ended May 1 were both considerably above the corresponding period of 1964.

NEWARK, May 6 -- The public relations director for the Newark Police Department, who was identified in a grand jury presentment last week as being on the payroll of a vending machine company run by an underworld leader, was dismissed today by Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio.

A new orchestra that has as its basic concept racial balance, made its debut last night at Carnegie Hall. The orchestra is called the Symphony of the New World because its founders believe that most orchestra's today do not reflect racial equality and therefore are "not of today's world."

ALBANY, May 6 -- Two strong legislative ethics measures that were beaten in the Assembly two days ago were dramatically revived today in a surprise parliamentary move by their sponsor, Assemblyman Daniel M. Kelly.
Treasury bond prices slipped slightly yesterday as trading came almost to a standstill.

F.W. WOOLWORTH stock advanced 1/8th of a point on the market Wednesday, but the gain could hardly have been the result of any hot tip on the art exhibition that opened at the Fifth Avenue store yesterday. Far be it from me to throw a wrench into the works of a going concern, but I am of two minds about what Woolworth's has done.
The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria was the setting last night for the eighth annual dinner dance sponsored by the board of trustees and the Women's Auxiliary of the Lenox Hill Hospital.

GENEVA, May 6 -- A Baptist laynian from New York will participate in the first major attempt by the Roman Catholic Church since the Reformation to reach a meeting of minds with the other Christian faiths.

The police disclosed yesterday that they had three definite leads that they hoped would bring about the solution of the murder two weeks ago of Paul Jung, the famous clown of the Ringling Bros. Barnum Bailey Circus.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 6 (UPI) -- Robin Roberts set down the Minnesota Twins on four hits today to gain his fourth consecutive pitching victory in a 5-1 triumph for the Baltimore Orioles.
The Federal Maritime Commission announced yesterday that it would investigate three steamship conferences that deal exclusively in the transportation of Department of Defense cargoes.

IT wasn't easy to find an Arthur at Arthur Wednesday night, but everyone else was there -- Caterine and D.D. and Jane, Jake and Mike and Rudolf, all those "in" people who know that Arthur is a place and not a person.
CLEVELAND, May 6 -- Johnny Keane made out his 18th straight "irregular" line-up for the New York Yankees tonight, then was reprieved from using it by rainstorms that swept in off Lake Erie.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -Lewis S. Rosenstiel, president of Schenley Industries, Inc., told Senators today that both his home and office in Miami had been "bugged."

The nomination of Charles C. Glavin as president of the Bond Club of New York was announced yesterday. Mr. Glavin, who is chairman of the executive committee of the First Boston Corporation, will succeed Walter W. Wilson of Morgan Stanley Co.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 6 -- The United States is planning to buy $30 million worth of industrial diamonds from the Congo and $55 million worth of uranium from South Africa. Both are barter deals for American farm surplus commodities.

SYRACUSE, May 6 -- The "Reverse Freedom Riders" from Selma, Ala., and members of the Syracuse chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality picketed the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation offices here this afternoon, demanding that the power company hire more Negroes.
PARIS, May 6 -- Nine countries agreed formally today to supply extra funds to the International Monetary Fund for a large loan to Britain. The new British borrowing is expected to total $1.4 billion.
LONDON, May 6 -- A trans-Atlantic dispute over visa applications for the Kenny Ball Jazz Band to play in the United States ended tonight with an apparent compromise.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, May 6 (Reuters) -- Bobby Simpson (201) and Bill Lawry (210) of Australia today became the first opening batsmen in test cricket history to score double centuries in the same innings as they batted on the second day of the fourth test match with the West Indies.
It was almost standing room only yesterday when more than 500 shareholders of Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc. crowded into the Hotel Biltmore's Bowman Room for the annual meeting.

Fears of persecution, demands for money and insistence on giving the President advice or "messages from God" are the leading motives of psychotics who try to force their way into the White House, two psychiatrists reported here yesterday.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 6 -- Roy Faber, Colonia pro, won the individual pro prize in the second annual John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital benefit golf tournament today with a 33, 36 -- 69 at the Plainfield Country Club.

Twenty years ago today, in a little French schoolhouse, Germany surrendered unconditionally to the Western allies and the Soviet Union. Amid the jubilation that followed, few in the West bothered to ponder the portent of Stalin's insistence that the surrender be re-enacted in the Berlin he controlled.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 6 -- Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge Thomas C. Yager reported today that his socially prominent 61-year-old bride of three days had apparently fallen overboard from their chartered honeymoon cruiser this morning as they were returning from Catalina Island.
A sharp price drop in shares of the New Mexico and Arizona Land Company overshadowed a generally weak but active market on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
CINCINNATI, May 6 (AP) -- Home runs by Derrell Griffith and Ron Fairly gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.
About $25 million of tax-exempt bonds were sold at competitive bidding yesterday, and the acceptance of new issues in the municipals market appeared to quicken.

SIXTEEN pairs of students begin play tonight in Chicago in a three-session event to decide the 1965 National Intercollegiate Championships. The tournament will be directed by William Root of New York, and Lawrence Rosler of Murray Hill, N.J., who organized the nationwide par competition in which the finalists qualified on a regional basis.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 6 (AP) -- A Canadian hunted all over the world since a Montreal bank was burglarized in 1961 was arrested today aboard his yacht -- the first victim of the police power of satellite television.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 6 (UPI) -- A Titan 3-A rocket was fired into four different orbits today in a record-breaking display of the maneuverability needed for military missions.
Bill Bradley, the nations finest college basketball player last season, was the No. 1 draft choice of the National Basketball Association yesterday.
Brooklyn Tech took its first city Public Schools Athletic League track and field championship, yesterday when it won the novice outdoor title at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Organization of American States set about today recruiting its first military force, an inter-American peace unit to help restore order in the Dominican Republic.

Governor Rockefeller instructed the State Commission of Investigation yesterday to open an inquiry immediately into charges and counter-charges between Eugene H. Nickerson, Nassau County Executive, and William Cahn, the Nassau District Attorney.
TEL AVIV, May 6 -- Israel unveiled her American-built Hawk antiaircraft missiles today in a parade of military might marking the 17th anniversary of the state.
The British pound inched ahead yesterday in quiet dealings on foreign exchange markets here. The debate on the steel industry white paper slowed trading.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 6 (AP) -- The Studebaker Corporation, attempting to rebuild its corporate image by diversifying after courting disaster in the automotive field, pushed through a reverse one-for-five stock reclassification today.
Threats of a possible shutdown of the entire port of New York because of the ferry stoppage were made yesterday by one of the top leaders of the International Longshoreman's Association.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 6 -- The Dominican rebels killed two United States marines and fatally wounded a third today. A fourth marine was wounded, possibly fatally, in an affray in downtown Santo Domingo.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6 -- Dr. Nikolai T. Fedorenko, the Soviet representative, denounced today the "so-called" decision by the Organization of American States to send an inter-American force to the Dominican Republic.
Reports Australia had exhausted her stocks of uncommitted wheat for the crop year sent futures prices for the bread grain soaring yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- There is a troubled spirit in the capital these days. It is not that the outsiders are sure they know what policy to follow in Vietnam and the Dominican Republic, but that they do not feel the insiders are making policy in a cool, orderly way.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP) -- The first world championship fight here in more than three years will be held tomorrow night between the featherweight titleholder, Vicente Saldivar of Mexico City, and Raul Rojas from nearby San Pedro.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 6 -- A forecast that American businessmen would continue for an indefinite period to cooperate with the Administration's voluntary program to reduce the United States deficit in international payments was made today by one of the business executives directly involved.

BOSTON, May 6 (AP) -- Summonses were issued today requiring Cassius Clay, the world heavyweight champion, and Sonny Liston to appear in court tomorrow to determine who is promoting their May 25 title bout in Boston.
VIENNA, May 6 (AP) -- Latin-American and Asian students in Bucharest clashed today with Rumanian militamen, in a demonstration protesting United States action in Vietnam and the Dominican Republic.

The second annual list of Distinguished Decoration awards given by the National Society of Interior Designers was announced this week. The eight award winners were cited for having "inspired good design in their environment, influencing public taste throughout the world."

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic May 6 -- Robert Satin, the youthful director of the United States Peace Corps in the Dominican Republic, today persuaded the military leaders of the Dominican rebellion to free two wounded United States Marines.
Increased demand for copper enabled the Phelps Dodge Corporation to show sharp gains In sales and earnings in the first quarter of this year, the company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The nation's employment situation was basically unchanged in April, the Labor Department reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 6 -- The South Vietnamese Government, foreseeing a major shift in the political nature of the war, is trying to start a diplomatic offensive in nonaligned countries.

Italian Minister of Foreign Trade Bernardo Mattarella asserted yesterday that Italy's recovery from recent recession should continue without setback or return of inflation. Among signs of strength in the economic upturn are con tinuing substantial export gains and an easing in the previously rapid rise of living costs, Mr. Mattarella said in an interview at the Carlyle Hotel.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., May 6 -- The plain oak table of the defense counsel in the courtroom here holds a worn family Bible, untidy piles of paper and photographs, a snap-brim straw hat and two pistols -- one nickel-plated and the other rusty and pitted.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., May 6 -- The jury in the murder case of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo deliberated for four hours and 15 minutes tonight without reaching a verdict. It was locked up until tomorrow morning in nearby Montgomery.
MANHASSET, L.I., May 6 -- The Miracle Mile on Northern Boulevard here grew longer today with the opening of a branch of Abraham Straus.

Catching up to the pacesetter on the 13th and final jump, Mrs. Dion Kerr's Gramatam went on to win the $14,250 Aqueduct Spring Steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday. Bob McDonald guided the Kerr color-bearer to a neck triumph over Mrs. Ogden Phipps's Mako in a thrilling finish to the two-mile event that marked the first chase stakes of the local season.

LONDON, Mas 6 -- The International Whaling Commission agreed today on a three-year plan for conservation of the world's whale stocks. It also set a lower quota on the catch for the next whaling season.
While the Dow-Jones industrial average posted a new closing high yesterday, the utility average moved sideways -- a direction in which it has been going for some three months.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Federal Power Commission refused today to reconsider its decision to grant the Consolidated Edison Company a license for its controversial Hudson River power plant on Storm King mountain.
MADISON, Wis., May 6 -- A Government team touring college campuses to defend Administration policies on Vietnam ran into an ambush at the University of Wisconsin today.

Barbara Long's violin playing at Carnegie Recital Hall last night reminded one of a remark once made about the cellist Janos Starker -- that he had so thoroughly mastered his instrument's technical problems he could concentrate entirely on interpretation.

WHEN Cy Young had passed his 80th birthday, his back was bowed ever so slightly by the weight of his years. But there was still the look of a former athlete about him. Perhaps it was the sweep of those wide shoulders that stirred visions of the gangling farmboy who shook the hayseed from his hair and then went on to baffle big-league batters for 23 seasons.

THE assistant commissioner the New York City Department of Public Events marched into the State Suite of the Plaza Hotel yesterday at 12:30 P.M., and squealed, "For a Princess, you should have a hat."
MEXICO CITY, May -- Opposition to the United States position in the Dominican Republic continued to mount here this week.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A Presidential commission on East-West trade reported today that a relaxation of restrictions on United States trade with the Soviet Union and other Communist countries of Eastern Europe would help promote American foreign policy objectives.

FAIRFIELD, N.J., May 6 -- Five children and their father died in a fire in a split-level home here this morning, as their mother screamed from the lawn to have the children thrown out to her.

Yale Express System, Inc., and its accountants, Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co., are at loggerheads over the reasons why the trucking concern's earnings reports for 1963 and 1964 had to be drastically revised.

That merger of Tatham-Laird, Inc., of Chicago, and the Kudner Agency, Inc., of New York, became official yesterday -- almost. The agencies announced that merger plans and terms had been set, subject only to approval of the shareholders of both companies.

Grove Press will publish this fall "The Nightclerk," by Stephen Schneck, which received the $10,000 Formentor Prize given by publishers from 13 countries at a meeting in Saint-Raphael, France, last Saturday.
NEWARK, May 6 -- This city became today the first community in New Jersey this year to declare a water emergency. It will take effect at midnight Sunday.

Earl Brown, the $20,000-a-year deputy borough president of Manhattan, will be named soon by Mayor Wagner as the first paid chairman of the strife-torn Commission on Human Rights.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy gets 1,500 to 2,000 letters weekly from the general public and should get a $50,000 Government allowance again next fiscal year to help her answer them, the House Appropritions Committee said today.
Robert Moses, president of the World's Fair, yesterday told international exhibitors who had urged a cut in the admission price that "no reduction was in the offing."

ALBANY, Calif., May 6 (AP) -- Johnny Longden, who has ridden more winners than anyone else in turf history, said today, that he would retire after riding 38 more winners, to put his lifetime total at 6,000. He rode three winners here today to lower the figure to 35.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 6 -- There is no better place to sense the uncertanties, tensions and dangers of the Dominican situation than in the zone in Santo Domingo held by the forces that rebelled against the Government headed by Donald Reid Cabral.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP) -- An official of the National Labor Relations Board held what he called "exploratory talks" with The Baltimore News-American today in an attempt to get the newspaper to resume publication.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- With hardly a voice raised against the measure, the House passed a $5,183,884,850 authorization bill for space funds today. It included almost everything the Administration requested.

The winners of the Deadline Club's awards for outstanding journalism in 1964-65 were announced yesterday as the New York Herald Tribune, the Toronto Telegram's United Nations bureau chief and WNBC-TV.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Senate passed today a special $700 million appropriation bill to finance expanding United States operations in Vietnam. The White House announced that President Johnson would sign it tomorrow.
The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States announced agreement yesterday on a three-year contract.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -Representative Adam Clayton Powell abruptly canceled a subcommittee meeting today at which decisions were to have been made on expanding the nation's antipoverty program.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 6 -Juan Bosch, former President of the Dominican Republic, charged tonight that the United States Embassy in Santo Domingo had prodded the commander of the counterrevolutionaries into bombing the city early Wednesday, April 28.

LONDON, May 6 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson's Government passed its first critical test on steel nationalization tonight by a margin of four votes.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 7 -- A strong new force of United States Marines began landing south of Danang today to provide security for the construction of an important new South Vietnamese air base.

A large collection of antique English silver and of gold objects, belonging to Mrs. A. Hamilton Rice of New York, was auctioned yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries for $360,050, bringing the total of Mrs. Rice's valuables so far sold to $1,702,610.
WASHINGTON -- Modern man's political habits seem to be governed by a strange twenty-year pulse whose rhythm encourages formation of ideological blocs within two decades after each major war.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A group of civil rights leaders urged the Administration today to expand an executive order against discriminatory housing. They want the expanded order to cover conventional mortgage lenders and all existing housing receiving Federal assistance.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6 -- The Security Council today adopted a resolution requesting Britain to take "all necessary action" to prevent Rhodesia from declaring its own independence after an election there tomorrow.
American Metal Climax, Inc., reported good news to several hundred happy stockholders yesterday and was rewarded with a minimum of penetrating questions and repeated bursts of laughter.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) -- Henry H. Fowler, Secretary of Commerce, said today that United States participation in the International Monetary Fund so far has been highly successful, both from the points of view of the national interest and the world economy.

SNAKETOWN, Ariz., May 4 -Newly found archeological evidence indicates that Indians with an advanced social order were operating a remarkably modern irrigation system in southern Arizona about the time Jesus was born.

Benton Bowles, Inc., elected yesterday two vice presidents who will work on the newly acquired automotive account of the American Motors Corporation in the agency's Detroit office. They are Robert S. Povey and Theodore T. Teegarden.

Business borrowings at New York City's 14 weekly reporting banks rose by $297-million during the week ending Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 6 -- American skippers compensated in part today for the loss of the Amorita Cup in international One-Design sailing yesterday.

LONDON, May 6 -- In "Portrait of a Queen," which opened tonight at the Vaudeville Theater, the United States playwright William Francis compiled a dramatic documentary about Queen Victoria. WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank board announced two modifications of its directives restricting the extension of credit by Federal Home Loan Banks to memher savings and loan associations raising dividend rates.

The Curtis Publishing Company announced yesterday its wholly owned paper making subsidiary, the New York and Pennsylvania Company, Inc., had sold its Lock Haven, Pa., division to the Hammermill Paper Company.
Six local residences, each with a garden, will be opened to visitors next Wednesday afternoon for a tour in behalf of the women's auxiliary of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

NEWBURGH, N.Y. -- Water Street, once the downtown shopping district of this Hudsons River city, is now a scene of desolation, destruction and hope. Haryou-Act announced yesterday a $7.7 million program for the treatment and rehabilitation of narcotic addicts in Central Harlem.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A special advisory committee recommended today retention of the honor code at the Air Force Academy but, in a blunt report, suggested many policy changes -- particularly de-emphasis of varsity football.

HONG KONG, May 6 -- Vietnamese students and Soviet policemen clashed in Leningrad last month over a student plan to hold an anti-American rally according to Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency.

ROME, May 6 -- The sensational trial of an Egyptian man and women charged with the murder of another Egyptian was declared a mistrial today as it went into its 14th week.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, chided the Pentagon today for flying generals and admirals to the Masters Golf Tournament at Augusta, Ga., and billeting them at nearby Fort Gordon.

The Democrats have now failed in their duty to enact a valid legislative reapportionment of New York State even more miserably than the Republicans did. Although well aware that the state was under Federal court mandate to produce by April 1 a plan that would comply with the one man-one vote doctrine of the United States Supreme Court, the Democratic leadership dawdled for many months before coming to grips with the problem.

A newly formed bipartisan committee of influential Democrats and Republicans and the New York Young Republican Club gave strong support yesterday to the movement for a direct primary law in this state.

" The Urban Crisis" is the topic of a luncheon address to be delivered by Dean Jose Luis Sert of the Harvard Faculty of Design on Friday, May 14. The meeting, sponsored by the Associated Harvard Clubs, will be held at 12:15 P.M. at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
BONN, May 6 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union flew into East Berlin today to preside over a mammoth anniversary celebration of victory over Germany in World War II.

THIS corner sometimes receives the impression that some readers suspect information is being withheld about where to obtain good fishing and hunting. The truth is that there is only one spot I do not write about.

Apparel credit men must give personal attention to the requirements of the independent retailer as opposed to the computer-fed decisions on credit lines to the large retail enterprises, a credit group was told last night.

The Board of Education will elect its president at its annual meeting next Tuesday. The office is now held by James B. Donovan, who succeeded Max J. Rubin in 1963 and was picked for a full one-year term last May.
LONDON, May 6 (Reuters) -- The Conservative party won a by-election in Birmingham tonight with an 8,150-vote margin over Labor -- only slightly less than in last October's general election.

A conference of businessmen, professional men, and religious leaders called to combat the distribution of pornography asked the Mayor and the City Council yesterday to take further steps to stop its sale on city property such as subway newsstands.
An advertising agency was found guilty by a Federal jury last night of promoting a fraudulent claim that Regimen Tablets caused a substantial loss of weight without the necessity of dieting.

GREENVALE, L.I., May 6 -- The 1965 Long Island Festival, which will open in a large tent on the campus of C.W. Post College in Brookville on July 30, will include performances by the new Philharmonia Orchestra of London.

Larry Gallo of the Brooklyn Gallo gang, released from jail only eight days earlier, was arrested again yesterday along with two other members of the gang for consorting with known criminals -- each other.

ALBANY, May 6 -- The New York County Democratic leader, J. Raymond Jones, said today that the Reform Democratic district leader in Greenwich Village had pleaded for a legislative reapportionment plan that "would get rid of the Italians in his district."

Looking for a $24,000 Gainsborough on the "lay-a-way plan" (10 per cent down, up to 30 days to pay)? Prints at $19.95? A Chagall lithograph at $995 (not $9.95)? Try Woolworth's Gallery of Fine Art, which opened yesterday. If you're not satisfied, you can get your money back within seven days.
Record first-quarter earnings and revenues were announced yesterday by the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) at its annual meeting in Whiting, Ind.
The Columbia Gas System, Inc., sold $40 million of 25-year debentures yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. and the First Boston Corporation.
The leader of striking workers in the garment district reported yesterday that settlements had been made with two major employer associations and a "definite breakthrough" had been achieved.
Alvin L. Mitchell, convicted March 12 of first-degree manslaughter in the fatal stabbing of Barbara Kralik in Queens, was sentenced yesterday to 10 to 20 years in prison.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 6 -- Paul Quinn's Navy crews in 1963 came within an eyelash of bringing off a Sweep in the championships of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association that would have been unparalleled as a triple shocker.
FARNHAM, England, May 6 (Reuters) -- The novelist Edgar Mittelholzer was found dead in a wood near his home here early today. His body was badly burned.
Women news reporters in television are on the increase.

ROME, May 6 -- Leaders of the Society of Jesus -- the Jesuits, the largest and probably the most powerful order of the Roman Catholic Church -- are assembling in Rome for a conclave to elect the new "Black Pope," the order's 28th president general.
ATHENS, May 6 -- Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, arrived today for consultations on the Cyprus dispute. He had not been due until mid-May.

Two contemporary operas will be introduced by the New York City Opera during its fall season. They are Prokofiev's "The Angel of Fire," which has never been given in the United States, and Ned Rorem's "Miss Julie," which will be receiving its world premiere.

PITTSBURGH, May 6 -- Plans were announced today by John W. Galbreath to build a 60-story downtown office building at a cost estimated at $50 million. The structure would be Pittsburgh's tallest. It will be erected on Grand Street in the Golden Triangle, Pittsburgh's downtown.

Two air traffic controllers who were on duty when an Eastern Air Lines DC-7B crashed last Feb. 8 off Jones Beach made conflicting statements yesterday on the relative flight paths of the Eastern plane and a Pan American jet just before the crash.

The theme of the third annual cocktail dance of the Manhattan Chapter of Childville, to be held at the St. Regis Roof on Tuesday, will be "Wine and Roses." Each table will have a bottle of imported wine nestled in a shocking-pink tub of roses and ferns.

CHICAGO, May 6, (AP) -- Larry Jackson enjoyed a perfect day at bat with three hits, including a two-run home run, and pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 5-3 voctory today over the Pittsburgh Pirates with ninth-inning relief from Ted Abernathy.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales totaled $5.61 billion in the week ended May 1, an increase of 6 per cent over the level of the previous week, and up 9 per cent from the comparable 1964 week.

The soft goods segments of industry have made a real contribution to the continuing economic expansion, Martin Gainsbrugh, chief economist of the National Industrial Conference Board, asserted yesterday.

MILWAUKE, May 6 -- Donald B. Straus, board chairman of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, warned members of this national birth control organization today that they could no escape the moral implications of widespread, easy-to-use contraceptives.

OFF and on, man and boy, I have been reading books about Japan for some 45 years. From Lafcadio Hearn to Fosco Maraini, Western authors have always insisted that they loved the Japanese, but in spite of their best efforts to understand they seemed to find the Japanese absolutely incomprehensible.

Dissatisfaction with the current status of reapportionment should not cause us to reach for stopgap or patchwork solutions. Admittedly, reapportionment in New York State, as elsewhere, has become a political football.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Following is the text of the resolution, adopted early today by the Organization of America States, establishing an inter-American force in the Dominican Republic:
THE unfamiliar strains conducted by William Steinberg at the beginning of last night's New York Philharmonic concert were not Julia Perry's Study for Orchestra, scheduled to open the evening.
Seven executives of wholesale meat companies were arrested here yesterday and charged with bribing a meat buyer for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to purchase meats from their companies.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 7 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith swept to victory tonight in Rhodesia's general election, winning all the 50 Parliamentary seats his party was contesting.
Widespread criticism of the Government's information policy on Vietnam, echoed in a Times editorial last week, is protested in our letters column today by one of that policy's architects.
Losses outnumbered price advances by a modest margin in a mixed session on the stock market yesterday as traders took profits at the close of another record-breaking week for leading indicators.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -Gov. George Romney of Michigan told a group of student leaders here tonight that a person need not support his party or his party's candidate "when they depart from basic American principles."
CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- Eighteen 3-year-olds were entered in the Illinois Derby today at Sportsman's Park and the track split tomorrow's race into two nine-horse divisions.

Columbia University and 10 other Morningside Heights institutions installed a 26-year-old Negro yesterday as manager of the Bryn Mawr Hotel and said they would expand a program of social work in the controversial building.
LOS ANGELES, May 7 (UPI) -- Willie Smith's two-run homer gave the Los Angeles Angels a 5-4 victory tonight over the Kansas City Athletics. The triumph was the fifth straight for the Angels.

RHEIMS, France, May 7 -Up the street the boys were waiting for the girls to come out of school. When they walked off arm in arm in the soft May air, none gave a thought to the dusty schoolroom where it all ended.
ROME, May 7 -- Pope Paul VI summoned the 36,000-member Society of Jesus today to battle against the "frightening peril" of atheism.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, May 7 (Reuters) -- West Indies, facing Australia's first-innings score of 650 runs for six wickets declared, made a spirited reply on the third day of the fourth test here today and earned 165 for two at the close.
Litton Industries, Inc., announced yesterday its sales and earnings reached new peaks in the nine-month period ended April 30.

According to United States Embassy sources and other observers in Santo Domingo, there were never any plans for the United States Marines to invade the rebel zone or capture Colonel Caamano's headquarters.

BUENOS AIRES, May 7 (AP) -- Out-of-court settlements with the Shell Oil Company and two United States oil companies on canceled contracts have been tentatively reached by the Argentine Government, informed sources said today.
CHICAGO, May 7, (AP) -- Dave Giusti won his fifth straight game today for Houston with relief help from Jim Owens in downing the Chicago Cubs, 5-4, on a three-run homer by Bob Aspromonte.
BOSTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Cassius Clay-Sonny Liston heavyweight title fight was transferred today from Boston to Lewistown, Me., and scheduled for the same date, May 25.
THE time-honored theory has been that little girls played with dolls in preparation for the day when they would be caring for real babies of their own.

NEW CENTERVILLE, Pa., May 7 -- Ch. Harmo Rough N' Ready, a black miniature poodle owned and bred by Mrs. Anna H. Mosher's Harmo Kennels of Amherst, N.H., led a field of 152 today to win best-in-show honors at the William Penn Poodle Club specialty.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., May 7 (AP) -- Edmund Sallee, a farmer who was one of the jurors voting for conviction, said: "It would have had to be on manslaughter because we could not have come that near to a conviction at all on any higher charge."
The following books of a religious and inspirational nature have been published recently:
WHEN Mia Fonssagrives, who is 23 years old, arrived from Paris Thursday afternoon, her father met her at the airport with a container of milk.
BOSTON, May 7 (AP) -- Luis Tiant pitched a five-hitter tonight in leading the Cleveland Indians to a 5-1 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.

PITTSBURGH, May 7 (AP) -- Manny Mota's two-out single drove in Gene Freese with the decisive run tonight in a three-run ninth-inning rally that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 7 -- It just wasn't a good day for golf today. Jim Bostwick found this out when he tried to get out of a trap guarding the second green during the opening round of the third Ray Torgerson Memorial invitation tournament at the Cherry Valley Club.

After spending much time away from home, church and community, a seaman arrives in the port of New York. In addition to the comfort of moderately-priced lodging, he needs the concern of others for his personal well-being.

The general congregation of the Society of Jesus comes at a time when many of the 36,000 members of the order are in a mood for change. But, with so many matters of ecclesiastical discipline left unsettled by the Ecumenical Council, the Jesuits are not sure how fast they should proceed in updating their society, which took the lead in combating the Reformation in 16th-century Europe.

Old and precious icons, as well as modern devotional pictures of the Russian and Greek Orthodox Churches will be shown from tomorrow at the Parish House of St. Jame's Church at Madison Avenue and 71st Street.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 7 (AP) -- Pakistan has sent a letter to the President of the United Nations' Security Council stating that "during the last few days the bulk of the Indian armed forces have been moved close to Pakistan's borders and are grouped in offensive formations, apparently for aggression against Pakistan."

LOS ANGELES, May 7 (AP) -- Vicente Saldivar of Mexico retained his world featherweight championship tonight by knocking out the previously unbeaten Raul Rojas of San Pedro, Calif., with 10 seconds remaining in the 15th and final round.
It was a day of visits for visiting royalty.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -President Johnson spoke on television to the people of Western Europe today, and by indirection criticized the policies of President de Gaulle as destructive of Atlantic unity.
The British pound fell yesterday in quiet dealings on foreign exchange markets here.

Many television viewers in the metropolitan area who tuned to New York channels yesterday were surprised to receive Nebraska, Missouri and Florida points instead. It was the result of freakish signal transmission caused by temperature inversion.

Benjamin Britten's comic opera "Albert Herring" was given a thoroughly delightful presentation by the Opera Workshop at the Hunter College Playhouse last night. The fine cast, without exception, was visually and musically pleasing, and the splendid little orchestra conducted by William Terrasch made the most of Britten's polished, witty score.

THE B.B.C. Symphony Orchestra's concert last night presented a retrospective view of the composers in the first half of this century who have been most influential on those of the second half. Pierre Boulez, the French avant-garde composer who is a guest conductor with the British orchestra, was responsible for the program.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled illegal today a contract clause that would let union brick layers refuse to work on a job employing any men working for less than union pay rates.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -Administration forces mounted a major campaign in the Senate today to defeat an amendment to the voting rights bill that would prohibit poll taxes in state and local elections.

A second trial for George Whitmore Jr. on a charge of attempting to rape Mrs. Elba Borrero will begin May 24, a year and a day after the crime, District Attorney Aaron E: Koota of Brooklyn announced yesterday.
MEXICO CITY -- The position of the two American-owned sulphur mining and exporting companies here appeared to be deteriorating last week in the wake of dissension within the Mexican Government.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The president of Aerospace Corporation defended today the spending practices of his federally financed research concern that have been under fire in several days of Congressional hearings.
With a penny in his pocket and a yen to see the World's Fair, a 7-year-old Long Island boy climbed aboard a commuter train yesterday morning and set out for Flushing Meadow.
Government securities dealers tried yesterday to determine whether or not the recent sharp increase in business loans by New York City banks was an omen for their market.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 7 -- In continuing air strikes against North Vietnam, the United States today suffered its first plane loss since a Navy aircraft crashed April 20.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 (AP) -- Dick Tracewski singled in the winning run in the eighth inning tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the San Francisco Giants, 4-3, despite two homers by Willie Mays.

FORT WORTH, May 7 -- Two visiting foreign golfers shared the lead in the $100,000 Colonial Invitation tournament today. George Knudson of Canada, who set the pace yesterday, scored a 71 for 139. And with one of the few sub-par rounds of the tournament, Bruce Crampton of Australia equaled Knudson's 36-hole total with a two-under-par 68.

IN the crucible of the Dominican conflict there are many ironies. A prime example is the rebel chieftain and No. 1 oponent of the United States Marines, Col. Francisco Caamano Deno, who now styles himself constitutional president.

The Dynamics Corporation of America will build the final link in a new commercial system in the Caribbean that will provide instantaneous telephone and telegraph communication between the Windward and the Leeward Islands and the rest of the world.

Action was taken yesterday to throw the remnants of William Zeckendorf's realty empire into involuntary reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy law. The move was the latest and most severe blow suffered by the 59-year-old realty operator.
SAN JUAN, P.R., May 7 -Juan Bosch told his version of the Dominican revolt in an interview today.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., May 7 -- The trial of a Ku Klux Klansman for the murder of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo ended today when the jury reported it was hopelessly deadlocked after coming within two votes of conviction.

MONTREAL, May 7 (AP) -- Roger Crozier, a 23-year-old rookie goaltender, and Norm Ullman, a seasoned center, were listed today as the top players on the 1964-65 National Hockey League All-Star team after leading the Detroit Red Wings to their first regular-season championship in eight years.
One of the nation's foremost chroniclers of the Wild West and Indians can continue writing about the subject in her Greenwich Village apartment because the Governor of Nebraska came to her rescue.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 7 (UPI) -- The death toll rose to 13 today as workers dug through wreckage of hundreds of homes shattered by tornadoes that cut through 15 Minneapolis suburbs last night.
Two district champions in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches retained their titles yesterday.

NAHA, Okinawa, May 7 -- An appellate court tribunal of the Ryukyu Islands Government today overruled a lower-court decision acquitting two Communists charged with having led an unauthorized demonstration against the United States in February.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Defense Department has ruled that R.O.T.C. units will be withdrawn from any college, military school or high school that practices racial segregation.
Several blocks along Fifth Avenue that lacked street signs in a spot check three weeks ago now have at least one marker.
MILWAUKEE, May 7 -- Despite the buffeting it has received, the State Department team explaining the Administration's Vietnam policy at Midwest universities expressed encouragement today.
TOKYO, May 7 -- Premier Eisaku Sato said today that the United States had given Japan a pledge to refrain from bombing Hanoi or occupying North Vietnam.

CAIRO, May 7 -- The Egyptian Government has just completed its first factory financed primarily by a United States aid loan. The multimillion dollar plant will produce paper pulp from bagasse, an exotic name for waste from sugar cane.
The baton in the orchestra pit of the Majestic Theater these days is not being wielded by either a long-haired or a bald-headed conductor, but by an energetic Negro woman.
LEWISTON, Me., May 7 -"This will be the most wonderful thing that ever happened to Maine," Saul Feldman said today.

PARIS, May 7 -- Despite the initial success of President Johnson's program to reduce the payments deficit through voluntary restraint, Europe's financial community remains relatively unconcerned about the prospect of a dollar shortage.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 7 (AP) -The three-man military junta opposed to the rebel regime of Col. Francisco Caamano Deno resigned tonight in what appeared to be a bid by the antirebel forces for popular support.
THE coolly controlled fury of Nadine Gordimer's storytelling stands out in this new collection. It is Miss Gordimer's best book.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- There is no spring like spring in Washington. In its move northward, it has reached its full glory here three weeks ahead of New York.

ROME, May 7 (AP) -- Cliff Richey of Dallas rallied today from two sets down to defeat Giuseppe Merlo of Italy and remain the only American in the men's quarter-final round of the Italian tennis championships.

As a former professional assistant to Myron C. Taylor when he was on mission as President Roosevelt's and President Truman's personal representative to Pope Pius XII I am deeply distressed to learn from Assistant Director C. Stanley Lowell's letter to The Times of April 22 that the Protestants and Other Americans United are in a mood to light an auto-da-fe against a mission to the Vatican State.
Because a shower brought about the scratch of the "strong horse," the Gedney Farm's Sought After became the favorite in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that the United States should have consulted the Organization of American States before sending troops to the Dominican Republic.

The Benevolent Society for Retarded Children will hold its 15th annual luncheon next Saturday in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton. The guest of honor will be Dr. Robert Guthrie, associate professor of pediatrics of the State University at Buffalo.

Malcolm Frager showed in his recital last night at Philharmonic Hall that the promise of his early days as a contest winner -- he is the only pianist who has won the Leventritt and the Queen Elisabeth of Belgium competitions -- was not a false one.

Madison Avenue reaction yesterday to the conviction of one of its inhabitants on fraud charges was for the most part defensive. Advertising agency executives talked primarily of client responsibility and of their own inability to check claims made by advertisers for their products.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -Peace and mutual appreciation reigned among the nations of the Americas on one front last night as the third Inter-American Music Festival, continuing through Wednesday, began. The concert was given at the Cramton Auditorium of Howard University.
Staten Island ferry service, crippled by a strike since Tuesday, moved closer to restoration yesterday. But most regular passengers continued to use alternate means of commuting.
A $5.5 million Neighborhood Youth Corps for 2,800 persons 16 to 21 years old was proposed yesterday to prevent summer rioting in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A plan was being advanced within the Organization of American States today to form an advisory committee of prominent Latin-American leaders to help restore constitutional government in the Dominican Republic.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he would ask the Legislature next week to make the Office for the Aging a permanent agency within the Executive Department, with power to receive and disburse funds.
BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP) -- Meeting with two Federal agencies failed again today to produce any progress toward the resumption of publication by Baltimore's daily newspapers.

LOS ANGELES, May 7 (UPI) -- A former policeman accused of conspiring to libel Senator Thomas H. Kuchel pleaded guilty today to a lesser charge and publicly apologized for his "extremely serious and far-reaching" action.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- An agent of the Food and Drug Administration testified in Federal Court today that Dr. Steven Durovic, the developer of Krebiozen, told him two years ago that all the Krebiozen powder that existed then was 5 to 15 milligrams, which was kept in a Chicago bank vault.
BERLIN, May 7 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin marked the 20th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany today with a flurry of oral attacks at the United States and a jab at Communist China.

The strike that has disrupted service on the city-operated Staten Island ferryboats since last Tuesday is both illegal and inexcusable. It will become calamitous if it is extended, as some union spokesmen have threatened, into a portwide shutdown. Neither the city nor the labor movement can tolerate such an outrageous abuse of union power.

" I Do So Politely: A Voice from the South," by Robert Canzoneri, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on June 10. The title employs an utterance of former Governor Ross Barnett as he barred the door of the University of Mississippi to James Meredith.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- With more problems than a bureaucrat who left the lights on, the New York Yankees limped into Washington today and promptly lost their second double-header in a week.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee went out of its way today to castigate a proposal made by its Senate counterpart that the present foreign aid program be terminated in 1967.

The cornerstone for the new Arturo Toscanini Junior High School at Teller Avenue and East 165th Street in the Bronx was laid yesterday in ceremonies attended by members of the late maestro's immediate family.

LONDON, May 7 -- The Labor party's left wing reacted angrily today to what it saw as the possibility of a Government retreat on steel nationalization after the surprising compromise offered in the House of Commons last night.

TORONTO, May 7 -- Relatively tighter monetary conditions have become apparent in the Canadian economy in the last few weeks. The condition has been signaled by a four-week rise in the Treasury bill rate and by art expansion in the monetary supply at a pace that some bankers say is slower than that needed to accommodate the present demand for loans.

NEW DELHI, Saturday, May 8 -- Sheik Mohammad Abdullah, leader of the Kashmiri Moslems, was detained under the Defense of India Rules this morning when he returned after a trip to North Africa and the Middle East.
President Johnson was at his best in reaffirming the ideal of a united, prosperous and responsible Atlantic Community in his talk marking the twentieth anniversary of V-E Day.

WINDSOR, Conn. -- As the Farmington River followed its curlicue course among protective maple trees, its surface was disturbed only by an occasional floating log and its peace was disrupted only by the raucous caw of a jay -- a sound that, in the quiet of the Connecticut countryside, seemed ear-splitting.
Republican state and city leaders conferred here again yesterday on the party's choice to run against Mayor Wagner in November, but reached no decision.
The second performance here of the Royal Ballet's new "Swan Lake" was given at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with three major cast changes.

NOBODY seems to know why polka dots are associated with spring, but they are, and Altman's will soon introduce a line of polka-dotted paper products and desk accessories that are as perky as the first robin. Among the paper things are tablecloths, napkins (cocktail and lunch), plates (salad and lunch) and cups.

TWO very fine exhibitions opened this week, one at Asia House, 112 East 64th Street, called "Mingei: Folk Arts of Old Japan," and the other a selection of drawings from the collection of Janos Scholz at the Metropolitan Museum.

MACKINAW CITY, Mich., May 7 (AP) -- The freighter Cedarville of the United States Steel Corporation rolled over and sank in the fog-shrouded Straits of Mackinac today after a collision with a Norwegian vessel.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- An Interior Department biologist testified today that while striped bass caught in the Hudson River are edible, he didn't consider them palatable.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 7 (UPI) -- Heavy fighting was reported today to have broken out in mountainous northern Iraq between the Iraqi armed forces and Kurdish tribesmen demanding autonomy. Losses were reported to be heavy on both sides.

ALBANY, May 7 -- The Legislature may decide to make the New York harness-racing season virtually year-round. It also is considering whether to open a $3 window at harness tracks and whether to introduce quarter-horse racing in the state.
THE HAGUE, May 7 -- Premier Joseph M.L.T. Cals informed members of the Cabinet today about the romance between Crown Princess Beatrix and a West German diplomat, Klaus von Amsberg.
