OKLAHOMA CITY, May 7 (UPI) -- The vote of a fourth justice of the State Supreme Court, now dead, was involved in the $150,000 Selected Investments bribery case, a key witness testified at the senate impeachment trial of Justice N.B. Johnson today.

VANCOUVER, B.C., April 30 -- Vancouver people seem to to be home-loving types. Houses constructed to conform to a cliffside, wooded ravine or rocky promontory are favorite topics of conversation here. The possibilities of unusual dwellings in this Pacific Ocean setting are boundless.
MONTREAL, May 7 (Canadian Press) -- The first vertical-take-off-and-landing aircraft designed and built in Canada made its first flights today at the Montreal plant of Canadair, Ltd.

A "stand-in" by 200 antiwar demonstrators at Columbia University, locking arms before a brigade of the university's Naval reserve unit, forced cancellation yesterday of the training corps' annual awards ceremony.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 7 (UPI) -- Searchers failed to find the body today of a honeymooning railroad heiress who disappeared from a small boat yesterday in what detectives described as an "unfortunate accident."

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 7 -- The tour of South America by W. Averell Harriman has developed a loose consensus that the Organization of American States must develop better tools against Communist subversion.

ADEN, May 7 -- The People's Socialist party, the South Arabian League and the Yemen-based Committee for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen (Aden and the protectorates) ill merge with the Organization for the Liberation of the Occupied South to seek to oust the British from South Arabia.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 -The crew of a trans-Pacific air freighter today described a desperate 30-minute struggle with a berserk harness racehorse that ended when they killed the valuable animal with a fire ax 8,000 feet over the ocean.
NEWARK, May 7 -- Newark will train 100 school dropouts as police clerks, aides of the Police Athletic League and school crossing guards as part of the campaign against poverty.
FALL descended on Seventh Avenue and environs in earnest this week as Bonnie Cashin followed Rudi Gernreich's knitwear collection with her leather and tweed fashions for Philip Sills.

An instructor pilot of Eastern Air Lines testified yesterday that there was "a good possibility" he could lose control of a plane if he were to fly through the turbulent wake of a jet while in an extreme bank.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -- Bob Gibson allowed only a fourth-inning single by Johnny Callison tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 2-0.

At her first show Thursday night at The Balcony, a downstairs boite in the World's Fair Bourbon Street area, Gail Gordon, a 24-year-old stripper, removed two gloves, two shoes, one stocking and a dress to the tune of "Tea for Two."

PRE-EMPTIVE responses by the partner of the opening bidder are relatively rare, and should be employed with discretion. If the opening bid is one club, for example, a response of three hearts or four hearts would show a long broken suit, at least 7 cards in length, and a fair expectation of making the contract opposite a minimum opening bid.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced one-tenth of 1 per cent to 101.7 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended May 4, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 7 (AP) -The XB-70A flew its fastest yet today, about 1,700 miles an hour, but landed earlier than planned because of a mysterious buffeting effect.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -President Johnson signed today the bill appropriating an extra $700 million for the Vietnamese war. He said the appropriation constituted a message that the United States "will do whatever must be done" to protect South Vietnam.
Inventories of manufactured goods held by business in this country rose by $900 million in March on a seasonally adjusted basis, nearly three times the rise for February.

RUNNEYMEDE, England, May 7 (Reuters) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy will watch Queen Elizabeth unveil a simple white stone plinth in the heart of the English countryside here next Friday as Britain's permanent memorial to President Kennedy.

A civil action in Federal Court here alleges that $900,000 of the funds of the Belgian American Educational Foundational was given illegally to the Herbert Hoover Birthplace Foundation in 1962 at the urging of Allan Hoover and Lewis L. Strauss.
ALBANY, May 7 -- A last-minute effort to resolve the complex legal struggle over reapportionment failed today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 7 -- Dick Aeschliman of Bermuda outsailed Rene Coudert of the Larchmont Yacht Club today by 1 minute 2 seconds to even the two-of-three-race series for the King Edward VII Gold Cup at 1-1.
ALBANY, May 7 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Federal Appalachian Regional Commission today to study the eligibility of 13 New York counties for Federal aid under the anti-poverty program.

The Treasury announced in Washington yesterday that holders of 94.3 per cent of $8,436,000,000 of notes maturing next Saturday had agreed to exchange them for two reopened issues of Government securities.
ALBANY, May 7 -- The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court upheld today the right of the State Liquor Authority to issue licenses for additional retail liquor stores.
Mayor Wagner came out emphatically yesterday in favor of a reduction in the price of admission to the World's Fair "during the evening hours."
The trend toward labor peace in the garment industry continued yesterday as more employers reached agreements with District 65 of the Retail Wholesale and Department Store Workers.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- Three major airlines asked the United States Court of Appeals yesterday to uphold a finding that a Civil Aeronautics Board order affecting their right to carry air cargo was illegal.

The New York Club of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs will hold its 12th annual Sojourner Truth Awards Luncheon tomorrow in the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana. Borough President Constance Baker Motley of Manhattan will be among the speakers.
Psychiatrists from throughout the country heard an appeal yesterday, at the close of a five-day meeting here, that they clarify their "technical jargon" and become more active in political affairs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 7 -- Canada suggested today that nonnuclear states cannot be expected to abstain forever from obtaining atomic weapons while the superpowers keep their atomic arsenals intact.
The Negro spiritual leader of 3.2 million United Presbyterians will speak in a Roman Catholic church in Brewster, N.Y., on Wednesday.

President Johnson incorporated in his V-E speech what amounted to an endorsement of his special commission's recommendation for increased trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. NEW LONDON, Conn., May 7 -- The maritime administrator of the United States Department of Commerce said here last night that cargo ships might some day reach speeds of more than 100 miles an hour.

MEXICO CITY, May 7 -- The most determined effort to date toward economic integration of Latin America is shaping up here in the 11th biennial session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America (E.C.L.A.).

All excuses for delay having been used up, Mayor Wagner and the Democratic leadership in the Legislature must now decide how they will fill the revenue hole in New York City's 1965-66 expense budget. The gap between revenues and expected expenditure is presumed, from official hints, to be about $250 million despite the most generous treatment on state and Federal aid that the city has ever enjoyed.

Angry new charges were exchanged yesterday on the issue of whether a Reform Democrat leader in Greenwich Village, Edward I. Koch, asked for new district lines to get rid of the Italians in his district.

MILWAUKEE, May 7 -- Dr. William D. McElroy, chairman of a special committee on population of the National Academy of Sciences, announced today that the committee would call for increased Federal action to encourage birth control.

SANTO DOMINGO, May 7 (UPI) -- General Imbert was sworn in today by Supreme Court President Julio Cuello in the National Congress building. The general said he had joined the National Government of Reconstruction to save the Dominican people from Communist dictatorship.
Prices of wheat for future delivery advanced again despite profit taking on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Soybean and other grain futures all declined.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today the appointment of John M. Leddy as Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 7 -- The Soviet Union and Cuba renewed their attack today on the legality of the decision by the Organization of American States to send an inter-American force to the Dominican Republic.
Leland Hayward is bringing the new musical "How Green Was My Valley," based on Richard Llewellyn's novel and the Academy Award-winning film, to Broadway in October.
A recruiting team of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference said yesterday it had enlisted 100 volunteers from New York colleges for Negro voter registration work in the South this summer.
SANTO DOMINGO, May 7 -Colonel Caamano affirmed to day that his "constitutionalist" regime "would prefer not to see the forces of any nation in our country."
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7 -- Government officials and big-business leaders agreed today that the economic outlook was good, with no real inflation in sight.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Chester F. Carlson of Pittsford, N.Y., the inventor of xerography, will receive his 37th patent next week. It is assigned to Xerox Cor poration, Rochester, N.Y., which built a flourishing business in copying equipment around his origi nal concept of "electrophotography," patented in 1942.
Any new tax is likely to hurt the city's economy to some extent, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday, but he said his problem was to find a tax that would hurt the least.
A Navy icebreaker has reached a rocky, hilly island that is drifting down into the warm Atlantic Ocean. Her mission is to rescue 18 residents before the island melts.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 8 (Reuters) -- Three leaders of an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow the government last Feb. 19 were sentenced to death by a military tribunal last night.

El Morocco, the supper club that has never been accused of being anything more serious than a zebra-striped playpen for rich adults, has had better nights. But the activities there Thursday will do for 1965.
MOSCOW, May 7 (AP) -The Cleveland Orchestra tonight completed a five-day stand in Yerevan, capital of Soviet Armenia, but the audience of 1,200 refused to go home.

A block of 129,200 shares of Union Carbide crossed the ticker tape at 1:45 P.M. yesterday and thereby earned a niche in Wall Street history as the largest single trade, in dollar value, ever made on the New York Stock Exchange.

LONDON, May 7 -- A resounding insurance row is expected to break out next week in the London financial district. Barring a last minute peace move, it could mean the biggest proxy fight here since Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., tried to win control of Courtaulds, Ltd., in 1962.
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson joined with city officials and the public yesterday in New York's annual Salute to Spring ceremony. But spring was conspicuous by its absence.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 7 (AP) -- The mutual savings and loan associations in the state were urged by Gov. Richard J. Hughes today to lead the way in tearing down the barriers that prevent Negroes from buying homes in all-white neighborhoods.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 7 (AP) -- Danny Cater's three-run homer in the seventh inning tonight was the deciding blow in a four-homer attack that led the Chicago White Sox to a 13-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

The issue of equal time on television assumed international proportions last night after President Johnson became the first head of state to request and obtain time on the Early Bird satellite to speak directly to the peoples of foreign countries.
A 40-year-old man was shot to death in a coal yard in the Bronx yesterday after he had attacked one of two patrolmen summoned to arrest him.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 7 -- Senegal asked today for a Security Council meeting "as soon as possible," to hear complaints of "repeated violations of Senegal's airspace and territory by the Portuguese authorities."
PITTSBURGH, May 7. -- The number of branches of the Young Men's Christian Assohas been reduced from 432 in 1963 to 135, national leaders of the association were told today.

The mistrial yesterday in the case of Collie LeRoy Wilkins Jr. marked the fourth time in the last 10 years that Southern prosecutors have failed to achieve guilty verdicts in major civil rights murder trials.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) -- President Johnson selected 15 panel chairmen today for a White House Conference on Natural Beauty May 24 and 25.
Stocks edged lower in active trading yesterday for the fifth day in a row on the American Stock Exchange.

Progress toward a common approach to revision of international load-line regulations was reported last night after a week-long conference attended by representatives of seven of the world's leading ship-classification societies.
Steel prices fell sharply on the London stock exchange yesterday amid uncertainties following the narrow Parliamentary vote for renationalization of the industry.

Protests from irate American Indian organizations led the Calvert Distillers Company yesterday to announce the cancellation of a nationwide advertising campaign depicting a warbonneted Sioux brave raising a glass of whisky.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Postal inspectors are near a break in their investigation of the biggest cash robbery in American history, the $1.55 million raid on a mail truck in Plymouth Mass., in 1962, it was learned today.
ROME, May 7 -- Additional shooting for the Dino de Laurentiis production of "The Bible," directed by John Huston, started today with New York's Living Theater company cast as inhabitants of Sodom.
Armed Forces Week began yesterday with an open house program at Governors Island, headquarters of the First United States Army.

BOTH of these beautiful books were written expressly for the Nature and Science Library, as third and fourth contributions to a series sponsored by the American Museum of Natural History for young people of junior high school age.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York won the United States Women's Chess Championship -- the Lucille Kellner Memorial -- last night at the Henry Hudson Hotel. By defeating Dr. Helen Weissenstein of New York in the final round of the 11-player round robin, Mrs. Gresser clinched the title by a score of 8 to 2, consisting of seven wins, two draws and one loss.
HAYNEVILLE, Ala., May 8 -- A woman shopkeeper here told a pair of visitors last night that she was surprised at the outcome of the Viola Gregg Liuzzo murder trial.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The Labor Department is completing plans for a program that will send slum youths who have dropped out of school into the fields this summer to harvest crops.
TRIPOLI, Liyba, May 8 -- Voting began quietly today to elect a new Parliament.

PRIMROSE, Neb., May 8 (UPI) -- A tornado streaked down the main street of this Nebraska community of 117 persons tonight, killing four persons and flattening most of the buildings in town. Only the schoolhouse, part of its roof ripped away, stood among piles of rubble that was once the business district.

WHILE Jon, the doctor's boy, is the principal actor in this warm, unsentimental tale of life in rural Sweden some decades ago, it is the youngster's regard for his father, and the parent's great understanding of his son that form the central theme.

JASPER, Tex., May 8 (UP) -- President Johnson dedicated the new $61 million Sam Rayburn Dam today by long distance telephone. He called the huge steel and concrete structure "a fitting tribute" to the late Speaker of the House of Representatives.

Flag Raiser did not require a pace-setter to win the $60,000 Withers mile in 1:34 1/5 yesterday at Aqueduct. Isidor Bieber's renowned front-runner led his eight rivals all the way except for a few strides at the start.
The majority leader of the state Senate predicted yesterday the passage of a bill providing state aid for New York City's drive against slums.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 8 (UPI) -- An Indian chief, a publisher, two district judges and the Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court testified today for Justice N.B. Johnson, who is accused of selling his vote in two Supreme Court cases for $10,000.

PATRICIA SEXTON'S problem is that she has absorbed so much about Spanish Harlem she can't wait to get it all down on paper. In attempting to be informative, fair, accurate and comprehensive all at the same time, she keeps the reader busy just trying to sort out all the ideas thrown at him in the early part of her book.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- After the last gun was silenced in World War II, a man in a six-button suit and Beatle haircut appeared from a time machine one night and wandered among a barracks-full of servicemen who were awaiting discharges.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 8 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club, skippered by Rene Coudert, retained the 58-year-old King Edward VII Gold Cup for the United States today.

TOKYO -- Japanese television manufacturers are banking on color to rescue the industry from an ominous slump resulting from saturation of the market. The town had 16 churches, 14 hotels, more than 50 saloons. The future looked bright, even in the heavy rain that soaked the already sodden Conemaugh Valley, dangerously raising the water level at the old South Fork Dam, 12 miles to the east.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- An 85-mile stretch of scenic shoreline running northwest from this British Columbian metropolis has been dubbed the Sunshine Coast, and with ample justification. The area's many forested islands, inlets, streams and beaches are a matchless haven for vacationists of every stripe -- from motoring sightseers to fishermen intent on landing a record-breaking salmon.

In Hollywood, a high-pressure town in which character-assassination is a sport, the very mention of Disney's name seems to inspire purest veneration. Among fellow showmen, Disney is exalted as a master film-maker, animator, amusement-park builder and overall creative genius.

NEW HAVEN, May 9 -- Harvard's track team scored a 108-46 dual meet victory today over Yale. It was the greatest number of points scored by the Crimson against Yale in their 74-year rivalry. Harvard's double winners were sophomore Wayne Anderson, who won both the 100-yard and 220-yard dashes, and Aggrey Awori, who won the 120-yard high hurdles and the broad jump.

TRUE to its promise, the Royal Canadian Mint has announced that orders for 1965 prooflike coin sets will again be accepted. The reopening, effective immediately, came almost exactly four months after the unprecedented January cutoff.

MONTREAL, May 8 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson spoke last night of "cooperative federalism" as the answer to Canada's constitutional problems, and warned that the federal Government would never "betray or surrender" its responsibilities.

TWO of television's most sophisticated shows are, ironically, religious. They usually receive excellent notices, yet their audience is only about 11 million because they are scheduled on Sunday mornings during the 10 to 11 hour when most people are leaving for church or too numb to go anywhere.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -President Johnson named new ambassadors to Belgium, the Ivory Coast and Gambia today and ordered his chief talent scout to conduct a study of policy-making Government jobs.

AMHERST, Mass. -- Famous as the land of codfish and baked beans, and of Paul Revere, the Old North Church, the Pilgrims and Plymouth Rock, the State of Massachusetts should also be hailed as a refuge of floral beauty during May and the first part of June.

Prominent persons in the New York area will meet over cocktails on May 17 to inaugurate the Friends of Channel 13, a group in support of the nonprofit, noncommercial television station. The party will be held in the Promenade of the New York State Theater at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

I was amazed by the lack of confidence in the teen-ager of 1965 as expressed by Phyllis Lee Levin in "How to Succeed as a Teen-ager" (April 18). I agree that self-confidence and sureness of oneself are definitely the basis of success during the teen-age years, but I do not feel that these traits come from any particular religion or financial situation.

I'M like most youngsters in one respect: I like to read about the restless pioneer who turns his back on the security of home and heads west into the vast and colorful unknown. Give me a book about a mountain man, a buffalo hunter, a gold seeker, a homesteader or a cowhand, and I settle back with vast contentment.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -Playing in a city familiar with crises of all sorts, the New York Yankees regrouped their tattered forces today and delayed doomsday by defeating the Washington Senators, 7-3.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -This island is primarily a summer resort, having left far behind the times when merchants closed shop at noon and went out for a sail, knowing that no business would be done for the rest of the languid day.

FORT WORTH, May 9 -- A rain check will permit spectators and the local waterfowl to view the fourth round of the Colonial Invitation golf tournament tomorrow. The first cancellation of a round in 12 months on the tour was necessitated today by a storm and left 12,500 spectators disappointed.
Three organizations announced yesterday that they would ask the three-judge Federal Statutory Court considering reapportionment to direct that it be handled by a nonpartisan agency.

I want to commend you for your strong editorial endorsement [May 2] of the anti-poll tax amendment sponsored by 39 Senators and due for a vote in the Senate on Tuesday, May 11, If the bill passes without it, the poll tax will remain as the last bar to Negro voting rights in the South.
Miss Bea Richards, star of the Broadway production of James Baldwin's play, "The Amen Corner," spoke yesterday at Spencer Memorial Presbyterian Church 95 Clinton Street, Brooklyn.

THIRTY-FOUR high school seniors -- 20 from Trinity, 14 from Collegiate (which had a soccer match going simultaneously) -- volunteered to take part in a seminar on "social security" this weekend as guests of the Four Seasons restaurant.

ROME, May 9 -- Pope Paul VI, addressing a crowd in St. Peter's Square, prayed today that "progress and prosperity will not serve to give arms into the hands of new generations, but tools of peace and work and methods of aid for which there is need."

POLAND SPRINGS, May 9 -- For the first time in the history of closed-circuit television of heavyweight championship boxing, there will be no local blackout for the Clay-Liston fight, an executive of Inter-Continental Promotions said today.

A FRIEND and sometime colleague of Geraldine Stutz, the perennially college-girlish president of Henri Bendel, hazarded a guess last week about the new hairdressing salon that opens today in the 57th Street specialty store.
PITTSBURGH, May 9 (AP) -- The national council of the Young Men's Christian Association moved today to end racial discrimination in Y.M.C.A.'s.
ATLANTA, May 9 -- Nine Southern Governors charged tonight that new school desegregation guidelines by the United States Office of Education would jeopardize public schools in many areas.

QUINHON, South Vietnam, May 9 -- More than 11 per cent of the people of Binhdinh, South Vietnam's most heavily populated province, have been displaced from their homes and are living as refugees in cities or district centers.

The Urban League of Westchester will hold its annual dinner on May 25 at the Glen Island Casino in New Rochelle, N.Y. Mrs. Frederick Green of Mount Vernon is chairman of the evening, and Mrs. Robert Popper is co-chairman.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., May 9 -- Uncle Max, Neal Shapiro's gray gelding, won a tense duel with Betsy Gerson's Red Shoes in a jumpoff today to capture the open jumper championship at the Saratoga Springs horse show.
LONDON, May 9 -- The chairman of the Labor party, Ray Gunter, pleaded with party members today to stop quarreling in public over steel nationalization.

MANY department stores carry camp clothes and equipment. Some have special camp shops that are open now or will open in the next week or two. In addition to clothes and equipment, the shops often provide name tapes and camp insignia.

The head of a major Jewish Orthodox organization criticized secular and lay Jewish groups last night for attempts to involve themselves in the Vatican Council move to absolve Jews for the crucifixion of Jesus Christ.
ANNISTON, Ala., May 9 (UPI) -- The three Ku Klux Klansmen accused of killing Mrs. Viola Liuzzo, civil rights worker from Detroit, marched side by side today in a 10-block Klan parade.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- Ernie Banks slammed two home runs and Glenn Beckert hit his first major league homer in leading the Chicago Cubs to a 7-1 victory today after Houston had taken the first game of the double-header, 11-5.
The April 29 article by John Devlin on new reading techniques shows that there is really nothing new in teaching.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) -- A young American scientist doing research in the Antarctic has apparently lost his way in a blowing snowstorm and wandered to his death, the National Science Foundation reported today.

HAVANA, May 9 -- United States actions in the Dominican Republic have strengthened the ties between Havana and Moscow and are strengthening pro-Moscow forces in Premier Fidel Castro's Government, it is generally agreed by Western diplomats here.

LOS ANGELES, May 9 (AP) -- Jose Cardinal slammed a homer and single and stole home, and Fred Newman scored his fourth straight pitching victory today as the Los Angeles Angels beat the Kansas City Athletics, 5-3.
BOSTON, May 9 (AP) -- Fred Whitfield, Cleveland's first baseman, drove in six runs while collecting seven hits today as the Indians defeated the Boston Red Sox twice, 9-4 and 10-7.
A bit of Spain turned up at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday by way of the World's Fair.

It was Tom Vaughn at the piano, Charlie Smith on the drums, Paul Brown on the bass fiddle and Pastor Jack Gensel in the pulpit. And it was probably the swingingest Eastertide Sunday anywhere in New York.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 9 -- A considerable number of mothers, nearly as many fathers and at least twice as many children were among the 1,000 persons who overflowed the Promenade Care at Roosevelt Raceway today.

When the Rev. Vivian Symons ascended the pulpit at Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, yesterday he was introduced by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin Minifie, as a miracle worker, a man who had moved a church and rebuilt it, almost singlehandedly.

SANTO DOMINGO, May 9 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Antonio Imbert Barrera's offerto permit the rebels to lay down their arms and leave the country without difficulty was brushed aside today by the rebel leader, Col. Francisco Caamano Deno.

THE most exciting moments of the Royal Ballet's weekend performances at the Metropolitan Opera House were provided by the dancing of Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev in "Swan Lake" on Saturday night.

TORONTO, May 9 -- Two weeks after irritating manufacturers by refusing to cut corporate income taxes in his new budget, Walter L. Gordon, the self-confident Finance Minister of Canada, has annoyed bankers with his new banking bills.

The Argentine apparel industry, the largest in Latin America, has great potential but its growth is limited by a dearth of adequate machinery and skilled workers and ex cessive restrictions on imports. This is the view of a visiting manufacturer from that country.
MOSCOW, May 9 -- The Soviet Union launched an instrumented space station toward the moon today for an unspecified series of scientific observations.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday he would rather see the Republican nomination for Mayor go to any one of the three Republicans now most prominently mentioned for it than to I.D. Robbins or any other Democrat.

ROME, May 9 -- Apparently in line with the new policy indicated by the Kremlin's partial rehabilitation of Stalin, the Italian Communist newspaper L'Unita published are interview today by its Moscow correspondent with Marshal Vasily D. Sokolovsky, who fought under Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov and later became commander of the Russian occupation troops in Germany.
A Harlem neighborhood celebrated yesterday the opening of a combination park and playground on what had been a rubbish-strewn vacant lot.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Senate Subcommittee on National Security set the stage today for the renewal of its security hearings with a memorandum sharply critical of ambiguity in foreign policy and of overextending national commitments.

BERLIN, May 9 -- The Action Committee for the United States of Europe, responding today to President Johnson's call to complete the unfinished business of the Atlantic Alliance, renewed an appeal for European political union and partnership with the United States.
STONY POINT, N.Y., May 9 -- A last-minute effort is being made to prevent the Palisades Interstate Park system from acquiring Iona Island, an important naval arsenal in both World Wars.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 9 (UPI) -- The Minnesota Twins moved within a half-game of the American League lead today by defeating the first-place Chicago White Sox, 6-1.
NEW DELHI, May 9 -- Scattered violence continued in Kashmir today, but reports tonight indicated that the police had the situation under control.
The Beatrice Foods Company reported over the weekend for the fiscal year ended Feb. 28.

The Waterfront Commission is convinced that a major campaign is under way to destroy its effectiveness.

With rare bipartisan agreement and a complete unanimity even rarer, the New York Legislature has approved Governor Rockefeller's most important program measure of this session -- the $1.7 billion fight on water pollution. Amid all the disappointments of a chaotic, often wrong-headed, session this will be remembered as a landmark accomplishment.

HIS friends in San Francisco's bay area tossed a rousing testimonial dinner in honor of Ernie Nevers the other night and that will have to set an Olympic record for delayed tributes. It's been 34 years since the bone-crunching Ernie last splintered a football line, but he's been such an estimable fellow that any recognition is richly deserved.
Seafaring nations of the Far East face monumental tasks in raising the standards of recruitment and employment of maritime workers, according to the International Labor Organization.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- The University of Chicago said today that one of its professors had developed a simple, inexpensive and reliable method for diagnosing cancer of the womb. About 14,000 women die of uterine cancer in the United States each year.

At 2:10 P.M. on May 7, 1915, the Cunard Line's biggest and most elegant steamship, the Lusitania, six days out of New York, was torpedoes off the Irish coast by a German U-boat. The Lusitania shuddered; there was a second violent explosion near where the single torpedo had struck, and the giant liner listed heavily to starboard. Eighteen minutes later she sank, taking with her over a thousand passengers and crew.

A comprehensive plan for a $6-million-a-year investment in academic research and education was proposed yesterday to bring better order into the development envisioned for the New York metropolitan area in the next 20 years.

ALBANY, May 9 -- The sponsor of the bill to make offtrack betting legal in New York City fought today to save the measure from defeat in the Legislature.

" Man on Another World," by Gosta Ehrensvard, Swedish biochemist, will be published on May 25 by the University of Chicago Press. He writes: "There is a feeling of departure in the air," meaning that man is thinking of departing from Earth.

BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP) -- Brooks Robinson batting with a fractured right thumb, pinch-hit a single, then scored the winning run in the 12th inning of the second game to give the Baltimore Orioles a sweep over the Detroit Tigers, 7-1 and 5-4 in a double-header today.

As winner of the 1964 Leventritt Award, the violinist Itzhak Perlman was assured engagements with seven major American orchestras. Yesterday after noon at Philharmonic Hall, the 20-year-old Israeli violinist had his day with the New York Philharmonic.

The Coast Guard is pursuing ways to furnish positive and unmistakable radar identification of objects -- such as lightships and icebergs -- that are dangerous to merchant mariners.
Six survivors of Nazi death camps stood on the platform of Hunter College auditorium yesterday afternoon and lighted six candles in memory of six million Jews who died at the hands of the Nazis.

NEW HAVEN, May 9 -- Two Yale golfers and two from Pennsylvania survived the first two rounds of match play today and advanced to the semi-finals of the Eastern Intercollegiate golf championships at the Yale course.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had some advice yesterday for a young lieutenant in the Army Reserve -- don't become a general.

A three-judge Federal district court will convene here today to review the progress that has been made in executing its mandate of last July. The creation of a Special Water Conservation Bureau was announced yesterday by Armand D'Angelo, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

Nearly 1,000 persons attended a benefit for the High School of Performing Arts last night at the 46th Street Theater. Eartha Kitt, the singer, Diana Sands and Janet Margolin, the actresses, and ether graduates of the school were in the three-hour show.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Republican leader in the House said today that his party "really shouldn't bother about a [Presidential] candidate in 1968" if it fails to pick up more governorships and Congressional seats next year.

PITTSBURGH, May 9 -- Steel shipments seem headed for new records. Shipments of most mills set new highs in March and again in April. By the end of last week, it appeared the whole steel industry was moving toward six-month and full-year records.

" Ballads, Blues, and Songs of Our Times" was the name of a folk-music program presented at Town Hall Saturday night by Sing Out! magazine.

The city of San Francisco is enjoying the largest boom in office-building construction in its history.

Men and women are different; and one of the key differences is that they can be intensely emotional about different things.

Schultz.

Mayor Wagner's bid for a fourth term is keyed to three issues -- winning the war against crime, routing the last of the county bosses and creating "the Great City in the Great Society." Top administration strategists have expressed in separate interviews the strong belief that these issues will be the main ones in a situation in which the opposition is split and disorganized and lacks focus on both issues and candidates.
BUFFALO, May 10 -- The bank accounts of a number of Democratic and Republican officials have been subpoenaed in the state's investigation of this city's garage purchase scandal.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A National Labor Relations Board trial examiner ruled today that Grossinger's, the resort hotel near Liberty, N.Y., had committed unfair labor practices in fending off a union organizing drive.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Tuesday, May 11 (Reuters) -- Shell, Caltex Ceylon, Ltd., and the Esso Standard Eastern oil companies have agreed to accept 55 million rupees (about $8 million) compensation for assets taken over for the state-run Ceylon Petroleum Corporation, a Government spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Retail sales in April declined slightly from the March level, according to preliminary, estimates, the Commerce Department reported today.
THE word "new" has an odd incantatory value. In Ralph E. Lapp's lively and controversial volume it defines a scientific power elite -- and dramatizes the atomic revolution of 20-odd years ago.

Five ferries ran between Staten Island and Manhattan yesterday, carrying about a third of the 22,000 commuters who normally use the service during the rush hours. It was the seventh day of a strike by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy has accepted an invitation from Assemblyman Stanley Steingut, chairman of the Kings County Democratic Committee, to speak at the organization's annual dinner May 20, Mr. Steingut announced yesterday.

BOSTON, May 10 -- Mickey Mantle returned to the New York Yankees' line-up with a roar tonight, hitting a single, double and home run and driving in two runs. But Carl Yastrzemski trumped the Yankees' ace with two home runs and three runs batted in to give the Boston Red Sox a 3-2 victory.
A policy row caused by the infusion of outside money into Berkshire Hathaway, Inc., rocked the 76-year-old textile company yesterday and resulted in the resignation of two top officers.

CAIRO, May 10 -- The Egyptian authorities are quietly scrapping a plan to offer a bargain rate to tourists traveling alone, informed sources say, because they found that American travel agencies were refusing to sell the economy package.
STRASBOURG, France, May 10 (Reuters) -- The European Economic Community's Parliament adopted a resolution today in favor of increased trade with Communist countries, especially in Eastern Europe.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- Mayor James H.J. Tate said today the city of Philadelphia could do nothing toward integrating Girard College "unless something is done first by the Supreme Court."
An extensive study of the possible use of data-processing techniques is now being made by wholesalers of wines and distilled spirits through their trade association.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 10 -- A youth board to help prevent and control juvenile delinquency was established by the Nassau County Board of Supervisors today.

Harvard and Cornell are seeded in all six events in the 20th regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges. The championships for heavyweight and lightweight crews will be held Saturday over a 2,000-meter course on Lake Quinsigamond at Worcester, Mass.
LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- Leaders of a world shipping organization announced a landlubber's solution today to the problem of collisions in the Strait of Dover: a two-way traffic system.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- The Association of National Advertisers, Inc., opened its annual "open" spring meeting here today with association officials extremely closed-mouthed about what is expected to be the highlight of the two-and-a-half-day meeting.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., May 10 -- On Tulip Lane here flowering shrubs have burst into lovely bloom -- as they have on Thrush Lane, Sugar Maple Road, Heather Lane, Thimble Road and the countless amiable ways that wander with finely calculated precision through this former expanse of potato fields in mid-Nassau County.

A 5 per cent gain in sales and profits in the second half of 1965 has been predicted by leading merchants in a survey conducted by the National Retail Merchants Association. This was reported by Carl N. Schmalz, president of the group, yesterday to the Metropolitan Milwaukee Association of Commerce at Milwaukee, Wis.

BOSTON, May 10 -- They may not have been the 30 days that shook the world, but they certainly shook the American League. For in the last month, the New York Yankees -- defending their title for the fifth straight season -- lost Elston Howard.

THE Cassius Clay-Sonny Liston fight is now in the same category as "Lady Chatterly's Lover" and other works of dubious distinction: It has been banned in Boston. Like fugitive fighters of ancient days, they've taken it on the lain across a state line and will set up their tent in Lewiston, Me., 130 miles to the north.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A sharp curtailment on the quantity of tax-free liquor that returning tourists may bring back to this country is being seriously considered by the House Ways and Means Committee.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., May 10 -- Promising results in the treatment of alcoholism with LSD and other mind-expanding drugs were reported at a medical meeting that ended here today.

I approve of the goals and ideals expressed in your May 3 editorial concerning our current policies in the Dominican Republic. But what would The New York Times actually want President Johnson to do? Obviously we do not want another Cuba in Santo Domingo.

ONE of the prize fashion trophies women have been bringing back from Europe in the last couple of years is a sweater adorned with delicate flower arrangements, dramatic abstract designs or romantic pastoral scenes.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 10 -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva, who since November has headed the first Christian Democratic Government elected in Latin America and whose program is one of social reform, faces the distrust of conservative property interests and the hostility of the Marxist left.

After months of study and revision, New York City has asked the Federal Government to approve the heart of its antipoverty drive -- a community action program covering almost 30 proposals that would cost $18,172,829.
It was the hottest day of the year here yesterday. At 3:25 in the afternoon the temperature reached 92 degrees, equalling the previous high for the date set in 1896.
A $32 million libel suit against Newsday was filed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court by the Waldemar Medical Research Foundation of Woodbury, L.I.

The American Institute of Architects has elevated 37 of its members to the status of Fellow, the institute's highest honor. Among the new Fellows is William F.R. Ballard, chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, who was honored for public service.
TOKYO, May 10 -- A special report to the Government has urged Japan to divert new purchases of raw materials from the United States to other countries, particularly in Southeast Asia.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 10 -- A line of poker-faced men in shirtsleeves here may unknowingly hold the secret of the timing of any attempt Rhodesia might make to seize independence from Britain.
THE gracious and comfortable apartment in which Jim and Isabella Lee live is filled with plants and sunlight and the gleam of old wood.
Snooping by the police department into the love life of a member of the force constitutes a violation of civil rights, a patrolman's attorney contended yesterday.
The leader of the nine-day strike in the garment industry expressed optimism yesterday that agreements would be reached soon with two major employer associations.
Although football at Fordham University may never become more than a club activity, the club's new coach said yesterday that "I'm here to win -- not just to play."

BUFFALO, May 10 -- Five more years of research will be needed to determine the feasibility of developing a cigarette less dangerous to health than the present product, a specialist on the subject said here today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Representative Richard L. Ottinger charged today that "hundreds of thousands to millions" of fish had been killed in the Hudson River as a result of the building of an atomic power plant at Indian Point, south of Peekskill.
LONDON, May 10 -- The United states refused categorically tonight to abandon responsibility for Germany's reunification to France and the Soviet Union.

The American Book Publishers Council and the American Textbook Publishers Institute, whose members account for almost all books issued in the United States, have begun a study of joining in a federation.
Amid reports of a short supply of potatoes and climbing prices, the important May potato futures contract expired yesterday at $6.20 a hundred-weight.
Standard Poor's, the investment-advisory firm, introduced four of them on the corporate level in yesterday's issue of its publication, The Outlook.
Did the Mets offer the Milwaukee Braves $500,000 for Joe Torre, as reported yesterday? Strictly speaking. yes, Here is what actually happened:

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (UPI) -- Johnny Briggs hit a pinch-double in the ninth, scored the tying run and then hit a two-run homer with two out in the 10th to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 4-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A special House Armed Services subcommittee was named today to look into the operation of the service academies. It is to determine whether aptitude tests and high school grades may be barring some potential generals and admirals.
MEXICO CITY, May 10 -- The United States' position in the Dominican Republic continued to come under attack here today at the 11th conference of the Economic Commission for Latin America.
Vladimir Horowitz, in a light blue robe over blue pajamas was stretched out at noon yesterday on a couch under Picasso's "Acrobate au Repos" in the living room of his town house on East 94th Street.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for the easy-to-prepare main dish.

CLEVELAND, May 10 (UPI) -- George H. Hartzog Jr., the director of the National Park Service, asked the Garden Clubs of America today to serve as watchdogs of conservation and oppose encroachment on public lands.

Following are excepts from the majority opinion by Judge Sterry R Waterman and the dissent by Judge Richard J. Levet delivered yesterday in Federal court in the New York case concerning legislative reapportionment:
A series of new shouts came from stock-brokers yesterday morning on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. "How's the General?" the cries rang out. "How's your Aniline?" "How's G.A.F.?"
JACKSON, Miss., May 10 (UPI) -- The police arrested a white civil rights lawyer for going past a stoplight last night as he fled from several cars of bottle-throwing youths.

LONDON, May 10 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson ordered an immediate investigation today of the employment by two Government departments of two men jailed on charges of having sold secrets to foreign powers.
DETROIT, May 10 (AP) -- The two-millionth General Motors car of the 1965 model run rolled off an assembly line today, just a day ahead of Ford's one-millionth car.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 10 -- The appointment of a 25-member "nonpartisan" committee to study proposals for the controversial reapportionment of Suffolk's governing body was approved today by the Board of Supervisors.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- Lucky Debonair, the winner of the Kentucky Derby, had a major workout today for Saturday's Preakness and afterward his trainer, Frank Catrone, said, "That ought to scare somebody."

The labor-relations and public-relations firm in which Carlo Gambino, the Mafia chieftain, was a partner has split up because of the bad publicity it got after Gambino's role in it became widely known.

A fleet of limousines and buses hauled an adequately star-studded cargo of partygoers to a Staten Island country house last night for a supper dance in an elegant pink-and-white striped tent. Trumbull Barton and John L. McHugh gave the gathering in honor of their old friend Dame Margot Fonteyn.
Ever since President Johnson announced that he favored reductions in excise taxes the Administration has been having a difficult time deciding just what cuts should be made.

The American Broadcast Company, hoping to be the first network to televise sports events live from Europe, announced yesterday that it planned to broadcast the Irish Sweepstakes and portions of the Le Mans automobile-endurance race next month.
WHEN an abbey on the edge of the Bad Lands of North Dakota needs to raise money for its schools and missions, selling brandy might not seem the most logical way to go about it.

All observers of Latin-American affairs have been watching with trepidation the steadily deteriorating situation in Colombia. Events in recent days have brought the possibility of a government crisis close to the surface.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Treasury-bill rate, still weak despite the current tightening of monetary policy, dipped slightly at today's auction an fell below the 3.9 per cent level, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

BABYLON, L.I., May 10 -- The West Bathhouse pool and beach at Jones Beach State Park will be open daily beginning Saturday, May 22, the Long Island State Park Commission announced today. Other bathing areas at Jones Beach will be open weekends, beginning May 29, and on a daily basis from June 19.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A 600-acre addition to the Fire Island National Seashore, combining historic and recreational value, was proposed today by Representative Otis G. Pike.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 11 -- A large Vietcong force overran a provincial capital 52 miles north of Saigon early today, killing five United States military advisers and wounding 11 other Americans.

SELMA, Ala., May 10 -- The failure of a Lowndes County jury to convict a Ku Klux Klansman of the murder of Mrs. Viola Gregg Liuzzo demonstrates that civil rights murders should be made a Federal crime, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today.

The Wagner administration's $3.5 billion budget, the biggest in city history, will be submitted Thursday with an unusual proposal that the Legislature make the final decision on whether to balance it by borrowing or by levying new taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Johnson Administration is exploring ways of using excise tax reductions at the beginning of next year to offset the drag on the economy from the large increase in Social Security taxes scheduled at that time.

THE 1965 baseball season is just one month old, and it's a good time to step back for a look at the National League picture in perspective. The games played so far constitute approximately one-seventh of the schedule, so it is obvious that nothing unalterable has yet taken place.
BUJUMBURA, Burundi, May 10 (Reuters) -- Voting began today in the first general election since Burundi became independent in 1962.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The major oil companies are fighting each other in efforts to eliminate the independent dealer by acquisition or merger, the Federal Trade Commission was told today.
A few hours after Judge Sterry Robinson Waterman had handed down his far-reaching opinion on legislative reapportionment yesterday, the telephone rang in his office at the United States Court House.

TOKYO, May 10 (UPI) -- The chief of the General Staff of the Chinese Communist Army has declared that his country will not go to war against the United States unless it is attacked, Hsinhua, the Peking press agency reported today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 10 -- The Indonesian Government has ordered its embassy in Washington to investigate the seizure of the Indonesian merchant vessel Johannes Latuharhari at Los Angeles last Friday, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

SELMA, Ala., May 10 (AP) -- John Devitt, the Mammermill Paper Company's president, said today that the concern had employed a former Negro high school basketball star from Selma and would train him to work in the new plant near Selma.
The stock market put on another wishy-washy performance yesterday, finishing with a few more declines than advances.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) -- Dick Bertell, a catcher for the Chicago Cubs, was fined today $500 for being overweight.
Bernard Gittelson went on trial yesterday in state Supreme Court, charged with 27 counts of perjury in a $50,000 parking-meter scandal involving "a certain public officer."

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 10 -- Casey Stengel started out of the visitors' locker room in the Army gymnasium today and was headed for his place of work, the baseball diamond. On a short but steep concrete ramp in the gym, his spiked shoes slipped out from under him and down went the 74-year-old manager of the New York Mets.
The British pound registered a small gain in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, in an attempt to get its state and local central units to participate more energetically in community affairs, has put one of its most respected state federation presidents on the headquarters staff.

BOSTON, May 10 -- Garrett H. Byrne, the district attorney who ran the Cassius Clay-Sonny Liston fight out of Boston last week, said today he had a letter telling of political pressures used to get this city to accept the fight in the first place.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 10 -- The United States marines have howitzers on the front lawn and a heliport on the polo field and hundreds of refugees sleep nightly amid the mirrored columns of the lobby, where Ginger Rogers might dance at midnight if only someone would clean up the mess.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 10 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said today he would ask the State Investigation Commission to broaden its inquiry on Nassau's County Jail to include Governor Rockefeller's "failure to take cooperative action" before Jan. 1.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 10 -- The opening pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association season drew 133 teams today to the Winged Foot Golf Club -- and four of them tied with net bestball cards of 65 for the 6.445-yard, par-36, 36 -- 72 West course.
An art show and sale Saturday through next Tuesday will be held at the Carnegie International Center in the United Nations Plaza at 46th Street for the scholarship fund of the Manhattan Day School.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday it had completed acquisition of the Vanderbilt Automotive Centers from the B.F. Goodrich Company for $10 million in cash.

ALBANY, May 10 -- The minority Republicans were talking like the majority again today, as they hailed the Federal court decision ordering a special election this fall under a Republican reapportionment plan.
LONDON, May 10 -- The Government's finance bill, which gives legislative effect to last month's budget, was approved in a House of Commons test tonight by 3 votes.

ANYONE who stumbles around the woods after game and splashes in the water for fish long enough learns to appreciate the value of a certain amount of -- well, sneakiness is perhaps too harsh a word -- deviousness is much better.

The appointment of Frank C. Bromber as executive director of the St. Regis Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street, has been announced by Alfred Simon, executive vice president of Wellington Associates, Inc., the new owner of the St. Regis.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- When Senate Minority Leader Dirksen chose co-authorship of the President's 1965 voting rights bill to a separate Republican draft of the measure, he became the hero of the Administration and of Mike Mansfield, the director of the Senate majority.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 10 -- Richard Tillman, an Air Force captain stationed in Dayton, Ohio, and Peter Barrett of Thiensville, Wis., the Olympic silver-medal winner in Tokyo last year, showed consistency in single-handed sailing at the start of the North America Finn Class championship today.
Steel production in the United States fell 2.2 her cent in the week ended Saturday to 2,715,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
NEWARK, May 10 (AP) -- Emergency restrictions on water use went into effect here at midnight last night, and by 7:30 A.M. the city had a violator -- City Hall.
An account in a Harlem bank containing donations collected to pay the 852,000 defamation judgment against Representative Adam Clayton Powell was frozen yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A National Water Commission to review the country's water supplies and requirements was recommended today by the Budget Bureau.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- An Administration bill to pump $280 million in Federal funds into health research facilities won quick house approval today and was sent to the Senate.

The parents on the Upper East Side of Manhattan who have been awaiting the construction of a junior high school are dismayed to hear that the Site Selection Board on April 26 delayed its decision on the Squadron A Armory site at 94th Street and Park Avenue.
James B. Donovan, president of the Board of Education, announced yesterday that he would resign from the board on June 30.
LONDON, May 10 (AP) -- Greece and Turkey agreed today to seek a peaceful solution to the Cyprus problem.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a bill to increase the United States quota in the International Monetary Fund by $1.035 billion.

The Ashland Oil and Refining Company announced yesterday that it has made a bid of $700 million in cash for the assets of the Pure Oil Company. The Hunt oil interests of Dallas are associated with Ashland in the offer, which would yield about $70 a share to the Pure Oil stockholders.

THE Radio Symphony Orchestra of Finland, in a performance of the Jan Sibelius freedom anthem, "Finlandia," was last night's star on a program relayed from Helsinki to New York earlier in the day on the Early Bird satellite.
Attendance at the World's Fair is continuing to slump badly.

Lila Kedrova, winner of an Academy Award for her supporting performance as the fading courtesan in the film "Zorba, the Greek," will make her American stage debut as Madame Ranevsky, the once-affluent Russian aristocrat, in "The Cherry Orchard."
Brooks Atkinson closed his last Critic At Large piece April 30 by quoting Alexander Pope. "Man never is, but always to be, blest."
TRENTON, May 10 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed a bill passed by the State Legislature today summoning a constitutional convention to draw a permanent legislative reapportionment plan by June, 1966.
A Federal court ordered yesterday that a legislative election be held Nov. 2 under a Republican reapportionment plan that had been invalidated by the State Court of Appeals.

More than 250,000 voters in 22 New Jersey communities will elect municipal officials today, Voting ;will take place in 9 of the state's 21 counties with hours from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. In two communitites, Lynhurst and Bordentown, polls will open an hour later and close at 9 P.M.
BONN, May 10 -- Chancellor Erhard and President de Gaulle will meet here June 11 and 12 for a "routine" consultation.
Prices held within a narrow range on the London stock market yesterday although the list generally closed on the firm side with some late buying.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) -- A special House-Senate committee began hearings today on how to reform the workings of the Congress. Most members did not expect much to come of it.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 -- Stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad were told here today that the line expected to start negotiations "during the latter part of this week" for the sale of the Long Island Railroad to New York State.
The New York Legislature is about to vote on the question whether residents of New York City shall have a right to hold a referendum on the issue of legalizing off-track betting on horse races.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Scientists are trying to make contact with civilizations on other worlds and, doubtless, they will soon succeed. People who understand such things say the universe contains so many stars with so many solar systems like ours that there are bound to be plenty of worlds as civilized as ours, and probably more so.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., May 10 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman, looking chipper and rested after a weekend of celebrating his birthday, watched tile unveiling of a statue of himself today. The statue was a gift from the people of Greece and Americans of Greek descent.
ROME, May 10 (AP) -- Top-seeded Manuel Santana of Spain and second-seeded Martin Mulligan of Australia gained the men's singles final today in the Italian international tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A thief opened the trunk of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's car last night and stole a $100 emergency oxygen kit that the general uses when short of breath, along with several other items.
HOUSTON, May 10 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit refused today to delay municipal elections in Sunflower County, Miss., long enough for more Negroes to register.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A spokesman for health insurance companies said today that the proposed voluntary Government insurance program for the aged would drive most private concerns out of business.
Two employes of the Police Athletic League's headquarters in the Bronx were arrested last night and charged with impairing the morals of a 14-year-old girl.

The size and composition of the New York Lyric Ensemble make it a flexible instrument. Last night in Town Hall, the four-year-old chorus, under the direction of its founder, Ilana Rubenfeld, presented a lively program ranging from 15th-century and 16th-century madrigals to the Dvorak Mass in D.

The wild, high-pitched squeals of a dozen tiny children running up the center aisle would ordinarily be out of place in church, but at St. George's Episcopal Church in Stuyvesant Square last week the incident was not only encouraged but also carefully directed.

A chief topic of conversion along Aqueduct's backstretch yesterday was thoroughbred sales -- both past and present. There was a sale of 75 head in the morning at Belmont Park and two expensive juveniles made their racing debuts at Aqueduct in the afternoon.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 10 -- Justice Napoleon Bonaparte Johnson of the Oklahoma Supreme Court took the witness stand in his impeachment trial before the State Senate today to brand "absolutely false" testimony accusing him of having accepted bribes.

HOUSTON, May 10 (UPI) -- Houston Negro pupils boycotted their high schools today, and 400 of them marched on the school administration building tonight. But their demonstration ended when a school board meeting was called off.

SAIGON, May 10 -- More than 300 casualties among South Vietnamese regular army troops were reported today in bitter fighting 25 miles northwest of Saigon. One United States army enlisted man was killed in the two days of fighting, which ended yesterday.
Two men, including a member of the Vito Genovese Mafia family, were convicted yesterday in Federal Court of wilfully failing to file income tax returns for 1956 and 1957.

The decision of the two Codes Committees of the New York Legislature to kill -- and thus prevent a vote on -- a bill to repeal the 1881 "Comstock" law prohibiting sale or distribution of contraceptives or contraceptive information is incredible. It cannot be allowed to stand, even in a Legislature so distinguished for wrong-headedness.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic. May 10 -- The United States' identification with the new national council, which functions behind the protection of American troops, has led to a surge of anti- United States feeling among many Dominicans who had welcomed those troops.

LONDON, May 10 -- Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart and Ambassador David K.E. Brucel signed today an agreement extending the student exchange program begun between Britain and the United States 17 years ago.
WASHIGNTON, May 10 -- Officers and enlisted men whose terms are about to expire were asked by the Navy today to continue in service voluntarily to help meet "the present challenge."

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A ministerial meeting of the Organization of American States voted this evening to give a five-man truce committee immediate responsibility for conditions in the Dominican Republic.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 10 -- Tom Nieporte, the home club pro and last year's winner, and Ed Kuna, an assistant pro at the Old Westbury Country Club, shot one-under-par 70's today and shared the lead as the Long Island Golf Association's 40th open tournament began on the 6,516-yard Piping Rock Club course.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 10 -- Two surprises followed the completion of today's post-position draw for the Realization Pace, the 1 1-16th-mile test that will head Thursday night's opening card at Roosevelt Raceway.
CLEVELAND, May 10 -- Three governors and other representatives of eight Great Lakes states held an inconclusive conference today on problems of pollution in Lake Erie.

SANTO DONMINGO, Dominican Republic, Tuesday May 11 -- United States Embassy sources said early today that Brig Gen. Elias Wessin y Wessin had changed his mind about resigning as commander of the armed forces after he had agreed to do so yesterday.
Irving Berlin, who has written words and music for more than 900 songs since his first one was sold for 23 cents in 1907, will be 77 years old today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10 -- Algeria renewed her call for world disarmament talks today and implied that such a parley might also lead to useful talks on Vietnam.
LOS ANGELES, May 10 (UPI) -- Ron Fairly singled home Lou Johnson from third tonight in the 10th inning to give the Los Angeles Dodgers a 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros.

The high corporate official breezed into the district tax director's office aware that he would probably have to back down a little from his $4,500 charitable deduction. Some time later, he emerged from the office looking "shaken" and "ashen-faced," according to an associate who waited outside.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The United States is placing no restrictions on tourist travel to Cambodia but will be unable to provide protection to Americans going there, the State Department said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 10 -- United States diplomats voiced surprise and annoyance today at a Victory Day speech by President Tito in which he implicitly compared current United States policy to that of Hitler and Mussolini.
State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan barred the Family Court yesterday from trying 56 civil rights demonstrators on charges of inducing truancy.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Fifteen national trade associations signed a joint protest today against possible cuts in Federal assistance for the improvement of airports.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers broke a tie with an unearned run in the sixth inning tonight and defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5-4. Robin Roberts, the Orioles' pitcher, suffered his first loss of the season.
A former Union City policeman was sentenced in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday to three years in prison for participating in a series of post office robberies.
The strong demand for metals that has accompanied the four-year-old expansion of business and exerted upward price pressures was evident on several fronts yesterday.

Kenneth Gilbert, harpsichordist, and Jasques Simard, oboist, made a joint appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The two young Canadian musicians were being treated to their local debuts by the Carnegie Hall Club.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 10 (AP) -- Mel Nelson, a relief pitcher, went into the game with two on and none out in the ninth inning tonight and saved a 4-3 victory for the Minnesota Twins over the Chicago White Sox.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board said today that it would file a formal complaint against The Baltimore News American, charging it with illegally locking out employes.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Johnson has chosen Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce, as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the White House announced today.

CAIRO, May 10 -- The Egyptian State Prosecutor's office today demanded the death penalty for a West German couple it said had spied for Israel and had attempted to murder German scientists working here.
