WHEN Lola Beer arrived in Palestine soon after Germany invaded her native Czechoslovakia, the pioneer land seemed as likely to nurture a couture house as it would an art museum.

Transit Commissioner John J Gilhooley, a leading possibility for the Republican mayoral nomination, is sailing for Italy next Wednesday and will be out of the country the day party leaders are expected to designate a candidate.

The General Bronze Corporation has contracted to sell its pant in Garden City, L.I., to Sigmund Sommer, New York realty investor and developer, for $4 million in cash. The sale does not include the company's manufacturing equipment or other machinery.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 10 (AP) -- Mel Nelson, a relief pitcher, went into the game with two on and none out in the ninth inning tonight and saved a 4-3 victory for the Minnesota Twins over the Chicago White Sox.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board said today that it would file a formal complaint against The Baltimore News American, charging it with illegally locking out employes.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- President Johnson has chosen Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce, as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the White House announced today.

I.D. Robbins, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, accused Deputy Mayor Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday of improperly using city funds for a nightclub party honor of Princess Benedikte of Denmark.
The Sunbeam Corporation, a major producer of electric appliances, reported yesterday that its sales and earnings in fiscal 1965 set records for the third successive year.
Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., announced yesterday the election of a vice president in each of its Chicago, Boston and New York offices.
ALBANY, May 10 -- A bill that would permit state scholarship holders to attend out-of-state colleges was approved today by the Assembly. Two similar bills had passed the Senate.

The Government and corporate bond markets ground almost to a halt yesterday. Municipal dealers had little time for trading, as they prepared for today's slate of 18 new issues headed by a $100 million state of California school issue.
SACRAMENTO, May 10 (UPI) -- The California State Senate bowed reluctantly today to the Supreme Court and passed a reapportionment bill that ends rural domination of the upper house.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Princess Benedikte of Denmark had lunch today at the National Arboretum, where 80,000 azaleas are in full, spectacular bloom, and then went to afternoon tea at the White House.
Ferris Booth Hall of Columbia University will be the setting Saturday evening for the eighth annual Mother Goose Ball, a benefit for the Medical Center Nursery School.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Army's No. 1 soldier, Gen. Harold K. Johnson, fears that continued use of off-color language is going to harm the Army's image.
MOSCOW, May l0 -- An antimissile missile and other powerful rockets of the Soviet arsenal were shown in action for the first time in a film presented in the last two days on Moscow television.

Appraisal problems and procedures will be discussed by a panel of eleven past presidents of the Metropolitan chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, to be held on Thursday evening at 5:30 P.M. at the Princeton Club, 15 West 43d Street.

THE Morton Rubinow Memorial contest, staged annually by the Cavendish Club, was played as a three-session event on Friday and Saturday. Tobias Stone, of New York, William Eisenberg, of Long Beach, L.I., and Robert Goldman, of Philadelphia, formed the nucleus of the winning team.

MONTREAL, May 10 (Canadian Press) -- The International Air Transport Association announced today that air cargo for scheduled North Atlantic routes increased by 64.5 per cent during the first three months of 1965 compared with the first quarter of 1964.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 10 -- The California Legislature is sending teams of members at state expense all over the nation to fight the one-man, one-vote edict of the United States Supreme Court.
Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday it would increase the price of its tires effective May 29.
DAYTON, Ohio, May 10 (AP) -- The Air Force reported today the death of Dr. Donald B. Haines, 37 years old, a prominent research psychologist, in a plane crash during a training mission in Ethiopia.
Five New York University graduates will receive tonight the 1965 Alumni Meritorious Service Medal, the highest honor that can be presented by the university's 150,000 alumni.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., May 10 -- Each day 10 Negro students at the University of Alabama stroll across the sprawling green campus or through the town and cross paths with the kin of Klansmen, the sons of Selma, the daughter of Gov. George C. Wallace -- with dozens of students and townspeople who either smile at them, befriend them, ignore them, or despise them.
John Brogan has been named tax manager of the Bristol-Myers Company. He has served as assistant tax manager since 1959.

FORT WORTH, May 10 -- Heavy rains today forced postponement of the Colonial Invitation golf tournament for the second straight day and left the Professional Golfers' Association with a schedule problem.
Predictions that this will be a big year for color television helped National Video dominate trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

TORONTO, May 10 -- H. George De Young was reported today to be resigning as the president of Rio Algom Mines, Ltd., a major uranium and specialty steel producer. The company would neither confirm nor deny the report.

GENEVA, May 10 -- The Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations entered an important new phase today as negotiators began clearing the way for hard bargaining on the removal of trade barriers in farm products.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Earnings of W.R. Grace Co. in April were the highest for any month in the company's history and are expected to show improvement in the second quarter and the full year over last year, stockholders were told here today.
At least 20 Columbia University students face disciplinary action by the school as a result of a demonstration Friday against the university's naval reserve training program.
The Board of Education disclosed yesterday that it is considering naming the new high school on Manhattan's West Side after the late Sir Winston Churchill.
LAWRENCE, Tenn., May 11 (AP) -- The teamsters union announced tonight it had withdrawn all pickets from the labor-troubled Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- A visiting Chinese Communist official praised Stalin here today as an outstanding military leader in World War II while the official Soviet press appeared to be trying to limit the impact of the current reappraisal of the dictator's wartime role.
James B. Donovan and the Board of Education arrived at an honorable compromise.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected an amendment of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, to write a provision against poll taxes into the voting rights bill:

ALBANY, May 11 -- Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today his promised bill to create an authority that would supervise Long Island Railroad operations and work out a long-term agreement for running the New Haven Railroad commuter service.

FORT WORTH, May 11 -Treading over soaked fairways, Bruce Crampton of Australia won the $100,000 Colonial national invitation tournament today by three strokes. After storms had forced a two-day postponement, Crampton scored a fourth round of 66 for a total of 276 as play was resumed.
The British pound edged lower in quiet dealings yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
The municipal bond market appeared to have little difficulty in digesting yesterday's heavy serving of new offerings.
I wish to associate myself with the views expressed May 7 by Salvador de Madariaga on the Dominican crisis.

Mrs. I.W. Kahn is chairman of the 1965 campaign cabinet of the National Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress. The third annual Louise Waterman Wise awards will be presented at the division's luncheon on Monday in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
The Graham Home for Children at Hastings-on-Hudson N.Y., will benefit from a "Port of Call" dinner dance, to be held on June 1 aboard the American Export Isbrandtsen liner Independence at Pier 84.
There may be life on even so inhospitable a planet as Jupiter, a recent study suggests.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy expressed confidence today that marine biologists could solve any fishery problems that might result from construction of a Consolidated Edison power plant at Storm King Mountain on the Hudson River.
Executives of Metromedia, Inc., proceeded through the business of the company's 1965 annual meeting in an uneventful 32 minutes yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency proposed new flying rules for private pilots and operators of executive aircraft or other light planes today.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- A Federal banking official testified today that three officials of a failing Colorado bank attempted to unload counterfeit securities on the Miami National Bank in 1964.
Cigarette purchases in the city plunged when the state cigarette tax doubled April 1, it was revealed yesterday.
Montgomery Ward Co. announced yesterday it was considering a public offering of $100 million to $150 million senior debentures.
Apparently believing that no news is good news, traders bid copper futures prices up yesterday to within a few points of the daily limit on the Commodity Exchange here.

The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences Foundation announced yesterday that a national library of television, which will house a recorded sampling of shows since 1948, would be established at three major universities.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP) -- Lucian (Sonny) Banks, a 207-pound heavyweight boxer from Detroit, underwent brain surgery today after he was knocked out in the ninth round of a fight at the Arena last night.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 11 (AP) -- Gov. George C. Wallace said today that Governors and Congressmen from nine Southern states would meet m Washington May 18 to plant resistance to what he called a Federal attempt to control schools.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 11 -- The United States opposed a Uruguayan resolution today that would give the Secretary General a vague authorization to intervene in the Dominican situation.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- Policemen recovered former President Dwight D. Eisenhower' s emergency oxygen kit today. It was stolen yesterday from the trunk of his car.
A five-year legal fight over a $9 million trust fund set up in 1917 by John D. Rockefeller Sr. has been settled.

BOSTON, May 11 (AP) -- An order was filed in the Massachusetts House of Representatives today calling for a legislative investigation of the circumstances behind the transfer of the Cassius Clay-Sonny Liston heavyweight championship fight from Boston to Lewiston, Me.

Business leaders intent on branching out abroad were told yesterday that India offered an excellent market provided the American entrepreneur could adjust to some of the official restrictions that the New Delhi Government still imposes.
BALTIMORE, May 11 (UPI) -- Hirsch Jacobs, the trainer, said today that Turn to Reason definitely would not be a starter in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Saturday.
DARIEN, Conn., May 11 -- Edmond J. Moran, an admiral in World War II, has resigned as a member of the Darien Police Commission without any explanation.
For the second consecutive day, National Video attracted attention on a declining American Stock Exchange yesterday.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 11 (AP) -- About 300 of South Bend's 1,400 public school teachers boycotted classes today in a continuing union meeting over salaries.

The Aetna Lifge Insurance Company of Hartford has agreed to make a $40 million leasehold loan on the 44-story office building that the Uris Buildings Corporation is erecting at 245 Park Avenue. The loan will be the largest mortgage commitment Aetna has made.

In a surprise move, stockholders of the J.J. Newberry Company, the variety and department-store chain, turned down yesterday a management-backed extension of an employe stock-option plan in which 12,000 workers had participated since 1956.

THERE is one kind of energy that continues to baffle scientific minds at the Oak Ridge Institute of Nuclear Studies. It is the energy of youngster, whose ability to wear out equipment specially designed to withstand their best efforts seemingly knows no bounds.

With the very troubling recent events in Selma, Ala., fresh in mind, it is in order to invite attention to the roles which American legal institutions and lawyers have played in the struggle for effective recogition of human rights.
Fifth and Madison Avenues will be converted to one-way traffic about March 1 next year.
Representative John V. Lindsay was seriously reconsidering last night making the race for Mayor.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 11 -- Although Capt. Richard Tillman of the United States Air Force wound up fifth and Peter Barrett of Thiensville, Wis., seventh today, they continued to set the pace in the North American Finn Class sailing championship.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -A special Presidential committee has suggested to President Johnson that he reverse a decision to close five veterans hospitals, two old soldiers' homes and eight regional offices of the Veterans Administration.
ST. LOUIS -- The people in St. Louis have a tendency to deride themselves with great frequency in two areas, Robert Miller observed recently.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, May 12 -- An unmanned Soviet space capsule will attempt the first soft landing on the moon today, an official Soviet announcement indicated.

BUENOS AIRES, May 11 -- The opposition of students and authorities of the University of Buenos Aires to United States policy in the Dominican Republic has forced a change in the site of an important international conference on space.

THOSE were wild, foolish, intense days 30 years ago when the nation was struggling to fight its way out of the Depression and the American Communists were busy organizing, sloganeering and clamoring to change the system.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 11 (AP) -- An oil workers' union demanded today that Indonesia expropriate American oil companies in retaliation for the seizure of an Indonesian merchant ship in Los Angeles.
Robert Moses, president of the World's Fair Corporation, has run into trouble getting into exhibits because some employes don't recognize him. He now carries a special pass.
ALBANY, May 11 -- Two well known physicists, Dr. Edward Teller and Dr. Chen Ning Yang, will teach for a limited time in the next academic year on state university campuses.
ALBANY, May 11 -- A controversial bill that would allow school boards to provide textbooks to students of private or parochial schools was overwhelmingly approved today by the Assembly.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 (UPI) -- Frank Linzy came out of the bullpen to get the final out tonight and save a 3-0 shutout for Ron Herbel and the San Francisco Giants over the Chicago Cubs.
CHICAGO, May 11 -- Representative Oren D. Harris called today for the establishment of a national television policy and the creation of a broadly representative advisory group to set that policy.

State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Sarafite has approved the sale of the Manhattan Club property, at the southeast corner of 26th Street and Madison Avenue, to Jackson A. Edwards, electrical supply distributor.
The Board of Education with no outward hint of the opposition that was evident behind the scenes, unanimously re-elected James B. Donovan yesterday as president.
Frank Sinatra, whose last New York full-time engagement was at the Copacabana in 1957, will appear with the Count Basie Orchestra at the Forest Hills Music Festival on July 9 and 10.
LONDON, May 11 -- Britain's steel companies moved tonight to take up the Government's apparent offer of a fresh look at its nationalization plans -- just as the offer seemed to be disappearing.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A professional boycott of Oklahoma's public school system was declared by the National Education Association today in a protest against what it called "subminimal" educational conditions.
New York Supreme Court Justice Owen McGivern awarded yesterday $1,876 million in fees to lawyers and consultants in regard to a celebrated stockholders' suit involving the Alleghany Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The increasing military commitments in Southeast Asia and the Caribbean are dramatizing once more the shortcomings and inequities of the Pentagon's current manpower policies.

The business of transmitting live television programs across the Atlantic, potentially one of the more valuable franchises in international communications, is full of questions as conversion of the Early Bird satellite to commercial operation nears.

OSSINING, N.Y., May 11 -- All trains on the four mainline tracks of the New York Central's Hudson division here were blocked for an hour this afternoon by a wrecked freight train. Service was resumed on one track at 4 P.M., but commuters were delayed an hour or more.

MIAMI BEACH, May 11 -- The increase in the number of big companies in the women's garment industry, traditionally the citadel of small enterprise, is posing new collective bargaining problems for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

The annual convention of the Episcopal Diocese of New York called upon its investing agencies and 206 parishes yesterday to confine their investments to "corporations that have demonstrated their commitment to equal opportunity in employment."
TRENTON, May 11 -- Five New Jersey Assemblymen think the New Jersey Highway Authority should stick to the roads and leave cultural advance to others.

Renewed and intensified efforts by businessmen, educators and members of the communications media to combat the "economic illiteracy" of the American public were urged yesterday by speakers at the 22d annual meeting of the Brand Names Foundation, Inc.

LONDON, May 11 -- The United States, Britain, France and West Germany have agreed on the terms of a new Western call for the reunification of Germany. The declaration reaffirms the role of the United States in con sideration of the German problem.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -Representative Emanuel Celler called today for a "special, impartial" Congressional inquiry into the nation's antipoverty program.
Two officials of the Belgian Village exhibit at the World's Fair charged yesterday that they were beaten by fair policemen while trying to break up a brawl outside the exhibit on Sunday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 12 (AP) -- Mao Tse-tung, the Chinese Communist leader, said today that "U.S. military intervention in the Dominican Republic has aroused a new wave against U.S. imperialism among the people of Latin America and the world."
BONN, May 11 -- The West German Government has disclosed a "recommendation" to its ministries and departments not to float any new loans on the country's ailing fixed-interest market.

MOSCOW, May 11 -- The Soviet Union ordered today the expulsion of Norris D. Garnett, cultural attache of the United States Embassy, on charges that he had conducted an anti-Soviet campaign among African students.

BOSTON, May 11 -- The New Breed of the New York Yankees -- men who were in Richmond, Portland and Kansas City a year ago -- came to the rescue of the old tonight and took leading roles in defeating the Boston Red Sox, 5-3.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 11 (AP) -- Harmon Killebrew's infield single off Dean Chance's leg drove in Tony Oliva in the ninth inning and lifted the Minnesota Twins to a 3-2 triumph over the Los Angeles Angels tonight that increased their American League lead to one game.

THE more the blights of industrialization and urbanization are spread across the country, the more the common American experience is of city streets and builders' hideous developments, the more acutely do writers seem to yearn for the simple life of their ancestors.
ABINGTON, Va., May 11 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson set out to prove today that Americans did not need passports to enjoy their vacations.
ALBANY, May 11 -- Two legislative committees will recomment tomorrow that New York State retain its minimum drinking age of 18 years.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Reds collected six hits for six runs in the eighth inning and beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-1, tonight.
The romance between Thomas H. Quinn, a mortgage company executive, and the World's Fair has ended in marriage. The Fair announced yesterday that Mr. Quinn had been joined to it as a director.
One of the leading American steamship companies, the Waterman Steamship Corp., of Mobile, Ala., was sold yesterday to a family investment group headed by two prominent New York shipping executives.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -Three New York City shareholders launched the 1965 stockholders' meeting of the Communications Satellite Corporation today with a disturbance that caused two of them to be ejected.
The heart of Times Square was a jaywalker's paradise and a motorist nightmare for more than five hours yesterday, because of traffic control-light failure.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Johnson signed today a proclamation making Ellis Island part of the Statue of Liberty National Monument in New York Harbor.
Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City won re-election by a surprisingly decisive margin last night.
There are two vitally important steps for the Legislature to take in the wake of the Federal District Court's decision that the interim election on Nov. 2 should be held under Republican Plan A.

WASHINGTON -- Those who urge the United States to begin Vietnamese peace negotiations and to cease bombing the North should know two things: (1) Neither Hanoi nor the Vietcong has shown any desire to talk; (2) Washington, through secret channels, has offered to halt our aerial attacks if North Vietnam will make some tangible equivalent move in the South.

THE not-infrequent mumbles from anglers about those "good old days" are quite, understandable. The mind sees only streams full of huge and hungry trout, of peace and tranquillity, and of uncrowded conditions.

" I take my hat off to Mr. Barnes," said Martin Weber, a taxi driver from Queens, when he learned of the Traffic Commissioner's announcement that one-way signs will adorn Fifth and Madison Avenues next year.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- President Johnson said tonight that "we would rather men would quarrel with our action to insure peace than curse us through all eternity for inaction which might lose us both our peace and freedom."

LONDON, May 11 -John Osborne's new play, "A Patriot For Me," will be presented before private audiences when it opens next month because it has five scenes dealing with homosexuality that were banned by the Lord Chamberlain.

DAN GURNEY has expressed the belief that the man who wins the "pole" this year at Indianapolis will have to go faster than 160 miles an hour, probably around 164. The "pole" is position No. 1 in the field of 33 cars that will start the Memorial Bay 500-mile auto mobile race on May 31.
MOSCOW, May 11 -- Douglas (Jocko) Henderson may be a disc jockey to his American rock 'n' roll fans, but in the Soviet Union he's an "American rocket ship commander."
More than 200 persons who have helped in the development of the Hamilton-Madison House at 50 Madison Street joined last night in honoring its custodian-caretaker for the last 30 years.

LOS ANGELES, May 11 -- Vast changes in the administration of the University of California, including greater autonomy for individual campuses and a more limited role for the Board of Regents, were proposed today in a report to a special regents committee.

Columbia University's chapter of the American Association of University Professors called yesterday for lenient treatment of the students facing disciplinary action as a result of a demonstration Friday against the university's Naval Reserve training program.
RICHMOND, May 11 -- Dr. Rachel Henderlite, a 59-year-old Richmond theologian, will become tomorrow night the first woman ever ordained as a minister of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S. (South).
ALBANY, May 11 -- Two of the Democrats' pet projects -- their offtrack betting bill and their effort to raise the minimum wage -- were badly beaten today in the Senate.
MCA, Inc., attained record first-quarter profits of $3,925,563, Jules C. Stein, chairman of the television film producer, announced yesterday.

ROME, May 11 -- Pope Paul VI welcomed President Charles Helou of Lebanon to the Vatican today and praised his country for setting an example of peaceful coexistence with a population of diverse religions.
Yesterday was a busy day for the animal quarantine station at Clifton, N.J.

The City Council got the first bill yesterday for Mayor Wagner's stepped-up drive against crime -- $6,182,508. Coincidentally, the Transit Authority reported that intensive night patrolling of subways had already sharply reduced serious subway crime.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 11 -- President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania appeared tonight to have been set back severely in his efforts to bring about firmer control of Zanzibar. The island of Zanzibar and the mainland territory of Tanganyika make up Tanzania.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Johnson Administration is trying to establish the basis for formation of a coalition government of the contending factions in the Dominican Republic. The belief in the Administration is that such a coalition could serve as a provisional government until new national elections could be held.

The Claremont String Quartet, fresh front performing in the third Inter-American Music Festival in Washington on Saturday night, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall last night bringing along a work it had given there as a world premiere -- Ezra Laderman's String Quartet No. 2.
CAMDEN, Ala, May 11 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that his Southern Christian Leadership Conference would carry the Negro protest movement to the Alabama Legislature.

ROME, May 11 (AP) - Maria Bueno of Brazil defeated Nancy Richey of Dallas, the No. 1 United States player, 6-1, 1-6, 6-3, today and became the second three-time winner of the Italian international championship.
The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday a "total commitment program" to protect the legal rights of Negro residents and civil rights workers in the Deep South.
WHITE PLAINS, May 11 -- The Westchester Water Works Conference announced a conservation program today specially tailored for the suburbs.

New York is extending its official hand and hospitality to visiting movie-production units. Five major film units have recently obtained technical clearance and a guarantee of city wide cooperation.

The special review board which scrutinized the Air Force Academy in the wake of the recent cheating scandal has ably identified a number of institutional weaknesses. The misguided military theory that any officer with the required rank is capable of running a service academy led to a rapid turnover of top administrators, including the institution's superintendents.
The biggest cheer heard from the 27,095 followers of form enjoying Aqueduct's pleasant breezes yesterday wasn't for a horse that won. It was for one that survived.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 11 -- Justice Napoleon Bonaparte Johnson of the Oklahoma Supreme Court suggested today that anti-Indian prejudice might account for bribery charges against him.

A New York County grand jury is investigating whether a State Senator and the owner of a consulting engineering company that designs state highways conspired to violate state laws against conflicts of interest.
The London stock market turned listless yesterday, with prices moving irregularly within a narrow range for the second day.

All it takes to eliminate the United States deficit in its international payments, they say, is to close the gap between the relatively low interest rates prevailing in New York and the relatively high rates that are the rule in the Common Market countries.

At least 20 Catholic-Jewish clergy and lay dialogues are being sponsored jointly this year by the Anti-Defamation League and Catholic colleges, it was reported here by Dore Schary, the league's national chairman.

WASHINGTON -- Parents who find themselves in a quandary about which nursery school to send their children to what preschoolers should or shouldn't learn, and what to look for in a nursery school teacher may derive some comfort from the fact that they are not alone.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Willie Horton's two-out single drove in two runs in the ninth inning tonight as the Detroit Tigers downed the Washington Senators, 7-6.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell ignored a notice to appear in State Supreme Court for a financial examination yesterday and thereby defaulted in a suit seeking $211,500 in punitive damages from him.
NEW DELHI, May 11 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri said today that India, if necessary, would accept arbitration of the dispute with Pakistan over the Rann of Cutch.

Amid predictions that credit sales would increase substantially this year in the nation's department and specialty stores, retail credit managers from across the country yesterday began a four-day meeting in New York, designed to find ways of using installment buying to increase the flow of customers.

" EYE ON NEW YORK" took a second and deeper look into "The Troubled Sea" last night. Instead of focusing on crew members, whose dull and unconstructive comments marred the pictorially impressive April 27 segment, WCBSTV concentrated on presenting hard, sad facts on the crisis in maritime labor aboard a dwindling fleet of merchant ships.

A possible "affiliation" of one Massachusetts and two Connecticut utilities into an $800 million-plus holding company was announced late yesterday by the heads of the three utilities. This would be the largest all-utility merger in many years.

ERIE, Pa., May 11 -- Sixtyseven civil rights demonstrators, most of them college students, were arrested here today when they refused to obey a court order to stop picketing on the grounds of the Hammermill Paper Company.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Building Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has withdrawn its support from the only program sponsored nationally by organized labor to help poor, uneducated youths train for jobs.
The ninth series of the Nuveen Tax-Exempt Bond Fund was offered to investors yesterday by John Nuveen Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Members of Congress have proposed everything from the creation of an office of ombudsman to hear citizens' complaints to guaranteed annual vacations and the hiring of management experts to improve the speed and quality of Congressional performance.

SEOUL, South Korea, May 11 ( UPI ) -- Counter-intelligence agents of the South Korean Army arrested a brigadier general today in connection with an unsuccessful plot to overthrow the Government of President Chung Hee Park.

The steel situation remains very much on the minds of both industry and Wall Street, despite extension of the steel-contract expiration date from May 1 to Sept. 1.
Arnold Schildhaus, a lawyer and real estate operator who has been battling the city through the courts for 10 years, was disbarred yesterday for professional misconduct.
Mayor Wagner disclosed plans yesterday for a 624-family middle-income cooperative housing project in central Harlem.
ALBANY, May 11 -- The Democratic legislative leaders patched together today a strategy designed to forestall a November special election under a Republican districting plan.
BALTIMORE, May 11 (AP) -- Dick Hall, a relief pitcher, drove in the winning run with a single in the 11th inning tonight, giving the Baltimore Orioles a 3-2 triumph over the Cleveland Indians.

JACKSON, Miss., May 11 (AP) -- The first Republican candidates for municipal office in modern times took part today in primary elections across the state.

Mayor Wagner, longtime ardent advocate of home rule, is reported planning to shift to the Legislature the responsibility for choosing the method to balance New York City's budget. Thus, having maintained silence throughout the bitter state sales tax fight in Albany he would now toss to the Democratic "leadership" in the Legislature the hottest potato he has to handle in the year he is seeking re-election to a fourth term.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 11 -- The junta led by Brig. Gen. Antonio Imbert Barreras announced today it was pumping $5 million into the Dominican economy, hard hit by the revolt that started April 21.
Yogi Berra said last night he was definitely through as a player. I'm an old man," he said, with a shy smile.

Two more meat wholesalers were arrested here yesterday and charged with offering to bribe a meat buyer for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to buy meats from their concern, Gol-Pac Corporation of 2214 Summit Avenue, Union City, N.J.
Governor Rockefeller said last night that he had been in "constant touch" with Representative John V. Lindsay and had "strongly urged him to run for Mayor."
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to reduce from $100 to $50 the value of duty-free goods that tourists may bring home from foreign countries.
VIENNA, May 11 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, declared today that Nikita S. Khrushchev had presided over the liquidation of Stalin's empire.

In New York City, critical surgery often must be delayed until a rare blood type can be located. The New York Blood Center, one of the Greater New York Fund's 425 agencies, came into existence to help solve this and other blood bank problems.
A total of $155 million of corporate bonds was offered to investors yesterday and all but an estimated $7.5 million appeared sold by the end of the day.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- United States space officials said tonight they were not surprised at the announcement in Moscow that Russia's Lunik 5 carried equipment for a soft landing on the moon.
CHICAGO, May 11 -- Shareholders of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad gave overwhelming approval today to its proposed consolidation with the Chicago North Western Railway.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 11 -- John Bartlow Martin, President Johnson's personal envoy here, conferred today with Col. Francisco Caamano Deno of the rebel regime in Santo Domingo.
The president of the American Jewish Congress urged last night a "final act of recompense'' by West Germany for 150,000 Jewish victims of Nazism barred by German law from receiving compensation.
Youngstown Steel and Tube Company announced yesterday that it planned to spend $375 million in the next four years on new facilities in the Chicago area.
PARIS, May 11 -- Europe's most affluent society was advised today to restrain its economy.
A civil suit was filed yesterday against the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company and 13 of its officers and directors by a group of former stockholders.
Mayor Wagner announced a reorganization of the city's antipoverty program yesterday. The new structure gives poor people more representation on policy- and decision-making bodies.

Two powerful unions that represent seamen of the merchant marine have been discussing a merger or an affiliation, but one of the unions complained yesterday that the talks were "an exercise in futility."

The mound upon which Windsor Castle stands was first chosen by William the Conqueror as the site for a fortress to guard the western approach to London. By the time his grandson, Henry II, ascended to the throne, Windsor had been transformed into a splendid residence and playground for the ever-expanding British royal court.

LOS ANGELES, May 11 (AP) -- The Houston Astros' unbeaten rookie pitcher, Dave Giusti, hurled a four-hitter for his sixth victory tonight as Houston defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2-1, on Joe Gaines's two-run homer.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The American Medical Association said today that "a deterioration in the quality of [medical] care is inescapable" if the House-passed Social Security-health bill becomes law.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 11 (AP) -- Oklahoma teachers voted by more than four to one today to boycott state schools next year unless their demands are met. The actual vote was 5,383 for the boycott, 1,275 against it and 1,038 undecided.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 12 (AP) -- Communist China said today that there could be no negotiations on Vietnam that were brought about through a cessation in United States bombing of North Vietnam. This, it said, would be "war blackmail."

TOKYO, May 11 -- Foreign Minister Etsusaburo Shiina said today that United States forces based in Japan may be used in South Vietnam without prior consultation with the Japanese Government, provided they are moved to Okinawa first.

Judge Justine Wise Polier of the Family Court and Miss Sarah Sussman, a social worker, have received the annual Naomi Lehman Memorial Foundation Awards. These are given each year at the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, 130 East 59th Street, to a volunteer and a professional social worker for outstanding service to children.

THE spiked shoes of Casey Stengel skidded on the concrete ramp in the West Point gymnasium on Monday afternoon and down crashed the peerless leader of the New York Mets. Two months before his 75th birthday, the presumably indestructible Casey had broken the radius bone just above his right wrist.
A sleepy market snapped to attention in the final minutes yesterday to pare early losses.

MEXICO CITY, May 11 -- A fund of $42 million to equalize economic growth within the Central American Common Market has been constituted, a spokesman for the trade bloc announced at today's session here of the llth biennial Conference of the Economic Commission for Latin America, a United Nations agency.

BOSTON, May 11 (UPI) -The United States Court of Appeals for the First Judicial Circuit relinquished its jurisdiction today in the case in which Northeast Airlines seeks to retain its money-making Florida route.

HAVANA, May 11 -- Two Italian Communist leaders were reported today to be on their way to Cuba. Their imminent visit is seen as a sign of growing involvement of the West s strongest Communist party in the Caribbean and in Latin America.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), May 11 -- In other countries it might seem odd, but in Israel it seems quite natural that the chairman of the board of the Israel Museum, which opened today, once engaged in gun running.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A 12-hour program of intellectual combat over Vietnam, featuring McGeorge Bundy in the main event, has been arranged here for a nationwide teach-in Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- President Johnson said today that his job development program had created the possibility of 25,558 new jobs since it began in February. He made the comment in a statement read at the signing of the largest on-the-job training contract on record.
PITTSBURGH, May 11 (UPI) -- Al McBean pitched three innings of sparkling relief to save a 4-3 victory by the Pittsburgh Pirates over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I. May 11 -- Tom Nieporte, a 31-year-old professional, celebrated his fourth year at his home club. Piping Rock today by winning the Long Island Golf Association's open championship for the third time.

CLEVELAND, May 11 -- The New York Central Railroad's results for the second quarter this year "will be better than last year" when it cleared $9.8 million, or $1.47 a share, on gross revenues of $163 million, according to Alfred E. Perlman, president.

The formation of a new architectural lighting consulting company, David A. Mintz, Inc., has been announced. Mr. Mintz, the principle, has designed lighting for hotels, banks, stores, the theater and a world's Fair attraction.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A bipartisan coalition of Senate liberals was narrowly defeated today in their effort to write into the voting rights bill a flat ban on poll taxes in state elections.
LONDON, May 11 -- Dr. Halvard Lange, Norway's Foreign Minister, deplored today the United States' failure to match military pressure with diplomatic activity for peace in Vietname.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, May 12 (AP) -- Four mortar shells apparently being used as movie props exploded today in a South Vietnamese film studio adjoining the residence of the United States Deputy Ambassador, U. Alexis Johnson.
The Borden Company is expanding its food operations through the acquisition of Henderson's Portion Pak, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- "In 10 or 15 years, it will be difficult to find within the Soviet Union a man capable of performing a Jewish religious burial ceremony, a Jewish wedding ceremony or a Bar Mitzvah," a Jewish leader told a House subcommittee today.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) -- President Johnson plans to go before the nation Thursday with an updated report on the international situation, his second such report in less than two weeks.
A series of depressing events descended upon the New York Mets at Shea Stadium last night, and the 4-3 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals was not the most important among them.

YONKERS, May 11 -- Yonkers Raceway's most successful harness racing meeting will conclude tomorrow night after attracting about 1,700,000 fans who will have bet more than $150,000,000 during the 70 nights of action here.

An unscheduled passenger is scheduled to be debarked from the Israeli luxury liner Shalom at Pier 32, at Canal Street, this morning. He is Marinus Boom. 21-year-old crew member of the Dutch freighter Alamak who was transferred to the Israeli liner Monday several hundred miles northwest of Bermuda to receive emergency treatment for a suspected case of pneumonia.
HONOLULU, May 11 (AP) -- Hawaii's new divorce law was signed Saturday -- two days earlier than planned -and no one told Circuit Judge Samuel King, presiding over the divorce courts.

DEMOPOLIS, Ala., May 11 (UPI) -- Police Chief Albert Cooper said today that he had sprayed tear gas on about 50 arrested civil rights demonstrators when they began seaming and pulling mattreses from bunks in the city jail.

CALVERTON, L.I, May 11 -- The F-111B, the Navy's version of the controversial TFX fighter design, was defended by military and industry officials today as the plane was rolled out for its first showing.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 11 (UPI) -- The shouts of a teenager brought down the house early today at a teach-in here.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 11 -- Plastic seaweed is being laid at this upper-middle-class coastal resort in Southern England to halt the ravages of the tides.
The seventh dinner dance of the New York Association for Brain Injured Children will be held on May 22 in the New York Hilton's Grand Ballroom.
ALBANY, May 11 -- Passage of a bill that would have the effect of legalizing rent strikes in New York City under certain conditions was predicted today by Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki.
MOSCOW, May 12 -- The Soviet Union's spacecraft Luna 5 struck the moon today in an apparent failure of the first attempt to achieve a soft landing of an instrumented package on the lunar surface.
KARACHI, Pakistan, May 12 -- A cyclone lashed East Pakistan today, bringing death, destruction and added misery to a poverty ridden, crowded region.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 12 -- Race track patrons who want to know what 4-5 or 9-2 on the tote board represent in actual cash will get their wish starting tomorrow night.
ALBANY, May 12 -- Republicans in the Assembly accused the Democrats today of reneging on a pledge to raise New York State's minimum drinking age from 18 to 21.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A proposal has been revived at the current hearings of a Senate-House committee that Congress equip itself with an "ombudsman." This is the official, conceived in Scandinavia and now fully operating there and in New Zealand, whose business is to investigate complaints by individual citizens of the acts and processes of government.

Mothers and grandmothers who were enchanted with Rachel Lent's original designs for little boys this spring (collarless shirts, bib-top shorts) will be able to buy her clothes for little girls next fall.

GREENVILLE, S.C., May 12 (UPI) -- The estranged wife and daughter of a Greenville Industrialist were arrested with a third woman today in a case involving the theft of $550,000 in cash from the industrialist's bathroom.
The appointment of two vice presidents of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the reassignment of a third was announced yesterday by Stuart T. Saunders, chairman.

VACATION-BOUND John and Rita Remondi had no intention of buying a dog when they left Armonk, N.Y., 12 years ago. Mrs. Remondi never had owned a pup. Her husband, as a youth, had hunted with pointers when he attended a military school in the Italian Alps.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 12 ( UPI) -- The Alabama Senate gave Gov. George C. Wallace a victory today by approving a controversial resolution urging schools to delay meeting Federal desegregation demands.
Robert Alex Baron lives at 55th Street on the Avenue of the Americas, where the city is building a subway spur. The work has been going on for a year and will continue until January, 1967.

LONDON, May 12 (UPI) -- Caroline Kennedy stole the show today when she arrived aboard a White House jetliner with her mother, Mrs. John F. Kennedy, to attend the dedication of Britain's memorial to the late President.

OMAHA, May 12 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal Court ruled today that the Nebraska Legislature's second attempt in two years to reapportion itself did not meet one-man, one-vote standards and was invalid.

Jack Fisher, who had been having ninth-inning trouble and other miserable experiences all season long, got through a final inning in fine shape at Shea Stadium yesterday, and pitched the New York Mets to a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 12 (AP) -- Ambassador W. Averell Harriman said today that the situation in the Dominican Republic arose from a Soviet-Chinese ideological split in which each side is trying "to prove its methods promise the fastest and surest road to Communism."

WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- The average American worker now needs $123 a week to provide just "the necessities of life" for a family of four, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization said today.

Replacement of the existing Community Mental Health Board by a new city Department of Mental Health has been recommended to Mayor Wagner by a committee of experts. This would be a great step toward better coordination in a complex field.

SOME of the simplest bids in standard methods become slightly less simple in the hands of tournament players. A raise of one spade to two spades, for example, traditionally shows 6-10 points in high cards, or slightly less if distributional values are present.

The apparent attempt by the Soviet Union to land a vehicle intact on the moon marks the start of a series of such shots by both the Soviet Union and the United States that will continue for at least two years.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The United States should expect more space "surprises" from the Soviet Union, without the ability to match them immediately, before the first American lands on the moon, space officials say.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- A major study of advertising agency-client relationships released here today revealed that a surprisingly high number of advertisers were reassessing their present systems of agency compensation.

HONG KONG, May 12 -- Passenger service on the principal southern rail line in Communist China has been periodically interrupted by what may be the movement of heavy military equipment to North Vietnam, informed sources said today.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 -- The Kansas City Securities Corporation, a subsidiary of a mutual fund management company becomes a member of the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange tomorrow amid an undercurrent of controversy and some bitterness.
WESTPORT, Conn., May 12 -- Shaw has come to suburbia in the spring in an experiment designed to change the image of the Westport Country Playhouse.

LONDON, May 12 -- The death last month of Joshua Macmillan, the 20-year-old grandson of former Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, was the result of "respiratory obstruction" caused by a mixture of alcohol and 20 tablets of Valium, a tranquilizer, the Oxford coroner ruled today.

Two of the three members of the 1965 Pulitzer Prize music jury resigned yesterday in protest against the Pulitzer advisory board's ignoring of the jury's unanimous recommendation for a citation to Duke Ellington.

LOS ANGELES, May 12 (UPI) -Ron Fairly's bases-loaded single drove in two runs in the third inning tonight to help Don Drysdale gain his fifth victory of the season as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Houston Astros, 4 to 2.
Disciplinary hearings began yesterday at Columbia University on the student demonstration last Friday that forced the cancellation of a ceremony of the school's Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps.
SHUSHAN, N.Y., May 12 -- The streams and rivers in the New York-Vermont border area are in prime condition for trout fishing.

A 24-acre tract fronting on the East River in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the National Sugar Refining Company to the News Syndicate Company, publisher of the Daily News and The Sunday News here.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12 -- South Vietnamese Rangers have made contact with the retreating Vietcong force that occupied most of a provincial capital yesterday, it was reported here today.
The British pound edged down in slow trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The Canadian dollar fell sharply in active dealings.

NEW DELHI, May 12 -- As the spotless white Congress cap of Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri disappeared into an Air India jetliner this morning, an American official sidled up to a friend and whispered, "The Russians just postponed the trip."
Many Manhattan residents may soon be able to satisfy their obligations to do jury duty by staying near a telephone for two weeks instead of sitting inactive in the County Courthouse.

ALBANY, May 12 -- With only one negative vote, tile Legislature passed a bill today calling for a referendum in November to decide whether there should be a constitutional convention to draft amendments for a new permanent system of apportionment.
NEW ORLEANS, May 12 -- The automobile of the president of the Louisiana affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union was heavily damaged by a fire bomb early today. No one was injured.
The "under-new-management" sign may soon appear in the windows of some of New York's most renowned restaurants.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Communications Satellite Corporation won today a bid for outright ownership of three ground stations for a global space communications network.

JACK CURTICE, who has coached college football 34 years, said recently: "Academic people look down their noses at us and make it difficult for us to get equipment and space for team sports in high schools and colleges.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India conveyed gratification to Soviet leaders today for their "understanding and respect" for India's policy of nonalignment. At a Kremlin dinner in his honor, Mr. Shas tri also called on "the international community" to prevent the acquisition of nuclear weapons by additional nations.
The State Assembly has killed in committee a bill that would have drastically curtailed the use of confessions in criminal cases.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- The Defense Department said today that an Army paratrooper shot a Dominican youth to death in Santo Domingo last night after accusing the youth of having poisoned him.

IN a manner that's entirely at variance with their exalted status as the champions of the world, the St. Louis Cardinals have been spending too much time in the slum area of the National League, bogged down in the lower reaches of the standings. It is the kind of start that would give most managers a bad case of the jitters, especially a freshman skipper in his first whirl at the big time.
On the same day in New fice, a saleswoman in a major York, an executive at his ofdepartment store and a Civil Service supervisor received similar memos.
The city's budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will be a record-breaking $3,875,724,495, Mayor Wagner disclosed last night. This will be $514,299,669 higher than the current budget.
The New York Racing Association will start building a new $30,700,000 Belmont Park within 90 days if the New York State Racing Commission gives its approval.
John Gielgud will film "Ages of Man," his solo Shakespearean program, for a two-hour television show to be presented next season by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Armand D'Angeio, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, drew the city's Boy Scouts into the active drive for water conservation yesterday.

" A desire to call all the signals" has led Draper Daniels to purchase a controlling interest in the Chicago agency of Roche, Rickerd, Henri, Hurst, Inc. Mr. Daniels resigned as executive vice president for creative services of Compton Advertising Inc., earlier this week.

LONDON, May 12 -- With a massive new loan from the International Monetary Fund, Britain has lost some of her economic sovereignty; but she has gained time in the attempt to solve her economic problems.
Copper futures dropped sharply in active trading here yesterday on the Commodity Exchange.
PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -- Tommy Harper's triple sparked a two-run seventh-inning rally that sent the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phils tonight.

" Swan Lake it ain't," said a baffled woman in the audience Tuesday night as 15 turtles with flashlights taped to their backs stirred sluggishly around the huge polished floor of an abandoned Columbia Broadcasting System studio at Broadway and 81st Street.

CLEVELAND, May 12 -- The International Telephone and Telegraph Company achieved a 12 per cent increase in its net income in the first quarter this year. The company has "every confidence that the upward trend will continue during the balance of 1965 and beyond" Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here today.

A movement to boycott Medicare if Congress approves the Administration bill will spread to at least a haft-dozen states, Dr. Jack Schreiber of Canfield, Ohio, predicted yesterday. Ht is a leader in the projected boycott effort.
The Transit Authority yesterday extended bus service to Staten Island for the duration of the ferry strike.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Johnson requested pay increases today for the armed forces and for most Federal employes. The increases, which would cost $853 million a year, would take effect Jan. 1.
PITTSBURGH, May 12 (AP) -- Jose Torre's bases-empty home run and a two-run homer by Felipe Alou paced the Milwaukee Braves to a 5-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.
ANOTHER opening, another show and don't you wish it were another "Kiss Me, Kate"?

MADRID, May 12 -- Twenty-three Basque nationalists were sentenced by the Public Order Court here today to prison terms of six months to six years on charges of having taken part in illegal activities in the Basque underground movement and of having distributed illicit propaganda.

Four public elementary schools with a preponderance of Negro and Puerto Rican students will open next fall with white students whose parents want them to attend integrated schools, the Board of Education announced yesterday.
JACKSON, Wyo., May 12 (AP) -- Donald Hough, author of "A Cocktail Hour in Jackson Hole," was burned to death last night in the small cabin where he lived alone. He was in his early seventies.

Unilever, N.V., and Unilever, Ltd., the twin Dutch and British companies that make up one of the world's largest businesses, reported yesterday a dramatic increase in sales and earnings for the first quarter.

ATHENS, May 12 -- Greece and Turkey have agreed to start talks on the Cyprus dispute at the ambassadorial level, a qualified source disclosed here today. The meeting would take place soon in Newt York, it was said.
The optimistic mood in the investment banking community that resulted from Tuesday's large and successful offerings continued to pervade the market yesterday.

Byron D. Woodside, acting chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that he did not expect corporate executives to "clam up" as a result of the lawsuit involving the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company.
DEMOPOLIS, Ala., May 12 (UPI) -- The police arrested 15 civil rights demonstrators and six parents today. The parents were charged with allowing their children to stay out of school.
BALTIMORE, May 12 -- The dramatis personae for the 90th running of the Preakness were rounded out today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, May 12 -- Prosecutors contended today that Napoleon Bonaparte Johnson, 74-year-old Justice of the Oklahoma Supreme Court, had spent $10,000 more during a two-year period than his financial records showed he had available to spend.

TORONTO, May 12 (Canadian Press) -- Companies controlled by George MacMillan, president of Windfall Oils and Mines, Ltd., and his wife Viola, sold shares of Windfall short last July while the stock was soaring on the stock exchange, a Royal Commission was told today.
The nation's electric power production rose 6.4 per cent in the week ended May 8 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

THE British General Wolfe said in 1759 that he would rather have written Gray's "Elegy" than beat the French at Quebec. Things might have gone a trifle more smoothly, later, if he had picked something by Racine.

Sundestine, Fleming B. Fraser's juvenile filly, a 6-to-1 shot, won the 67th running of the Fashion Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday beating Inyala the odds-on favorite from C. W. Englehard's stable, by a nose.

ALBANY, May 12 -- Following the vote by which the Senate approved today the abolition of capital punishment, with some exceptions, in New York State:

The construction of 15,500 cooperative apartments on the site formerly occupied by Freedomland in the Bronx won the approval of the City Planning Commission yesterday. The $300 million project, known as Co-op City, will be sponsored by the United Housing Foundation.

SIR FREDERICK ASHTON'S choreographic interpretation of Maurice Ravel's "Daphnis and Chloe" made a welcome return to New York on Tuesday evening when it was given the first of four consecutive performances by the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House.
Councilman Paul O'Dwyer, Manhattan Reform Democrat, has decided to oppose City Council President Paul R. Screvane in a primary contest this fall, associates reported yesterday.

PEAKS OF OTTER, Va., May 12 -- It was more instant vacation today as Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall took the high road and Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson took the low road among Virginia's spectacular Blue Ridge Mountains.
Five West Harlem residents -- a building superintendent, a luncheonette operator and three housewives -- met with top Morningside Heights officials yesterday to discuss low-cost housing.
LONDON, May 12 -- The Labor Government indicated tonight that it would allow time in Parliament for consideration of a bill to reform the law on homosexuality.

YONKERS, May 12 -- Bret Hanover, acknowledged as a great colt, was clearly the best in the 11th edition of the $125,236.25 Cane Pace tonight as Yonkers Raceway's spring harness racing meeting ended before a crowd of 27,122.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell publicly abandoned today attempts to make sweeping changes in the Federal anti-poverty program.
The New York Shakespeare Festival has so far received $244,285 from 7,725 donors to launch its most ambitious summer season of free performances.
SANTIAGO, Dominican Republic, May 12 -- People now call this lush green valley the "independent republic of Cibao."
NYACK, N.Y., May 12 (AP) -- Lee D. Stern, 50 years old, said today he had ended a fast protesting United States policy in Vietnam after 84 days without solid food.
EVERYBODY'S so art-conscious these days, it's no surprise that Estee Lauder, who is somewhat of a collector herself, has been looking at portraits to inspire her new make-ups.
Mayor Wagner expressed high confidence yesterday that he could win if Representative John V. Lindsay challenged his bid for a fourth term.
PARIS, May 12 -- Andy Warhol, the man who taught art how to pop and movies how not to move, opened his second one-man show at the Ileana Sonnabend Gallery today. It was called "Flowers."

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Following is the text of a letter from Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, to Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, dealing with the office's policy on local administration of poverty program:

THE man who took leadership yesterday in the city's campaign against poverty has lived a life of unusual privilege in settings of marked underprivilege -- settings he has sought to serve, rather than escape. Dr. Arthur Courtney Logan is a distinguished general surgeon.
The World's Fair is in tight financial difficulties that are reaching a critical stage, according to those close to the fair's fiscal situation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 12 -- The United States has offered $13.5 million in supplementary aid for a power and irrigation project in Laos under the United Nations development program for the Meking River basin.

The recent Supreme Court decision upholding the Secretary of State's right to prohibit American citizens from visiting Cuba -- and, by implication, any other area -- throws a shadow over the future of freedom of travel abroad. A minority of three justices declared the decision to be bad law. We believe the decision reflects bad policy.

A news item in your May 6 issue reported that the car of the Spanish Consul General and the car of the Argentine Consul General collided in midtown Manhattan with considerable impact. The report continued: "Pedestrians, after noting the 'FC' on each of the license plates, shifted emotional gears quickly from sympathy to something close to joy."

Of 2.305 golfers entered in the 1965 United States Open championship, 31 will be exempt from all qualifying and 41 others will be exempt from the first qualifying round, the United States Golf Association said yesterday.

PAVEL KORIN, 73 years of age, Member of the Academy of Art of the U.S.S.R. elected in 1962). People's Artist of the U.S.S.R. (so designated on his 70th birthday), winner of the U.S.S.R.'s highest as award, the Lenin Prize 1963) and usually called the dean of Soviet painters, is having a one-man show at the Hammer Galleries, 51 East 57th Street.
Further price rises on aluminum products were posted by producers yesterday.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 12 -- Mediators from the Organization of American States met twice today with the rebel command and once with the United States-backed civilian-military junta, but the prospects for a prompt political settlement appeared dim.

In his letter on May 4 Altemur Kilic, Information Counselor for the Turkish Embassy, states that he grew up imbued with Ataturk's principle that "Whosoever has shared the misfortunes of our country with us is our compatriot and fellow citizen, regardless of his race, religion or culture."
Two major trade associations ratified a new union agreement yesterday and virtually ended an 11-day strike in the garment center here.
Following Tuesday's deluge of about $170 million of municipal bonds, offerings decreased yesterday to about $27 million of state and local government bonds.

Prime Minister Shastri's agreement to negotiations and, if necessary, arbitration of the Rann of Cutch dispute with Pakistan promises to bring a cease-fire and ultimately a settlement of this minor but troublesome frontier conflict. But there will be little likelihood of a lasting peace on the Indian subcontinent until New Delhi and Karachi come to grips with the central issue that embitters their relations and encourages Pakistan's drift toward Peking -- the issue of Kashmir.
IRVINGTON, N.J., May 12 -- The Town Council last night failed to renew the annual operating license of Olympic Park, New Jersey's oldest amusement park.

HAVANA, May 12 -- The regime said today that it had uncovered a network of persons spying for the United States and said they would "receive merited punishment from revolutionary justice." This seems to mean mass execution.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 -- Iraq broke diplomatic relations with West Germany today in protest against Bonn's establishment of relations with Israel, the Baghdad radio reported.

" Fifty Best American Short Stories 1915-1965," edited by Martha Foley, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on June 25. The story annual's 50th anniversary will be marked by a selection from the 2,450 tales printed up to this year.
LONDON, May 12 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization ended its meeting tonight with a hopefully worded communique making no reference to the division in the alliance.

Churches in the Soviet Union remain "very active" despite the Communist leadership's unrelenting campaign against religion, an American Presbyterian clergyman said yesterday upon his return from two and a half years in Moscow.
Edwin L. Dale Jr. of The New York Times and Lee Silberman of The Wall Street Journal received the eighth annual Loeb Awards of the University of Connecticut for business and financial writing.
LONDON, May 12 -- Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., one of the five biggest shipowners in Britain, is seeking to acquire full control of the Royal Mail Lines, Ltd.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy announced yesterday that 1,000 extra policemen and policewomen would patrol the city's parks and recreational areas during the summer months.
SONGBE, South Vietnam, May 12 -- S. Sgt. Horace E. Young was lying wounded in the mess hall at 3 A.M. yesterday when a grenade rolled through the door.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The House Judiciary Committee ignored Administration wishes today and insisted on retaining in the voting rights bill a ban on payments of poll taxes in state and local elections.

Lincoln's "little lady who made this big war" with her "Uncle Tom's Cabin" has an undeserved reputation as a prim New England do-gooder who, by accident, wrote one great book. Actually, Mrs. Stowe was far from prim and, more to the point, she possessed a fine narrative ability and a keen eye for character that sustained a half-dozen very good and still readable novels.

ST. LOUIS -- "I never have cooked and I don't want to ever," Mrs. August A. Busch Jr. stated resolutely as she stepped into a lady's phaeton to drive a pair of hackneys. "But in our home we love to dine well and do."
Earl Douglas Hansen, president of the firm bearing his name, has announced the opening of a new real estate and insurance office at 509 Fifth Avenue.

Westinghouse Electric stock closed yesterday at 53 1/4, up 1 5/8 for the session, after touching 53 3/8, its highest price since 1960. The stock's progress demonstrates that mutual funds and other institutions, like everyone else, love a winner and hate a loser in the market.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 12 -- John Rigos, Middle East correspondent of The Christian Science Monitor, and Dana Adams Schmidt, Middle East correspondent of The New York Times, who were badly injured in a jeep accident in northern Yemen last Thursday, were flown into Beirut tonight for treatment.

LONDON, May 12 -- Plans to maintain the Atlantic alliance's military and political vigor in the event of France's withdrawal have been quietly advanced in Washington and London, authoritative sources disclosed tonight.

BUFFALO, May 12 -- Stockholders of the Marine Midland Corporation approved today acquisition of the Grace National Bank of New York by the Marine Midland Trust Company, also of New York. The trust company is a subsidiary of Marine Midland Corporation, a Buffalo-based bank holding company.

In a move to attract more businessmen from abroad to the city, the Convention and Visitors Bureau opened an office last week in Paris. It is the first office set up by the bureau outside the United States.
A total of 111 companies in 21 retailing categories were presented with brand-name-retailer-of-the year awards last night by the Brand Names Foundation, Inc., at a dinner at the Americana Hotel.

Selection of a jury of eight men and four women, plus four alternates, was completed yesterday in State Supreme Court for the trial of Bernard Gittelson, 46-year-old public relations man, charged with testifying falsely before a grand jury investigating a conspiracy to bribe a city official.

BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored all their runs in a first-inning rally highlighted by Paul Blair's lead-off homer and defeated the Cleveland Indians, 4-2, tonight. The victory moved the Orioles into fourth place in the American League.
CHICAGO, May 12 (UPI) -- Pete Ward got four hits and drove in four runs to lead the Chicago White Sox to a double-header sweep over the Kansas City Athletics, 7 -- 4 and 6 -- 4, tonight.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 12 -- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama vetoed today a Federal grant for the Birmingham anti-poverty program headed by one of his political enemies.

BOSTON, May 12 -- Bill Monbouquette, a 28-year-old insurance salesman from Woburn, Mass., enhanced two professional distinctions tonight as he pitched the Boston Red Sox to a 2-0 victory over the New York Yankees.

ROME, May 12 (AP) -- A monastery mystery that centered on a dead Roman and $64,000 worth of contraband cigarettes led a Vatican newspaper to express the belief today that some Capuchin monks might be involved in a vast tobacco-smuggling racket.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Several hundred persons bearing placards held a peaceful interfaith vigil before the Pentagon today to protest United States policies in Vietnam.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 12 -- Chilean copper officials indicated today that this country would not try to force further increases in the world producer price for copper.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 12 -- The six elected members of the Security Council tried without success today to agree on a compromise resolution on the United States' "emergency action" in the Dominican Republic.
BONN, May 12 -- The West German Government gave a bland welcome today to the declaration on Germany. It came too late to be really welcome here.
