SAN JUAN, P.R., May 11 -- United States military intervention in the Dominican Republic has been a windfall for the small Puerto Rican elements that clamor for independence.
The London stock market continued to be quiet yesterday, with a firming trend evident mainly in industrial shares.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Leaders of the Ku Klux Klan are finally starting to worry about the Klan's image and taking the first uncertain steps to improve it.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 12 -- Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy, president of Adelphi University, and Mrs. Eddy of 55 Brompton Road will hold a champagne reception at their home on Friday evening after a performance of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" at the university's Little Theater.

A growing campaign to change the rules of the Waterfront Commission and weaken its authority over waterfront activity in the Port of New York has been marked in the last few days by feverish activity in New York City and Albany.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The International Monetary Fund approved today a $1.4 billion package of financial aid to help Britain defend the pound.

ALBANY, May 12 -- In a historic action, the Senate resoundingly approved today a bill that would effectively abolish the 350-year-old death penalty in New York as punishment for murder, kidnapping or treason.
Mayor Wagner appointed Dr. Arthur C. Logan, a Harlem surgeon, as chairman of the newly reorganized city antipoverty campaign yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Honduras today made the first formal offer to supply troops to an inter-American military force for the Dominican Republic.

The Chrysler Corporation's offering of 5,611,360 common shares to its present stockholders was estimated late yesterday to be "about 98 per cent subscribed." The rights offering expired yesterday at 3:30 P.M.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- An ex-convict testified today he introduced a forger to James W. Egan, principal stockholder in the Brighton, Colo., National Bank.
The list of officers of the Pan American Sulphur Company who have been selling their shares was expanded yesterday to include Marlin E. Sandlin, chairman.
LONDON, May 12 -- The Government tonight denied further war damage compensation to the Burmah Oil Company and virtually killed a long and complicated argument over retroactive legislation.
The State Commission of Investigation began closed hearings yesterday on the exchange of charges between Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson and District Attorney William Cahn.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The White House has cleared the appointment of a racial moderate from Mississippi for a key appointment to the Federal Court of Appeals with the heaviest volume of civil rights cases in the nation.
ERIE, Pa., May 12 -- Civil rights leaders withdrew today a demand that the Hammermill Paper Company suspend "indefinitely'' its plans to build a $25 million pulp mill near Selma, Ala.

May I add a footnote to your controversy [editorials April 30 and May 8] with Assistant Secretary of Defense Arthur Sylvester over the number of weapons lost to and captured from the Vietcong? The Defense Department would clarify the picture if instead of giving round numbers it broke down these weapons into categories.

MERV GRIFFIN, the amiable gentleman last seen on a civilized program of daytime chitchat, has returned to the home screen with an evening presentation closely patterned on the format of the "Tonight" show. The program is being produced by the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company for independent syndication and is seen locally at 11 P.M. on WPIX (Channel 11).

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 12, (AP) -- Harmon Killebrew blasted two home runs, the second a mighty two-run drive in the eighth inning that gave the Minnesota Twins a 4-3 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight.
The stock market surged ahead on heavy volume yesterday, giving the list its first strong direction this week.

A 25-year-old "gypsy" taxicab driver, who had plied his trade in the after-midnight hours in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant district was sentenced yesterday to 10-to-30 years in Sing Sing Prison on his conviction for robbery, attempted rape and grand larceny.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., May 12 -- The chief executive of the Republic Steel Corporation sharply criticized today the recent Government report on wages, prices and productivity in the steel industry as poorly timed and wrong in its implications.
A painting that is 10 feet tall and stretches 85 feet 3 inches -- more than one-third of a block -- in length was sold yesterday to a couple whose next problem is where to put it.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 12 -- The Senate's rejection of a ban on poll taxes in state elections was called "tragic" tonight by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Influential Republicans declared yesterday there was no doubt in their minds that Representative John V. Lindsay would accept the party nomination for Mayor. If there was ...

LONDON, May 12 -- The steel industry proposed today that the Government establish a new authority to supervise its operations -- without the total ownership of major companies sought by the Labor party.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Officials here are studying what they regard as one of the most serious and systematic discussions of military doctrine to come from Communist China in many years.
PARIS, May 12 -- The French Government took a conciliatory position today on two major problems dividing it from the United States.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 (UPI) -- A two-run homer by Ron Santo and timely eighth and ninth inning hitting helped the Chicago Cubs gain a 7-3 victory today over the San Francisco Giants.
Noramco, Inc., a diversified operating and manufacturing company, announced yesterday the appointment of Bert Fein as executive vice president.
LONDON, May 12 -- Rembrandt's painting of his son Titus, the center of a dramatic auction room dispute in March, is finally on its way to the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Congress needs a corps of expert auditors to provide an independent review and analysis of the Federal Budget, the Joint Committee on the Organization of Congress was told today.
SAYREVILLE, N.J., May 12 (AP) -- A 30-foot-long baby whale that resisted efforts to force her out to sea for five days was washed ashore dead yesterday.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 12 -- Governor Rockefeller's plan to create an authority to supervise the Long Island Rail Road is apparently opposed by many persons in at least one Long Island community.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 12 -- Richard Tillman, a young Air Force captain stationed at Dayton, Ohio, sailed Bermuda's Great Sound as if he owned it today. He became more firmly entrenched for the North American championship among the single-handed yachtsmen who sail Finn Class dinghies.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) -- Willie Horton collected three hits, including his second home run in two nights, to pace the Detroit Tigers tonight to a 5-2 triumph over the Washington Senators.
In his May 4 letter Cooper D. Ponton states that "the chief reason they [the poor] and impoverished is because of the inefficient way they have operated their own lives."

A 5 to 10 per cent annual decline in the number of American apparel companies as a result of mergers and acquisitions was forecast yesterday by a leading economist. This forecast for the next five years was delivered yesterday by Dr. Pierre Renfret.

GENOA, Italy, May 12 -- The United States aircraft carrier Saratoga joined the water-jet and whistle salute to the Michelangelo, flagship of the Italian lines, as she departed today on her maiden voyage to New York.
A sharp price drop in National Video overshadowed a generally weaker and very active market on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

GENEVA, May 12 -- Two Swiss banks have been placed under court supervision at their own request because of financial difficulties that are said to result from loans advanced to a Spanish financier for real estate deals outside that country.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan won the right yesterday to examine the records of Representative Adam Clayton Powell's financial account in the House of Representatives.
NEW ORLEANS, May 13 -- Jack Nicklaus returned to the tour today with a seven-under-par 65 in the $100,000 Greater New Orleans Open.
The British pound advanced yesterday in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here.
PITTSBURGH, May 13 (UPI) -- Joe Torre singled home Frank Bolling in the eighth inning tonight to give the Milwaukee Braves a 5-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 13 (UPI) -A three-judge Federal court panel enjoined today the merger of the Atlantic Coast Line and Seaboard Air Line railroads.

President Johnson's speech on Vietnam yesterday could not have been more clearly addressed to Hanoi if it had been marked "attention Ho Chi Minh." It was an effort worth making even if it remains unanswered at present. For the mere attempt to talk intelligently at, if unfortunately not to, the adversary forces the formulation of ideas in a new and useful way.

BALTIMORE, May 13 -- A heel burn that developed into an obvious swelling of Lucky Debonair's rear right ankle generated apprehension and anxiety today as to whether Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Kentucky Derby winner would start in Saturday's $150,000 added Preakness.
The New York Concert Ensemble gave another of its tidy sets of performances last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The program was all 20th century.

Roger Hilsman, former Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, charged last night that what he called the "tough line" in United States foreign policy is driving the newly emerging nations in Asia and Africa into allying with Communist nations.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The main debate of a nationwide teach-in about Administration policy in Vietnam is expected to be witnessed here Saturday by more than 5,000 persons.
The B.B.C. Symphony Orchestra, Antal Dorati conducting with Jacqueline du Pre, cellist, and Heather Harper, soprano, will perform at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:30.
LOS ANGELES, May 13 (AP) -- Many of the nation's top collegiate track and field stars arrived today for the 25th annual Coliseum Relays tomorrow night.

Complete reorganization of the city's school system, with the transfer of administrative power from central headquarters to local districts, was proposed yesterday by Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Acting Superintendent of Schools.
BALTIMORE, May 13 -- More than a dozen Italian opera singers found themselves without a stage today after coming here from Rome to help inaugurate a new cultural venture.
Stanley Steingut survived yesterday an attempt to unseat him as Kings County Democratic leader at an emotional meeting of the organization's executive committee.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Eugene Patterson, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, urged Congress today to revise a law that he said encouraged Government officials to withhold vital public information.

SAIGON, Friday, May 14 (AP) -- Government forces claimed a decisive victory today over elements of two Vietcong battalions, totalling about 500 men, after sharp fighting in the Mekong delta, about 100 miles southwest of Saigon.
The International Ladies' Garment Workers Union has supplied a novel answer for a problem that has brought chaos to labor-management relations in automobiles and other mass industries.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Johnson said today that Communist China was opposing a political solution of the Vietnamese war that would be in the interest of North Vietnam.
Traditional pomp, ceremony and ritual marked the inauguration yesterday of Dr. Samuel B. Gould as president of the State University of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Government said today that radio-controlled garage doors were becoming a menace to aviation in some parts of the country.
BOSTON, May 13 -- The New York Yankees lost their second straight four-game series to a second-division team tonight when the Boston Red Sox defeated Whitey Ford, 4-1.

LOS ANGELES, May 13 (UPI) -- Sandy Koufax came up with his top pitching performance of the season tonight, hurling the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 3-0 shutout over the Houston Astros in which he struck out 13 batters and allowed only three hits.
IF the weather is cooperative, and indications are it will be, the weekend should be about as fine for angling as a hook-tosser could desire.

GRINNELL, Iowa, May 13 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower called today for general public support of the policies of the Johnson Administration in Vietnam, the Dominican Republic and all points of tension with the Communist world.

CHICAGO, May 13 (UPI) -- The results of a study of cancer deaths among children may lead to more knowledge of the origin of leukemia, bone cancer and kidney cancer, an article in The Journal of the American Medical Association said today.
HOUSTON, May 13 (AP) -- Roy Hofheinz bought majority control of the Houston Astros today.
STOCKHOLM, May 13 (UPI) -- Sweden's neo-Nazi "fuhrer" was a Grand Dragon of the American Ku Klux Klan and planned to establish a klan in Sweden, a Stockholm newspaper said today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler disclosed today that the deficit in the nation's international payments was slightly above $750 million in the first quarter of this year.
Mayor Wagner put forward yesterday a $3.87 billion budget, highest in city history, to be balanced by what he described as "borrow-now, repay-later" financing.

Governor Rockefeller established the New York State active branch, was established in 1960 by the Legislature at the Governor's request. It functions on annual appropriations. Originally, the Legislature called for its dis-Council on the Arts as a permanent, agency yesterday.

MOSCOW, May 13 -- A Soviet space engineer described the flight of the spacecraft Luna 5 today as "still another step" toward a manned lunar expedition, despite the apparent failure of the craft to make a successful soft landing on the moon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Johnson told Congress today that he planned to merge three Government agencies dealing with the earth, the oceans and the atmosphere into an Environmental Science Services Administration.
ALBANY, May 13 -- The Democrats have decided to adjourn the Legislature no later than May 29 because many of its members are not willing to work now and get paid later.

Exhibit managers who were questioned at the World's Fair yesterday said they were not certain that the big industrial participants would put up additional money if the fair's financial plight became desperate.

CAIRO, May 13 -- The United Arab Republic broke diplomatic relations with West Germany today as a reprisal for its recognition of Israel but did not recognize East Germany, as President Gamal Abdel Nasser once threatened to do.
LONDON, May 13 -Britain's exports Ieveled off last month, while imports continued to rise, the Government reported today.
NEW HAVEN, May 13 (AP) -- The Yale Daily News, a student newspaper, announced its support of Representative John V. Lindsay for Mayor of New York City in an editorial tonight.

At a time of life when many thoroughbreds are prepared to enjoy the peace and quiet of the pasture, Milton Ritzenberg's Wise Ship seems ready to start a new phase of a racing career that had started to go downhill.

In his signed article on the May 10 editorial page Herbert L. Matthews states that the adoption of the "Johnson Doctrine" and the maintenance of the Monroe Doctrine will make "a shambles of the Inter-American System."

TORONTO, May 13 -Viola MacMillan, a $1.5 million winner in last summer's wild trading in Windfall Oils and Mines, Ltd., told a Government inquiry today that the Toronto Stock Exchange was to blame for permitting a disorderly market.
MOSCOW, May 13 -- Weekend fishermen and hunters will be permitted to sell their fish and game freely in Soviet farmer markets under new rules made public today.

New car sales maintained a fast pace in early May, rising by 17 per cent over the level a year ago and setting a new high for the period. Dealers retailed 227,171 cars in the May 1-10 span, against 194,206 in the 1964 period.
STOCKHOLM, May 13 (UPI) -- Floyd Patterson of New York, the former world heavyweight champion, will face Tod Herring of Texas tomorrow night in a 10-round bout in his favorite corner away from home.
LOS ANGELES, May 13 (AP) -- Jack L. Warner, his son-in-law and two lawyers were sued for $50 million yesterday by the former business manager of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The first contingents for the inter-American force that are to maintain order in the Dominican Republic will arrive tomorrow in Santo Domingo, the Organization of American States announced tonight.

West Germany formally announced the establishment of diplomatic relations with Israel yesterday, whereupon the United Arab Republic, Syria, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Algeria and Yemen broke relations with Bonn. Lebanon will do so today and Kuwait, which was going to establish relations with Bonn, has changed its mind.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13 -- Growing concern is being felt here about the constriction of rice supplies to the South Vietnamese cities and the possibility of adverse political consequences for the Government.
Three gunmen took jewelry valued at $40,000 to $60,000 and $130 in cash yesterday morning from the duplex apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Joseph Lebworth, 784 Park Avenue at 73d Street.

WHAT was poor Arthur Grumiaux's loss was Edith Peinemann's gain. Mr. Grumiaux, the eminent Belgian violinist, injured his shoulder a few weeks ago, and his scheduled American appearances had to be canceled.
Ad men who believe that no one out there likes them or their work can take heart. Substantial support for their efforts has been found -- in Brooklyn.

The bond market simmered down yesterday, quieting after prices and light trading activity. ity earlier in the week.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Phillies scored three runs to tie the score in the ninth tonight and then defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 7-6, when Dick Stuart scored from third on Deron Johnson's bad throw with two out in the 10th.
RALEIGH, N.C., May 13 -- Gov. Dan Moore announced today that 92 students had been accepted for study at the North Carolina School of the Arts.
First-quarter net earnings of the operating companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group were reported yesterday at $148,369,000. Sales and operating income totaled $2,466,590,000.
William Zeckendorf, who has decided not to contest a Federal Court suit demanding reorganization of Webb Knapp, Inc., his realty concern, still hopes to retain a major role in the company's affairs.
It is not often that the chairman of a company can report to his stockholders a doubling of gross receipts between one annual meeting and the next.

Michelle Duclos, former Canadian television personality and member of a separatist movement, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to illegally transporting dynamite into this country in a plot to destroy the Statue of Liberty, the Washington Monument and the Liberty Bell.

A 29-yoar-old woman narcotics addict died early yesterday in the infirmary of the Women's House of Detention in Greenwich Village, less than two days after she had been committed on charges of felonious assault and carrying concealed weapons.
City College marked the 118th anniversary of its founding yesterday with Charter Day ceremonies in the redecorated Great Hall of the college's Shepherd Hall, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.
WEBSTER, N.Y, May 13 -The Xerox Corporation believes it has found a new field to conquer -educational and industrial training equipment.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Willie Horton clouted his sixth and seventh home runs, added a double and drove in five runs tonight in leading the Detroit Tigers to a 13-3 rout of the Washington Senators.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 13 -- Roosevelt Raceway's venture into the new electronic era tonight left some fans impressed, others indifferent and the more reactionary ones downright defiant. The new system translated the approximate odds into probable money payoffs for the first and second horses to finish.
I would like to take exception to Mrs. Francis T.P. Plimpton's letter published May 3.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 13 -- Justice Napoleon Bonaparte Johnson of the Oklahoma Supreme Court was convicted on bribery charges today after a week-long impeachment trial.
CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) -- It is best to tell the truth to a child who is suffering from a fatal illness, a medical report said today.
PEKING, May 13 -- Communist China launched a mammoth protest demonstration today against United States intervention in the Dominican Republic.

The Dell Publishing Company acquired Noble Noble as a wholly owned subsidiary yesterday in the latest stage of a 43-year progression from pulp magazines and comic books to a full line of adult and Juvenile books.
The advance man for the State Academic Ensemble of Popular Dance of the Soviet Union came to town yesterday to tip off New Yorkers to what lies ahead starting next week.
E.J. Korvette, Inc., the nation's biggest discount department store chain, is thinking of going into the art business.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate Rules Committee, which spent 15 months investigating the tangled financial and business affairs of Robert G. Baker, is still wrestling with the language of its final report to the Senate.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., May 13 -- Mrs. De Witt Alexandre and Mrs. William M. Vogel Jr. of Somerset Hills teamed with two Essex County players, Mrs. Henry B. Cross Jr. and Mrs. Ernest Johnson, to win low-gross honors today in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's four-ball best-ball tournament.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 13 -- The Cornell University faculty passed a resolution yesterday expressing "disquiet" over a noisy student demonstration during an appearance on the campus of W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador at Large, on Tuesday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 13 -- President Humberto Castello Branco asked Congress today for tighter judicial control over who can seek political office in Brazil.
BONN, May 13 -- West Germany and Israel, partners for years in a close but informal relationship, announced today the beginning of full diplomatic relations.

A new ecumenical gesture was made yesterday by the American Bible Society when it announced that one of its major goals was to develop, with sister bodies in other countries, a single text of the Scriptures that would be acceptable to all Christians.
PHILADELPHIA., May 13 -- Several hundred policemen are manning wooden barricades here to protect the 10-foot-high walls of a school for white orphans from militant Negro pickets.

Mayor Wagner greeted Representative John V. Lindsay's entry into the mayoral race yesterday with some taunting comments on Republicans in general. "Our Re publican friends," he said, "only begin to take an interest in public affairs just before election. You can't find them any other time."
The city's concern for the poor, the unemployed, the troubled youth and the sick and aged will cost it about $1.2 billion in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. May 13 -- Denmark suggested today that Communist China could be heard by the 18-nation disarmament conference in Geneva and urged that the conference resume its work soon. The proposal was made in the 114-member Disarmament Commission.

The city will have six ferries running to Staten Island in the morning rush hour today and provide half of the normal passenger capacity, a spokesman for the Department of Marine and Aviation announced yesterday.

Thanks to the dome in Houston, baseball attendance is up 5.4 per cent over last year despite problems at Milwaukee and Kansas City. The figures, issued yesterday, were based on an Associated Press survey of games through last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) -- Representative Harold D. Cooley, Democrat of North Carolina, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, introduced a new cotton bill today. It is designed to cut surplus production and to permit direct payment to farmers of Government marketing subsidies which now go to traders.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 13 -- The Security Council was warned today that if Senegal had to fight to defend her independence she would be joined by many other states in a "holy crusade for the liberation of Africa."

TOKYO, May 13 (AP) -- The lower house of Parliament adopted a resolution today calling on Premier Eisaku Sato's Government to "correct the inequality" of the existing United States-Japan aviation pact.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 13 -- The Soviet Union and France joined today in an attempt to have the Security Council give a hearing to a representive of Col. Francisco Caamano Deno's rebel regime in the Dominican Republic.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 13 -- Harness drivers left their two-room bungalows and a sizable contingent of hotel guests left their borscht and bingo for horse racing tonight as Monticello Raceway opened its eighth and longest season.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 13 (UPI) -- Speeds soared with the rising temperature at the Indianapolis Speedway today as the 1964 winner of the 500-mile race, A.J. Foyt, passed the 160-miles-an-hour barrier and one of the famed Novis crashed in practice.
The Board of Education received a record-breaking allocation of more than $1 billion for the operation of the public schools yesterday.
Features on heart disease, birth control and narcotics addition have won the 16th annual Albert Lasker Medical Journalism Awards, the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation announced yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 13 -- Race Time, last season's sophomore pacing, champion, made his debut as a 4-year-old tonight at Roosevelt Raceway and stamped himself the horse to beat for the title in that division.
The United States gold stock declined $60 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday he had "no objection to France becoming a reserve-currency nation" but added that the French Government does not want the responsibility that goes with it.
Columbia University has bought for all undisclosed price the drawings of Louis Sullivan, pioneer of modern architecture, which were given to Frank Lloyd Wright shortly before Sullivan died in 1924.
The Chrysler Corporation's $269 million offering of common stock to its shareholders was completed yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Four Southerners and an Ohioan have been picked to conduct the hearings on the Ku Klux Klan by the House Committee on Un-American Activities, a source said today.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 13 -- Francis J. Musso Jr., a trustee of the Village of Freeport, was charged today with extorting $500 from a witness who was scheduled to appear before a grand jury investigating a vice case.

Mayor Wagner's $3.9 billion executive budget for 1965-66 is founded on a credit-card fiscal policy so reckless that it invites repudiation at Albany and challenge in the courts. The Mayor's own description of the method used to "balance" it is "borrow now, repay later."

Chuck Hiller, the second-base replacement for the injured Ron Hunt, will get his first experience with his new team in the New York Mets' dugout tonight. Casey Stengel's club will open a four-game series against the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium and Hiller is slated for utility duty only.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Pressures are mounting on David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers of America, to accept the official results of the union's election.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 13 (UPI) -- Ambassador Howard P. Jones Will leave his post here May 29 after seven years' service in Indonesia, the United States Embassy announced today.

A State Supreme Court jury awarded $755,000 yesterday to four young sisters whose parents died in the crash of an American Airlines jetliner in Jamaica Bay on March 1, 1962, in which all 95 passengers and crew members perished.

The American Broadcasting Company notified the Federal Communications Commission yesterday afternoon that it was preparing plans for a domestic communications satellite that would relay network television programs to hundreds of affiliated stations for rebroadcast to home viewers.
OXFORD, England, May 13 (UPI) -- Oxford University and the town were stirred today by a stepped up police hunt for narcotic peddlers.

TOKYO, Friday, May 14 (AP) -- Communist China denounced today a new Indian proposal for ending the Vietnam war as "preposterous." The United States had said it was giving the plan "very careful consideration."

Wayne Thomas Lonergan testified yesterday that he was repeatedly struck in the back of the head with the heel of a hand by persons he could not see during the 16 hours before he signed a confession to the brutal killing of his heiress wife.

ALBANY, May 13 -- Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki said today that he had "absolutely no doubt" that the key financing elements in Mayor Wagner's $3.87 billion budget would sail through the Legislature.

Beginning today, men and youths who are willing to spend eight weeks learning one of six trades in which there are job openings may sign up at either of two offices designated by the city's Department of Labor.

TOKYO, May 13 -- A Japanese television network promised today to tone down a documentary film series on South Vietnam after viewers complained of an episode broadcast Sunday that showed atrocities committed by Government forces.

WASHINGTON, May' 13 -- John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, Speaker of the House broke with the Administration today as he threw his full support behind the inclusion of poll tax ban in the voting rights bill.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The State Department said today that the Communist policy of supporting "interference and subversion under the guise of so-called wars of national liberation" was threatening world peace.

Much criticism of United States policy in Vietnam focuses on three complaints: That Washington (1) refuses to start peace negotiations; (2) continues to bomb North Vietnam; (3) and gives insufficient attention to Southeast Asia's economic requirements.

A former enlisted man in the Air Force who pleaded guilty to having spied for the Soviet Union in this country and abroad was sentenced yesterday to 30 years' imprisonment. He is Robert Glenn Thompson, 30 years old, of Bay Shore, L.I.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., May 13 -- A slender, 47-year-old lawyer has embarked on the grueling and digestively perilous upstate speaking circuit.

A two-and-a-half year investigation into the illegal diversion of $6 million worth of surplus grains to eight European countries, including two behind the Iron Curtain, resulted yesterday in the indictment of a New Orleans grain exporting company, three European concerns and four individuals.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 13 -- A 32-year-old former medical student set the stage here tonight for a constitutional test of a state law prohibiting the dissemination of birth-control information and contraceptive devices.

A major stockholder of the Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation filed a suit in Philadelphia yesterday to block the concern's proposed merger into Armour Co. Thomas M. " The Rockefeller Billions," by Jules Abels, will be published by Macmillan on May 24. The author, a law graduate and economist, estimates the Rockefeller wealth at $4 to $10 billion. The book deals with the men who built the fortune and those who have since managed it, and with its influence on society.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 13 (AP) -- Public school officials announced today that 360 members of the American Federation of Teachers would be discharged if they did not return to classrooms tomorrow morning.

A 1,000-mile life-saving operation, engaging doctors and the police in Brooklyn and Florida, was set in motion yesterday afternoon by a telephone call to the suicide prevention service maintained by Kings County Hospital.

The 67-year-old Child Care and Adoption Service has merged its program with the 102-year-old Children's Aid Society. The merger was announced yesterday by Morgan Dix Wheelock and Mrs. Charles P. Healey, presidents of the respective organizations.

A prosecutor in court yesterday quoted a defendant charged with perjury as having said that Council President Paul R. Screvane took a $25,000 bribe for political campaign purposes in 1961. Mr. Screvane will deny this allegation as a witness later in the trial.
BALTIMORE, May 13 -- Radio, television and the Pimlico Pony Press were doing their best tonight to keep the local citizenry up to date on Lucky Debonair's puffed ankle. It wasn't easy.

Fifty to 70 Columbia University students have submitted signed statements to the school's administration asking that they be held equally responsible for a demonstration last Friday against Columbia's Naval Re[serve training unit.
The Ford Foundation announced $2.97 million in grants yesterday that will aid education in Latin America and Africa and a school of international urban studies in Athens Greece.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The House Education and Labor Committee reacted swiftly today to Gov. George C. Wallace's veto of a Birmingham antipoverty project by voting to strip governors of such power.

A Brooklyn grand jury has begun an investigation into allegations that private contractors have defrauded the Board of Education with inferior work and materials in the paving and landscaping of school playgrounds.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Some good may come out of the Vietnam and Caribbean crises after all. Here and there in recent days at least a few statesmen have begun to talk more earnestly again about the imperative need to organize international military forces to maintain the peace.

ABOUT 9:30 o'clock on the night of May 30, 1961, a chauffeur-driven limousine sped down a lonely coast road toward San Cristobal, in the Dominican Republic. In the shadows, a 1958 Chevrolet moved out and followed the limousine for two miles.
Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. visited Queens College yesterday to address students on the campus from which, almost year ago. Andrew Goodman had gone to his death in Mississippi.

DUPLICATE bridge is increasing in popularity at a fast pace. The membership of the American Contract Bridge League has doubled in the last three years, from 80,000 to 160,000, and this represents only a small fragment of the game's adherents.

ST. IGNACE, Mich., May 13 (UPI) -- Capt. Martin E. Joppich of the sunken limestone carrier Cedarville refused to submit to cross-examination yesterday during the United States Coast Guard inquiry into the collision of the freighter with the Norwegian merchantman Topdalsfjord last Friday.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board dropped its fight today to continue subsidy payments to helicopter lines in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Administration's next big tax-reduction bill -- the one covering excise taxes -- is in President Johnson's hands for final decision now and will go to Congress "within the next few days," Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler said today.
Reversing the pattern of the last eight days, prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday in heavy trading. Brokers attributed the improvement to a technical rebound.

Governor Rockefeller will not be called as a witness in the State Investigation Commission's inquiry into an exchange of charges by Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson and Nassau District Attorney William Cahn.

BRUSSELS, May 13 -- The logjam over world agricultural trade, which has been blocking the Kennedy round of tariff cutting negotiations, is expected to loosen next week as a result of decisions reached here today by ministers of the European Common Market.
MOSCOW, May 13 (Reuters) -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin promised India "unlimited" aid today in both the political and economic fields, according to Indian sources here.

BONN, Germany, May 13 (Reuters) -- Following is the official translation of letters, published today, between Chancellor Ludwig Erhard and Premier Levi Eshkol concerning the establishment of diplomatic relations between West Germany and Israel:

CHICAGO, May 13 -Stockholders of Montgomery Ward Co., were told at their annual meeting here today that first-quarter sales and earnings of the company moved ahead despite a s1ow start, but that the company would limit expenses for new programs until its profits improved.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- President Johnson was honored by his Cabinet today, the anniversary of his 28th year in elected Government office. The Cabinet presented him with a rare book. Woodrow Wilson's "Congressional Government."

Research by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission has disclosed that not a single building is left on Manhattan Island dating to the sixteen-hundreds when the city was under Dutch and English rule.
CHICAGO, May 13 (UPI) -- Gary Peters, who has never been beaten by the Kansas City Athletics, scored his ninth straight victory over them today, allowing nine hits in a 6-3 Chicago White Sox triumph.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) -- A special report said to urge an all-out supersonic transport program has gone to President Johnson for final decision, it was learned today.
OSLO, Norway, May 13 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia and Norway expressed tonight their determination to uphold and strengthen the United Nations.

State Senator Owen M. Begley, Schenectady Democrat, was directed yesterday to appear before a New York County grand jury by June 2 even if the Legislature is still in session. The directive came from Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson.

THE name behind the label in some of the prettiest shoes in America is now appearing in dresses. Jean Bandler, the designer of Pappagallo shoes, has just created a group of summer dresses as a prelude to a complete collection of fall clothes that will be sold in shoe stores throughout the country.

One of the best-kept secrets in real estate has been the purchase of Douglas L. Elliman Co., the 54-year-old brokerage and apartment management concern, by a vigorous young man who started learning its operations eight years ago.

DETROIT, May 13(UPI) -- The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit became the second diocese in the nation today to join formally in Project Equality, a new program to combat discrimination in buying, selling and hiring.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 13 -- The Tanzanian Information Ministry broke a three-week silence today on the whereabouts of Sheik Othman Shariff, Ambassador to the United States, by announcing that he was in good health and on holiday.
BALTIMORE, May 13 (UPI) -- John (Boog) Powell hit a homer in the seventh inning to give the Baltimore Orioles a 3-2 victory tonight over the Cleveland Indians and a sweep of their three-game series.

CANNES, France, May 13 -- The two initial entries of the Cannes Festival's prize-seeking program were shown today: "The Knack" from Britain and "Tank 34" from the Soviet Union. The former is an example of British experimentation and the latter a specimen of the Russian heroic history school.
The appointment of three scholars of international reputation to the faculty of New York University was announced yesterday by President James M. Hester.
LONDON, May 13 -A battle broke out today in the normally tranquil, stiffly dignified, ever so discreet English insurance community.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 13 -- The Actor's Workshop here announced today that John Hancock had accepted the post of artistic director.
Representative John V. Lindsay announced yesterday that he had decided to run for Mayor.
TOKYO, May 13 (UPI) -- The Communist Vietcong forces recently held their first "congress" in South Vietnam, North Vietnam's official news agency said today.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the week ended May 8, were both considerably above the corresponding week of 1964.

All-day live television coverage of the Saturday teach-in on Vietnam will be presented by educational stations in New York, Washington and Boston.
MIAMI BEACH, May 13 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union made an urgent demand yesterday for repeal of the section in the Taft-Hartley Act that permits states to outlaw the union shop.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Barry Goldwater said today that the Republican National Committee and the Senate and House Campaign Committees must have full control over any national television series put on in behalf of Republican candidates.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Johnson's speech on Vietnam today virtually acknowledged the Administration's hope that it can get into negotiations by driving a wedge between North Vietnam and Communist China.

The stock market scored another broad advance yesterday and toppled its day-old records.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest retail food chain, reported yesterday a decline in sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Feb. 27.

An expert in the care of ambulatory patients charged yesterday that most hospital outpatient departments were totally inadequate, unattractive, unhygienic and undignified.
Prices on the London stock exchange dipped yesterday following the announcement of adverse British trade figures for April. Declines were mostly minor.

THE Japanese are not the only people who make a ceremony of serving tea, to judge by a series of table settings slated to be shown at the World's Fair commencing today.
NEW HAVEN, May 13 -- Yale University has appointed Charles W. Moore, a leading California architect, as chairman of its department of architecture. The appointment will take effect July 1.
OXFORD, Ala., May 13 (AP) -- A bomb smashed the inside of a Negro church today. No one was hurt in the explosion at the Pine Grove Christian Methodist Episcopal Church, which has 29 members.

The entry of Representative John V. Lindsay into the mayoral race has forced Mayor Wagner to reconsider his decision to approve the Lower Manhattan Expressway, according to City Hall sources.

CANNES, France, May 14 -- The message film made its appearance on the Cannes Festival program today. Egypt contributed "The Sin", which depicts the wretched condition of field hands when Farouk ruled. Bulgaria presented "A Hot Noon", a rather primitive explanation of social solidarity.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 14 -- A fortnight of international sailing on Great Sound ended in moderate airs today with Richard Tillman, an Air Force captain especially gifted in small boats, and Bob Mosbacher, a Texas oilman who can sail anything, gaining the Finn and Dragon Class honors, respectively. After reading your delightful editorial on "Fowler Revised" [May 10]. I opened my unrevised "Modern English Usage" to re-read the vignette on "Malaprops." If Fowler had discoursed on unattached "particles," he might have perhaps enriched physics, but the English language (and four decades of its readers) would have been so much the poorer for it. Any future reviser should be grateful for your contribution to "Pairs Snares."
The opening phase of New York's own triple crown -- for fillies -- is on tap this afternoon with 11 3-year-olds slated to start in the $50,000 added Acorn Stakes at Aqueduct.

Publicker Industries, Inc., the distiller and producer of industrial alcohol and chemicals, announced yesterday an operating loss of $1,056,044 for the first quarter. This compares with a deficit of $554,153 in the corresponding 1964 quarter.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Government's index of industrial production, after recording extremely large increases every month since last fail, moved up only three-tenths of one point in April. The rise was the smallest for any month unaffected by major strikes since that of June, 1964.

GENEVA, May 14 The United States is "hopeful" that an effective start will he made here Monday in the Kennedy round negotiations for a grains pact.

Numerous anti-Wagner Democrats were privately expressing the hope yesterday that Representative John V. Lindsay would name a Democrat as a running mate in his campaign against the Mayor.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Senate Public Works Committee approved today a bill designed to control air pollution from automobiles. It would become effective by the time the 1968 models are placed on sale.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- One of the 1,200 inventions patented this week is an aluminum box 20 feet long, which led to the Government's Mobile Trade Fairs Program. ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 14 -- Eight contracts, totaling more than $17 million, have been awarded by the United States Army Corps of Engineers for work on Florida's Cross-state Barge Canal. The canal is now under construction, more than a century after its building was first advocated in 1821.

TORONTO, May 14 -- Viola MacMillan, under fire for her role in trading activity in Windfall Oils and Mines, Ltd., last summer, acknowledged a few mistakes and many lapses of memory but declared her intentions had always been good.

FOUR players from New York and vicinity will begin play today in the World Championship event in Buenos Aires. They are Howard Schenken and Peter Leventritt of New York, B. Jay Becker of Flushing, Queens, and Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Hastings-on-Hudson, Westchester.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Saturday, May 15 -- A cyclone that cut a swathe of death and destruction through East Pakistan on Tuesday killed up to 5,000 persons and left five million homeless, according to unofficial reports reaching here today.

Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor painted an optimistic picture of the short and long-term economic prospects in the United States yesterday in a speech to the Society of American Business Writers.
Huntington Hartford is reorganizing his Gallery of Modern Art by selecting a board of trustees who will offer both artistic and financial assistance.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced two-tenths of 1 per cent to 102.0 of the 1957-59 base during the week ended May 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 14 -- India and Japan condemned Communist China's second nuclear test today as a threat to mankind and an affront to the United Nations.

MOSCOW, May 14 -- The Soviet Government affirmed today its opposition to the proliferation of nuclear weapons but refrained from criticizing publicly the decision of the Chinese Communists to explode their second nuclear device.
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Johnson joked today about the trouble he had getting outside the White House and the trouble he had keeping newsmen inside it.

IT is a little early yet for the type of tomato that still has the muskiness of the vine clinging to its glowing red skin. It is a little early, too, for the type that makes a minimal dent in the budget. But in the meantime there are substitutes that are well worth taking a knife to.
WRIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 14 (AP) -- The death of a dog that had maintained a vigil over the body of a companion dog touched off a threat of court action by an angered citizen today.

LODI, N.J., May 14 -- Two light planes collided in the air near here this morning and crashed in open spaces in two adjacent heavily populated communities. One of the pilots was killed while the other suffered only minor injuries.

VIENNA, May 14 (AP) -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union gathered in Vienna today to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Austrian State Treaty. The gathering has provided an opportunity for an impromptu Big Four discussion of major world problems.

BEFORE World War I, the airplane was a fragile, sometime thing, a challenge to inventors, a toy for daredevils and publicity stunters; by 1918 it had become a formidable machine of war.

OSLO, Norway, May 15 (AP) -- South Africa advanced to the third round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition today by taking the doubles match from Norway, 6-1, 3-6, 6-1, 6-3. South Africa will play the winner of the match between Britain and Denmark.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 (UPI) -- Arthur Ashe of the University of California, Los Angeles, overcame a disastrous start today and defeated Tom Edlefsen of Southern California for the singles championship of the Pacific Eight tennis tournament. The scores were 0-6, 6-4, 11-9.

DOMESTIC air travelers may be able to tote a bigger load, if the Civil Aeronautics Board permits American Airlines to put a new baggage plan into operation. Under American's proposal, which has met with resistance from several other domestic carriers, the passenger's free baggage allowance would be limited by size and not by weight, as at present.
The Mets' game against the Milwaukee Braves at Shea Stadium a week ago Friday night was rained out, canceling a heavy advance ticket sale and bookings for the Diamond Club restaurant.

HONOLULU -- Hawaii's economy less than six years after statehood "is in bad shape -we're too prosperous." Gov. John A. Burns, a Democrat now in his third year in office, made this poker-faced observation in his Iolani palace office just before taking off on a trip to the mainland.

THOSE small flats of annual plants that florists started in their greenhouses during the winter will expand into exciting carpets of color in gardens this summer. Even the names are fascinating -- Coral Satin petunia, Magic Carpet portulaca, Persian Carpet zinnia and Jewel Mixed nasturtium.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 15 -- Prince Abdul Rahman, Malaysia's Prime Minister, failed today for a cessation of the bitter political controversy that has been developing between leaders of his United Malays National Organization and Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's Prime Minister.

EVEN as American commitments expand in Vietnam and the Dominican Republic, the nation is hearing an insistent call to withdraw from full involvement in the military and political processes of the world. The unadorned truth is that isolationism is reviving in our midst.

The Opportunity Shop, the thrift shop of the Community Service Society, will celebrate the 40th anniversary of its founding with a benefit reception at the shop, 46 West 47th Street, from 5 P.M. to 7 P.M. on June 2.

BOSTON, May 15 (AP) -Mickel Lolich gained his fifth victory toay and Willie Horton continued his heavy hitting as the Detroit Tigers scored their sixth consecutive triumph by defeating the Boston Red Sox, 6 -- 2.

The Tudor Hotel, which is really two buildings set back to back on a narrow plot extending from 41st to 42d Street between First and Second Avenues, has been sold and leased back by the Tudor Rose Corporation. The deal involved a mortgage of $2,075,000 and an undisclosed amount of cash.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 (AP) -- Willie Mays staged another hitting and base-running show today as the San Francisco Giants swept a double-header from the Houston Astros, 10-5 and 4-3.

BALTIMORE, May 16 -- Tom Rolfe and Dapper Dan who have been in each other's in-the-money company in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, are likely to extend their rivalry in the Belmont Stakes at Aqueduct on June 5.
Afternoon sunlight poured over the high wooden barriers into the ring as the brave bull bore down on the unarmed "matador" -- a scientist who had never faced a fighting bull.
THE long chess dynasty in Puerto Rico held by the Colon brothers, Arturo and Miguel, was overthrown in the recent 1965 Puerto Rican championship in San Juan.

The Rev. Walter M. Abbot, associate editor of the Jesuit weekly, America, said yesterday "that the laity of this country will set the pace in grassroots ecumenism for the simple reason that no other country in the world is prepared for ecumenical mobilization as well as America."

" The 20th Century," Columbia Broadcasting System's award-winning public service series, will turn almost completely to the contemporary scene next season to better reflect the events that are shaping the era.
Following are excerpts from the transcript of the national teach-in on Vietnam in Washington Saturday as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The gross national product rose by $14.2 billion in the first quarter of this year, Commerce Department figures disclosed today.
William Booth, the founder of The Salvation Army, was described yesterday as "a general sent from God."

FARMINGTON, Conn., May 16 -- Australis, under a cool ride by 16-year-old Danny Lopez of Glen Head, L.I., came through under pressure today to win the open jumper championship at the Children's Services Horse Show at the Farmington Valley Polo Club.
More than 1,000 worshipers filled the Marble Collegiate Church at Fifth Avenue and 29th Street yesterday to dedicate the church's Poling Chapel.

The Sanitation Department will begin distributing 6,650 new litter baskets today, raising the city total to more than 45,000, Commissioner Frank J. Lucia said yesterday. The distribution will be completed in a week.

Representative John V. Lindsay went out on a bright warm Sunday yesterday to meet the people from Fifth Avenue to Bay Ridge. He shook hands all the way, marched in a parade and never once stepped before a microphone.

Mrs. Charles M. Spofford of 120 East 78th Street will give a tea tomorrow at her home as a benefit for the Barnard College scholarship unit of Everybody's Thrift Shop. The thrift shop has raised more than $250,000 for Barnard students in need of financial aid.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox swept a double-header from the Detroit Tigers, 5-0 and 4-3, today as Earl Wilson pitched a four-hit shut-out and Carl Yastrzemski knocked in three runs in the second game.

NOW that 30-year-olds have become obsolete in terms of fashion, it's hard to believe that the chic young things once strove to age before their time. In those days, "sophisticated" was the key word in the fashion vocabulary.
KINGS POINT, May 16 -- Dean Rasmussen of the United States Merchant Marine Academy won the National Amateur championship walk today.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, May 16 -- Further explosions were expected at this major airfield in the aftermath of a chain of blasts early today that killed at least 21 Americans and one Vietnamese. More than 40 aircraft were destroyed or damaged.

SEZANA, Yugoslavia, May 16 -- A dozen blue, white, red and green Fiat cars are lined up on either side of the Yugoslav-Italian border here 18 hours a day, waiting to carry passenger-purchasers into the interior.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The teach-in attained tenure here this weekend. It became respectable, accountable and probably permanent. What began as an academic roadshow at the University of Michigan eight weeks ago suddenly blossomed into a big-time production of scholars and officials debating Vietnam policy a mile from the White House and before a huge radio and television audience.
The American Zionist movement took a major step yesterday toward revising its program to strengthen every phase of Jewish religious and cultural life in this country.
Harold Seletsky, to whose works the program at Carnegie Recital Hall was devoted late yesterday afternoon, is a composer with a gift for writing long, poised lyrical passages.

NEW HAVEN, May 16 -- The Yale School of Music has received a $160,000 contract from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare's office of education for a three-year project of preparing and testing materials to develop musical understanding in secondary schools.
WILLLIAMANTIC, Conn., May 16 -- Ch. Fezziwig Raggedy Andy, an Old English sheepdog, was judged best in show today at the Windham Kennel Club's 21st all-breed show and obedience trial.
The Liberal party declared yesterday that it would make no statement on the race for Mayor until the eve of its nominating conference on June 14.
GARMISCH - PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, May 16 (UPI) -- The death toll in the worst avalanche ever to hit the German Alps was at least 24, the head of rescue operations said today.
BUENOS AIRES, May 16 -- President Arturo Illia has decided to ask for Congressional authorization to send Argentine peace-keeping troops to the Dominican Republic, a Government source said today.

Carter Nice, a 25-year-old violinist, made his recital debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last night. He disclosed a sweet tone and confident technique in Veracini's E minor Sonata and a fiery temperament that made Beethoven's Kreutzer Sonata the invigorating experience it can be.
NEW ORLEANS, May 16 -- Dick Mayer came back from golfing oblivion today to win the $100,000 New Orleans open.

THE televising in full of the Washington debate on the United States policy in Vietnam, running from 9 A.M. Saturday to 12:30 A.M. Sunday, was a fascinating and important landmark in the evolution of communications.

MIAMI BEACH, May 16 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union strived today to correct what it called the "false" impression that it was one of the nation's wealthiest unions and to show that it needed to increase dues.

A slender, white-haired Scot from Kirkcudbright (pronounced Kir-coo-bree) in Scotland is dedicated to the proposition that London, England, is the finest place in the world to hold an American business convention.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 16 -- Bill Edwards putted with accuracy to get an early lead on Pete Bostwick Jr., today and then finished him off with fine chip shots and sand blasting to win the 55th Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 16 -- Mark Usiskin's Tern, a 35-foot white-hulled sloop out of the Raritan Yacht Club, won the Winged Foot trophy today by posting the best corrected time for the 56th annual New York Athletic Club distance race on Long Island Sound.
NEW DELHI, May 16 -- The pilot whose plane dropped the first atomic bomb over Hiroshima 20 years ago has run into some heavy flak here.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America last night presented its Hebert H. Lehman Medal to United Stares Circuit Court Judge Thurgood Marshall and Donald C. Cook, president of the American Electric Power Company.

Dean Jefferson Fordham's letter [May 12] praising two organizations furnishing legal assistance to civil-rights defendants in the South, is a welcome reminder that the active participation of lawyers in this endeavor is indispensable.
Americans of Greek origin and descent paraded proudly on Fifth Avenue yesterday to celebrate the independence of the modern Greek state and an even older cultural and religious heritage.
Foreign freight forwarders in the port of New York fear that recent administrative action by the Federal Maritime Commission, which licenses the companies, will have ruinous effects.
A part-time City College student was fatally stabbed and two companions injured early yesterday in a street brawl outside a Greenwich Village restaurant.

Dr. Goodhart, an American and a professor of jurisprudence at Oxford University for many years, contends that the proposed Oxford Union debate would hurt Britain's national interest and would therefore be highly improper at this stage in international affairs.
PRAGUE, May 16 (AP) -- Allen Ginsberg, avante-garde poet of New York's Greenwich Village, has been expelled from Czechoslovakia, the youth newspaper Mlada Fronta said today.

PITTSBURGH, May 16 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals swept a double-header from the Pittsburgh Pirates today. They won the opener, 6-3, for unbeaten Bob Gibson's seventh victory and the scored game, 5-1, on a six-hitter by Ray Washburn and Bob Purkey.

BALTIMORE, May 16 -- Johnny Keane, the manager of the New York Yankees, issued a printed "answer" today to one of the statements made by Bell Veeck, a former baseball owner, this week in an article in Sports Illustrated magazine.

Governor Rockefeller said last night that Mayor Wagner had neither sought nor received from him a commitment to support the city's "borrow now, pay later" plan for financing its record $3.875 billion budget for 1965-66.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 16 -- Kenyan security forces last night intercepted 11 truckloads of weapons, including a quantity of Soviet small arms, on the road from Tanzania to Uganda.

They celebrated Salute to Labor Day between games at Shea Stadium yesterday, but the real fireworks were supplied by those living symbols of oppressed classes everywhere -- the New York Mets -- as they smashed the Cincinnati Reds, 6-2 and 8-5.

BALTIMORE, May 16 -- Eyebrows were raised around Memorial Stadium today when the New York Yankees jumped into a 4-1 lead and seemed headed for their third straight victory over the Baltimore Orioles. But the eyebrows were soon lowered when the Orioles bombed four home runs out of the stadium to defeat the Yankees, 7-5.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- This weekend, as he has on most weekends this year, Senator John J. Sparkman went home to Alabama to look after his badly battered political fences.
PARIS, May 16 -- President de Gaulle will perform a major rite of his regime this week when he tours four western departments.

American businessmen are being rewarded for their adherence to President Johnson's request for voluntary restraint in making investments abroad by more profitable day-to-day dealings in foreign exchange markets here.

Col. Francisco Caamano Deno, president of the Dominican rebel regime, said in a television interview put on the air yesterday that he blamed the United States Ambassador, W. Tapley Bennett Jr., for any ill-will that Dominicans may have toward the United States.
LONDON, May 16 -- In his history of World War II, Sir Winston Churchill wrote bitterly of a resolution by the Oxford Union in 1933.
