LONDON, May 16 -- In his history of World War II, Sir Winston Churchill wrote bitterly of a resolution by the Oxford Union in 1933.
The Regional Plan Association and 70 prominent businessmen announced their support yesterday for Governor Rockefeller's proposed Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority.

HAVANA, May 16 -- The police in a western Cuban town recently questioned a Baptist minister after a graveside address. An informer had reported that the minister had used the funeral for propaganda against the Communist regime.
BOSTON, May 16 -- The American Academy of Arts and Sciences announced yesterday that 140 new members had been elected. The announcement was made by the academy's council land membership committees.
PARIS, May 16 -- France's largest oil company -- and third largest industrial company may soon seek financing outside the country through an issue of dollar bonds.

Harry and Freddie K. of Brooklyn, aged 10 and 9, were born out of wedlock. Their mother tried to support them for a while, but, when the strain became too much, she left them with a neighbor and disappeared. Finally, the neighbors who had been caring for the boys asked for help from a Greater New York Fund agency, the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and Children's Aid Society.

The Times deserves the unreserved thanks of the whole metropolitan community for its continuing, intensive and thorough coverage of the water dilemma. The temptation is strong to call it a water crisis.

BUENOS AIRES, May 16 -- The North American team took a 58-to-41 lead in international match points over Italy, the defending champions, after 28 deals in the world championship contract bridge tourney in the Plaza Hotel here today.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- About 500 delegates gathered here today for a conference based on the concept that gains won for workers at the bargaining table are too often lost by workers at store counters.

St. Helena's High School of the Bronx captured its fourth straight Metropolitan high school rowing championship at the Orchard Beach Lagoon yesterday as 16-year-old Jim Dietz won five sculling events.

WASHINGTON, May 16, (UPI) -- Thirty-six more Southern and Border State school districts, including Selma, Ala., have been cleared for Federal school aid funds by agreeing to desegregate by the fall of 1967 or earlier, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) -- President Johnson appointed today Lieut. Gen. Marshall S. Carter of the Army, one of the country's top intelligence officials, as director of the National Security Agency.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI) -- President Johnson and his wife paid a surprise visit by helicopter today to the home of Senator Harry F. Byrd for a country-style dinner of Virginia ham, hot biscuits, chicken gravy and strawberry shortcake.

The attacks by the United States-backed junta against the northern sector of the rebel zone in Santo Domingo add a new dimension to the tragic conflict. The junta has deliberately violated the truce, as a matter of policy, since Thursday, when it disabled the rebel radio station from the air. This is a different proposition from the sporadic sniping incidents that have been solemnly counted from the beginning as violations of the cease-fire.
The Rev. Dr. D. Reginald Thomas, a 48-year-old native of Wales, was called by the congregation yesterday to be minister of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 91st Street.

" Last year I had a class of 35 pupils," said Mrs. Carole Jacobson. "This year I have 22. It makes a tremendous difference. I can get to know each child better. I can give them more individual attention."

ALBANY, May 16 -- The revolution in treating mental illness started a decade ago with tranquilizing drugs has resulted in a reduction of 9,000 patients in the state's mental hospitals, Dr. Christopher F. Terrence, acting Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, reported today.

Bold Lad, last season's 2-year-old champion, is finding it difficult to get back to the races. The Wheatley star, who finished far back in the Kentucky Derby and missed the Preakness, will not be ready for the Belmont, the third jewel in racing's Triple Crown.

Gilbert A. Bond, labor lawyer and former Assistant United States Attorney, has been appointed director of the Brooklyn office of the city's Rent and Rehabilitation Administration. Mr. Bond will supervise the administration of 500,000 rent-controlled apartments.

PARIS, May 17 (UPI) -- Frank Froehling of Coral Gables, Fla., and Cliff Richey of Dallas scored opening-round victories in the French international tennis tournament today, but Roger Werkman of New York failed in his bid for an upset.

HOLMDEL, N.J., May 17 -The Marlboro Hospital Auxiliary will hold its eighth annual tour of local homes tomorrow afternoon in behalf of the state mental hospital. Proceeds have been assigned to establish a home economics unit in the therapy center there. Mrs. D. Louis Tonti is tour chairman.

BONN, May 17 -- The Spiegel affair, which ostensibly ended last weekend with the dismissal of treason charges against the new magazine's editors, erupted again today in a flurry of accusations and denials.

TRENTON, May 17 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that a private day camp that advertised for customers and offered a wide range of educational and recreational facilities was a public accommodation subject to the state anti-discrimination law.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- Dr. Possony, an authority on Communist tactics, told the Senate subcommittee that "the radicalization of American youth is proceeding beyond the wildest expectations of the Communists."

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 17 -- The United States was reported today, on the highest authority, to have reached an agreement in principle with the rebel movement of Col. Francisco Caamano Deno settle the Dominican civil war.
ALGIERS, May 17 -- President Ahmed Ben Bella declared today that Algeria was "obliged to forgo" aid promised by West Germany to reconstruct the port of Bone in eastern Algeria.

The nine years of Jimmy's life have been lived in darkness. His parents have done their best to give their blind son a normal life, but, despite their efforts, he has never been able to join the other boys in recreation.
DALLAS, May 17 (AP) -- The most elaborate security precautions ever taken in Dallas were put into effect today for the visit of Vice President Humphrey.

TRENTON, May 17 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes threatened today to go to court or to the Interstate Commerce Commission to require the Norfolk Western Railroad to negotiate for merger with the Erie Lackawanna Railroad.

INWOOD, L.I., May 17 -- Arthur Silvestrone and Herb Seaman, Lake Success, scored a five-under-par 37, 30 -- 67 today and won the Long Island Professional Golf Association pro-amateur tournament at the Inwood Country Club.
The Small Business Administration announced yesterday the success of an experimental program designed to help Negroes and Puerto Ricans develop their own businesses in New York.
ROME, May 17 -- Discussion of amendments to the Ecumenical Council's draft decree on religious liberty was quietly brought to an end over the weekend, Vatican sources said today.
Government bonds and gold shares were steady in light trading yesterday on the London stock exchange.
Some of the ideas that have been flowing from research and development departments were assembled yesterday on four floors of the Coliseum for engineers and business executives.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 17 -- Premier Levi Eshkol forcefully appealed today for peace between the Arab states and Israel.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Seafarers International Union of North America today charged that the Maritime Administration "has muddied the collective bargaining outlook" for negotiations on seamen's contracts that expire this June.
GENEVA, May 17 -- Proposals for a pact on wheat and other grains were placed on the bargaining table today in the Kennedy round of negotiations for the expansion of world trade.

Tenants demanding immediate repairs by the city in 21 buildings conducted sit-ins yesterday at the offices of the Housing and Redevelopment Coordinator and the Department of Buildings, Health and Real Estate.

Maritime employers of the port's 24,000 waterfront workers urged the Senate Finance Committee yesterday to eliminate from the medicare bill a section that they estimated would add $500 million a year to the cost of the Federal Social Security program.

The Kayser-Roth Corporation, one of the nation's largest apparel manufacturers, achieved the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its history in the three months ended March 31, it was announced yesterday.

Huntington Hartford, the founder of the Gallery of Modern Art, has revealed that he is in need of outside financial help to underwrite the operating expenses of the museum on Columbus Circle. Although there is "absolutely no imminent emergency," he warns that if he doesn't get some help "there won't be any museum in two or three years." He has been divesting himself of other commitments.

An economist predicted yesterday that spending for point-of-purchase advertising could be at least 50 per cent higher in 1970 than today, but only if the medium maintained a competitive position through innovation and research.

SOME surprising statistics and a resignation made yesterday an active day for New York Met followers, even though the schedule gave the rest of the National League a respite from its newest intimidating force.
ALBANY, May 17 (AP) -- The Senate voted by a narrow margin today to turn over New York State's Barge Canal system to the Federal Government if Congress agrees to take it.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 17 -- A normally sedate Reserve Officers Training Corps award ceremony at Cornell University turned into a near riot today, as about 4,000 students turned out to jeer and throw eggs at 75 other students who had attempted to stop the ceremony with a sit-in.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 -- Security analysts received a sizable dose of optimism adulterated with only a modest bit of caution as the 18th annual convention of the Financiallysts Federation began here to-today.

LONDON, May 17 -- Collaboration between Britain and France on advanced aviation projects took a big step forward today as the two Governments signed an agreement to build two supersonic military planes for the nineteen-seventies.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 17 -- Among his other distinctive qualities, Speedy Scot doesn't like the rail position -- a garden spot for most other standard-breds. Today, the great 5-year-old harness horse drew post position No. 3 for Thursday night's $25,000 Goldsmith Maid Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

TO observers of the American architectural scene it seems that today's building is running off in all directions at once. The record amount of new construction in recent years has been equalled only by its bewildering variety.

LIKE those wondrous patent medicines that cynical sideshow spielers guaranteed as a cure-all for the woes of mankind, including everything from falling hair to beri-beri, the sure-fire panacea that baseball owners offer to a gullible public never changes. When a ball club is sick, the same old remedy is unfailingly offered: The manager is fired.

DAVOS, Switzerland, May 17 (UPI) -- Dr. Horatius Albarda, 61-year-old president of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, was reported killed today in the crash of a private plane in the Swiss Alps. Also on the plane were Dr. Albarda's 44-year-old wife and two crewmen.
BUENOS AIRES, May 17 -- Excellent play by all the American players gave North America a lead of 26 international match points in their world championship match in the Plaza Hotel here against Italy.

Stockholder efforts to bring about a merger between the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., were brushed aside here yesterday by Harland C. Forbes, chairman of Con Edison, at the annual meeting here.
It took 25 men, a 100-foot crane and some unscheduled underwater acrobatics yesterday to move two half-ton white whales to their new quarters at the New York City Aquarium.

CLEVELAND, May 17 (AP) -- M.A. Hanna Company, a closed-end investment concern, announced today it had agreed to sell to Consolidation Coal Company of Pittsburgh for $25.5 million a block of 500,000 shares of Consol stock.
The city's 10th annual observance of Marine and Aviation Day ran into a little rough weather yesterday from an unexpected quarter picketing by 40 Staten Island ferry engineers.

CAIRO, May 17 -- Egyptian officials said today that the United Arab Republic will consider an unfavorable decision by the Civil Aeronautics Board over its proposed excursion fare flights for individuals traveling from New York to Cairo as a "top political issue."
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

Appointments to three newly created positions of vice president were announced yesterday by Brother Gregory, president of Manhattan College, as the first step in a planned reorganization of the Catholic college's administrative operations.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 18 (AP) -- The Kyodo News Agency, in a report from its Peking correspondent, said today that the Chinese Communist official it had identified as the source of a report that Communist China's second nuclear device had been carried aloft by a missile has denied making such a statement.

TOKYO, May 17 -- Despair over poor crop forecasts because of unusually cold weather this spring has resulted in the death of 25 Japanese in suicides and killing of children in depressed farming villages of northern Japan, it was reported today.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 -- A.J. Foyt of Houston, the top qualifier for the 500-mile race on May 31, ran into tire trouble today during a shakedown run with a full load of fuel in his Lotus-Ford.
Fifty-seven colleges have entered the track and field meet that annually settles the Eastern championship.

C. Day Lewis, former Professor of Poetry at Oxford, has expressed in a series of lectures at Harvard in the last year his distress that poetry is trending away from "the singing line" views that the Harvard Press will publish in "The Lyric Impulse" on May 24.
TRENTON, May 17 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that the mayoral election in Palisades Park last November was invalid.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- No administration in decades had seen anything quite like the personality and role of McGeorge Bundy, White House assistant for national security under Presidents Johnson and Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- J. Edgar Hoover and a spokesman for the International Association of Chiefs of Police have told Congress there was Communist involvement in the student demonstrations at the University of California last fall.

A countersuit against the Godyear Tire and Rubber Company has been filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York by the Weather-Rite Sportswear Company, Inc., an importer of rainwear.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- It is not surprising that President Johnson is complaining he can't get a moment's peace around the White House. He is talking wistfully about spending more time at the LBJ Ranch, where, he seems to believe, some kind of sensible order can be imposed on his household.

Mrs. Maria Hawkins Cole, the widow of Nat King Cole, joined Peggy Lee and Capitol Records yesterday in seeking to enjoin Camay Records from selling and distributing two disks, one labeled "Nat King Cole's Golden Hits" and the other "Peggy Lee's Greatest."

Copper futures took off yesterday, soaring to gains of as much as 3.20 cents a pound before touching ground. Final quotations after considerable late profit taking were unchanged for the most distant delivery but gained 2.45 cents on the spot May contract.
ALBANY, May 17 -- The perennial fight to repeal the state's railroad full-crew laws seems to have been lost again.
A dispute yesterday over how much should be paid to plumbers arriving on the job early to turn on the water at two Bronx school building sites disrupted about $9 million worth of construction.
The pay increases President Johnson is seeking for military personnel and for most civil service employes are fully justified. In fact, there ought to be more of them.

The New York State Assembly found another way yesterday to stall a final vote on Assemblyman Daniel M. Kelly's bills for strengthening the legislative code of ethics. An overwhelming bipartisan majority voted to amend them to bring them into conformity with two measures introduced by Senator Frederic S. Berman. These are still frozen in the Senate Finance Committee, despite efforts by seven Democratic Senators to get them out.
The election of Jack C. Malugen as president and chief executive officer of the United-Greenfield Corporation was announced yesterday. The appointment becomes effective Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- By plunging headlong into New York City politics, Representative John V. Lindsay has turned a local election into a national election.

Civil rights action will be needed to overcome "resistance and foot-dragging and dilatory procedures" in the North as well as in the South, Jack Greenberg, director-counsel of the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said last night.
" When I first came to your country, I met many nice people, people who were friendly and kind to me. But if I had met Joey Giardello first, I'm not so sure I would have liked any Americans."
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Patricia Harris is being considered for appointment as Ambassador to Luxembourg, informed sources reported today.

CANNES, France, May 17--Japan came forward at Cannes today with the most distinguished motion picture that has yet been shown at the festival. The Japanese entry, "Kwaidan," is composed of three long sketches, all eerie tales of the supernatural drawn from Lafcadio Hearn's book of Oriental ghost stories.
Lucile Boy-Sendra, mezzo-soprano, put together an unusually interesting program for her New York public debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
John L. Sullivan, for many years vice president and a director of the Dalzell Towing Company, who retired several years ago, is returning to the industry for his second career as a towboatman.

The New York Rangers of the National Hockey League traded four players, including Marcel Paille a goalie, to the Providence Reds yesterday for Ed Giacomin, considered one of the most promising goalies in the American Hockey League.
The State Supreme Court has approved an order restraining William Zeckendorf from transferring his personal funds to the Webb Knapp Company, which he heads.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The United States has formally offered to turn over its troops in the Dominican Republic to an inter-American military force being formed by the Organization of American States.
MIAMI BEACH, May 17 -- Roy Wilkins said today that "deeply ingrained patterns of racial discrimination" in labor unions had not been broken.

George Weltner, president of the Paramount Picture Corporation, charged yesterday that there was a "conflict of interest" in the offer to purchase at least 125,000 shares of Paramount stock at $64 a share, made by a Philadelphia company and two other groups.
DETROIT, May 17 (AP) -- The road ahead appeared clear to the automotive industry today as it prepared to build the four-millionth passenger car of the calendar year on Thursday.

IN his latest play, "The Wives," which opened last night at Stage 73 on East 73d Street, Lionel Abel appears to be taking the point of view that the ardors of married life are bound to cool -- if not disappear completely -- after a while.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Treasury bill rate showed little change at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Queens County District Attorney Frank D. O'Conner is looking into reductions in property-assessment valuations granted by the County Tax Commissioner to clients of a political leader.
Wall Street's hopes for a stock split by du Pont were shattered yesterday and the stock tumbled 8 3/4 points to close at 252 1/4.

The dramatic reversal in the American position toward the Dominican conflict should help re-establish a constructive peace. The United States, it is reported from Santo Domingo, has withdrawn its support from the unpopular right-wing military junta it put into power. This will presumably clear the way for installation of a more representative Government headed by Antonio Guzman, Minister of Agriculture in the Bosch Cabinet.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 17 -- The ruling military junta declared a state of siege tonight to cope with bloody rioting in La Paz and tin miners' seizure of hostages and a mine south of La Paz.

JAMESBURG, N. J., May 17 -- Gene Zachary of Glen Rock High School won the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association golf championship today with a tournament record 35, 37-72 at the 6,459-yard, par 35, 36--71 Forsgate Country Club.

TONYPANDY, Wales, May 17 (AP) -- A gas explosion killed 31 coal miners today in a narrow gallery 850 feet under the Rhondda Valley. The mine, one of Britain's most highly mechanized, had been destined for closing soon.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 17 -- Pressure by Parent-Teachers Association groups, church organizations, the Boy Scouts and the Salvation Army apparently was too much for Robert L. Coutts Sr., chairman of Morristown's 250th anniversary parade slated for Saturday.
The City University of New York held its first commencement yesterday and awarded its first two doctoral degrees.
Two new camp directories -- "Resident Summer Camps" and "Summer Day Camps" -- have been published by tile Community Council of Greater New York.

City Councilman Dominick Corso said yesterday he was being "blasted from pillar to post" by city officials and civil rights groups because of his plan for a police review board made up of City Councilmen.
A celestial object so distant that it seems to lie close to the beginning of time has been discovered with the world's largest telescope, on Mount Palomar, Calif.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 17 -The mystery surrounding 11 truckloads of weapons that Kenya security forces intercepted and impounded Saturday night deepened today. Uganda said it was all a mistake that had been happily resolved, and Kenya said nothing.
An interracial group in Jackson, Miss., has started its own antipoverty corporation, whose members pay dues of 25 cents a year.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy has ordered an investigation of an apparent breakdown in communications that resulted in Mrs. Gloria Sideratos's being held in jail for 20 days for possessing "narcotics" that were not narcotics.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court delivered a setback to the Justice Department today on some types of prosecutions for income-tax evasion.

ROME, May 17 -- Pope Paul VI, expressing "trepidation over new uncertainties" in the Dominican crisis, appealed today for the restoration of "unity, concord and internal collaboration" in the island republic.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 17 -- More than 180 residents here, angry that age-old trees are to be torn down in a road-widening project, took direct action today to stop bulldozers from carrying out the tree-killing program.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, challenged members of the Senate Rules Committee today to face him in the Senate and say whether they criticize his role in forcing the reopening of the Bobby Baker inquiry.
The Ladies of Charity of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York gave Cardinal Spellman bouquets, a five-tiered cake and checks in undisclosed amounts yesterday in honor of his birthday.

WASHINGTON, MAy 17 -- (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission charged today that giants of the dairy industry have gained enough strength by buying up smaller companies to "raise substantial barriers" to the success of independent dairies.

The Goldfield Corporation which has been searching since last January for a way to invest the more than $6.5 million it raised last January from the sale of control of Frontier Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday it had purchased a 41.1 per cent interest in the General Baking Company.

Robert Moses has appealed to the Weather Bureau here to take a more "positive" approach in its forecasts to avoid discouraging attendance at the World's Fair.

The paramount Building, the 38-year-old landmark on Times Square that William Zeckendorf contracted to buy last June, has been sold to Mrs. Evelyn Sharp, former owner of a chain of New York and California hotels.

Chuck McKinley will play only in the doubles in the Davis Cup match with Canada, and the United States will be without the services of its two top-ranking players in the singles. The match is scheduled for the Bakersfield (Calif.) Racquet Club June 4, 5 and 6.

A champagne dance in the Great Hall of the New York State Theater on May 27 will follow the benefit preview performance of "Don Quixote" by the New York City Ballet. In this performance only, George Balanchine, who choreographed the full-length ballet, will dance the title role.
Moses Weinstein, Democratic leader in Queens, termed as "laughable" yesterday suggestions that his law firm had benefited from favoritism in getting reduced property evaluations for its clients.

NEW YORK STATE'S public camp site system through the Catskill and Adirondack Mountains will be completely open to the public next Wednesday. The 45 locations usually open, under caretaker supervision, on Memorial Days.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 18 -- No reason was given here for the resumption of United States air strikes against North Vietnam today. American officials had also declined to discuss the reasons for suspending the attacks.

Daniel Lang, author of several books dealing with social aspects of science, went to Washington to ask a question: Since we already have thousands of nuclear weapons, when will we have enough? The responses of many leading officials form the basis of a book, "An Inquiry into Enoughness," which McGraw-Hill will publish on June 15.

WITH swimsuits bared to a minimum, what is worn over them assumes more than passing significance. Coverups presented yesterday at a Bonwit Teller swimsuit show rivaled the suits, about half of them bikinis, in fashion news.

BUENOS AIRES, May 18 -- North America lost ground slightly in last night's world championship play in the Hotel Plaza here against Great Britain. With 48 deals completed out of a total of 144, the North Americans trailed by 22 international match points, 83-105.

OTTAWA, May 18 -- The new working uniform of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, adopted this spring, dispenses with the broad-brimmed felt hat that has accompanied the Mounties to fame. It also does away with the high boots and spurs.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Justice Department moved today to block a merger that would make the American Hospital Supply Corporation the nation's biggest distributor of scientific supplies.
LISBON, May 19 -- Portugal agreed today to an international inquiry on education in her African territories of Angola and Mozambique on the condition that other countries accept a similar inquiry.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Conservation Commissioner of New York State said today that the killing of fish in the Hudson River at Consolidated Edison's Indian Point atomic plant was unfortunate but by no means criminal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 19 -- The Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution today against asking Portugal to "take all effective action to prevent any violation of Senegal's sovereignty and territorial integrity."
The expiration of the May contracts dominated trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. All expiring deliveries were under selling pressure, which spread to other months in late dealings.
Heart valves taken from persons who have died are showing promise as replacements for seriously faulty valves in heart patients, according to report from Britain.

Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson has demanded the return of a handwritten letter sent to her by Mrs. John F. Kennedy in 1960. The letter was to have been put up for sale at public auction tonight by a New York autograph dealer.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 9 -- Radovan Zogovic, the Communist poet who was vice president of the all-powerful Yugoslav Writers Association until 1948, explained today that his reappearance on the literary scene was nonpolitical.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 19 -- The two rival factions in the Dominican revolution agreed in principle tonight to a 12-hour humanitarian truce for Friday amid hopes that a political solution of the crisis might be found by then.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- India and the Soviet Union called jointly today for an immediate end to United States bombing raids on North Vietnam. A solution of the Vietnam conflict, they said, can be found only in the framework of the 1954 truce agreement for Indochina.
The New York Yankees, who began by ignoring the Mets, then disdaining them, then competing with them for attention and lovability, have been reduced to a rank imitation of their perplexing neighbors.

The "Israel Independence Day Concert" at Carnegie Hall last night brought one Israeli star, Jo Amar, to this country for the first time and brought back another Israeli star long favored by audiences here, Yaffa Yarkoni.

TURIN, Italy, May 20 -- The Soviet poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko said today that he preferred to write about industrial plans and dams because he wanted to describe the spirit of those who labor. He called himself a "workers' poet."
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 19 -- Receipt of a $140,000 grant to study the effects of volunteer work by college students with mental patients was announced today by Wesleyan University.

Michael J. Murphy will be a hard man to follow as Police Commissioner. Vincent L. Broderick, chosen for the job by Mayor Wagner, represents a break with recent tradition in being a civilian, rather than a policeman risen from the ranks. His law-enforcement experience has been as Chief Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District and in a brief tour as Deputy Police Commissioner in the Adams and Kennedy regimes.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 19 -- Rutgers University finished first in the final event, the one-mile relay, in the meet record of 3 minutes 18.1 seconds today to take the third annual New Jersey collegiate track and field championships.
New traffic restrictions were imposed in Greenwich Village yesterday by Mayor Wagner in another step to rid the Macdougal Street area of its honky-tonk atmosphere.
President Chung Hee Park of South Korea was welcomed to New York yesterday with a ticker-tape parade, bouquets of roses and tributes as a stanch anti-Communist ally of the United States.

The world's food problems can be expected to get worse before they get better a specialist on agricultural problems said here yesterday. Shortages of food may well endure for the rest of this century, he declared.
MEXICO CITY, May 19 -- Riot policemen armed with gas guns dispersed 3,000 would-be braceros from Ciudadela Park in downtown Mexico City this morning.

PITTSBURGH, May 19 -David J. McDonald bowed today to the decision of the membership of the United Steelworkers and agreed to abandon protests to the election that brought his defeat as union president.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Thursday, May 20 -- The Security Council last night requested me Secretary General's representative in the Dominican Republic to try to obtain an immediate suspension of hostilities to permit the Red Cross to search for dead and wounded.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (UPI) -- Rodger Ward and members of his crew said today they thought they had solved the problems that kept Ward from qualifying last weekend for the May 31 500-mile automobile race at Indianapolis Speedway.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 -Directors of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) presented the happy financial news of a booming company to about 1,800 stockholders at their annual meeting here today. The directors then were re-elected to control of the $12.5 billion concern for another year.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) -- The House Banking Committee approved today, 26 to 7, President Johnson's $6 billion housing program. Republicans cast six of the negative votes, objecting primarily to his proposal for Federal rent subsidies.
TULSA, Okla., May 19 (UPI) -- The Oklahoma school crisis worsened today when the Tulsa school board dismissed five teachers for attending a special meeting of the Oklahoma Education Association.
BONN, May 19 -- Queen Elizabeth and the people of Germany responded to each other with growing warmth today as the sun burst through the clouds over the Rhine valley.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 19 -Old Sumie, known officially as Su Mac Lad, makes his return to the races tomorrow night. The gallant 11-year-old gelding is expected to be the second choice as a field of seven takes part in the $25,000 Goldsmith Maid Trot.

PARIS -- The pale, stiff salons of the French haute couture, with their gilt chairs and their gladioli, look like stage sets. When the new collections are shown twice a year, there is the turmoil and tension of an opening night on Broadway.
Lady Allen of Hurtwood is absolutely right [news article May 16] -- playgrounds in New York are drab and are laid out with no understanding of children's needs.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The voting rights bill made headway toward Senate passage today after a delay of four weeks while its proponents quarreled over an antipoll tax amendment.

Trevor Howard and George Rose have been engaged for two of the principal roles in "The Royal Hunt of the Sun." Peter Shaffer's spectacle about Pizarro's conquest of Peru. Mr. Howard, who has not appeared on the Broadway stage previously, will be seen as Pizarro.
Road signs "talked" to motorists yesterday on congested Manhattan and Queens streets as an experimental radio alert system was demonstrated by the Ford Motor Company.
ST. LOUIS -- Among the amateur chefs of St. Louis, Harry Kleefiscth is something of a legend in his own time.

ATHENS, May 19 -- Officers of the Athens garrison were being questioned today as part of a Government-ordered inquiry into reports that two secret officers' organizations had been set up in the Greek army.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- President Johnson plans an appearance Saturday night at a dinner in New York for large financial contributors to the Democratic party.
LUSAKA, Zambia, May 19 -- Elephant sausage, hippo pie and buffalo goulash may seem exotic fare but they soon may be on menus here.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 19 (UPI) -- The Southern Pacific Company plans to add "substantially" this year to its railroad and highway equipment, including 4,745 new freight cars and 149 locomotives.

The Ford Foundation disclosed late yesterday afternoon that it planned to dispose of 6 million shares of Ford Motor Company common stock in a public offering in late June.

The strike of 2,000 Queens taxicab drivers and the sporadic violence that has accompanied it indicate the danger involved in the continued controversy over taxi unionism. The soundest way to end this controversy is to hold a citywide election to determine whether the cab drivers want a union or don't want one. Such a solution was proposed three weeks ago by Mayor Wagner's taxicab labor panel.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 19 (AP) -- Darby Dan Farm's Candalita, who defeated most of the best 2-year-old fillies in the country last year, scored an easy victory in her first start of the season today at Garden State Park.
The Arts Councils of America and the American Symphony Orchestra League will hold their joint annual conference in Washington from June 16 through June 19.
DACCA, Pakistan, May 19 (AP) -- A cyclone that slashed across East Pakistan May 12 took 12,033 lives, Gov. Abdul Monem Khan announced tonight. He said 1,300 people were missing.
THE Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club honored its founder, Harry Miller of New York, at Luchow's restaurant yesterday and wondered how the organization could continue without him.

BONN, May 19 -- West Germany's two mass political parties, which are running even in popularity polls four months before the national elections, formed a coalition in the state Government of Lower Saxony today.

Newcomb, as a result of writing "Iwo Jima," which olt, Rinehart Winston published on Feb. 19, the 20th anniversary of D-Day on the Pacific island, met John E. Lane, assistant professor of history at Long Island University, who was a Marine private in the invasion.

A dinner dance will be held at the Tavern-on-the-Green on Monday for the benefit of the Manhattan Society for Mental Health.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was the star yesterday of a drama involving Broadway "ice," scalping and new legislation to eliminate a black market in tickets. License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo gave him an unfavorable notice, saving that the script needed revision.

Brooke Astor, widow of Vincent Astor, has written a novel, "The Bluebird is at Home," which Harper Row will publish on June 9. It is described as a story of a young marriage among the very rich. Well, Henry Brant has done it. For years musicians have been unhappy about the string family. The violin, viola, cello and bass are related but not closely enough. Built to different specifications, each has its own timbre and range.

MIAMI BEACH, May 20 -- The Boy Scout movement hopes to double its growth rate under a "Breakthrough for Youth" program that was announced here today by Thomas J. Watson Jr., president of the Boy Scouts of America.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- The United States is now more preoccupied with Asia than at any time since the Korean War, yet there is a notable gap in our Asian policy-making machine. President Johnson has at his right hand a competent array of bureaucrats, diplomats and former professors, but not even Harvard has been able to furnish him with one essential.

Four members of a group that calls itself the United Peoples of African Descent were paroled yesterday in Criminal Court on charges of violating the weapons law. They were accused of carrying police-like nightsticks on the Lower East Side Wednesday night.
ATLANTA, May 20 -- In his three decades in Washington, Senator Richard Brevard Russell Jr. has changed from a spokesman for the New Deal to a defender of the Old South.
MOSCOW, May 20 -- The Soviet Union warned today that armed United States intervention in local crises was threatening to ignite a broader conflict between East and West.
Prices for industrials moved irregularly in slow trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

Gustave L. Levy, a partner in Goldman, Sachs Co., was elected vice chairman of the New York Stock Exchange's board of governors yesterday. He thus became the first non-floor governor in a quarter-century to occupy the responsible post.
PRINCE GEORGE, Va., May 20 (AP) -- The Federal Government has agreed to release $303,000 in school aid for Prince George County, which had threatened to close the school system.

The retail industry, particularly the country's three largest chains with department stores and catalogue operations, acted yesterday to prevent consumer delay in buying merchandise on which excise taxes may shortly be repealed.
Thalidomide, the drug that has a black name because it has been linked with severe human birth defects, may prove valuable in treating leprosy, according to a medical report just published.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy told a Democratic audience last night that the Democrats in the Legislature had reneged on their campaign promises regarding nonpartisan redistricting and constitutional reform of the state's government.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- A defense attorney accused a Government witness today of concealing information from the jury in the trial of four men accused of conspiracy and fraud in the promotion of Krebiozen.
Mayor Wagner, the City Council and License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo have moved to put so-called "billiard clubs" out of business.

LANSING, Mich., May 20 (AP) -- Gov. George Romney discharged Maj. Gen. Ronald D. McDonald as Michigan Adjutant General today, but reinstated another National Guard general after finding both guilty of gross neglect of duty.

A pioneer plan to provide indigent defendants in criminal cases in Federal Courts with lawyers who will be paid by the Government was filed yesterday with the United States Judicial Conference by Chief Judge J. Edward Lumbard of the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee decried today the plight of the American farmer and recommended $5,692,537,000 in new funds to run the Agriculture Department for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 20 -- Adlai E. Stevenson vigorously denied today that United States troops had treacherously killed a Dominican colonel by firing on him from behind while he was fighting forces of the civilian-military junta.

LONG BEACH, L.I., May 20 -- Residents of Long Beach, Atlantic Beach and Lido Beach turned out today to object to a proposal by the Army Engineers to build a 10-mile-long, 100-foot-wide sand dune across the oceanfront communities.
Scientists at the Bell Telephone Laboratories have observed what a group at Princeton University believes may be remnants of an explosion that gave birth to the universe.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 20 -- Governor Rockefeller said tonight that he would ask legal and religious leaders to give him their views on a bill to abolish capital punishment and then decide whether to sign the measure into law.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A House committee decided today to consider repeal of a student loyalty oath as a separate bill rather than as part of the Administration's higher education program.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 20 -- A beloved village landmark here will crumble under the march of progress by July 11 to make room for a widening of Main Street.

PARIS, May 26 (UPI) -- The United states was left today with one survivor in the men's singles of the French tennis championships when Cliff Richey of Dallas and Allan Fox of Los Angeles were defeated.
The museum of the near future is the museum without walls, an open house of treasure that will be brought into millions of homes by color television, Robert W. Sarnoff predicted yesterday.

CACAK, Yugoslavia, May 20 -- Just as the people of Serbia's verdant Morava Valley are beginning to dry out their possessions after last week's flash floods, high waters are threatening other areas of central Yugoslavia.

A state supreme court justice tonight ordered a halt to a five-week-old strike of union electrical workers against the Sperry Gyroscope Company. The walkout has affected $300 million in Government space and defense contracts.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 20 -- The Minister of Development and Housing and the Deputy Minister of Defense, both stanch supporters of former Premier David Ben-Gurion, resigned today as the internal crisis in the dominant Mapai party deepened.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Sen. Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, advocated today a halt in Federal expenditures on the New York Barge Canal unless the state transfers it to Federal jurisdiction.

Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division, First Department, urged laser night that a continuing institution be created to study "the entire pattern of criminal behavior and criminal justice."
Attracted by the prospect, of a slugging match, 9,785 boxing fans showed up at Madison Square Garden to watch Dick Tiger and Rubin (Hurricane) Carter do battle last night.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 20 -- Homeowners who have been battling bulldozers and chain saws along the Cross County Parkway here were told today that they would be barred from a meeting tomorrow night at which the controversial reconstruction project will be discussed.

CAIRO, May 20 -- The United Arab Republic seems to have won a tourist-war point against Israel with the announcement today that Trans World Airlines has accepted an economy-package deal on an individual basis.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Senate and House Republican leaders said today that they had some "constructive suggestions" on how to eliminate the Castro Government in Cuba that they would be "delighted to present to President Johnson."

MAY is baby month in nature's calendar and an expecially appropriate time for children to see day-old ducklings, foals or piglets in farm nurseries, some of which are in pastoral settings less than an hour from the city.
Another good year is in store for Smith Kline and French Laboratories in 1965, "perhaps a record year," Walter A. Munns, president, predicted yesterday at the annual meeting in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., had acted properly in dismissing a cadet for a violation of the honor code.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Administrator, Najeeb E. Halaby, warned today against limiting travel abroad as a means of solving the balance of payments problem.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The president of the Consumers Union said today that consumer credit was no longer a sales tool, but the object of the sale.

TRIPOLI, Libya, May 20 -- The recent sabotage attack on five British-operated oil wells in Cyrenaica has been followed by Egyptian broadcasts alleging that the wells were blown up by revolutionary elements opposed to the Libyan Government's breach in "Arab unity."

HAVANA, May 20 -- A new Government decree authorizing the Cuban National Bank to print paper money nominally worth $220 million is taken as a sign that Premier Fidel Castro's regime is sticking to its singular monetary system despite inflationary strains.
Fifty Columbia University students have been censured by the school's administration for their participation in a demonstration on the campus May 7 against Columbia's Naval Reserve training unit.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 20 -- The United States, having failed this week to interest Hanoi in peace talks, appealed to the soldiers of North Vietnam with leaflets today to end the war in the South.
A good jumper and a good jockey combined yesterday to register a decisive triumph in the $11,275 Hitchcock Steeplechase at Aqueduct.

A Canadian lawyer testified here yesterday that he had been denied a conference with Wayne Thomas Lonegran after Lonergan was arrested by the Toronto police for questioning about the murder of his wife.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Rail carloadings in the week ended May 15 achieved a new high for the year and the highest since the week ended last Nov. 21.

A largely technical recovery erased a 4-cent drop in old-crop soybean futures prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The near months closed with slight gains, while the distant soybean deliveries fell along with wheat and oats.
CINCINNATI, May 20 (UPI) -- Vada Pinson, Frank Robinson and Gordie Coleman accounted for 10 hits among them tonight to lead the Cincinnati Reds to an 11-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

BUENOS AIRES, May 20 -- The North American team met disaster in the first 14 deals against Great Britain here this afternoon in play for the world championship. Facing a 22-point deficit, the Americans lost 63-2 to a British team playing in devastating form.
MOSCOW, May 20 -- The Soviet aviation industry put its newest aircraft, including the IL-62 passenger plane, on display today in an effort to expand a foothold in the world export market.

Columbia University awarded its 1965 Bancroft Prizes in American History last night to Dorothy Borg, research associate and lecturer at Columbia's East Asian Institute, and Bradford Perkins and William B. Willcox, professors of history at the University of Michigan.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The nation's Governors won today their brief but furious fight to retain some degree of control over antipoverty programs in their states.

Ed Tarangioli Jr. of Fordham Prep, the top-seeded Player, and Richard Palmer of Archbishop Stepinac, the defender won quarter-final matches yesterday in the 17th Fordham University invitation tennis tournament for high schools and grammar schools at the Fordham Courts in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- George Meany accused Labor Department investigators today of "witch-hunting and harassment" in checking into the financial records of unions.
The state's Democratic legislative leaders went into Federal court yesterday to try to block a special legislative election in the fall under a Republican reapportionment plan.

Eight maritime unions representing some 350,000 seamen, longshoremen and shipyard workers, plan to send 1,500 representatives to Washington today to picket the White House, the Maritime Administration and the Departments of State, Commerce and Agriculture.

ST. LOUIS, May 20 (AP) -- Unbeaten Bob Gibson won his eighth game tonight, checking Philadelphia on six hits while the St. Louis Cardinals pounded five Phillie pitchers for a 12-2 victory.

Most stocks moved backward yesterday, apparently in sympathy with a weak automobile group.

The announcement yesterday by the Rob Roy Company, Inc., a leading boys' wear manufacturer, that a plant would be built to produce durable-press garments has again put the spotlight on this new development in the apparel industry.

A New York City detective who has been credited with thwarting a plot by three members of the Black Liberation Front to blow up the of Statue Liberty and other national shrines told in Federal court yesterday how he had been assigned by his police superiors to join civil rights groups.

Your May 15 editorial "The Delgado Mystery" seizes on the death of former Portuguese Air Force Gen. Humberto Delgado to east a veiled and totally unfounded attack on the Portuguese regime. WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 20 (UPI) -- The United States wants 1.4 million tons of stockpiled aluminum, considered surplus to Government strategic requirements, returned to the commercial market over the next 10 years or so, top aluminum industry officials were told today. The surplus has a market value of $686 million.
CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP) -- Fred Whitfield capped a four-run second inning tonight with a two-run homer to lead the Cleveland Indians to their third straight victory over Baltimore, 5 -- 2.

In wholly predictable fashion the House Ways and Means Committee voted to top President Johnson's request for almost $4 billion in excise-tax reductions by another $900 million. Its action was prompted by Mr. Johnson's own proposal to cut the excise on autos. Where he asked for half a loaf in the form of a 50 per cent reduction in the tax, the committee, under pressure from Detroit, wants a whole one.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Willie Mays's 15th home run and tight pitching by Bob Shaw and Masanori Murakami led the San Francisco Giants today to a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The Giants thus salvaged the final game of a three-game series.

NEW DELHI, May 20 (Reuters) -- The Defense Ministry said today that Indian troops killed 40 Pakistanis early yesterday while driving off an attack across the Kashmir cease-fire line.

ALBANY, May 20 -- A bill that would create a transportation authority to deal with commuter problems in the New York metropolitan area was passed by the Assembly today.

Dean Jefferson B. Fordham's letter published May 12 correctly emphasizes the obligation imposed upon the legal profession to represent unpopular causes and stresses quite properly the contribution made by Northern volunteer lawyers who went to the South last summer.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Federal Communications Commission ordered a Mississippi broadcasting company today to cease racial discrimination in its television and radio programing.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 20 -- Former President Marcos Perez Jimenez, on trial here on charges of having embezzled $15 million in public funds, took the stand in his own defense today.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 20 (UPI) -- Parnelli Jones, a former 500-mile auto race winner escaped serious injury today when the rear-engine Lotus-Ford he had qualified for the May 31 classic smacked into a wall at the Speedway.

A travel agent predicted yesterday that more than 6,000 of the nation's 7,500 travel agencies would be forced out of business if a sales-commission reduction proposed by domestic airlines was approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 20 -- Two Winged Foot teams, playing in the same foursome, tied today in the British Victory Cup golf tournament at Century Country Club and will have to play off to determine the winner of the big silver trophy.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- William D. Rogers, deputy foreign aid adminstrator and second in command of the Alliance for Progress with Latin America, has announced he intends to resign at the convenience of President Johnson.
The World's Fair Corporation denied yesterday any legal responsibility for carrying out the provisions that it said last year were to govern the disbursement of funds remaining when the fair closed.
WASHINGTON, MAY 20 -- The Treasury Department announced today that Americans in India can now buy rupees from the United States Embassy and Consulates.

" Alice's Adventures under Ground" is being reproduced from Lewis Carroll's printed script with his sportive drawings in a departure in publishing for University Microfilms, Inc., of Ann Arbor, Mich., a subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation.

DETROIT, May 20 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings obtained Andy Bathgate today from the Toronto Maple Leafs in an eight-player National Hockey League deal. Billy Harris, a center, and Gary Jarrett, a minor league left wing, also were sent to the Wings in exchange for Marcel Pronovost, Eddie Joyal, Larry Jeffrey, Autrey Erickson and Lowell MacDonald.

NEWARK, May 20 -- The president of the Jersey Central Railroad asked Gov. Richard J. Hughes today to press for $5.6 million in state funds to maintain the line's commuter service until the end of the year.

LEE, Me., May 20 -- Lower Sysladobsis Lake is not much different from many of the other numerous lakes and ponds in this northwest portion of Maine. The area seems to be at least half water and bog and swamp.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) -- Two banking officials Urged Congress today to speed legislation that would exempt approved bank mergers from the antitrust laws.

The election of two new directors and a vice president of the Eastman Kodak Company was announced yesterday at the annual Stockholders' meeting in Rochester.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The $3.37 billion foreign aid authorization bill was cleared today for House debate Monday and Tuesday. The House Rules Committee sent the legislation through despite critical questioning by some members at a brief hearing.

BAY SHORE, L.I., May 20 -- Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook, a former Long Island champion, scored a 42, 38 -- 80 today to lead the field and win her group prize (handicap 1 to 8 strokes) in the Women's Cross County Golf Association gross tournament on the 5,995-yard, par 72, Southward Ho Country Club.
A jury in Supreme Court awarded $1.2 million yesterday to the families of six men who died in a fire in a six-story Manhattan paper and twine factory on Feb. 14, 1958.

WESTBURY; L.I May 21 -- Early-bird railbirds witnessed an astounding workout by Bret Hanover at Roosevelt Raceway this morning. The four-day-old wildcat strike by ship engineers against American-flag freighters in the Port of New York was ordered ended by an arbitrator yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva submitted an optimistic message to the nation today six months after the start of his six-year term as Latin America's first Christian Democrat leader.

A Washington Heights woman returning from her night job as a Western Union teletype operator was slashed repeatedly and left dead early yesterday on an upper floor of her apartment building at 600 West 162d Street.

BALTIMORE, May 21 (AP) -- Elmer Brown, president of the International Typographical Union, said today that he had issued an order directing Baltimore Typographical Union 12 to recall travelers' cards from its members employed by the Baltimore Sunpapers.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 21 -- Uganda and Tanzania threatened today to break up the East African Common Market unless Kenya relinquished Chinese-supplied weapons shipped through Kenya.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 21 (AP) -- Gen. Chung Hee Park, South Korean President, exercised the privilege accorded visiting heads of state and granted a general amnesty to Military Academy cadets today.

Stock prices staged a broad decline yesterday for the second day in a row. Sizable losses in investment-grade issues were instrumental in erasing the gains made earlier this month by leading market averages.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The number of babies born in the United States this year is expected to fall below the 4 million mark. This would be the first time this total has not been exceeded since 1953.
An angry North Atlantic yesterday appeared to have claimed the lives of two Norwegian seamen and their ship, the small freighter Lionne.

The Police Department undercover man who is credited with exposing an extremist plot to blow up the Statue of Liberty disclosed in Federal Court yesterday that he had given the alleged plotters an Army field manual on detonations and explosives.
Vice President Humphrey said yesterday that the conquest of disease and the prolongation of human life were more important than efforts to land a man on the moon.
The city is about to announce what it calls a summer crash program of relief for the poor people of New York that goes beyond the present multimillion-dollar antipoverty program.
BALTIMORE, May 21 -- Sol Hurok Day was declared here yesterday and at last night's performance of the Royal Ballet, Mayor Theodore R. McKeldin made the impresario an honorary citizen of the city.

Water Commissioner Armand D'Angelo ordered all of New York's 320 permanent ornamental and display fountains shut down yesterday to save water. The measure is not binding on fountains at the World's Fair, however.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 21 (AP) -- Unbeaten Camilo Pascual, with help in the ninth inning, posted his fifth victory tonight as the Minnesota Twins scored a 6-4 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics.
An insurgent group has won the proxy battle at International Breweries, Inc., and will take over control of the company.

TUNIS, May 21 -- President Habib Bourguiba today reaffirmed his friendship for the United States, condemned Egyptian efforts to "dictate" to other Arab regimes, and indicated that Tunisia might boycott future meetings of the Arab League.

" The Brothers Harper," by Eugene Exman, will be published on June 2 by -- guess who? -- Harper Row. The book traces the growth of the publishing concern from its beginning as a printing business established by James, John, Wesley and Fletcher Harper.
GENEVA, May 21 -- The World Health Organization was authorized for the first time today by its assembly of member nations to include birth control in its official program.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- A Congressional declaration that the United States opposes boycotts against friendly countries was approved today by a House Banking subcommittee. It was aimed at the Arab States' economic measures against Israel.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate leaders filed a closure petition today, confident that they had the votes to shut off debate on the voting rights bill.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent to 102.3 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended May 18, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
A team of American archeologists will begin in July a second season of exploration at the Biblical city of Hebron, in Jordan.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 21 -- An application by County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson to examine certain grand jury records of an investigation into the county jail was denied today by the State Supreme Court.
Vice President Humphrey said last night it is "imperative" that the deficit in the United States' international payments be brought to a "swift and sure end."

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) -- The Army is worried that guns and ammunition for its civilian marksmanship program might fall into the hands of armed extremist political groups or criminals, informed sources said today.

If it really is ninth-inning melodrama replete with self-defeating mistakes and misfortunes that the New York baseball public craves, the New York Yankees are doing their best to be obliging these days.
CHICAGO, May 21 (UPI) -- Dick Roznovsky's two-run homer off Don Drysdale today gave the Chicago Cubs and Dick Ellsworth a 4-3 victory over the league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers.
The city re-evaluated its drive against crime yesterday with an eye toward the summer months ahead.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Four surgeons closed their offices here today and became dollar-a-year Government employes to go to the Dominican Republic in response to a call from the Organization of American States for help in Santo Domingo hospitals.
A regional director of the National Labor Relations Board opened the door yesterday for employes of a Long Island candy factory to leave an alleged racket union without losing their jobs.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 21 -- After two weeks of deliberation, the Rhodesian Prime Minister, Inn D. Smith, produced a Cabinet tonight that contained no surprses. However, it could be construed as a move toward conciliation and away from extremism by this British colony's all-white Government.

New Roman Catholic textbooks that are being distributed in increasing numbers in parochial schools portray a positive image of Jews and reject the principle of collective Jewish guilt for the Crucifixion of Jesus.
BRUSSELS, May 21 -- The European Economic Community, or Common Market, turned down today a bid from Austria to participate in the trade bloc's common farm policy.

ATHENS, May 21 -- An official inquiry into a rumored leftist organization in the Greek Army was extended today to Cyprus following reports that officers serving in the Greek contingent there had been implicated.

TRENTON, May 21 -- Informed sources said today it would be possible for the present Legislature to produce a redrawn map of the state's 15 Congressional districts before it adjourned after Monday's final session.
MILWAUKEE, May 21 (AP) -- Vern Law and the Pittsburgh Pirates ended long losing streaks tonight by whipping the Milwaukee Braves, 6-1.
PITTSBURGH, May 21 -- St. Paul's Cathedral provided the setting last night for Francis Poulenc's "The Dialogues of the Carmelites."
BUENOS AIRES, May 21 -- The North American team had a seesaw day here yesterday in its world championship match against Great Britain.

The special stockholder meeting of the Paramount Pictures Corporation originally scheduled for June 1 has been postponed by order of the Supreme Court of New York County. Justice Birdie Amsterdam handed down the decision yesterday at the request last week of an insurgent group that had also asked for a list of Paramount stockholders.

HONOLULU, May 21 -- Hawaii is going into economic partnership with its surrounding waters. Every study is emphasizing the potential of this state's unsurpassed location for oceanographic research and development.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 21 -- The Government decreed a state of siege, or modified martial law, throughout Colombia today following widespread student disorders.

The Democratic leadership, trapped into an indefensible position by its own bad faith and shortsightedness on legislative reapportionment, is now desperately trying to recover by a series of last-ditch maneuvers. These antics should not obscure the fact that the deplorable absence of a fair and equitable reapportionment statute results from the efforts of both major parties to capitalize on the situation for partisan advantage.

An exhibition and sale of oil paintings and water-color stage designs by Elizabeth Montgomery, who under the name of Motley has created costumes and sets for more than 100 theatrical productions, will open on Monday in the grand lounge of the Broadway Theater, where "Baker Street" is playing.
COTONOU, Dahomey, May 21 (Reuters) -- A plot to overthrow the Dahomey Government was being investigated today, with several of the suspected plotters and confederates behind bars.

A "technological revolution" under way in the newspaper business will lead not only to better newspapers but also to better newspapermen, an editor and publisher said yesterday in the seventh Pulitzer Memorial Lecture at Columbia University.
LANCASTER, Pa., May 21 -- Jacks or Better, the defending national champion, won the first open jumper class in the Lancaster Horse Show today -- and he did it with a clean round under Neal Shapiro.

CHICOPEE, Mass., May 21 (UPI) -- A dozen uniformed police and plainclothes detectives rushed to the training camp of Cassius Clay, the heavyweight champion, today following a warning from New York City police.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Gemini 4 manned space flight, which will almost quadruple the number of hours American astronauts have spent in space, is now scheduled for June 3.
Mayor Wagner ordered the City Labor Department last night to hold an election among taxi workers "as expeditiously as possible" to measure their interest in union representation.
The British pound continued to ease slightly on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The spot rate closed at $2.7967, compared with $2.7976 during the preceding day.

The State Supreme Court here yesterday ordered J. Raymond Jones, New York County Democratic Chairman, not to make any changes in the voting district lines of the party's county executive committee pending a hearing Tuesday.

The Glen Alden Corporation is searching for other companies to acquire and it has $38 million in cash on hand. Albert A. List, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday. He also said that Meshulam Riklis, chairman of the Rapid-American Corporation who recently joined the Glen Alden board as vice chairman, was leading the search.
LONDON, May 21 -- The Labor Government will not try to push its bill to renationalize the steel industry through the present session of Parliament.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 21 -- Leon Shapiro, who was dismissed as director of the Children's Shelter in Westbury, was indicted by a Nassau County grand jury today on charges of willful negligence and omission of duty.

MEXICO CITY, May 21 -- Charles H. Kellstadt, retired chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., was re-elected today as chairman of the Association of Better Business Bureaus. The association concluded its 51st annual convention here today. It also re-elected Victor H. Nyborg, of Rye, N.Y., as national president.
The Xerox Corporation made good yesterday on a promise made by Joseph C. Wilson, president, at the annual meeting on May 13. It entered the field of education in a big way.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21 -- A leader of the country's major social work organization today predicted the emergence, "possibly very soon," of a social planning state in which "social utilities" will become as vital and acceptable to every citizen as public utilities have.
WASHINGTON, Army 21 -- Laurance S. Rockefeller said today that "the people of the United States want a better environment" and "are ready to work for it."

The Penn-Texas Corporation, now Colt Industries, Inc., obtained a $1,760 million judgment yesterday against Jacques Sarlie, a financier and leading figure in the company's proxy fight eight years ago.

CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP) -- Archie Roberts, star Columbia University quarter- back, signed an agreement with the Cleveland Browns today that would help him fulfill his ambition of becoming a physician and playing professional football.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 21 -- The police used tear gas and rifle butts to disperse 2,000 striking workers today as Bolivia's military junta moved toward a decisive confrontation with labor leaders.
The director of the Kennecott Copner Corporation announced 2 esterday I an inerease J in the quarterly dividend to[ $1.25 a share from $1 in pre-I v,ous quarters.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The United States and Argentina jointly announced plans today to collaborate in launching weather rockets in a search for more information about hemispheric weather patterns.
The MOM's of Greenwich Village confronted the beatniks of Macdougal Street last night.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Provisions for a program of college scholarships were deleted from the Administration's higher education bill today by the House Education and Labor committee. The vote was 13 to 12.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Another Congressional assault on Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara's management practices was brewing today -- this time an effort to restrict his right to close military bases.

" A Musical Travelogue -- Barbershop Style" was presented last night at Town Hall by the Manhattan Chapter of the Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing in America.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, May 22 (UPI) -- North Korea today returned the body of a South Korean Army lieutenant shot down Tuesday after his plane crossed the demilitarized zone into Communist territory.
A soft answer from Robert E. Kintner, president of the National Broadcasting Company, yesterday turned away Walter Cronkite's wrath.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21 (UPI) -- A group of students challenged Ohio State University's speaker's rule today by having a visitor who had been barred from the campus appear silently on stage while passages from his books were read.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 21 -- The emergency room in the Salvador B. Gautier Hospital is a small room, with paint-shredded green walls, a peeling pink linoleum floor and flies.

I am somewhat dismayed at the lack of imagination displayed by Messrs. Siegel, Starr and McLaughlin [letter published April 28] in condemning an as yet unpublished architectural study for the proposed development of the 94th Street Armory site on Park Avenue.

Dr. Peter Leonidovich Kapitsa, one of the Soviet Union's leading physicists, is leaving Moscow today for a scientific conference in Copenhagen, according to a dispatch from Tass, the Soviet press agency.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) -- Vanity, boy friends, soft drinks and potato chips combine to make the teen-age girls the worst-fed members of the family, an agriculture department nutritionist maintains.

MONTREAL, May 21 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks raised his post-season bonus earnings to $7,750 today by being named the winner of the Hart Trophy as the National Hockey League's most valuable player of the 1964-65 season.

IF you want to write a novel about politics that becomes a best seller and makes you lots of money, let Fletcher Knebel be your guide. His credentials are excellent: "Seven Days in May" brought in a fortune and "Convention" only slightly less. Those two books were co-authored by Charles Bailey, but now Mr. Knebel has braved it on his own. Axiom: Never split royalties if you can help it.
ALBANY, May 21 -- The current legislative session acquired another distinction today; it is now the longest in more than half a century.
LOS ANGELES, May 21 -- Public response to the new $12 million Los Angeles County Museum has been so great that it has created problems for museum officials.
There were widespread declines on the London stock exchange yesterday inspired by fears of the effects of the credit squeeze and the decline in industrial production in March.
EDWIN COOPERSTEIN'S new television station WNJU-TV, operating on ultra-high-frequency Channel 47, has inaugurated on Thursday nights a series that promises to be worth sampling.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., May 21 -- The East Hudson Parkway Authority said here tonight that it would consider a revision of its plans to widen the Cross County Parkway in order to uproot as few trees as possible.

Governor Rockefeller's proposal for a Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority should be carefully scrutinized by the Legislature to make sure it contains proper safeguards for local community planning and budgeting. However, that scrutiny should not become an excuse for blocking action in 1965 on this essential first step toward coping with the current commuter crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- An advisory panel called tonight for a postage rate increase and elimination of preferential rates to help overcome the operating deficit of the Post Office. The deficit now totals about $762 million a year.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Mr. McDonald received a hero's welcome at a labor dinner here last night.
A shopkeeper was stabbed critically last night as he went to the aid of a white patrolman being menaced by an angry crowd of 200 Negroes on a Bronx street, the police said.
For the fifth consecutive day, issues on the American Stock Exchange lost ground yesterday in quiet trading.
Most Government and corporate bonds wound up yesterday with prices at Thursday's closing levels.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 -- Forty to 50 persons are under arrest here today as suspects in a plot to depose Premier Phan Huy Quat.

PEOPLE who are in search of attractive greeting cards may now be trekking to the mid-East Side whenever an occasion demands, to pore over the choice selection at a newly opened card shop called Auguri at 900 First Avenue (near 51st Street).
OTTAWA, May 21 (UPI) -- Canada has made another giant wheat sale to Red China -- possibly $100 million worth -- informed sources said here today.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 21 -- Morristown lost another round today in its 10-year fight to change the course of a new interstate highway when a judge ruled that a demolition company could resume leveling houses in the path of Interstate 287.

One of the veils of secrecy shrouding the Kennedy Round of trade negotiations has been lifted by Christian A. Herter, the Administration's special representative for trade. Mr. Herter revealed that the confidential list of industrial items that the Common Market wants excluded from large-scale tariff cuts is "overly large, particularly in relation to those submitted by other principal countries," including the United States.

MOSCOW, May 21 -- The Soviet leadership is showing signs of increasing disillusionment with the policies and attitudes of President Johnson, and it is beginning to compare him unfavorably with John F. Kennedy and Franklin D. Roosevelt.
The Missouri Portland Cement Company has offered to acquire the Obear-Nester Glass Company for $38 a share.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 21 -- President Johnson's home state government struck twice today at his recommendation that Congress repeal Section 14 (b) of the Taft-Hartley Law, which permits the states to ban union shops.
VENICE, May 21 -- A good bit of the talk of Venice these days as in most 20th-century cities, centers on the transportation problem, but with a special Venetian twist that sets it apart.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission dismissed today, for lack of proof, a complaint of monopoly tactics against the nation's largest bubble gum maker.
PITTSBURGH, May 21 -- The telephone rang in Room 866 at the Penn-Sheraton Hotel and the squarely built man with the gray hair and deeply lined face went to answer it.

Exhibitors pinning up their sidewalk picture galleries yesterday for the spring show around Washington Square were talking over a movement to form a union and to start a post card campaign to Mayor Wagner -- both designed to resist curtailment of exhibition.

One of the less welcome aspects of the present political engagement of professors is that professors can easily develop some of the less desirable traits of politicians -- such as the tendency to classify people in neat little packages.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Johnson is expected to visit NEW York tomorrow -- but he has scrupulously avoided committing himself to the trip.
NDIANAPOLIS, May 21 (UPI) -- A frantic dash to make the field for the 500-mile Speedway auto race will start tomorrow with a sizable contingent of seasoned drivers hoping to join the 33-ear line-up.

BIRMINGHAM, England, May 21 (UPI) -- Angel Miguel, the Spanish champion making his third appearance in a British golf tournament, posted a 4-under-par 68 today for a two-round total of 135 and a three-stroke lead in the $16,800 Martini tournament.

THE Secretary General of the Organization of American States, selected by that body Thursday to work out a cease-fire in the Dominican Republic, has a stock phrase that illustrates his philosophy in a crisis.
MOSCOW, May 21 -- Ambassador, Yosef Tekoah of Israel was accused today by Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, of having "insulted the human dignity and religious feelings" of Soviet Jews.
LISBON, May 21 -- The Government of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar dissolved the Portuguese Writers Association tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 -- Representative William S. Mailliard urged today that the Maritime Administration be made an independent agency so that it could effectively carry out the policy set down in the Merchant Marine Act of 1936.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), May 21 -- Election years in Israel are traditionally a time of political excesses but there has never been such a political donnybrook as there is today.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 21 (AP) -- New Jersey's apportionment of its 15 Congressional districts was ruled unconstitutional today and the Legislature was ordered to start at once on a new alignment.
The elections of Seymour Perkins Jr. and Stuart D. Stevenson as vice presidents in the bond department of the Bankers Trust Company were announced yesterday by William H. Moore, chairman.
MEMPHIS, May 21 (AP) -- Julius Boros shot a six-under-par 64 today for a 36-hole score of 130 and a four-stroke lead in the $60,000 Memphis open.

As one of the panel speakers at the national teach-in that discussed the war in Vietnam, I was glad to read your approving comments in your May 17 editorial. Two further points about the meeting need to be made, however.

Ever since 1922 the New York State Constitution has required that voters in this state must be able to read and write English. Since most political candidates speak only English, political campaigns are conducted in English and the affairs of the state are transacted in English, this is a perfectly reasonable requirement. A voter who spoke or read no English would have great difficulty in knowing whom or what he was voting for.
David Dubinsky began his 34th year as president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union yesterday in Miami Beach "seeing delegates from all over the nation."
WHITE PLAINS, May 21 -- The State University of New York rejected two more proposed sites today for a branch of the university planned for Westchester County.
Vinton Freedley was reelected president of the Actors Fund of America yesterday at the charity organization's annual meeting at the Helen Hayes Theater.

A leading spokesman for a major international bank made a strong plea yesterday for the exemption of export financing abroad from the limit set by the Federal Reserve Board on domestic banks' international transactions.
