IOWA CITY, Iowa, May 21 (AP) -- Jim Garrett led favored Michigan State to a strong start toward its first Big Ten outdoor track title today by winning the broad jump and qualifying in two sprint races.

HOUSTON, May 21 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Giants bombed Houston Astros pitching for eight hits and six runs in the first two innings tonight and coasted to an 8-1 victory behind the five-hit pitching of Ron Herbel.

The decentralization plan for the city's school system will be appraised by educational and civic leaders early next week, prior to Board of Education action on the proposals in June. The reorganization, as outlined by Acting Superintendent Bernard E. Donovan, is an essential step toward reform of the giant system.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., May 21 -- The board of regents of the University of California took under advisement today, without discussion, two exhaustive committee reports growing out of recent campus disorders.
ALPINE, N.J., May 21 -- For the second year in a row Montclair won today the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub championship.
CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP) -- Rocky Colavito hit a tie-breaking homer tonight off Dick Radatz and Vic Davalillo drove in six runs as the Cleveland Indians walloped the Boston Red Sox, 11-6.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21 The 3.3-million member United Presbyterian Church was asked today to work for the repeal of state laws that prohibit interracial marriage.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews presented Mass Media Brotherhood Awards to 52 organizations and individuals yesterday for "outstanding contributions to the cause of brotherhood and better human relations.

Traffic Siren had a pretty good pick-up jockey in the main race at Aqueduct yesterday The last-minute rider was Ron Turcotte, the young French Canadian who gained international fame last Saturday by steering Tom Rolfe to victory in the Preakness.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 21 (UPI) -- A legislative investigating committee today blamed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and unruly white persons for last summer's racial troubles in St. Augustine.
After gaining a 3-1 lead at half-time, the Hannover-96 team of West Germany defeated the German-American Soccer League All-Stars, 3-2, last night at Eintracht Oval in Astoria, Queens.
ONE of the liveliest and least expected exhibitions in town is William Gropper's group of etchings -- his first forays into the medium -- at the Associated American Artists Gallery, 605 Fifth Avenue.
All soybean futures deliveries touched contract lows yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade before a late recovery lifted the old-crop months from their low levels.

NEWARK, May 21 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge James A. Coolahan dismissed today a Government civil antitrust suit seeking to block the proposed $100 million cash sale of Penick Ford, Ltd., to the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.

The Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra, conducted by David Randolph, celebrated its 10th anniversary last night at Carnegie Hall with a baroque program. There was Bach's "Magnificat" and Orchestra Suite No. 4; Handel's Concerto Grosso in G (Op. 6, No. 1), and Vivaldi's "Gloria."

POLAND SPRING, Me., May 21 -- On the dinning room floor of the 171-year-old Mansion House, Sonny Liston sparred five rounds today, skipped rope to Lionel Hampton's Railroad No. 1," and shrugged away reports that a carload of men with guns from New York was en route to Cassius Clay, the heavyweight champion.
The Green Giant Company, the large producer of canned vegetables, announced yesterday that it attained record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended March 31.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Representatives of small independent bankers told Senators today they opposed a bill to exempt bank mergers from the Federal antitrust laws.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit has reversed two New Jersey murder convictions because the police did not advise the defendants, before taking their confessions, of their right to counsel and their right to remain silent.

A Canadian radio, television and electronics manufacturer criticized yesterday the Canadian Government's delays in authorizing color television and told his stockholders that he plans to introduce in June a line of 11 color receivers for the United States market.

Lucky Turn, winner of the $23,100 Riggs Handicap at Pimlico last month, will be among the top thoroughbreds that will compete today in the 17th meeting of the Adjacent Hunts at the Blind Brook Club in Purchase, N.Y.
The Itek Corporation, a producer of advanced-information systems, announced the appointment yesterday of J. David Hopkins Jr. to the new post of vice president for commercial activities.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 21 -- As a 30-mile-an-hour wind sent scores swirling, three tied for the 36-hole lead in the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament today. Jerry Courville, Tim Holland and Jim Maver were deadlocked at 147 at the seaside Seawane Club course.
RANGOON, Burma, May 21 (AP) -- With the end of the monsoon season, the Burmese Army has begun another massive drive against Communist and tribal rebels.
For the second day in a row Upper New York Bay was alive with sound yesterday to greet a vessel on a maiden voyage.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The United States disclosed today that it would soon withdraw about 1,700 troops from the Dominican Republic and cooperate in the establishment of a joint command there under a Brazilian officer.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 21 -- A fleet Of 111 auxiliary cruising yachts, the biggest ever to sail in Larchmont Yacht Club's six-mile reef race for the Edlu Trophy, set out from off Larchmont breakwater just before sunset this evening on the start of the season's first major distance race on Long Island Sound.

PARIS, May 21 (UPI) -- Bob Hewitt of Australia upset seventh-seeded Rafael Osuna of Mexico and sixth-seeded Martin Mulligan of Australia was stopped by Ingo Buding of Germany today in the third round of the French tennis championship.

John H. Young, a former aide to Representative Adam Clayton Powell, charged yesterday that the proposed re-drawing of City Council districts would continue to deprive Negroes and Puerto Ricans of fair representation.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 21 -- A 24-hour truce to permit the removal of the dead and wounded went into effect at noon today. Whitey Ford, listed so often in the "lost" column this season and presumed dead as pitching leader of the New York Yankees, hurled a three-hit shutout against the Washington Senators at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

WESTERN movies, which have been shedding their beloved cliches for many years, are under pressure to shed one more, their lily-whiteness. With another cycle of Westerns beginning, the effects of Civil Rights moral and economic suasion can already be seen, and, if it raises some uneasy questions in Hollywood, it also provides screen writers with a broad new dimension.

The New York Yacht Club found it necessary last week to restate the conditions under which it held the America's Cup, the world's foremost sailing prize, and to emphasize that there had been no change in the competition's underlying concept for 114 years.
NEW DELHI, May 22 -- As India's Mount Everest expedition made its second assault on the peak today, the country was still in a mild state of euphoria over Thursday's successful first attempt.

ATLANTA, May 22 -- One dramatic measure of court-ordered reapportionment of legislatures will be apparent when nine, and possibly 10, Negroes take their seats at the next session of the Georgia General Assembly.
A free-swinging brawl between members of rival seamen's unions broke out on the gangway of the ferryboat Hamilton yesterday, just as she was to start her 2 A.M. run from Staten Island to Manhattan.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22 -- Nikolai T. Fedorenko, the Soviet representative, was visibly shaken today when the Ivory Coast delegate suggested in the Security Council the abolition of the veto power held by the five permanent Council members.

The state of the economy was subjected to widespread examination in business and economic circles last week and was pronounced generally healthy and vigorous but bearing a few blemishes that should be watched.

Your critic expressed the fact that the failure of the non-musical or non-light comedy cannot rest solely on the critic. Yet, neither is it possible to shift the entire blame to "the blocks of public largely conditioned to all-out praise and smash hits."
NEW DELHI, May 22 -- The Indian Government acted this week to restore order and discipline at Aligarh Moslem University, where serious violence broke out last month.

HAVANA, May 22 -- If a scholarship student in a state education colony falls ill, suffers an accident or experiences "any other fact of real significance in his life, his parents will be duly informed," Cuba's Education Ministry ordered this week.
Following is the text of an address by Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey at a "See the U.S.A" luncheon given by the National Association of Travel Organizations in Washington on May 12:

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 22 (AP) -- A craft resembling a miniature Apollo spaceship plunged at 25,800 miles an hour into the atmosphere today to measure the intense heat that will envelop manned capsules returning from journeys to the moon.
NEWARK, May 22 -- New Jersey Republicans will have a choice of sharply contrasting individuals and platforms when they choose their candidate for Governor at the primary June 1.

THE lonely Farne Islands, lying in the storm-tossed North Sea off the Northumbrian coast, were, in the seventh century, a cultural center founded by Christian missionaries from Iona. It was to these islands that Saint Cuthbert, a Scot and Bishop of Lindisfarne, retired to die.

POLAND SPRING, Me., May 22 -- Sonny Liston talked today about setting up a nonprofit foundation to finance a sports center for youngsters in Denver. The former heavyweight champion, usually brusk at his daily news conference, spoke slowly and feelingly about his project.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 22 -- In keeping with tradition on Long Island Sound, the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club of Larchmont conducted the first regatta of the new Yacht Racing Association season today.
MILWAUKEE, May 22 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, shut out for five innings, rallied on the hitting of Roberto Clemente and Donn Clendenon today for a 9-4 triumph over the Milwaukee Braves.

BONN, May 22 -- Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, arrived at Salem Castle near the shores of Lake Constance today to spend a quiet weekend with some of their many German relatives.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) -- Two drivers made dramatic comebacks today in the thir day of time trials for the annual 500-mile automobile race May 31.

CAMBRIDGE, England, May 22 (Reuters) -- Ray White, Cambridge University's 24-year-old South African captain, and Derryck Murray, a West Indian wicketkeeper, led the Cambridge cricketers' attack today in a partnership of 198 runs on the opening day of their three-day match here.
The Child Study Association's Art Jackpot and Champagne Party will be held at association headquarters, 9 East 89th Street on Tuesday evening. Hermione Gingold will be the master of ceremonies.

The most heated words in legal circles these days are being used in the controversy over the admissibility of confessions. On Friday the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit added fuel to the fire by throwing out confessions in two murder cases because the police did not advise the defendants of their right to counsel and to remain silent before they took the confessions.

State Senator Thomas J. Mackell, Democrat of Queens, has introduced an amendment in Albany to his bill of March 16, which called for closing the longshore employment register and transfer of control of the 13 employment centers from the Waterfront Commission to joint operation by the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association.

HAVING for many years watched Americans "doing Europe" in a few days, we decided to try and reverse the process. We wished to see a large number of places on a 21-day excursion, and, since the normal travel agencies did not meet our requirements, we decided to make our own arrangements.
States and cities appear likely to borrow record amounts of money in 1965, despite a slowdown in bond sales in the first four months of the year.

MARIA CALLAS proved again last March when she sang two performances at the Metropolitan Opera of Puccini's "Tosca" that she is among the best singing actresses of this age, and probably ranks with the best of any time.
The Gulf of Mexico is cluttered with so many offshore oil rigs that navigation in the waters has become dangerous, a spokesman for a major shipping company said yesterday.

DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- Dick McAuliffe's two-run triple in the fifth inning and Jim Northrup's first major league home run in the sixth, paced the Detroit Tigers to an 8-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today.
HIBBING, Minn., May 21 -- After a decade of decline, optimism is rising in the Minnesota iron ranges. The optimism is based on three factors: taconite, new technology and taxes.
Charles Morrow made some wild sounds with his trumpet in Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Organization of American States was too slow in deciding what to do about the civil war in the Dominican Republic. The United Nations was too fast in entering a situation where the O.A.S. was just beginning to make some progress.
BONN, May, 22 -- West Germany has launched a political offensive in Eastern Europe aimed at ultimately putting its ambassadors on the job in most of the Communist capitals there.
DETROIT, May 22 -- The passage of legislation to cut the automobile excise tax will not automatically assure all new car buyers of an equivalent reduction in the price of their automobiles.
The Metropolitan Opera National Company, with the addition of 4 singers, has raised its roster to 32, and it has appointed Edwin Stahl assistant conductor.
Representative John V. Lindsay said yesterday he would be "greatly flattered" if Controller Abraham D. Beame and several others had any interest in joining his Republican mayoral ticket.

Recent peace overtures toward the National Football League having failed, the American Football League's ownership is attempting to look into its future with one eye open and one eye shut. The question the owners are asking is simple, to expand or not to expand?

A family of four who wanted room to entertain, a place to get together (as well as plenty of room to get away from each other) and a view, were given all this plus an architecturally exciting structure by John Fowler, a British architect. The house is distinguished by the fact that areas serving each of the specified functions are separated as half-levels on either side of a central staircase.
LONDON, May 22 -- Prime Minister Wilson will fly to Vienna tomorrow on a European "bridge building" mission to try to bring Europe's rival trading blocs together.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 22 -- The United States has provided close to $3 million to meet Dominican government payrolls and must decide next week if it will cover army and police pay for the last month of fighting.

BLUE flash bulbs have been standardized for all amateur flash photography, whether color or black-and white, according to recent announcements by the General Electric, Eastman Kodak and Agfa-Gevaert companies.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 23 -- Davada, Albert G. Preston Jr.'s Luder-16 Class sloop, and Llewellyn S. Howe's Flying Scot, Aeolus, were winners on Long Island Sound today when the Riverside Yacht Club was host to the opening regatta for Connecticut area fleets of the Yacht Racing Association, based east of Rye.
A record 172,500 students will sail or fly to foreign countries this summer, according to a survey by Travel Weekly, a trade publication. Their travel bill was estimated at $100 million.
ATHENS, May 23 -- Greek archeologists have urged the Government to take prompt action to halt decay in the monuments of the 2,400-year-old Acropolis. The collapse of the monuments is feared.
PITTSBURGH, May 23 -- Steel inventories continue to grow and there is no sign when liquidation will start.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 23 (UPI) -- The Government of President Guillermo Leon Valencia plans to put through an emergency economic program to combat Colombia's chronic rural problems and head off more student violence, informed sources said today.
BUSINESSMEN whose formal education stopped in their early teens will frolic tonight in the halls of Academe. The outside walls are not covered by ivy, nor is the campus set in a rolling countryside.
The New York family was off on a joyous motor holiday in Canada, feeling safe and content in their automobile.

Society discovered a new spot for dining and dancing Saturday night, when some 550 persons attended the first benefit party held aboard the Italian Line's new flagship, the Michelangelo, at Pier 90. The event is expected to raise about $50,000 for the New York division of the American Cancer Society.

CHICAGO, May 23 (UPI) -- Howie Reed, a relief pitcher, walked in the winning run in the 16th inning today to give the Chicago Cubs a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. The game was the longest in the major leagues this season.
SAN JUAN, P.R., May 23 -- The American Bar Association acted today to encourage cooperation between the legal profession and the Government's program to provide free legal services for the poor.
WAILUKU, Hawaii, May 23 -- The Republican party in Hawaii set out this weekend to revive itself under new leadership.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A possible answer to the problem of financing the development of a supersonic airliner was offered today by a Washington consulting concern.
Representative John V. Lindsay said last night that New York City "has been dreadfully short-changed on the poverty program" and pledged he would make this a campaign issue.
Special combination rates and a readership of more than 19.6 million are being offered to advertisers by the publishers of The Ladies' Home Journal and American Home magazine.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- With sales amounting to $1.5 billion a year, the United States has become the biggest arms merchant in the world.

Pan American World Airways has reported that organizations representing 10,000 Europeans are seeking flights to the United States this summer and fall under a "Thriftyway to U.S.A." charter program announced earlier this month.

ROME, May 23 -- The Very Rev. Pedro Arrupe, the white-haired, ascetic-looking priest who was elected the 28th Father General of the Society of Jesus yesterday, is known for varied accomplishments, not all of them spiritual.

TOKYO, May 23 -- Playing with guns is said to have been the undoing of Japan's favorite sumo wrestler in the current tournament for the huge silver Emperor's Cup, emblematic of supremacy in the ancient Japanese sport of pot-bellied giants.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has issued a stern warning that any change in the accounting method used by the United States to calculate its international payments position "would serve the country poorly."

THE orderly woman who has already organized her swimsuits and sun tan lotions into shape for her summer vacation may be ready to start thinking deep thoughts about her winter furs. Altman's is ready to help, with Lilly Dache's fall fur collection ensconced in its third-floor fur salon.
AUBURN, Me., May 23 -- It began early this morning in the lobby of the Schine Inn at Chicopee, Mass., with Cassius Clay grunting "huh . . . huh . . . huh" as he stabbed the air with practice punches.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- The chairman of the Civil Service Commission skid today that there was no "race quota" for the hiring or advancement of Negro Federal employes.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 23 -- The soldier behind the sandbag said, "There is a great misunderstanding about Communism and misery."

The Administration's gun-control bill, which is now the subject of Senate hearings, is excellent as far as it goes, but it does not go far enough. The bill would ban the sale of guns through the mails, would increase license fees for gun dealers and, except for certain kinds of hunting rifles, would forbid the sale of firearms to persons under 21.

Lack of reverence for land and the earth's resources is an offense to God and a breach of faith with future generations, the Rev. Dr. Charles Howard Graf declared yesterday at St. John's in the Village Episcopal Church.

WITH ROYALIST ARMY, in northeast Yemen, May 5 -- Most of the princes leading the royalists in Yemen no longer say they can decisively defeat the Egyptians assisting republican forces and drive them into the sea. However, they feel stronger than ever and believe they are closer to forcing the Egyptians to allow the republicans to reach a political compromise in Yemen's civil war.
A parade on Fifth Avenue and ceremonies in Central Park and other parts of the city were held yesterday to honor the nation's war dead.
Political leaders have been studying the bitter 1961 mayoral campaign to see what light is might shed on the race between Mayor Wagner and Representative John V. Lindsay.

POLAND SPRING, Me., May 23 -- There's something almost pathetic about an ogre who has lost his power to frighten victims into a state of paralysis with one baleful glance. That erstwhile monument to terror, Sonny Liston, no longer seems to be a monster from a horror movie. He has been deflated into a surly, disagreeable hulk who can't even scare interviewers into choking on their words before his beady, withering glare.
VIENNA, May 23 -- Six European prime ministers officially reopened today the question of uniting all of Western Europe.
Demonstrators in white held a sit-in for 10 minutes on the clay courts in Central Park yesterday, and one carried a sign reading: "Newbold Morris Unfair To Tennis Players."
MOSCOW, May 23 -- The musical world here has been stirred by the official approval given to two musical forms denounced by Nikita S. Khrushchev -- 12-tone music and jazz.

The American Stock Exchange's Rule 21, which provides for the appointment of governors and other members as floor officials, has been amended effective today to define more fully the role of the chairman, backed up by the vice chairman and the senior floor officials as the senior supervisory official on the floor.

The Nottingham Forest soccer team, celebrating the 100th year of its founding, had little to cheer about yesterday as it was defeated by Hannover '96 of West Germany. 3-1, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

The council Mayor Wagner will formally create today to direct the city's war on poverty contains the essential elements for a soundly based attack on the social and economic problems of the slums. But how well it achieves its purposes will depend, in important measure, on the application and imagination of the community leaders who have policy-making responsibility in the new governing council.

When the text of John V. Lindsay's first major address as candidate for Mayor of New York arrived at newspaper offices late last week the one word missing from it, in letterhead and throughout, was "Republican." It came from his "Campaign Press Center." It identified him merely as "candidate for Mayor of New York."

As City Hall prepared for three days of public hearings on Mayor Wagner's record $3.87 billion budget, the Mayor's borrowing plan was attacked yesterday by civic, commercial and homeowner groups. The hearing, opening this morning before a joint session of the Board of Estimate and the City Council's Finance Committee, promises to be acrimonious.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy paid visits of gratitude yesterday to two men who had never met until they faced a threatening mob together in the Bronx on Friday night.
The European Free Trade Association was lauded last week as an economic entity whose increasing vitality makes it as important in world trade as the European Common Market.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 23 -- Franz von Ziegesar of the Norwalk (Conn.) Yacht Club accepted the Edlu Trophy today at an awards breakfast that followed Larchmont Yacht Club's 11th six-mile reef race.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A policy of think American and drink American, instituted at the White House under Lyndon B. Johnson, is being put into effect at the State Department and in American missions abroad.

The honorary sponsors of the dinner to raise funds for a new wing for Gracie Mansion have been announced by the committee for the event, to be held June 3 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 23 -- A peaceful Sunday lull in the Dominican crisis permitted progress today in negotiations for the formation of a new civilian government.

ST. JAMES, N.Y., May 23 -- Diamond Cutter, from the stables of Ira Wiesenfeld of Jericho, N.Y., won the open-jumper championship at the Hollandia Farms horse show today. Ridden by Michael Ahearn of Jericho, the clever gelding turned in a series of top-flight performances to out-do the reserve champion, Dutch Maid of Hollandia Stables.

PARIS, May 23 -- Eleven members of a network of right-wing extremists have been arrested in western France, the police announced here today. Two of those seized are high officials of the police branch that deals with subversion.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 Thousands upon thousands of people are descending upon Indianapolis these days -- but not, alas, to the Busoni Festival. Right now the Speedway trials are in progress, and the big race takes place next week.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 23 -- Solution, Thor Ramsing's sloop from Indian Harbor, and Rainmaker, piloted by Skip Shaw, won the first races in the Philip J. Roosevelt and Elihu Root Jr. Trophy series on the Sound today. The sponsor was the Seawanhaka-Corinthian club.

JERSEY CITY, May 23 -- The appointment of the Rev. Leo P. McLaughlin, dean of St. Peter's College since 1959, as president of that college was announced today by the Rev. John L. Swain, Vicar General of the Society of Jesus.
The majority leader of the State Senate accused United States Senator Robert F. Kennedy yesterday of being "a divisive force" in the state's Democratic party.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox capitalized on Dean Chance's wildness for six runs in the first three innings today as they broke a three-game losing streak by beating the Los Angeles Angels, 8-3.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler will send to President Johnson this week a major proposal to reduce or eliminate the silver content in dimes, quarters and half-dollars.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in the Senate during the week ended yesterday.

Of all the problems that afflict the American merchant marine, none is more persistently hurtful than interunion feuding. The current strike of municipal ferryboat employes and its sporadic spillover of interference with deep-sea ship operations is a reminder of the need for more unity among the perennially battling maritime unions.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., May 23 -- Jim Hall and Hap Sharp of Midland, Tex., lapped the field and finished one, two today in the 213-mile United States road-racing championship contest on Bridgehampton's 2.86-mile course before 15,000 spectators.
Please permit me to make a correction in your May 5 editorial "Suffolk County's Board."

ALBANY, May 23 -- R. Burdell Bixby, chairman of the State Thruway Authority, charged today that "the billboard lobby is trying to get its foot in the door to create a billboard alley" on the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- The State Department, under the not-so-gentle prodding of Representative John J. Rooney, Democrat of Brooklyn, persuaded the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to keep Adlai E. Stevenson's rent at $33,000 a year, Congressional testimony disclosed today.
If you want a glass of water while dining out here, the restaurant will be glad to supply it. But any eating place that serves water except by request is risking a fine of up to $50.

The Allied Stores Corporation, a major department store chain, had record sales and increased earnings in its first quarter ended April 30, according to Theodore Schlesinger, president and chief executive officer.

BOSTON, May 23 (AP) -- The first Soviet-American team to inspect fishing vessels operating off the New England Coast returned today with a Soviet offer of free medical assistance to United States fishing boats.

A preview of the motion picture "A High Wind in Jamaica" followed by a champagne reception will be held tomorrow evening to benefit the scholarship fund of the American Foundation for the University of the West Indies.

SEATTLE, May 23 -- A Seattle furniture dealer named G.J. Doces paid $575 last night for the privilege of having dinner with the Governor of Washington. Another businessman bid $2,300 for a 35-year-old fire engine and a third paid $600 to have a chamber music group led by Mr. and Mrs. Milton Katims perform a concert at his home.

BUENOS AIRES, May 23 (AP) -- The British bridge team tonight ceded all its points in the world championship after officials of the World Bridge Federation accused two British players of having cheated.

The Sam S. Shubert Foundation announced yesterday grant, totaling $175,000 for playwriting fellowships at 34 universities and assistance to 12 theatrical organizations throughout the country -- and one foreign institution.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 -- Ron Swoboda, the 20-year-old rookie New York Met outfielder with so much promise, charged in today on a fly ball hit by Dal Maxvill of the St. Louis Cardinals with two out in the ninth inning.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The State Department has contracted with the Stanford Research Institute of California to study the effects of a sea-level canal on Panama's economy.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 23 -- The Dominican crisis, which may have cost more than 2,000 lives to date, will be a month old tomorrow.
The Transit Authority has decided to ask permission to operate buses on Park Avenue from 46th to 125th Street.

BILOXI, Miss., May 23 -- Jesse Hardy Cutrer Jr. slept until 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Then he arose and opened wide the door of his motel room and let in the haze, wind, smell and general grumble of the Gulf of Mexico.

Richard Palmer of Archbishop Stepinac High, White Plains, won the varsity singles competition in the 17th Fordham University invitation tennis tournament for high schools and grammar schools yesterday for the second straight year.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 23 -- The Southern Christian Leadership Conference opens a new phase of its voter registration drive in Alabama this week with an effort to stage a day of Negro lobbying at the Capitol here.

World wide ocean transportation of coal by 1970 is expected to reach an annual rate of close to 110 million metric tons, half of which will be United States exports, a leading British shipping analyst said last week.
CLEVELAND, May 23 (AP) -- Felix Mantilla's three-run homer led the Boston Red Sox to an 8-3 victory over Cleveland and a sweep of their doubleheader today. The Red Sox won the opener, 6-2.
The best thing that could happen to Nelson A. Rockefeller, one of his friends said last week, would be for John V. Lindsay to be not quite elected Mayor of New York City.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 23 --Jemminy Cricket, an aged brown gelding handled by Mrs. Robert Pierot of Port Chester, won the championship at the Stratford Farms spring horse show today with 29 points.
Harry B. Helmsley, president of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., has acquired all the stock of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc. The purchase was a personal one, and the two concerns will remain separate.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A compromise solution to the controversial question of how the Government should police bank mergers is being worked out quietly behind the scenes.
VIENNA, May 23 -- The Socialist Mayor of Vienna, 65-year-old Franz Jonas, was elected President of Austria today by a 60,000-vote margin over former Chancellor Alfons Gorbach, a Conservative.

The Illinois pavilion found at the beginning of last season that its animated figure of Lincoln was drawing 6 per cent of the fair's visitors. Word-of-mouth advertising helped double the percentage by the end of the 1964 season.
MOSCOW, May 23 (UPI) -- Soviet scientists say they have produced a synthetic caviar that is indistinguishable from the real thing.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 23 -- Social workers and lawyers have been engaged in the unauthorized and ineffective practice of each other's profession for years, a prominent lawyer said here today.

Two independent directors of the Equity Corporation have resigned, according to the company, because David M. Milton, chairman, insists on pushing for approval of a hand-picked slate of board nominees.
Twenty firemen were injured yesterday at a four-alarm blaze on 125th Street, Harlem's main shopping street.
CHARLOTTTE, N.C., May 23 (AP) -- Fred Lorenzen won the World 600-Mile stock car race today after mechanical failures forced out most of the drivers who could challenge him.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Some of the most distinguished shapers of the American environment will assemble here tomorrow for the first White House Conference on Natural Beauty.

ADENAU, Germany, May 23, (AP) -- The world champion driver, John Surtees of Britain and Ludovico Scarfiotti of Italy gave Ferrari a fourth consecutive victory today in the 620-mile Nuerburgring auto race, which was marred by the death of a driver.
DEEP in the interior of Southern Brazil, 500 to 600 miles from the City of Sao Paulo, there is a frontier community inhabited chiefly by colonists of German and Italian origin.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 23 -- Local and out-of-state residents clogged winding, tree-lined country roads here today for a biennial public tour of dramatic contemporary houses and one modern-style church.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- A recent economic study presents a grim picture of the Dominican Republic as a land of near-starvation and underscores the grave task that will confront whatever government emerges after the current crisis.

PARIS, May 23 (UPI) -- Tomas Lejus of the Soviet Union was reported today to be suffering from a turned ankle and may not be able to play against Cliff Drysdale of South Africa tomorrow in the men's singles quarter-finals of the French tennis championships.

OUTSCORING a strong 14-man field, the veteran master Marcel Dion won the recent championship match of the City of Quebec with 12 points out of a possible 13. A half-point behind was Serge Lacroix, 11 1/2.
MANILA, May 23 -- The Philippines has agreed to support Malaysia's bid for admission to the African-Asian conference.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 23 -- The triennial convention of B'nai B'rith opened here today with a reaffirmation of the vitality of Jewish life in the free societies outside Israel.

BOGALUSA, La., May 23 -- Mayor Jesse H. Cutrer Jr. promised tonight in a radio address that all city ordinances requiring segregation would be repealed and the city would hire Negroes for the police force and possibly for other departments of the city government.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Total public and private debt was $1,172,000,000,000 at the end of 1964, an increase of $76 billion over the total in the preceding year, the Commerce Department reported tonight.

To a half-million children in the nation's slums and pockets of poverty, this summer will offer special preparation for their entry into school in September. President Johnson's announcement of the details for Project Headstart has transferred the responsibility for this vital program from Washington to 2,500 individual communities.

TOKYO, May 23 -- The Government gave assurances today that official action in concert with leading Japanese banks would seek the economic redemption of the Yamaichi Securities Company, Japan's second largest brokerage house, which has been stated to be virtually insolvent.

NEW ORLEANS, May 23 -- The airline industry, which has long accepted the idea that it should pay a share of the Federal cost of the airway system, should re-examine this conclusion, a leading spokesman said here last week.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 23 -- The United States must help develop political stability as well as economic strength among nations of the world to insure the success of the foreign aid program, David E. Bell told the graduating class at the University of Vermont today.

Charles Reiner, pianist, and Arthur Garami, violinist, began their three-part survey of the Beethoven sonatas last night at the Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Reiner, until recently accompanist to Henryk Szeryng, was given first billing, perhaps to emphasize that his role now is full partner. In any event, this was most happily borne out.

Christians should not think of the qualities and personality of God in exclusively masculine terms, the Rev. Hugh Blenkin of Hockerill College in Hertfordshire, England, said yesterday at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 64th Street.
A Protestant minister pleaded yesterday for understanding on the part of people the world over in international relations, civil rights and human relations.
LEBANON, Ind., May 23 (AP) -- A finance executive who served as General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's senior military aide in World War II was killed today in a traffic accident.

MEMPHIS, May 23 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus came roaring up from out of the pack today, tied Johnny Pott at 72 holes in the $60,000 Memphis open, then won the tournament on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff.

DALLAS May 23 (UPI) -- Mickey Wright shot a four-over-par 75 today but won the Dallas Civitan golf tournament by one stroke over Kathy Whitworth. Miss Wright finished the tourney with a one-under-par 283.
LANCASTER, Pa., May 23 -- Untouchable, the Olympic ace, captured the open jumper championship by the slim margin of one point tonight in the Lancaster horse show.
THE Chet Huntleys and the Mike Wallaces and all the men who dispense news so coolly on television have only one sartorial worry -- they can't wear white shirts on camera.

CINCINNATI, May 23 (AP) -- John Herrnstein scored an unearned run in the 10th inning today when the Reds' catcher, John Edwards, dropped a throw from the outfield, giving the Philadelphia Phils a 4-3 triumph.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Congress, facing one of its heaviest workloads of the year, will focus its attention this week on five of the Administration's major proposals.
CANNES, France, May 23 -- "The Hill," a film submitted by Britain, was shown last night at the Cannes Festival.
LOS ANGELES, May 23 -- Three women are centers of attention in political jousting that will be settled in a municipal election Tuesday.

THE National Broadcasting Company's religious unit, under the guidance of Doris Ann, added another fine hour to its list of accomplishments yesterday afternoon. In cooperation with the Southern Baptist Convention it presented "The Inheritance," an hour-long documentary illustrating the Old Testament narrative of man's slow and tortuous acceptance of belief in one God.

The endorsement by the New York City Council of a Police Department Civilian Complaint Board is a droll perversity. It abnegates the autonomy of decision which is essential for efficient departmental administration.

British newspapers have made a start on meeting the problems of automation and overstaffing that may offer some guidelines for American publishers and unions.

FORT LEE, N.J., May 23 -- "Don't jiggle the books," Sister M. Louis Bertrand warned as "An Anthology of Light Verse," dropped to the floor. "They're going to slip out of the string and spill all over."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 23 -- Plans are well under way to bring the equivalent of a United States Army combat division into Vietnam next month, informed sources in the American mission said today.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- William E. Simkin, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said today organized labor's major weapon, the strike, had become almost useless in a few automated industries.

THE trek to the nursery is on, not to visit the small fry but to choose from among the flats of annuals, perennials and balled-and-burlapped bushes. The planting season for window boxes, terrace gardens and larger plots is here again.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 23 -- A leading churchman proposed today that six of the major Protestant bodies in this country "immediately" unite their social action and national missionary agencies without waiting for doctrinal problems to be ironed out.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced over the weekend the appointment of Thomas J. Flynn, Richard H. McCarthy and John A. Schaffer as vice presidents.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for the easy-to-prepare main dish.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May 23 -- Five hundred leaders of Conservative Judaism were told tonight that Jewish communal leadership was failing to provide sufficient financial assistance to enable American Jews to "retain their authentic cultural and spiritual heritage."
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The United States used Seabees to search out listening devices in its embassy in Warsaw and to repair the building.
The liberalization of criminal-law procedures by the Federal courts is resulting in a substantial and continuing increase in the number of suits charging false arrest.

Mayo, Cork and Kerry were the winners yesterday in an Irish football and hurling triple-header played before a crowd of 10,000 for the Cardinal Cushing Charities at Gaelic Park, the Bronx. Twelve of Ireland's top football and hurling players were brought here by the Ruppert Brewery Company to participate in the games.

A fresh and fervent concert of unusual chamber music was played late yesterday afternoon at the Carnegie Recital Hall. The program was considerably enlivened by Jozef Dylewski's "Essent VII III/XVI," written for the occasion.

The New York Yankees appeared in danger of another double defeat at the hands of the Washington Senators yesterday until their leading crossword-puzzle enthusiast, Al Downing, came up with the right seven-letter word: Victory.

Dr. Maria Montessori, a pioneer in modern methods of child education, was eulogized yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The achievements of the Italian educator were held up as an example of the "faith in action" that all Roman Catholics should emulate.

The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association criticized Representative John V. Lindsay yesterday for advocating the addition of four civilians to the Police Department's three-man board of deputy commissioners for reviewing complaints of police brutality.

YONKERS, May 23 -- Gar Williams, who earned a doctorate from the University of Chicago in 1963, realized another ambition today: He won a marathon for the first time. It was doubly satisfying, because the race was the Amateur Athletic Union's national championship.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 23 -- The smallest dog in the ring walked off with the biggest prize at the Long Island Kennel Club's 63d annual fixture today when Ch. Rebel Roc's Fiesta, a five-pound miniature pinscher, was named best in show by Harry T. Peters Jr. of New York.

POLAND SPRING, Me., May 23 -- Big Red, the sometime wayward bus, brought Cassius Clay to the gentle rolling banks of the Androscoggin River today, and the heavyweight champion said. "Every city in America looks the same to me. I don't know nothing about Maine."
TORONTO, May -- 23 -- "We don't have a national lottery," a Canadian broker said recently. "But we do have the Toronto Stock Exchange."

SANA, Yemen, May 21 -- Yemen's new republican Premier offered friendship today to both Saudi Arabia and Britain in a new effort to react a political settlement of Yemen's prolonged and costly civil war.
ALBANY, May 23 -- The Legislature will get another chance this week to tighten its code of ethics.

Western Europe's drive to mechanize and modernize its agriculture still has a lot of ground to cover. Nevertheless, the progress made in recent years has brought an impressive change. Farm machinery, once rare on the European landscape, has become a familiar sight.

BRUSSELS, May 23 -- Early returns in the Belgian national election tonight indicated major gains for the Liberal party as voters registered dissatisfaction with the previous coalition Government headed by Pemier Theo Lefevre.

The Mussorgsky-Ravel "Pictures at an Exhibition" is a prime orchestral showpiece, to be undertaken only by a real virtuoso ensemble. At Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, the shattering sonorities of "The Great Gate at Kiev" ended, a concert played by the 92 teen-agers who constitute the Cosmopolitan Young People's Symphony Orchestra.

Edward F. Rodgers, executive vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co., has been elected president of the Tenant-Owned Apartment Association, Inc., which is made up of New York real estate companies and individual owners of cooperative apartments.
" An Hour and Sixty Minutes With Jack Benny" will be the opening bill from June 24 through July 3 at Bruce Becker's Tappan Zee Playhouse in Nyack, N.Y.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 23 -- A fleet of 119 boats sailed today in the season's second Yacht Racing Association regatta conducted by the Horseshoe Harbor Club on Long Island Sound.
Anything Dean Eugene Rostow writes deserves respectful attention, but some things more than others; his letter to The Times published May 18 is one of the others.

HOUSTON, May 23 (AP) -- A three-run, inside-the-park homer today by Jim Ray Hart on a routine fly ball that Jimmy Wynn lost against the background of the dome paced the San Francisco Giants to a 5-2 victory over the Houston Astros.
The National Broadcasting Company will televise a one-hour color special on the crisis in the Dominican Republic at 7:30 P.M. Friday.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 (UPI) -- Johnny Boyd, Bill Cheesbourg and Chuck Rodee joined two rookies today as the final qualifiers for the Indianapolis Speedway 500-mile auto race, but Rodger Ward will miss the May 31 show.

PORT WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Robert Kron's Therapy whipped 25 Rhodes-19 Class competitors as 72 boats sailed in the Cow Bay Racing Association's regatta. It marked the largest single class start with the exception of Race Week on Manhasset Bay.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, said today that "it's absolutely disgraceful" that a committee on the conduct of Senators and their employes remained unselected although it was authorized 10 months ago.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23 -- President Sukarno today told Asian and African nations that intend to support Malaysia's participation in the forthcoming second African-Asian conference at Algiers to stay at home.

LONDON, May 23 -- Police officials in Birmingham and London began a search today for the "tall, well-spoken, man" they believe returned Goya's portrait of the Duke of Wellington after keeping it for almost four years.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 23 -- Heavy fighting broke out between troops and striking miners today after Bolivia's ruling military junta ordered the armed forces to occupy tin mines throughout the country.
Representative William Fitts Ryan announced yesterday that he would not oppose Mayor Wagner in the Democratic primary because he did not have enough money to conduct a campaign.

PARIS, May 23 -- President de Gaulle returned to Paris today from a tour on which he tore through the French countryside at up to 80 miles an hour and denounced United States and Soviet leadership in the world.
MILWAUKEE, May 23 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates completed a three-game sweep of Milwaukee today by crushing the Braves, 10-1, behind the four-hit pitching of Bob Veale.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP) -- Jackie Brandt batted in five runs and sparked the Baltimore Orioles to 7-3 and 8-3 victories over Detroit today. The doubleheader loss was the fifth of the season for the Tigers.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 24 -- The 77th annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball will be given in the Tuxedo Club Oct. 16. Eight debutantes will be presented.

" Commander-I," by Peter George, which Delacorte will publish on June 21, presents fictionally the interesting future the world would face after a nuclear war. He has Communist China starting the war and then, when there are only a few thousand survivors to worry about, he tells of Commander One's attempt to take over as leader of "The United States of the World."
A three-man Federal court rejected yesterday an attempt by the Democratic legislative leadership to forestall a special election this fall.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 24 -- A total of 396 Negro teachers have lost their jobs because of the integration that began in Oklahoma schools in 1955.
Before Huntington Hartford turns that first spade of earth for his restaurant in the cluttered southeast corner of Central Park, he should ponder:

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren, in a memorial ceremony today for Supreme Court Justice Harold Burton, called the jurist "a man of noble character, stamped by both integrity and humility."

Portions of the Soviet Union's television coverage of the Soviet-United States track and field meet in Kiev this summer will be relayed here by the Early Bird satellite and presented live by the American Broadcasting Company, the network announced yesterday.
Mayor Wagner defended his administration's handling of requests for Federal antipoverty money yesterday, stating that "we worked to get as much as we could."

A treasure of Western Americana moved along with a lot of corporate valuables when the Sperry and Hutchinson Company -- the green stamp people -- transferred its headquarters in recent months from 114 Fifth Avenue to 330 Madison Avenue and recreated the suite of executive offices known intramurally as Beinecke Alley.
The British pound declined in moderate trading here yesterday in foreign exchange markets.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz endorsed President Johnson's call for repeal of the so-called "right to work" clause of the Taft-Hartley Act today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 24 -- Bolivia's military junta and striking tin miners agreed to a cease-fire tonight after bitter fighting in La Paz and other areas. The cease-fire agreement was signed by Gen. Alfredo Ovando Candia, the armed forces commander, and leaders of the Bolivian Drivers Union, who mediated between the ruling junta and the miners.
THE most popular decorating game this year seems to be to take as many periods and fashionable decorating notions as possible and mix madly.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A plan to block the closing of the Brooklyn Navy Yard by curbing Defense Department powers was offered today by Representative Otis G. Pike, Democrat of Long Island.

LA PAZ, May 24 -- Forty-eight deaths were reported today in fighting that enveloped Bolivia in a virtual civil war during the day as the Government fought to overcome armed resistance by striking tin miners.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 24 -- Five women climbed into the shovel of a bulldozer this morning and sat there for more than an hour to prove that they considered the fight over Interstate Highway 287 far from finished.

At least 500 of North Carolina's 12,500 Negro teachers will lose their jobs this year as a result of the transfer of Negro students to formerly all-white schools, an official of the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., declared here yesterday.
The stock market drifted downstream all day yesterday and prices generally closed at their lowest levels of the session.

HOUSTON, May 24 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Reds hammered Dave Glusti for five hits and three runs in the second inning tonight and went on to defeat the Houston Astros, 5-2, behind the six-hit pitching of Jim Maloney and Joey Jay.

No American worker enjoys fewer statutory safeguards than the migratory farm laborer; he is outside virtually all the laws that guarantee any element of decency in wages or working conditions. Yet he can always be sure that powerful political and economic interests will combine to erode whatever small measure of protection he finally wins through Government action.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- The board of trustees of Girard College rejected unanimously today a proposal that they integrate the institution voluntarily.

A stockholder of the Curtis Publishing Company has instituted an action in behalf of the company and its shareholders against directors of the big publishing concern and against the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company.
Absence of demand on the London stock market sent prices down irregularly yesterday, although the list steadied just before the close of the session.
Corporate bonds declined yesterday, apparently under the weight of the large amounts of securities offered or announced recently.

Samuel Rubin of New York and Charles B. Wrightsman of Palm Beach, Fla., have been elected to the board of the New York University Medical Center, it was announced yesterday by Samuel D. Leidesdorf, chairman of the board.
It was a blue Monday on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as both proces and volume slumped.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews's three run homer gave the Milwaukee Braves a 4-3 victory today over the San Francisco Giants, who played without Willie Mays.

The New York State Attorney General's office disclosed yesterday it had found evidence that some savings and loan association brokers had sold confidential financial information about their customers to other commercial investment enterprises.
Councilman Paul O'Dwyer denounced City Council President Paul R. Screvane yesterday as lacking in leadership and formally announced that he would oppose him in the Democratic primary.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 24 -- United States efforts toward a political settlement in the Dominican crisis made little progress today, but the cease-fire continued.

By unanimous decision a three-judge Federal district court did the inevitable yesterday. It rejected the request of New York's Democratic legislative leaders to cancel the interim election of a new Legislature in November. Judge Sterry R. Waterman was mild indeed in characterizing the present legislature as inept and inactive for its failure to enact a valid reapportionment statute since it took office last January.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- A prosecution witness testified today that Dr. Andrew C. Ivy, pioneer sponsor of Krebiozen, offered to cooperate with the Government in the investigation of the chemical compound.
The final round of the American Zone Davis Cup matches, scheduled to be played in Mexico City in the event Mexico qualifies with the United States, has been transferred to Dallas.
The first trans-Atlantic televised art auction, relayed by the Early Bird communications satellite, was held yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania awarded 2,737 degrees today at its 209th commencement.
Representative John V. Lindsay, who hopes to unseat Mayor Wagner in this fall's mayoral election, got a far better reception than the Mayor last night at a dinner of leaders of the printing industry.
Prices of frozen pork bellies for future delivery closed at record levels yesterday in the heaviest volume of trading for that commodity on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- A 30-year-old African woman is being treated here "as if she were a smallpox victim" until tests prove otherwise, officials said today.
The president of the Equity Corporation, a closed-end, non-diversified investment company, took sides yesterday with two directors who resigned earlier in a dispute with David M. Milton, chairman.
The board of directors of the New York Heart Association at its annual meeting yesterday, elected Dr. Alfred P. Fishman president of the association.

WHITE PLAINS, May 24 -- At a cost estimated at $218,000, the state will again attempt to curb motorists' confusion on the Cross County Expressway. New directional signs will be installed, the Public Works Department notified Westchester County officials today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 24 Two of the world's most famous contract bridge players, Terence Reese and Boris Schapiro of Great Britain, were accused here last night of exchanging improper information during the world bridge championships.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Luis Aparicio's double against the left-field fence in the seventh inning scored Russ Snyder with the winning run as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Washington Senators, 2-1 tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Senate rejected today, 49 to 29, an amendment to the voting rights bill that would have eliminated the so-called "automatic triggering device" in the Administration measure.
TRENTON, May 24 -- A 1965-66 state budget of $639.6 million was passed by the Assembly and sent to Gov. Richard J. Hughes today at the last legislative meeting before the summer recess.
BONN, May 24 -- Stuttgart gave Queen Elizabeth a roaring welcome today -- the most enthusiastic she has received on her state visit to West Germany.
BOGALUSA, La., May 24 (AP) -- Crowds of white persons tonight tore down the gates to Cassidy Park, one of two city parks closed after a racial clash last week.
NORTH ATTLEBORO, Mass., May 24 -- The John Birch Society today postponed an address by a Roman Catholic priest who is a member of its national council.

AUBURN, Me., May 24 -- It seemed appropriate. The water- purification motor of the pool at the Holiday Inn was causing the water to gurgle gently against the sides.

DALLAS, May 24 (AP) -- Jack L. Ruby, who killed President Kennedy's assassin, declared today that he had taken numerous pills -- "they stimulate you" -- shortly before he shot Lee Harvey Oswald.
Blair Clark, former broadcasting and newspaper executive, was named yesterday to the new position of associate publisher of The New York Post.
PITTSBURGH, May 24 (AP) -- A Government banking official said today that the present economic environment requires increased use of auditing programs by the country's banks, both large and small.

SANA, Yemen, May 24 -- Like something out of the Arabian Nights, 60 riflemen swept into the courtyard of the United States Embassy in full tribal, regalia -- rifles slung over their shoulders, long curved daggers on their jeweled belts and bandoleers crisscrossing their chests.
Dr. John M. Cotton, the retiring president of the New York County Medical Society, called on medical societies last night to help make any Federal medicare legislation work if it becomes law.

BOGALUSA, La., May 24 -- In a move to help maintain order, Negroes postponed today a scheduled test of Mayor Jesse H. Cutrer's declaration Sunday ending city segregation policies in this tense Louisiana paper mill town.
The String Quartet of the National School of Music of the University of Brazil, now on its first United States tour, paid its respects to New York last night in a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Strong pitching by Warren Spahn and especially by Frank Lary, errorless play and power hitting made the New York Mets winners in two games against the Philadelphia Phillies tonight before a crowd of 21,701. The scores were 6-2 and 4-1.
The Theater Guild and Gerard Oestreicher will co-produce two plays: "So Much of Earth, So Much of Heaven" and "A Secret Hiding Place."
The chances are better than three to one that random selection of a stock on the New York Stock Exchange between 1926 and 1960 would have produced a winner.
Representatives of community groups in New York's poor neighborhoods expressed bitterness and skepticism last night over the city's tactics in its campaign against poverty.
For the first time in 40 years the national indoor track and field championships will leave New York.

MONTREAL, May 24 (UPI) -- Thousands of demonstrators calling for the separation of Quebec Province from Canada stormed through city streets tonight, setting fires and destroying property. About 130 persons were arrested.

BRUSSELS, May 24 -- Surprising gains by extremist groups in yesterday's general election have raised fears of a renewal of hostilities between French-speaking and Dutch-speaking Belgians.

POLAND SPRING, Me., May 24 -- Cassius Clay, a 23-year-old who has won all 20 of his professional fights, will defend his heavyweight title tomorrow night against Sonny Liston. Clay said today that it would be an "interesting, exciting, shocking, dreadful fight."

A 115-pound policewoman, dressed in shabby clothes and wearing a gray wig, shot and wounded a man suspected of peddling narcotics and captured his partner as dozens of persons looked on in midtown at 2:15 yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Dominic Donatello first saw Alaska as a G.I. going to the Aleutian Islands in World War II. Two and a half years later, he was heading home and he wasn't thinking about life as a civilian in Alaska.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The White House Conference on Natural Beauty opened today with a call from Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson for all citizens to help erase an ugly America.
LONDON, May 24 -- The House of Lords approved in principle tonight a bill to remove from criminal law all penalties for homosexual conduct by consenting adults in private.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 24 -- Adlai E. Stevenson rejected today a United Nations report on the security corridor in Santo Domingo. According to the report, American officers had said the corridor would be "extended as and when United States forces deem it necessary."

The Hewlett-Packard Company, California manufacturer of electronic test equipment, had "the best first-half-year period in its history" in the six months ended April 30, David Packard, chairman, reported yesterday.
New-car sales continued their upward movement in mid-May, topping last year's performance by 8.3 per cent.

A plot by an alleged Negro terrorist group to bomb the White House and Congress from the air while carrying out nationwide assaults on police stations, airfields and industrial plants was unfolded in Federal court yesterday by a police of undercover agent.
SELMA, Ala., May 24 (UPI) A large but apparently routine shipment, of surplus military rifles to a local gun dealer created concern in the civil rights movement today.

The financially troubled Yale Express System, Inc., which has run a deficit of more than $4.6 million in the last two years, filed a Chapter X bankruptcy petition in Federal District Court here yesterday.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 24 -- On a Sunday afternoon or any evening, the women in brightly colored leotards play upon guitars and sing of patriotism and love.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 24 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. told a mass meeting of Alabama Negroes tonight that "there will be no peace in the statehouse" until the Alabama Legislature "puts us on its agenda."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 24 -- The United States asked today for assurance from the Soviet Union that it would keep strict control over nuclear warheads for missiles given to East Germany and other Eastern European armies.

The J.C. Penney Company is reducing by 10 per cent the retail price of several lines of appliances and home electronics on which Federal excise taxes are expected to be repealed. The action will apply to merchandise sold in retail stores, as well as through catalogues, beginning tomorrow.

ALBANY, May 24 -- Daniel McGowan Kelly, the owlish-looking Assemblyman sponsoring the controversial new ethics code for legislators, is proudest of a Citizens Union endorsement calling him "the conference of the Legislature."

The principle that Americans are entitled to receive their mail without interference by an oversolicitous Government has been upheld by the Supreme Court. The law under which the Post Office withheld what it considered propaganda mail from Communist countries unless the addressee specifically requested its delivery was an indefensible infringement on the free exchange of ideas.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, and Representative Herbert C. Bonner, chairman of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, received special recognition from the Department of Commerce today for their efforts in promoting the American Merchant Marine.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A new complication in the search for a coalition government in the Dominican Republic was introduced today by the disclosure that Antonio Guzman Silvestre was a director of a Dominicas agricultural bank accused of irregularities.

CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI) -- Bill Freehan hit two home runs tonight, one of them the first grand slam of his career, and drove in five runs as the Detroit Tigers scored an 8-3 triumph over the Chicago White Sox.
PARIS, May 24 -- The news that French wines were no longer available at the White House was received here philosophically.
PARCHMAN, Miss., May 24 (AP) -- State penitentiary guards shot three convicts to death today during an escape attempt that was frustrated by an alert guard who was being held as a hostage.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Johnson signed legislation today permitting full United States participation in the International Coffee Agreement, nearly three years after the agreement was first signed.

JERSEY CITY, May 24 -- Dr. Francis M. Tiers, 38-year-old director of anesthetics at the Jersey City Medical Center, was found dead today in his apartment at 10 Huron Avenue here. He was believed to have been dead about five days from an overdose of drugs, the police said.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Treasury, responding to criticism from Congress, announced tonight that it would not mint 45 million silver dollars after all.
Dutch Harrison and Johnny Bulla, who were disqualified after three rounds of the 1940 United States Open for starting too early, were still trying to make up for it yesterday.

AT 9:30 A.M. on Thursday, June 3, the new Vidal Sassoon-Charles of the Ritz salon will open its doors at 803 Madison Avenue (67th Street). To the Ritz office and the beauty editors who have been plagued since last fall with cries of "When?" the opening is a welcome relief.
Edward Albee, the playwright, has purchased the house that Maurice Evans, the actor, has occupied since 1949 at 50 West Tenth Street in Greenwich Village.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- As tiresome as it is to keep returning to the subject of President Johnson, something must be said in praise of his refusal to let his speech to the President's Club of New York be reported in the press.

PITTSBURGH, May 24 (AP) -- Andre Rodgers rapped a double and two singles in three consecutive innings in sparking the Pittsburgh Pirates to their fourth straight victory, a 6-4 decision over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

Alfred J. Roach, chairman and president of International Breweries, Inc., resigned yesterday following the formal announcement of the stockholder vote for directors in which his management slate gained three of the nine board seats.

Enrique Negron, the grocer who was stabbed in the back last Friday night after he had come to the aid of a policeman who was being pushed, threatened and kicked by an angry crowd of 200, was released from Fordham Hospital late yesterday -- and returned to his Bronx neighborhood a hero.
Jersey Central and Erie-Lackawanna ferryboats failed to operate on the Hudson River yesterday morning after about 20 ferry engineers had called in "sick."

Plans were filed yesterday with the Department of Buildings for a $13.7 million 42-story office building to be erected on the site of the Park Lane Hotel at 299 Park Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets.

LONDON, May 24 -- Thousands of British boxing fans are planning to forgo the better part of a night's sleep this week to watch a live telecast of the world heavyweight title fight between Cassius Clay and Sonny Liston.

The Library and Museum of the Performing Arts will open at Lincoln Center by early October, the New York Public Library announced yesterday. To meet the needs of students and scholars, the library's reference collections will open earlier, in mid-July.
TOKYO, May 24 (AP) -- Fire raged out of control aboard the Norwegian oil tanker Heimvard today despite efforts to put out the blaze.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department predicts that shipments through the St. Lawrence Seaway this year will exceed the record tonnage of 1964.

COPENHAGEN, May 24 -- The first major novelty of the 16th Annual Danish Ballet Festival taking place here is a new production of the full-length "Swan Lake," the first ever to be attempted by the Royal Danish Ballet.
DENVER, May 24 (UPI) -- A New Jersey mortgage banker predicted today that the Federal Housing Administration would eventually offer 100 per cent loans to home buyers.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Federal District Judge Julius J. Hoffman rejected contentions today that the House Committee on Un-American Activities exercised "raw power." He refused to enjoin hearings by the committee and dismissed a suit challenging its constitutionality.

TOKYO, Tuesday May 25 (AP) -- Communist China announced today that all outward marks of distinction between officers and men and between one grade and another would be abolished in its armed forces beginning June 1.
VIENNA, May 24 -- Ministerial talks between the European Common Market and the European Free Trade Association were proposed today by a conference of prime ministers of the E.F.T.A.'s members.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- With fewer than 60 of its 435 members present, the House of Representatives began debate today on the foreign aid authorization.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 24 -- Work on widening the Cross County Parkway was resumed without incident today.

A written driver's test administered to 2,000 drivers in New York, Philadelphia, Chicago and Los Angeles by the Columbia Broadcasting System showed last night that the average driver can only be rated as fair.
BONN, May 24 -- There will be no meeting of the foreign ministers or Government chiefs of the Common Market this summer to chart further steps toward European union.

OTTAWA, May 24 (Canadian Press) -- Trade Minister Mitchell Sharp confirmed today that Canada had sold wheat "in the order of 50 million bushels" to Communist China in recent negotiations in Hong Kong.
Apparently impressed with the new image Eastern Airlines has gotten for itself, United Air Lines now wants one, too.
The United States Internal Revenue Service is initiating a study of Federal regulations, particularly those involving standards of identity and labeling requirements, covering distilled spirits.

DETROIT, May 24 (AP) -- United States automobile makers registered their fifth successive 200,000-plus production mark last week and hoped to come close to that target again this week before the Memorial Day weekend starts.
MILWAUKEE, May 24 (AP) -- A State Assemblyman and 10 other demonstrators were arrested today when they blocked school buses transferring Negro children to another district.

A nationwide system of tuition-free higher education, with the Federal Government and the institutions sharing the cost evenly, was proposed yesterday by Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College.
Steel producrion in the United States climbed 1.5 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The White House issued a report today contending that it had saved $217 million in the operations of nondefense agencies of Government in the first quarter of this year.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The House Ways and Means Committee reported out the $4.8 billion excise tax cut bill today. The measure is expected to come before the House for debate and approval next week.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 24 -- The Vietcong today cut the strategic coastal railroad at six points between Danang and Hue in the northern part of the country.
TEL AVIV, May 24 -- Deputy Premier Abba Eban predicted tonight that Arab voices calling for peace between the Arabs and Israel were "likely to grow in strength and become more widespread."

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- President Johnson's plan for reorganization of the Customs Bureau was assured of becoming effective today when the Senate rejected a resolution of disapproval and the House adjourned without acting.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Justice Department announced today that it had reached an agreement with the El Paso Natural Gas Company that would require the concern to divest itself of properties of the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation, which it acquired in 1957.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) -- Representative Charles S. Joelson, Democrat of New Jersey, said today that the Defense Department was no longer selling serviceable small arms to the public.
The Meredith Publishing Company has announced the election of a new chairman, a new president and two new directors.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- President Johnson said today it gave him "great personal pleasure" to reappoint 14 trustees of the Eleanor Roosevelt Memorial Foundation and name a new one, Mrs. Robert E. Kintner.
