WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A panel of scientists today urged a far-reaching birth-control program to extend the "basic human right" of family planning to all in the United States.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced last night it had reached a "preliminary understanding" to acquire four divisions of Universal Controls, Inc., for $66 million.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 24 -- Howard P. Jones, who is known as President Sukarno's favorite ambassador, today ended seven years of service in Indonesia, with relations between Jakarta and Washington at their lowest since Mr. Jones's arrival in 1958.

CANNES, France, May 24 -- Italy's entry in the Cannes festival sweepstakes -- Francesco Rosi's "Moment of Truth" -- was seen this evening. Scattered boos reproved its cruelest and bloodiest scenes, but the applause that arose at its conclusion was widespread.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Treasury-bill rate slipped back again today from last week's rate, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Two Justices of the Supreme Court urged more states today to set up procedures under which prisoners could obtain review of pleas that their Federal constitutional rights had been violated in state criminal proceedings.
A proxy battle for control of the Paramount Pictures Corporation apparently was averted late last night, just a week in advance of the company's annual meeting, which is set for next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the filing of a Federal Trade Commission antitrust action suspends the running of the four-year statute of limitations on private antitrust suits.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Johnson's proposed military pay rise -- part of the general Federal pay increase he recommended May 12 -- is under heavy fire among professional military men and in Congress.
For the first time in Wall Street history, two men known as Gus simultaneously began their week yesterday as vice chairmen of the governing bodies at the two leading stock exchanges.
BERGENFIELD, N.J., May 24 -- Twenty residents here and in neighboring Dumont, mostly housewives, called upon the "conscience" of their communities today to end discrimination in housing.
ROME, May 24 -- John J. Gilhooley, New York Transit Commissioner, withheld a declaration today as to whether he would run with Representative Lindsay in the city elections.

NOSTALGIA frequently colors and clouds memories of people, places, events and even foods enjoyed. Who has not heard. "Mother's apple pie tasted better"? In a case where there is no local product, memories tend to get out of hand.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Supreme Court held unconstitutional today a Federal law requiring persons to whom "Communist political propaganda" from abroad is addressed to make a special request to the Post Office to deliver it.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 (UPI) -- Julian Javier's three hits, including a triple, led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight. The victory was the Cards' seventh in a row and cut the Dodgers' National League lead to one Cincinnati.

Trans World Airlines announced an agreement yesterday with San Francisco and Oakland Helicopter Airlines to establish scheduled helicopter service between San Jose and Palo Alto, Calif., and the T.W.A. terminal at San Francisco International Airport.
MOSCOW, May 24 -- The latest American styles in men's apparel were demonstrated today before several hundred representatives of the Soviet clothing industry at Moscow's Sovetskaya Hotel.
The president of the corporation that built Howard Park General Hospital in Howard Beach, Queens, was arrested yesterday on charges of failing to report his concern's financial dealings.

DETROIT, May 24 -- Cyrus S. Eaton said today that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin told him last week that the Soviet Union was adjusting its differences with Communist China and would "pool our forces with China" to strike at United States forces in Vietnam unless the United States altered its policy there.
ALBANY, May 24 -- Governor Rockefeller's program for clamping down on loan sharks moved halfway through the Legislature today.

The Transit Authority's plan for two-way buses on Park Avenue should be killed at City Hall before any more time is wasted on it. The motive -- to recoup any losses in fares suffered by the authority when Fifth and Madison Avenues are converted to one-way traffic movement next March -- provides no adequate justification for invading one of the few beautiful thoroughfares left in New York.

Under the auspices of the City University and the Institute of Yiddish Lexicology, a monumental dictionary of the Yiddish language has been launched, one that will run to an expected ten volumes. A project of such intellectual dimensions deserves warm support but the situation is not without its ironies.
TRENTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Appellate Division of Superior court today ordered a runoff election for mayor of Hoboken next month.

Representative John V. Lindsay's mayoral campaign team is setting up organizations in each of the city's Assembly districts, to the chagrin of some of the Republican reg ulars. The Lindsay organization seeks to duplicate the entire Republican organization in the city, Robert Price, the Congressman's campaign manager, said yesterday.

LONDON, May 24 -- United States bombings in North Vietnam have had a drastic effect on the daily living habits of the civilian population in the capital city of Hanoi, according to a dispatch printed today in The Daily Mail.

BERLIN, May 24 (AP) -- The commander of a United States Army train bound from West Berlin to West Germany was prevented by a Soviet soldier at gunpoint from checking his train on May 1, an Army spokesman said today.

Boxholders for the 1965 season at the Monmouth Race Track in Oceanport, N.J., have been announced by the Monmouth Park Jockey Club, whose board chairman and president is Amory L. Haskell. The 20th year of racing at the track will begin June 4.
Operators of sightseeing buses promised yesterday to bypass the area around Bleecker and Macdougal Streets in Greenwich Village.
THERE's so much outdoor recreation available these days, the sportsman might have trouble deciding where to begin.

WHITE PLAINS, May 24 -- This city of 51,000 residents has been so cooperative in trying to conserve the water it draws from New York City's reservoirs that brown water came from the faucets today and officials had to change plans.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 24 (UPI) -- Howard Boyd, chairman of El Paso, and H.F. Steen, president, agreed with the Justice Department that the new company would be much stronger than the original Pacific Northwest Pipeline Company.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 24 -- If tonight's first event at Roosevelt Raceway had been part of a Hollywood scenario, the script would have called for Roosevelt Baby to break stride at the start, recover and proceed to win. After all, Roosevelt Baby was foaled on the Raceway grounds on Mother's day, May 13, 1962.

It is the height of folly for a public official to criticize the news media. He is in the position of a duelist without a gun; his views can reach the public only if and to the extent the media allow, whereas they can publicly castigate him to whatever extent their conscience permits.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the constitutionality of a 105-year-old Pennsylvania law allowing juries to assess costs against defendants acquitted in misdemeanor trials.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- As the Organization of American States concluded a session recently, a Latin American wearily closed his briefcase and said: "This has been the Waterloo for the O.A.S."
ROBBINS, Tenn., May 24 (AP) -- An explosion, presumably caused by gas, ripped through an East Tennessee mountainside coal mine today and apparently killed the five men working in it.
Opposition to the conversion of Fifth and Madison Avenues to one-way traffic and to a Park Avenue bus route gained momentum yesterday.
MACY'S entered phase two last weekend of a campaign to get to teen-agers where they live by introducing them to decorating concepts and furnishings for the home.

KONTUM, South Vietnam, May 24 -- More than 2,200 South Vietnamese Government troops began an urgent offensive today to disrupt the Vietcong build-up in this vulnerable area of central Vietnam.

OMAHA, Neb., May 24 (UPI)The Rev. Edward A. Conway, director of Creighton University's Center for Peace Research and long a campaigner for international cooperation in arms control, died today at Omaha Hospital. His age was 63.
PARIS, May 24 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York rejected today President de Gaulle's charge that the United States has established hegemony over the Western alliance.
The Greater New York Fund's 425 hospital, health and welfare agencies mean better health for those who work and live in the metropolitan area.

The Maritime Administration announced yesterday the award of a $7.3 million contract to Aerojet-General Shipyards of Jacksonville, Fla., for the construction of two hydrographic ships for the Coast and Geodetic Survey.

Dr. Donald F. Hornig, special assistant to President Johnson for science and technology, told computer experts from more than 50 countries yesterday that their favorite device would "transform the world in which we live."
A payroll tax was recommended yesterday by a major businessmen's group as preferable to Mayor Wagner's borrowing plan to balance the city's new expense budget.
ALBANY, May 24 -- The Assembly approved tonight a strengthened code of ethics for the Legislature.

LONDON, May 24 -- International economists, bankers and businessmen got together at a seminar here today to discuss the French economic striking force and what many of them described as the urgent need for international monetary reform.

MOSCOW, May 24 -- The great diversity of advanced design for American homes and public buildings is subpect of a United States architecture show that opened a five-month Soviet tour today in Leningrad.

The first and basic necessity in the Dominican crisis has been achieved. A de facto cease-fire is in effect. The next step is to get an agreement on a coalition government that will not shut either contending party out of the possibility of defending the interests for which it was fighting.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- President Johnson told Congress today that while men will one day control the weather, "it would be misleading to suggest that such a day is near now."
The Gulf Sulphur Corporation said yesterday that there were "good indications" that it had discovered an additional sulphur deposit on its Mexican concession.
PARIS, May 24 (AP) -- Nancy Richey, the United States' No. 1 woman player, moved into the quarter-finals of the French tennis championships today with another of her methodical victories.
MOSCOW, May 24 -- A new official census of Communist party membership in the Soviet Union shows a significant increase in the last three years of young adult members and those with higher education.

SALT LAKE CITY, May 24 (AP) -- The El Paso Gas accord with the Justice Department on how El Paso should divest itself of its Pacific Northwest Pipeline unit was filed here today in the form of decree of divestiture, with the clerk of the Federal District Court.
LEWISTON, Me., May 24 -- In this Down East neck of the woods, motorists don't "pork the core," as in some areas of New York and New Jersey. They "pahk the cah," as in Boston.

WHITE PLAINS, May 24 -- Mohawk Airlines, a regional carrier that started 20 years ago last month with three-passenger Fairchild F-24's, proudly displayed its first jetliner today -- a 69-passenger BAC-111 made by the British Aircraft Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- For almost a fortnight now President Johnson has retreated into what, for him, is comparative silence. Instead of constantly appearing in person on the first pages of newspapers and video screens, he has been absent from both on most of the days and nights in this period, in sharp contrast with the weeks previous when its exposure was almost total and incessant.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Alan S. Boyd, President Johnson's nominee for Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, testified today that private industry could not afford the whole $2 billion risk of developing a supersonic commercial transport plane.
LONDON, May 24 -- The British Government announced today plans for the conversion of weights and measures to the metric system over the next 10 years.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The "Portrait of the Artist's Son Titus" by Rembrandt, which was purchased last March 19 for $2,234,000, will have its first public showing in this country at the National Gallery of Art, beginning Friday at 3 P.M.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- A spokesman said today the State Department had no information from other sources along the lines of a prediction by Cyrus S. Eaton, the financier and industrialist, that the United States was threatened by nuclear war with Communist China and the Soviet Union in a week to four weeks unless it stopped bombing North Vietnam.

OTTAWA, May 25 (Canadian Press) -- Canada has sold China 58.7 million more bushels of wheat, Trade Minister Mitchell Sharp announced in the Commons yesterday.

Mrs. Alice Kohn Pollitzer, still sprightly and still active in seven benevolent, civic and political organizations, was honored at a dinner last night to mark her 95th birthday.

An air of fantastic make-believe hangs over the budget-making process at City Hall this year. The public hearings that conclude today are dealing with a financial plan so devoid of responsibility that it could not escape being described as shocking. Mayor Wagner himself was brazenly candid when, in his budget message, he said: "The best tax is no tax. A good loan is better than a bad tax.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Johnson announced today that he would send bills to Congress tomorrow to eliminate most junkyards and billboards from the nation's major highways.
Ammonia fumes spread in Central Park around noon yesterday after escaping from an ice-making unit of the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink during routine maintenance work.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- After 24 days of debate, the Senate invoked closure on the voting rights bill today and moved quickly toward final passage.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday his decision to begin construction of the $110 million Lower Manhattan Expressway "as quickly as possible." He set a target date for completion in September, 1971.

Most prices eased yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

The one-day strike of marine engineers on Hudson ferryboats operated by two New Jersey commuter railroads ended shortly before noon yesterday.

Amid age-old Russian Orthodox ritual, mourners paid final respects yesterday to Metropolitan Anastassy, former president of the Synod of the Russian Orthodox Church outside Russia, at the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign.

WARSAW, May 25 -- Wladyshaw Gomulka, the First Secretary of the Communist party, delivered a pre-election speech at a factory today and then answered questions.

A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy who had given the police information that sent two youths to jail for a fatal stabbing was arrested early yesterday and charged with the same crime. The two other youths were released.

Va.

Universal Controls, Inc., moved up yesterday to the third most active issue on the American Stock Exchange on the strength of a possible take-over of four of its divisions by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

Belgium's general election has proved to be a species of political disaster. The old coalition of Social Christians and Socialists lost so heavily that it is now one seat short of a two-thirds majority in the Chamber of Representatives. Without such a majority the Constitution, which has been in force unchanged since independence in 1830, cannot be altered. The hopes of at least arresting the widening breach between Walloons and Flemings have been dashed.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Al Kaline rapped two triples and a single, leading the Detroit Tigers to a 7-5 triumph over the Chicago White Sox tonight. The loss was the fifth in six games for the Sox.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- President Johnson said today, after signing an authorization bill for a new embassy in Saigon, that "we will not desert or fail" South Vietnam.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 25 (AP) -- A Saturn I, the world's most powerful rocket, hurled the Pegasus 2 satellite into orbit early today to measure potentially dangerout meteroids.
Bargain hunters moved into the stock market yesterday and bid spiritedly for stocks that had taken a three-day beating.
The Philips Incandescent Lamp Works (N.V. Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken reported yesterday its first decline in earnings in recent years.

ALBANY, May 25 -- Governor Rockefeller, acting on a pledge made at the start of the legislative session, sent to the Legislature today a bill that would provide state funds for the building of mental health centers.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The Senate Labor Committee approved today President Johnson's nominations of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and four others to serve on the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The American Negro's fight for legal equality is in its closing phase, and his push to the left will soon begin. With the passage of the voting rights bill most of the artificial legal barriers will be down, but the major barriers to economic and social equality will remain.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that "tactical nuclear weapons will remain deployed with front-line troops."
SOONER or later every trout fisherman finds a heavy fish feeding in a pool. The problem is how to take it.

BAY SHORE, L.I., May 25 -- Mrs. Alexander Cushing and Mrs. Gordon McGrath teamed to score a 33, 41 -- 79 today and win low gross in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's Pinehurst tournament. The contest was held at the Southward Ho Country Club, a 5,995-yard, par 35, 37 -- 72 layout.
BRUSSELS, May 25 -- One reason for Italy's enthusiastic support of European economic integration, as made clear today by the European Investment Bank, has been money.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor asked Congress today to provide $90 million for a three-year research program in improved ground transportation vehicles, including a 150-mile-an-hour train for the Northeast.
COLOGNE, Germany, May 25 -- Despite rain and chill winds, Germany's third-largest city gave Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip a cordial welcome this morning.

LONDON, May 26 (Reuters) -- European television viewers of the world heavyweight championship bout at Lewiston, Me., last night were treated to clear if brief reception early today by the Early Bird satellite.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Seventeen demonstrators protesting a hearing of the House Un-American Activities Committee here today were arrested. Most of them had tried to block a police wagon that was taking away a demonstrator arrested earlier.

MT. VERNON, N.Y., May 25 -- Picketing of the Cross County Parkway reconstruction job here was resumed today by residents who declared a hoax had been perpetrated to make them believe trees were to be saved.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- George Champion, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, told the Illinois Bankers Association today that there was a "facade of friendliness" between Government and business, and he saw a dangerous trend toward "government-by-guideline."
For its brief run, the Maine encore to Miami Beach's 1964 first showing of The Beauty (Cassius Clay) and The Beast (Sonny Liston) was even a bigger box office hit on Broadway.

Thank you for publicizing in the news article appearing May 19, the long-delayed unveiling of Anna Hyatt Huntington's fine statue of Jose Marti, Cuba's great liberator-author. The Cuban who placed the rose at the base of the statue may not have given his name, but the symbolism of his act is immediately apparent to all who know Marti's writings.
The British pound fell sharply yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange market here.
BONN, May 25 -- Hans Deutsch, an Austrian lawyer under arrest here since last year, was set free today after he had paid record bail of $4 million.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May 25 -- A new Jewish High Holy Day's prayer book that will include major liturgical changes in English and will incorporate Yiddish poetry and references to contemporary events will be issued soon by the Conservative Judaism Movement.

EMMANULE KHANH, who at 27 is already the doyenne of the French Ye-Ye designers, has had babies on her mind this last year. Seven months ago, she produced Othello Khanh -- "huge and happy" -- and last month she introduced baby-toe shoes to go with her young, but far from childish, designs.
A national survey of manufacturing and business companies shows a "considerable gap" between policies favorable to Negro employment and actual practice.
WASHINGTON May 25 -- Consumer intentions to buy automobiles and large appliances last month were above April, 1964 the Department of Commerce reported today.

LONDON, May 25 -- Dr. Herzog, 44 years old, was born in Dublin, where his father, Dr. Isaac Herzog, was Chief Rabbi of Ireland. In 1935 he went to Palestine when his father was appointed Chief Rabbi there.
The Canada Cup golf matches will be played this year at the Club de Campo, Madrid, on Sept. 30 to Oct. 3, the International Golf Association said yesterday.

After 51 months of expansion the impression is growing that Washington has developed a formula for growth that is recession-free and inflation-proof. But some econo mists think that the economy is developing some dangerous symptoms and question whether the Johnson Administration will be able to come up with a cure.

J.P. Stevens Co., one of the nation's largest textile manufacturers, is entering the women's hosiery business. Its new hosiery division will be headed by Robert J. Froe ber, who comes to the company from the Madison Throwing Company and was formerly executive vice president of Hanes Hosiery Mills.

A section of Cleveland's downtown area is to be jointly utilized by that city's newly-formed university and the Cleveland Play House's theater complex. The target date to complete the dual development is the fall of 1968.
A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the recently redrawn Assembly district lines must apply to party leaders as well as to legislators in the election this fall.

LOS ANGELES, May 25 (UPI) -- Mrs. Rosalind Wyman, a 12-year City Council member, conceded defeat tonight in her bid for re-election, giving Mayor Samuel W. Yorty one of his biggest political triumphs.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Ed Blinkman drove in three runs with a single and double and Frank Howard hit a two-run homer to lead the Washington Senators to a 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles and a sweep of their doubleheader tonight.

Real Estate Commissioner Frank L. Lazarus announced yesterday 14 appointments to one-year terms on the Real Estate Advisory Commission. A fifteenth member of the commission, which advises the Real Estate Commissioner on problems affecting the department, will be named soon.

PITTSBURGH, May 25 (UPI) -- Andre Rodgers lined a single to right field in the 12th inning scoring Donn Clendenon from second base tonight to give the last-place Pittsburgh Pirates their fifth straight victory, 7-6, over the Chicago Cubs.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Johnson Administration asked Congress today for a $5 billion increase in the national debt limit, from $324 to $329 billion.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 25 (Reuters) -- Striking students will return to their classrooms tomorrow, their leaders said today.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 25 -- Unbeaten Bret Hanover, the 3 year-old who needs a favorable post position less than the Mets need another defeat, this morning drew the No. 2 slot for Friday night's Commodore Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
A major exhibition of treasures of Mexican art was opened last night at the World's Fair by Mrs. Guadalupe Borja de Diaz, wife of the President of Mexico.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 25 (AP) -- The administration of Gov. Edward T. Breathitt today won seven of the 10 Senate districts in which it was challenged by Lieut. Gov. Harry Lee Water-field in the Democratic primary.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A foreign aid authorization of $3,367,000,000 was approved by the House of Representatives today after the most one-sided contest on the sometimes controversial legislation since Marshall Plan days.

Travel agents mounted an all-out "war" yesterday to avert a 40 per cent cut in commission on their sale of airline tickets for point-to-point flights within the United States. Such sales account for 70 per cent of their income.
PEKING, May 25 -- Communist China is stripping its generals and other officers of their rank and insignia in a move to strengthen Communist control over the People's Liberation Army.

THE least conspicuous of all Dominican laeders and politicians in the current civil war is at the center of a controversy over how to end the crisis in the Dominican Republic. He is Silvestre Antonio Guzman, a short, retiring man of 54, whom a great many Dominicans -- and impor tant United States official quarters -- regard as a possible head of a new government suitable to both Do minican factions.
MOSCOW, May 25 -The Soviet Union published today a new history of the six-month Battle of Stalingrad, generally regarded as the turning point of World War II.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which has been picketing Girard College daily since May 1, attacked the tax-exempt status of the institution today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, evoked today a homely figure out of the American past -- the village blacksmith -- in arguing for repeal of Section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Act.

PARIS, May 25 -- Although Frenchwomen normally purchase 16 million dresses, 7.4 million brassieres, 3 million suits and 500,000 pairs of blue jeans a year, Frenchmen still spend more money on their wardrobes.

The world premiere of the Joseph Wheeler reconstruction of Mahler's Tenth Symphony will be given by the Caecilian Symphony, Arthur Bloom, conductor, at the High School of Art and Design tonight at 8:30.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 25 -- In the headquarters here of the II Corps, commanders are deciding who will be saved first in the area, which is expected to be the scene of a Vietcong offensive in June or July. The United States advisers think the Communist forces may try to hit several posts and cities at once.

TUNIS, May 25 -- President Habib Bourguiba voiced gratitude today for the "encouraging refusal" of his fellow-North African Arab leaders to "side with Radio Cairo" in the feud between Tunisia and the United Arab Republic.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 -- The Soviet Union would be willing to help the United Nations out of its financial difficulties, but only on its own terms, Dr. Nikolai T. Fedorenko, its Permanent Representative, said today at a meeting of the Special Committee on Peace-Keeping.
ALBANY, May 25 -- The stringent code of legislative ethics passed by the Assembly last night was held up at least for 24 hours by the Senate Finance Committee today.
Ticket applications are being accepted for the Jaycee Football Classic, a benefit game between the New York Giants and the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League.
A $35 million offering of debentures of the Family Finance Corporation is expected to be made today at a yield of slightly less than 4.84 per cent.
The City's Art Commission has given final approval to plans for a privately financed $500,000 addition to Gracie Mansion, the Mayor's official residence.

The Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia is one of 20 Orthodox bodies in the United States listed in the "Yearbook of American Churches." In all, these churches have nearly three million of the 100 million Orthodox Christians in the world.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- The New York Mets were routed by the Philadelphia Phillies, 10 -- 3, tonight as the Phils pounded five Met pitchers for 18 hits.
LEWISTON, Me., May 25 -- As always seems to happen in the strange wonderland inhabited by Cassius Marcellus Clay things keep getting curiouser and curiouser.
The annual Four Freedoms Award, for service to the ideals of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, was presented posthumously last night to President Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Treasury auctioned $1 billion in one-year bills today at an average discount rate of 3.954 per cent.

NEWTON, Mass., May 25 (AP) -- Two teams of women golfers from greater Boston, New York and Philadelphia wound up with similar 38, 36 -- 74 scores today in the sweepstakes tune-up for the Griscomb Cup tournament at Brae Burn Country Club.
NORFOLK, Va., May 25 (AP) -- Navy personnel up to the rank of captain are forced to moonlight "just to make ends meet," according to Rear Adm. John M. Alford.
LONDON, May 25 -- The Labor Government reversed its field today and dropped a proposal to use the criminal law against racial discrimination in places of public accomodation.

PARIS, May 25 -- A plot to kill President de Gaulle during his trip to western France last week was thwarted by the arrest of a band of right-wing extremists who failed in a similar attempt last year, the Ministry of the Interior announced today.

RYE, N.Y., May 25 -- Mrs. O. Waring Mellick and Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill won the annual 36-hole four-ball, best-ball tournament of the Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association with 150 today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 -- Cuba's representative, Fernando Alvarez Tabio, joined the Soviet delegate today in a series of attacks on the United States over action taken in the Dominican crisis.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 25 -- A provisional cease-fire agreement concluded just before dawn between the military junta and striking tin miners and factory workers appeared extremely shaky today. Both sides had grave doubts that it would last -- at least on its present terms.

James E. Burke has been elected a director of Johnson Johnson, the drug products manufacturer, and a member of its executive committee, the company announced yesterday. He will serve as general manager of the domestic operating division of Johnson Johnson.

ONE of the wonderful things about books is their variety. It is never compulsory for an adult to read a book he dislikes, although vanity and status-seeking may seduce him into claiming to have read books he has not read -- anything from "Hamlet" to "Dog Years" by Gunter Grass.
PARAMUS, N.J., May 25 -- Fourteen high school seniors were injured tonight when a set of overhead stage lights collapsed and fell on a choral group performing at Paramus High School.

THE "Bell Telephone Hour" could not lose last night. It offered an hour's tribute to Cole Porter on the National Broadcasting Company network, and to heat a generous sampling of the composer's works was bound to have its share of rewards.

Detective Raymond Wood, the police undercover agent who is credited with thwarting a plot to bomb national shrines and stage a nationwide uprising, denied yesterday that he had been advised by his superiors and Federal agents to doctor his reports of clandestine meetings of the alleged plotters.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Treasury auctioned $1 billion in one-year bills today at an average discount rate of 3.954 per cent.

NEWTON, Mass., May 25 (AP) -- Two teams of women golfers from greater Boston, New York and Philadelphia wound up with similar 38, 36 -- 74 scores today in the sweepstakes tune-up for the Griscomb Cup tournament at Brae Burn Country Club.
NORFOLK, Va., May 25 (AP) -- Navy personnel up to the rank of captain are forced to moonlight "just to make ends meet," according to Rear Adm. John M. Alford.
LONDON, May 25 -- The Labor Government reversed its field today and dropped a proposal to use the criminal law against racial discrimination in places of public accomodation.

Three young real estate men have organized a new Long Island concern that will specialize in industrial and commercial property. The name of the company is Penguin Realty. It has offices at 125 Willis Avenue in Roslyn Heights.
Reversing the pattern of the last six days, stock prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday in quiet trading.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- At least six Latin American foreign ministers will come here Thursday to review the Dominican crisis and probably to discuss the broader question of Communist subversion in the Western Hemisphere.

LEWISTON, Me., May 25 -- No sooner had it been announced a few weeks ago that Sonny Liston would complete his training chores at nearby Poland Spring for tonight's heavyweight championship fight with Cassius Clay than local historians began thumbing through the archives. One researcher produced the information that Gene Tunney had trained there after breaking his hand against Harry Greb in their first fight.
DALLAS, May 25 (UPI) -- The judge who presided at Jack L. Ruby's murder trial said today he doubted that Ruby would die in the electric chair for murdering Lee Harvey Oswald.
Twenty-two issues of state and local government bonds totaling about $104 million were sold at competitive bidding yesterday in one of the most active underwriting days in weeks.
ALBANY, May 25 -- The Democratic legislative leadership began a new effort today to block an election this fall.
Chief Inspector Lawrence J. McKearney, the city's "top cop" in uniform, announced yesterday that he had applied for retirement.
ALBANY, May 25 -- A bill that would authorize pari-mutuel betting on quarter-horse racing at up to eight new tracks in the state was approved by the Senate today and sent to the Assembly.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Legislation to provide up to $21 million a year in Federal subsidies to the arts and humanities won committee approval today and was sent to the Senate.

The New York Society of Security Analysts announced yesterday the election of Todd G. Alexander as president. Mr. Alexander, who is 49 years old, is a partner of Auchincloss, Parker and Redpath, members of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The failure of negotiations for a provisional Dominican government have left the Johnson Administration hoping for a continued cease-fire and a more prominent mediation role by the Organization of American States.
MONTREAL, May 25 -- The authorities are ready to clamp down on the activities of extremist separatists. Quebec's Justice Minister Claude Wasner, warned today.
WASHINGTON, May (AP) -- A Senate Banking subcommittee was urged today by a group of businessmen to condemn as national policy an Arab boycott against companies doing business with Israel:

Jerry Pittman, a newcomer to the metropolitan area's professional ranks, led the local preliminary qualifying trials for the United States Open golf championship yesterday. The 28-year-old player from Tulsa, Okla., an instructor since May 1 at the Westchester Country Club, Harrison, N.Y., scored 139 for 36 holes.
SCARSDALE, May 25 -- It took a song writer, Frank Loesser, to put this wealthy village's name to literary use, in the lyrics of "Guys and Dolls," whose hero chides his girl:
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 25 -- Miguel Angel Capriles, a newspaper publisher, and 12 others arrested by the Government April 9, were ordered released tonight.
Municipal and Government bond dealers reported a pick-up in sales yesterday, but corporate bond underwriters continued to experience slow going.
TEL AVIV, May 25 -- Former Premier David Ben-Gurion said today that there was a need to revitalize the covenant of the Bible in which a united Jewish people would serve as "a light to other nations."
PARIS, May 25 (AP) -- Roy Emerson and Tony Roche used their power games today to give Australia three of the four men's singles semi-final berths in the French tennis tournament.

BOSTON, May 25 (UPI) -- Ted Whitfield, the undefeated New England welterweight champion, scored his 14th career victory tonight by gaining a unanimous 10-round decision over Gaspar Ortega in a bout at Boston Garden that preceded the closed-circuit telecast of the Cassius Clay-Sonny Liston fight.
ST. LOUIS, May 25 (UPI) -- Ken Venturi put in a heavy practice session today at the Bellerive Country Club, where he will defend his United States Open championship next month.

In the largest sale outside the housing authority field yesterday, the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power awarded $15 million of water revenue bonds to a syndicate managed by the First Boston Corporation and Drexel Co.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- A new name on an old street is hardly a guarantee of acceptance in this staid resort community. But Jeremiah on Job's Lane is bound to charm summer residents away from their well-manicured lawns and out of their swimming pools long enough for it to achieve success.
The Manhattan Consort's program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night was just the sort of aural tonic to refresh the spirits after yesterday's steaming forestate of August.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Johnson snarled rush-hour traffic this evening when he made an impromptu tour of the historic Court of Claims building. He was reported to have come away "favorably impressed" with suggestions to turn the 106-year-old building into an art gallery.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- A 10-year-old question of an airline's liability for the death or injury of a passenger on an international flight was revived today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Why do so many books fail to become best-sellers? To answer this question, which has puzzled publishers for centuries, a typical American book reader was mailed one book a week for 57 weeks and interviewed after the final mailing.

The New York Philharmonic, William Steinberg conducting, with Lois Marshall, soprano; Shirley Verrett, mezzo; Charles Bressler, tenor; Kenneth Smith, bass-baritone, and the American Concert Choir, will perform Bach's Mass in B minor in Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30.
Stocks generally decline on the day they go ex-dividend, but American Telephone and Telegraph proved a fairly dramatic exception yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers, disputing a view held in the Federal Reserve Board and among private bankers, said today the present economic situation and outlook "removes any serious prospect of overheating of our economy in the next year."
Friends of the Claremont Neighborhood Centers will be able to view the Manhattan skyline as they sip champagne during a Hudson River cruise on the evening of June 5.
HOUSTON, May 26 (AP) -- Jim Wynn drove in four runs with a homer, triple and single, pacing the Houston Astros to an 8-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26 -- South Vietnam's latest government crisis was further complicated today, and no early solution was in sight.
LONDON, May 26 -- The campaign to reform British criminal law affecting homosexual conduct ran at least temporarily aground today in the House of Commons.

A 64-year-old Rockland County judge used karate to fell a knife-wielding youth who tried to rob him last night, tile police said. The incident, they said, took place at 6:35 P.M. on Seventh Street between First and Second Avenues.

The operating companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group plan combined capital expenditures at a record of more than $1.3 billion this year, John Loudon, president of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, told members of the New York Society of Security Analysts last night.

A proposed revenue-pooling agreement covering commercial cargoes moving between Brazilian ports and ports on the United States Atlantic Coast was disapproved by the Federal Maritime Commission yesterday.
LONDON, May 26 -- The House of Commons today wrote a five-year limit into the pending bill to abolish the death penalty.
The Equity Corporation, a closed-end, non-diversified investment company, suspended its president and named two new directors yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 26 (UPI) -- Luis Tiant limited the Chicago White Sox to five singles tonight while his Cleveland Indian teammates bunched four of their 12 hits after two out in the seventh inning to score all their runs in a 3-1 victory.

MOSCOW, May 26 -- Soviet officials are privately expressing confidence that the antiaircraft defenses around Hanoi will soon be sufficient to deter-United States air attacks, reliable sources said today.

CAIRO, May 26 -- An Arab League premiers conference opened here today in at atmosphere of unease and tension. The divergence of views found expression in argument over the choice of date and place for the next conference of Arab heads of state.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The World Bank announced today the approval of its first loan bearing an interest cost higher than its standard 5 1/2 per cent rate. The bank said it would lend the equivalent of $75 million to Japan to assist in the financing of the last section of a major toll express highway.
BONN, May 26 -- The Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament, adopted today a last-minute amendment liberalizing the laws on compensation payments for victims of war and Nazi persecution.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 26 -- Six hundred United States marines flew by helicopter today to the carrier Boxer off Santo Domingo.
LONDON, May 26 -- Peers, like commoners, are migrating from central London. Dukes are moving faster than earls, marquesses or viscounts, but the trend is unmistakable.
President and Mrs. Johnson are planning the most extensive arts festival ever held in the White House.
In the isolated mountain communities of Albania the breach of a man's word is regarded as one of the most serious of offenses -- an offense that demands revenge.
DURING a discussion on German shepherds in Germany, Matthias Stappen of Cologne said that the breed's parent club there had 40,000 members.

In the long agony that the Dominican nation faces, any move toward sanity and peace deserves applause. The United States has withdrawn 600 of the 23,000 troops sent into the country. With more Brazilian soldiers en route to join what is now called the Inter-American Force, as many as 1,700 American soldiers may be sent out of Santo Domingo by the end of the week.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a $328 billion limit on the national debt for the fiscal year 1966, which starts July 1.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Justice Department has quietly arranged for a private attorney to defend its star undercover agent in the Ku Klux Klan in a suit that is being brought against him by the Klan's chief lawyer, Matt H. Murphy Jr. of Birmingham, Ala.
BALTIMORE, May 26 (UPI) -- Jim Gentile's 475-foot homer in the fifth inning snapped a 3-3 tie tonight and the Kansas City Athletics went on to a 6-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
Civil rights leaders here began a joint campaign yesterday for the establishment of an independent civilian board with Negro and Puerto Rican members to review charges of police brutality.

The American Stock Exchange did a turnabout yesterday after Tuesday's show of strength and prices fell in active trading. The market opened strong but then weakened gradually. Most declines were less than a point.
Directors of the Celanese Corporation of America voted here yesterday to raise the company's quarterly dividend to 50 cents a common share from 45 cents in preceding quarters.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 26 -- The board of governors of the American Bar Association criticized today a tendency toward "proliferation of judicial circuits" and ordered a study of alternate means of coping with court congestion.
ALTHOUGH bluefish are beginning to show along the New Jersey-New York coastline, the chances are that the fishing for them is better to the south in Chesapeake Bay.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- The poor of Philadelphia's slums elected 144 of their impoverished neighbors today to represent them in initiating and directing the city's $4 million antipoverty program.

POLAND SPRING, Me., May 26 -- Ten hours earlier, Jersey Joe Walcott had stood bewildered in the center of the ring at the Central Maine Youth Center in nearby Lewiston with his hands on his hips and a "what can I do?" look on his face.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- House members agreed today that further research was needed into the structure of cows, the sterilization of fruit flies and the love life of the honey bee.
Superman arrived in style yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange. National Periodical Publications Inc., was listed for trading on the Big Board and it finished the session at 22 1/8.

THE hot, humid, plain-looking auditorium of the High School of Art and Design was the scene last night of an unlikely event, the world premiere of Gustav Mahler's Symphony No. 10 in the realization by Joseph H. Wheeler.

The strong growth rate of discount retailing should continue indefinitely and a possibility exists that since discount chains "are doing so well, they may once again soon accelerate their expansion," a leading retailer declared here yesterday.
A Bronx painting contractor yesterday became the first person to be indicted in the investigation into reported rigged bidding by painting concerns to obtain contracts from the city.
There was novelty upon novelty last night for the New York music listener in the program of Argentine music at Philharmonic Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Labor Department signed a contract today for a $386,930 project to train 1,250 youths for jobs in Cleveland. Civil rights spokesmen immediately announced that they were calling off picketing of the Federal Building site in Cleveland.

SYOSSET, L.I. -- There is in this suburban community an outdoor roasting contrivance that is the very model of a major, modern charcoal grill. It is the property of Elisha Walker Jr., a financier whose interest in fanning the fires of an outdoor spit dates almost to the genesis of the charcoal revolution in this country.
ALBANY, May 26 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 266 of 519 persons who took the bar examinations on March 24 and 25 had passed.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26 -- United States Air Force and Navy planes attacked targets in North Vietnam again today on a virtual round-the-clock basis.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- A hearing here of a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities was thrown into turmoil today by demonstrators and by lawyers who demanded that the hearings be closed to the public to protect clients who were subpoenaed to testify.
The National Education Association offered yesterday to provide legal aid and job relocation assistance to Negro teachers who lost their jobs because of racial discrimination in the South.

The need for the Lower Manhattan Expressway is clear. But the Mayor's decision to make it an elevated highway is most disappointing, and even now, late as it is, cannot be accepted as final. To put this expressway underground would add 50 per cent, or even more, to its cost, but this initially more expensive method would be a long-term investment that would pay off many times over in the future of downtown New York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates used home runs by Del Crandall, Bill Mazeroski and Willie Stargell and a run-scoring bunt by Manny Mota tonight to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5 -- 3, and stretch their string of victories to six.
Robert Lyman Thayer's letter published May 7 concerning the logistic problems that threaten an American Dunkirk in Vietnam could not be more off target.
MIAMI, May 26 (UPI) -- The Haitian consul here was indicted by a Federal grand jury today in the latest of a long list of incidents involving the shipping of arms to the strife-torn Caribbean nation.
The Chase Manhattan Bank jumped into the capital market yesterday with the announcement that it plans to sell $250 million worth of 25-year-notes.
Major expansion plans were announced yesterday by several companies in the paper industry.
Deere Co., the producer of farm and industrial equipment, reported yesterday a decline in earnings for the fiscal half-year ended April 30, despite a 6 per cent rise in sales.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 -- Sargent Shriver, head of the Federal Government's antipoverty program, today asked "the establishment" -- including specifically social workers -- to move over and make room for the poor.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The entire strength of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations will be used to keep United States shipping from declining further as an industry, George Meany, president of the labor organization, said today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The House Armed Services Committee has acted to keep the Aerospace Corporation from going into any more real estate ventures without Congressional approval.

CAESAREA, Israel, May 26 -- A leader of the American Jewish community expressed concern tonight about the impact on Jewish and world opinion of the bitter political feud between Premier Levi Eshkol and former Premier David Ben-Gurion.

PARIS, May 26 -- Readers of the spring issue of The Vassar Alumnae Magazine may assume that the Marquise de Brantes -- called Sue when she was an English major at the college -- is now steeped in ancestral diamonds and new Diors.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- Five tornadoes ripped through the Chicago area today, causing extensive damage and some injuries. Tornadoes also struck other parts of Illinois. Indiana, Missouri, Wisconsin, Michigan, Iowa, Ohio and Oklahoma also were hit.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 26 -- Two Cornell University undergraduates were suspended last night for walking out of a disciplinary hearing on a student antiwar demonstration on May 17.

Earl Brown, loser in a bitter political battle over the post of Manhattan Borough President early this year, was named by Mayor Wagner yesterday to be chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights.

Joseph Ryba has been appointed director of the management department of Koeppel Mohr, 59 East 54th Street, and will be in charge of the company's residential and commercial properties in the city and in Westchester. He had been management director of Shapiro, Inc., which has holdings in Washington and Baltimore.

FALLSBURG, N.Y., May 26 -- Leaders of Orthodox Judaism's major institutions in the United States said today that the introduction of Reform and Conservative Judaism into Israel could serve only as a divisive influence.

NEW DELHI, May 26 -- India's Cow Servicing Society warned the Government today that it would begin a campaign of nonviolent civil disobedience unless the slaughter of cows was banned throughout the country before November.

HONG KONG, May 26 -- Communists in at least nine countries rebelled during the last year against the pro-Soviet alignment of their parties and founded new pro-Peking organizations, according to an official British survey.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 -- The California Supreme Court agreed today to grant a hearing on a dispute over the constitutionality of Proposition 14, a measure permiting racial and religious discrimination in housing.
The Broome Street area was simmering yesterday, not so much from the heat as from Mayor Wagner's decision to begin construction of the Lower Manhattan Expressway.
BALTIMORE, May 26 (AP) -- Presses at The Baltimore Sun, idle for 38 days after printers refused to cross picket lines of the striking American Newspaper Guild, began rolling again tonight.

MOSCOW, May 26 -- The official Soviet history journal gave Stalin credit today for having led the nation through World War II but declared him responsible for the lack of military preparedness at the time of the German attack.
The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday the election of Cornelius W. Owens as president and chairman of the executive committee.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Of all the legislation proposed by President Johnson for the attainment of what he calls "The Great Society," none has raised a more basic issue of political philosophy than Section 101 of the Administration's housing and urban development bill.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 26 (UPI) -- Dwight D. Eisenhower, whose eyes have seen much of war, relaxed in a swivel chair, toyed with one of his three desk pens and mused about ways of handling an international crisis.

All nine active judges of the United States Court of Appeals for this district will review seven cases involving a suspect's right to counsel and his right to remain silent in the face of police interrogation.

A plan for close collaboration between missionaries of two of the nation's largest Protestant denominations was announced here yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Alford Carleton, executive vice president of the Board for World Ministeries of the United Church of Christ.
There was an air of optimism bordering on jubilance at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday as the 73d general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute convened.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Following are excerpts from the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Dean Rusk's news conference today:
Those who suffer a decline in mental ability as they grow old tend to be of the lower social and economic levels, according to a specialist in the problems of aging.

THE Mexican Pavilion added a reason, and one of the best, for visiting the World's Fair when it opened its new art exhibit to the public yesterday. The show easily matches the star until now, the Spanish art exhibit, even though the less spacious Mexican quarters do not allow for quite the same discreet sumptuousness of installation.
How can poor people get the power to organize themselves into powerful groups within the framework of a democratic society and political system?
A communications satellite system capable of transmitting three television programs directly to any home in the United States and Canada was foreseen yesterday by David Sarnoff.

LONDON, May 26 -- London's postwar plan for a cultural center on the south bank of the Thames was completed today with the unveiling of plans for the last two buildings, a national theater and an opera house.

The American Export Isbrandtsen Lines has filed another plan with the Government for enhancing the future of the waning merchant marine. Top Federal authorities responded by praising the company's "original and enterprising" thinking.

WONDERFULLY gifted Flannery O'Connor, 1925-64, seemed to have less herd instinct than any other writer in her young generation. That rare attribute places anyone who has it in a special category -- since, for reasons that elude me, categorize we must.

The Harvard Crimson, the university daily, is publishing a book, "The Art of Fine Words: Offerings in Honor of Arthur H. Hopkins." Mr. Hopkins is a linotypist known to many toilers on the Crimson. The book is a collection of memoirs of collegiate journalism supplied by 70 contributors.

Ballet Concepts, a small company headed by Marvin Gordon, made its New York debut last night in the Clark Center Auditorium of the West Side Young Women's Christian Association. The company was first seen in the Midwest, where it recently completed a tour of 15 engagements.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Representative John V. Lindsay said today that he would seek no outside Republican help, not even from former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, in his campaign against Mayor Wagner.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 26 -- Gen. Alfredo Ovando Candia, commander in chief of the armed forces, was installed as co-President of Bolivia tonight.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 26 -- A broken sesamoid, an injury from which few horses recover sufficiently to resume racing, threatened today to terminate the trotting career of Roosevelt Baby.
Mark Fein, 33-year-old Park Avenue executive, was sentenced to 30 years to life in prison yesterday for the murder of a Brooklyn bookmaker, Reuben Markowitz.
Eversharp, Inc., and Technicolor, Inc., purchased yesterday for $4 million cash 27.5 per cent of the outstanding stock of Schick Electric, Inc., from Revlon, Inc.
An active market in Maine potato futures dominated trading yesterday on the nation's commodity exchanges.
For more than 50 years International Railways of Central America has been hauling bananas mainly for the United Fruit Company, with a modest profit in most years up to 1957.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 26 -- The Organization of American States extended its police power in principle today to all sections of the country controlled by the antirebel junta.
A 43-year old policeman who was arrested seven years ago for allegedly stealing guns from the Police Department won a $40,000 judgment against the city yesterday for false arrest.
LEWISTON, Me., May 26 -- Russell D. Carroll, New England's most celebrated "minute" man, said tonight he could have been wrong.
ALBANY, May 26 -- A bill to prohibit the use of professional strike breakers in labor disputes was defeated in the Senate tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor disclosed tonight that an additional 3,000 companies would soon be asked by him to join in the cooperative effort to reduce the United States international payments deficit.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The recalcitrance of the junta in the Dominican Republic was reported today to have become the central obstacle to formation of a provisional government there.
The following article was written by Alan Truscott, bridge columnist of The New York Times, who covered the 13th World Bridge Championship in Buenos Aires.

BOSTON, May 26 -- About 1,000 clergymen and lay leaders of the Unitarian Universalist Association marched on the headquarters of Boston's School Committee today to protest racial imbalance in the city's public schools.

Your excellent editorial of May 21 on the Mangano-Ferrall bill to provide state funds for textbooks to be "loaned" to students in parochial and private schools pointed out that the measure seems in "clear violation" of the State Constitution.

HAVANA, May 26 -- The Havana Revolutionary Tribunal has sentenced two United States Baptist ministers to ten and six years in prison, a Cuban official stated tonight. A public announcement is expected in the next few days.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Two securities firms that are major market makers in over-the-counter stocks and an official of a third major securities firm have been disciplined by the National Association of Securities Dealers for improper activities.
A heavy selling wave in the final minutes of trading yesterday washed away the morning's stock-market gains and cut into Tuesday's advance.

LOS ANGELES, May 26 (UPI) -- Julian Javier singled home Bob Uecker in the seventh inning tonight and the St. Louis Cardinals gained a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers that snapped Sandy Koufax's three-game winning streak.

Mayor Wagner's office announced yesterday that a public hearing on a bill passed by the City Council, raising the number of Councilmen elected by districts from 25 to 27, would be held Tuesday at 10:30 A.M. in City Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Authors and publishing representatives advocated revision of the 1909 Copyright Act at the start today of Congressional hearings that will probably continue for three or four weeks.

ONE of the credos of theater people is that they be allowed the chance to fall. Well, last night we were introduced to two playwrights, Bertrand Castelli and Jack Raphael Guss, who surely cannot complain about lack of opportunity to do just that.
The Chase Manhattan Bank's announcement of its plans to sell $250 million of capital notes caused a decline in corporate-bond prices yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, accused the Administration today of drawing up a "diabolically clever plan" designed to influence a Federal grand jury into clearing Robert G. Baker.

MANCHESTER, Mass., May 26 -- Joseph Clark Grew, United States Ambassador to Japan at the time of Pearl Harbor and a career diplomat for 40 years, died at his summer home here last evening. He lacked two days of being 85 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell has decided against trying to attach an antidiscrimination amendment to the bill to repeal section 14 (b) of the Taft-Hartley Act, informed sources said today.

The New York Mets teetered on the brink of the National League cellar for nearly four hours last night, then fell in when George Altman, an ex-Met, pinch-hit a two-run home run for the Chicago Cubs in the 10th inning.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Johnson asked Congress today for legislation to clear the nation's main highways of billboards and junkyards, and to build more scenic roads for drives to beauty spots.

NOW Tow that Earl Louis Brown has been appointed head of the city's Commission on Human Rights the public may expect to hear him described either as "the lonely intellectual in Harlem politics" or "look-down-Brown."

LEWISTON, Me., May 26 -- It was a gargantuan bungle from its inception and the Cassius Clay-Sonny Liston return match ended in shameful disarray. Only one clear result emerged from the welter of confusion. Clay is still the heavyweight champion of the world, although even the legality of his stunning annihilation of the Big Bear is at least slightly open to question.
There may be less to President Johnson's billboard control bill than meets the eye.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The White House Conference on Natural Beauty completed its deliberations this week, and the natural beauty ball started rolling immediately. President Johnson picked it up before the first bounce by receiving the conference's hot-off-the resolution recommendations with the announcement that he had already prepared four bills to be sent to Congress dealing with billboards, junkyards and highway beautification.

Through the early morning mist, two heavily laden buses droned up Harbor Hill on Long Island. Near the top, in an elaborately manicured suburban development, they discharged a determined-looking crew, armed with military entrenching tools, picks, shovels and hammers.

Cassius Clay's first-round knockout of Sonny Liston Tuesday night in defense of his world heavyweight boxing championship touched off demands yesterday for an investigation of the fight and for Federal control of boxing.

The refinancing of first and second mortgages with a new first mortgage loan of $2,265,000 has resulted in substantial savings for tenant-owners of the cooperative apartment house at 1120 Park Avenue according to the broker, Peter Sharp, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co.

AUBURN, Me., May 26 -- The magical youth, Cassius Clay-Muhammad Ali, poet and prophet, danced on a carpet of grass today, his mighty right fist cracking into his open left hand. "Sonny Liston stepped into it.

ALBANY, May 26 -- Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki, who watched the Cassius Clay-Sonny Liston fight last night with "a feeling of disgust," introduced a bill today to outlaw professional boxing in New York State.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- A falling piece of metal inside a tank probably caused the explosions that destroyed the tanker Bunker Hill, a Coast Guard report said today.

LONDON, May 26 (Reuters) -- European papers and fans delivered an angry verdict today against that "60-second stinker," that "squalid little shemozzle," that "biggest clownery in the history of boxing."
The city's second largest factory employer, a multistory plant with 5,000 workers, is considering moving to another city.

Some 4,000 public school teachers, demonstrating near City Hall, said yesterday that they would stay away from their jobs next September unless the Board of Education granted satisfactory salary increases and improvements in school and working condi tions.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels, held to one hit for eight innings by Pete Richert tonight, scored in the ninth on Jim Fregosi's single off Benny Daniels and beat the Washington Senators, 2-1.

Nosy that it has been decided to let the traffic flow on Fifth Avenue comply with the main stream of twentieth-century thinking, perhaps it is appropriate to suggest two further improvements for this famous thoroughfare.

A limousine went through a red light in Times Square last night, and struck eight pedestrians, several of whom were sent sprawling onto Broadway in front of southbound traffic, the police said. A woman's leg was broken.
Eight advanced art students have received Ford Foundation interneships to work in fine arts museums around the country.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy designated Gerlad J. Bruno today as his upstate New York representative with headquarters in the Syracuse Post Office-Federal Building.

LUSAKA, Zambia, May 26 -- The United Nations was urged to intervene militarily in Rhodesia if Britain does not call a new constitutional conference for the country. Rhodesia, a self-governing British colony, is slated for independence soon.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Brokerage houses doing a general securities business will be required, beginning Dec. 1, to maintain net capital of at least $5,000 to backstop their operations under a rule announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 26 -- A vigorous minority opposition developed here today against a plan to update and broaden the traditional doctrinal stand of the United Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk warned the Soviet Union and Communist China today against underestimating the gravity of the situation in Vietnam or the risks of widening their military involvement there.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which discovered to its dismay this past season that "The Beverly Hillbillies" and other shows had declined in ratings, now faces a subsidiary problem: What to do about the sagging television rating here of the New York Yankees, of which it owns 90 per cent.

A California Congressman said yesterday that Representative Adam Clayton Powell's wife should be taken off the House payroll. He said that under a hitherto-overlooked nine-month-old resolution she had been illegally paid.
ALBANY, May 26 -- The Senate Finance Committee deleted today one of the major provisions of the strict code of legislative ethics approved by the Assembly on Monday.
The London stock market eased moderately yesterday on light trading.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, May 26 (Reuters) -- Nine member states of the Inter-African and Malagasy Organization announced tonight that they would not attend the Organization of African Unity conference in Accra Ghana in September.

Ten weeks after President Johnson stood before Congress and embraced the rallying cry of the civil rights movement, "We Shall Overcome," the Senate has given overwhelming passage to the voting rights bill for which he called that night.

PARIS, May 26 (UPI) -- Nancy Richey relied on powerful baseline drives today to beat Francoise Durr of France, 8-6, 9-7, in a quarter-final match to keep United States hopes alive for a singles title in the French international tennis championships.
Mohasco Industries, Inc., the home-furnishings industry's largest manufacturer, has consolidated its operations into two groups, Herbert L. Shuttleworth 2d, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- Government officials conceded today that consumer food prices had shot up in the last year and said they would continue to rise for the rest of this year, but at a more moderate rate.

It is almost impossible to write a lifeless story about the Irish, but Muriel Rukeyser, an American poet and biographer, has succeeded where other less well-intentioned visitors to Ireland have failed. "The Orgy" describes Puck Fair, a three-day cattle market held in County Kerry each year. A goat is crowned King Puck, drovers get drunk, children run loose and tinkers tell fortunes.

LONDON, May 26 (Reuters) -- The unknown thief who stole the National Gallery's Goya portrait of the Duke of Wellington -- valued at nearly $400,000, complained that the painting was "pinched back by a broken promise."

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP) -- Three United States Circuit Court judges heard a Government request today to stop the purchase by the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for nearly $100 million of an Iowa corn starch and grocery produce manufacturer.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Eight regional winners were announced today in the National Symphony Orchestra's 1965 Merriweather Post Contest for violinists and cellists.

In 1877 the Rev. Willard Parsons, a young graduate of the Union Theological Seminary, had an inspiration that has proved both contagious and durable. He saw to it, during that year, that sixty children from the tenements of New York City had a chance to spend a vacation in the country. The first installment was a small band of nine youngsters, who traveled by Erie Railroad to the hills of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk, in the face of diplomatic and political criticism, defended the Administration today against charges that it had bypassed the Organization of American States in the Dominican crisis.

Affectionately, who has become one of the best female race horses of the era, will endeavor to beat males in the Metropolitan Mile at Aqueduct on Monday. Hirsch Jacobs, who trains the 5-year-old mare for his wife, Ethel, said yesterday that he would run Affectionately in the $100,000 fixture, after he had learned that her weight assignment would be 121 pounds.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 26 -- President Jomo Kenyetta agreed today for the sake of good relations with Uganda to release the arms convoy his security forces intercepted near Lake Victoria 11 days ago.
George Whitmore Jr. won the right yesterday to be retried on a murder indictment before he stands trial for a second time on charges of an attempted rape.

It seems a shame if Police Commissioner Murphy's resignation should have been speeded by the calculated campaign of character assassination by career agitators misleading certain groups in this city. He was one of the best Police Commissioners we have had and deserved far more support than he received from responsible people.
LONDON, May 26 -- The reactions of Britons to Cassius Clay's one-minute knockout of Sonny Liston ranged from disgust to rage today.
LUSAKA, Zambia, May 25 -- President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia made a strong plea Tuesday for Communist China's admission to the United Nations.

SEVENTY-FOUR players took part in the recent South Jersey Amateur Open at the Plaza Hotel in Camden, N.J. Thomas Meola of Maplewood upset the form and, without losing a single game outright, captured first prize, scoring 5-1.
A $15 million offering of the City of Oslo, Norway, 5 3/4 per cent sinking fund external loan bonds, was made yesterday by an international underwriting group.
ALBANY, May 26 -- Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki threw his support today to a plan for a legislative study of the state's controversial divorce laws.
Local housing authorities sold yesterday 31 issues of tax-exempt bonds totaling $126.15 million.

LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- Lord Thomson of Fleet, Canadian-born newspaper magnate, said today that publishers should continually strive for full freedom of the press but must be prepared to accept for a time some compromise with this principle in newly emerging nations.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the appointment as vice presidents of Warren F. Beer, Joseph J. Harkins and Raymond V. O'Brien Jr.
Net new orders for machine tools, the machines that make machinery and, in essence, industry's production lines, took a sharp downturn in April.

A leading Belgian steel authority answered American criticisms of European sales practices yesterday by suggesting the establishment of an international tribunal that would be empowered to "investigate violations of the standards of fair trading."

PARIS, May 26 -- President de Gaulle asserted today that continued "foreign political and military intervention" in the Dominican Republic threatened world peace there and in the Caribbean area generally.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) -- Mariner 4, scheduled to arrive at Mars July 14, has already passed the red planet. But, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today, this is nothing to worry about.

Menasha Skulnik will return to Broadway after an absence of five years in "The Zulu and the Zayda," due Nov. 23. His wife, Anna Roman, also may appear in the play, dramatized by Felix Leon and Howard da Silva from a short story by Dan Jacobson.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 26 (AP) -- Joe Torre and Felipe Alou each hit two home runs today to give the Milwaukee Braves a 10-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter on natural beauty that President Johnson sent to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House today:
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, May 26 -- Monday evening's capacity crowd accorded the Chicago Symphony a tremendous ovation as it concluded the first of two concerts in Lathrop High School auditorium.
BOSTON, May 26 (UPI) -- The Minnesota Twins ran their two-game homer production to eight on blasts by Bob Allison, Harmon Killebrew and Tony Oliva and beat the Boston Red Sox, 9-7, tonight.
The outdoor advertising industry was almost unanimous yesterday in expressing support for President Johnson's proposed legislation to eliminate most billboards from the nation's major highways.

Police Lieut. Thomas R. Gilligan, who fatally shot a 15-year old Negro boy last summer, sued several prominent civil rights leaders yesterday for a total of $5,250,000 for allegedly calling him a murderer.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
The nation's electric power production rose 5.8 per cent in the week ended May 22 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

HAVANA, May 26 -- The propaganda guns of Premier Fidel Castro's regime were trained on the Organization of American States today for its endorsement of an inter-American force in the Dominican Republic.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Senate passed the voting rights bill today, 77 to 19.

SERIOUS bridge players vary widely in their educational attainments. Professors mingle on equal terms with high school dropouts, although none of the latter have reached the eminence of Bobby Fischer in chess. Actual illiteracy is rarer than bridge administrators sometimes believe: There are many who can read, but who do not exert themselves to do so.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 26 -- Extension of publicly aided birth control programs to unmarried mothers and those separated from their husbands was approved by a 41-to-8 vote today by the Illinois Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The confusion that followed President Kennedy's assassination, from a quarrel over removing his body to the fatal shooting of Lee Harvey Oswald, was reviewed today at a House Judiciary subcommittee hearing on corrective legislation.
DENVILLE, N.J., May 26 -- After a rules discussion, a 68 by Bob Shields of the Green Brook Country Club was the low score today in the opening round of the $16,000 Dodge open golf tourney.

One of the most intense competitions for a military aircraft order in recent years ended yesterday when the Army awarded a $14,966,964 contract to the Hughes Tool Company of Culver City, Calif., 714 light observation helicopters over the next three years.
WHITE PLAINS, May 26 -- The State Supreme Court's Appellate Division held today that a public official had a duty to speak bluntly about acts of other public officials he considered improper.

Ruddy-faced Edward J. Daly, 50-year-old president of World Airways Inc., reached into his own pocket yesterday for $152,500, so that 2,000 victims of a bankrupt travel agency would not lose their savings.

CAIRO, May 27 -- The Arab League was urged at a stormy meeting tonight to expel Tunisia because her President, Habib Bourguiba, has proposed a negotiated settlement of the Arab-Israeli dispute. But an ouster move failed.
For the first time in memory, the 173-year-old New York Stock Exchange could boast yesterday that one of its 1,366 members was the father of quadruplets.
One night last April a couple of agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation sat in their car a block away from a diner in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. It was a dull, routine assignment.

CLEVELAND, May 27 -- The industrialist Cyrus S. Eaton made available today transcript of his recent talks with high Soviet officials, quoting them as sharply critical of President Johnson and the recent trend of United States foreign policy.
CAIRO, May 27 (Reuters) -- Christophe Gbenye, Congolese insurgent leader, is no longer "president of the republic," after a reshuffle of the Congolese revolutionary Government announced here today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -- Three United States Circuit Court judges denied motions of the United States Government today for an injunction to prevent the purchase by the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company of Penick Ford, Inc., for nearly $100 million.
The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday plans for a new intercity private business telephone service that needs no dialing and has no minimum time charges.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The United States lost another $60 million of gold this week, it was officially announced today, as a series of reports gave further details of the continuing international financial problem.
Despite a last-minute plea by Mayor Wagner, the executive committee of the World's Fair decided yesterday not to reduce the admission price to the fair.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 27 -- Royal Laotian forces cut a Communist assault to pieces Monday in the northeastern Laotian province of Samneua, according to well-informed military sources here.
LONDON, May 27 -- Walter Lippmann today credited United States correspondents in Santo Domingo with having saved their country from a "moral disaster."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- House Republican leaders, pressing a fund-raising drive for next year's Congressional elections, complained today that competing splinter groups were diluting the sources of campaign contributions.
Attendance at the Museum Modern Art has set a record of 1,058,700 in the year since the museum reopened on May 27, 1964, after extensive remodeling.
A new clue to the mystery of multiple sclerosis was reported yesterday by scientists here.
ALBANY, May 27 -- The Legislature, hobbled by absent members, deferred action today on controversial bills until next Tuesday.

State Supreme Court Justice William Lyman refused yesterday to issue an injunction sought by minority stockholders of the American Steel and Pump Corporation to bar salary and other payments to the company's officers.

Howard Goodman, New York University's National Collegiate saber champion, was presented the Alumni Trophy last night as the Violets' athlete of the year during a sports dinner at University Heights campus.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Top national civil rights leaders strongly endorsed today repeal of Section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Act.
