Walter C. Ivancevic, suspended president of the Equity Corporation, filed suit in the Supreme Court of New York State yesterday seeking an injunction against the company's chairman, David M. Milton, five other directors, and William A. Metz, the company's new general counsel.
TORONTO, May 27 (AP) -- Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton said today that the United States had wasted and polluted its own water resources and was now trying to "plunder" Canada's.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- Vice President Humphrey received a round of tributes from his former Senate colleagues today on the occasion of his 54th birthday.
Prices of rayon textile filament yarn will go up 3 to 7 cents a pound on July 1.
The corporate bond market continued to sag yesterday under the weight of Wednesday's announcement by the Chase Manhattan Bank that it would market $250 million of capital notes on June 8.
A temporary halt of trading in British Government bonds enlivened a generally unsettled London stock market yesterday.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 27 -- The Organization of American States announced tonight that it would pay the salaries of all Dominican civil servants, regardless of which side they supported in the civil war.
Charles M. Brinckerhoff was elected yesterday as the chairman and chief executive officer of the Anaconda Company, the world's largest producer of copper.

Two record companies have made a gift to Island Concert Hall, Inc., that, according to the president of the organization, will insure the success of its 1965-66 series at the Mineola (L.I.) Playhouse.
A stumbling stock market finally found its footing yesterday morning at about 11:30 A.M. Prices then began a long, hard trek uphill but closed with losses.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- "A Family Album" compiled by the late mother of President Johnson, Mrs. Rebekah Baines Johnson, will be published this fall, the White House confirmed today.

ALBANY, May 27 -- More than six months after election day, the contest between Francis X. Altimari and Julius R. Lippman for Judge of the Third District Court in Nassau County has apparently come to its conclusion in the Court of Appeals.
LONDON, May 27 -- British biochemists have unraveled the internal structure of one of the most potent bacteria killers in the human body.
The Fusion Party, Inc., of New York City announced yesterday that it planned to endorse a full list of candidates for the Nov. 2 elections.
As an Arab Palestinian who was born in Palestine, I would like to comment on the statement of Levi Eshkol of Israel which he made before the Knesset as reported in The New York Times of May 18.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Supreme Court will consider tomorrow whether to suspend a lower court order directing a special election of the New York State Legislature this fall.
PARIS, May 27 (AP) -- Four Americans advanced today to the second round of the French amateur golf tournament. Two lost and two defaulted.
The move by E.J. Korvette, Inc., the country's leading discount chain, to realign its top executive echelon was viewed yesterday by retail observers as an effort to spur the company's growth.

WHEN the committee finished computing time allowances for late measured yachts yesterday and deleting a few that found they couldn't go after all, there were 159 entries for the 20th annual Block Island race of the Storm Trysail Club.

PARIS -- Whether we wish it or not, the form of NATO must undergo great changes by the end of this decade. Therefore, since the United States is both the alliance's sponsor and paramount power, Washington would do well to try and guide the inevitable transformation.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Johnson Administration began today to let the Organization of American States assume a growing number of trusteeship duties in the Dominican Republic.

New York City's antipoverty board agreed yesterday to increase its size from 62 to 100 members, with a third of them representatives of the poor. Until now, no poor people have played a direct part in planning or implementing the program to fight poverty here.

Your editorial (May 24) raising questions about state funds being used in churches to support the Headstart Program mentions the New York City Society of the Methodist Church as one of the agencies granted such funds.
Buildings Commissioner Harold Birns sent more than 700 of his inspectors into the city's water conservation drive yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee approved today legislation that would require a health-hazard warning on cigarette packages.
CHICAGO, May 27 (AP) -- The Chicago Board of Education voted 7 to 4 today to rehire Superintendent of School Benjamin C. Willis until his 65th birthday -- Dec. 23, 1966.
LONDON, May 27 -- Princess Margaret and her husband, the Earl of Snowdon, will pay their first visit to the United States in November.

BOSTON, May 27 (AP) -- Dick Radatz preserved Dave Morehead's three-hit shutout by striking out two pinch-hitters today with the bases filled in the ninth inning as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Minnesota Twins, 2-0.
The Legislature has dropped plans to abolish criminal sanctions against homosexual acts committed between consenting adults in private.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Government scientists reported evidence tonight of the transmission of a leukemia-like cancer between laboratory animals by means of mosquitoes.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 27 -- The South African Government, often the target of boycotts, has been conducting a boycott of its own against the Ford Motor Company.

Silver trumpets glinting in the sun sounded a triumphant fanfare, and the Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, said: "Praise ye the Lord, because the foundation of this building is laid!"

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Davy Crockett, the Army nuclear weapon that was a political issue in last year's election campaign, has turned out to be a military dud. No more of the weapons are to be manufactured.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- An internal struggle for control of the Atlantic Research Corporation was disclosed today with the filing of proxy statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The polluted air of New York is choking the pipes of church organs all over town.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Soviet Union is winning "an ocean space race by a lopsided margin" Edwin M. Hood, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, said today.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 27 -- Four explosions in the workers' district here last night injured three persons, damaged 40 houses and destroyed some water mains and electrical lines.

George Balanchine, artistic director of the New York City Ballet, made one of his rare appearances as a performer last night in the title role of the new ballet "Don Quixote" at the New York State Theater.
ALBANY, May 27 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals split 4 to 3 today in upholding the State Constitution's provisions that literacy tests for voter registration must be given in English.

LONDON, May 27 -- Britain's leading bridge players have become hotly divided over the allegations leveled against Terence Reese and Boris Schapiro, partners at the world bridge championships in Buenos Aires.
Columbia University announced yesterday a major reorganization of its School of Architecture and the election of Kenneth A. Smith as dean of the school.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 27 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, suggested today that peace-keeping action in the Dominican Republic by the Organization of American States rather than by the United Nations might set an embarrassing precedent.

The one constant that Harry Schwartz, a member of The Times editorial board and a specialist on Russian affairs, finds in the ups and downs of the Soviet economy since 1953 "is the consistency with which great plans have been announced with much publicity and boasting and then abandoned a few years later."
The entry of more and more American advertising agencies on the European scene has resulted in a significant rise in the status of the agency and the ad man in Europe.

EMILY POST is gone, but Mrs. Richard Worldly and most of the other characters she created in 1922 for "Etiquette," her book of social usage, have been preserved in the recently published 11th edition along with most of Mrs. Post's rules for proper behavior.
Grand Union Company, the food retailer, plans increased emphasis on the development of its Grand Way. Department Store division, Thomas C. Butler, president, announced yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 27 -- Not everyone wins money in a race. Sometimes even the track loses, which is a likely possibility tomorrow night when nine 3-year-olds, including undefeated Bret Hanover, go to the post in the $35,800 Commodore Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

By refusing to listen to reason Robert Moses has won his fight against reducing the admission prices to the New York World's Fair. The members of the fair's executive committee who sought to boost flagging attendance by cutting the price of entry had facts and the exhibitors on their side, but they were unable to budge Mr. Moses.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 27 -- Governor Rockefeller said tonight that the fine arts "must be subsidized -- increasingly with public funds."

HARRISON, N.Y., May 27 -- Long Island won the Myra D. Paterson Trophy at Harrison Country Club today by defeating Westchester and New Jersey in the 36th annual intersectional team competition of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Parts of an Administration plan to increase the limits of liability of international airlines for the death or injury of passengers were denounced today as out moded, outrageous, unjust and possibly illegal.

DETROIT, May 27 -- The Detroit Tigers learned at first-hand tonight that the currently popular game of "beat the 16 Yankees" isn't too difficult at that. In their first encounter with the American League champions this season the Tigers received a five-hit performance from big Joe Sparma and whipped the Yanks, 4-1, before 18,257 fans at Tiger Stadium.

Two speeches sympathetic to the steel industry seemed to be in conflict yesterday. Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor told the dinner meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that the steel industry "underpins our economy" and that it affects almost all other industries.

BERLIN, May 27 -- Standing on the exact spot where President John F. Kennedy two years ago declared "I am a Berliner," Queen Elizabeth today promised Berliners "the full support of the British Government and people in the great tasks that lie ahead."
BONN, May 27 -- The West German police have traced an attempt to frighten the Bonn Parliament into halting prosecutions of Nazi criminals to an international neo-Nazi organization.

The Federal Reserve appears to have tightened credit another notch. Net borrowed reserves in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported, amounted to a daily average of $173 million, up $11 million from the week before and almost $75 million from the level at the beginning of May.

The news division of the Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday it had adopted "standards of self-restraint" in reporting pre-trial and trial matters in judicial proceedings. The purpose is to help safeguard the rights of defendants and the state to fair trials.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 27 (AP) -- Thomas Hart Benton resigned today by letter from the American Academy of Arts and Letters in New York.

LONDON, May 27 -- Dealings in British Government securities were suspended for nearly three hours on the London Stock Exchange today while jobbers assessed a concession made by the Government on capital gains taxation.

NAPLES, Italy, May 27 (AP) -- The Australian 5.5-Meter boat Southern Cross, skippered by its owner, Norman George Booth, won the Lower Tyrrhenian Commandant's Cup yacht race today in the Bay of Naples. United States boats finished second and third.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 (AP) -- Tommy Bolt threw birdies instead of clubs at the tough Greentree course today for a three-under-par 68 and the first-round lead in the $87,500 Speedway Festival golf tournament.
L.E.J. Brouwer, president-elect of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the Shell Oil Company.
SUCCASUNNA, N.J., May 127 -- New Jersey's Gov. Richard J. Hughes made the first official call today from the Bell System's new electronic central offices here.
Despite its weakening at the hands of the State Senate, the bill to strengthen the legislative code of ethics still has positive values that make its enactment highly desirable.
HOUSTON, May 27 (UPI) -- Houston got maximum mileage out of six base hits and coupled them with the clutch seven-hit pitching of Dick Farrell tonight to pin a 6-1 defeat on the St. Louis Cardinals.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- A West Virginia coal miner who performed two life-saving acts in one day has won a gold medal for heroism from the Joseph A. Holmes Safety Association.
James D. Landauer, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, has announced the election of the group's board of governors.

" EVEN the Indians wouldn't live on the West Side," said the Rev. Henry Joseph Browne yesterday, discussing the neglected upper West Side where he has spent six years fighting for what he calls "the human approach" to urban renewal.

The Government withdrew deportation proceedings yesterday against five Zulu dancers from South Africa without deciding whether their contention was justified that they were entitled to asylum because they would be subject to persecution under their country's apartheid policy.
The owners of the major taxicab fleets refused yesterday to cooperate in a city-sponsored election to test the cab workers' interest in joining a union.

MOSCOW, May 27 -- The Soviet Communist party warned today that the continued airing of ideological differences between Communist countries was weakening the whole movement in the confrontation with the West.
A low-income project unusual in its name, size, design and occupants was dedicated on the West Side yesterday, after a six-year battle by residents for its construction.

PARIS, May 27 (AP) -- Tony Roche, a young left-hander from Australia, spoiled Roy Emerson's bid for a tennis grand slam today by beating the world's top amateur in the semi-finals of the French championships, 6-1, 6-4, 3-6, 6-0.
One sometimes wonders if the Republican party is not bent upon becoming a splinter party of yahoos.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that Representative John V. Lindsay's failure to produce a studied statement on the city budget marked him as "a candidate who does not have much knowledge of the city and its financial problems."
LONDON, May 27 -- The wooing of Lady Luck has created one of Britain's biggest and fastest-growing industries, the Churches' Council on Gambling reported today.

DESIGNERS like Andre Courreges, the controversial Paris couturier, usually have a vision in their minds' eyes. His intention is to liberate young, fast-moving moderns from corsets, high heels and other fashion appurtenances that strike him as fossilized vestiges in the space age.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A majority of Senate Republicans have signed a statement calling on President Johnson to make some "firm decisions" on the financing of the United Nations and stand by them.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 -- Life in the slums is characterized by the lawlessness of private businessmen and government agencies even more than by that of the slum dwellers, several sessions of the National Conference on Social Welfare were told today.
PARIS, May 27 -- The chiefs of the French and Italian Com munist parties conferred secretly Monday and Tuesday in Geneva on a wide range of subjects, the French party announced today.
James A. Farley said yesterday that Sir Winston Churchill once told him the Western powers should attack the Russians "with the full atomic arsenal" if the Russians did not get out of Europe.

A crowd of about 10,000 persons jammed the upper level of Pier 90 on the Hudson River yesterday to see the new Italian Line luxury liner Michelangelo before she left on her first eastbound Atlantic crossing.
Representative John V. Lindsay was designated by acclamation last night as the Republican party's candidate to oppose Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Johnson Administration, in numerous briefings, news conferences and interviews, is justifying its actions in the Dominican crisis by citing five positive achievements.
The May 20 news report from your Washington bureau leads me to believe there is a great deal of misunderstanding about the poll tax in Vermont as a requirement for voting in local elections.
The El Paso Natural Gas Company announced yesterday it had prepared for filing with the Federal Power Commission a proposal it believed could save California gas consumers $112 million by 1970.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 27 -- The camping fund of the Episcopal Mission Society will benefit from the Laurel Ball, to be held at the Tuxedo Club here next Friday.

CHICOPEE, Mass., May 27 (UPI) -- Cassius Clay, suffering from a slight head cold, said today the unfavorable reaction to his title defense aginst Sonny Liston was from critics who "just hate to give me credit for being so good."
LOS ANGELES, May 27 (AP) -- County officials said tonight that some doctors at Los Angeles County Hospital were staging a "heal-in" -- packing the hospital with patients -- in a salary protest.
TEL AVIV, May 27 -- Dr. William A. Wexler of Savannah, Ga., was elected president of B'nai B'rith today at the closing session of the Jewish service organization's triennial convention.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- Officials of Federal and city antipoverty agencies expressed satisfaction today with Philadelphia's popular election of impoverished neighborhood leaders to the committee that will run the multi-million dollar antipoverty drive here.

Leading scientists of Western Europe, the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, Israel, Japan and the United States paid tribute last night to Herman F. Mark, one of the founders of polymer science as a separate branch of chemistry.

Tile Department of Health, Education and Welfare is forewarning Southern hospitals before investigating them for compliance with civil rights laws, the N'. A. A. C. P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc. charged yesterday.

PARIS, May 27 -- A Government bill replacing France's 60-year-old tradition of universal military service with a selective service system won the approval of the National Assembly early this morning after two days of debate.

Twelve, card-playing housewives in Brooklyn were robbed of $600 during a poker session at 10 o'clock last night in the apartment of Mrs. Terry Miceli, 6907 14th Avenue, in the Bensonhurst section, according to the police.
A months-old dispute between a union and a shipline over how many men should man an automated vessel moved a step closer to solution yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Rail carloadings and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended May 22 were both considerably above the corresponding period of 1964.
The Union Pacific Railroad reported yesterday that its net income in April was the highest for any April in the company's history.
The New York Mets turned hotter than the weather yesterday and stayed hot long enough to score seven runs in four innings and defeat the Chicago Cubs, 8-5.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 27 -- A series of banking scandals here led yesterday to the appointment of a three-man commission to run the Government's National Bank of the Republic. It will replace the bank's present board of directors.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The public has a right to see, hear and know what Congress is doing, Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Nearly half a million families moved out of the Government's poverty classification last year.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 27 (AP) -- The Houston Post quoted a granddaughter of an Orange, Tex., millionaire, Edgar Brown Jr., as saying shortly after she was married in Maryland tonight that she had been disinherited by her grandfather and her parents because a Negro was a member of the wedding party.

TO start the last weekend of the New York Philharmonic's season, William Steinberg faced no less a work than Bach's monumental Mass in B minor. The terrors and difficulties of presenting so difficult a piece of music need not be dwelt upon. But the musical joys are in equal proportion.
NEW DELHI, India, May 27 -- India today marked the first anniversary of Jawaharial Nehru's death with a full day's work.

BONN, May 27 -- A Government-owned holding company known as Veba (Vereinigte Elektrizitaets-und Bergwerke, A.G.), now being partially denationalized through the sale of stock to the public, is planning a major expansion in West German energy markets.

The Continental Ore Corporation, a marketing organization for metals and ores, has leased 20,000 square feet of floor space for its New York headquarters in the building being erected by the Uris Buildings Corporation at 245 Park Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets.
Three New Yorkers were honored yesterday by the Police Department for "heroic and unselfish acts." All three had risked their lives to help the police. All said they would do it again.
Scars, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest merchandiser, continued to report growing profits yesterday with its 16th consecutive record for quarterly earnings.

MONTREAL, May 27 -- The first International Piano Festival, with more than 60 competitors from 22 Western and Communist countries, opened last night with a gala concert at the Place des Arts concert hall.

A special showing yesterday of the movies of Tuesday's world heavyweight title fight convinced expert observers that Sonny Liston had been hit by a damaging blow in his vain effort to regain the championship from Cassius Caly.
If the Pure Oil-Union Oil merger fails to win stockholder approval the Pure Oil Company will not be for sale, Robert L. Milligan, president of Pure, declared here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Two additional Americans have been arrested in Cuba in what seems to be a campaign of increasing repression by Premier Fidel Castro's Government against foreigners.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Broad authority for the Pentagon to spend more than $15 billion on new missiles, aircraft, combat vessels and other military hardware received final Congressional approval today.

LUSKA, Rhodesia, May 27 -- Evidence of beatings and torture of African nationalists by drunken Rhodesian policemen was given here today to the United Nations Special Committee on Colonialism on the third day of its hearings.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 27 -- How cultural and biological forces are shaping the evolutionary destiny of a racially mixed community in the southeastern United States was described at a scientific meeting here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 27 -- The Soviet Union called today for a prohibition on the use of nuclear weapons and for liquidation of all overseas military bases.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of a point in April, its largest rise in a single month since last July.

Four women out of 20 chosen to be in the Women Hospitality Center's Hall of Fame at the World's Fair attended dedication ceremonies yesterday afternoon for the hall's gallery of photographs of the 20.

Archbishop Stepinac of White Plains won the team title in the track and field championships of the New York division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association yesterday at Randalls Island. Eight meet records were set and one tied.
More than 15 men of letters in a dozen languages agreed yesterday that American books are more in demand than any other translations in their home countries.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 27 -- Warships of the United States Navy have been turning their guns against Vietcong troop concentrations and other coastal targets in South Vietnam, an official American spokesman announced today.
LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk was reported tonight softening his terms slightly for an international conference on Cambodia. This leaves Communist China as a main obstacle.

FALLSBURG, N.Y., May 27 -- Two Yeshiva University faculty members emphasized today that while Orthodox Judaism had made great progress in the United States, "it must not overlook its failures" on the contemporary scene.

Contracts for residential construction in the United States reached their highest point in history last month, and the total of contracts for future work of all kinds was second only to the record volume of May, 1963.
They felt their marriage had reached the breaking point. Mr. and Mrs. D. quarreled constantly and each blamed the other for the problems of their 4-year-old son, Daniel.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 -- If Maj. Edward H. White leaves his space capsule during next Thursday's Gemini 4 flight it will only be a "space spectacular" stunt, Rep. George P. Miller, Democrat of California, said today.

SANA, Yemen, May 25 -- President Abdullah al-Salal said today that Yemeni Government and Egyptian forces had captured a large cache of arms made in the United States, Belgium and Britain from royalist tribes.

CATAVI, Bolivia, May 27 -- In an atmosphere of tension. Bolivia's biggest mining center slowly went back to work today after a 10-day strike that dealt a hard blow to this economically backward and politically unstable nation.
The Paramount Pictures Corporation announced the elections yesterday of Herbert J. Siegel and Ernest H. Martin as directors.
TEL AVIV, Friday, May 28 -- An Israeli Army spokesman announced that army units had carried out three punitive, retaliatory raids into Jordan late last night and early today.
The British pound improved moderately in foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The spot rate closed at $2.7947, compared with $2.7943 on the previous day.

The steady build-up of American combat troops in South Vietnam raises questions that deserve forthright answers. Only a month ago reports of a projected build-up in ground forces were officially denied in Washington. Since those denials there has been a 50 per cent increase in American military personnel in Vietnam.
Although trading was slow in most grain futures, prices firmed on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.
The heat wave that had been oppressing the city with 90-degree temperatures for two days was broken last night with rain and thundershowers, accompanied by gusty winds.

The United Steelworkers of America presented a new proposal to five aluminum producers yesterday after having rejected a 16.5 cent an hour offer from the Aluminum Company of America.

WARSAW, May 27 -- Pope Paul VI will visit Poland next year to help celebrate the millennium of Polish Roman Catholicism, church sources said today.

IT was only after the Battle of Waterloo that the illegitimate son of a petty Bantu chieftain succeeded his father as the head of the Zulu clan, one of the hundreds of clans of the Nguni Bantus. The new chief, Shaka, was a bloodthirsty savage and partly mad; but he was a great warrior and a military innovator of genius.
The Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo announced yesterday that it planned to issue $18 million of capital notes due in 1990.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Youthful demonstrators against the House Committee on Un-American Activities rushed police lines today in a vain effort to reach a heavily guarded subcommittee hearing on alleged Communist infiltration of union, civil rights, peace and youth groups in Chicago.

CLEVELAND, May 27 -- Following are excerpts from conversations held May 20 in Moscow by the industrialist Cyrus S. Eaton with Aleksei N. Kosygin, the Soviet Premier, and with Anastas I. Mikoyan, the Soviet President, as recorded by Mr. Eaton's wife.

PRIMO CARNERA stabbed out with an ordinary left jab and Ernie Schaaf went down. He stayed down while the crowd in Madison Square Garden screamed "Fake." It did look like a palpable dive and the cynics in the press rows even risked laws against libel to hint as much. After all, the Preem was mobster-controlled and this appeared part of the build-up to maneuver the Italian giant into a shot at the world heavyweight championship.
THE 37th Eastern States Regional Championships, which begin today, just miss the distinction of being the world's oldest tournament. But they are certainly the oldest held continuously in one city.
The American Stock Exchange had its worst day in more than three months yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by a wide margin.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 27 -- Big Bob Shields played through a thunderstorm and shared the lead today in the $10,000 Dodge open golf tournament. With pars on the last three holes as lightning flashed and rain fell at the Rockaway River Country Club, Shields carded a two-under-par 70.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Government wants "everything conceivable investigative weapon," including the right to offer rewards or grant immunity to an informer, if there is even an indication of an assassination plot against the President, Congress was told today.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) -- Retail sales in the United States totaled $5.39 billion last week, down about 1 per cent from the previous week's $5.44 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

LOS ANGELES, May 27 (UPI) -- Al Ferrara walked with the bases loaded in the last of the ninth tonight to send home Willie Davis with the rim that gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 2-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Criticism in Washington never ends, but the object of criticism seems to change with the personality and methods of each administration.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Johnson signed today a bill extending for three years the life of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. He took the occasion to deliver a plea for peace and called upon all nations to resist "the spread of nuclear weapons."

TOKYO, May 26 -- Communist China was reported today to have denied permission for a large number of Japanese businessmen to go to Peking after attending a trade fair in Canton, where numerous Japanese products were exhibited for sale.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. May 27 -- Fifteen years ago the United Nations implemented the first international system of mutual aid among governments with a modest budget of $20 million for the first 18 months.

ABOARD THE CORAL SEA, May 27 -- "Planes from the carrier Coral Sea struck military targets in North Vietnam yesterday. Fifty-three aircraft took part in the raids, dropping more than 30 tons of bombs and rockets on North Vietnamese installations."

Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism yesterday awarded the 1965 Pulitzer Traveling Fellowships to three students, David E. Rosenbaum of Tampa, Fla.; Richard J. Pothier of Quincy, Mass.; and Robert D. Lee of Estherville, Iowa.
Alfred A. Knopf presided over a screening yesterday and described the first of two films as "hammy and pontifical," the second as better. Nobody became angry; they were Mr. Knopf's own films.

An eligible for the $125,000 added Belmont Stakes a week from tomorrow won the $15,000 feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Joseph Straus's La Cima came along with a late rush to take the 1 1/8-mile event in rather the same fashion that the horse the purse was named for, Carry Back, used to win his races.

The Memorial Day weekend begins for many New Yorkers today and motorists, railroads, safety experts, paraders and the police have begun preparing for their traditional roles in the holiday's observance.

MOSCOW, May 27 -- A five-month experiment on introducing the profit motive into a Soviet coal-mining operation was declared a resounding success today.

The Mortgage Bankers Association of America will hold its third and final national mortgage banking conference this year on June 7 and 8 at the Leamington Hotel in Minneapolis. Darrel M. Holt, president of the Towle Company, Minneapolis, will be chairman.
The New York Rovers of the Eastern Hockey League will not return next season, ending a one-year renaissance of the Rangers' farm team that once drew capacity crowds at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, May 28 -- The House of Commons in its 700th year asked itself today whether there was a video tube in its future.
ENTERING the office of the Weddle Tea Company at 108 Water Street is rather like finding oneself unexpectedly in an orchard full of blossoms.
ROME, May 28 -- A visit by Pope Paul VI to Poland within a year, while unlikely, cannot be entirely ruled out, Vatican sources said today.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) -- Canadian and United States Government and airline officials will meet in Quebec next week for a three-day conference on ways to streamline customs procedures.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized individual airlines today to increase the free baggage allowance for passengers.

THE Eastern Regional Championships continue this afternoon with the four-session open pair championship for the Goldman Cup. Play is at 2 P.M. and 8 P.M. today and tomorrow at the New York Hilton Hotel.

Mao Tse-tung suggested early this year that he was "getting ready to see God very soon." His remark was reported by the American journalist Edgar Snow in The New Republic Feb. 27. Mr. Snow said it was made in a four-hour interview Jan. 9 in Peking.
NEWARK, May 30 -- This city, convinced of the success of its five-month-old Neighborhood Youth Corps, the country's first, is asking the Federal Government for a larger budget.

Acme Markets, a large supermarket chain, achieved record sales in the 53 weeks ended April 3, but earnings declined from the preceding fiscal year covering 52 weeks, according to the company's report issued over the weekend.

Senator Everett Dirksen, the minority leader, and his friends in the Senate who are sponsoring the proposed constitutional amendment that will allow a state to make up one house of its legislature on a formula other than one man, one vote seem motivated in part by the fear that the national Government is becoming too powerful.
A National Labor Relations Board trial examiner has upheld the right of two Brooklyn warehousemen to seek representation from a union other than the one that has a contract with their employer.
PARIS, May 30 -- France struck a sharp new blow at cooperation within the North Atlantic alliance today by refusing to participate in military exercises next year.
The three candidates for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey appealed for support side by side yesterday morning under the watchful eye of the man each hopes to replace.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 30 -- Chile, running a neck-to-neck race with Zambia and the Soviet Union as second world producer of copper after the United States, has confirmed her intention to reach an understanding with African producers for a possible common front in future world markets.
PEKING, Monday, May 31 (Reuters) -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman denied today rumors that Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung was ill.

TOKYO, May30 -- Civic groups and opposition political leaders plan to begin one of the largest signature-collecting campaigns in Japan's history tomorrow to force the dissolution of the scandal-ridden Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly.
BUDAPEST -- Little Hungarians, up to one meter tall, can get into the Budapest International Fair for less than half price, and they do by the thousands.

NEW HAVEN, May 30 -- The five hooded men who looted the Yale University Numismatic Collection early Saturday morning chose coins they could easily sell, the temporary curator of the collection said today.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 30 (AP) -- The Texas Legislature passed and sent to Gov. John B. Connally Jr., today a highly controversial bill realigning the state's 23 Congressional districts to meet Federal court demands.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- The fastest field ever to qualify will compete before a crowd of more than 200,000 in the 49th 500-mile automobile race tomorrow. The average qualifying, speed of the 33 cars that will start rolling at 11 A.M. (noon New York time) was 156.058 miles an hour.

TOKYO, May 30 -- Special measures announced by the Bank of Japan late Friday to save the debt-ridden Yamaichi Securities Company from possible bankruptcy appeared to day to have halted uneasiness among investors that had sent the Tokyo stock market plunging to a five-year low.

The World's Fair had a banner day yesterday and recorded the largest attendance figure for a single day in its history. The attendance reached 265,568, compared with 264,552, the old record, set on Sunday, Oct. 11, 1964. On the second day of the Memorial Day weekend last year, 224,488 persons attended the fair.
KUTZTOWN, Pa, May 30 -- This quiet borough in the heart of the fertile Pennsylvania Dutch farm country paused today in its weeklong sesquicentennial celebration and observed the Sabbath.

Every year around the middle of May, the New York Mets seem to contract a peculiar form of spring fever. The symptoms include swooning under fly balls, leaving men on base, general shakiness, excessive losing and a falling sensation in the league standing.
WARSAW, May 30 -- Millions of Poles voted today in this Communist country's one-slate election.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 -- The civil rights struggle in American cities was described here today as no longer a fight against racial discrimination but as a fight against poverty, unemployment and hopelessness.

Construction has begun on an office and manufacturing building in Totowa, N.J., that will consolidate three plants now leased by Rafco Plastics, Inc., a subsidiary of the Spencer Chemical division of the Gulf Oil Corporation.
ROME, May 30 (AP) -- The Salvatorian nuns have elected a German sister, once superior of the Roman Catholic order's United States province, as their new mother general.
GAMBIER, Ohio, May 30 -- At its 137th commencement today. Kenyon College awarded degrees to 125 members of its graduating class.

LINDEN, N.J., May 30 -- For the second consecutive day Ch. Bengal Leprechaun, a 3-year-old airedale terrier from Pinos Altos, N.M., captured a best-in-show award. Today's victory was over a field of 871 in the Plainfield Kennel Club show and yesterday's came in the Monmouth County event in Oceanport, N.J.

LOS ANGELES, May 30 (UPI) -- Sandy Koufax pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 12-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today. The Dodgers eased the left-hander's task with a six-run uprising in the third inning.

Five years after the last of her devastating winds faded seaward, Hurricane Donna of 1960 is still a subject of legal dispute. Some of the damage left in her wake has just been judged an act of God that man could not have mitigated by taking prudent precautions.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP) -- Ernie Banks got three hits, including his 10th home run, and drove in two runs to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 4-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.

A South African paper (The Star, Johannesburg) has reprinted the letter of the Rev. Alton Stivers which appeared in your paper on April 24 commenting on an advertisement of the Information Service of South Africa.
LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- The British Government has received word from Peking that Mao Tse-tung, who has not been seen publicly for seven weeks, may have suffered a stroke. He is 71 years old.
The importance of the Holy Spirit to a Christian's mind, head and hands, his thoughts, love and actions, was the subject of the sermon at the 10 A.M. solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.
OTTAWA, May 30 -- Government economists expect that figures for April will show the first pause in Canada's industrial expansion in more than four years.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Phillies purchased Lew Burdette, a pitcher, from the Chicago Cubs today and asked waivers on another pitcher, Ryne Duren, for the purpose of giving him his release.
The world's largest oceangoing dry cargo barge -- a 17,000-ton, 475-foot vessel -- has been ordered by a subsidiary of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, Inc.
The sound of taps drifted over many of the nation's cemeteries yesterday. Veterans in the uniforms they wear once a year stood stiffly in salute to fluttering flags.

FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., May 30 -- New York, Long Island and Philadelphia all scored their third victories today and finished undefeated in the United States women's lacrosse tournament at Germantown Academy.
Shots fired during the robbery of a beer distributor's plant in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, Saturday night took the life of a 16-year-old employe.

RICHMOND, May 28 -- It is generally acknowledged here that repealing, the poll tax for state and local elections would probably speed the demise, or transformation, of the Byrd political organization in Virginia.
LONDON, May 30 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson met with his top economic ministers today amid numerous danger signs for Britain's economy.
BALTIMORE, May 30 (UPI) -- Jerry Adair's single drove in John Orsino from second base with the winning run in the seventh inning today as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 4-3.
PARIS, May 30 -- Lesley Turner of Australia upset top-seeded Margaret Smith, 6-3, 6-4, today to win the women's singles title in the French tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) -- Camilo Pascual, backed by homers from Zoilo Versalles and Harmon Killebrew, turned back Washington, 6-0, on four hits today to record his sixth victory without a defeat for the Minnesota Twins.

The directors of General Dynamics Corporation have authorized the redemption on July 30, the 1963, 1964 and 1965 groups of the company's convertible preference stock at $62.43 a share, including 23.9 cents of accrued dividends at the redemption date.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 (UPI) -- Bruce Crampton came the year's first triple winner on the Professional Golfers' Association tour today by taking the $87,000 Speedway Festival open tournament with a five-under-par 279 for 72 holes.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- It took the Yankees 12 innings today to beat the Chicago White Sox, 3-2; salvage something out of a hapless road trip and end a four-game losing streak, their longest of a season full of losses.

CAIRO, May 30 (Reuters) -- Arab heads of government today ended their second conference here this year after five days of almost continuous wrangling over a unified political and military stand against Israel.

Max Roach and his quintet and the singer Abbey Lincoln were heard in a jazz concert Saturday night at Town Hall called "A Night of Cafe Au Go Go." Cafe Au Go Go is a Greenwich Village night club where Miss Lincoln and Mr. Roach's group have just concluded an engagement.

Starting tomorrow, residents of southeastern Queens and Nassau County are being told to limit their watering of lawns -- but they can water them every day, instead of just one day a week, the New York City limit.

HOUSTON, May 30 (AP) -- Hank Aaron s two-run homer and bases-empty homers by Felipe Alou and Mack Jones led the Milwaukee Braves to a 6-5 victory over the Houston Astros today as the Astros' winning streak ended at four games.
PURCHASE, N.Y., May 30 -- Herb Pennell scored five goals today in leading Connecticut to a 10-7 polo victory over New York in the opening game of the season at the Blind Brook Polo Club.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 30 -- The first advice given by General of the Army Hugo Penasco Alvim to his United States deputy, Lieut. Gen. Bruce Palmer Jr., was characteristically forthright.
THOMPSON, Conn., May 30 (AP) -- Gaston Andrey of Framingham, Mass., driving a Lotus-Alfa, set a Formula Libre record at Thompson Raceway today with an average speed of 71.95 miles an hour.
LONDON, May 30 -- Doubts about the authenticity of Goya's portrait of the Duke of Wellington are being raised a week after the painting's dramatic return to the National Gallery.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 -- Steel mills may be facing their second consecutive summer without a market letdown. By the end of last week, nothing in the order picture indicated a drop in steel shipments in either July or August.
Chancellor Erhard's fourth visit to the United States in eighteen months comes at a time when the Western allies are increasingly troubled by the problems of Germany and Europe.

Only a few hours after the 1964-65 musical season officially ended yesterday afternoon (with the New York philharmonic's final subscription concert in Philharmonic Hall), the summer season of outdoor events began last night with a concert by the Naumberg Orchestra on the Central Park Mall.

It seems both unnecessary and arbitrary for Water Commissioner D'Angelo to turn off the fountains that use recirculated water. These fountains should be turned on again and, furthermore, put in full working order where needed.
"Dem Parts," a song in the Chrysler Pavilion show at the World's Fair, has drawn a sharp protest from the state branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 30 (UPI) -- Graham Hill of Britain, driving a B.R.M., won the Monaco Grand Prix for the third straight year today with an average speed of 74.29 miles an hour, a record.
"Funny Girl," starring Barbra Streisand and Sydney Chaplin, is the second musical to raise its admission scale for the second time. The other was "Hello, Dolly!"

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 30 -- The Government-controlled Israeli radio broadcast a report that the United States State Department deplored the use of force by Israel in Friday's reprisal raids into Jordan and immediately followed it with an item on the continued bombing by United States aircraft of targets in North Vietnam.
NORWALK, Conn. -- A double-header took place here recently. The sport was not baseball, but fishing, and the angler was Leslie Bloom of Norwalk, 10 years old.

ALBANY, May 30 -- The budgetary impasse that paralyzed the Legislature a month ago has prompted a former New York fiscal official to propose some major changes in the state's financial planning system.
MOSCOW, May 30 -- A 25-year-old Soviet flying instructor was reported today to have beaten the world altitude record for women set four years ago by Jacqueline Cochran of the United States.
A policeman was threatened by an angry mob at 2:40 A.M. yesterday in the same neighborhood of the Bronx where another patrolman was beaten by a crowd 10 days ago.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Unrelenting pressure from the White House for the President's legislative program has had a side effect -- the creation of a huge traffic jam in Congress.

Thousands of families taking their cue from the weather man and the calendar, have invaded the suburbs in the quest of their dream houses. The initial question they may ask themselves is whether their dreams are in step with economic reality.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 (AP) -- Bob Skinner dropped a high fly by a pinch-hitter, Willie Mays, with the bases loaded and two out in the 10th inning today, allowing Frank Linzy to score a run that gave the San Francisco Giants a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Washington's space-age children are proving that iron horses that crawled along the rails a century ago can be just as engrossing as rockets that whiz through the stratosphere at 18,000 miles an hour.

LONDON, May 30 (UPI) -- Thousands of cheering Britons welcomed Queen Elizabeth when she returned home today from West Germany. A crowd began to gather at dawn in the Channel port of Portsmouth to greet the royal yacht Britannia.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 30 -- Overtaking the Penn Athletic Club today in the last 200 yards, the New York A.C. won the senior eight-oared race for the Capt. James H. Hughes Cup and top honors in the Memorial Day regatta of the New York Rowing Association.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Who killed Mary Etheredge?
BONN, May 30 -- The United States Ambassador, George C. McGhee, declared today that the time had come to concede that the Germans had earned back the respect and confidence of the civilized World.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP) -- John Wyatt walked Lenny Green with two out and the bases loaded in the 11th inning, forcing in the winning run that gave the Boston Red Sox a 3-2 decision today over the Kansas City Athletics.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk gave United States backing tonight to a plebiscite in the Dominican Republic on a new constitution. He said it was "possible and desirable" that the Dominican people should be asked to choose a constitution in such a manner.

Affectionately, "a real lady" to her owner, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs, will be the only mare in today's $112,600 Metropolitan Handicap at Aqueduct. The mile race is the first part of racing's handicap triple crown.

LONDON, May 30 -- Patrick Gordon Walker, the former Foreign Secretary, said tonight it would be "a major error" for the United States to "lose patience" in Vietnam and bomb Hanoi or other industrial targets in the North.
MOSCOW, May 30 -- Yiddish-vaudeville artists in the Soviet Union are becoming bolder in their comments on the Jewish scene.

WITH that splendid documentary, "Plisetskaya Dances," a recent Soviet tenant at the Cameo, that theater is retaining its terpsichorean motif with still another documentary but of considerably less impact.

Hope that this year the Legislature might at last create a commission of distinguished citizens to study New York State's uniquely illiberal and unrealistic divorce law has now gone the disappointing way of many hopes for this session. Virtually unchanged since it was adopted in 1787 -- with adultery as the only grounds allowable -- this divorce law has been through the years a kind of sacred cow of the Legislature.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -- The Indianpolis Motor Speedway was unusually quiet today for a place that will be jammed with about a quarter of a million racing fans tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, May 30 (AP) -- Judy Garland left Cincinnati today after a tempestous session last night in which about 1,000 persons besieged her dressing room after she broke off a concert because of illness.
GENEVA, May 30 -- The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany announced today that it had allocated $130 million in West German reparations payments over 11 years.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 30 -- Few people have seen much of President Johnson during his Memorial Day vacation. But tell that to the cattle.
Once upon a time there was an attractive receptionist in the showroom and the boss looked at her one day with fond eyes. Not long afterwards, they married and she began studying fashion design.

By May's end the urgency of spring begins to abate and the fecundity of summer is everywhere. The sprouting is done. The canopies of chlorophyll are spread and silently transforming the sun's energy into food for root and stem. Early blossoms fade, the ovules are fertilized and seeds are fattening. Eggs hatch. Nestlings appear and the noise of insects makes the air vibrant.

LONDON, May 21 -- On a seven-hour stopover in London, Secretary McNamara sought to reassure Britain and other NATO allies that the United States sought no unfair advantage in the sale of arms. He said purchases by any member of the alliance should be guided by price and quality.

No more heartening a case can be made for democracy than the object lesson provided by the lopsided vote in the New York State Assembly reversing its earlier rejection of a stronger code of ethics for members of the Legislature.

More than 150 off-duty policemen picketed in civilian clothes for two hours on the Lower East Side yesterday as a protest against recent demonstrations by civil-rights groups against Lieut. Thomas R. Gilligan.
BALTIMORE, May 30 -- The Baltimore Sunpapers rejected today a proposal by the American Newspaper Guild to submit all issues in its 44-day-old strike to final and binding arbitration.

HAVANA, May 30 -- Cuba expects to sell about a fifth of this year's good sugar harvest to non-Communist countries, but she continues to depend on the Soviet Union as the outlet for the bulk of her main cash crop.

The Toho Cinema, on 45th Street west of Broadway, which opened Jan. 22, 1963, to show Japanese films, will close next Monday. According to Ryu Yasutake, manager of the theater, "the Toho Cinema was operated for the period initially contemplated and fulfilled its purpose."

LISBON, May 30 -- The Portuguese political police have broken up the underground network of the Mozambique Liberation Front in Lourenco Marques, capital of Portugal's sprawling East African possession, it was announced here today.
A self-exiled, 108-pound Vietnamese law professor has ended a fast of almost 10 weeks in a Brooklyn Unitarian Church.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 30 (AP) -- A jet aircraft carried 30 scientists and a million dollars worth of delicate instruments in a race with a total eclipse of the sun over the South Pacific today.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 -- "They may not have won it for us, but they made it a lot easier."

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 31 -- Two weeks after a state of siege and other drastic measures were imposed to break the power of leftist labor organizations, Bolivia's military junta has established tight control over this poverty-ridden country.

MONTREAL, May 31 (UPI) -- Toe Blake, who at one time during the last National Hockey League campaign offered to bet a sportswriter $1,000 he wouldn't be back next winter, signed a one-year contract today to coach the Montreal Canadiens for his 11th season.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 31 -- A contingent of Young Americans for Freedom was prevented from marching in today's Memorial Day parade.
Theodore W. Kheel has urged the Legislature to pass a measure limiting the number of new workers in the Port of New York.

PARIS, May 31 -- Maria Callas, who began a series of five guest performances of Bellini's "Norma" at the Paris Opera against medical advice two weeks ago, was unable to get through the final performance on Saturday.

Gun Bow thrilled the biggest crowd ever to attend a thoroughbred horse race in this state in winning the $111,600 Metropolitan Mile yesterday at Aqueduct. With 73,375 customers looking on, the million-dollar horse that runs in the silks of the Gedney Farm scored a neck victory over Raymond Guest's Chieftain, with Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Affectionately next in the field of eight.
BOGALUSA, La., May 31 (AP) -- State troopers broke up street fighting between Negroes and whites today after having been decoyed by exploding firecrackers.
WEST BEND, Wis., May 31 -- Students in Wisconsin and France talked for 40 minutes today in the first trans-Atlantic linkup of classrooms by live television.
Mayor Wagner yesterday made three speeches, reviewed a parade, dedicated a memorial -- and still said he did not know whether he wanted the job for another term.

The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has suggested that regulations be changed to allow Federally chartered savings and loan associations to make a nominal service charge against small, inactive savings accounts.
STANTON, Del., May 31 (AP) -- Gerard S. Smith's Duende won the $26,750 Polly Drummond Stakes today at Delaware Park with a strong finish.

WHEN the late Herman Hickman resigned as Yale's football coach, he thereby severed formal connections with the sport he had graced with distinction for more than two decades as a player, scout, coach and analyst. So this jolliest and most literate of hillbillies was finally able to witness a football game in the unfamiliar role of a civilian, shorn of all responsibilities.

Court reform leaders yesterday accepted Mayor Wagner's contention that the Mayor should name at least a majority of a committee screening would-be judges. The actual appointments would be made by the Mayor.
NEW DELHI, May 31 -- Sand in your rice, sawdust in your tea, chalk in your wheat and blotting paper in your curds -- these are a few of the surprises behind the grocer's smile here.

The fall, winter and even spring of discontent that erupted this year in a hot academic climate at the University of California will be gauged by the Columbia Broadcasting System on a news special, "The Berkeley Rebels."

ST. LOUIS, May 31 (AP) -- The Southern Christian Leadership Conference, headed by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., is recruiting college students here to tutor Negro high school students in 10 Alabama cities this summer.

ST. LOUIS, May 31 -- The Federal Office of Economic Opportunity was accused here today of "fostering class struggle" in the country's cities and of "creating tensions" among the urban poor by insisting on participation by impoverished citizens in the antipoverty program.

CRITICISM of specific makes and models of automobiles, including products of General Motors, Ford, Chrysler and American Motors was a feature last night of an excellent documentary by National Educational Television on the subject of highway fatalities. The program was seen on Channel 13.
The Bathgate Avenue neighborhood in the central Bronx, where angry Negro crowds have twice menaced white policemen in recent days, has undergone a marked transformation since World War II.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 31 -- Eddie Yowell decided to put blinkers on Mrs. Ben Cohen's Hail to All today for the sixth modern running of the $133,700 Jersey Derby and the move paid off.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- It was just too much to expect the Mets to win a double-header away from home today, although they had won the opener, 5-2, and had led by two runs going into the bottom of the eighth and by one run going into the last of the ninth of the second game.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Export-Import Bank announced today a series of changes designed to liberalize the present system of export credit insurance and guarantees.
NAPLES, Italy, May 31 (AP) -- Australia's Southern Cross II won the opening race in the world 5.5-Meter sailing championships today with American yachts taking second and third places.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 1 -- Government troops were moving today through the hills of central Vietnam in search of the Communist forces that gave them the worst beating of the year.
GENEVA, May 31 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, was elected president today of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture.
James Bond imitations are in the works all over the world right now, but moviegoers still want to see the real thing.
BONN, May 31 -- The Berlin wall was reopened today for the first of 400,000 West Berliners who are expected to visit relatives in East Berlin during the Whitsun holidays.

BOSTON, May 31 (UPI) -- Dennis Bennett, the ailing Boston Red Sox southpaw, gained his first American League victory today by beating the Los Angeles Angels, 3-0, in the second game of a double-header.
NEW DELHI, May 23 -- The "camp" movement, already firmly established on New York's East Side and in Greenwich Village, has pitched its tent in India's capital.

LONDON, May 31 -- The remains of Anne Mowbray, Duchess of York and child bride of Richard, one of the princes murdered in the Tower of London in the 15th century, were reinterred tonight in Westminster Abbey.
TAFT, Calif., May 31 -- The hot wind was arching clouds of dust across the arid plains here this weekend and the temperature soared to 110 degrees in the sun.
BONN, May 31 -- West German businessmen are viewing with avid interest Bonn's new political offensive in Eastern Europe.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 31 -- A deep rift in Kenya's Cabinet was brought into the open today when the Commerce Minster and four other Members of Parliament called on Vice President Oginga Odinga to stop attacking Government ministers or resign.
The Educational Alliance on the Lower East Side believes that it is conducting the most successful racially integrated settlement house program in the United States.

IT is arguable whether cooking is more art than science, or vice versa. But art will definitely prevail at the lesson to be held Wednesday at the Helen Worth Cooking School, 106 East 31st Street, from 7 to 10 P.M.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The United States threw its support today behind a Brazilian proposal to set up a three-man committee of prominent diplomats to seek a political solution of the Dominican crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Inter-American Development Bank announced today the formation of the first "consultative group" of foreign countries and international institutions to help in the development program of a Latin American country.

PARIS, May 31 -- The United States proposed today the formation of a select committee of four or five North Atlantic allies empowered to improve strategic nuclear planning and consultation on the use of nuclear weapons.
A bill that would have allowed the police to give a motorist 48 hours in which to repair a single defective automobile light without being fined has been vetoed by Governor Rockefeller.

LONDON -- Eighteen-year-old Rory Davis, an American who was voted the most popular debutante last year by certain of her peers, could be described as switched on, swinging and with it. But no one ever would.

ALGIERS, May 31 -- Foreign Ministry sources said tonight that Algeria had received 37 affirmative replies to date to invitations for the second conference of African and Asian leaders opening here June 29. The first such parley was held in Bandung, Indonesia, in 1955.

Harold S. Prince, president of the League of New York Theaters since March of last year, has resigned, effective June 15. He announced yesterday that he was relinquishing the post as head of the organization of Broadway producers and theater owners to campaign for the election of Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican candidate for Mayor.
Plans for further capital expansion by American business were raised considerably in the first quarter of 1965 with a 9 per cent increase in capital outlays over the level in the preceeding quarter.
The election of Stanley B. Erlandson as vice president of the United States Tobacco Company was announced yesterday.

An admiring mob rushed Senator Robert F. Kennedy and knocked him down yesterday minutes after a monument to President Kennedy was unveiled at Brooklyn's Grand Army Plaza. Mr. Kennedy, shoved off his feet as he walked from the monument site to Flatbush Avenue, was helped up and went on through the crowd of 20,000.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 31 -- All technical problems threatening the scheduled launching of Gemini 4 on Thursday morning have been cleared up, NASA officials said today.

The New York Yankees tried to reverse their ebbing fortunes yesterday by sending their oldest and youngest pitchers against the Detroit Tigers in a double-header. But the results were as extreme as the age spread.

A leading international banker has warned that if Eurodollar interest rates continue to rise, foreign dollar holders -- and possibly some Americans -- might be induced to shift abroad their investments from the United States.

ROME, May 31 -- Guido Carli, governor of the Bank of Italy, urged today that nations finance international payments deficits through common administration of foreign-exchange reserves. He opposed a French proposal to return to the gold standard or a system of variable exchange rates.
Markets Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta announced yesterday that he was preparing new rules to combat unethical practices in the sale of pro-packaged meats.

BOSTON, May 31 (AP) -- The carrier Wasp, the main recovery ship for the Gemini astronauts, sailed for its station east of the Bahamas today with a novel sighting test aboard for the orbiting spacemen.

The appointment of James H. McInerney as vice president and manager for "open" states for the National Distillers Products Company was announced yesterday. National Distillers Products is the liquor division of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Republican leaders, including the party's last four Presidential candidates, will meet here tomorrow to draft policy statements on Vietnam and other subjects.
NEWARK, May 31 -- A light vote is expected in New Jersey's primary tomorrow despite a three-way contest for the Republican gubernatorial nomination.
CHICAGO, May 31 -- Every four minutes someone in this country dies prematurely because of cigarette smoking, Dr. Luther L. Terry, United States Surgeon General, said here today.
PARIS, May 31 -- Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo ended a four-day visit to France tonight. He had conferred with President de Gaulle and leading members of the French Government.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 31 (UPI) -- Terry's Secret was ruled first today in the $57,500 Will Rogers Stakes when the stewards disqualified Carpenter's Rule as the winner in the Hollywood Park feature witnessed by 64,000.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Senate will shift from the domestic to the foreign this week with a major debate over American policy toward the United Nations.

BRUSSELS, May 31 -- With per capita production of goods and services four times greater is some areas of the European Common Market than in others, the six-nation bloc has outlined a new plan for closing the gaps between advanced and backward areas.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., May 31 (AP) -- Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that Alabama, in time of racial strife, "suffers not so much from the violence of bad people as from the silence of good people."
SALT LAKE CITY, May 31 (AP) -- A 23-year-old University of California graduate student was rescued tonight from a cold, watery mountain cave four miles southeast of Salt Lake City.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Ten Soviet scientists have arrived in the United States to tour installations handling radioactive waste disposal operations for radioactive waste.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 31 -- The White House released today two reports indicating slight reductions in Government employment both at home and overseas.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators swept a double-header from the Kansas City Athletics, 5-2 and 5-1, today with four-hit pitching by Pete Richert and three homers winning the second game.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Members of the National Association of Securities Dealers will be able to use the completely automated central bookkeeping system of the Midwest Stock Exchange under an agreement between the two organizations announced today.

STUTTGART, Germany, May 29 -- Prokofiev's "Romeo and Juliet" has become a popular ballet in Europe. Within the last few months versions have been produced in Hamburg, London, Copenhagen, two days ago, and, tonight in Stuttgart.
BALTIMORE, May 31 (AP) -- Thirty-five persons were injured tonight, none seriously, when some aerial bombs from an amusement park fireworks display landed in the spectator area and exploded.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Archibald MacLeish, addressing the International Publishers Association, said today that the conception of the United States had changed in the minds of many people in recent weeks.
PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) -- I.W. Abel will be sworn in tomorrow as president of the United Steelworkers of America, ending the 12-year rule of David J. McDonald.
ST. LOUIS, May 31 (UPI) -- After 47 years as a nun, Sister Francetta Barberis has hung her habit in the closet.
GREENWICH, N.Y., May 31 -- Along the Battenkill River the term "Fishing for Fun" is much in use these days when talk turns to the state's plans for this potentially great trout stream.

Three men were arraigned yesterday on assault charges that grew out of a Queens street fight Sunday night, when two of the men were said to have tried to protect a young woman motorist from the third.

The line of succession after the Vice President, in case of the President's death, is discussed by Donald Young in "American Roulette: The History and Dilemma of the Vice President." He contends that the Secretary of State and not the Speaker of the House should be next in line for succession.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Administration is seeking to encourage a student-to-people program to help the people of South Vietnam.
MOSCOW, May 31 -- The wartime chief of the Soviet Navy, who was dismissed nearly 10 years ago by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, has emerged from obscurity.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Four finalists, two of them residents of New York, were selected today in the National Symphony Orchestra's Merriweather Post contest.

Caldor, Inc., a chain of discount department stores, has leased the former plant of the Armstrong Rubber Company, a complex of buildings on a 44-acre site at the Merritt Parkway and Route 7, Norwalk, Conn.
Your editorial of May 21 "The Lesson of Santo Domingo" finds unfortunate the discrepancy between policy enunciated in Washington and American action in the Dominican Republic.

POTATOES come heavily and steadily to market throughout the year and can generally be counted upon to be both available and cheap. This year, however, things have been a little bit different. Bad weather in the West and Middle West cut the crop down to such an extent that this normally potato-happy area was forced to import supplies from Maine and Long Island.

A Police Department spokesman said yesterday that an initial investigation had failed to turn up any evidence of alleged "intimidation" by patrolmen to get lawyers and defendants in courts to sign petitions opposing a civilian review board.

ABOARD THE CORAL SEA, in the South China Sea, May 27 -- "Tell the driver of that Phantom if he bolters again he'll have to leave the penalty box," said the air control officer. "He's in a low state and if we don't trap him this time he'll have to take a drink from a whale."
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Seafarers International Union of North America today authorized its president, Paul Hall, to continue merger talks with the National Maritime Union.
Gains in earnings for the quarter ended April 30 were reported yesterday by Marshall Field Co., a large department store in Chicago.
UNION CITY, N.J., May 31 -- A stocky, gray-haired manufacturer of coats and suits here has decided to establish his own free training school for needle trades workers.

Directors for "Arms and the Man'" and "A Raisin in the Sun," both to be performed during the six-week season in the Music Grove of Brooklyn's Prospect Park, were named yesterday by Kenneth N. Whitlock, president and executive producer of the Prospect Park Summer Theater Committee.
DEVON, Pa., May 31 -- This was Kathy Kusner Night at the Devon Horse Show even though it was not listed on the program.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (AP) -- A prominent Illinois Democratic official was killed and one of his sons was injured fatally today in the crash of a light plane near Weir Cook Municipal Airport.
The B.V.D. Company is making plans to acquire the Palm Beach Company.
A former Argentine actor-director who came to New York seven years ago is guiding a burgeoning Spanish theater here.
The A.C. Gilbert Company hopes to sing a different financial tune this year, and it will draw on the musical talents of four mop-haired salesmen from Liverpool to help swing it.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) -- Donn Clendenon tripled in two runs and scored himself in a five-run third inning today as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Philadelphia Phillies 5-2, for their 11th consecutive victory.

CLEVELAND, May 31 (AP) -- Bruce Howard threw Joe Azcue's sacrifice bunt into left field, enabling Vic Davalillo to score from second with the winning run in the ninth as the Cleveland Indians beat the Chicago White Sox, 4-3, in the second game today.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., May 31 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower unveiled today the Freedoms Foundation's American Credo Monument, calling it "the essence of the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence in monument form."
FORT WASHINGTON, Pa., May 31 -- The United States No. 1 team defeated the United States No. 2 team, 10-2, today as the three-day women's national lacrosse tournament ended at the Germantown Academy.
ALBANY, May 31 -- The fate of an omnibus judgeship bill for New York City is in doubt.

The fumes from diesel buses in the Port Authority's midtown terminal are so strong they "penetrate clothes, pocketbook, hair and even one's insides," a commuter wrote recently to the city's Department of Air Pollution Control.
Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany arrived yesterday to receive an honorary doctorate today from Columbia University.

GENEVA, May 31 -- Australia has formally applied for an exemption from the rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to accord preferential treatment to some imports from underdeveloped countries.

LOS ANGELES, May 31 (AP) -- Joey Jay halted Cincinnati's six-game losing streak by pitching a three-hitter today as the Reds whipped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-1, in the second game of a double-header.
POLEI KRONG, South Vietnam, May 28 -- When United States bombs began to fall this week in Kontum Province, mountain tribesmen left their homes and began walking to safety.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., May 31 -- Jimmy Wynne, the bearded Miamian whose designing ideas are revolutionizing hull lines, completed his voyage to victory today in the roundtrip Gateway Marathon between West Palm Beach and Lucaya-Freeport in the Bahamas.
VIENNA -- A tower greenhouse with the aura of a science-fiction enterprise has lately become a somewhat puzzling addition to the Viennese skyline.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 31 -- Political violence in the interior spurred efforts today to neutralize the Presidential Palace, where shooting by the Dominican factions continued.
BALTIMORE, May 31 (AP) -- Sam Bowens's lead-off homer run in the ninth inning gave the Baltimore Orioles a 5-4 victory and a spilt of their doubleheader with the Minnesota Twins today.
Representative John V. Lindsay's mayoral campaign trail took some bumpy turns in Queens yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 -- Jim Clark of Scotland rode a rear-mounted Lotus-Ford to a record-shattering victory today in the 49th Indianapolis Speedway 500-mile race.
ROBERT PEN WARREN has been pursuing a valuable teach-out. He is the pupil. The United States citizens whose skin is dark are his teachers and their leaders are his special lecturers.
SANA, Yemen, May 26 -- There is a new spirit of nationalism and independence in republican Yemen.
A woman detective picked a prosecutor's pocket in Queens Criminal Court yesterday to demonstrate how "jostlers" -- the police terminology for pickpockets -- work.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31 -- "Only" 27,110 fans turned out tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, where the game is trotting and pacing, played as at Aqueduct with mutuel machines, but with differently gaited horses.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 1 (Reuters) -- A Hanoi broadcast said today that 45 United States Marines were killed by the Vietcong Thursday night and early Friday morning during an attack at Thanh Mountain in Tamky district between Quangnam and Quangngai provinces.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 (AP) -- Gaylord Perry was touched for two first-inning singles, then pitched no-hit ball over the final 8 2-3 innings today as the San Francisco Giants ran their winning streak to five by defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-1.
SOMERVILLE, N.J., May 31 (AP) -- A young West German won the 22d annual Kugler-Anderson Memorial 50-mile bicycle race today in the record time of 1 hour 53 minutes 21 seconds.

AZUSA, Calif., May 31 (AP) -- Members of the International Association of Machinists picketed Aerojet-General Corporation's rocket-engine and torpedo plant in a light rain today after going on strike at 12:01 A.M.
Exhibitors heartened by Sunday's record attendance at the World's Fair said yesterday that it would take a: good many more such days before they could turn the red ink black.
Gilberto Gerena Valentin sat up in his bed in Room 701 of Manhattan Avenue Hospital the other day and said acidly:
DETROIT, May 31 (AP) -- The tempo of atttomobile production is expected to pick up tomorrow after the long Memorial Day weekend.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Another school year is ending in Washington, too, and report cards are out. It seems a long time since the term opened last September.
The Weather Bureau confirmed yesterday what New Yorkers already knew: May was a hot, dry month.

THE four-session Goldman man Open Pair Championship at the Eastern Regionals ended Sunday night in a victory for Fred Bickel and Ronald Rosenberg, both of New York. Second were Philip Feldesman, of Queens Village, Queens, and John Solodar, of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- If Congress ends laws that ban the union shop a "new wave of controversy and bitter labor disputes" will result in the 19 states that have such laws, the National Right-to-Work Committee predicted tonight.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 30 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia starts a hectic month of diplomatic exchanges this week, including three state visits.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Whether or not the Conservative party decides to run its own candidates in the contest for the three highest offices in New York City, its attitude toward John V. Lindsay was always certain to be negative. Like himself, it is an embodiment of splinter party politics.

Administration officials have not yet determined where they went wrong in estimating the amount of taxes to be paid by individuals. The Treasury has collected $1.5 billion more than expected, but this huge windfall remains a puzzle. Some officials argue that it reflects a surprise, one-shot rise in individual incomes while others think that the increase in incomes may turn out to be permanent.

LIGONIER, Pa., May 31 (UPI) -- Bobby Nichols, the Professional Golfers' Association champion, registered a par 4 today on the 18th hole of the Laurel Valley Golf Club course to beat Ken Venturi by a stroke in their National Golf Day target-score match.
THOMPSON, Conn., May 31 (AP) -- Michael Goth of Pound Ridge, N.Y., driving a Cobra, was timed at 70.04 miles an hour today to turn in the fastest time of the day at Thompson Raceway.
The United Steelworkers of America reached basic economic agreements last night with five major aluminum producers.
A total of 125 industrial waterside plants were built or expanded in the first quarter of this year, compared with 79 in the last quarter of 1964.

On the initiative of Britain's Harold Wilson, the summit meeting of the seven-nation European Free Trade Association has decided to seek consultations with the six-nation European Economic Community. The object is to bridge the gap between the Seven and the Six.
The police circulated yesterday a composite drawing of a tall, cross-eyed man wanted in the fatal shooting of a 16-year-old boy last Saturday night during a Brooklyn holdup.
TEWKESBURY, England, May 31 -- "Meds" and "progs" are battling in this divided town of 7,300 persons about 100 miles west of London.
HONOLULU, May 31 (AP) -- Scientists who flew out of American Samoa to view yesterday's solar eclipse arrived in Honolulu today pleased with the preliminary results of their experiments.
This week will be the lull before the storm in corporate securities sales.

The valedictorian of Columbia College was booed yesterday when he criticized student political activities. Long-time faculty members said it was the first such response to a valedictorian's address that they could recall.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 31 -- Two civilians were killed and four were wounded in the Israeli sector of Jerusalem today during a 20-minute exchange of gunfire with the Jordanian sector.
