PARIS, May 31 -- Robert M. O'Kane, director of schools for children of United States servicemen in the European area, announced his resignation over the weekend. He explained by telephone today from Karlsruhe, Germany, that his basic reason was the attitude of Congress and the Defense Department.

Arthur Krock in his May 13 column fears my proposal to establish an administrative counsel of Congress, modeled after the Scandinavian ombudsman, would lead to a "bureaucratic explosion" because of Parkinson's Law.
OTTAWA, May 31 -- A Soviet Embassy attache said today that Russian diplomats in Canada were followed wherever they went and that the embassy offices were bugged."

STAMFORD, Conn., May 31 -- At 7:03 o'clock this morning, the Vanguard 32 Class F sloop Frolic, owned by Herman D. Segel of Mamaroneck, N.Y., slipped across the finish line, the last of 153 yachts that had begun the Storm Trysail Club's 20th Block Island race late Friday afternoon.

MOSCOW, May 31 (AP) -- Moscow theatrical impresarios are hoodwinking provincial audiences with stand-ins of famous stars and tape-recorded voices, the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia charged today.

Shares of companies with large overseas interests made small gains on the London stock market yesterday. Buyers were active in the hope that the Chancellor of the Exchequer would make a concession on corporation taxing.
Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara indicated yesterday that Fort Slocum, an Army post near New Rochelle, N.Y., might be made available for a Job Corps training center.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 31 -- Unless Congress or the Supreme Court beats them to it, Texas voters will have another opportunity to eliminate what President Johnson calls "the shame of Texas" -- the $1.75 tax on voting.

It is ironic that Mayor Wagner announced the building of the Lower Manhattan Expressway at the time of the White House Conference on Natural Beauty. The conference emphasized the importance of building a more dignified environment, but the present expressway design would leave "economic and social blight," to use the Mayor's own words of December 1962. [Editorial May 27.]
AN 11-year-old and her family were discussing summer plans over Sunday dinner recently when the girl announced, "You know when I'm at camp, there are certain things I don't talk about."

BOSTON -- Boston's aristocratic old establishment is still dedicated to hard work, education and the pursuit of perfection and truth, but there are moments along the Charles River when the Puritans are not quite so staid and proper as they once were.

Secretary Rusk says that the United States would support a plebiscite on "a new constitution" for the Dominican Republic. Whether or not a new constitution is necessary to supplant the 1963 Constitution, the important point is that, as Mr. Rusk suggests, the Dominicans must be permitted to decide for themselves what kind of constitution and what kind of government it is that they want.
In the intensifying game of musical chairs in which New York nightclubs engage, three recently vacated nightspots have blossomed anew, each with its own gimmick.

PANAMA, May 31 -- The status of the United States military base in the Canal Zone, like all other aspects of Panama's relations with the united States, is being reviewed in current negotiations, Foreign Minister Fernando Eleta said today.

Vowing to "bring the La Guardia-Javits traditions to City Hall," Representative John V. Lindsay yesterday introduced the co-chairmen of his mayoral campaign -- Senator Jacob K. Javits and Mrs. Fiorello H. La Guardia, widow of the former Mayor.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 1 -- Syria is in conflict with the United Arab Republic on how to deal with the Palestine issue.
Recent editorials of The Times, particularly "The Lesson of Santo Domingo" (May 21) places in its proper perspective the issue of reactionary militarism and Communism versus Latin America.
James M. Roche, a 58-year-old executive vice president, was elected president yesterday of the General Motors Corporation, the world's largest industrial concern.
In what seemed at first glance to be a paradox, aluminum apparently had an effect yesterday on copper prices.

BERLIN, June 1 (AP) -- East German demonstrators invaded the United States military mission in Potsdam today, tore the American flag off its pole and damaged the building, the East German press agency A.D.N. said.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 1 -- Elliott Roosevelt was elected Mayor of Miami Beach tonight.
ALBANY, June 1 -- The proposed new code of ethics for legislators and public officials was softened once more today.
United Air Lines announced yesterday it had entered into agreements for the sale of $175 million of 20-year, 5 per cent notes to institutional investors.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 1 -- The Des Moines Register proposed today that high-level Russians make another farm tour of the United States.
Allan Shivers, Governor of Texas from 1949 to 1957, was appointed yesterday as a director of the Celanese Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 2 -- The Organization of American States, in a renewed attempt to resolve the Dominican crisis, voted early today to send a three-man committee to Santo Domingo to mediate the political dispute.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 1 -- David T. Gibbons, a former District Court judge, was named tonight as a Democratic candidate for District Attorney of Nassau County.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Johnson said today he welcomed debate and criticism of his foreign policies, but indicated that he would not change the course he has set in Vietnam and the Dominican Republic.
Representative William Fitts Ryan charged yesterday that New York City had fallen down on the job in screening applicants for the Job Corps, the Federally sponsored antipoverty program for youths.
BERLIN, June 1 (AP) -- An East German, whose escape caused the jailing of two West Berliners in the Soviet sector, was sentenced today to three years' imprisonment by a West Berlin court.

Two groups will benefit from the baseball game between the New York Mets and the San Francisco Giants at Shea Stadium next Wednesday and from buffet suppers on the stadium's Press Level Terrace before the game.

WARSAW, June 1 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, first Secretary of Poland's Communist party, polled 99.3 per cent of the votes in the Warsaw workers' district, where he was running in Sunday's Parliamentary elections.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that there were any number of Democrats who could defeat Representative John V. Lindsay if he himself decided not to run for re-election.

MANCHESTER, England, June 1 (UPI) -- Margaret Smith the favorite from Australia, got little more than a workout today as she ousted Jean Wilson of England, 6-0, 6-0, in the first round of the Northern lawn tennis tournament.

New York Mailers Union No. 6 announced yesterday that it had "broken off" contract negotiations with seven of the city's daily newspapers. It asked for help from its national leadership in overcoming an impasse on job security.
POHAKULOA, Hawaii, May 31 -- Deception practiced by wildlife experts here on a slope of Mauna Kea is helping to spare Hawaii's official state bird, the nene, from extinction.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Dr. Jeremiah Stamler, the Chicago Health Department's heart expert who tried unsuccessfully to halt last week's hearings by the House Committee on Un-American Acitivities here, met with Dr. Eric oldberg, the board president, today.

Arthur Weisberg, bassoonist, played a program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night with impeccable musicianship and rare beauty of tone. What is more, he had the help of five assisting artists of his own caliber.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Seafarers International Union took steps today to avert a nationwide maritime strike on June 15.
ALBANY, June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller signed without ceremony this afternoon a bill that will virtually end capital punishment in New York State.
THE last time I innocently entered into hand-to-hand combat with a lake trout was while testing the validity of Jack Knight's Solunar Tables on Lake Keuka in the Finger Lakes.
The confessions in which three Cubans allegedly admitted having fired a bazooka toward the United Nations last Dec. 11 were ruled invalid yesterday.
United States production of steel increased last week for the second consecutive week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
STUTTGART, Germany, May 20 -- The most popular choreographer in Germany today is unquestionably George Balanchine. He has ballets in the repertory of most of the major German ballet companies.
Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, former Allied Supreme Commander in Europe, was elected yesterday as a director of Federated Department Stores, Inc.

Bertram D. Wolfe, author of "Three Who Made a Revolution," has a new book on Dial's schedule for June 11. It is "Marxism: 100 Years in the Life of a Doctrine" which attempts to answer such questions as: what was the original Marxism -- national or international; did it affirm defensism, defeatism, or pacifism; democracy or dictatorship?

One group of Americans increased the number of its young people in colleges and professional schools from 124,000 to 233,000 between 1947 and 1961. This same group multiplied the number of its wage-earners making more than $4,000 a year in the most recent census by ten to twenty times over a decade earlier, jumping in New York alone from 11,000 such wage-earners to nearly 200,000.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Following are the highlights of President Johnson's news conference today:

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- A lawyer for a dissident stockholder said today he would prove that a majority of the directors of the Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation was being kept in the dark concerning a merger with Armour Co., the Chicago meat-packing concern.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Administration spokesmen urged flexibility today in legislation controling patent and licensing rights to inventions resulting from Federally financed research and development contracts.

" THIS education is ruining our Negroes. They're demanding equality." Little did James K. Vardaman, Mississippi politician and rabid segregationist, know how right he was when he spoke these words some 60 years ago. The social revolution now proceeding by fits and starts in this country is undoubtedly led by educated Negroes.
ALBANY, June 1 -- The Senate defeated tonight a bill that would have restored power over the hiring of longshoremen to the waterfront unions and the shippers.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday the election of F. Mark Garlinghouse as a vice president, effective July 1.

Brazil has overcome the inflationary virus. The steep climb in prices, which was so chronic and crippling that it came to be known as "the Brazilian disease," has been halted. This development has been accompanied by the disappearance of inflationary psychology which contributed to the spiral.
Word that the death penalty had been abolished for most crimes in New York State was received joylessly, almost without comment, in the death house at Sing Sing late yesterday afternoon.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 1 -- There are many good reasons to justify going out of one's way for the Minnesota Theater Company's "The Way of the World," and hardly the least of them is Congreve himself.

For weeks, the track world has been waiting hopefully for the end of its front-office feud and the start of unrestricted competition. There was a development yesterday, but the news was bad. The feud is still on.

MANCHESTER, England, June June 1 (AP) -- Jim Burke of San Francisco, a lightweight, was eliminated and the American seven-man team won three of 10 matches today in the opening-day competition of the world free-style wrestling championships.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court sidestepped today the heated legal controversy over admissibility of voluntary confessions as evidence in criminal trials.
The City Council voted 25 to 2 yesterday to make the chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights a fulltime paid position.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 1 (AP) -- The Minnesota Railroad and Warehouse Commission said today a "blatant misuse" of public highway funds may be involved in a proposed merger of two railroads.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 1 -- The danger that Maj. Edward H. White 2d might detonate explosives on the Titan 2 booster during his planned "space walk" Thursday was discounted today by Lieut. Col. William D. Baxter, the range safety officer here.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 2 (Reuters) -- Two hundred and thirty-six men have perished in one of the worst Japanese mine disasters since World War II. The toll was announced by mine officials late last night.
NAPLES, June 1 (AP) -- Gardner Cox of Philadelphia, in Complex V, took a strong lead in the world 5.5-meter yachting championship today with a victory in the second race.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- An Administration spokesman asked Congress today to adopt a revolutionary method of setting pay scales for its own members as well as for almost everyone else in the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Despite Chinese Communist threats of intervention, military sources here continue to doubt that any ground attacks are pending. It is possible, these sources believe that Chinese MIG fighter planes may join in forays occasionally.

LONDON, June 1 -- The British Medical Association said today that the Government was prepared to back the establishment of a medical loan corporation to help family doctors buy, build, improve or equip their offices.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Kennecott Copper Corporation had violated the Clayton law by acquiring the Okonite Company in 1958.

NEWARK, June 1 -- The Elizabethtown Water Company offered today to supply 10 billion gallons of water annually directly to this city and adjacent Elizabeth, if they would build a pipeline to carry it the 10 miles from Linden.
OTTAWA, June 1 -- A statement of principles issued today by the Anglican and United Churches of Canada called for the union of those Protestant denominations, the two largest in the country.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Former Senator Barry Goldwater entered a vigorous dissent today as other Republicans cheered Representative John V. Lindsay's decision to run a nonpartisan campaign for Mayor of New York.

The New York Legislature is beginning to yearn for adjournment. The Democrats, in control for the first time in thirty years, are already suggesting that, contrary to anything else the public may believe, this has been a very productive session.

PEKING, June 1 (Reuters) -- Hundreds of Chinese Army officers and men strolled through the streets today wearing identical uniforms as an order stripping more than 2.5 million men of their insignia and rank went into effect.

ALBANY, June 1 -- Governor Rockefeller signed today a controversial bill requiring school boards to supply private and parochial school pupils with any textbooks they request from the list of those approved for public schools.
NEWARK, June 1 -- A West Orange insurance executive who died in 1960 left an estate of $23 million, according to an accounting approved today by Essex County Judge John F. Crane.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Now that it has had a taste of American wines on ambassadorial menus, the Administration is seeking other ways to make the United States embassies think as well as drink in an American atmosphere.
The syndicate offering $125 million of Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company debentures was terminated yesterday with about 75 per cent of the issue unsold.
TOKYO, June 1 -- I.B.M. Japan, Ltd., announced today that it had obtained informal approval from the Japanese Government to manufacture two models of its new 360-system electronic computer.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court today denied a hearing to Lenny Bruce, who sought a Federal court order to prevent New York authorities from interfering with his appearances, which sometimes include obscene words.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 -- The Federal Government went to court today to seek the dissolution of the $3 billion Crocker Citizens National Bank.

THE most important event of the Eastern Regional Championships, the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, began at the New York Hilton Hotel last night with an entry of 90 teams. The top-ranked teams will have a bye-round tonight, and will resume play tomorrow night.
Larry Gallo was acquitted yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court of consorting with known criminals -- two other members of the Gallo gang.

THE Edelmans stand out as a couple not only because he, Arthur, is 6 feet 6 and she, Teddy (Theodora), is as tall as his shoulder, but also because their good-natured, homey manner could charm the spots off a python.
Students at Adelphi, Iona, Marist College of Poughkeepsic and Long Island University are the latest to jump into the field of intercollegiate club football.

PARIS -- It is perfectly plain that Secretary McNamara's proposal to NATO's defense ministers suggesting an alliance committee to consult on the use of nuclear weapons is a very late endeavor to meet the request along similar lines made in 1958 by General de Gaulle.
The five Borough Presidents have assailed a sharp reduction in the highway maintenance performed by the city's road crews in the last five years.
The British pound inched ahead yesterday in moderately active trading in foreign exchange markets here.
HARTFORD, June 1 -- Gov. John N. Dempsey presented to the Legislature today a proposal for a multimillion-dollar aid program for the financially distressed New Haven Railroad.
The London Stock Exchange was depressed yesterday by new pressures on the pound sterling in foreign-exchange markets.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court today removed the last obstacle in the path of a special legislative election in New York State this fall.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that Communists participated in the student march on Washington in April and were striving to start other demonstrations against United States foreign policy.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 1 -- Jim Clark's Lotus Ford consumed 164 gallons of alcohol in winning the 500-mile race yesterday. Clark started with 58 gallons in his two fuel tanks, one on either side of the body.
Following are excerpts from the speech of William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to Columbia University alumni yesterday.
The Civil Aeronautics Board turned down yesterday an airlines proposal to ban the showing of movies on international flights.

The Federal Reserve and the Johnson Administration are having an argument over economic history that reflects a deepening conflict over the kind of policy the money managers should be pursuing right now.

An outdoor advertising executive spoke out strongly yesterday against President Johnson's proposed billboard legislation on the ground that it was a threat not only to highway advertising, but to all advertising.
MOSCOW, June 1 -- Soviet planning practices were portrayed today as working against a current nationwide campaign for higher quality of production.

SAIGON, Wednesday, June 2 (AP) -- United States paratroopers killed four Communist guerrillas in an ambush 40 miles northeast of Saigon last night Troops of the United States 173d Airborne Brigade cut down the Vietcong with machine-gun fire as they tried to infiltrate United States positions along the Dongnai River.
William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said yesterday he saw a series of "disquieting similarities between our present prosperity and the fabulous twenties."

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Perhaps it was just as well that the Mets played today before their smallest audience of the season. Otherwise, a mistaken impression that the Mets are strong and mighty and a team to be feared might have got wide circulation.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Johnson asked Congress today for $89 million as a first installment on a vast American-supported regional development plan for Southeast Asia.
The police seized a 21-year-old assistant cook at Columbia University early yesterday in connection with the knife murders of two women in Washington Heights apartment houses.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The only issue in the debate over repeal of Section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Act is individual freedom, opponents of repeal contended today.

The Association for Homemaker Service will gain from a party on Tuesday evening at Shea Stadium, where the New York Mets will play the San Francisco Giants. Mrs. A. Varick Stout, benefit chairman, Mrs. Joseph A. Meehan and Mrs. John R. Stevenson, vice chairmen, are in charge of arrangements.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 1 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan said today he hoped British mediation efforts would soon produce a "meaningful settlement" with India in the dispute over the Rann of Cutch.
A vacant lot at the northwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 94th Street was crowded last evening with what the city believes will rejuvenate the West Side-large middle-income families.
The Aluminum Workers International Union went on strike yesterday against the Reynolds Metals Company after marathon negotiations failed to bring a new agreement.

LOCDAO, South Vietnam, June 1 -- Brooding over the smoldering houses of this wrecked hamlet is a 600-foot high hill that marks the high-point of the biggest Vietcong attack this year on Government forces in South Vietnam.

The restaurant, store and bus terminal at St. Nicholas Avenue and 167th Street have been purchased for $400,000 by Columbia University for future expansion by the university's College of Physicians and Surgeons.
Institutional investors have raised their participation in the stock market to record levels, the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday in its latest study of public transactions.
NATCHEZ, Miss., June 1 (AP) -- Eighteen Negroes are being held in jail out of 28 arrested in a march of 80 on Saturday on a city park used by whites.
Bronx ice cream vender was robbed of a winning twin double ticket worth more than $13,000 as he drove home from the trotting races at Roosevelt Raceway early yesterday, the police reported.
MOSCOW, June 1 (UPI) -- A Soviet newspaper today accused a high-ranking Israeli diplomat of subversive activities among Jews in the Caucasian republic of Georgia.

Less than five months after a $60 million fraud suit involving Allan P. Kirby appeared to be dead, the case of Alleghany vs. Kirby is about to come to life again before the United States Supreme Court.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 1 -- Lee Kuan Yew, Prime Minister of Singapore, suggested today that Malaysia be partitioned if the country's Malay leaders did not accept what he called a "Malaysian Malaysia."
PARIS, June 1 -- The United States assured its North Atlantic allies today that Western nuclear strength in Europe had been increased by 10 per cent since Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A major floor fight was assured today in the House of Representatives on whether American businesses should be barred by law from aiding the Arab economic boycott of Israel.
Six Black Muslims accused of assaulting a messenger and biting two patrolmen were arraigned yesterday under the tightest security measures seen in the Criminal Courts Building for at least 10 years.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Senate passed a bill today to pump $3.32 billion of Federal aid into economically depressed "little Appalachias" throughout the nation in the next five years.

The transfer of title in the sale of the Paramount Building, scheduled to take place yesterday, has been postponed, according to a spokesman for Mrs. Evelyn Sharp, who recently contracted to buy the 33-story landmark on Times Square.

ST. LOUIS, June 1 -- A group of angry big-city mayors failed today in a move to get the United States Conference of Mayors to back their charge that the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity was "trying to wreck local government by setting the poor against City Hall.
All 3.5 million cards of New York City's registered voters in last year's election will have to be renumbered for this year's special election.
Norton Simon has moved to add another company to his large and growing collection.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Johnson said today that he planed to address the delegates to the United Nations when the world body celebrates its 20th anniversary later this month in San Francisco.

LONDON, May 31 -- The remains of Anne Mowbray, Duchess of York and child bride of Richard, one of the princes murdered in the Tower of London in the 15th century, were reinterred Monday in Westminster Abbey.
LONDON, June 1 (Reuters) -- Three American physicians will receive a 12,500 ($35,000) grant from the Wellcome Trust in London to carry out cancer research.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- Judge Leo Weinrott of the Common Pleas Court postponed today hearings on a petition by dissident stockholders of the Reading Company who sought at the annual meeting last Tuesday to prevent the Baltimore Ohio Railroad from voting its 38 per cent Reading stock interest.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's news conference in Washington yesterday afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times:

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court ruled illegal today contracts under which oil companies promote the sale of a particular brand of tires and auto accessories through their retail gasoline dealers and receive a commission from the tire manufacturer on such sales.
DALLAS, June 1 -- Col. John H. Glenn Jr., the first American astronaut, said today that he would like to be going on the Gemini 4 spaceflight.

TOKYO, June 1 (Comtelburo) -- Some 13.5 million metric tons of Australian hard coking coal will be purchased by major Japanese steel mills from an American company over a 10-year period beginning in 1968, the Yawata Iron and Steel Company reported here today.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 1 -- Julius R. Lippman of New Hyde Park, whose contest for Judge of the Third District Court last November ended in a tie vote, was appointed to the post today by Couny Executive Eugene H. Nickerson, a Democrat.
ALBANY, June 1 -- The State Senate voted unanimously today to set a minimum age of 21 for members of the Legislature, the first step in the long process of amending the State Constitution.

An out-of-court settlement for $80,000 has been made in the suit of 12 Hollywood writers, directors and actors, who charged the Motion Picture Association of America, and all its major corporate members except United Artists, with maintaining a blacklist.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 1 -- The Organization of American States obtained formal agreement today from both Dominican factions to "neutralize" the Presidential Palace, a point of recurrent shooting incidents endangering the 12-day-old ceasefire.

LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- Twenty-four horses, including four that are American-owned, are entered in the 186th running of the English Derby tomorrow and many bettors are looking for another American triumph.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- New orders received by manufacturers continued to climb in April, despite a drop-off in incoming orders to steel mills.

The freight-forwarding subsidiary of the financially distressed Yale Express System. Inc., Republic Carloading and Distributing Company, filed a Chapter X bankruptcy petition here yesterday. A trucking subsidiary, the Yale Transport Corporation, reportedly is preparing to do the same.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 1 -- The United States offered a four-point disarmament proposal today that aims at a resumption of negotiations "as soon as possible" at the Geneva disarmament conference.

Firemen and fire equipment, young and old, marched up Lower Broadway to City Hall yesterday to mark the 100th anniversary of the city's professional fire department. When they got there Mayor Wagner praised them as "the bravest of the brave."

Dapper Dan had a workout at Belmont Park yesterday in preparation for Saturday's $125,000 Belmont Stakes. Tom Rolfe, the horse that is expected to press him for the role of favorite in the famous test of 1 1/2 miles, vanned into Aqueduct early in the morning from Delaware Park.
ATHENS, MAY 20 -- At Salonika's American Farm School the diploma is a straw hat. It gives Greek village boys graduating after a four-year course the right to call themselves farmers.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 1 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, the United States representative at the United Nations, said today that international peace-keeping machinery must be adjusted to meet the new technique of aggression known as "war of national liberation."

The Association of Producing Artists, the repertory troupe, and its sponsor, the Phoenix Theater, will not be able to transfer their joint nonprofit activities to a new home next season. They had planned to move from the 299-seat home at 334 East 74th Street to Broadway's Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street. with a seating capacity of 995.
EAST NORWALK, Conn., June 1 -- Conductors of the New Haven Railroad probably will be examining tickets of westbound passengers from this community with extra attention tomorrow.
HAVERHILL, Mass., June 1 (AP) -- The Haverhill Journal, established in 1957 by The Manchester (N.H.) Union Leader, halted publication today.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court sent four apportionment appeals back to lower courts today for application of its one-man, one-vote doctrine without ruling on the details of any of the state districting plans.

ALBANY, June 1 -- As one of the moving forces behind legislation to abolish capital punishment in New York, signed by the Governor today, Assemblyman Richard James Bartlett has encountered strong opposition from many of his colleagues.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., June 1 (AP) -- Assemblyman Hyman E. (Bucky) Mintz, Sullivan County Republican who figured in a grand jury's inquiry into an alleged $100,000 bribe to obtain a license for an upstate race track, said today that he would not seek re-election in November.

CHICAGO, June 1 (UPI) -- A Federal judge jailed Momo Salvatore (Moe) Giancana, reputed Chicago crime boss, for contempt of court today. Giancana's former traveling companion, Phyllis McGuire, the singer, appeared before a grand jury.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Administration is "concerned" over the latest turn in the fighting in South Vietnam, President Johnson said today.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 1 -- Elliott Roosevelt, who will take office as Mayor tomorrow, campaigned in a style that reminded many observers of his father. He had a big handshake, a broad smile and quick word for all.
The four principal players in the forthcoming television series of dramatizations on the work of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were cleared by the agency before getting their assignments.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 -- United States planes made their heaviest bombing raid today of their three-day attack on Hoaian, an ammunition depot 45 miles southwest of Hanoi. A total of 48 jets flew to the depot, but, unlike yesterday, no Communist MIG fighters were seen.

The television special is headed for a comeback next season on the Columbia Broadcasting System. Four years ago the network substantially reduced special shows because the pro-emptions brought a drop in ratings of its regularly scheduled bread-and-butter programing.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The first Negro woman to be named as a United States Ambassador won quick approval today from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 1 -- Congolese rebels retreating before a Government force of two white units aided by national army soldiers are holding nearly 100 Europeans as hostages.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The International Publishers Association favors helping emerging countries by allowing translations of books for small initial fees plus subsequent royalty payments. This was the sense of a resolution passed today by a working group.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 1 -- Judge Edward J. Plunkett ruled in District Court today that an "acknowledgement" receipt on the New Hampshire sweepstakes is a lottery slip and that its possession in Rhode Island violates a state law.

A COLOR feature made in Nigeria, "Fincho," is hardly a feather in the cap of the Gallery of Modern Art, which recently has been introducing varied film fare from overseas. This Raymond Rohauer presentation, made in 1958 by a writer-director-producer, Sam Zebba, is a tame, fitfully engrossing and perfectly respectable little semi-documentary, enacted by non-professional natives and a few Britons, about how industry modernizes the living pattern of a remote village.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 1 -- Sixty-eight-year-old Octavio Jorge squeezed through a small opening in the door today with his shirt soaked with perspiration and his necktie undone and askew over one shoulder.

TOKYO, June 1 -- The Bank of Tokyo, Japan's leading foreign exchange bank, has announced the elevation of Sumio Hara from the vice presidency to the post of president. Mr. Hara, 54 years old, succeeds Shigeo Horie, head of the bank since 1957, who assumed the newly created post of chairman of the board of directors.

LAST year Americans devoured an average of about nine and one-half pounds of cheese per person (as compared to 18 pounds of ice cream). Although most of this was presumably consumed between bread or atop crackers, some of it was doubtless in the cooking pot.

Mayor Wagner came fluttering into town in a helicopter yesterday morning, and for the rest of the day he was followed everywhere by the hard, clinical looks of Republicans who thought he looked "worried" and "tired," and by Democrats who thought he looked "confident" and "great."

The Senate is this week going to debate -- and it should ratify -- two amendments to the Charter of the United Nations. These would enlarge membership of the Security Council from 11 to 15 and the Economic and Social Council from 18 to 27.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 -- Roman Catholic political leaders, seeking to capitalize on the impasse within South Vietnam's Government, pressed the Chief of State today to remove Premier Phan Huy Quat.

On Nov. 2 New York State voters will elect a new Legislature of 65 Senators and 165 Assemblymen for one-year terms, on the basis of flamboyantly gerrymandered district lines provided in the reapportionment plan put across by the Republicans last November. This is the meaning of the United States Supreme Court's refusal yesterday to accede to the request of the Democratic legislative leaders to delay the election.

THE Grand Canyon, carved into the state of Arizona like an extraordinary slash across a smooth face, is the kind of place people usually enjoy visiting, but, of course, they wouldn't want to live there.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to authority of the Federal Power Commission to regulate sales pipeline companies of leases covering natural gas still in the ground.
Herbert J. Siegel and Ernest Martin, two new directors of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, were featured players in a 130-minute stormy annual meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Following are excerpts from President Johnson's speech as delivered today at graduation exercises of the National Cathedral School for Girls:
RYE, N.Y., June 1 -- A record entry of 432 golfers began play today in the 61st United States Seniors Golf Association championship at the Westchester Country Club and the Apawamis Club.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 -- I.W. Abel was sworn in today as the third president in the history of the United Steelworkers of America. He said the first challenge for the union was to reach a full and complete contract with the steel industry.
Earl K. Angstadt, president and chief executive officer of Abercrombie Fitch, Inc., sporting goods retailer, also has been elected chairman of the board, the company announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- In every war of this century American propaganda has come under attack at home, and the Vietnamese war is no exception.
DALLAS, June 1 -- The Southern Baptist Convention, the nation's largest Protestant denomination, faced the question of its role in society as its annual meeting opened here today.

ON the first day of June, the American League standing showed the New York Yankees in eighth place with 19 victories and 25 defeats, 9 1/2 games behind the league leader. The standing should be clipped and saved: It is a collector's item.
One hundred and sixty young men, Mayor Wagner and other city officials turned out yesterday morning to open a city employment program designed to find work for 5,000 young persons this summer.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the dismissals of Federal conspiracy indictments against six men accused of killing a Negro educator, Lemuel A. Penn, on a Georgia highway last July.
The Executive Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church disclosed yesterday that it had overruled the Alabama Bishop's objection to its recent Civil rights activity in Selma.
TRENTON, N.J., June 1 (AP) -- Many defendants convicted in New Jersey before last April 23 are expected to receive new trials because of a State Supreme Court ruling today.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

The Chrysler Pavilion at the World's Fair agreed yesterday to change "Dem Parts," a musical number in the show at the pavilion to "Them Parts." The move followed a protest from the state branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Special-situation stocks helped pace trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the market declined in active trading.

The words of William Mc-Chesney Martin weighed on the minds of Wall Street analysts yesterday after the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board's speech to Columbia University alumni sent the stock market into a slide.
The University of Utah awarded $11 million of student fee revenue bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by Goodbody Co. and F.S. Smithers Co.
HONG KONG, June 1 -- Communist China asserted today it had greater justification for aiding Hanoi in view of intensified United States military activity in Vietnam.

A code of ethics for operators of cruise lines here was advocated at a conference yesterday in the office of Assistant State Attorney General Barnett Levy, chief of the Bureau of Consumer Frauds and Protection, at 80 Centre Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 1 -- The Secretary General and the President of the General Assembly reported today that the prevention of another deadlock in the Assembly was "one of the immediate tasks" before the United Nations and "must necessarily deserve special attention."
State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr., who tried twice before and failed, was nominated yesterday as Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey.
PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP) -- Bob Veale struck out 16 and yielded five hits tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-0, for their 12th straight victory.

The passing of Ambassador Joseph C. Grew is a sad occasion for Turks. He was indeed one of the first American diplomats to recognize the greatness of Ataturk and importance of the new Turkish Republic.
A woman detective picked a prosecutor's pocket in Queens Criminal Court Monday to demonstrate how "jostlers" -- the police terminology for pickpockets -- work.
HOUSTON, June 1 (UPI) -- Hank Aaron and Mack Jones slammed consecutive home runs off Hal Woodeshick in the eighth inning tonight as the Milwaukee Braves scored a 2-1 triumph over the Houston Astros.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 (UPI) -- Dick Groat's single with two out in the sixth inning drove in the decisive run and Ray Sadecki pitched a five-hitter today to pace the St. Louis Cardinals to a 2-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
FATE, Tex., June 1 -- Mrs. Marina Oswald, Russian-born widow of the man who assassinated President Kennedy, was married to a divorced electronics worker today in this little north Texas farm town.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP) -- Doubles by Jose Cardenal and Julio Gotay highlighted a pair of two-run innings today as the Los Angeles Angels defeated the Boston Red Sox 4-1. George Brunet, the winning pitcher, hurled a seven-hitter.
We, Jewish citizens of the U.S.S.R., express profound indignation regarding the fact that some Western circles continually spread all kinds of fabrications on the position of the Jews in the U.S.S.R.
Roman Catholic and Jewish parochial school officials hailed Governor Rockefeller's action in approving a textbook bill yesterday as a victory for all the state's schoolchildren.

Carter Products, Inc., a diversified manufacturer of prescription and proprietary drugs, toilerties and specialty food products, recorded the highest sales in its history in the fiscal year ended March 31. However, earnings declined slightly from the level a year earlier.

Merchants, mercenaries and missionaries sailed forth to the East of marvels in the 1500's. What they wrote of what they discovered is examined in these two volumes of a promised six. Donald F. Lach divides his materials rigorously: knowledge of Asia before da Gama; the pepper trade, printed accounts and Jesuit activities in the 16th century, and writings on India, Southeast Asia, Japan and China.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, warned yesterday that irresponsible actions by students and faculty members could endanger the independence and integrity of the university.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- Charles E. Moore, public relations director for the International Association of Chiefs of Police, testified May 17 that Bettina Aptheker "was behind Mario Savio" in the student disturbances at the University of California at Berkeley.

ALBANY, June 1 -- Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki predicted today a long Republican dominance of the Legislature as a result of the United States Supreme Court's refusal to cancel a special election scheduled for November.
ALBANY, June 1 -- Peter J. Crotty, the Buffalo Democratic leader and one of the most powerful politicians in the state, resigned today as chairman of the Erie County Democratic Committee.
The stock market reeled yesterday following a bearish speech by the chairman of the Federal Reserve Beard.
COCHABAMBA, Bolivia, June 1 -- A long-awaited program of economic measures and curbs on labor unions went into effect in Bolivia's nationalized tin-mining industry today.

NOT even a heart attack can dim the enthusiasm of Charlie Dressen. Sidelined for the better part of three months, the 68-year-old pepperpot returned to the controls of the Bengals on Monday and was directing strategy when they split a double-header with the Yankees.

DEVON, Pa., June 1 -- Kathy Kusner, the top rider of the United States Olympic team last year, took a jarring spill off Untouchable, but came back to win the open jumper stake tonight in the Devon Horse Show.

Detective Joseph J. Mulligan of the Police Department's Bomb Squad testified yesterday in Federal Court concerning the danger posed by 30 sticks of dynamite allegedly smuggled into the United States from Canada in connection with a purported Black Liberation Front plot.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- President Johnson, in a televised news conference, made a detailed defense today of his actions in the Dominican crisis. He emphatically asserted that his Administration had been "unanimous" in its decision to intervene militarily.
Saks-34th Street will close its Herald Square store next spring or earlier after 63 years of operation.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 1 -- President Jomo Kenyatta declared today before tens of thousands of cheering Kenyans that there was no place for Communism in the country.
LONDON, June 1 -- With a background of continued weakness in sterling, the Government sought today to warm up its frigid relationship with the business and financial community.

MANCHESTER, England, June 2 (UPI) -- Guzam Sagaradze of the Soviet Union out-pointed Russ Camilleri of Pacifica, Calif., America's premier hope for a title, in a third-round welterweight bout tonight in the world amateur free-style wrestling championships.

WHITE PLAINS, June 2 -- After months of quarreling among the 48 leaders of the Westchester Republican County Committee, Theodore Hill Jr., the chairman, and two of his chief aides announced today they would resign next Monday.
The election of William E. Petersen as president of the Greater New for Councils of Boy Scouts of America was announced yesterday.
A committee of Park Avenue property owners voted unanimously yesterday to oppose a Transit Authority plan for routing buses along the avenue from 46th to 125th Street.

PARIS, June 2 -- Delegates from Britain and the six members of the European Common Market recommended unanimously today the establishment of a permanent conference of advisers to coordinate foreign policies.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 2 -- Airdois, a 3-year-old pacing colt, found the muddy track in the second race at Roosevelt Raceway decidedly to his liking tonight. Prominently placed throughout the mile race the brown son of Parading Adios defeated Afton Perry by a nose and returned the highest win price of the New York harness racing season -- $115 for $2.

KANSAS CITY, June 2 (AP) -- Curt Blefary's two-run double and a two-run homer by Norm Siebern in the sixth inning tonight powered the Baltimore Orioles to a 6-4 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics.
Price trends were lacking in most commodity markets yesterday despite brisk volume.

LUGENO, Switzerland, June 2 (AP) -- Owen Davidson of the powerful Australian contingent defeated 19-year-old Cliff Richey of Dallas in the second round of the Swiss international tennis tournament today, 7-5, 4-6, 6-0.
ST. THOMAS, V.I., June 2 (UPI) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson arrived in the Virgin Islands today for a short vacation.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- House Republicans announced today that they would send four Representatives to Paris to explore what they called the "neglected" problems of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and Franco-American relations.

LONDON, June 2 -- The Government reported today a net gain in Britain's gold and currency reserves for May, which brought strength to sterling in the foreign-exchange market and revived talk that the bank rate might be cut.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 (AP) -- The Washington Senators swept their fifth double-header of the season tonight, defeating the Los Angeles Angels 13-0 behind the power of Joe Cunningham and Frank Howard and 7-1 behind the hitting of Ken McMullen.
The visibility was almost zero yesterday for airline account traffic.

A plant with a capacity of 200,000 tons of newsprint, magazine paper and bleached pulp a year is to be built in a Southern state by the S.I. Newhouse publishing interests and the Gilman Paper Company.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 -- One of the nation's few Negro test pilots charged today that the Air Force was "petrified" about racial equality, and that Negroes' opportunities in the service were therefore stringently limited.

RECENTLY a desire to refer to a female woodchuck as a sow was accompanied by a certain amount of trepidation. Having heard the male called a boar and the female a sow over the years, the presumption was that these were the correct terms.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Banking Committee, charged today that the Bank Holding Act was "riddled through and through with exemption."
Harlem may establish its own educational television system.
DEVON, Pa., June 2 -- Kathy Kusner continued her domination of the open jumper division of the Devon horse show tonight when she rode Untouchable to victory over a treacherous, rain-soaked course.

When ex-King Farouk died in Rome last March at the age of 45, Bantam Books commissioned journalist-author Mike Stern to do a biography of the deposed ruler of Egypt. Mr. Stern, who lives in Rome, had been a neighbor of Farouk's for twelve years.
WOMEN who blench at the thought of having to make unusual travel arrangements have a friend at Impossibles Ltd.

PARIS, June 3 -- In a ceremony of imposing splendor, a relic revered by Roman Catholicism returned for a few hours last night to the shrine that a saintly king built for it here more than 700 years ago.

Former United States Senator Kenneth B. Keating of New York was named trustee yesterday of the Yale Express System, Inc., and its freight-forwarding subsidiary, the Republic Carloading and Distributing Company.
The Textile Workers Union of America announced yesterday that it had reached a new three-year agreement with the American Viscose Division of the FMC Corporation.

THE Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, the premier event in the Eastern Regionals at the New York Hilton Hotel, enters the third round tonight with 32 teams scheduled to play. The original entry of 98 teams was reduced to 49 teams in Tuesday night's session, and the 15 top-seeded teams, all of which survived the first round, enjoyed a bye-round last night.
Bankers and economists had mixed reactions yesterday to Mr. Martin's citations of the "disquieting similarities" between the present and the pre-Depression period of the 1920's.
One of the three defendants accused of plotting to bomb the Statue of Liberty testified in Federal Court yesterday that Raymond Wood, an undercover policeman, had proposed the bizarre scheme.
ALBANY, June 2 -- A bill that would forbid lobbying by officials of the Citizens Union or bar associations was quietly introduced today through the Senate Rules Committee.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed corporations.
GUATEMALA, June 2 -- Guatemala is to return to constitutional government Sept. 15 after more than two years of government by decree.

BOSTON, June 2 -- The Storer Broadcasting Company, operator of a chain of radio and television stations, took a 30-day option today to acquire control of Northeast Airlines, Inc., from the Hughes Tool Company. The transaction would involve an indicated $15 million or more.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 -- While the nation awaits tomorrow's launching of Gemini 4, the McDonnel Aircraft Corporation, prime contractor for the two-man spacecraft, is busily putting the finishing touches on Gemini 5.

THE early morning haze rested on the treetops at Belmont Park yesterday, but the rain had stopped. The mud was everywhere, though, including the track. The grandstands have been leveled, but the running surface was still a busy training site and the barn area was still jammed to capacity.

Blum's of San Francisco, a restaurant and confectionery chain in California, plans to establish an Eastern headquarters and retail store at 121 East 59th Street, a new 33-story office and apartment building east of Park Avenue running through to 60th Street.
DALLAS, June 2 -- The Southern Baptist convention declared its unwillingness tonight to send a representative to the fourth session of the Ecumenical Council Vatican II this fall.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The Chicago Board of Health unanimously upheld today Dr. Jeremiah Stamler, an internationally known heart disease specialist who refused to testify before a House Un-American Activities subcommittee here last Thursday.
Some supporters of Mayor Wagner are reportedly upset over fund-raising here by the President's Club.

Representative John V. Lindsay leaned against a kitchen cabinet, not noticing a can of roach spray, in Mrs. Sherrie Jenkins's fifth-floor city-owned apartment in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday and pointed to a large hole in the ceiling.

Thirteen reputed horse-race touts who net about $25,O00-a-year each by supplying tips to bettors were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of telephoning gambling information interstate.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Lynda Bird Johnson is going to spend half the summer digging in an Arizona ruin, touring the West by trailer and seeing Minnesota by dugout canoe.
MOSCOW, June 2 -- Four teenage boys stood on a Moscow street corner. It was close to midnight. With summer approaching, it was warm enough to be outside without an overcoat.
Residents of Manhattan's Murray Hill section expressed fears yesterday that the J.P. Morgan mansion at Madison Avenue and 37th Street might be demolished to make room for a 21-story office building.

CINCINNATI, June 2 (AP) -- Tommy Harper's three-run double capped a four-run outburst in the second inning that carried the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-2 victory over Houston tonight in a game shortened to six innings by rain.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- President Johnson awarded gold medals for distinguished Federal civilian service to five officials today and expressed the "entire gratitude of a grateful nation" to the winners.
STRATFORD, Conn., June 2 (UPI) -- A Sikorsky S-61 helicopter has completed the first commercial trans-Atlantic helicopter flight.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 2 (AP) -- Harmon Killebrew and Jimmie Hall backed Jim Perry's brilliant relief pitching with two-run homers tonight as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Boston Red Sox, 6-3.

A Bronx ice cream vender who told the police on Tuesday that two masked men with pistols had robbed him of a racetrack twin-double ticket worth over $13,000 never had a ticket in the first place, according to the police.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 -- Three well-executed Vietcong ambushes near Pleiku have destroyed three convoys, killing more than 80 South Vietnamese Government troops and two Americans.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 -- The lawyer for the Crocker-Citizens National Bank succeeded today in thwarting the introduction of two exhibits in the Government's antitrust suit against the $3.75 billion institution and the Transamerica Corporation.

Governor Rockefeller has signed into law a bill providing free textbooks for use in private and parochial, as well as public, schools. Although customarily rather loquacious in commenting on bills signed or vetoed, he said not a word in this instance.

The Shipbuilders Council of America, a private organization representing the nation's ship construction and ship repair industry, is planning a four-month study on ways to cut the cost of building American merchant ships.

SODOM, N.Y. -- When the water level in the Sodom Reservoir is low, the reservoir, with its stepped retaining wall, resembles the ruin of a Greek amphitheater. At the moment the reservoir is a place where "Electra" might have been performed.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Four Federal grants totaling more than $1.5 million have been allocated to New York City groups, Senators Jacob K. Javits and Robert F. Kennedy announced today.

NAPLES, June 2 (AP) -- Composition, from the Seawanhaka Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L.I., grabbed the lead at the outset today and hung on for a victory in the third race of the world 5.5-meter yachting championship. Britton Chance Jr. of Philadelphia was the winning skipper.
The realignment of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company's top operating officers continued yesterday.

BALTIMORE, June 2 (AP) -- Printers who have continued to honor picket lines at The Baltimore Sun papers were urged today by union leaders to report to work. They were promised there would be no reprisals.
FOR the American teen-ager, fashion begins with the British Mods, Courreges looms high on the horizon and Mrs. John F. Kennedy and Audrey Hepburn are symbols of middle-aged elegance.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The general counsel of the American Retail Federation injected a controversial issue today into the battle over repeal of Section 14(b) of the Taft-Hartley Act.
EPSOM, England, June 2 -- Under clear blue skies at Epsom Downs, a French-bred and trained colt named Sea Bird II won the 186th running of the English Derby.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 2 -- In their third joint try at a Shakespeare production, Tyrone Guthrie and the Minnesota Theater Company have come up with a decisive winner.

YOUNG blood starred when Earl Pruner, a University of California junior, won first prize in the recent Arthur B. Stamer Memorial Tournament at the famous Mechanics Institute Chess Club in San Francisco.

BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Haverhill Gazette agreed today to accept $1.1 million in cash in settlement of its antitrust suit against The Manchester (N.H.) Union Leader Corporation, and its publisher, William Loeb, who also published The Gazette's rival, The Haverhill Journal.
In the menus that follow, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The chief sponsors of a proposed state constitutional amendment on the selection of New York City judges have accepted a reasonable objection raised by Mayor Wagner. The modification agreed to in principle should now insure approval of the proposal by the Legislature, a first step toward adoption.

BRUSSELS, June 1 -- The police are providing protection for the headquarters of the pro-Peking faction of Belgium's Communist party against the possibility of reprisals for the killing of a pro-Moscow Communist.
A MASTERY of languages is a most likely tool in becoming conversant with the world's cuisine.
The British pound advanced 7 points to $2.7935 yesterday in moderately active dealings in foreign exchange markets here.

Julius Baker, flutist, Emily Oppenheimer, harpist, Lorin Bernsohn, cellist, and Leonid Hambro and Leah Effenbach, pianists, will be the guest artists at the seventh annual festival of the Silvermine (Conn.) Guild Chamber Music Center.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The House voted today to repeal excise taxes that now cost buyers of automobiles, jewelry, handbags, household appliances and many other products about $4.8 billion a year.
The New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects elected Max O. Urbahn its president at its annual meeting yesterday at 115 East 40th Street.
Returns from some of the major domestic automobile manufacturers indicated yesterday that retail sales in May increased by 8.4 per cent to 624,547 units from 528,360 in the same period last year.
NIMES, France, June 2 (AP) -- The police said that three American girls were killed early today when their car went out of control near Nimes and hit a tree. A fourth American girl was injured.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Thursday, June 3 -- Final preparations were pushed here early today for the start at 10 A.M. Eastern daylight time of this country's most ambitious space venture to date. Fueling was completed during the night for a 62-orbit flight in which, it is hoped, an orbiting rocket stage will be approached, inspected and perhaps even touched.
The election of Donald A. Petrie as a director of the Long Island Trust Company was announced yesterday by Frederick Hainfeld Jr., president.
The election of Grant M. Young to the new position of senior vice president in charge of marketing for the Marathon Oil Company was announced yesterday.

The awesome destructive power of nuclear weapons means that a perpetual and unlimited arms race is not the correct option for mankind. A decade of patient approach to the task of taming it has resulted in a partial test-ban treaty.
NEWARK, June 2 -- New Jersey Republicans began today the difficult task of closing ranks after a bitter and divisive primary fight yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, June 2 (AP) -- Don Drysdale, with relief help from Ron Perranoski, gained his ninth victory tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers trimmed the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 -- 1.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company took the lead yesterday in the race for providing commercial television and voice communications with Europe via satellites.
Norton Simon, collector of corporations and art masterpieces, has complicated but winning ways.

BUCHAREST, June 2 -- The Rumanian Communist Government is playing down the Vietnam and Dominican crises in its press and official statements as part of its policy of being friendly to everyone. This attitude is yet another sign of Bucharest's independent policy.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it had arranged to sell privately $100 million of 4 3/8 per cent unsecured promissory notes due Oct. 15, 1990.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 2 -- United States military planners, under the pressure of the broadening conflict in Vietnam, have begun to assign added strategic importance to the Chinese Nationalist armed forces garrisoned on this island.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company this year will finance about 60 per cent of its $3.7 billion capital expenditures program from earnings and depreciation reserves and the balance through new public financing and the sale of temporary investments, according to John J. Scanlon, vice president and treasurer.

GUILDFORD, England, June 2 (Reuters) -- Britain's newest playhouse, the Yvonne Arnaud Theater, was opened tonight by Ingrid Bergman and Sir Michael Redgrave, starring in Turgenev's "A Month in the Country."
An American astronaut is to float across North America in 10 minutes at about 1 P.M. Eastern daylight time today in the United States first experiment in having a man operate independently in space.
The stock market was caught up in a whirlwind selloff yesterday afternoon that carried prices to levels of early April before the selling reached a climax at 2:30 P.M.
BERMUDA, though hardly a major center of pure-bred dog activity, has been making progress under the Bermuda Kennel Club, which is observing its 10th anniversary this year.
Virtually no important horse race gets off without a certain amount of ritual partying these days, and the Belmont Stakes, oldest of the Triple Crown events, is no exception.
Eight New York fair housing committees charged yesterday that city and state authorities were failing to enforce anti- discrimination laws.
The Queens District Attorney's office won a delay yesterday in the trial of three Cubans charged with firing a bazooka toward the United Nations.
Red Owl Stores, Inc., has purchased its second radio station in the upper Middle West, Ford Bell, chairman, reported to stockholders yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Hopkins, Minn.
President Johnson presented the Administration's case for intervention in the Dominican Republic persuasively at his press conference, but his argument requires further examination.

HOW marvelous it is to have the City Center to remind us of the golden age of the American musical theater. For its first revival this season the Fifty-fifth Street playhouse offered us "Guys and Dolls."

CHANNEL 13 is showing a lively foot. On Tuesday night the educational station borrowed the format of the teach-in for a provocative study of the multitudinous aspects of the war on poverty in the metropolitan area.

MANCHESTER, England, June 2 (UPI) -- Margaret Smith led an Australian advance into the third round of the Northern lawn tennis championships today with a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Trudy Groenman of the Netherlands.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- It was an all-Korean final in the National Symphony Orchestra's Merriweather Post Contest for young violinists and cellists.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company announced yesterday that it would proceed with plans to merge with Penick Ford, Ltd., under an agreement between the two companies on March 1. The closing date for the merger has been set for June 9.
ALBANY, June 2 -- A mistake in the ethics bill passed by the Assembly last week and last-minute Republican objections prevented action on the measure today by the Senate.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 2 -- Canada will be represented by the best-organized and prepared team it has probably sent out for a Davis Cup match when it plays the United States at the Bakersfield Racquet Club starting Friday.
Declines of fractions predominated on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as trading slowed.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The United States today ordered a first secretary of the Soviet Embassy to leave the country as soon as possible for engaging in "activities incompatible with his diplomatic status."
The New York City Housing Authority received the annual award of the Park Association of NexYork City yesterday for its recent designs of open space plazas in city housing projects.
ST. LOUIS, June 2 -- Mayors of both political parties voted their support today for the Great Society programs of the Johnson Administration. They asked for more.
ALBANY, June 2 (AP) -- A bill to strip the embattled East Hudson Parkway Authority of its power to take property of municipalities without their consent was narrowly approved in the Senate today.

BONN, June 2 -- The commander of the United States Army in Europe sent today a sharply worded note to the Soviet military chief in East Germany protesting yesterday's mob attack on the United States military mission in Potsdam.

A delegation from the American Jewish Committee gave Chancellor Ludwig Erhard a four-page memorandum yesterday urging Bonn to extend until 1975 the legal limit for prosecution of Nazi war criminals. The statute was recently extended to 1969.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed by voice vote today President Johnson's nomination of this country's first Negro woman ambassadors Mrs. Patricia Roberts Harris.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Seven hundred book publishers from forty nations have been meeting here this week. Yet not a word has been spoken about the gravest threat now facing their industry. This threat is literacy.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The State Department asked the New Jersey Turnpike Authority to forget about its threat to expel speeding diplomats from the Turnpike.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 2 -- Arab marauders from Lebanon and Jordan struck at two Israeli settlements last night and early today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Johnson Administration has developed a plan for the Dominican Republic that looks toward elections within two to three months under the supervision of the Organization of American States.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Great Society may be trying to prettify America, but meanwhile, what about the noise?
The bond market yesterday was an area of much talk and little action.
Inconsistent weather conditions in May held sales results in New York City's leading department stores to a small increase over the level of the corresponding month last year.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 2 -- Brazilian troops of the inter-American peace force neutralized the presidential palace today under an agreement signed by both armed Dominican factions.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- William McChesney Martin Jr. could be described as a boy wonder who became a puritan. The seasoned chairman of the Federal Reserve Board -- who has held high office longer than any other official in Washington except J. Edgar Hoover of the F.B.I. -- has assumed the role of Cassandra in the euphoric economic boom.
A syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company and the First National Bank of Chicago submitted the winning bid yesterday for the $47.9 million issue of highway bonds of Connecticut.
The four gorillas at the Bronx Zoo, born to the life of the jungle or a reasonable facsimile thereof, have successfully adapted to the "vast wasteland."
ALBANY, June 2 -- The State Senate voted unanimously today to extend the harness racing season to almost the entire year, from Jan. 3 to Dec. 15.
WASHINGTON, June2 (UPI) -- The latest step in the Freedom Democratic party's challenge of the Mississippi Congressional delegation ended in a stalemate today.
A period of "a more normal rate of growth" for the economy is expected by the First National City Bank following the "breathless pace" of recent months.
Workers at 19 plants of the United States Rubber Company went on strike yesterday in a dispute centered on demands for improved working conditions.

State Senator Owen M. Begley waived immunity yesterday and testified before a New York County grand jury investigating whether he and the owner of a consulting engineering company had conspired to violate the state's conflict-of-interest laws.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Johnson Administration is dismayed over the wage settlements reached this week in the aluminum industry and the price increase that immediately followed.

The war between the Amateur Athletic Union and the National Collegiate Athletic Association continued yesterday with a communique from an A.A.U. spokesman, who said the absence of N.C.A.A. athletes in next month's track meet with the Soviet Union did not mean disaster.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 2 -- Mexico offered a new plan today to end the threat of a confrontation of the big powers over finances and to solve the financial problems of the United Nations.

Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz and Carl Kaplan, the former police chief of Fallsburgh, N.Y., were indicted and arrested yesterday on charges of conspiring to bribe a detective assigned to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office.
GENEVA, June 2 -- The European Free Trade Association's council agreed today that issues should take priority over procedures in the search for an accord with the European Common Market.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The prophecy of the late Justice Frankfurter that the Supreme Court would find itself deeply entangled in a "political thicket'' when it asserted jurisdiction over apportionment of state voting districts was emphatically verified in this week's related decisions.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2 (AP) -- Barbara Bauer, a nurse and the daughter of a Navy captain, will be the color girl for the United States Naval Academy's June Week graduation program. She is 22 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A State Department spokesman described as "press speculation" today a report from Seoul that South Korea would send a reinforced division of 15,000 troops to Vietnam soon. Earlier dispatches had put the size of the force at 25,000 men.
Dr. Calvin E. Gross obtained a court order yesterday restraining the Board of Education from ousting him as Superintendent of Schools tomorrow, when his enforced three-month leave of absence ends.
The City Planning Commission approved yesterday plans for a $50 million urban-renewal project in a 14-block area of the Lower East Side.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- The Senate approved today a $5.2 billion space authorization, including annual installments on the two-man Gemini orbital flights and the Apollo man-on-the-moon program.
ROME, June 2 -- Italians marked today the 19th anniversary of their republic with parades, speeches and fireworks -- and concern over an epidemic of scandal.

GRAND BLANC, Mich. -- Ken Venturi will return to tournament golf tomorrow, rain or shine. Cold, fog and rain, however, prevented the United States Open champion from competing today in the pro-amateur preliminary to the $100,000 Buick Open.
DANANG, South Vietnam, June 2 -- The United States Navy has turned its biggest guns against the Vietcong in South Vietnam.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its poorest performance so far this year yesterday as prices fell in active trading.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The International Publishers Association heard criticism today of the proposal now before Congress for revision of the nation's copyright law.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. officially took over today as chairman of the new Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and found himself faced with a set of problems.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Senate, in a surprise action, voted today to require Sargent Shriver to give up one of his two Government jobs.
Radiating optimism in several directions, the New York Yankees got an unexpected rest last night when rain forced postponement of their scheduled game with the Detroit Tigers at Yankee Stadium.
Otis A. Thompson, president of the National Bank and Trust Company of Norwich, has been elected a director of the Gladding Corporation.

The State Senate has voted down by a 29-26 margin a bill that would undermine the Waterfront Commission's control over longshore hiring in the Port of New York Leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association are working hard to revive the measure; the port and the public will be better off if they fail -- unless they recognize the need for revising the bill to kill its destructive features.

The pro football team doing the most trading this year has been the Los Angeles Rams. They have acquired Jack Snow, the all-America rookie end from Notre Dame; Dan Currie, a former all-pro linebacker; Tommy McDonald, a former all-pro flanker; Ed Holler, a linebacker who also can punt the ball, and Joe Krupa, a longtime regular defensive tackle.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Senator J.W. Fullbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, decided today that he would act as floor manager for the $3.35 billion foreign aid authorization bill despite his earlier assurances to the contrary.

Once a family has selected its dream house -- or a reasonable facsimile -- its reaction, more likely than not, is a strange blend of excitement and relief, relief at having completed an exhausting hunt.
An agreement has been reached for New York State to buy the Long Island Rail Road from the Pennsylvania Railroad for $65 million.

PARIS, June 2 -- France's official reserves of gold and dollars showed a slight dip last month for extraordinary reasons. If there had been no exceptional factors, these reserves would have risen, but by much less than has been the trend.

Lieut. Thomas R. Gilligan, whose fatal shooting of a 15-year-old Negro boy brought on six nights of riots here last summer, went to the aid of a Negro man yesterday afternoon when the man collapsed on Broadway near 67th Street and suffered an epileptic attack.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee today called President Johnson's proposal for military pay increases "disgracefully inadequate."

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A band of Senate Democratic liberals opened their long-planned offensive today against a proposed constitutional amendment to permit states to nullify the Supreme Court's one-man, one-vote ruling.
GENEVA, June 2 -- Julio Munoz, 49-year-old Spanish financier, is under arrest in Zurich on a complaint filed by the Swiss Federal Bank Commission.

One of the country's largest shipping operators has warned the Government that unless it acts on the company's longstanding application for Federal subsidies its ships and operation will be transferred to foreign flag.

The House's speedy passage of inflated reductions in excise taxes makes it obvious that all previous skepticism about the effectiveness of tax cuts has been forgotten. It must be admitted that the performance of the economy since taxes were reduced last year has been impressive, but the tax cut has not lived up to the over-optimistic claims of its advocates.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 2 -- A reliable army source said tonight that 55 European hostages were thought to have been killed by Congolese rebels before the rebels retreated in the face of an advance by Government forces.

PORT HURON, Mich., June 2 (AP) -- Fred L. Riggin Jr. resigned today as president of the Mueller Brass Company, citing differences of opinion with the concern's new owners. Mueller was bought in April by the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company of Boston.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Administration has thrown its support behind a New York Republican's effort to strip the loyalty oath from a Federal education program.
I was shocked to read the May 24 letter from Richard C. Maybruck in which he mentions "the Communist take-over of Vietnam, Cuba, East Germany, Cambodia and Indonesia."
CHICAGO, June 2 -- The Ebony article was signed by Charles L. Sanders, an associate editor of the magazine, and Jerome S. Cahill, Washington correspondent for The Philadelphia Inquirer.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 2 -- The New Haven Railroad ticket thief was believed to have struck again today, but this time he left a nice note for the stationmaster.

The block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 49th and 50th Streets has been assembled for development by the Madison Square Garden Corporation after six years of negotiations involving the purchase of 18 parcels.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) -- A Senate subcommittee said today that one of its agents had infiltrated the Minutemen, a militant nationalist organization that says it is preparing for guerrilla warfare in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Johnson Administration maintained a glacial silence today in the aftermath of yesterday's warning by the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of "disquieting similarities" between the present time and the late nineteen-twenties.
The Paramount Theater, revived temporarily with a series of stage-screen programs, is giving up again tonight.
RYE, N.Y., June 2 -- Fred Brand Jr. of the Oakmont Country Club, Pittsburgh, became the 61st United States senior golf champion today.

Richard D. Heffner said yesterday direct satellite-to-home transmission could solve the financial plight of educational television. The former general manager of Channel 13 said he saw no signs indicating that educational television in its current framework could meet the massive financial challenges before it.

HOUSTON, June 2 -- For the first time a modernistic glass and concrete building here is being used for control of a manned space flight. It has already been nicknamed "earth control" in anticipation of flights to the moon and beyond.

Dennis King, an actor for almost half a century, is the new president of The Players, whose members represent a cross-section of the arts, it was announced yesterday. He succeeded Howard Lindsay, playwright who resigned after serving 10 years.

In your May 24 editorial "Project Headstart" you use such phrases as "dangerous trend," "neither educational quality nor constitutional principles are properly protected," "unmistakable inroads on vital separation of church and state," and you close by saying "the constitutionality of Project Headstart's proposed operation should be tested in the courts."
A profitable "peace" plan was unfolded yesterday by the country's airlines to placate travel agents in the wake of their opposition last week to proposed changes in their commissions.
