A profitable "peace" plan was unfolded yesterday by the country's airlines to placate travel agents in the wake of their opposition last week to proposed changes in their commissions.
The Beaunit Corporation reported yesterday a 19 per cent increase in earnings in the fiscal year ended March 31 over a year earlier. Sales gained 11 per cent in the same period.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 2 -- Gemini 4, ready to begin a four-day orbital flight tomorrow, will bring back from space next Monday a wealth of scientific information about the effects of space itself on man, about space itself and about the earth below.

New York City's hospital and ambulance service was assailed yesterday as "a gamble with death." A 27-page report issued by the New York Young Republican Club described conditions at six of them as "intolerable."

ALBANY, June 2 -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz disclosed today that he had warned Governor Rockefeller there was "a serious question concerning the constitutionality" of the textbook bill the Governor signed yesterday.

HAVANA, June 2 -- Pizza, Cuban-style, is a culinary revolution within a Communist one. It betrays a quest for sophistication in a Marxist-Leninist society and shows up the shortcomings in the service sector of the economy.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Deep divisions within the Republican party on voting rights legislation were disclosed today in the House Judiciary Committee's report on its pending bill.
Robert Lowell, the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, yesterday rejected an invitation to appear at a White House arts festival because of his "dismay and distrust" of American foreign policy.

MANNEQUINS parading before a backdrop of the board carrying stock market quotations celebrated a new fashion alliance yesterday. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, the giant brokerage house, co-sponsored the showing of the lively Robert Sloan Sportswear collection for fall at the Plaza hotel.
ALBANY, June 3 -- A proposal that would restrict the authority of the Mayor of New York to appoint judges appeared today to be doomed for this session of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce today opposed repeal of Section 14(b) of the Taft- Hartley Act.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 3 -- A series of drastic measures aimed at halting the deterioration of this country's economy is being prepared by President Guillermo Leon Valencia and top monetary aides, according to sources close to the beleaguered executive.
LONDON, June 4 -- The British press was unanimous in its acclaim today for the successful "walk in space" by Maj. Edward H. White 2d.

THE co-pilot of the Gemini 4 spacecraft, Maj. Edward Higgins White 2d, was recently described as a man who, when asked an intelligent question; will answer thoughtfully and to the point, but will rarely volunteer information.

Loans to business at the 14 weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York City dropped $42 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a drop of $98 million in the week a year ago.
Japan's largest automotive producer, the Toyota Motor Company, yesterday introduced an economy priced car here to compete in the Volkswagen price field.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The new coinage announced by President Johnson today was the result of a race against time, with science, industry and Government striving to resolve the coinage problem before the Treasury ran out of silver.

ALBANY, June 3 -- The Legislature cleared the way late today for action on two major proposals -- a bill to raise the drinking age to 21 and a resolution to start legal machinery that could lead to a statewide lottery.
TEANECK, N.J., June 3 -- It may be more blessed to give than to receive, but a lot of people in Bergen County have found that it's a lot of trouble.
CHICAGO, June 3 -- President Johnson issued an unusually strong and direct appeal to the people of the Soviet Union tonight to seek new initiatives for world peace.

FOR the amusement of children and also those adults who are interested in theatrical gadgetry, especially the techniques of combining live actors and motion pictures in a hybrid entertainment form, there is a new show in the Travel and Transportation Building at the World's Fair.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Consumer installment credit outstanding increased by $744 million in April -- a rise that was a record in dollar amount. Although not in percentage.

THE command pilot of the Gemini 4 spacecraft, Maj. James Alton McDivitt, keeps his space role in perspective by recalling the words of his older son back in 1962, when he first told the family that he had been selected to be an astronaut.
WHILE 16 teams are battling for survival in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championships at the New York Hilton Hotel tonight, play will go on in many of the Eastern Regionals one-session events.
HOUSTON, June 3 (AP) -- All 29 astronauts except Navy Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter were involved in today's launching of Gemini 4 with Majors James A. McDivitt and Edward H. White 2d aboard.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- Ron Fairly's two-run homer off Barney Schultz in the eighth inning tonight gave the Los Angeles Dodgers an 11-10 victory over the slumping St. Louis Cardinals in a game that featured 29 hits, 11 for extra bases.
Shares on the American Stock Exchange staged a comeback yesterday morning but then fell at the close of trading for the third consecutive day.

The new Indonesian freighter Johannes Latuharhary, which has been running into legal troubles since she arrived in this country with cargo early last month, is now in Boston following the posting of a $2 million bond to free her from a court attachment in Port Newark.

In one of the biggest trading days this year, contracts for silver futures covering more than 2.5 million ounces changed hands yesterday on sharply declining prices. The activity followed a message by President Johnson.
STUTTGART, Germany, June 1 -- There are three very positive things to report about John Cranko's new full-evening ballet "Onegin," given here tonight as part of the Stuttgart Ballet Festival.

The Eastern railroads, which for more than a dozen years have been fighting for a larger share of the receipts on traffic moving from the Eastern Seaboard through Chicago and St. Louis to the West Coast, finally reached an agreement yesterday with three big Western roads.

The Radio Corporation of America challenged the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the field of Transatlantic satellite communications yesterday by filing for authority ot lease 30 channels on the Early Bird satellite.
DALLAS, June 3 -- Robert Anderson's new play, "The Days Between," is a lot better than most of the stuff introduced on Broadway during the last season.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
ALBANY, June 3 -- The cost to state and local authorities of combating crime has increased by one-third since 1961-62, according to a study made public today by Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The day after William McChesney Martin, Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said in New York this week that he saw a series of "disquieting similarities between our present prosperity and the fabulous twenties," he had lunch with Secretary of the Treasury Fowler and Secretary of Commerce Connor at the Treasury Department.

PARIS -- A fascinating Soviet philosophical revolution has just taken place with minimum public notice. This is symbolized by the demotion of T.D. Lysenko, a biologist who succeeded in attracting the support of both Stalin and Khrushchev to his strange theories of genetics.
WHITE PLAINS, June 3 -- A rabbi scanned an audience of 4,000 from the speaker's stand in the County Center tonight and voiced belief that a Kremlin agent was undoubtedly covering his speech.
Urban renewal is a small-town project rather than a big-city program, according to a survey by the National Association of Home Builders.
ALBANY, June 3 -- The Assembly voted approval today of a complete revision of the Penal Law, which lawyers agree has become a bewildering morass since its last major overhaul in 1881.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee put off today a decision on President Johnson's request for $89 million for a stepped-up program of economic and social improvement in Southeast Asia.

BONN, June 3 -- Charges against former West German Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss and two of his former aides were dropped today by the state attorney in Bonn. The charges had said that the men had illegally arrested members of the staff of Der Spiegel on suspicion of espionage.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 3 -- The Brazilian Government began today to encourage sales and production after deciding it had restricted credit as much as was advisable in its program to curb inflation.

Theater grants, totaling $338,022, have been made by the Rockefeller Foundation. The University of Minnesota received $116,522, a combined project of the Carnegie Institute of Technology and the Pittsburgh Playhouse $115,000, and the Arena Stage of Washington $106,500.

Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz will be arraigned on the conspiracy indictment against him before the July 6 date set for the arraignment, according to his lawyer, Matthew H. Brandenburg. The date was set Wednesday in the Sullivan County Courthouse in Monticello.
CINCINNATI, June 3 (UPI) -- Rusty Staub hit a three-run homer and Ron Brand and Bob Lillis had three hits each to lead the Houston Astros to an 8-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

Proposals to transfer the Cooper Union Museum to the Smithsonian Institution, if the museum's collections are kept in New York, were discussed here yesterday by representatives of Cooper Union and the national museum.
The stock market took another wide swing yesterday, opening strong and ending with losses for the third day in a row.

NESCO, N.J., June 3 -- Ernest E. Lawton is a dirt farmer in coastal New Jersey. The economic statistics in his life are simple: Last year he farmed his 20 acres of sweet potatoes and strawberries and made $2,500 to support himself and his wife.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Two hundred young men, 16 to 21, left poverty-level homes in a dozen states today and headed for a Job Corps training center in Texas.

MANCHESTER, England, June 3 (UPI) -- The Wimbledon champion, Maria Bueno of Brazil, romped to a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Rita Bentley of Britain today in the quarter-finals of the Northern lawn tennis championships.

David A. (Sonny) Werblin, the president of the New York jets, confirmed his resolve yesterday to forbid new Jet players from performing in two all-star games this summer. Werblin went on to admit that his position threatens the continuance of these games.
The Sperry Rand Corporation, producer of business machines and navigational instruments, announced yesterday the election of Robert E. Slater and Carl A. Frische as directors.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 3 --The director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has rejected a State Departmerit request to rescind its plans to expel speeding foreign diplomats from the turnpike.

The national economy is beginning to pay the uncomfortable price of the Administration's failure to defend its wage-price guideposts in the Big Three automobile agreements last fall. The auto companies, with profits so large they should have been reflected in price cuts to car buyers, chose instead to enter into union contracts that ran well above the standards the White House had set for guarding against a new inflationary spiral.

WHITE PLAINS, June 3 -- Carl Spad, the Republican State Chairman, warned the once all-powerful Republicans in New York City's suburbs today that they must change their ways if they don't want to become part of "a permanent political minority."

A decline of 2,248,000 barrels in the country's gasoline supplies in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend total supplies were 212,504,000 barrels, compared with 214,752,000 in the preceding week and 208,852,000 a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended May 29 was considerably above the volume in the corresponding week of 1964.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Kuwait Ambassador and his wife were tied up and robbed in their residence early today by three men.
THEY wear life preservers and fiber-glass helmets, compete in a kneeling or sitting. position and never insist on egg in their boating beer. All they demand is plenty of foam.
LONDON, June 3 -- Britain cut the bank rate today to 6 per cent from 7 per cent.
The nation's electric power production rose 11.4 per cent in the week ended May 29 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

NEWARK, June 3 -- The 25th anniversary of Archbishop Thomas A. Boland's elevation to the Roman Catholic hierarchy was celebrated here today with a solemn pontifical mass in the Sacred Heart Cathedral.
LONDON, June 4, Friday (Reuters) -- The state-owned British European Airways warned today that it would not buy British airliners unless they competed in price and quality with American planes.
A leading travel agent scored as "ridiculous" yesterday the domestic airlines' statement on Wednesday the proposed changes in commissions would increase agents' income by as much as 20 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3 -- The 114-member Disarmament Commission was asked today to propose a world disarmament conference that would include Communist China. The commission also was asked to call for a speedy renewal of negotiations by the 18-nation Geneva Disarmament Conference.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., reported yesterday a 32.5 per cent increase in earnings in the 13 weeks ended May 1 on a sales gain of 5.6 per cent. The report, which covers the third fiscal quarter of the 48-store nationwide retail chain, will be mailed to some 21,000 stockholders.
United States Government securities prices strengthened yesterday following the reduction in the British bank rate to 6 per cent from 7 per cent.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 3 (AP) -- Unbeaten Camilo Pascual, supported by Bob Allison's two-run homer, registered his seventh straight victory today as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4-3.
ALBANY, June 3 (UPI) -- The Senate began action today to extend pay to employes of the Legislature who have been drawn-out session.

An IND subway motorman was pinned for more than seven hours in his cab after his train hit a layup track bumper in Brooklyn last night. Rescue workers were continuing their efforts to free him early this morning.
HAVANA, June 3 -- Premier Fidel Castro and Italian Communist leaders are holding formal talks "in a brotherly spirit of frank comradeship," it was announced today.
President Johnson appealed last night for amelioration of the situation of Soviet Jews as a step toward the relaxation of tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union.

The air was brisk enough last night, and the women turned up in their mink stoles, but for Philharmonic Hall it was strictly summer dress as the third season of the New York Philharmonic "Promenades" got under way.

The beautiful brunette in a low-cut jersey blouse smiled appealingly as the highway patrolman walked up to the door of her white convertible. The officer relaxed his guard and at that moment a gunman sprang from concealment in the back seat and fired three shots point blank.
ALBANY, June 3 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed today changes in state laws on public health, social welfare and insurance that affect hospitals and hospitalization plans.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that its board of governors had voted to suspend trading in the class A common stock and the 4 1/4 per cent convertible debentures of Yale Express System, Inc., effective at the market opening June 14.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Twenty-eight Democratic Representatives joined today in a request for public hearings in the House on the Administration's Vietnam policy.
MOSCOW, June 3 -- Two Soviet economists charged today that industrial reforms based on consumer demand were being hampered by bureaucracy and by the dead weight of the past.
OTTAWA, June 3 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson announced today that Canada would insist that all future uranium exports be used only for peaceful purposes.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 3 -- Premier Chou En-lai said here today that friendly relations between Pakistan and Communist China had been developing "with each passing day," particularly since President Mohammad Ayub Khan took power in October, 1958.
The first official Roman Catholic observer to attend a meeting of the National Council of Churches received a standing ovation yesterday at the council's general board meet-in Riverside Church.
The reduction in the British bank rate yesterday caused a modest rise in bond prices here.
The space flight of the United States astronauts, Maj. Edward H. White 2d and Maj. James McDivitt was reported to the Soviet Union yesterday in Russian and 16 other languages by Radio Liberty.

PARIS, June 3 -- Prosperous but worried coin traders from 16 countries opened today their first international congress to combat counterfeiting. One of them promptly assailed the host government, France.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Johnson asked Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach today for an opinion on the right of Congress to divest Sargent Shriver of one of his two Government positions.
The British pound tossed and turned yesterday on the foreign exchange market here but closed unchanged.

TOKYO, June 3 -- Premier Eisaku Sate appointed a new 18-member Cabinet today. The emphasis in his selections was on men experienced in economic affairs and on the fielding of a strong Government team in the election to the upper house of the national Diet (Parliament) a month from now.
HOUSTON, June 3 -- As Maj. Edward H. White 2d maneuvered outside his Gemini 4 capsule today, 300 men in a vital command post here followed every move.
The London Stock Exchange showed little response yesterday to the reduction of Britain's bank rate and prices generally continued to ease.

President Johnson's coinage proposal is a compromise that has not produced a consensus. Miners and industrial users of silver reacted to the plan yesterday in direct relation to the degree to which they were affected.

JITTERY and awestruck by the magnitude of the occasion, Jim Ryun, a 17-year-old schoolboy from Kansas, ran poorly in the 1,500-meter event at the Olympic Games in Tokyo last October and suffered an early elimination from the competition. Neither jittery nor awestruck was Peter Snell of New Zealand, already the successful defender of the 800-meter crown he had won at Rome four years earlier.
Stevedores in the port of New York were urged yesterday to achieve a 30 per cent reduction in accident rates by 1970.
Former President Romulo Betancourt of Venezuela scored the United States last night for its unilateral armed intervention in the Dominican Republic.
Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany made a plea yesterday before 635 businessmen, industrialists and bankers here for a reconciliation between the United States and French Governments.

Richard Szaro, a 17-year-old St. Francis Prep sophomore, threw the javelin 192 feet 3 3/4 inches yesterday for a meet record in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championships at Randalls Island.

Murray Rossant of your editorial board, writing on the "Seeds of Monetary Crisis" May 17, gave quite comprehensive coverage to the problem, and his points are well taken, especially on the shortcomings of present and past official action.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 3 -- The Gemini 4 spacecraft was carrying today only half the maneuvering fuel it had been designed to carry because it had been thought the full amount would not be needed.
Mayor Wagner hinted yesterday that his decision on whether to seek a fourth term might be made his weekend.

HALE CENTER, Tex., June 3 (AP) -- The south plains of Texas counted property damage in millions and three deaths today from a tornado that cut a wide path of destruction. About 100 persons were injured.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Johnson joined millions of Americans this morning in observing the liftoff of Gemini 4.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, June 3 -- The Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation are both completing major expansions of their manufacturing facilities in this coastal city, which calls itself "the Detroit of South Africa."

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 3 -- Robert Bird's rapid-fire auctioneer's chant started the season's first vine-ripened Long Island strawberries to short-cake-hungry consumers today from the Riverhead auction block.
The current drought is a "blessing in disguise," a Westchester official declared yesterday.

Benjamin Abrams, a pioneer in the radio, television and phonograph industry, confirmed yesterday family plans for tendering the bulk of the family stock in the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, to the National Union Electric Company. Trading in Emerson Radio stock had been halted Wednesday afternoon in anticipation of an announcement from Mr. Abrams.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 3 -- Bolivia's military junta is pressing for wide economic and military help from the United States to complement its measures to reorganize the nationalized mining industry and overcome a violent, Communist-dominated strike.

S. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, June 3 (UP) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said today that a strong, new trend had developed among young people who want to improve society. "They believe progress begins at home," she said.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- Questions about sex attitudes, religion and family life have been eliminated from examinations for persons seeking a Government job, it was announced today.
The American Shakespeare Guilds of Greenwich and Westport, Conn., will give a two-part tour of homes and gardens for the benefit of the American Shakespeare Festival Theater at Stratford, Conn.

CAIRO, June 3 (AP) -- Premier Chou En-Lai of Communist China was quoted by a weekly magazine today as having said that a "world war could not erupt because of the war in Vietnam, or even if Red China itself were attacked by the United States."
BROADCASTING'S coverage of the walk in space of Maj. Edward H. White 2d was a tantalizing emotional experience for the television viewer and radio listener.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 3 -- Degrees were awarded to 522 undergraduates and 390 graduate students at Adelphi University's 69th annual commencement on the campus here today.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 3 -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that he would like to see Representative John V. Lindsay heading a local government "coalition similar to La Guardia's."

Maurice G. Read of Berkeley, Calif., president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, will head a delegation of 104 members of the American chapter, International Real Estate Federation, to the federation's world congress in Brussels from June 11 to 16.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to approve the first major change in United States coinage since 1792.
Pete Rozelle, the Commissioner of the National Football League, recommended to his club owners yesterday that there present 14-team league expand to 16 teams for the 1967 season.

NAPLES, Italy, June 3 (AP) -- An Italian Navy boat, Grifone, sailed by Agostino Straulino, won the fourth race in the world 5.5-Meter Class yachting championship today. However, the American sloop Composition moved into the over-all lead.
More than $40 million of municipal bonds were sold to underwriters yesterday in a total of seven issues.
NEW DELHI, June 3 -- India's quest for a hoard of "black money" has produced only a comparative trickle of silver.
The duties of chief executive officer of Heublein, Inc., were transferred yesterday to Ralph A. Hart, the president, from John G. Martin, the chairman.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 3 -- Colonel Caamano Deno's rebels were critical today of a new United States proposal to find a solution to the Dominican crisis through supervised elections.
The critical item in making possible the transcontinental excursion of Maj. Edward H. White 2d into space from his spaceship was the special protective suit he wore.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals today ordered the Civil Aeronautics Board to reconsider the trans-Pacific route case and determine whether Western Airlines should be given authority for California-to-Honolulu flights.

Presiding Justice George J. Beldock of the Appellate Division ordered a Supreme Court justice yesterday to explain why he thinks George Whitmore Jr. must be retried for murder before facing a second trial on an attempted rape charge.
LONDON, June 3 -- Britain has urged the Soviet Union several times in recent months to join in reconvening the 1954 Geneva conference on Vietnam, but the replies have been uniformly negative.
PARIS, June 3 -- Gaston Defferre, the Socialist candidate for the French Presidency, pleaded with his party today to join other left and center forces in a federation as the only way back to power.
BOGALUSA, La., June 3 -- Washington Parish's first two Negro sheriff's deputies were ambushed and one was killed last night, increasing tensions in this racial trouble spot.

The Procter Gamble Company said yesterday it would increase prices of refined glycerin by half a cent a pound, effective July 1, following the lead of other producers. The increase will affect all grades and quantities.
At change-of-command ceremonies today Capt. Joseph Mazzotta %vill relieve Capt. Ross P. Bullard as Coast Guard Captain of the Port of New York and as Commander, Coast Guard Group New York.

WHITE PLAINS, June 3 -- Westchester opened today, for emergency use in wartime, an underground civil defense center and county government headquarters. The rooms are two floors beneath the nine-story County Office Building.

" I would like to make myself a suit for fall," Mrs. Jones said to her friend, "but when I think of having to sew the lining in, I get scared." Mrs. Jones apparently has not heard of the new bonded fabrics that combine the out er fabric and its lining, and which are now available from Sears, Roebuck Co., Macy's, Gimbel's and other stores.
LOS ANGELES, June 3 -- An unusual theatrical experiment that has gained national attention faces extinction here at the time when it appeared to be at the height of its success.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Representatives of 19 nations both developed and underdeveloped, indicated today that they were willing to contribute $173 million toward the financing of a broad economic development plan in Ecuador.

LONDON, June 3 -- Britain's National Gallery today defended the authenticity of its Goya portrait of the Duke of Wellington. "Questions raised regarding the duke's medals," the gallery said, "have no relevance to the picture's authorship."

MILWAUKEE, June 3 (UPI) -- Eddie Mathews's two-run home run, his 11th of the year, capped a nine-run third inning that powered the Milwaukee Braves and Ken Johnson to a 10-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight.

MANCHESTER, England, June 3 (UPI) -- Larry Kristoff, a heavyweight from Carbondale, Ill., was the only medal winner for the United States in the world amateur free-style wrestling championships that ended tonight. Iran captured team honors.
In your May 6 editorial [International Edition May 7] you analyze the reasons which impelled Cambodia to sever diplomatic relations with the United States.
Two young women were raped in Queens Wednesday night and early yesterday in the third and fourth such incidents in that borough in just over a week.

The Puritan Fashions Corporation, one of the largest companies in the apparel industry, will spend close to $1 million to attract customers ranging from teen-agers to 25-year-olds this fall to an array of English Mod apparel.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 3 (AP) -- Major White's father said today that his son must have had the "time of his life" as he floated in space.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 -- Two ambushes by the Vietcong 50 miles southeast of Pleiku wiped out another South Vietnamese Army battalion today. The setback raised Government losses in ambushes to 1,000 men during the last week.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Friday, June 4 (Reuters) -- United States Marines early today repulsed a fierce Vietcong attack on two key bridges six miles from the huge air base here in the marines' hottest engagement since they arrived in Vietnam 10 weeks ago.
BERLIN, June 3 (UPI) -- An East German spokesman denounced today the United States military liaison mission in Potsdam as an unnecessary holdover of the postwar occupation.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Senate consented tonight to the ratification of two amendments to the United Nations Charter. The amendments would increase the membership of the Security Council and the Economic and Social Council.
What loomed as a match race between Tom Rolfe and Dapper Dan a couple of weeks ago has burgeoned into a seven-horse contest as the field for the Belmont Stakes assumed definitive shape yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House Government Operations Committee warned today in a lengthy report on space programs of a military lag in space technology.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 3 -- Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore denied today that he had advocated partitioning Malaysia if the country's large ethnic Chinese population was not allowed to hare in its "ownership."

MILWAUKEE, June 3 -- Five civil rights demonstrators were arrested here today as protests of a school busing policy continued. The five, all women, had sat down and formed a human chain in front of a school bus at the 20th Street School.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 3 -- Vice President Oginga Odinga was withdrawn today from Kenya's delegation to the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference in London later this month. He was to have led the delegation, which will be headed by the External Affairs Minister, Joseph Murumbi.
General Mills, Inc., the largest miller of flour in the United States, will close nine of its 17 flour mills, it was announced yesterday by its president, Gen. E.W. Rawlings, retired.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3 -- The United States made public today its rejection of a series of Soviet complaints concerning a plaque on the wall of Congregation Zichron Ephraim, a synagogue facing the Soviet Mission at 136 East 67th Street.
A classic case of self-entrapment may result from the current campaign by labor lobbyists in Albany to kill the Condon-Wadlin Act outlawing strikes by state and municipal employes.

DEVON. Pa., June 3 -- Kathy Kusner continued her perfect record in the open jumper division of the Devon Horse Show tonight when she piloted Untouchable to victory in the puissance (high jumping) class.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- Ranking Republican members of the Senate and House Joint Economic Committee called today for early hearings on Federal Reserve Chairman William McChesney Martin's recent warning of "disquieting similarities" between the present boom and that of the 1920's.
A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that a $375,000 bequest to aid needy Jewish students could not be used toward the construction of a library for Yeshiva University.
The New York Board of Trade, a group that almost always has its mind on business, gave itself a cultural luncheon yesterday and promised that it would become a habit.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Retail sales in the United States for the week ended May 29 climbed 5 per cent above the level of the previous week and were up 10 per cent from the corresponding week of 1964, the Commerce Department said today.
John O. Green Jr. has been elected secretary Of Richardson-Merrell, Inc. He was formerly assistant secretary and assistant general counsel.

The Electro-Motive division of the General Motors Corporation, which has supplied American railroads with more than 23,000 diesel locomotives since 1938, or about 80 per cent to 85 per cent of the carriers' total fleet, announced yesterday a complete new line of the power units.
SEABROOK, Tex., June 3 (UPI) -- Pat White chewed on a pencil today while her husband, Maj. Edward H. White 2d, floated around in space outside the Gemini 4 capsule.

Dr. Ray E. Trussell, for more than four years the city's Commissioner of Hospitals, will resume his post as director of the Columbia University School of Public Health and Administrative Medicine on July 1.

LIMA, Peru, June 3 (AP) -- Four American Peace Corps volunteers who have been teaching at the National University of Engineering have been expelled from the faculty because of United States intervention in the Dominican Republic, the newspaper La Prensa said today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- A National Science Foundation official said today that Federal funds might have intensified but did not cause a concentration of scientific work in a few universities and research centers.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Johnson announced today that the nation's unemployment rate fell in May to 4.6 per cent, the lowest level since October, 1957, when the rate was 4.5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The assets of all pension funds, Government and private, reached $147.1 billion at the end of last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Manufacturing Chemists' Association, Inc., predicted yesterday that the chemical industry would set new production and sales records in 1965.

Andrew Jackson High of Queens and Boys High of Brooklyn had been expected to wage a close battle for the team title in the 61st annual Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships. It couldn't have bee closer after yesterday's 11 events in the first day of the two-day meet as they found themselves in a tie for first.
GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 3 -- Steve Spray, a 24-year-old rookie professional who has yet to win a dollar on the golf pro tour, was the surprising leader today in the $100,000 Buick Open.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 -- The Mets, of all people, put an end to the Pittsburgh Pirates' 12-game winning streak tonight, but not before they started acting like their old selves and nearly lost control of the situation.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 3 -- The 14th running of the Tyro Stakes for 2-year-olds at 5 1/2 furlongs will mark the opening of the 56-day thoroughbred meeting at Monmouth Park today.
The two daughters of an investment broker and his former wife were awarded by the Appellate Division to their father yesterday because it was "part of their birthright" to be reared in this country.
The Wagner administration got help from two unexpected quarters yesterday in its drive to pass its record city budget by next Wednesday's deadline.

Britons, long known as masters of understatement and the soft sell, are being urged more and more to blow their own horns -- and louder -- in the advertising and promotion of British-made goods in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- There was an urgent matter involving the possibility of a cutoff of Federal funds to 14 state-supported colleges in Alabama today, but an official in the Office of Education could not reach anyone at the state Capitol in Montgomery by telephone.
Indian Head Mills, Inc., has signed an agreement to acquire all the stock of Fenimore Fabrics, Inc., in exchange for 50,417 shares of Indian Head Mills common stock, it was announced yesterday.
Tentative plans for dividing the city school system into 30 "more manageable" local school districts were made public yesterday by Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Acting Superintendent of Schools.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- United States and Latin-American diplomats believe that a "third force" is emerging in the Dominican Republic that could provide the impetus and the nucleus for an interim government.
BALTIMORE, June 3 -- Striking members of the American Newspaper Guild voted overwhelmingly today to end their seven-week walkout at The Baltimore Sunpapers.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange Inc., announced yesterday its board of managers had reinstated the personal membership of Dominick R. Comenzo. Mr. Comenzo and his company had been suspended in December, 1963, in the wake of the salad-oil scandal involving Anthony DeAngelis.

The Columbia Broadcasting System and Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts have terminated the contract under which C.B.S. was to televise a "Lincoln Center Day" anniversary program each September through 1967.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., June 3 -- David Hoffman of the home club, a 55-year-old chemican engineer, won the state amateur handicap golf championship today with a net 89-19 -- 68 at the Shackamaxon Country Club.
On the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange, brokers like to keep their eyes on several bellwether issues in order to judge the tone of the general market.
BUCHAREST, June 3 -- The Rumanian Workers party disclosed plans today to change its name to the Rumanian Communist party.

Twenty writers and artists, including six Pulitzer Prize-winning poets, voiced support yesterday of Robert Lowell, the poet, for rejecting an invitation to a White House arts festival because he objected to United States foreign policy.

Sales and profits of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the fiscal second quarter and half-year period ended April 30 were the highest in its 65-year history. Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman and Earl B. Hathaway, president, issued the report in Akron, Ohio yesterday.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 3 -- This snug little haven on the east coast of Africa has been made festive for the arrival tomorrow of Premier Chou En-lai.
Workmen began installing an acoustical shell at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday for the Metropolitan Opera's first season of outdoor concerts. The seven-week series is to begin on June 21.
VANCOUVER, B.C., June 3 (Canadian Press) -- Premier W.A.C. Bennett has announced that Japan will invest hundreds of millions of dollars in British Columbia.
JACKSON, Mich., June 3 (AP) -- "Buck Rogers is getting that ride now . . . I'm in orbit, too," the mother of Major McDivitt said today as the Gemini 4 spacecraft was circling the earth.
ANNAPOLIS, June 3 (AP) -- George A. Kent of Ithaca, N.Y., son of a Cornell university professor, will graduate first in the Naval Academy's class of some 800 midshipmen next Wednesday.
ALBANY, June 3 -- The Senate voted overwhelmingly late today to strengthen the legislative code of ethics after engaging in the longest and one of the most vigorous debates of the session.

A tie-up of the United States merchant fleet on June 15 is a "foregone conclusion" despite an offer by six maritime unions to declare a 60-day "no-strike" moratorium after their contracts expire, industry spokesmen reported yesterday.
Sister Anthony Joseph, administrator of St. Francis Hospital in the south Bronx, sadly discussed plans to close the institution with an aide yesterday.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 3 (AP) -- Speedy Scot won the $25,000 Marquis de Lafayette Trot at Brandywine Raceway tonight in a three-horse photo finish with Su Mac Lad and Big John.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois attempted today to smooth an apparent rift with House Republican leaders.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3 -- The Soviet Union today attacked the creation of the inter-American peace force for the Dominican Republic. It charged that such a force was a cover-up for the threat of United States' intervention elsewhere in Latin America.

LELAND, Miss., June 3 -- The Cotton Belt's first plantation strike since the nineteen-thirties ran into stiff resistance today. The strikers, all Negroes, were evicted from their homes on the plantation and replaced in the fields.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today the only major change the Johnson Administration has sought in the House-passed bill for medical care for the aged under Social Security.

PARIS, June 3 -- The assembly of the Western European Union demanded unanimously today the establishment of permanent links between the European Free Trade Association and the European Economic Community.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 3 -- A not-too-easy victory in the $25,000 Bye Bye Byrd Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight enabled Cardigan Bay to make the winner's circle for the first time at the Nassau County harness racing plant.
DALLAS, June 3 -- The Southern Baptist Convention acknowledged today that its silence on race relations had created "stumbling blocks instead of stepping stones" toward a solution of the problem.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) Representative Adam Clayton Powell's charge that Federal antipoverty funds were being illegally used in New York, Chicago, Cleveland and other big cities was rejected today by Joseph Campbell, the Controller General.

Britain's account of its frustrating efforts to arrange conferences on Vietnam and Cambodia leaves little doubt that the route to peace in Southeast Asia is barred for the moment by the negative attitude of Moscow, as well as Hanoi and Peking.

BALTIMORE, June 3 (UPI) -- Joe Don Looney, the halfback who was the No. 1 draft choice of the New York Giants for 1964, today was traded by the Baltimore Colts along with an undisclosed draft choice to the Detroit Lions of the National Football League for Dennis Gaubatz, a linebacker.

MOBILE, Ala., June 3 (UPI) -- A three-judge Federal panel today ordered Dallas County authorities to dismiss charges, set aside convictions and pay back fines to 74 persons involved in civil rights arrests during a five-day period last summer.
Representative John V. Lindsay's announced determination to visit every neighborhood in the city took him into heavily Democratic Brooklyn yesterday.

CHELTENHAM, England, June 3 (UPI) -- Nell and Christine Truman of England scored straight-set victories in the Cheltenham lawn tennis championship today and joined Annette Van Zyl of South Africa and Elizabeth Starkie of Britain in the semi-finals.
LONDON, June 3 -- The story of Harold Pinter's play "The Homecoming," which opened tonight at the Aldwych Theater, is bizarre and disconcerting.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Defense Department announced today that a "small number" of Soviet jet bombers of an old type had been sighted near Hanoi, the capital of North Vietnam.
William F. Buckley Jr., editor of The National Review, a conservative magazine, is seriously considering running as the Conservative party candidate for Mayor, informed sources said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Air Force refused to comment today on charges by Capt. Edward Dwight Jr. that he had been subjected to racial discrimination in the service. The charges were made in an interview with the New York Times.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 3 -- Arthur Ashe of Richmond, Va., and Eugene Scott of St. James, L.I., Were named today to play the singles matches in the American Zone Davis Cup competition with Canada. They will oppose Keith Carpenter and Harry Fauquier, respectively, tomorrow at the Bakersfield Racquet Club.

BUENOS AIRES, June 3 -- Juan Ramon Vazquez, Under Secretary of Foreign Affairs, announced his resignation today. His move, seen as an indication of tension within the Administration of President Arturo Illia, is understood to have been made because he opposed the Government's neutral stand on the crisis in the Dominican Republic.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 3 (AP) -- Louis Meyer, the head of the Los Angeles company that makes the Offenhauser racing engine, said today that none of the famous old four-cylinder power plants would be built for the 1966 Memorial Day 500-mile race.

It would forbid lobbying in Albany by the Citizens Union, bar associations or any other civic agency that "grades or classifies" legislators or the judiciary. Such civic scorekeeping is a service performed annually for the benefit of the voters, but rarely appreciated by the men whose records are subjected to nonpartisan scrutiny.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 4 (AP) -- A story of public beheadings and of teen-age Congolese rebels shooting prisoners in the back was told today by a Norwegian Baptist missionary, freed after eight months captivity in the northern Congo.

GARY, Ind., June 4 -- Mayor A. Martin Katz and the United States Steel Corporation signed an air pollution control pact today outlining the company's intention of abating its pollution problems here.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Rail freight carloadings in the week ended May 29 were considerably above the corresponding week of 1964, which included the Memorial Day holiday. The total was the highest since the week ended last Nov. 14.

CLEVELAND, June 4 (AP) -- Joe Azcue drove in the tying and winning runs tonight with a pinch-single in the eighth inning as the Cleveland Indians beat the Detroit Tigers, 7-6.

The New York Rangers completed the third major National Hockey League trade in the last 10 days yesterday, a six-player transaction with the Chicago Black Hawks.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 4 -- Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration cautiously speculated here today on what might have gone wrong yesterday in the unsuccessful attempt of Gemini 4 spacecraft to rendezvous with its second-stage booster.

The 20-minute space feat of Maj. Edward H. White 2d will probably provide a strong argument for the "man-in-space" program and for increased emphasis on the military applications of space technology. Major White floated and maneuvered, with the aid of a small manually controlled gas-firing jet gun, outside the Gemini spacecraft to which he was tethered.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 4 -- Westminster Choir College awarded 58 bachelor degrees and two honorary doctorates at its 36th annual commencement this morning.
In the first week of a new Government program aimed at finding summer jobs for young people, more than 16,000 youths registered with the New York State Employment Service.
This spring, Vassar College has been saying goodby to Mrs. Agnes Rindge Claflin, a lively woman with bright blue eyes who has taught art history to two generations of students
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany threw the support of his Government today behind the efforts of the United States to resist Communist aggression in Vietnam.

Some 75 New York public school teachers gathered recently after their working day for their regular once-a-week lesson at the New York Stock Exchange. That day, instead of the usual classroom lectures, they toured the empty floors of the exchange and listened to talks about floor procedure.
The Bronx Post Office was criticized and defended yesterday when it became the focus of renewed political warfare between the two leading Democratic factions in the borough.

A 68-year-old man was found dead in his apartment in downtown Brooklyn yesterday surrounded by jars, cans, bottles and cartons containing the savings of a lifetime -- $13,000 in quarters, dimes and nickels.
DALLAS, June 4 -- A lanky, red-haired preacher from Jackson, Tenn., has been presiding in the old Baptist tradition over the 15,578 delegates to the annual meeting of the Southern Baptist Convention.
PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- The Mets ran their streak to four games tonight by winning in a most peculiar fashion -- for them.

MILWAUKEE, June 4 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews hammered a three-run homer in the ninth inning tonight -- his 12th of the season -- and brought the second-place Milwaukee Braves a 5-2 victory over the league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers.

A tactical patrol force unit assigned to a Bronx neighborhood, where crowds tried recently twice to take prisoners from policemen, headed off a third such attempt by the use of walkie-talkie radios last night.

LIMA, Peru, June 4 -- The national convention of the Accion Popular political party, of which Peruvian President Fernando Belaunde Terry is the founder and leader, approved unanimously yesterday a resolution for the immediate nationalization of the International Petroleum Company's La Brea and Parinas oilfields, refinery and other installations.

Doris Pines earned points for her piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall last night before she played a note. Programing Schumann's "Faschingsschwank aus Wien" was a master stroke calculated to win the good will of the most jaded listener.
MILWAUKEE, June 4 -- Five clergymen were arrested here today in another protest of a School Board policy on the transportation of Negro pupils.
Shabuoth, the Jewish commemoration of the giving of the Ten Commandments to Moses on Mount Sinai, will star at sundown today with observances in temples and synagogues.
Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's top merchandiser, reported yesterday gross sales in May of $559,226,341, an increase of $59,681,453, or 11.9 per cent, over the $499,544,888 volume in May, 1964.

Directors of the Equity Corporation, a closed-end, non-diversified investment company announced yesterday they had dismissed Walter C. Ivancevic, president, and Frederick W. Jaqua, vice president for legal affairs.
Gem Lucius D. Clay has been asked to fill the long-vacant post as national Republican finance chairman, informed sources disclosed last night. He has not yet Indicated whether he will do so.

Governor Rockefeller remains silent on whether he will sign the bill for a November referendum on the calling of a state constitutional convention. The bill was passed unanimously by the Senate, and there was only one dissenting vote in the Assembly.

KANSAS CITY, June 4 (UPI) -- Jim Gentile, who shared the American League lead today with 10 home runs for the season, was traded by the Kansas City Athletics to the Houston Astros for a minor league pitcher, Jesse Hickman, another player to be named later and $100,000.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP) -- Ron Brand slammed a three-run homer off Bob Gibson with two out in the ninth inning tonight, powering the Houston Astros to a 5-2 victory over the slumping St. Louis Cardinals.
DUNKIRK, France, June 4 -- The little ships that saved an army returned to Dunkirk today.
The New York Philharmonic, with Andre Kostelanetz conducting and Teresa Stratas, soprano, will give a "Promenade" concert in Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30.

Two Virginia businessmen returned home yesterday after a trip to Brooklyn where, they told the police, they lost $25,000 to confidence men in a swindle involving a mysterious money-making machine and a pair of spurious Secret Service agents.
EPSOM, England, June 4 (UPI) -- Long Look, an American-bred filly owned by James Cox Brady of New York, surged in the stretch to win the $100,520 Oaks by 1 1/2 lengths today.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 4 -- Dr. Fred Hoyle, the British astronomer, predicted here today that man would someday control enough energy to maneuver planets in their solar systems to suit his purposes.
Governor Rockefeller signed the last of three bills yesterday aimed at ending scalping and the blackmarket in the theater industry.
The American Stock Exchange staged a mild advance yesterday in quiet trading.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 4 -- The Junior League of Mount Kisco plans to hold its second debutante assembly Friday at the Whippoorwill Country Club in Armonk. Mrs. John B. Macreery of Granite Springs is chairman of the benefit for the league's community trust fund.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 4 -- More than 400 members of the Bond Club of New York came out to the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here today for their annual Field Day. They played golf, were entertained by comedian Jack E. Leonard, watched dancer Killer Joe Piro and escaped from such problems as how to sell the half-billion dollars of bonds coming to market next week.
